name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Hugues Bayet report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Council's proposed directive establishing rules to combat tax evasion practices that have a direct impact on the functioning of the market (COM(2016)0026 - C8-0031/2016 - 2016/0011 (CNS)) (A8-0189/2016).

name: Hugues Bayet
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, this week is an important step in the fight against tax fraud and evasion by multinationals, and I would really like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who helped me present this text here in plenary. I will not recall the stakes - everyone knows them, since the last financial scandals that mixed an industrial scale tax evasion, tax evasion and money laundering have erupted, whether in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, Switzerland or Panama, and this continues since, as recently as last Friday, France decided to sue "Booking.com" for tax evasion to the tune of 356 million. I would therefore like to reiterate today why this is a crucial step that we are taking here in the European Parliament. As you know, the European Parliament, since the media coverage of these scandals, has been one of the driving forces behind a fundamental reform of the taxation of multinationals in Europe. It is here that political awareness has taken shape, and it is here that the pressure has accumulated to push the Council and the Member States to realis that we no longer want this two-speed Europe where, on the one hand, the huge majority of citizens finance tax and, on the other hand, the most powerful multinationals in the world evade this tax. This way of analysing the situation is not ideology or political positioning, it is simply a question of wishing that everyone contributes in the same way to the financing of youth employment, health care, school, universities, housing or security.  (The President interrupts the speaker.) Multinationals cannot choose to escape the collective effort simply because they can afford financial or tax advisors whose sole mission is to imagine how to evade tax - the same financial/tax advisors whose remuneration is based on the amounts that are diverted from the tax base. This report is therefore the logical continuation of our work, since a comprehensive reflection on taxation has been initiated in Parliament, notably thanks to the special committees TAXE 1, TAXE 2 and the Commission of Inquiry on the Panama Papers, which will soon begin its work. The technical measures in this report therefore ensure that the gaps in our legislation are filled or that these dysfunctions are repaired. So let's get to the heart of the matter: what's in this report? First of all, the report provides that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits, and that is why it contains a whole series of precise and binding definitions of the conditions that attest that a multinational is well established in a country, since today, all too often, multinationals organize themselves to transfer their profits to tax havens without paying any taxes in the country where they really operate. Secondly, the report also provides for a strict and common blacklist of the 28 Member States of tax havens and countries that distort competition through favourable tax conditions, including those located in the EU. Clearly, it is a common definition of what a tax haven is. The report also provides for clarification of patent legislation, since so far too many multinationals are using patent incentives to artificially reduce the amount of their profits, whereas initially it was really a policy to help countries and companies that were truly innovative. The report also provides for an end to double non-taxation. Clearly, it is over for a multinational to be taxed anywhere because the legislation of the 28 is so complicated that some multinationals put in place tax arrangements that hide their profits and the actual amount of taxes paid. With regard to the switch-over clause and the rules on controlled foreign companies, this report calls for the debate on a fair tax rate between all Member States for corporation tax in the European Union, and this measure will allow all Member States to tax, at their national rates, the profits of multinationals that are not taxed or taxed at less than 15% in another country. Finally, the report proposes to effectively control loans between entities of the same multinational, since too often multinationals use this system of loans not to boost investment, but only to evade tax. These measures are not intended, as I have unfortunately heard, to kill the economy, but to effectively combat tax evasion and evasion by multinationals. This is another step in the process initiated by the European Parliament, and I think that is exactly what the European citizens expect from us here in Parliament.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted to be here today to discuss the proposed directive against tax evasion. Step by step, and, as we also see, debate after debate, we are moving towards a deeply renovated, more modern and also more ethical European tax landscape. I have already had the opportunity to present a proposal to you, so I will not go into more detail. I just want to remind you of what our political objective is - and I know how much it is shared by the European Parliament - which is to put an end, quite simply, to tax evasion in the European Union.  The current situation, in which some companies can avoid paying their fair share of taxes in the EU, is simply no longer sustainable. Like you, I was shocked by the new revelations in the press with the Panama Papers and, as you pointed out, the news offers us extensions every day. Like you, I know that the citizens of Europe have had enough and, like you, I feel the urgent need to act. That is why, from the beginning of its mandate, this Commission has constantly worked to reform the taxation of our companies and will work in this direction until the end of its mandate.  I now turn to Mr Bayet's report. This excellent report recognises the directive as a positive step in the fight against tax evasion, and I welcome that. I thank all those who have contributed to its drafting and, of course, I congratulate the rapporteur first. This report proposes a number of amendments. I go back briefly to some of them without being exhaustive. Firstly, to point out that, in many cases, the Commission is in complete agreement with the points suggested. Secondly, we believe that the objectives of some amendments would be better addressed in other initiatives or instruments. Many of them deal with issues covered by previous or lateral initiatives of the Commission. I will take two examples, if I may, Mr rapporteur.  The June 2015 action plan first confirmed that the Commission will provide Member States with guidance for adopting the so-called modified link approach to the patent-friendly tax regime system. He also indicated that transfer pricing rules needed to be adapted. The directive against tax evasion discussed this morning therefore does not appear to be the right legislative instrument to deal with these issues. At the time, the Commission chose to take a non-binding approach and this approach still seems sufficient to achieve our objectives. However, the Commission has made it clear, and I repeat here, that it could consider legislating on these issues, as you have suggested, if necessary but, again, within the framework of a legislative instrument that would be different from this directive. Second, you propose that the issue of tax havens be dealt with within the framework of this directive. Frankly, we do not think that is desirable, not that we do not want to fight tax havens; on the contrary, it is an indispensable political objective, and we obviously agree with you on the need to adopt extremely strong and determined additional measures to better combat tax havens. However, as you know, again, the Commission initially opted for a non-binding approach. The external strategy we have recently adopted has thus defined a common approach to assess, list and, if necessary, sanction third countries that refuse to apply internationally defined tax rules. We are working towards the establishment, in a timely manner, of a European blacklist of tax havens, which does not exist today and is in need, with common methods, common approaches and common sanctions. I also welcome the support given by The Member States to our blacklist proposal, with the selection of a first set of countries as early as this summer. Therefore, I join you in the objective, in the purpose, in the ambition and in the requirement. Again, I think this is an approach that needs to be disjointed or dealt with elsewhere or otherwise.  As you know, this text is being discussed in the Council. We had a first meeting at the last Ecofin Council, which allowed us to see both a number of points of agreement and to see where we still needed to make progress in reaching an agreement. On some points, the Council amended the proposal in the direction suggested by this House. I am thinking, for example, of removing public infrastructure projects from the interest limitation rule or introducing a definition of associated companies. The Commission approves these changes, which undoubtedly improve the proposal and are included in your report. Again, it is a guarantee of its quality.  I want to make my position very clear here: we need an agreement and we need it now. We must seize the opportunity of this Dutch Presidency, which has been ambitious in this area and which has been vigorous. We must also seize the political moment in which we are, in the shock wave of the Panama Papers, to conclude now. I do not want this debate to get sit down or take longer. The Member States are very close to an agreement, in truth.  I therefore welcome the timing of this debate, because I believe that it is an opportunity for Parliament to send a very clear and very strong message to the finance ministers of the 28 Member States. Always remember - but you are even better placed than I am to know this - that it is certainly the Commission that proposes and Parliament that legislates or co-manages, but that the Member States have decision-making power, also blocking, which must be revisited. The political pressure we are exerting together is extremely important in this regard.  The message you are sending, as I understand it, Mr rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, is that the rapid adoption of this directive, namely next week, in the framework of the Ecofin Council, to be held on 17 June in Luxembourg, is essential to better combat tax evasion. We have a kind of obligation to succeed. That is how I understand this report. Those are the main points I wanted to make today quickly to introduce our debate. Time does not allow me, in this introductory remark, to review each of the amendments contained in your report, but, of course, we will be able to discuss them in more detail in this debate, to which I am ready as always, with the conviction that the Commission and the European Parliament are, in this fight against tax evasion, partners who share the same purpose and the same will.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all this is the second step in the European effort to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance and let me appreciate the quality and speed of the Commission proposal. At the same time, let me say that I fully understand the difficulties in the Council in finding agreement on the directive. Nevertheless I would very much appreciate it if the Council pays a little bit more attention to Parliament’s position as I believe it can significantly improve the quality. Let me therefore send this message to Council members regardless of their not very strong presence.  Let me first give some overall remarks. This is an anti-BEPS directive that is focused on tax evasion and tax avoidance. We must be aware of the risk that efforts to make it stronger at any cost can change it from an anti-BEPS directive to an anti-business directive. So we must be sensitive to the fact that most firms do pay taxes fairly, and by economic activity, by employment, they are contributing to the prosperity of our society. We should also bear in mind that the administrative burden for SMEs is quite serious so we must always consider the pros and cons of tightening the directive. Second, let me say that we should not forget that this is just the beginning. There are more proposals that should come, and CCCTB especially is the key. On a substantive issue, one of the proposals focuses on making a distinction between genuine economic activity and activities used for tax avoidance, things like income from active business, tangible assets and so on should, in my opinion, be incorporated. Also some rules should be extended. Hybrid mismatches should be applicable not only within the Union, but also outside the Union, and I also believe that a nominal limit in the interest limitation rule can be increased without harming the fight against tax evasion. Let me conclude by saying that I believe we will approve it very soon and it will significantly contribute to improvement in this area and the opinion of Parliament will be taken into account.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Bayet, rapporteur of this important text, when things move forward, we must acknowledge that they are moving forward. And, unquestionably, in the area of taxation, in recent months we still have this feeling that the European Union is moving forward.  It is making small steps, it is moving forward under duress, because it is obviously in the wake of scandals, revelations, and thanks to tremendous pressure from public opinion, European citizens, but also to an undeniable determination of MEPs that we now have to discuss a quality text that makes a number of proposals going in the right direction.  It is an ambitious text and it gives - especially at this very moment when people doubt the merits of European integration, where citizens are asking questions, where they are constantly expressing their circumspection, their disappointment, sometimes even their anger - the opportunity to prove with texts of this nature that Europe knows how to be ambitious , that Europe knows how to move forward, and that the European Parliament can find itself, right and left, on important texts. I congratulate the Committee on Economic Affairs and, of course, rapporteur Bayet for presenting a text in one block which, nevertheless, lays the foundations for important and progressive legislation.  First, this reform contains major progress in our tax regulations. It allows us to more accurately track the flow of profits coming in or out of the Eu- - both ways - and to ensure that they are taxed fairly. With regard to the incomes of companies returning to Europe, the so-called 'switch-over' clause, which ensures that inflows into the Union have been taxed at a rate that is not unfair, has been intelligently supplemented by our rapporteur Bayet in order to apply a common criterion throughout the European Union. That has been said, it is very important. Secondly, for flows coming out of Europe, the tax measure on the exit of profits that leave the Union completes the scheme. It has long been forgotten, by focusing on double taxation, that there is also a massive double non-taxation, and the Bayet report responds to it. Finally, and this seems very clear to me - the rapporteur and the Commissioner have insisted on this point - this text has been enriched by definitions that are at once simple, clear and understandable; this is particularly the case for "stable establishment". Why is this important? The rapporteur alluded to that at the time. We have a scandal in France with Booking.com, it is 300 million euros that are exempt from tax - I finish, Madam President - and for that reason, the text goes in the right direction. Of course, this is only the beginning, of course, the Council is not convinced, but we are on the right track.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – About a year ago, we also sat here together in the European Parliament to talk about private investment: how can we attract more private investment in the European Union with the EfSI Juncker Plan? I looked it up, Mr Bayet, rapporteur of the report we are discussing today and a member of the Parti Socialiste, also spoke in the debate. And I can agree 100% of what he said at the time, which is that in the current economic climate, and I quote 'it is important that we give priority to investments that accelerate the recovery, that increase productivity and that promote reality'. 100% agreement: we must give priority to these additional investments in the European Union. Unfortunately, with this report today, we are doing the opposite, we are sending the opposite signal, also under the direction of the rapporteur, Mr Bayet. Each country decides how much tax it levies on corporations, so that's not really the problem. On the contrary, we can all recognise that taxes, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, are too high and have to go down today. So that's not really the problem. But there is a problem when tax structures are put in place specifically to artificially shift profits to countries where taxes are lower for the sole purpose of avoiding those taxes and the tax authorities.  We note that multinationals in particular use this, and that small and medium-sized enterprises cannot do so, that they do have to pay the full pound, and that is not true. That's just not right, it clashes with all people's feelings. Taxes must be paid where the profits are created. That is why we must adapt our European legislation to ensure that taxes are paid where economic activity takes place.  But instead of tackling these fraudulent constructions, I see that the focus in the report is being put elsewhere, namely on raising taxes. At the same time, I note that the finance ministers discussing this report are moving in the right direction and will make correct adjustments to the Commission's proposal. In any case, I hope that they will ignore most of this resolution and that they will value genuine entrepreneurs, and certainly the jobs they create.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon
text: au nom du groupe ALDE. – Madame la Présidente, Monsieur le Commissaire Moscovici, je vais continuer dans la langue de Cervantes. Look, this is a key, economic and political issue, at the moment we are living on, and of the greatest importance to the system on which we all base European construction, which is that of liberal democracy, because civil society — and we are the highest representatives of civil society — no longer endures the lack of ethics in certain businesses. Parliament, therefore, Commissioner, sends you and the Council a very strong message, a very strong support for everything that is done to rationalize and to make more ethical the functioning of the economy in this area where, it is true, the Commission has been sensitive to popular outrage lately. That is why what I want to tell you is that beyond the technical terms which Mr Bayet has very well set out here, and on which we have fortunately reached an agreement a large majority of the House, beyond that we must make a good understanding of what this is all about. Because sometimes it is said that this goes against companies, that this is an anti-enterprise attitude. We're not going to go against companies at all. Those old demagogueries happened. But it is a question of companies, per maybe focusing more and more investment – as has been said here – linked to production, linked to their actual activity, than to paying for large law firms. And not just to combat evasion and fraud; even circumvention. That's what we want to stop. And, while we make these big companies more focused on producing, we're fairer to all medium- or small businesses that have no option to find investment in law firms to escape tax networks. That's what it's all about, protecting greater competitiveness and efficiency of our companies while, if we can raise a little more, the tax burden will be fairer and have a better response to the potentiality of agents and taxes. That's what it's all about, and it has nothing to do with attacking companies. It has to do with making a Europe fairer, more ethical, but also more efficient, and in that we ask you to be strong, Commissioner.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Moscovici, I would like to thank mr Moscovici for his work and for his work A US president once said that politics must serve those who work hard and follow the rules. But it is not only since Panama Leaks and Lux Leaks that we know that every cleaner in the European Parliament and every medium-sized company pays more tax on their income than Google or Apple. No social cuts, no failure to invest in the EU would be necessary with clear rules against the tax thieves of McDonalds and Co. Corporations in the EU should finally pay their taxes where they make profits – whether they artificially shift profits through subsidiaries or letterbox companies. The European Commission has now presented the regulation against tax avoidance. In the Council, the usual suspects are blocking tax justice. In Parliament, unfortunately, the usual suspects have watered down an originally very good draft by the rapporteur. Unfortunately, the rules in the EP report against fictitious interest rates are weaker than the Commission's absolute interest rate barrier and weaker in percentage interest rates than in the United States. Profits that have not been sufficiently taxed in tax havens should remain untaxed if they are active business. The law firms are already looking forward to lazy deals with Luxembourg. Withholding taxes on financial flows in tax havens also remain non-binding. Unfortunately, profits can continue to leave the EU untaxed. Withholding taxes would be a much more effective method than blacklists, which are a diplomatic disaster. I am curious to see whether the EU Commission will blacklist the United States with Delaware, for example. Unfortunately, we are missing a phase out of patent boxes, although here too the position of the OECD and also of the US Treasury is clear: patent boxes reduce taxes, but do not contribute to research and development. There should be no barrier to royalties in the same way as the interest rate barrier. Despite some positive aspects, such as the definition of tax havens and the extension of the rules against hybrid arrangements to third countries, we are therefore disappointed by the report. As long as the cleaner in Parliament has to pay more tax on her income than McDonald's and Co., it's hard for us to agree. However, we are always open to improvements.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, rapporteur Bayet, after several weeks of discussions, sometimes difficult but always cordial, I believe that the European Parliament is ready to send a clear signal to the Member States which have not yet managed to agree on the directive to combat corporate tax evasion. This message is simple: it is possible to go further than the original proposal of the European Commission. Any setback would therefore be a deliberate choice of our European leaders to maintain I do not know what national advantages in this great competition for the less tax.  Unfortunately, the latest discussions between finance ministers suggest a cheap deal. Indeed, one of the six provisions of the text, the switch-over clause, which ensures that money entering Europe is properly taxed, risks being withdrawn from the final agreement. In addition, it is important to limit the deduction of interest by large companies to prevent them from artificially indebted some of their subsidiaries and thus pay no tax in those countries. Unfortunately, this limitation would not apply to existing loans and interest, which nevertheless play a key role in all the tax scandals identified so far. And the list of setbacks is still long... On this point, however, Parliament speaks with a clear voice. The European Commission's position should be a minimum. We need to go further and be more ambitious.  That is why the Greens have defended the addition of an update on pro-patent tax regimes. I want to emphasize this issue as this issue is essential in the fight against tax optimisation. This tool is a purely European invention, launched in 2006 by the Netherlands and which has spread to more than a dozen countries in Europe. Supposed to promote research and development, these tools actually offer an opportunity for large companies to reduce their tax rates without developing innovation and research, as the Commission itself points out. This problem must therefore be resolved without delay. The Commission is expected to present a legislative proposal in the coming months in co-decision, to allow Parliament to have a say. Mr Moscovici, you have an important role to play, first of all by making our recommendations to the finance ministers in order, at least, to limit the damage. Second, it is time for you to stop waiting to speed up other key issues such as the creation of a blacklist of tax havens, the introduction of sanctions against territories, intermediaries or companies engaged in or inciting tax evasion, as well as the publication of country-by-country information, extended to all countries. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), blue card question. Madam President, because there is often talk here of a great deal of unfair competition within the European Union, I think we must be clear. I come from a small country, which is a financial centre, Cyprus. Its comparative advantage is that it has low corporate tax rates; we are at 12%. That's what healthy competition requires. As in the various consumption taxes there are different taxes, different VAT, I believe it is fair and healthy competition to make a difference in terms of tax rates. It is one thing to have a different tax rate and another to avoid tax avoidance and tax evasion, for which we are clearly in favour of falling for it. It is not the countries of the European Union and it is the tax havens that we have to fight. In other words, we must not come to the end of hitting the European Union itself, bearing in mind what is happening in tax havens and has nothing to do with what is happening in the European Union.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. It is not a question of tax competition. No one disputes the possibility of having different rates by country. What we dispute is this race to the abyss with opaque measures. For example, in Luxembourg, it is not the 29% rate that is applied, but tax rulings and individual agreements. As for Cyprus, companies are not looking for a low rate, but rather the opacity that your island offers.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at this time when we have an election campaign in Italy, I have travelled a lot in the area and I have to say that I have met a great many small businesses. It is no secret that the large multinationals do not pay taxes, while the small ones are very crushed. In a European Union that works, in a world that works, a compromise really should be found to make everyone pay a very low level of tax, so that it is possible, precisely, to generate an economy and not to create distortions of competition and not to create unpleasant situations, such as those of the scandals that in Italy are called 'pulcinella's secrets'. Because everyone knew that Luxembourg was a tax haven. Everyone knew about the existence of Panama and everyone knows that everyone in these tax havens is there: there are great managers, there are politicians and there are all those who then go to manage politics from above and go and regulate the world a little as it works. People are a little angry and from now on we are trying in Europe to take forward proposals like the one we saw with the rapporteur, Mr Bayet. We as a group have worked very well, trying to work with the very groups that really wanted to take a step forward, and we initially found good participation from groups such as the GUE and the Greens to put forward a proposal to make companies pay real taxes. In addition, we have called for lower deductions for large multinationals, especially on elusive transfer pricing practices. The problem is that a compromise has also been found here, because in this Parliament, as in the Council, there are representatives of countries that use these practices to take advantage of the other members of the European Union. So we must examine our consciences because this is an issue on which no compromises must be found. People are archstufa of this system and further action needs to be taken, especially on the banks, where we have not yet made a single proposal. I would like to address the Commissioner on this point: banks encourage tax evasion in the first place, above all, and so action must be taken here, even to the point of removing the banking licence from the banks that carry out these practices.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, the fight against aggressive tax optimisation and its devastating consequences for public finances is therefore a seemingly consensual struggle. Multinationals that have built their business model on tax evasion or circumvention need to understand that the game is over. The six points proposed to regulate the directive that is the subject of Mr Bayet's report would be a step forward, indeed.  The question is whether the European Union is politically legitimate to fight this fight.  In principle, you know our reluctance to deal with the political inefficiency of the European Union. However, we have to be pragmatic. States have used tax competition to the point of dumping. Their governments have been unable to cooperate and have resulted in the loss of tax revenues conducive to all scandals, such as LuxLeaks and Panama Papers.  France is a country that fails to make itself fiscally attractive because of the spending madness of the socialist and UMP governments. I also wonder about the real sincerity of the EPP and S-D legislators, who pretend to support projects that only come about under the pressure of scandals. France probably has more to gain from the implementation of the control tools proposed by the directive. If the improvement can be achieved through international tax cooperation, even with the European Union, then banco.  But this is by no means a blank cheque: I would remind you that patriots are more against the concept of the fiscal union than ever before. France must remain in control of its tax rates.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). – Gentlemen, you are making fun of crowns of the fight against tax evasion, when the inviolable principle of the European Union is the freedom of movement of capital, leaving offshore, tax havens – between them and the Member States of the Union, as long as they are cooperative. The scandal of scandals is this very rotten exploitative system, the privileges of capital inseparable from unpopular barbarism in all states, regardless of memoranda. It is the folk sacrifices without end that finance the profits. What the capital earns is what the employee loses. With development laws like the one now being passed in Greece, you are funding new subsidies and tax exemptions to business groups from the tax evasion of the people, who are in danger of losing even their home to ever-increasing taxes that they cannot pay. If the objectives of the Memorandums fall out, wages and pensions will be cut further with the budget cutter; This legitimate tax evasion quantitatively is infinitely greater than illegal capital tax evasion. The proposed directive, the result of competing interests rather than the will to clean up, concerns an infinitesimal part of corporate tax evasion. It is simply trying to defuse the indignation of the people, who are facing the tax evasion of their ever-decreasing income to finance capitalist development. Popular prosperity is possible only with the people in power, owner of the wealth it produces, free from the domination of monopolies and its associations.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the economic crisis has required very important efforts from European citizens. In this context, the fight against tax avoidance, particularly by large multinationals, must be an absolute priority of the European institutions. These practices reduce government revenue, income that could be earmarked for education, health or public investment. And not only that: the tax avoidance on the part of multinationals leaves small and medium-sized enterprises, which are undoubtedly the engine of growth and job creation, in a much more unfavourable situation. In this regard, active work is being made within the European Union to promote measures necessary to reduce the so-called fiscal gap, and we must continue in that direction. I have no doubt. I would like to thank the European Commission and its Commissioner Moscovici for their proposal here today, and I would ask the Council to look up and listen to this House.  The OECD has worked in recent years on the so-called BEPS project. Oecd and G20 countries have committed the project and made a political commitment to adopting their conclusions. Let's do it, ladies and gentlemen. The Directive we are discussing today is an appropriate instrument for transposing the conclusions and recommendations of the OECD BEPS programme in a coordinated and coherent manner throughout the European Union. We must all, I stress, all, show our commitment to actively collaborate in driving these measures.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In the TAXE Special Investigation Committee, one of the most frequently spoken sentences of guests we invited was: we finally comply with common laws. So sad - so true! I would like to thank the Commission for doing something at this point to ensure that we have better legislation in the future. Although I may not hide the fact that we in the Socialist Group would like us all to be even more courageous here, we can see the constraints on which the Commission is moving. We are shocked to note that it is the elected governments of the Member States that often block developments here, withholding developments where we want to go much further. The most frightening question is: why does someone have to pay taxes somewhere and why not? We note that many multinationals have their profits precisely in countries where there is little tax. What do we expect? We expect them to prove to the tax authority that they actually developed the economic activity that led to that profit in this place. Pure sham constructions, legal structures, letterbox companies within the EU – there is no need for Panama, we remain within the EU – are unacceptable. If we agree on this – and I am sure that we will agree very quickly with 500 million Europeans – then we must shift the burden of proof to companies. In the future, like every single taxpayer, they will also have to prove in their tax return that it is right to claim a scheme that leads to lower taxes.  I am surprised that the governments of the Member States are in the most heated discussion here, and I am surprised that we ourselves in this House may still be discussing this, when all of us here know exactly how the tax authority, when it wants to deduct something from its income tax return, asks for evidence and provides evidence. Why should this apply to everyone, including any small and medium-sized enterprise, but not to multinationals? This is not to be understood by anyone. I am sure that if we move forward at this point, we will have managed to deal with one of the major problems much better than we have in the past. I would ask ourselves to be courageous here in this House, let us take it to the outside world, let us help the Commission to put the Council on the trail here.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for It is good that the Commission has come here with a proposal to combat tax avoidance, which is indeed scandalous lyrum in some cases in the European Union. A very important instrument of this tax avoidance is intra-company credit agreements between parts of companies in different jurisdictions. Interest payments are more or less faked for these in-house credit agreements to push profits back and forth, and then, of course, they end up where the tax rates are lowest. This is a shift in profits, these are tax loopholes, and something needs to be done about it. But the Commission, in its otherwise good proposal, is overdoing the OECD proposal and saying that we are now, in principle, limiting the deductibility of interest to 30%. I do think that this OECD proposal is inappropriate, because it naturally affects all companies, including those that finance honest investment projects and borrow from third parties – that is, financial intermediaries, banks and other financial institutions. Interest is the cost of investment projects, and if we limit the deductibility of interest, then that means nothing more than double taxation, because the non-deductible interest is taxed on the one hand as a profit for the company that carried out the investments, and on the other hand as income from the lender. It is all the more wrong that the European Parliament is now trying to limit this deductibility even more than the Commission has already proposed – to 20%. We must take action against this, particularly in the interests of honest businesses in our country and in the European Union.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE).
text: First of all, I would like to thank Mr Bayet and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this piece, because it is not an easy subject. We have votes later this week on the Panama Papers, on the proposal to set up a new committee. It has become clear once again how much it is necessary for us to tackle tax evasion and tax avoidance at world level. As many speakers have said, the OECD has done a very good job with the BEPS project in this respect. I therefore wholeheartedly support all the recommendations that are made in them.  Unfortunately, this report goes a little further and is being done a little bit on the part of Parliament. I have two objections to this. Firstly, I believe that this may disrupt the global level playing field. Then we could indeed turn 'anti-BEPS' into 'anti-business'. That shouldn't be the point. Furthermore, when we visited the TAXE 2 Committee in Washington, we were told indignantly that the ink of the negotiations was not yet dry or that Europe was going to go back to gold-plating and even go to the top of it. That's what's indignant. After all, why would you still be negotiating with each other if one of the partners would do something else immediately? So, full support for the whole OECD package as it stands, but don't go any further.  (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – We saw in the Panama papers that there were not very many US companies there mentioned as transferring their profits, and that is obviously because they do not need to because they have their own internal tax havens in the states of Delaware and Nevada. We as Greens published a report recently demonstrating that, so I would like to ask Cora whether she would support a proposal to have a withholding tax on such transfers by companies when it is not clear why the transfers are being made and what the implications are in terms of tax.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. I think your political groups have done a good job with that research. We have indeed had to establish that within the United States there are states that have their own policies. I can only reiterate that, of course, we want to do everything we can to ensure that tax avoidance and tax evasion by multinationals, but also by wealthy individuals and sometimes even SMEs, are tackled. I would just like to repeat my plea and say that we must all do so at world level and that the OECD is the most suitable platform for this.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Mr Moscovici, according to official calculations, EUR 1 trillion is lost annually to this giant tax fraud. It is lost from state budgets and must return to support investment, growth and the strengthening of the social state. We are talking about a challenging deficit of fairness and healthy competition revealed by the Panama Papers in favour of multinationals and at the expense of consistent taxpayers, small and medium-sized enterprises and states. The position of my group is that profits should be taxed where they are produced. Finally, there should be a register, tax harmonisation, a blacklist for tax cheats, negative publicity and severe penalties. There must also be more and more effective and European and global cooperation to tackle this blatant injustice and fraud. The Commission has taken a small late positive step. Some Member States are trying through the Council to limit this. The European Parliament must exert counter-pressure in order to deal effectively with tax evasion within Europe as well.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the last time we discussed taxation, we crossed swords a little bit, but I must admit that, for the time being, you have put on the table proposals which I believe are making significant progress in the fight against corporate tax evasion. And what do I see? That today this Parliament, which is preparing to adopt a relatively ambitious position, should address an empty seat. I note that the Council, which prides itself on being the only one with jurisdiction in this matter, treats this Parliament over the leg, as if we did not exist! We know the Dutch Presidency - the Netherlands is the champions of tax cover-up, as we know - but here they are hiding and not even below the seat. One wonders what they have to hide.  What they have to hide is an avalanche of amendments - from the Member States - to the Commission's proposal. Amendments whose sole purpose is to significantly weaken the scope of the texts tabled. One would have hoped that after LuxLeaks, SwissLeaks, Offshore Leaks and the Panama Papers, the finance ministers would have amended themselves. Not at all! Of course, could we expect those who, for decades, have launched this tax war that Member States are engaged in at the expense of small taxpayers who suddenly change their minds?  I would like to take two examples: the Netherlands, during their Presidency, has refrained from making any progress on this concept of effective minimum taxation of companies. Of course, they have made quasi-non-taxation their main selling point. But also, the very virtuous Wolfgang Schauble - whom you so often quote, Commissioner - so quick to give lessons to the whole of Europe, is opposed to companies being forced to publish their results by country - you know, transparency could stimulate public passions... Finally, the same Wolgang Schauble does not refrain from stimulating public passions when it comes to Greece, but of course, if it is the German companies and their small interests that once financed Mr Schuble's CDU, then it is better to be opaque. I warn the Council, because to continue in this way, their empty seat will soon be occupied by the populists of the worst kind. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr. Lamberts has just made a fantastic film, but expresses a point that I share. He just arrived ten minutes ago; I've been here since the beginning of the debate.  He has criticized the Council, and he is right. Ms Joly worked well with rapporteur Bayet. I hear that in the Green Group you are arguing against this report; however, I hear all colleagues greet him, saying that this is a step forward, because, of course, putting an end to tax evasion is something fundamental. Today, you have criticised the Council, and you have done the right thing. Are you prepared to support rapporteur Bayet's report?

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. Indeed, you are quite right, we objected to the report in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, mainly because of a setback on an important provision at the last minute. But it is true that in the meantime, together with Hugues Bayet, the Green Group and other parties, we have done a good job and, as a result, we have decided to support the report when it is voted on earlier in plenary.  We have worked well together, but I still regret that this limit - I will not fit into the technique - of 20% for the interest deduction remains in the text. It's unfortunate.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the Committee’s amendments urge the EU to introduce a common consolidated corporate tax base. This is clearly intended as a move towards a harmonised corporate tax rate. In a free market context, competition is always a good thing, and tax competition between jurisdictions is always, and everywhere, a good thing. Any attempt by governments to harmonise taxes is a conspiracy by those governments against the interests of taxpayers. The effect of such tax harmonisation is always to increase taxes, to reduce competitiveness – in this case of European economies – and, ultimately, it is the individual consumer who pays more because these costs are simply passed on. Countries with high-tax economies, like socialist France, cannot compete with countries which have lower corporate tax rates, such as Ireland. The EU’s solution is to destroy globally competitive business environments because it envies them. If countries like Britain want to have a globally competitive environment in which to create business, jobs and wealth, then we must leave an EU which is intent on harmonising taxes. Not only that, but in the EU the state is to be given more weapons with which to intimidate ordinary taxpayers. General rules against tax avoidance, as proposed today by the Commission, will be difficult to interpret and will consequently give the state a large stick with which to threaten the ordinary taxpayer. These rules will not be used against large corporates, as is claimed, they will be used by the state against those who cannot afford expensive lawyers. It would be better to simplify the tax system so that the taxpayer could be certain of his or her tax liability, rather than add a layer of complexity with anti—avoidance rules which will scare ordinary people away from making sensible investments for the future and into paying more tax than they need to do today.  We are also being asked to endorse the Committee’s proposal for an EU tax identification number. Clearly, the EU is too scared of British public opinion to tell us before our EU referendum, but we can put the pieces of the jigsaw together. The EU wants to tax us directly if we are daft enough to remain. The report recommends an EU-wide withholding tax and an EU exit tax, added to which are proposals in committee for a global register of assets held by individuals. Put these things together and you have the necessary building blocks for a wealth tax on citizens. The prospect of a financial transaction tax is also being discussed in working documents aimed at creating a eurozone budget. Not content with just its own budget, the eurozone wants to use the EU’s general budget as a means to keep the euro on life support. We know this actually from David Cameron’s so—called renegotiation, which attempts to protect the British economy from these costs but will fail to do so.  May I end on a positive note? We in Britain are about to vote – if the polls are to be believed – to leave the European Union so we shall not be troubled by these problems. We we will happily leave you to cope with the problems of your own creation.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Helmer, you are right. Tax competition is a good thing. The question is for whom? For the shareholders of large companies. But it is probably not such a good thing for the small taxpayers – individuals and SMEs – who then end up bearing the brunt of financing public services. That means that – unless of course you want to get rid of education, the NHS and all the rest of it – someone has to pay for it, and the name of the game today is tax injustice. Basically, what you are defending with your positions is even more tax injustice so that the little man pays and the big man gets away with it in the tax havens that you defend so well.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, of course, that is the sort of nonsense we expect from the Left. The fact is that if you leave politicians to their own devices, they will simply keep increasing and increasing rates of taxation, and the result of that will actually be that they damage the economy: they kill the goose that lays the golden egg and they collect less tax.  If I can get one message out into this Chamber today, it is that raising tax rates does not increase revenues beyond a certain reasonable limit. If you have tax rates which are too high and you then increase them you reduce the revenues, you have less money for education and health and all those good things that you want. Your policy is utterly self-destructive. (Exclamations of protest from Mr Lamberts)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It is quite interesting how emotional a debate about tax avoidance can be. It is also interesting to see that two groups in this House are agreeing on how they will vote today on the report on combating tax avoidance practices by means of a blue card. So it is a very interesting discussion, and I would say that this shows how important the issue of combating tax avoidance is here in this House and at European level. It is an important issue, and I believe there is broad agreement that the three most important points on this issue are the following, and there is agreement on this: effective taxation at the place of value creation, that is, profits should be taxed where they are actually generated. More transparency: we have recently brought country-by-country reporting to the stage in this House, we have voted on the automatic exchange of information – transparency is important. Thirdly, as has already been mentioned today: a level playing field for all companies. Small and medium-sized enterprises cannot generally pay a third more corporation tax than large companies. This is unfair, it is not fair competition, and it is also damaging to Europe in the end. Fair competition also means fair competition at the global level. In this case, the OECD has set out a very important measure in this case with the BEPS Action Plan, namely this 15-point action plan. More than 100 Member States and countries outside the OECD have committed to comply with this Action Plan and to carry out an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts from 2018. Even Panama has done so because of international pressure under the spell of the affair. This report, which we are to vote on today, is moving away from these provisions of the OECD-BEPS Action Plan on a number of very important points, which I personally consider to be a mistake. The Commission's draft has adhered very strongly to this draft, but the rapporteur is going away: for example, with regard to the interest rate barrier, which has already been mentioned today, 20 instead of 30 per cent on EBITDA, which is a mistake, or when switching from exemption to imputation method. The same applies to additional taxation or hybrid taxation. If we want to remain competitive, we need to... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, all over the world multinational companies are tax evaders either by exploiting loopholes and differences in national tax systems or by funding corrupt politicians in certain countries, as Siemens did in my home country of Greece. As a result of this tactic, States have significant economic losses and amounts that could be allocated to other development-related activities are lost. At the same time, the respective small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the economic backbone of each country, are also affected. There should therefore be a uniform and fair system of taxation applied by all the countries of Europe. Under this system it should be to tax the profits of multinational companies in the country where these profits are obtained, so that they cannot channel them to other countries that are tax havens. Moreover, if they try to send this money to other countries, it should be taxed in the way that it would be taxed if it were acquired in the country in which it was acquired. Finally, multinational companies should not be able to deduct interest and exploit incentives to submit ......  (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise three points in this context. First of all, I think we should see the measures in this directive as part of a bigger picture – as part of the entire EU agenda to fight tax dodging. I think that it is fair to admit that, over a very short period of time, a lot has been done to improve our tax systems. I also believe that today we better understand the need for sound cooperation in tax policies, both across Europe and globally. Secondly, I hope to see the Council reach swift agreement on this directive because it is a much—needed fix. I also hope that, at the end of the day, the directive will be designed and implemented in accordance with global standards and in coordination with our partners.  Thirdly, I believe that there are other items on the agenda needed in order to achieve fair, efficient and simple taxation in the internal market. It is true that owners of shell companies benefit, often exploiting weak rules in offshore tax havens, but gaps also exist in our tax rules and can be exploited. Tax systems in Europe are in need of reform in order to fully close those loopholes allowing tax evasion and avoidance, eliminate special rules, and limit deductions, exemptions and credits. That would ensure a lower rate for everybody. This is important because I believe that we need a system that energises growth, a tax system that is built for growth, ensuring that fair rules are respected and that the economy works for everybody.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Madam President, colleagues in this House may just have noticed that, yes, we do have a referendum coming up in the UK on our EU membership, and I must say when I meet people in my constituency, real people in the South-East of England, they want information. They want to know what the EU does, and they want to know why it might be better or worse for us to be part of a Union of 28 countries working together, or to be on our own.  I have to say it is hard to think of a more compelling case where collective action works than fighting tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. Tax dodging, just like pollution, climate change and international crime, does not respect borders. In fact it thrives in the mismatches that happen when countries do not speak to one another, when they do not cooperate and so helpful little loopholes emerge. We have to take a collaborative approach to tackling this problem if we are ever to succeed, and I am delighted that this is what is happening at EU level.  In its proposal for an Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive the Commission proposes to implement three of the OECD’s recommendations and has introduced a further three recommendations where the EU can and should go further. I welcome this ambition. It should set the templates for how we in the EU tackle tax dodging, leading the way internationally, and setting the example for other jurisdictions to follow.  The Commission’s original proposal was good, but my S&D colleague Hugues Bayet has made it even better, more ambitious in its scope and more precise in its definitions of key concepts where ambiguity only serves those who are looking to dodge tax. I am delighted to give Hugues’ report my support and I would urge finance ministers like George Osborne in Ecofin next week to take on board his recommendations and make the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive as ambitious as possible. This is a good step forward and a clear indication that anyone who cares about tackling tax dodging should see that the UK is best placed to carry on the fight by staying in the European Union.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Conservative MEPs support the implementation of the OECD’s anti-Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) framework. We support the fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning; we support the implementation at EU level of international commitments that our government has entered into. We want to see increased transparency, but we do not support the rapporteur’s ambitions of going far beyond what the OECD is proposing. This report should have focused on the Council’s priority of ensuring that taxes are paid where value is generated. Instead, the rapporteur seems more interested in looking at the rates at which activities are taxed. That is not our business: rather, it is unwanted interference in the rights of Member States to decide on their own tax policies. We do not support a common corporate tax base or the establishment of an EU tax inspectorate, with European tax identification numbers for companies. We need to understand in this House that imposing far stricter rules in the EU than in the rest of the OECD will impact on international investment: it will reduce growth and jobs. By acting through the OECD, we will ensure that Member States not only fulfil their obligations, but remain competitive in international markets. We must ensure that multinational companies pay their fair share of taxes. The best way of ensuring that is to keep tax rates low and tax codes simple.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When the Luxembourg papers were opened to us, we had perhaps no idea how big this problem was. But when the papers from Panama landed on the Süddeutsche Zeitung's editorial table, we gradually began to imagine how big this problem really was. The best example of investigative journalism can be found in yesterday's International New York Times. There's the description of how this works, how this industry works: There are shell companies at shell companies that are spreading all over the world. For this reason, I do not think that even such a specialist as the current President of the Commission really knows how big this Lerneian hydra really is. The example mentioned in yesterday's New York Times describes a case in which the man who ordered the aggressive planning of taxes paid $4.5 million to bring about this system of shell companies. For this reason, I suspect that no one, either the Commission or the European Parliament, really has any idea how big a problem we are facing. Every time someone mentions tax competition as an excuse to continue this, I suspect they have their hands in the honey jar.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the objectives of this directive are commendable. However, and this is clear, with each passing day, the great plan announced by the Commission in 2015, at the height of the tax scandals and at the height of public outrage, is confronted with reality.  In the name of pragmatism, that is, in the name of the hypocrisy of the governments of the countries that have created the conditions to exempt large multinationals from paying taxes, today we have a proposal from the minimalist Commission that does not correspond at all to the legitimate expectations of citizens. We therefore follow the report which required that the maximum standards be adopted in the framework of the OECD proposals, not the other way around. We do not understand the exemption from the financial system, the Commission's criteria for applying the switch over are ineffective. On the other hand, we do not understand the coherence of this proposal with others that are promised, such as the common consolidation of the tax base or the list of tax havens, i.e. this directive seems to us to be more of a propaganda tool designed to give citizens that something is being done to stay the same.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The Panama Papers, LuxLeaks and other scandals have made it clear in recent years that tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning are now one of the most serious problems facing governments in Europe. A lot of important elements of this problem have been mentioned in this debate, and I think that the proposal that the Commission has come up with and the report that Parliament has prepared clearly identifies the problems.  At the same time, we have to keep going, and that's not enough. I would like to highlight two areas that may not have been discussed in this debate so far: the nature of the tax system itself, the nature of the European tax systems. Of course, the Member States have the right to set tax rates, different tax methods, but we need to know that as long as europe has such fragmented tax systems, companies in this European Union will use the resulting tax optimisation options, so that tax unification is inevitable in order to reduce tax avoidance. Secondly, it is not just about variable tax rates in general. There is a specific set of legislation tailored to individual companies. To give you an example, last year in my country, Hungary, an American company called General Electric used a tax-setting option in which, after revenue of some HUF 4000 billion, or about EUR 15 billion, it paid tax not in the country where it was doing business, but as a result of sales contracts between various tricky subsidiaries, broughtd tax payments to Hungary and benefited from tax advantages there. , which could result in a reduction in the corporate tax rate actually paid to 2%. I think that this is a typical example of tax avoidance, and the Commission must also pay particular attention to these tax planning legislative processes tailored to individual companies. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (point 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), blue card question. Madam President, I would like to ask a question. It has been said that we must be even more ambitious. My question is very simple: We are not the United States of Europe as the United States of America is. In the United States of America, states have the right to determine their tax policy. I think you will agree with me that, if we want to be effective, let us stick to the OECD agreed basis for BEPS. If you want to go beyond that, I think we're entering very uncharted waters. Do you agree or disagree?

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Blue card answer. – I agree that the European Union is not the United States. At the same time, I believe that the OECD standards must also be fully enforced, and that we must also use the instruments that the European Commission and the European Union now have much more effectively in order to reduce tax avoidance.  For example, in the case of taxation tailored to such companies, which I was talking about in the case of General Electric, I think that the Commission should act with the utmost rigour, examine, for example, the extent to which this infringes, for example, illicit State aid rules, internal single market regulations, and in this case the Commission must be forced to enforce European law, existing European law.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: –  Madam President, only the other week I voted in vain to stop the committee from proposing an EU tax identification number. We all know where this is going: the EU wants to tax the British directly, if we are mad enough to stay in. These proposals include an EU-wide withholding tax and an EU tax coherence and coordinating centre. Worst of all, we know from the tax committee that the EU wants to create a global register of all assets held by individuals, no doubt in anticipation of an EU wealth tax on all citizens. The last time we had a register of assets was in 1087: the Domesday Book, imposed by William the Conqueror, or William le Bâtard. It was so unpopular that it has not been repeated.  Let us hope that Brexit will mean the EU will not get a chance to repeat that mistake in the UK. God help the rest of you!   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "As juvenile crime increases, we wonder what we have done wrong. As crime grows among taxpayers, instead of thinking about how to tell them to pay, we may think that maybe we've done something wrong. Do you not think that punishing a man who works – and the higher the fine the better he works – is simply idiocy? Will you vote to abolish income tax in the UK once you leave the Union?

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, that is an interesting proposition, sir, but I do not think that we will be abolishing income tax in the UK. What I think we will do, which this place does not do and the rest of Europe does not do, is to minimise tax as much as possible so as to allow citizens to keep as much as possible of their hard-earned money in their pockets. That, I think, is a right. It is a human right to keep most of what you earn in your own pocket. Obviously, you have to help the less fortunate and those who are sick, but you should be allowed to keep the fruits of your own labour. That is a human right.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we all know that achieving budgetary revenue throughout the Union is extremely important, with direct consequences for the safety of the European area itself. The avoidance of taxes in any form must be prevented by simple and transparent measures which do not allow the concealment of taxable amounts.  The main legal mechanism by which money comes out of the European economy is the use of tax havens. We all know it. In the Panama Papers scandal we have all seen the magnitude of business in this area. The use of these channels indirectly contributes to undermining national economies. If, indeed, the defenders of the euro area are in good faith, then they should propose packages whereby large companies are no longer tempted by the facilities in tax havens. If not, then European officials must give free hands to national laws. Solutions must therefore be found to encourage multinational companies to retain and invest profits in the countries in which they make them.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the Commissioner and the Commission on being in the vanguard of the efforts at global efforts to stop fiscal evasion and aggressive fiscal planning. What I would like to say is that we should be very clear that tackling fiscal evasion and aggressive fiscal planning is not possible without a global financial system and an international fiscal system. This draft directive which we will debate today is a good step in this direction.  I want to draw attention to the Convention on Avoiding Double Taxation. In many cases this kind of bilateral convention has really become a convention on avoiding any taxation. In my country, for instance, an investor sold shares in a big bank and my country could not tax a single euro of capital gain. Why? Because the owner of the shares was a company in Cyprus and in Cyprus capital gains are not taxed. I want to tell you that India has started to renegotiate these kinds of conventions and we have to do the same thing.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. They know it: many large companies do not pay their taxes or they pay far too little. That is reprehensible, and it is therefore right, right and logical for the Commission to come forward with proposals on this. After all, companies should pay their taxes where they have made the profits. We cannot repeat this often enough. In his report, Hugues Bayet has worked in this direction – step by step, but the direction is clear. We need a fundamental change in the system. Tax avoidance and tax evasion and all these forms of aggressive tax planning are a democratic problem, but they also lead to huge distortions of competition, because SMEs, micro-enterprises, which pay their taxes nicely, the employees anyway, and the big companies choose it. It is therefore high time that we also did something about European things. What is new and a plus is that, as is so often the case with artificial loans within a group of companies – for example, at Ikea – the profit is reduced by deductible interest. It is also important to demand transparency in trusts and foundations. Commissioner, will there be anything coming from you?  The authorities' means of control are also important. We see it everywhere in Europe: austerity is also reducing the financial authorities, especially those who are supposed to control, especially in the southern countries. So, here are three call signs also addressed to the absent Council. Here we need to increase the number of staff and not reduce them. And, of course, the ban on letterbox companies. Only on the basis of mandatory country-by-country disclosure can scaffolding such as letterbox companies be debunked as such. It is only through public country-by-country reporting that it becomes clear which companies make and how much revenue. Finally, I would like to remind you that I am waiting for explanations as to why, for example, Maltese Deutsche Bank employees are three times more productive than their counterparts in the rest of Europe.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the data leaks of recent years have revealed the huge number of companies that do not pay taxes in the country where the profits have been made. Companies empty their profit accounts into countries with low taxation or even tax exemption.  Even old and reputable companies have begun to engage in arrogant tax evasion in the belief that they will not be caught up in this shameful activity. The publicity of tax information and fair and clear tax laws are the best medicine for the problem of tax evasion. Tax evasion companies want stable conditions from society. This is what they achieve at the expense of their competitors, who pay their own taxes on these competing small and medium-sized enterprises. Public services have been privatised in many countries. I hope that those companies that engage in tax avoidance will be completely excluded from public tenders. Hopefully, we will find effective rules to combat tax evasion.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, maintaining the capacity of our institutions to make policy, to boost productive investment and innovation, to maintain the European social model is about ending tax avoidance, with what we call aggressive tax planning, and to encourage companies to pay their taxes where they generate profits. A coordinated and harmonised approach to the functioning of tax regimes in which all tax administrations are integrated is also needed. When I say all I am also referring to regional ones which meet the criteria of the Court of Luxembourg to be regarded as autonomous systems because they have institutional, regulatory and economic autonomy. It has been shown that the proximity offered by these systems promotes control, prevents corruption, promotes support for the real economy and is an effective antidote to the deficit that occurs more easily in those administrations that have fewer responsibilities over their income than powers over their expenditures. Let us provide above coordination and strategic approaches, and, below, experiences that have proven their usefulness and we will move in the right direction. It is not welcome that many multinationals pay a la carte, that public administrations lose between one hundred thousand and two hundred and forty billion per year in this way. To put an end to this, we need another fiscal governance at European level. Building it requires the clear and unprecedented commitment of the 28 Member States and, in line with the answer it gave us to our question on the Fiscalis programme, to also have the autonomous regional tax authorities, such as the Basque concert or the Navarrese convention, which show their commitment to our objectives.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I want to start by supporting the rapporteur's proposal on this matter and saying that, of course, one scandal after another does not clear us from taking a strong position because citizens continue to pay and multinationals continue to flee.  Mr. Moscovici, therefore, I ask you to stand by the maximum standards of demand in this matter. Do not praise the Dutch Presidency because saying that the Dutch Presidency is doing very well in this matter is more or less the same as defending a fox guarding the chicken coop.  Our problem is the tax justice we have in the European Union. And I have heard colleagues from the EPP say that this directive and this proposal by Parliament is a proposal against the economy. No, it isn't, it's not. Paying taxes where profits are made is not against the economy, having tax justice is not against the economy, tax ing at source is not against the economy.  Against the economy is that workers and small and medium-sized enterprises continue to pay, multinationals to flee and that money is lacking in health, school and everything that is important to public accounts. That's what's against the economy.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the European Union the tax load is 10% to 15% higher than in any other competing region in the world. This means that there is no other place in the world where companies and employees are paying as much tax as here. Let us not forget that when we talk about these issues. This is not – and must not be – about fighting European business and European companies. It must not be about increasing taxes. It must be about addressing those who are bending the rules and those who are breaking the rules. It must be very clear there is a responsibility for national authorities, in cooperation with each other, to minimise all of these things that are undermining taxation.  But it must also lead to the fact that we stay within the OECD rules because, if we go beyond them, we are creating a disadvantage for European industry and are also creating new loopholes and new grey zones for those who would like to misuse the different systems. So we need to ensure that investments can come to Europe and we need to have a stable legislation and responsibility for national authorities.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – When I look back, about ten years, things have changed. Ten years ago I became a member of the Dutch Parliament and started the debate on tax avoidance, with which I had little chance in the Dutch Parliament, let alone that there were international agreements.  They're coming into view now. There has been a lot of work to be done: a financial crisis, scandals such as panama papers and Luxleaks. Anyway, these international agreements are coming into view, and that may be somewhat optimistic. They also find more and more resonance, because this is not about taxing companies, but about basic justice – equal monks, equal logging. Every business, every person should pay taxes, and people want that basic justice to be enforced. This requires international agreements, and a country cannot do this alone. I am also pleased with the Proposal of the European Commission, my congratulations to Mr Moscovici, which went beyond the agreements laid down by the OECD. I am also pleased that there is a report in the European Parliament that shows that political differences can be bridged and that improvements can be made. Where there's a will there's a way. The European Parliament can also set a good example here for the countries that are currently obstructing. This began with German Finance Minister Schäuble proposing to halve the package and implement only the OECD proposals. Ireland and the United Kingdom are also struggling with proposals on disparity through hybrid structures, the switch-over clause or the CFC. And we cannot have this resistance if we want to make change. I would call on the Commission to report extensively on what discussions have taken place in the Council and how countries have conducted themselves. Transparency is extremely important, not only about companies that pay or do not pay tax, but also about how countries behave. Let me hope that this is also a turning point for the Netherlands, that the Dutch Presidency shows that it is breaking with the past.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Mr Moscovici, the practices of tax evasion and avoidance followed by multinationals hiding their super-corporations in various tax havens are well known. This was demonstrated by both the "Lux Leaks" and the "Panama Papers", which include the names of 400 Greeks directly or indirectly linked to 223 offshore companies. But instead of the Greek government taking action against the creation of offshore companies, it eventually legislated from above and a provision to legitimize the political persons who own offshore companies. Of course, after the popular outcry that has sparked the government, it has been forced to table an amendment establishing a total ban on participation in the administration or offshore capital for all political persons. The only solution to the problem of tax evasion practices is to tax the profits of companies in the place where profits are made, in order to stop companies resorting to tax havens and to burden the Member States of the Union with losses of tax revenue.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
