text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Tax evasion and aggressive tax planning arouse the feelings of citizens, because it weakens the common welfare that everyone contributes to. Of course, it also has a negative impact on the internal market, and that is why we must now ensure that entrepreneurship, both for large and small players, can take place on an equal footing throughout the European Union. Critical scrutiny is important for a functioning democracy and citizens must be informed, because then they can also demand that we make available political decisions that will prevent scandals such as 'Luxleaks' and the 'Panama Papers' from actually being able to take place in the future. The citizens expect this from us. Public and critical scrutiny is beneficial, including with regard to national tax systems. I can agree with the rapporteur and regret that the Commission has not yet presented a legislative proposal on the consolidated corporate tax base, because this proposal has the support of entrepreneurs and would simplify the tax system in the internal market and ensure that we create a clearer common playing field for all players across europe. And we need that.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, my home country of Ireland has a reputation as an enabler of massive tax avoidance for large corporations and the wealthiest in society, and unfortunately the perception is true. The Irish Government recently stated that it would phase out the notorious double Irish tax system, but companies like Google and Microsoft have until 2021 to restructure their tax avoidance techniques. The government has now introduced a so-called knowledge box, a tax rate of 6.25% for certain companies. We know this will not foster innovation; it is just another tax avoidance mechanism, another hand-out of millions to multinationals.  All the while Irish and European authorities have pushed taxes and charges on ordinary families who are already struggling to cope. The loopholes in the Irish system have been designed to perfectly complement the loopholes in the US tax law to benefit massive US corporations.  We can see that the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) measures are not enough to deal with the scale of the problem and that an EU set of legislative measures is not the answer. The response needs to be truly international.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: We have asked a lot of our citizens in recent years. Through their efforts during the crisis, we have been able to safeguard the foundations of our economy. In the reforms that followed, we once again appealed to them.  It is therefore necessary that these reforms should be accompanied by a justice agenda. Otherwise, you're undermining your own support base. If ordinary citizens feel that only they pay the bill and others escape the dance, then you create a breeding ground for extremism and populist recuperation.  That is why it is necessary for us to show that Europe is much more than painful savings and neoliberal free-market thinking. Europe is and must be a key player in the fight for fairer taxation, through the Panama Commission of Inquiry, on which we will vote later this week, but also in this dossier. If not, the citizens will drop out and thank them for a European project that seems to only serve the interests of large companies and wealthy mobile citizens. With this bill, Europe can take a major step towards a more equitable taxation. By translating the commitments made by Member States at OECD level into binding European legislation, we are also avoiding a patchwork of 28 different types of legislation to combat tax avoidance. This gives companies more tax certainty and also creates a more level playing field for all companies, small and large. After all, it is mainly the multinationals that are currently taking advantage of the stifling tax competition between the Member States. SMEs simply do not have the means to do so. It is high time we fulfilled our promises to the citizens and show that European cooperation is the best guarantee for strong and dynamic social welfare states, propped up by fairer tax systems.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a trillion a year lost as a result of tax evasion and tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning: we could have financed three Juncker Plans. The LuxLeaks scandal, first, and then the Panama Papers, are in danger of being just the tip of the iceberg. This is unacceptable. Evasion and avoidance increase tax costs for all, exacerbate the debt crisis and take away resources for investment and basic services for the weakest sections of society. We need strong and immediate responses from Europe. The package we are debating today is certainly a step forward, but it cannot be the last. Rules such as a limit on the deductibility of interest in a tax year, the fight against so-called double taxation and the transfer of income to subsidiaries in low-tax third countries are the minimum necessary to begin to tackle the problem. This report, which is the result of the rapporteur's excellent work, proposes the introduction of important changes to the proposed package in order to make it more effective. But while the Commission seems to have grasped the importance of this challenge, the Member States are still showing a schizophrenic attitude. There is a lack of political will in the fight against tax evasion, and it is to them that we must turn. I am thinking of the issue of patent boxes, tax concessions which more and more Member States adopt and which are often not linked to real investment in research and development, turning into gifts to multinationals and loopholes to evade taxation. These are global challenges that also require global responses, because these phenomena affect the poorest countries the most. Well, we need a Europe that does not give discounts on this issue and that sets an example with legislative initiatives that are strong and comprehensive. Decisive progress has also been made on the automatic exchange of information with developing countries and on state-by-state reporting, which is also compulsory for activities in third countries and which is public.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive should be a priority for all of us, but we should aim for precise provisions that make it impossible to interpret them differently. I believe that the Commission's original proposal was far from perfect, and that subsequent work only worsened the proposals for solutions. The results of the ECON vote probably speak for themselves: 20 votes in favour, 15 against, 21 abstentions. At the same time, I would point out that tax policy is a competence of the Member States and this should be borne in mind in further work, as further work on this directive, on this document, seems necessary.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before giving the floor to Mr López Bermejo, I wanted to inform you that this morning there was a serious attack in Istanbul, with over ten dead and many injured.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I regret your words.  The billions referred to each year are jobs, schools, hospitals, public residences that will never be built. An organized theft of the rich from the poor and the working classes, on whom the tax burden finally falls.  Today's report is right to point out the mechanisms that facilitate this circumvention at the international level: the false transparency of tax havens, the complicity of double taxation treaties. But in their specific respects, the improvements they make are very modest. We value the minimum taxation of companies abroad at 15%. But it's not enough.  Nor are we satisfied with indifference to the tax avoidance of companies within the European Union itself. Worse, it is supported that it is the Treasury that is complicit with tax avoidance and even tax evasion—as evidenced by today's revelations about the Bourbons—that certify that risky practices, such as transfers of assets from one country to another, should not be taxed, or the perception that foreign income should not be taxed either. The end result is uneven and unsatisfactory; only requirements are added where there should be an effective commitment to link production and taxation. We're sending a disappointing signal back to the European people.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the so-called Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive, which we are discussing today, is part of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package, which should ensure effective corporate taxation in the EU. I fully support this initiative. Unfortunately, the document adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs in many instances goes too far in imposing excessive tax restrictions on European companies, and is more an anti—business instrument than anything else. The report is actually much worse than the Commission’s original proposal.  One of the most controversial issues is the general interest limitation rule, which in the draft report was set at the level of 10% of earnings  before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA). In times when we strongly support efforts to encourage and promote investment in Europe, this restrictive limit would clearly hamper large investment projects. That would fly in the face of everything we have been saying here in this Chamber on the Juncker Plan. We should remember that interest payments are legitimate investment costs. I personally would be in favour of a much higher deductibility level of 30%, which is still within the range set by the OECD, but I am prepared, in the spirit of compromise, to support a deductibility level of 20%, as agreed in the committee. I understand that some Member States would consider stricter thresholds, but this is perfectly possible as Article 3 of the directive underlines the de minimis principle, which allows Member States to be more ambitious in application of the directive. But there is no reason to apply these excessively restrictive limitations to all Member States.  There are a number of other anti-business measures in the report. I hope they will be softened or eliminated in the final vote. I would like to call on the Parliament to focus on genuinely fighting tax avoidance, rather than yielding to populist sentiment and punishing European companies with excessive taxation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers and tax avoidance tactics by multinationals – all these revelations demonstrate one thing, that if you are powerful enough and have tax advisors you are not obliged to pay your tax. On the other hand, normal hard-working people and SMEs have to pay.  I am sure that individuals in small organisations pay more proportionally. The other day I was speaking to some small business representatives in my constituency in the West Midlands. One of the issues they raised and which they want Europe to tackle is this unfair competition from multinationals to the SME sector. This is unfair and it is unjust, because aggressive tax planning by multinationals leads to a loss of between EUR 100 to 250 billion every year in Member States’ budgets. This means we lose between 4% and 10% of global revenues from corporate taxes.  We have to address this, and the Bayet report does this and my congratulations to the rapporteur. I particularly welcome the precise definition of what constitutes a tax haven. This builds upon our earlier work where we call for country-by-country reporting for all companies as applied in the financial sector.  Corporate tax evasion is a global problem which requires global solutions. The G20 has shown its clear commitment and we need to be doing the same. Those anti-Europeans, the Brexiters, are misrepresenting our work here. We are talking about corporate taxation whilst they are implying that we are alluding to personal taxation which is not what this report does. I think what the rapporteur is trying to achieve in this report is absolutely right and as I said before, my congratulations to him.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Multinational corporations do not pay their fair share of taxes in the Member States of the European Union and pour their profits into tax havens. We need to stop the practices of shell companies, which are suing states for considerable profits. My own Slovak Republic is an infamous example, where we have seen a number of scandals in recent years. These have deprived our country of a huge amount of money and are still not being investigated. As citizens of Slovakia and Europe, we have been the victims of blatant thefts from politicians and our oligarchs in this way. Such an approach is contrary to Christian culture and ethics and is immoral. We have to end this. However, I do not see the current proposal as an entirely effective instrument, rather as a first step. I am in favour of a better agreement that restricts tax evasion, but at the same time I do not consider it right to enforce a common corporate tax policy. Tax harmonisation is not the way to go. Let us return to the idea of a European community. We are stronger when the strengths of every nation show. Let us therefore leave the trend of violent political unification and the creation of an artificial superstate.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – We are often criticised here in Parliament for not being effective enough and that the solutions and proposals we are proposing are coming too slowly. Today, however, we have a report on the table that proves the opposite, a step forward towards creating an environment that will force businesses to pay taxes more fairly and fairly. The fact is that, due to lax legislation and a lack of data exchange, billions of euros of money that could otherwise be spent on health, for education, to improve social conditions disappear. The harmonisation of taxation is also one of the conditions for achieving economic and monetary union. Without this, it is difficult to expect the single market to function well. Let me also express my support for efforts to establish a common consolidated corporate tax base. Although we all agree that we must be very determined in preventing tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance, we must, of course, also be aware that excessive demands and overly burdensome bureaucratic rules can also work negatively. There is a decline in economic activity and, consequently, less taxes. Of course, we must strive to ensure that such a report and such a document are balanced.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Aggressive tax planning – this is a concept that I am afraid european citizens do not really understand, but I would like to address this with a sentence at the end of my speech. Therefore, the practice of aggressive tax planning is completely unacceptable from the point of view of the integrity of the internal market and social justice, so I propose that we make tax fraud, the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance a top political priority for the European Union, that is, to address them.  Europe cannot afford to continue to take advantage of the differences between national tax systems without problems, reducing the tax burden for small and medium-sized enterprises and fair-taxed citizens. In order to create a reliable single market, Member States need to bring their tax systems into line, as this is a prerequisite for a well-functioning single internal market and economic and monetary union. The Commission directive rightly seeks to address this situation with the six specific anti-tax avoidance rules. With Parliament's recommendation, we could even take a more ambitious form, as these rules now make it legally binding for Member States to effectively manage corporate tax evasion while ensuring free competition.  One of the most important elements in the fight against tax avoidance would be the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base, which could make a radical difference in the fight against artificial base erosion and profit-transfer strategies. The Commission has already promised to submit a proposal for a common consolidated company fund. It is important that this is published as soon as possible and that the negotiations on this are concluded as soon as possible.  But this is where I'd like to go back to aggressive tax planning. Dear Mr President, This is not just a crime of multinationals. These conditions are indeed established by the Member States of the European Union. National governments are creating the rules that are now the result of large international companies paying taxes below 5%, and everyone else paying around 30%. It's shameful, it's untenable.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The losses in budget revenue caused by aggressive tax planning of multinational companies – as has been said many times – account for between 4% and 10% of corporate tax revenues. In this situation, the Commission's desire to ensure that companies pay taxes where they make a profit deserves support. However, the report's proposals to call on the Commission to introduce a common consolidated corporate tax base or to set a minimum corporate tax rate of 15% should be considered too far-reaching, as it is nevertheless for the Member States to shape income tax rules. For example, in my country, Poland, in order to limit the removal of untaxed profits abroad, a clause was introduced, inter alia, prohibiting the circumvention of tax law, which means that financial operations unrelated to the real economic activity of the taxpayer will be illegal. That should be enough.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A package of measures to combat tax avoidance is the right step to create fair and efficient corporate taxation across Europe. These include improving transparency and avoiding aggressive tax planning in EU Member States. One principle must be that companies are taxed exactly where they make profits and where the value creation takes place. That is what we in the TAXE Special Committee have also proposed and called for. It is high time that nations took a better line with increasingly sophisticated tax avoidance strategies, which insiders can only see. It is in the interests of the citizens, who are really tired of the fact that we are always just tricking here. It is hardly legitimate for us all to lose huge tax revenues over and over again – to the detriment of workers, to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises. I welcome the European Commission's ambitious plan, Mr Moscovici, which aims at fair corporate taxation. It is not a question of eliminating competition from locations completely, it is not a question of compulsory harmonisation of taxes, but of developing sustainable European common solutions, hopefully also globally, and of initiating legislative initiatives. If tax privileges are abolished, if illegal practices such as tax evasion can be effectively combated, only then will justice be created to which our EU citizens are entitled.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that we are all against tax evasion, against tax avoidance; But listening to the debates, I believe that, in our exaggerated attempt to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion, we may in the end strike the European Union itself in the back and, instead of creating blacklists and companies avoiding tax havens, in the end they will avoid the European Union itself. In the end, we're going to hurt our own businesses. In the end we will hurt the consumers themselves, the citizens themselves, the Gross National Product of our countries. We have to be very careful.  I'm hearing about tax flattening and uniform tax rates. These were applied to centrist systems in the former communist countries. You cannot, in free economies of fair competition and healthy competition, especially on the issue of taxation, come and impose a single leveling tax rate. What are the companies going to do? They will all leave the European Union, they will go to other countries and we will actually come in this way to put the United States of America, the third countries that are outside the European Union and the tax havens themselves in a very favourable position. We will essentially be blacklisted in our efforts to tackle tax avoidance and tax evasion.  I think we need to be clear: not tax avoidance, not tax evasion, not tax havens, but yes to free healthy tax competition. And we must say this: the European Union has the strictest rules on tax transparency, as far as its control systems are concerned, which no other competitive countries have. We must not harm competition from the European Union's financial services. As we have some countries that are strong in industry, we have some other countries are strong financial centers. Well, aren't we going to hurt them?

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! Europe needs a common consolidated tax base that nation states can use for the necessary collection of the taxes to be collected. Today, large international companies choose for themselves how much they want to pay in taxes. They call it tax optimization, and unfortunately there are some countries that are more than willing to help these companies. So we need the tax to be paid where the profits are generated. And the losers in this tax cheating game, as I would call it, are small and medium-sized enterprises. After all, small and medium-sized enterprises do not have the opportunity to avoid paying their taxes when they have made money. And that is why this is damaging the internal market. The big ones decide how much they will pay in tax, the little ones have to pay at box 1. And we should not forget that it is small and medium-sized enterprises that generate 80% of all the jobs created in the European Union. That is why we must have a level playing field for these companies. Then it is also important for the credibility of the European Union towards its citizens that real action is taken in relation to the tax evasion that we are seeing in these years. Sometimes we legislate here in the European Union on a lot of small things that citizens find difficult to understand. At the moment, citizens find it difficult to understand that we are not taking action against these international companies, which are simply cheating on tax.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the OECD base is a good basis for us to move closer to the objective we have set ourselves of avoiding and tax evasion. We have also achieved a good basis of reference, a pillar shared in our parliamentary debate, by establishing the criterion according to which taxes must be paid where profits are generated. Thus, fictitious transfers of the tax base on which taxes are calculated must be disadvantaged. That is the point of the debate. Let us not forget that the main problem is the transfer of the taxable amount, not so much the size of the tax rate, because sometimes, in the parliamentary debate, one has the impression that the concept of courage is confused with the idea that taxes must be increased. Let us not forget that the main reason why large and small businesses sometimes evade or evade taxes is that taxes are too high. Therefore, trying to solve the problem by increasing it further means going against precisely those small and medium-sized enterprises that are often filled with the debate. The second element is intra-group financial transactions. Be ware, because further reducing the limit on interest deductibility is a huge pleasure for banks and not for small and medium-sized enterprises. So the debate is a very good debate, the work that has been done is an excellent piece of work, but be careful because certain ideological obsessions could result in a reduction, a kind of eavesration of that good work which aims, let us not forget, small and medium-sized enterprises and the economic recovery of the whole continent.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think the general impression is that the smaller the company, the more tax they pay, and the bigger the company, the less tax they pay and the better they are at avoiding tax. This has been recognised globally and now measures have been put in place to deal with it – and rightly so, because it is costing the European Union billions every year. Having said that, I must take issue with my Irish colleague from the GUE/NGL Group, Mr Carthy, who pointed the finger at his own country, Ireland and indeed went into rather a lot of detail, which was totally unacceptable. I just want to remind him that Angel Gurria, Secretary—General of the OECD, said of Ireland, ‘I am very happy, very proud, to say Ireland has been a strong and very exemplary case of adapting and adopting’. We fully support the Commission’s measures on tax transparency. That is why we feel that the OECD BEPS proposals are the best ones right now. We must make sure that we do everything we can to ensure that they are adopted right across the European Union.  We do not think, though, that tax harmonisation is the way to go, because the setting of tax rates is a matter for the Member States’ competence. Having said that, there is huge scope for us to develop and to improve the situation so that all companies pay their fair share of tax within the European Union, and so that we can continue to grow our companies and attract foreign direct investment into the European Union and get jobs and growth, which is necessary.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Much of tax avoidance is caused by laws that make tax loopholes possible, laws that are poorly coordinated internationally and are not effectively applied and controlled. This is where we need to act. And we are in the middle of acting: within the framework of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, within the framework of our special committee on tax rulings, as well as in the future Committee of Inquiry, which we are to launch tomorrow. The OECD has already drawn up a plan that deserves the full support of the European side. It is absolutely right and necessary that the European institutions should now put the OECD recommendations against tax avoidance into concrete legislation. This is the only way to ensure that the Member States apply the measures uniformly, and only in this way can we ensure that international tax coordination gains momentum. A letterbox oasis like panama must not have a future. I think it is extremely important that we Europeans work together at international level for further progress. Nor should our companies have to fear distortions in international competition that would damage the growth capacity and the innovative capacity of the internal market. The OECD is an appropriate platform for international progress in the fight against tax avoidance. It has already achieved significant successes in the exchange of data, and so we want to promote consistent implementation of the OECD recommendation today. As the European Parliament, we are sending another clear signal in the fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance, and we have a clear expectation that the Member States will join us in our commitment.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, clear and simple tax rules and the prevention of specific tax treatments and arrangements outside the rules are essential to create a favourable business environment and a quality functioning single market. Communion, cooperation, effective data exchange between Member States' tax administrations are the cornerstone of establishing a system in which taxpayers will be properly identified and double non-taxation prevented, as we have an even bigger problem than double taxation of non-taxation. However, we must not, in our desire to prevent tax avoidance and to punish evaders, make it more difficult for entrepreneurs to do business and impose new tax and administrative burdens on them. We need a unique global approach and unique solutions, but while respecting the specifics of business conditions in the Member States.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we must put an end to the masking of earnings for multinationals and all those who practice this method under the name of 'optimisation'. We need to introduce income tax in the country where it is carried out. That is why we need to vote on this report. I support measures to combat fraud against large companies, fraud that has led to the closure of many jobs, SMEs, but also to the impoverishment of national budgets and, finally, to the impoverishment of citizens. Commissioner, I appreciate your work, but I am surprised that you are saying that we should not treat tax havens in this directive. Wrong, Commissioner! The speed with which the Commission and the Council act leave room for further evasion and discrimination against SMEs. We don't have to put it off. There are many foreign, multinational investors in my country who have not paid any euro corporation tax for years. If you wanted to treat tax havens separately, you should have already acted. We can't put it off any longer. We need a blacklist of fraudsters at European level, and we need to vote. I congratulate the rapporteur and support this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, corporations should return to society some of what they use by selling their products and services to its members. Tax avoidance and tax evasion are an unfair practice that often does not have enough money for the quality public services that modern states want to provide to their citizens. But the problem is not only in corporations, but also in governments that reach for high taxes because they do not know or do not want to otherwise consolidate public finances.  It is also an unfair practice towards those who create new value, employ people and make our lives easier with their products and services. Taxes must be paid, but they should be reasonable. In 1980, today's EU member states accounted for 30% of global GDP, and today this share is 17%. Accelerated growth is happening in the rest of the world, not more in Europe. If we are going to keep up, we must not drive capital out of the European Union with insane levies.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, citizens pay taxes, craftsmen pay taxes, medium and small businesses pay taxes. Large and multinational companies do not pay taxes or try to avoid it or do everything not to pay it. So, what we really need to do is support the OECD rules, support the Commission's intentions as well, because I am deeply convinced that only in this way, assuming, of course, the quality cooperation of member states, their tax agencies, their tax competences, the tax services of individual member states, can their close coordination largely solve this problem.  The principle is that where profits are made, where profits are made, where everything that needs to be taxed is made, it should be taxed at the point of creation. So, I am convinced that in this way and what this Commission is proposing at the moment is a good step forward to put an end to all tax avoiders and to provide more resources.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, legal tax avoidance by large multinational companies using aggressive tax planning techniques is estimated to cost the Member States of the European Union around EUR 70 billion in lost taxes per year. If this leakage is drastically reduced, the tax burden on small businesses, which create more jobs in proportion to their turnover than large multinationals, could be reduced equally, thus boosting employment and reducing unemployment. The draft anti-tax avoidance directive presented by the European Commission is moving in the right direction but is too timid. We need much stricter common tax policy rules and their immediate implementation in cooperation with the tax authorities of the Member States, in order to effectively combat cross-border tax avoidance. It is unacceptable to impose austerity measures at the expense of the economically weaker, because multinational giants continue to avoid tax burdens.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – The public is, of course, entitled to take decisive action against the practice of tax avoidance. This, of course, requires a thorough tax reform, which will address decisively the origin of the problem. Tax transparency over corporate activities and public reporting by country is, of course, crucial, especially here where companies operate, make a profit and therefore where they pay taxes. Sanctions on banks and other institutions that allow and actually advise on tax havens that promote such practices and which help with tax evasion are also necessary. Public disclosures of all personal tax rulings agreed between tax authorities and large companies are needed, which we have known since, at least since the Luxleaks scandal, this is a widespread practice. Last but not least, the political will, both member states and the European Union, to really tackle the heart of the problem and toe tax havens and large corporations, which make profits at a time when Europe is tightening its belt, is also violating social rights.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the setting of tax rates is a Member State competence and I think where reports such as this go beyond that particular competence, it is incumbent on all of us to take a stance against that. Tax sovereignty, in my view, is a fundamental principle. It should be decided at a Member State level and should not be imposed by this Parliament, or other parliaments of the 28 Member States of the European Union. That is why the way to address the loopholes question – as the coordinator from the EPP, Burkhard Balz, has said, and as has Mr Kelly – is to address it at the OECD level.  The objective of the OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) process that my country is fundamentally in favour of, and has been leading, is to increase the tax take in Europe, cut out aggressive tax planning, but not distort the market in such a way against European businesses in a circumstance where EU businesses pay 15% more than US businesses. We have to address that issue at its source. I believe parts of this proposal are rushed, there are unintended consequences here and, for people who claim to be in favour of tax sovereignty, they should read what is in this report before they vote tomorrow.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hayes, you said that tax sovereignty remains with the Member States. On paper you are right, but when a company is basically playing one Member State against another and uses, for instance, your country or mine basically to lower its tax rates, I would argue that the real tax sovereignty does not lie with the Member State but with the major multinational corporations. That is where it lies, so let us take it back.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think there are things we can cooperate on and I think that has to be done at EU level to reduce aggressive tax planning, but I fundamentally disagree with you. I believe that tax competition is a good thing. It is a way of ensuring that we can promote industrial policy in poorer parts of the European Union, peripheral parts of the European Union, parts of the European Union that did not have colonies, parts of the European Union where there was no industrial revolution, parts of the European Union where there is now a strong industrial and enterprise culture. That is good for Europe. It is good for smaller Member States. It is good for peripheral countries, and it is something we should stand up for and defend.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this proposal is going in the right direction, but in order to revive the European economy, to ensure fair competition in the internal market, in particular for SMEs vis-à-vis multinationals, and to ensure a minimum of fiscal justice, ending the real tax jungle that is in the European Union, we need to go further, as the Luxleaks and Panama Papers revelations impose on us. We need CBCR, CCCTB, to eliminate gimmicks such as patent boxes, and so we are already proposeing the reduction of the interest deductibility limit and the strengthening of switch over clauses to prevent the double non-taxation of dividends, capital gains and profits of companies entering the European Union from third countries. These are unfair schemes that explain the fact that the largest Portuguese companies have chosen the Netherlands as a country of establishment, stealing important tax revenues from my country. The Council must act. Act to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the richness and quality of the proposals put forward this morning. Of course, I cannot respond to each and every one of you, given the number of speakers. I will therefore limit myself to resuming three points, which have been raised repeatedly this morning: the issue of tax evasion in relation to competitiveness, the pro-patent tax regimes and, finally, the general balance of the text, as it emerges before the discussion in the Council next week. I would like to make two small political remarks in an introductory way: one towards Mr Monot, who wondered if we were legitimate to act on this matter. No, we are not only legitimate, we are necessary, and it is typically in this kind of subject that we see what Europe is for, and the anti-Europeans are wrong about the target, because none of our Member States could separately fight tax evasion effectively. We are dealing with phenomena that are international, global, and the answer is, at least, European. And that is why we must have a voluntary Europe, an exemplary Europe; it proves the inanity of nationalism, of withdrawal, of excesses of all kinds or kinds.  I would also like to have a word for Mr Lamberts and the Greens, because I am pleased that this time we are no longer being criticised for not doing what we are doing, and I find it quite positive that there is a move towards taking into account a number of proposals which are of high quality. Moving forward together is all I want, as long as the analyses are of quality and the aims shared. But I go back to my three points. First, the issue of competitiveness and sovereignty and, in particular, the underlying issue of ACCIS (or CCCTB).  Our proposal, I should say, in general, our tax proposals are, I am convinced, balanced. The political will to fight against tax optimisation is not a fight against the company; this is not the case with this directive on or against tax evasion, nor is it the case with the public communication project - and I say publicly - country-by-country information, and I am proud to fight for it from the beginning, I say this in particular to Mrs Joly, who may not have yet understood it or found it. , but since I have been Commissioner, since the first day of my mandate, it has been a cause that I have been defending. I see in different media a particular voice that seems to claim that there is a contradiction between competitiveness and transparency. I am convinced that transparency is a weapon for competitiveness. We are not in an ideological battle for or against the company. Our fight is a fight for fiscal justice, which is also something that deeply serves the interest of the company. How? By ensuring a level playing field, especially for the benefit of our SMEs, which, as everyone knows, are the engine of growth and employment in the European Union. I would add, moreover, that we are committed to measures such as the common and consolidated corporate tax base, but also the resolution of tax disputes, which are important elements in the fight against double taxation.  Finally, I would add that both what we are doing in the fight against tax evasion and the project that I am pursuing - and I will go all the way - to resume in a smarter and perhaps more consensual way ACCIS is not a harmonization of tax rates. This is a debate we had in the Council, for example at the last Ecofin Council with Minister Noonan. What we want is not a minimum tax, it is not forced harmonisation - we respect fiscal sovereignty - but effective taxation. The time when a particular multinational company could, because it had a well-located head office or strategically placed subsidiaries, no longer pay taxes or pay substantial taxes where it creates wealth, that time is a time that must end. Our proposals do not call into question, I stress, the sovereignty of states over the setting of the level of taxation: we do not denied tax competition, but we want it to be harmonious, regulated and effective taxation rules. The proposal you are debating today - I am saying this because, again, I do not want there to be lies, falsehoods, misinterpretations - that there is no mechanism for withholding tax or tax identification. The Commission is still accused of being a super state - or rather Europe to be a super state and the Commission to be a super-government - that is not correct, do not we make a bad trial by accusing us of attacking sovereignty: I think on the contrary that by giving us collective rules, we are strengthening our common sovereignty. On patent-friendly tax regimes, it will be quicker, I repeat what I said in the introduction, we leave it to the Member States to implement their own commitments, that is to say to make their regime coincide with economic reality. At the end of this year, if this process is not satisfactory, we will consider binding measures; the Commission remains, I assure you, very vigilant on this point. This approach, moreover, allows us to remain in full coherence with that of the OECD, as several parliamentarians have called for. Finally, I want to say a word about what awaits us next week in the discussions in the Council after the exchange of views we had this morning. Our proposal, I am sure, not because I am putting it as Commissioner, but because we have worked it, because it is also in the direction of history, it is expected by the public, was good. It is true that you have improved it, and some of these improvements are in the compromise text currently on the Council table. Parliament, as always, will have done a useful job.  Like you, I regret that some provisions have been weakened in the negotiations, such as the transition rules on interest deductibility. I also regret that some are questioned in their entirety, such as the switch-over clause, which I still believe is useful and even necessary. But the text retains strong provisions, such as the rules on controlled foreign companies, strengthened to cover stable establishments, for that matter, which will apply within the European Union and in relations with third countries. This is a great step forward, as the general anti-abuse clause is a great step forward. We live in an institutional system that we know: the Commission proposes; Parliament is a legislator, it also represents the people of Europe; Member States decide, and they must be put under pressure, under pressure to decide the best. As I said in my introduction, I think we have to act and decide now. Your vote should help to keep up the pressure for an ambitious agreement in the Council on 17 June. It is to be credited to your rapporteur, Mr Bayet, it is also to be credited to the debates of this House. I really hope that the message that you are delivering, which I consider to be a converging message, will be consistent with what the Commission is proposing, to be heard next week by the Member States meeting in the Council. For the future proposals that the Commission will make in the coming months, I also think that the spirit that drives us is a useful spirit, a spirit that must endure. As you have understood, as I have come before you every time I come before you, I am struck by the fact that the Commission and Parliament, with, of course, differences on this or that point, with differences in sensitivity on the different benches of this House, have the same purpose, the same ambition, the same will in the fight against tax evasion and that yes, we are also here to make strong proposals, to make courageous proposals that put Member States before their responsibilities. That is what I am taking out of your debate, and you can count on the Commission to relay this to the Council as early as next week.

name: Hugues Bayet
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I thank you all for your speeches, and I thank in particular my fellow shadow rapporteurs, because, in this very political and relatively technical matter, I wanted to underline the quality of their listening and the respect they have shown during all the exchanges. Commissioner, as you have understood, I think that, although the methodology or methods differ somewhat from one political group to another, Parliament's unanimous will is to put an end to this system which allows multinationals not to pay taxes where they do business, to pay almost no tax, because - contrary to what I heard earlier - the average tax in Europe , the levy on corporate income or profits is 2.4%. In the United States, it is 19%. And these are not political figures. If someone doesn't believe me here, they can check the Parliament website. These figures are taken from studies by the OECD and the Commission. That's the reality. Therefore, we do not tax more in Europe than elsewhere, I would even say that it is the opposite.  Of course, this opinion sets out in a single text a whole set of principles that we believe are essential to ending this system. As you have said, in particular, my colleagues Niedermayer or Calvet-Chambon, we are not going to kill the economy, because we obviously differentiate between the real economy and the cheaters - the cheats who hide their profits, the cheats who use mailboxes in Panama, for example. We are not going to over-regulate either, we are just defining a whole series of holes in the legislation, those holes that are used by multinationals to avoid paying taxes. There has also been talk - as you said, Commissioner - of pro-patent tax regimes and tax havens, and my colleagues Joly, De Masi and Valli have told you so; but, Commissioner, this is no longer an administrative or institutional piping problem. What we want are solutions. We cannot continue with a patent regime that currently allows a whole series of multinationals to charge exorbitant amounts for years, mere logos simply to avoid paying taxes. Therefore, 'through the door or through the window', the Commission will have to help us make a difference.  We are counting on you, Commissioner, to influence the Council's decisions, because if the Council does not change its tune and hear our remarks more, it will be solely responsible for the future scandals that will unfortunately still happen in Europe and elsewhere in the world.

name: Le Président. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, June 8, 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I strongly support this future Council directive and the improvements made to it by Parliament.  This Directive lays down rules against tax avoidance practices. According to one study, the aggressive tax optimisation by multinationals deprives all countries of the world of budgets of between EUR 100 billion and EUR 240 billion a year. Dollars. This amount represents between 4% and 10% of the world's corporate tax revenue. Such a huge loss of income is particularly damaging to states by reducing their ability to invest in promoting employment, combating poverty and developing effective global healthcare systems.  As we continue to establish economic and monetary union, we must also harmonise tax systems in the European Union, including in order to limit tax avoidance by multinationals. A fair and effective corporate taxation system must be the cornerstone of the single market. Because if the Member States agree on taxation issues, we will create an efficient and reliable single market. We need a sustainable approach to the introduction of tax systems.  I also support the main objective of Parliament's proposals, namely that companies pay taxes where they make a profit, and I therefore call on the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. – Harmful tax competition, together with the aggressive tax planning of multinationals, causes huge losses in tax revenue for states, reducing their ability to invest and carry out reforms. I have spoken on this subject several times. We need harmonised and coherent regulation that will control savings and promote transparency. The report addresses the sensitive issues of introducing definitions of 'stable organisation', 'double deduction' and 'minimum economic substance'. The elements enabling a company to be defined on the basis of factual criteria, taking into account human and material resources, management autonomy, legal reality and the nature of the activities, must be defined in a harmonised and coherent way. The report deals with the sensitive issue of the digital economy, including entirely dematerialised companies that escape a factual definition but which nevertheless have permanent establishment in a Member State. The clarification of patent legislation is also a good one. Congratulations to the rapporteur on his work.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. " The measures proposed in the proposal would significantly facilitate the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. There are a number of sensible proposals in the proposal that will not only bring cosmetic changes, but will really make tax avoidance more difficult and less difficult. There is always room for improvement, but I am very pleased that Parliament is opting for a firm position. Talk of eradicating tax evasion has been promising, especially since the Panama Papers came to light. What we need now is action. Large international companies pay less tax than small and medium-sized enterprises that conscientiously manage their affairs. European competitiveness requires European companies to be at least on the same footing as international giants. In tax disputes, the losers are honest companies and states that deal with their business fairly. That is why every honest and fair country and company should support measures to combat tax evasion.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. – In the United States of America, each state determines its tax practices. The EU is made up of Member States with the right to formulate their own tax policy, which we ask them to harmonise as having the characteristics of a federal state. If we were United. States of Europe, we would have implemented many more before we studied common tax practices. Enhancing transparency, combating tax fraud and tax evasion, as reflected in the OECD programme to tackle base erosion and profit shifting, is a balanced basis, unlike the commission's and Parliament's proposal to go ahead with calls for further measures. Such advanced measures are the so-called switch over clause for non-exemption from the taxation of income from the sale of shares in a third country and the exit taxation which provides that, when the tax domicile of a company is transferred from one country to another, tax equivalent to fair market value should be paid. The Directive effectively eliminates the comparative advantage of Member States in the context of free competition and works to the detriment of the small countries that have founded their economy for decades by creating a comparative advantage, without even proposing a compensatory framework.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The search for ways of tax optimisation often accompanies the conduct of business. The problem arises when the path to tax optimisation leads by circumventing the applicable laws. The recently revealed Panama Papers scandal demonstrates the extent to which an offer in this area can be made on a large scale. And how differences between national tax systems promote tax avoidance. It should therefore come as no great surprise that the European Commission estimates the annual losses from tax fraud and tax avoidance in the EU at around EUR 1 trillion. Therefore, a good directive is needed to effectively prevent money from leaking out of tax systems. And whether this directive should be a comprehensive set of broad tax avoidance issues or a starting point for further reform of European tax systems. The work on its final shape must also take into account that the measures adopted to combat tax avoidance do not reduce competitiveness on the European market.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr President, the report on anti-tax avoidance practices raises a number of important issues that I would like to draw attention to. The Union's political priorities relating to international taxation should focus mainly on regulating the payment of taxes where profits are generated, i.e. at the place of residence or at the place where the commercial activity is carried out. This approach will help to protect national tax systems more effectively. All the more importantly, according to OECD research and data, unfair and aggressive tax planning for multinationals contributes to the loss of between USD 100 and 240 billion from public budgets annually. Such actions directly lead to the loss of public income, reduce their employment and lead to problems in pension systems. For this reason, the emphasis on combating tax fraud in the report is the right move to condemn the threat to the cohesion of the internal market. In addition, when it comes to legal developments in this area, we should follow the rules on social integrity. It is therefore necessary to oppose the transfer of profits to tax havens and non-payment of profits in the country of origin, in particular multinationals having to pay taxes in good faith. However, a common European tax identification number should not be introduced, as this does not have much to do with the fight against financial fraud, but only unnecessarily limits the sovereignty of the Member States in this area.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on the report by Markus Ferber, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on the markets for financial instruments with regard to certain dates (COM(2016)0056 - C8-0026/2016 - 2016/0033(COD)) (A8-0126/2016), and - the report by Markus Ferber, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on the markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuses and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on the improvement of the Securities Regulation in the European Union and central securities depositors , with regard to certain dates (COM(2016)0057 - C8-0027/2016 - 2016/0034(COD)) (A-0125/2016).

name: Markus Ferber
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I very much regret that the Presidency of the Council is not here, because I wanted to praise it explicitly for the fact that we have managed to make a necessary postponement in a very short time. Now that the Commissioner has the headphones, I can begin my criticism of the Commission. When, in April 2014– and I would remind you of this – we adopted MiFID and MiFIR here in this House in April 2014, we actually felt that we had adopted a cornerstone of European financial market regulation, where we were also able to proudly stand before the electorate at the last European election. It is more than regrettable that we are now debating an extension – more than two years later – and that we are going to decide this lunchtime to postpone the whole thing for another year, because the competent supervisory authority in particular has not been able to obtain the necessary technical infrastructure in good time, and because the Commission, too, has by no means kept to the timetable in the preparation of the delegated acts. , which we agreed in 2014. I would like to say this before: if we had a task to deal with in the last parliamentary term, it was to make the financial markets stable, to ensure consumer protection, to ensure that non-regulated areas such as high-frequency trading are regulated, to ensure that where people were driven speculatively in distress, on commodity futures markets, it was necessary to ensure that non-regulated areas such as high-frequency trading were regulated. , regulations that make this impossible – to name the challenges. It is more than regrettable that the whole thing can only enter into force on 3 January 2018. On the other hand– and I would also like to mention this – since I expressly believe that the Council and Parliament – in a very short period of time – in less time than the Commission took to draw up its proposal for postponement – we have also managed to identify the points that the Commission had overlooked. It hadnot moved a few dates, although they were part of it. And we have done something that has not been seen in Europe before, because we have been able to correct all the problems that we have identified in the context of implementation. I will also say that. It is not the case that the European legislator can have taken into account all the problems in detail in every directive, every regulation it enissues. The fact that we sometimes stand by and say ' we still have to make adjustments in a few places' has succeeded because, on the parliamentary side – and I would like to thank all the staff who have worked together here as shadow rapporteurs in the political groups – we have really succeeded in concentrating on the key points that deserve to be readjusted. So we have not marched into legislation with a belly-load of questions. And the Council – the Dutch Presidency of the Council – has shown the necessary flexibility to have us able to agree on this in a very short time. I think that's certainly on the credit side. We have therefore tried to adjust the problems that were to be faced without having to be included in other legislation elsewhere. This should also be a model for future legislation. Sometimes you still have to readjust, and if you agree on it, you can do that very quickly. I would now ask the Commission to really ensure that we get the missing regulatory technical standards as soon as possible, so that the markets really know what is to come so that the systems can be implemented and adjusted. We want stable financial markets, we want financial markets that have earned the trust of investors and that ensure that excesses are a thing of the past. That is our common mission, and we should work together to do so.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to discuss these amendments to MiFID II, and I recognise there has been a huge amount of hard work done in the European Parliament and in the Council to get these agreed before July. I am particularly grateful to Mr Ferber and to the shadow rapporteurs on this file for having kept up the momentum and having dealt with it so effectively.  I very much agreed with what Mr Ferber said, that this package is a key part of our financial reforms, increasing the transparency of markets and improving their oversight. It responded to the G20 agreement back in Pittsburgh to reform derivatives and commodity markets, to make those markets work better, to make them more resilient, to make them more stable – and also of course to strengthen investor protection, not only by ensuring that investors have the right information, but also by introducing stronger rules to avoid conflicts of interest.  So we are agreed on the goal, and if that is the goal, to achieve it we need this legislation to be implemented properly, in a way which gives legal certainty, and which does not disrupt markets that provide investment to the wider economy and help businesses manage their risks.  This reform was always going to be an ambitious reform. It calls for data from hundreds of trading venues, from some 15 million financial instruments. Given the scale of that challenge, the complexity of the IT systems that were needed, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) judged – rightly, in my view – that more time was needed to get it right, not to undermine the new framework but to make sure that it works properly when it kicks in.  So, at their request, it is true that we proposed to extend by a year, until January 2018, the deadline for MiFID II entering into application, and I am grateful to the European Parliament and to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for its support in accepting what I see as being a common-sense proposal. Like Mr Ferber, I am also glad that we have avoided revisiting the key aspects of the package that was agreed just two years ago, but that we have got some technical amendments in this package which improve the quality of the rules. Further clarification of the scope of the transparency requirements on package transactions was an issue raised by ESMA when they submitted their regulatory technical standards (RTS), and here I think that Parliament’s amendment helps us get the balance right. It ensures that the pre-trade transparency regime continues to apply where it is needed, without imposing unnecessary burdens where it is not.  It was also right to exempt securities financing transactions (SFTs) from transparency obligations. SFTs are not price forming and they will of course be regulated by the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation in the future, and so increased transparency in this area would create new burdens but serve little purpose. With the amendment on own account exemption we are acting to make sure that non-financial companies do not fall unnecessarily within the scope of MiFID II and its administrative and capital requirements.  We are now working hard to get the majority of MiFID II’s large number of level 2 measures adopted in June, and I completely agree with Mr Ferber that we have to keep the pace up. In a handful of areas we have asked ESMA to look again at their proposals reflecting issues that have also been raised by the European Parliament. Taken together, I believe that these measures should make MiFID II more effective. Member States will have to transpose the elements of MiFID II they are responsible for by 3 July 2017. The industry would need to start complying from January 2018. I believe that this is a sensible way forward to ensure the smooth implementation of this legislation and to bring more transparency, better consumer protection and more efficiency to markets in Europe.

name: Othmar Karas
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. We do not just want, we urgently need stable financial markets. This has been expressed because stable financial markets are a prerequisite for the public and our customers regaining confidence in the financial market. The prerequisite for stable financial markets is regulation, where necessary is more transparency and control. In the new regulation of MiFID and MiFIR, investor protection was the central concern of the European Parliament, and increased investor protection can only be enforced if the technical conditions are met. These technical requirements did not exist. The rapporteur pointed out that, on the one hand, there was a gap in supervision, and on the other hand, the Commission was in default in presenting delegated acts. That is why Parliament has de facto used the post-match period to erase the implementation problems. Mr Ferber has pointed this out, and it is a sincere thanks to him, for using this extra time with the Council. Although we have used this time, although the implementation problems have now been corrected and the legislation has been restructured, we need an extension to stay in the footballer's language. It has to be said that even in the extended period, the deadlines are tight and the detailed work is extensive. Whoever now lets the reins grind, will have a nasty awakening. The appeal goes to the Commission and to the companies to use the time gained and the refurbishment of the project so that we finally have more stable financial markets from the new period of 3 January 2018. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. We agree that we need rules and, moreover, transparent, clear rules. But what do you think the European Union can do if a national bank in a Member State anoises all the rules with noble simplicity and allows a wide variety of operations and then does not check them later and there is no supervision: this is the Hungarian National Bank. Moreover, eur 1 billion is the amount that has disappeared from the Hungarian market completely out of control.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, as you know, central banks are independent. In the case of all central banks, national parliaments and the national public are the inspectors, and in the context of the European Union, it is the European Parliament. Therefore, if problems arise, they will be discussed publicly and corrected within the limits of legal possibilities and responsibilities.

name: Anneliese Dodds
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, of all the pieces of legislation put in place after the 2008 financial crisis, the Markets and Financial Instruments Directive and regulation are some of the most wide-ranging and most important. As Mr Ferber said, these pieces of legislation are incredibly ambitious in their scope. They aim to make markets more transparent, offer better protection to consumers, regulate new high-frequency trading techniques and stop speculation in vital commodities like food and fuel. All measures which, sadly, were not in place before the financial crisis and for which citizens across Europe paid the price. Partly because of the sense of scope and ambition, it has proved difficult for the European Securities and Markets Authority to set up all of the technical infrastructure needed for the legislation to go live on the original date of 3 January 2017. This is inevitably disappointing. Undoubtedly, it would have been better if Parliament had been made aware of this problem much sooner than we were, but at the same time, with a new regime of this scale, it is vital that we get things right. That is why I am prepared to support the proposal to postpone the application of the new regime by 12 months. However, I want to reiterate, this is not an invitation for the European Securities Markets Expert Group (ESME) or the European Commission or the financial services industry to breathe a sigh of relief and do nothing. We have been told that 12 months was the minimum delay needed. If that is the case then every single day we will need to count in order to ensure that all is ready for the new go—live date of 3 January 2018; to be absolutely clear, there will be no second delay.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank Marcus Ferber, the rapporteur, and all the shadow rapporteurs for working so cooperatively together. In doing so we have been able to send a very clear message from this House about exactly what we expect from ESME and the Commission during these additional 12 months. First, we expect regular updates and progress reports. We want to know exactly how the delay is being used to make sure that on 3 January 2018 the new improved financial services regime of method 2 comes into full effect. Second, we expect our concerns about some of the secondary legislation to be taken on board. We have been very clear over the last two years, about what these concerns are. If they are not reflected in the final level 2 legislation, then we have the right and the responsibility to reject what we have been sent. For me the most important parts of the level 2 framework are dealing with commodity derivatives. It is unacceptable that speculators and financial markets can so manipulate the markets that they drive up the price of food for shoppers or damage the incomes of farmers. Method 2 very clearly states that this kind of speculation must stop and so places limits on the size of position that any one player can hold at a given time. It is in the secondary legislation that those limits will be defined. I have said time and time again that I want to see the limits as low and as strict as possible, especially for the most liquid markets. The original ESME proposals were not good enough and I am glad to see they were sent back by the Commission. But the Commission did not take on board all of Parliament’s concerns. We will be looking very closely to make sure that it has done so by the time the draft come back to us for adoption or rejection. We listened to ESME and the Commission when it came to their concerns about implementation; they now need to show that they have listened to us when it comes to our concerns about secondary legislation.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The aim of this proposal is to postpone the entry into force of Directive 2014/65 of the European Union of 3 January 2017 by 12 months, i.e. 3 January 2018. In view of the complexity of the data to be collected and processed under this solution and the need to complement the necessary technical infrastructure, as well as to ensure that national and Union stakeholders complete their obligations, it is necessary to postpone this period by 12 months. The infrastructure deployment process involves five stages: business requirements, followed by specifications, development, testing, and deployment. The legal situation, on the other hand, will be known by July this year. Due to the correct implementation of the security of this system, it is appropriate to extend the time limit.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Markus Ferber, for the joyful and constructive way in which he has guided us as a negotiating team through these difficult, tough discussions. They also have enormous consequences not only for the financial markets themselves, but also for all users, all European consumers and all the companies affected by this. Because we are dealing here with the difficulty of finding the right balance. On the Commission's side, of course, there is the fine aim of the Capital Markets Union. We want more jobs, we want more economic growth. We all wholeheartedly support that. The financial sector must also make an important contribution to this, by making it easier to finance and to flow the money needed as a lubricant. We are, of course, also dealing with Commissioner Timmermans' better regulatory agenda on the Commission's side. That's very difficult in a complicated case like MiFID/MiFIR, which is incredibly technical. Especially when you consider that, on the other hand, we naturally stand up for European citizens, consumers who want to get good information when it comes to financial products or their investments, so that they can also make a good decision in this area.  How do you weigh those interests? We have seen that this is a struggle, that it has not been too easy and that it has been delayed as a result. We understand that. It is more important to get good, workable regulation than to get it quickly. We also felt the risks were too great to disrupt markets, so we fully support this delay. However, of course you have to use that delay – as Mr Dodds just indicated – to make these regulations really better and workable.  Also, there are still issues around - I'll just say - a definition of research. What is research? That is the crux of these regulations, it is not just a detail somewhere. So we will have to find good solutions to get as much clarity as possible. Unambiguousness to those parts of the regulations that are essential. Because we don't get away with giving people all kinds of unnecessary information. It should be relevant information, not information about transactions that may never take place, but relevant information for investment decisions. To add Einstein: not everything you can measure is of value and not everything of value, you can measure. We will always have to use our common sense. It is also good that there is constant contact with consumer protection organisations, but also with the financial sector itself, to ensure that we end up with workable regulations that benefit consumers and investors, and which do not have to burden the sector too much because it creates too much administrative burden.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In short, almost a decade after the onset of the financial crisis, the rules against financial speculation have still not been sufficiently implemented. My group gave its opposition to the technical postponement. However, the majority groups have now tabled amendments to partially improve MiFID under pressure from the financial lobby. With regard to the common positions, speculation, particularly on commodity derivatives, is still a number of points in line with the decisions of the last Parliament, despite a number of protests by Parliament to the securities and supervisory authority ESMA and the Commission. Thus, market fluctuations are not taken into account when determining the position limits and it is still possible for individual traders to control more than one third of the total market volume. This means that we are falling behind the US in position limits. The EU therefore remains ill-positioned for the next financial crisis, which is as safe as the Amen in the Church. With the Capital Markets Union and growing inequality in Europe, the seeds for the next crisis have already been laid.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, this summer it will be nine years since the financial crisis began. Even today, the nominal volume of financial markets is ten times the size of the real economy on a daily basis. Ten times! In other words, for a dollar of trade, you speculate for ten dollars. Needless to say, these activities are unnecessary and, in reality, harmful to the real economy. In particular, Anneliese Dodds mentioned, there is speculation on a daily basis about raw materials and especially food raw materials.  It is incredible that a text adopted in February 2014 with a view to being implemented at the beginning of 2017, that is, three years later, is still not in a position to be implemented in six months and which the Commission is asking, eighteen months after the adoption of the text: "Can we not postpone for another year?" This shows the state of readiness and above all the hyper-complexity of the text - and, make no mistake, complexity is often the vehicle of laxity. Simple legislation is often much stricter than hyper-complex legislation. Because of this complexity, we are being asked for an additional one year. And if it were just that, you could say, "Either they were pretty unfe professional, let's give them another year", knowing that this year more would be a year more speculation, especially on food products.  But it's not just about that. As luck would have it, this text was an opportunity to convey a number of new exemptions that will further reduce the transparency of financial markets. In other words, by inducing these exceptions, we confirm the suspicion that these delays are being used to weaken a text which already did not have the necessary level of ambition. Therefore, we will vote against this deadline. If it had only been the deadline, we would have voted reluctantly in favour, but because of the additional exemptions that this text was the vehicle for, we will refuse to vote for it.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too understand that it is very complicated to try to regulate the financial market, but all this time we are taking to do so is something that the citizens do not have at the moment.  As Mr Lamberts said, the financial market has even paradoxically increased since the great crisis that took place in 2008-2009, precisely because this type of practice has been encouraged. This is also what the Commission is doing, by relaunching the Capital Markets Union and the financial market a little, instead of prioritising banking separation and the real economy. It is a demonstration that this Europe, this Juncker Europe, is a Europe that very often represents the strong interests of banks and interests other than European citizens. With regard to this proposal to extend – as I have already said – this is not good for us. Among other things, we have also taken advantage of the inclusion of changes – as my colleague from the Greens have always said – and these changes go to exempt, on own-account transactions by banks and financial operators, the transparency that they should have on derivative financial instruments, such as SFT (Securities Financing Transactions) and EFP, which are instruments on which, however much they may cause costs to banks , banks must be transparent because they are systemic bodies and when they need banks, they obviously knock on the door of governments and taxpayers. So if we exempt – and Parliament and some groups are in favour, but we are not – from transparency the banks on certain transactions, those responsible will then, after history, pull them out. Therefore, I recommend, we need to act very firmly on banks and financial regulation. Unfortunately, with a Commissioner like you, Mr Hill, I think this is very difficult.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner Hill, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has We are agreeing today that the reform of the securities market, that is, the regulation of financial instruments, will be postponed by one year. That is a good thing, although I share the rapporteur's criticism in substance and it should not be a carte blanche, neither for the Commission nor for ESMA, to delay things here.
