The fact is, however, that neither the supervisory authorities nor the financial industry are ready for implementation in the coming year. The set of rules is too complex, and MiFID II should finally draw the right conclusions from the 2007-2009 financial crisis and take into account the rapid progress in securities trading. The aim of MiFID is to create more transparency and, in particular, to strengthen investor protection. This will require stronger and stricter reporting requirements for banks and trading houses. The raw materials industry is also affected, as has already been mentioned today. Commodity traders will in future be treated like financial institutions and their hedging operations will be backed up with equity capital. This is based on two size criteria: the share of speculative derivative segoing transactions in the volume of trade and a market share test. Commodity traders may only have certain thresholds for goods in certain categories of goods, and 3% or 20% for emission allowances for oil products. However, commodity traders are not banks, as the Commissioner has said: we want to readjust here, and we need to find a regulation here, because regulating the raw materials sector could lead to serious financing problems, especially if prices are rising.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, I do not think anyone will disagree that, like so many sectors of the economy, the market for financial instruments needs specific regulations to make it safer for all those who choose to operate in it; However necessary some of these arrangements may be, however much any gaps have been foreseen, the truth is that the everyday life of the ordinary citizen will not be affected for the better. Unemployment is rising and poverty is knocking on the door every day for more families. Unfortunately, in the midst of the crisis that Europe has been going through for the last ten years, citizens are demanding drastic solutions to their daily problems. But reports such as those we are discussing today do not offer these solutions. We should therefore focus on tackling the many serious and chronic problems of European citizens beyond targeted interventions.  The aim of the report is to strengthen investor protection by establishing strong organisational and behavioural requirements – but issues of little importance to the vast majority of the public. The reason why the citizens of Europe have chosen us to represent them here is to provide solutions to their daily problems and they are waiting for results, which unfortunately this House finds very difficult to present, since there is very little you have managed to do for the benefit of the many and not the few to date.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, I think it is necessary to extend it, which most of us will vote for. At the same time, however, I consider it a defeat, we might say, of the European institutions, in the sense that we are not witnessing a reality at the rate at which it is evolving. We have an institutional slowness in dealing with specific problems. We had the international financial crisis of 2008, which the European Union paid very dearly for and which we can say has changed through the social and political consequences that the composition of the European Parliament itself has had. So we risk intervening in 2018, with no guarantee that until then there will be no new financial crisis.  There is a good chance of a new financial crisis. We only have to look at what is happening in China, for example. We only have to look at the problems of the banking system in the European South. We only have to look at the difficulties that banks have with negative interest rates, the difficulties of insurance companies and even the difficulties that will arise in the United States and the United Kingdom, two powerful financial centres because of political developments. So in my view we need a transitional defence, that is, how to go from one period to the next, of stricter control, without getting too much damage.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote successfully concludes a crucial process for the completion of regulation on the European Union's financial markets, of which MiFID and MiFIR are the essential pillars. Parliament and the Council reached an important agreement to ensure stability and certainty for market players, supervisors and Member States, accepting the Commission's proposal to delay the implementation of the legislative package and the transposition of the directive by one year, allowing operators and authorities to adapt the IT infrastructures for the collection of data necessary for the implementation of the new framework. Parliament has been cohesive in getting this process concluded quickly and effectively. Thanks to the initiative of Parliament and the rapporteur, with the support of the negotiating team, this quick fix was also an opportunity to make specific amendments to the two texts, which will make their application more consistent with the objectives of legislative intervention and with the whole regulatory framework. In this regard, I would like to call on Mrs Lamberts to read the texts rather than make polemics that seem to me to be completely improper if we read the nature of the changes that have been made, which go in the direction of making the legislation more coherent and effective. Among other things, I would point out that for securities financing operations, they are already covered by the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation and are not essential to pricing. MiFID legislation is a key element in the effort to harmonise the Union's financial architecture and the creation of the Single Rulebook, which is a prerequisite for the creation of a single market in Union investment services and capital markets. That is why we reiterate to the Commission the need to adopt rapidly the second-level legislation necessary to complete the regulatory framework and ensure its full implementation from January 2018.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! Today's proposal represents a necessary intervention in the functioning of our securities market. That is why we are voting in favour. We consider it essential that we take action against high-frequency trading, which has led to huge destabilisation of the financial market, and that we take action against algorithm trading and futures trading. One thing in particular is my concern: the trading of derivatives in food, which originally introduced the possibility of commodity derivatives, in order for farmers to recover the profits from future harvests sooner. We saw how it developed into huge bubbles, which led to increases in the price of food, which have had disastrous consequences, especially in the developing countries.  It is good that, after all, years after the financial crisis, but better late than never, we are now having these areas regulated so that we have a securities market, a financial market that operates on fair and reasonable terms and not under the jungle rules.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I think that almost ten years after the financial crisis, it is time for us to start to stop gilding the pill because the discussions we have had here, and the Commissioner has tried to justify the unjustifiable, but the truth is that financial speculation remains virtually unchanged, there have been no major changes after ten years.  Commissioner, you are talking about 50 million financial instruments and that all this is very complex, because it certainly is, that is why we need to regulate. There are two weights and two measures. There was no problem, all the rush in the world to punish citizens who had no blame on the financial crisis. With regard to financial markets, we depute, deputize, leave market changes unchanged, market volume unchanged, exemptions for other instruments, 50 million, of course they are. We need to re-re- re- we rein, the financial markets have taken over our politics and our democracy.  So we don't need any more excuses to continue to show citizens that they are absolutely right not to trust the European project, because in fact we need to restore democracy and politics.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Mr President, the MiFID Directive aims in particular to prevent banks from continuing to sell anything to anyone, i.e. high-risk assets to uninformed and vulnerable customers. The report that we will vote on just now intends to postpone the implementation of this directive until 2018, ten years after the subprime crisis. Thus, we still want to give extra time to banks that abuse the credulity of individuals and sometimes fragile companies. One of two things: either the European Securities and Markets Authority, the AEMF, does not have the authority to establish serious financial regulation, or it gives the major international banks an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations. In all cases, in this area as in others, we should not make untenable promises, because in the impossible no one is kept. How can the Commission combat the rapacity of banks, when it is constantly encouraging the most unbridled free trade? In reality, beyond the big statements of principle, it is your ultraliberal software that prevents you from better framing the activities of speculative finance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – I am sorry, of course, that the implementation of the directive will not take place at the beginning of next year, as was otherwise envisaged. However, I agree that if this will allow for greater consumer protection, then this extension is also justified. The past financial crisis, which has taught us a lot, has also shown many weaknesses in the multinational economic framework. In addition to eliminating these vulnerabilities, we must also ensure that market barriers are removed and discriminatory practices are eliminated. Once we get rid of them, we will also achieve greater protection for our consumers. And, of course, more efficient financial markets. I agree that we need to establish more reliable and efficient market structures and, of course, greater control and greater competence over these markets is also necessary. All this, of course, towards and in the light of greater consumer protection. ESMA, together with the competent national authorities, should establish a common data system to achieve, not least, more transparency.  Of course, on the basis of everything that has been said, I can conclude that the amendments proposed in the report are justified and support.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is important that the Parliament and the Council have managed to find a compromise on this Directive. MiFID II and MiFIR are two of the biggest pieces of financial services regulation that needed to be resolved post-crisis. Our aim was to protect the investors, increase transparency and tackle speculation. That is why we have introduced new rules here.  However, it is regrettable that the issues around the IT infrastructure make it necessary to postpone MiFID and MiFIR by a year. I echo what has already been said, that the Commission should not take this as a carte blanche. I expect clear and regular reporting on the progress towards the new implementation date of 2018, and I would be deeply disappointed it we were not able to be ready by 2018. I do not think we could tolerate another delay.  Hand in hand, we need to see progress on the Level-2 measures stemming from these, taking into account the concerns that Parliament has raised, in particular the new regime in trading in commodity derivatives. Our intention is to ensure that the financial traders in commodity markets do not drive up food and fuel prices, which affect ordinary people, not just in my constituency, but across the whole of the EU. Finally, I expect the Commission to set the detail of the new regime in the Level 2 and not water down the ambitious agreement we have achieved at Level 1.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús aontaím leis an gCoimisinéir Hill gur gá an pacáiste seo a chur siar go dtí dáta nua an 1 Eanáir 2018 mar tá sé i bhfad níos fearr rud a dhéanamh go déanach agus i gceart ná é a dhéanamh go luath agus mícheart. Dá bhrí sin tá an moladh sin ciallmhar. This is extremely important legislation for a European Union that is in recovery, following the huge hit taken in the global recession. I welcome the move towards well—regulated and well—functioning financial markets in the EU. Financial markets are vital for our economy and for generating the funds needed for growth and recovery to occur. This is clear. However, these markets need to be well regulated, as failure to do so can have detrimental effects on the economy. I particularly welcome legislation on improving investor protection. Measures to prevent conflicts of interest and to improve transparency in this regard were long overdue and are much needed, and I look forward to their implementation. New stringent requirements in communication and disclosure will contribute greatly to reducing dishonest practices and hopefully eliminate the possibilities for opportunistic intermediaries to exploit less—experienced investors and consumers for personal financial gain. In a wider context, this legislation will surely play a big part in stabilising our economy for the years ahead. It should help us to prevent speculative bubbles from occurring once again which would plunge us back into recession. I welcome these measures.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the texts we are discussing relate to complex regulations developed in the past few years as a response to the demands and needs of financial markets in Europe and elsewhere. They provide us with an opportunity to reflect on the financial services sector, to which they relate. In recent years, especially since Lux Leaks and the Panama Papers scandals, financial services have become associated in people’s minds with tax evasion, aggressive tax avoidance, money laundering and corruption. They have been seen as operated by unscrupulous bankers and accountants whose only commitment is to greed and the promotion of tax havens. There is some truth in that impression, but it is very far from being the whole truth. The globalised economic system in which we live, and the Europe which is being built, need robust financial services to ensure that available resources are being effectively utilised. This truism needs to be repeated. Here, we are devising new methods that make financial services more geared to today’s and tomorrow’s needs. Just as importantly, however, we need new measures to ensure that the best practice in financial services is defined by professional behaviour which is committed to the highest ethical and social standards. At present, we do not have that assurance.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to the point where we are, it is inevitable that we will arrive at 3 January 2018 to ensure more effective and transparent data collection infrastructures for both ESMA and national authorities. The truth is that we must be more cautious when introducing reforms of this magnitude without setting credible and certain time targets, without having adequate instruments to guarantee the transition phase, for example by upgrading ESMA with financial and human resources. This helps investors, savers and consumers and makes the battle to make financial markets more transparent. We cannot set ambitious targets in our legislation and leave it to itself. That is why the postponement of a year is not a give-up, but a necessity that should not be wasted by the various institutions.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, the regulation of financial markets is obviously an imperative which brings together almost all European citizens, who have witnessed and often the victims of successive crises, notably the one in 2008, which demonstrated the exorbitant place that some very complex financial instruments had taken in the direction of our economies.  I hear the arguments in favour of deferral, but I insist on one point: this postponement cannot be a blank-seing given to the Commission to postpone, or even abandon, measures that are absolutely necessary. I am thinking in particular of the scandal of speculation on raw materials and food. Finally, I think there is one last thing that needs to be addressed. We cannot close one door to open another, and the concern we have, particularly within the Social Democratic Group, is the indiscriminate liberalisation of certain practices such as securitisation, which is now envisaged in the framework of the capital markets union project. We will therefore be vigilant on this point, but, again, this text is moving in the right direction.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Mr President, protecting consumers, investors and citizens, restoring confidence, combating all forms of speculation and ensuring transparency in financial transactions are obviously goals to be achieved as soon as possible. The 2008 crisis should have further informed us of the risks of an uncontrolled financial system that penalizes the real economy. This money, which flows at the speed of light, without any impact on the real economy, makes me angry. How can Europe let this happen? It is time to pull together and implement effective legislation that prevents speculation and restores confidence to European citizens. It is said that the devil is hiding in the details, and the new time frame requested should allow, as I understand it, to settle these details. Let us hope that there will not be another financial crisis in the meantime.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the pricing of financial instruments and contracts depends to a large extent on how accurate the reference data will be. Competent authorities should provide reference data on financial instruments and, for this reason, the European Securities and Markets Authority and national competent authorities should establish a system of financial instrument reference data in order to facilitate the data processing process. Of course, the competent authorities will operate under appropriate supervision so that there is full transparency, correct pricing conditions and, of course, the elimination of any case of market abuse. Moreover, the Commission has already adopted requirements relating to the authorisation and operation of investment services and data reporting undertakings. However, since the infrastructure for collecting these necessary data is not ready by the dates laid down, the regulation proposed by the Commission may be transposed one year later in order to complete the system procedures.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, conciliations in the markets for financial instruments by their nature contain a great deal of aggressive risk. Impudence is no excuse. But it is a huge moral sin, if you will, a criminal offence when it is a field of exploitation of people who are simply looking for investment opportunities. Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of large banking giants and governments, in order to raise money for citizens who are not depositors.  A great example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the government at the time with lies and false hopes, invested their labors in ghost companies and bubble shares.  The European Securities and Markets Authority must first and foremost enforce transparency rules and best rules for the execution of transactions. More importantly, however, it must establish a sanctions framework against those who use unfair means and even misinformation, resulting in market distortions and the loss of money for private investors.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start with the basic point about good regulation – the principles of good regulation –which are to set realistic deadlines and to hit them. I hate missing deadlines. I hear very clearly the views that have been expressed. I am very grateful for the support on this occasion, and the common-sense argument for having the delay in order to make sure that this extremely complex piece of legislation can be properly introduced is, I think, the right decision. But I am completely committed to making sure that we hit the deadlines that we set, so they need to be realistic. Then we need to implement them. So far as the specifics are concerned, we are working to get the majority of these Level 2 measures adopted in June. We have already adopted 11 RTSs. We will get the bulk of the remaining RTSs done this month.  It is the case that we have asked in just a handful of areas for ESMA to look again at its proposals, and in many cases that reflects issues that have been raised with us by Parliament. So we are looking again at some of the transparency requirements for bond and derivative markets. You asked for a more cautious approach and, in our view, that is warranted. On the important issue of position limits, which a number of Members raised, where agricultural derivatives are concerned we want to make position limits more sensitive, both for highly liquid markets and for less liquid markets. I understand that there are some in Parliament who want to restrict excessive volatility and speculation in vital commodities via the position limit regime. ESMA, as you know, has come back with a revised proposal, taking on board our ideas to make the limit regime more tailored to the underlying commodity type. We welcome that and now the task is to assess the merits of its proposal, balancing how the revised regime addresses excessive price movements in commodities, whilst maintaining liquidity in the markets. Also, for non-financial companies we want to make sure that the scope of the rules is appropriate and that they do not apply to those using financial markets responsibly to hedge their risk or where their financial business is genuinely small, relative to their core business.  In terms of the question I was asked about the implementation of the Level 2 measures, yes, I am determined to do that as fast as possible. Yes, I accept entirely that we are not looking for carte blanche. Also, of course, I will make sure that my officials keep the negotiating team fully informed of the progress that we are making.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, iwould like to thank all those who have taken part in the debate. I would just like to make a few points clear. Firstly, as rapporteur, I would never have agreed to a postponement if it had only been the industry that called for it. So anyone who says that we have followed the industry here – if I may say so, is lying to this House and lying to the public. It is a question of ESMA's failure to create the technical infrastructure and to create the conditions for national supervisory authorities to fulfil their role. Secondly, the two reports on which we are about to vote are not about the issue of the position limits for commodity futures. This is a regulatory technical standard where we are still in discussions – Lord Hill has just taken it up – where we as a Parliament have clearly described our position and where we are now waiting to see whether the Commission meets these requirements. But that is not part of the current vote. Thirdly, we have not taken up any point on the points that we have taken up, because the industry has called for it, but because over the last two years we – the shadow rapporteurs and I – have met monthly with ESMA and the Commission and discussed time and again how individual problems can still be resolved. And the points where ESMA or the Commission told us 'this is not possible to solve this because the directive does not exist', we have taken up the points. And we have taken up one last point – and I will also say this: within the framework of the Prospectus Directive proposed by the Commission, a change is being made to MiFID, and we have now done so in MiFID, and then it does not have to be done in the Prospectus Directive. These are not requirements of industry, but better regulation, as we have agreed here. That is why I firmly reject the accusation that we are only creating new loopholes for industry here. It is untrue and unfair to say so here. I would like to thank all those who have worked constructively. That gives me courage for the future. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place immediately. (The sitting was suspended for a few minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to associate myself, together with all of you, with the words of President Schulz, who yesterday, at the opening of the plenary session, recalled my colleague Gianluca Buonanno who died in recent days as a result of a road accident. We want to be close to family, friends and, of course, to the political group of which Mr Syley was a member. Buonanno. The relevant Swedish authorities have announced the election of Jakop Dalunde to replace Peter Eriksson as a Member of Parliament, with effect from 7 June 2016. Pursuant to Rule 3(2) of the Rules of Procedure, until its powers have been verified or a decision has been taken on a dispute, Jakop Dalunde sits with full rights in Parliament and its bodies, provided that he has previously stated that he has not held any office incompatible with that of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I propose the following oral amendment: "The European Parliament proposes that an arbitration mechanism entrusted to the President of the European Commission be set up to ensure policy coherence and that, in the event of a divergence between the various EU policies, it is up to the President of the Commission to fully assume his political responsibilities on the main guidelines and to decide under the UNION's commitments on CPD."  I will tell you why: if we accept this amendment, we are merely confirming our position voted by a large majority in 2013 as part of my report on the CPD. If we refuse to do so, we are depriving ourselves of an indispensable tool in terms of policy coherence, in particular because of its ability to arbitration or, in the words of our former colleague Jean-Louis Bourlanges, we would contribute, if refused, to ensure that the CPD remains a kind of knife without a blade to which the handle is missing.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The framework convention on tobacco control, signed in 2003, aims to reduce, through a global approach, diseases and deaths due to smoking. It is therefore clear that the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products is an essential component in achieving these objectives. In short, the contracting parties are obliged to put in place all the necessary measures to combat the phenomena of illegal production, counterfeiting and smuggling. On the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour, considering these practices not only harmful to the EU Erario, but above all extremely harmful to the health of citizens.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation on the protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products at the World Health Organization Framework Convention. Indeed, through provisions such as licensing, monitoring and tracing of products, monitoring of the entire production and transport chain or imposing sanctions against violators, this text aims to establish international cooperation by imposing principles without forcing Member States to implement them.   Unlike the EU texts, this report respects the sovereignty of the Member States and pursues a goal that I support. I regret, however, that it is the EU that is a signatory to the agreement and not the Member States.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a huge step in the right direction in the fight against smuggled and illicit tobacco products. Tobacco products, both illicit and legal, cause unfathomable harm to the health and well-being of citizens. Smoking has recently been identified as the single greatest cause of preventable illness and premature death in the north of Ireland. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a scourge that affects all of Europe and Ireland is no exception. It costs the north of Ireland UKP 450 million each year. Internal company documents reveal that smuggling became an integral part of tobacco companies’ business strategies and according to Customs, Imperial Brand, the world’s fourth-largest international cigarette company, accounted for 55% of the 17 billion cigarettes smuggled into ‘Britain and the north’ every year. The passing of this report means that the European Union is now under pressure to ratify and enforce the World Health Organisation’s Protocol on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products. When ratified this protocol will see countries collaborate in the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is intended to send a signal to the Member States to ratify, as soon as possible, the additional protocol to the World Health Organisation's Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. If this text is to become legally binding, we must not forget that at least forty ratifications are necessary. Currently, only seventeen countries in the world have ratified it, including only five European states.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an agreement to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as it is the first multilateral initiative to tackle the illegal trade in tobacco and cigarette smuggling by ensuring supply chains. It is also an important step in the fight against public health and the fight against tax evasion.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, or FCTC for short, is the first global health agreement. It was created to counteract the widespread consumption of tobacco worldwide. Above all, it focuses on the illicit trade in tobacco products, which is not only a criminal act, but also a serious health hazard, because every 6 seconds a person dies from a smoking-related disease. The Protocol on the Suppression of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol) regulates the following important points: the establishment of a tracking and tracing system, the regulation of internet sales and the recording requirements. While there is already a comprehensive EU strategy to combat cigarette smuggling, it is important to note that a significant proportion of illegal tobacco products in the EU come from third countries. For this reason, it is now important to make the protocol signed by the EU in December 2013 legally binding. However, this will not happen until it has been ratified by 40 contractors, which has not yet happened. I therefore support Parliament's call for ratification by the EU and its Member States in order to allow it to enter into force quickly.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2003, a WHO framework convention on tobacco control was signed at the World Health Assembly. The WHO Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was signed on 20 December 2013 subject to its conclusion at a later date. The protocol calls for combating smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The objective is to protect public health and recover tax revenues. The text calls for licensing, monitoring and tracing of products, monitoring the entire manufacturing and transport chain, and putting in place sanctions against violators. Unlike the texts of the European Union, this protocol respects the sovereignty of the Parties, imposes principles but not the precise way to implement them, and calls for proper international cooperation. I regret that it is the European Union that signs this text and not the Member States, but I can only agree with the objectives and with the text of this protocol, in which I therefore voted.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I agree with the principle the UK Government should be signing us up to the WHO framework rather than the EU signing us up giving the British people no option. I abstained on this issue.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to give the European Union the legitimacy and the weapons to effectively combat the illicit trade in tobacco products. This illicit trade often funds illegal practices and is done to the detriment of the consumer through random application of standards for the health of users of these products.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products is criminal activity that poses a serious threat to public health and huge losses of revenue to the EU in unpaid taxes. The Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol) was adopted by the FCTC in 2012 and constitutes the only multilateral regulatory initiative in combatting illicit tobacco trading and needs to be ratified by 40 parties for it to enter into force. The protocol contains a set of rules and policies in the field of fighting illicit trade in tobacco and aims to make the supply chain, products, and equipment of tobacco secure in the global system. The ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and improve the fight against the illegal trade of tobacco products. I voted in favour of the resolution to give the European Parliament’s consent to the conclusion of the protocol and forward its position to the Council, Commission, and Member States to ensure the quick ratification so the protocol can enter into force and implementation.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global health agreement. It is designed in response to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to address certain causes of this phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products is the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area and must be ratified by the European Union for its entry into force.  Illicit trafficking in tobacco products and cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to public health. In addition, unpaid taxes and duties are suffering huge revenue losses in the EU. The proposed protocol aims to ensure a safe supply chain for tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment by establishing a global monitoring and tracking system.  I agree that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will be beneficial to public health and will contribute to the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2003, a WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was signed at the World Health Assembly, followed by a protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products, signed on 20 December 2013. This protocol calls for combating smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products, in order to protect public health and to put an end to what constitutes a significant shortfall in Member States' tax revenues, through the monitoring and tracing of products and closer control of the manufacturing and transport chain.  I therefore voted in favour of this text, which constitutes a definitive acceptance of the measures advocated by the protocol: it calls for proper international cooperation that preserves the sovereignty of States, enacting a number of principles but giving States full latitude as to how to apply them.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global treaty in this area of tobacco control. The protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products is the main global tobacco initiative. It contains a set of measures, rules and strategies to combat this illicit trade. To address this phenomenon, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption of a series of measures by governments. I approved this report.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the Framework Convention of the World Health Organization for Tobacco Control (FCTC). I have done so because it is the world's first treaty in the field of health. It was developed in response to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to address some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. It entered into force on 27 February 2005 and to date 180 parties have joined it. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to public health, as it undermines tobacco control policies and promotes access to tobacco products that are often cheaper. In addition, it results in huge revenue losses for the Union as a result of unpaid taxes and customs duties. It is estimated that more than EUR 10 billion will cease to enter each year by the Union and the Member States.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Szejnfeld report approving the protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This instrument is the most important international initiative in this field and aims to stop a criminal practice that seriously threatens not only public health but also states, generating huge tax losses estimated at over EUR 10 billion per year.  The protocol introduces new licensing legislation and a number of new obligations concerning document retention, regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. Adopted in Seoul on 12 November 2012, it will need to be ratified by 40 parties to enter into force. The adoption of the text by the EU and its Member States may represent a real step towards the entry into force of this important instrument. it is possible to implement an effective regime at world level to put an end to this cross-border criminal phenomenon.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the problems arising from the illegal trafficking in tobacco products can only be tackled from an international and multilateral approach.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the WHO Convention on Tobacco Control. It is the world's first treaty in the field of health. This protocol is the world's leading initiative in this area, which also includes a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to improve the safety of the tobacco supply chain, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment by creating a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime. I support the rapporteur who believes that ratification of the protocol will benefit public health and contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report on the protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on The Fight against The Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. Signed in 2003 at the World Health Assembly, this convention, but especially the protocol that followed in 2013, allows cooperation in the fight against smuggling, tobacco manufacture and trade, objectives closely linked to public health issues, but also, for states, tax revenues. In particular, this report will enable the granting of licences, the monitoring and tracing of products and therefore a real control in the production and transport of tobacco products, with possible sanctions. Moreover, unlike the European texts on this subject, which tend to deny the sovereignty of the Member States, the protocol ensures the cooperation of sovereign nations in good intelligence, the latter being able to decide in particular how they implement the principles to which they have adhered in the WHO Convention.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that it is necessary to combat the illegal trafficking of tobacco products that endangers the health of consumers and generates unfair competition against our Italian producers. That is why I supported this report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2003, the World Health Assembly adopted the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), which aims to reduce tobacco-related deaths and diseases worldwide globally.  This protocol develops and complements Article 15 of the FCTC, which seeks the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products, such as smuggling, illicit manufacturing and counterfeiting; it is an essential component of tobacco control, and forces the parties to take and implement effective measures to eliminate illicit trade, and I have supported its ratification. Illicit trade in tobacco products, and in particular the smuggling of cigarettes from third countries to or within the EU, is a criminal activity that results in huge revenue losses for the EU and Member States as a result of unpaid taxes and customs duties, estimated at more than EUR 10 billion per year. The Tobacco Products Directive already contains monitoring and tracing provisions that were developed in line with the FCTC Protocol.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health agreement. It is designed in response to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to address certain causes of this phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. The Convention entered into force in 2005 and currently has 180 Parties to the Convention. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was adopted at the Conference of the Parties in Seoul in 2012. The FCTC Protocol was signed by the EU in 2013. For the Protocol to enter into force, it must be ratified by 40 countries and ratified without delay by the European Union (and its Member States), which would make a significant contribution to the rapid entry into force and implementation of the FCTC Protocol.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products.  A comprehensive EU strategy to combat cigarette smuggling has been in force since 2013. In this context, the EU has also strengthened the legal basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements concluded by the EU and the Member States with the four largest tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol.  Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial to public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution to conclude a protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The Protocol to End Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products is the only multilateral legislative initiative in this area signed by the EU on 20 December 2013 and enters into force after ratification by 40 signatories. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a global problem and also a criminal offence, as it undermines tobacco control policies, facilitates access to often cheaper tobacco products and poses a major threat to human health. From an economic point of view, illegal trade is causing a major revenue short-fall for the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties, which is estimated to amount to more than EUR 10 billion per year. Thus, given the fact that member states' tax revenues from legal trade in tobacco amount to more than EUR 90 billion per year, one in ten cigarettes on the European market is sold illegally. Illegal trade must therefore be combated at global level, and that protocol is the central platform for this. It lays down a system of traceability and detection of tobacco products, licensing, recording requirements, regulation of Internet sales, sales in duty-free shops and international transit. It also identifies infringements, deals with liability and payments in the event of seizure, as well as the destruction of seized products.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this decision, as it relates to the ratification of the FCTC Protocol of the World Health Organisation, which joins the EU's global efforts to combat the smuggling of tobacco products. The damage from tobacco smuggling is twofold, as it negatively applies to public health and the public budget.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol aims to combat smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products for the purpose of public health and the recovery of tax revenues. I am in favour of such an approach insofar as the means envisaged seem to me to be appropriate - monitoring and tracing products, controlling the production and transport chain, sanctions against offenders - and where the sovereignty of States is respected. For all these reasons, I voted for this text.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a huge step in the right direction in the fight against smuggled and illicit tobacco products. Tobacco products, both illicit and legal, cause unfathomable harm to the health and well-being of citizens. Smoking has recently been identified as the single greatest cause of preventable illness and premature death in the north of Ireland. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a scourge that affects all of Europe and Ireland is no exception. It costs the north of Ireland UKP 450 million each year. Internal company documents reveal that smuggling became an integral part of tobacco companies’ business strategies and according to Customs, Imperial Brand, the world’s fourth-largest international cigarette company, accounted for 55% of the 17 billion cigarettes smuggled into ‘Britain and the north’ every year. The passing of this report means that the European Union is now under pressure to ratify and enforce the World Health Organisation’s Protocol on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products. When ratified this protocol will see countries collaborate in the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products; it was ratified on 20 December 2013 subject to its conclusion at a later date. It aims to combat illicit manufacturing and to eradicate counterfeit tobacco products in order to contribute to the protection of public health and to recover the tax revenues associated with this trafficking. In concrete terms, the text calls for the monitoring and tracing of products, the strengthening of controls throughout the manufacturing chain and the tightening of sanctions against traffickers. We are in total harmony with the philosophy and objectives of this text. Although it is the European Union that signs this protocol in place of the Member States, our national sovereignty remains preserved. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Illicit trade in tobacco products is an activity with a negative impact on both public health and revenues to state budgets. Cigarette smuggling undermines tobacco control policies, favouring access to tobacco products at lower prices that result in significant revenue losses for the European Union, since taxes and customs duties are not paid. As a result, the Union and the Member States are losing more than EUR 10 billion annually. The Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention includes a complex set of measures, rules and policies to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, with a view to a safer process on the tobacco supply chain, tobacco products, creating a global tracking and location system. I was in favour of this report because I consider it essential to ensure the highest standards in order to protect public health, and enhanced international cooperation is needed to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The World Health Organisation’s protocol on the illicit trade in tobacco products is designed to eliminate the producing, shipping, receiving, being in possession of, distributing, selling or buying of illicit tobacco. This will be achieved by targeting the supply chain, through the creation of an international tracking and tracing system, strengthening licensing and record-keeping requirements, and increasing the regulation of sales and international transit. To curb the existing illicit trade, the protocol will introduce dissuasive law enforcement measures and enhance international cooperation. Since, tobacco products have severe public health impacts worldwide and are toxic, mutagenic, carcinogenic and addictive, I consider it of the utmost importance to ensure that there will be no further increase in consumption of tobacco products and so I vote for the recommendation that the European Union should immediately ratify this protocol. Decreasing the availability, affordability or attractiveness of tobacco products, and by further developing stricter tobacco control, the European Union can better protect health, healthcare systems and national budgets from the damage caused by tobacco consumption.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's vote, I welcomed the conclusion of the protocol in question signed under the World Health Organisation Framework Convention to combat smoking because it represents the most important international initiative taken to date in the fight against illegal trade in tobacco products. This agreement includes a complex set of measures, rules and strategies with a view to making the supply chain of tobacco, its derivatives and production equipment safe through the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability system.  Other provisions to ensure control include licensing rules, document retention obligations, regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. New offences were also introduced and issues relating to liability and payments in the event of confiscation, as well as the disposal of confiscated products, were addressed. The aim is also to strengthen international cooperation through mutual administrative assistance in customs matters. Its ratification by all participating countries and organisations will benefit public health and facilitate the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which constituted giving consent for the EU to conclude the Protocol to Eliminate Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. I voted in favour as I think that the problems stemming from this illicit trade can be dealt the best through international cooperation.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation because the protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products should be ratified as soon as possible to regulate this particularly important issue. Cigarette smuggling has led to huge loss of tax revenue and customs duties and more importantly the sales of cheap and illegal tobacco products result in many tobacco-related diseases and deaths. Clearing up the illegal tobacco trade will benefit public health and help to prevent tax evasion and related criminal activities.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The illegal trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity which must be vigorously combated by the European Union and the Member States. These activities not only cause economic damage to the tax revenues of the EU and the Member States, but also constitute a threat to the effectiveness of European and national policies to promote and protect public health. I therefore voted in favour of the ratification of the protocol on the elimination of illegal trade in tobacco products signed by the EU in December 2013.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the conclusions of the protocol aiming at elimination of illicit trade and smuggling of tobacco products. Smuggling of cigarettes and other tobacco products into the Union and within its borders is a serious criminal activity having terrible consequences on public health. Not only that, it is one of main important sources of finances supporting organised crime and one of the key losses in revenue for the EU and its Member States which we cannot and should not afford. We need to address this problem seriously, as a lot is at stake, therefore I would be happy to support swift implementation of the protocol. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to OLAF estimates, the illicit trade in cigarettes takes around EUR 10 billion out of European finances every year. Such a fact brings with it several reflections. First of all, we must consider the effects that such a spread of contraband products, which are therefore not subject to the right controls, has on the health of smokers. Account must also be taken of the proliferation of the black economy and the substantial gains that this entails for organised crime, with the consequent lack of protection of the Union's financial interests.  The Protocol on the Elimination of The Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol) provides for a package of measures to secure the supply chain for tobacco, its derivatives and production equipment through the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability system. Signed by the EU in 2013, the document will need to be ratified by 40 parties for it to enter into force. Timely ratification by the European Union (and the Member States) would contribute significantly to the rapid entry into force and implementation of the FCTC Protocol. I supported the vote of this House, which gave its approval to the Council for the conclusion of the protocol, which represents the most important international action and at the same time the only multilateral legislative initiative in this area.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we agree with the rapporteur's view that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and strengthen the fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime at international level.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the Recommendation on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products in the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is an opportunity to highlight an area of para-trafficking that has a direct impact not only on citizens' health, but also on public finances. As such actions can be the reason for dealing with illegal activities, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I considered it important to combat the illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, as a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health, as it damages tobacco policies and promotes greater access to often cheaper tobacco products. This activity also entails significant tax losses to the DETRIMENT of the EU in terms of tax avoidance and customs duties. The FCTC protocol is the most important international initiative in this area. It includes a complex set of measures, rules and strategies in the field of combating the illegal trade in tobacco products, with the aim of making the supply chain of tobacco, its derivatives and production equipment safe through the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability system.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating the illegal trade in tobacco products is a very important issue in many respects, including health and taxation. I am convinced that the European Parliament must combat this criminal phenomenon, which seriously threatens public health. This activity carries serious risks as it facilitates access to products that are not controlled and potentially do not comply with EU regulations. In addition, these activities result in substantial losses of money to the detriment of public finances in terms of taxes and customs duties. The aim of this legislation is to step up border controls, increase sanctions in the event of confiscation and the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability system. For these reasons, I could only vote in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this as tobacco smuggling is a serious crime which affects tax revenue in Member States. This lost revenue could be used to support programmes to help people quit smoking, as well as contribute towards the medical costs of tobacco-related illness.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's first health treaty designed to respond to the smoking epidemic and remove some of its causes, including illicit trade in tobacco products. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health and causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. To this end, the FCTC Protocol is the world's leading initiative in this area, which contains a set of rules, measures and policies in the fight against illicit trade in tobacco products aimed at making the supply chain safe. On the other hand, it seeks to strengthen international cooperation, in particular by providing mutual administrative assistance in customs matters. I support this Recommendation, as the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will be beneficial to public health and will contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The illegal trade in tobacco products poses a serious threat to public health, damaging anti-smoking policies and promoting greater access to tobacco products. Furthermore, illegal trade entails huge economic losses to the detriment of the European Union, in terms of the avoidance of taxes and customs duties. I voted in favour of adopting the protocol because it is a necessary initiative in this area, establishing a global system of traceability and traceability of products. In addition to the protocol, it aims to strengthen the international cooperation of customs police authorities in order to reduce incentives for smuggling, including by tightening sanctions. I believe that the ratification of the FCTC protocol will promote public health benefits and contribute to the fight against illegal international trade in tobacco, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a comprehensive EU strategy in force since 2013 to combat cigarette smuggling which proposes actions in the areas of decreasing incentives for smuggling, the improvement of the security of the supply chain, a stronger enforcement of tax, customs, police and border authorities, and strengthening sanctions. I agree with the protocol being proposed to counteract illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling which is a criminal activity posing a serious threat to public health. Noting that it also causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties, with estimates indicating more than EUR 10 billion losses of revenue annually to the EU and Member States, it is calculated that roughly one cigarette out of 10 is sold illegally, which to me is very worrying. This means that as the EU we need to step up our action towards the ratification of the FCTC Protocol which will benefit public health and help the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention to Combat Smoking, which came into force in 2005 as the first international health treaty, reacts to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to address some primary causes, such as the illegal trade in tobacco products. The illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health, not even considering that this is a cross-border phenomenon. In fact, cigarettes from other brands bought in non-EU countries are circulating in the European market at cheaper prices and introduced into the Eu ropean Union, avoiding taxes and customs duties. Since 2013, the European Union has implemented a strategy to combat cigarette smuggling, as well as binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements between the EU, Member States and the four main tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). By voting in favour, therefore, I wanted to support the ratification of the FCTC Protocol, because I believe in its contribution to safeguarding public health and to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global health treaty. Illicit trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity with serious repercussions on public health. According to EU estimates, losses are recorded on Member States' budgets of around EUR 10 billion each year as a result of non-payment of taxes and customs duties as a result of this trade. This means that about 1 in 10 cigarettes is sold illegally. I voted for the establishment of an effective global regime to combat this phenomenon affecting the lives of European citizens.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's first international public health treaty. This treaty was created after four years of negotiations and discussions between members of the World Health Organisation. By 2004, as many as 180 parties (including the European Community) had signed the Convention, officially entered into force in February 2005. The main objective of the Convention is to protect the parties from the health, social, environmental and economic consequences of smoking and inhaling tobacco smoke. The Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products is based on Article 15 of the FCTC and was adopted by the Conference of the Parties on 12 November 2012 in Seoul. The EU signed the FCTC Protocol on 20 December 2013. The Protocol has so far been ratified by 9 of the 40 parties needed for its entry into force. This is a mixed agreement, with ratification by the EU and its 28 Member States as a result adding 29 pages to the FCTC Protocol. I believe that the legislative resolution is substantive and correct. I agree with the rapporteur that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and support the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, tax evasion and organised crime. The European Parliament should give its consent to this ratification. In view of the above, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a consent file for ratifying the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this field. This protocol consists of a complex set of measures and rules to tackle illicit trade, such as establishing a global tracking and tracing system to make the supply chain more secure. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licensing, record keeping requirements, and regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products. Smoking is a huge threat to public health while illicit trading also leaves behind a trail of abuses and illegalities, hence I voted in favour of this consent.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Vote on the Szjnfeld Report - Eliminating the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products: Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention (INTA). This non-legislative report is a recommendation by the European Parliament to ratify the Council's proposal for the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC). The CCALT aims to reduce tobacco-related deaths and diseases worldwide and to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular the smuggling of cigarettes to and within the EU, which has caused significant revenue losses, in terms of evaded taxes and tariffs, for the Union and the Member States. In view of all these issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which aims to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products in the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The illicit trade in tobacco products, and in particular cigarette smuggling, not only poses a serious threat to public health, but also results in significant revenue losses for the European Union. We must therefore actively combat this phenomenon.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products.  The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, based on Article 15 of the FCTC (FCTC Protocol), was adopted by the Conference of the Parties in Seoul on 12 November 2012. The Protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. The EU signed the FCTC Protocol on 20 December 2013. The entry into force of the Protocol requires ratification by the 40 Parties. A comprehensive EU strategy to combat cigarette smuggling has been in force since 2013. In this context, the EU has also strengthened the legal basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements concluded by the EU and the Member States with the four largest tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol.  Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2003, as part of the World Health Assembly, a WHO framework convention on tobacco control was signed. The WHO Protocol to Eliminate the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was signed on 20 December 2013 subject to its conclusion at a later date. It aims to combat smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The objective is to protect public health and recover tax revenues. The text calls for licensing, monitoring and tracing of products, monitoring the entire manufacturing and transport chain and better punishing violators. Unlike the European Union, this protocol respects the sovereignty of states parties. It sets principles while leaving a freedom of implementation. The only downside is that this text is signed by the European Union and not by the States. I nevertheless voted for it, because it is going in the right direction.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products: Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention, as ratification of the Protocol by the European Union and its Member States will speed up its entry into force. So far, only 9 countries have joined it, with 40 needed for its entry into force. And if the EU ratifies the protocol, it will add 29 more countries to it. The protocol in question will benefit public health and strengthen the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive because illegal tobacco products pose many risks to human health

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol.  Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Illicit and smuggled tobacco products have the potential to cause profound harm to the well-being and health of my constituents in Wales. Smoking was recently identified as the number one cause of preventable illness, and so I supported this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health as it undermines tobacco control policies by increasing access to often cheaper tobacco products. In addition, estimates point to annual revenue losses for the EU and Member States of more than €10 billion. The sale of tobacco provides Member States with tax revenues of more than EUR 90 billion per year. This means that one out of ten cigarettes is sold illegally. The protocol in question is the world's leading initiative in this area, containing a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products, with which I agree.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: agree with the objectives and the text of this protocol.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The illegal trade in tobacco products has acquired a significant cross-border character which requires international measures, standards and strategies in order to effectively combat it. The criminal activities that revolve around this business generate huge illicit proceeds and huge losses in terms of tax evasion. Illegal tobacco products, and in particular cigarette smuggling, pose an additional risk to the health of consumers and undermine the objectives of policies aimed at reducing diseases and deaths caused by smoking. I therefore declare my vote in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol), to enter into force, must be ratified by 40 parties. Thus, its rapid ratification by the EU (and its Member States) would make a significant contribution to the rapid entry into force and implementation of this Protocol. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health and causes huge losses of revenue in terms of taxes and unpaid customs duties. In every ten cigarettes, one is sold illegally. A substantial part of illicit trafficking in tobacco products in the EU comes from third countries. Therefore, the best political option to combat this transnational phenomenon is to establish an effective global regime. The FCTC Protocol is the world's leading initiative in this area, containing a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to secure the supply chain of tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment by establishing a global tracking and tracking system. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the ratification of the protocol on the elimination of the illegal trade in tobacco products (FCTC protocol) will have a substantial benefit in terms of public health, and will also promote the international fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I think that the problems stemming from the illicit trade and illicit trade in itself can be dealt the best through international cooperation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Illegal trade in tobacco products, involving cigarette smuggling, poses a serious threat to public health in addition to the economic consequences for the state. It undermines tobacco control policy and thus makes it easier to access cheap and often health-poor tobacco products. The Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, adopted by the Conference of the Parties in November 2012, is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area in Seoul. The Protocol contains a comprehensive set of measures, rules and policies to combat illicit trade in tobacco products and also aims to strengthen international cooperation, including mutual administrative assistance in customs matters.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report in favour of greater combating the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation because illegal tobacco products pose many risks to human health.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In accordance with Council Decisions 2013/744/EU and 2013/745/EU, the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was signed on 20 December 2013, subject to its conclusion at a later date. The aim of the protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade. In order to address this, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products via a series of measures by governments: creation of a global tracking and tracing regime and establishment of a global information sharing point. The protocol will establish offences, address liability and seizure payments as well and the disposal of confiscated products. The protocol concedes the irreconcilable conflict between the tobacco’s industry’s interests and public health’s interests. I voted in favour of the conclusion of this protocol.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products.  The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, based on Article 15 of the FCTC (FCTC Protocol), was adopted by the Conference of the Parties in Seoul on 12 November 2012.
