Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. With tobacco we are facing a global epidemic: smoking. Some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products, must therefore be addressed. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was adopted on 12 November 2012 in Seoul and represents the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. The Union signed the Protocol on 20 December 2013, but in order for it to enter into force, the Protocol must be ratified by 40 parties. Its ratification by the Union (and its Member States) would contribute significantly to the rapid entry into force and implementation of the Protocol. That's why I voted for it.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As a non-smoker and family man, I am basically not a friend of smoking – but even less so when cigarettes are smuggled illegally on a large, international scale. The EU must be well placed to play its part in the global struggle. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Ratification of the FCTC Protocol will have a positive impact on public health and contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trafficking, tax evasion and organised crime. The FCTC is the first global health agreement. It has been developed to respond to the worldwide widespread consumption of tobacco.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol, which is another tool in the fight against the trade in illicit tobacco products. The protocol also includes plans to establish a global tracking system, thus making the supply chain more secure. Furthermore, it will establish offences, address liability and seizure payments as well as the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Protocol to Eliminate the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was signed on 20 December 2013, including smuggling, illicit manufacturing and counterfeiting.  These criminal activities now cover 10% of the market and represent a danger to public health and a loss of tax revenue. The protocol proposes new rules to combat trafficking, including strengthening product traceability, control of the manufacturing and transport chain, international customs cooperation and increased penalties for violators. So I voted for this project which is beneficial not only for public health but also for the health of public finances.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the problems arising from the illegal trafficking in tobacco products can only be tackled from an international and multilateral approach.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of a Protocol on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products in the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with the exception of provisions falling within the scope of Part III, Title V, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, poses a major threat to public health. In addition, consumer access to illegal and consequently cheaper tobacco products undermines tobacco control policies and causes huge losses for EU revenues from unpaid taxes and customs duties. The ratification of the FCTC protocol, in my opinion, will bring public health benefits and support the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, tax evasion or organised crime.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol, which is another tool in the fight against the trade in illicit tobacco products. Not only is illicit trade in tobacco products harmful to public health, but it also results in huge losses in revenue to the EU. Therefore, I supported giving consent to the protocol, as it is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. The protocol also includes plans to establish a global tracking system, thus making the supply chain more secure.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of ratifying this protocol, which must provide the European Union with new tools to combat smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products, often organised by the tobacco companies themselves, and which results in a tax shortfall of 10 to 12 billion euros a year in the Union. After the tobacco directive came into force on 20 May, it was another blow to the tobacco industry, whose fierce lobbying fortunately did not succeed. We must now ensure that the WHO protocol is ratified as quickly as possible by all EU Member States.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Tobacco is trafficked everywhere during its production, transport and consumption: 12% of the 6 trillion cigarettes sold each year worldwide are traded illegally. For public health reasons, we must fight the illicit tobacco trade to prevent proven or potential consumers, particularly minors, from having cigarettes at very low prices, and that is why I supported this report. Combating the illicit tobacco trade also means preserving the public finances of states. For Europe, the tax shortfall is estimated at more than 10 billion euros per year. I therefore support the approval of the European Parliament to give a strong signal for other Member States to ratify this protocol, and for the European Union to also become one of the parties to the protocol, even if not all Member States have ratified it.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity posing a serious threat to public health because it undermines tobacco control policies and increases access to often cheaper tobacco products. In addition it causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Draft Legislative Resolution calling on increased judicial cooperation in criminal matters in relation to illicit trade in tobacco product. Enhanced international cooperation, valid information sharing, technical and law enforcement cooperation, mutual legal and administrative assistance are all necessary measures in the fight against illegal tobacco trading in Europe. Cooperation between the Member States will strengthen the European stance against criminal activity and also boost support for healthy living. The establishment of a global information sharing point on Tobacco Control would help direct the creation of national and regional tracking and tracing systems.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is the first global response to the tobacco epidemic we are now experiencing. By ratifying this WHO framework, Parliament will be making a significant contribution to the FTC protocols’ swift entry into force and implementation. This will allow for provisions to be made to tackle the wide range of problems which should lead to successes in reducing tobacco-related deaths and diseases worldwide.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, based on Article 15 of the FCTC (FCTC Protocol), was adopted by the Conference of the Parties in Seoul on 12 November 2012. The Protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area.  A comprehensive EU strategy to combat cigarette smuggling has been in force since 2013. In this context, the EU has also strengthened the legal basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements concluded by the EU and the Member States with the four largest tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol.  Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to support the protocol at the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which has been in force since 2005 to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products. We know the harmful effects of tobacco on human health. But all too often citizens are unaware of the indirect effects of cigarette smuggling on our societies. This criminal activity must be vigorously combated for a variety of reasons: - it feeds criminal networks whose activities are not limited to cigarette smuggling alone, but which also operate in other sectors of activity, such as money laundering, drug and arms trafficking, trafficking in human beings and migrants, or participate in the financing of terrorism; - it results in revenue losses in terms of taxes and tariffs for states.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Recommendation proposing the ratification of the FCTC Protocol, which will benefit public health and contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organized crime.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is very important from the side of public health as well as fight against tax evasion. I welcome the achievement of the first multilateral initiative to tackle illicit trade of tobacco and cigarette smuggling by securing supply chains.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products with the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with the exception of its provisions belonging to the area of the third part of Title V of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  In my view, this Protocol covers measures and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products which can provide significant support in addressing this problem. The illicit trade of these products contributes to the loss of revenues for the EU due to non-payment of taxes and customs duties and affects the deterioration of the public health situation. Therefore, I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We can only agree with the objectives and the text of this protocol. We can only regret that it is the European Union that signs this text and not the Member States. I voted in favour of the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The illicit trade in tobacco products, and in particular cigarette smuggling, poses a serious threat to public health by undermining tobacco control policies and certain standards and increasing access often to the cheapest tobacco products. Moreover, it is, of course, causing major economic losses for the EU, with Member States running out of profits from unpaid taxes and duties. I believe that ratifying this Protocol will benefit the health of European citizens and help the international fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, tax evasion and organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of joining the Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to ratify the WHO protocol to eliminate the illicit tobacco trade. This is a great victory for the health of Europeans and a great defeat for the tobacco lobby. The WHO Protocol to Eliminate the Illicit Tobacco Trade will help control the flow of tobacco from its manufacture to delivery, through the establishment of a traceability strictly independent of tobacco manufacturers but paid for by them. It will take 40 ratifications for it to become legally binding, so the Union's ratification is a strong signal for the Member States to follow suit, knowing that, at the moment, only 5 Member States have already ratified it.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This recommendation concerns the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The Convention was drawn up to respond to the high levels of tobacco consumption worldwide. It aims to address some of the causes of this, such as the illicit trade in tobacco products. The illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal act which poses a serious threat to public health. I am therefore voting in favour of this recommendation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this field. Not only is illicit trade in tobacco products harmful to public health, but it also results in huge losses in revenue to the EU. Therefore, I supported giving a consent to the Protocol, as it is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products.  The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, based on Article 15 of the FCTC (FCTC Protocol), was adopted by the Conference of the Parties in Seoul on 12 November 2012. In this context, the EU has also strengthened the legal basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements concluded by the EU and the Member States with the four largest tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol.  Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution on endocrine disruptors. I believe that it is essential and necessary for the European Commission to publish scientific criteria necessary to identify and reduce exposure to substances leading to hormonal disorders, as they lead to serious adverse results.  Even in the REPORT of the United Nations Environment Programme/WHO, endocrine disruptors are classed as a global threat. It is also quite disturbing that endocrine-related disorders are increasingly and increasingly prevalent among people. There is new evidence that hormonally disturbing substances can have a serious negative impact on reproductive health (cancers, infertility), as well as thyroid functions, brain functions, obesity and metabolism, as well as insulin and glucose homeostasis. I welcome the European Commission's decision to publish the criteria by the end of June 2016.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The illegal trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity that causes serious social, economic and health damage. According to statistics, one in ten cigarettes is illegally sold in the EU. Furthermore, a large part of smuggling is carried out by third countries, which is why we need a unified approach that is able to prevent and combat these violations. In this regard, we propose the ratification of the World Health Organisation (WHO) Protocol on the elimination of the illegal trade in tobacco products (FCTC). This protocol, which is the most important international initiative in the field of health, provides for a series of measures to strengthen international cooperation in this fight against illicit trade in tobacco, tax evasion and organised crime. Therefore, in order to ensure greater safety of the health of our citizens, I am voting in favour of the Commission's recommendation.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to combat smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products while respecting the sovereignty of countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report ,"Eliminating the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products: Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention." In 2003 a WHO framework convention on tobacco control was signed at the World Health Assembly. The WHO protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products was signed on 20 December. It calls for the fight against smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The objective is to protect public health and recover tax revenues. The text calls for licensing, monitoring and tracing of products, monitoring the entire production and transport chain, and putting in place sanctions against violators. Unlike the texts of the European Union, this protocol respects the sovereignty of the Parties, imposes principles but not the precise way to implement them and calls for proper international cooperation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this report. It is part of the World Health Organization's (WHO) tobacco control. The objectives are clear: to combat smuggling and illicit tobacco products while protecting public health. A protocol was signed on 20 December 2003 at the World Health Assembly to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products. This protocol is part of the WHO Framework Convention signed in 2003. In concrete terms, this text sets specific objectives such as tracking and tracing products, monitoring the entire distribution and transport chain... It stands out in particular from European legislation because it respects the sovereignty of the parties to the agreement and gives them the freedom to choose the means to implement the objectives set.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Colleagues, I am happy to have been given the opportunity to support this consent procedure. The World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is a global response to a global epidemic of tobacco consumption, and the first of its kind. Meanwhile, and as a part of this, the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products introduces important cross-governmental measures that establishes a framework for a secure supply chain of tobacco products. This includes information-sharing through a global tracking and tracing scheme as well as the sharing of best practices in licensing, technical and law enforcement cooperation and legal and administrative assistance. Working together on this basis is the only effective way of preventing the flow of illicit goods that are placed on the black market at a cheaper price, but which most importantly are unregulated and can cause even greater harm to health than traditional tobacco products. Eliminating the flow of these goods will have beneficial effects for world health and I hope that by ratifying this deal the Parliament can encourage other Parties to help reach the 40 signatures needed for the agreement to enter into force.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that looks at supply chain control, licensing and global tracking, we must work towards reducing tobacco related illnesses.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting to give the European Parliament its consent to the conclusion of an international protocol to combat cigarette smuggling. I take the view that Member States should have the right to join the Protocol without the consent of the European Parliament. I consider that protocol to be harmless, which is why I have chosen 'abstention'. However, I believe that the main motivation for cigarette smuggling is their uniform price and high tax across the European Union, which is a great incentive for smuggling, especially in poorer countries in the east of the EU, and that the protocol, which encourages increased state control over cigarette sales, will not improve the problem of smuggling.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The first health contract is called the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC). The treaty is designed as a key response to the global epidemic of tobacco addiction. In addition, the key role of the contract is also to combat the negative consequences caused by tobacco consumption, including the illicit trade in tobacco products.  Under the contract, a Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was developed, adopted on 12 November 2012. The Protocol is the only multilateral regulatory initiative active in terms of tobacco products. The Union signed the Protocol in 2013, but 40 countries need to be ratified in order for the Protocol to become active and in force.  Illicit trade in tobacco products is considered a criminal activity that threatens public health. In this way, the availability of cheap and for the health of very dangerous tobacco products increases. The illicit trade in tobacco products, in addition to having negative health consequences, also has a negative impact on the financial aspect. It causes huge revenue losses due to unpaid customs duties and unpaid taxes. The financial loss is estimated at more than €10 billion a year. I supported the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament, as I believe it is necessary to eradicate the illicit trade in tobacco products, as it threatens public health and damages the Union budget.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was confirmed on behalf of the Community by Council Decision 2004/513/EC. The Protocol to prevent illicit trade in tobacco products was signed on 20 December 2013. Today's vote, on the other hand, was aimed at approving this protocol at Union level, with a few exceptions. The Protocol is an important contribution to international efforts to eradicate any illicit trade in tobacco products and, consequently, to combat circumvention of excise duties and customs duties. Given the importance of the problem examined, as well as the need to contribute to the protection of public health – including in the Latgale region of the Republic of Latvia, where this phenomenon is quite common – it was logical to vote positively.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Illegal trade in tobacco products poses a serious threat to public health. At the same time, it causes financial losses to EU countries in the form of unpaid taxes and customs duties of more than EUR 10 billion per year. The Protocol is an international cooperation agreement to combat illicit trafficking and smuggling of tobacco products. The aim is to monitor and detect this crime through an established system of measures. Since a substantial part of illicit tobacco products originates in third countries, the Protocol will also bind these countries to its objectives.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Tobacco is trafficked during its production, transport and consumption. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 12% of the 6 trillion cigarettes sold worldwide each year are illegally traded. Fighting this practice is above all a public health measure. The aim is to prevent proven or potential consumers, particularly minors, from having cigarettes at very low prices. Combating the illicit tobacco trade also means preserving the public finances of states. For Europe, the tax shortfall is estimated at more than 10 billion euros per year. The proposed protocol provides the necessary tools to secure the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption of a series of measures such as the establishment of a global monitoring and traceability regime and the creation of a global focal point for information exchange. In order to strengthen public health and the fight against tax evasion, I therefore give my consent for this protocol to be ratified by the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with the exception of its provisions falling within the scope of Title V of Part Three of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union , because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This report is a continuation of the protocol of the World Health Organization Framework Convention signed on 20 December 2013 for tobacco control to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to strengthen judicial cooperation between Member States in criminal matters. It is undeniable that the illicit tobacco trade represents a considerable shortfall in tax revenues for Member States. These losses are estimated at 10 billion euros annually for each Member State, while the lawful sales of tobacco bring them 90 billion euros annually. Added to these financial considerations are the proven health risks of smoking.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the recommendation concerning the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention for the Fight against Smoking. The Protocol sets out a set of rules and measures to ensure and promote a common strategy for all EU countries to combat the illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, which is also an activity that seriously threatens public health.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report dealing with the World Health Organisation (WHO) Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, in which Parliament gives its consent to the conclusion of this Protocol. The WHO Protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Any practice or conduct prohibited by law relating to the manufacture, distribution, purchase or sale of tobacco products shall be defined as illegal trade. Furthermore, the Protocol should apply to supply chains. It focuses on the fight against counterfeit tobacco products or on money laundering that comes from the illicit trade in named products. I voted yes.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. With the Szejnfeld report, the European Parliament was called upon to agree to the ratification by the European Union of the World Health Organization (WHO) protocol to eliminate illicit trafficking in tobacco products. The protocol complements the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It is to be welcomed that more and more states are pursuing proactive public health policies to combat tobacco use (tax increases, illustrated warnings, neutral packages, etc.). As a corollary, however, tobacco traffickers thrive: 12% of the 6 trillion cigarettes sold each year worldwide are illegally traded, which also encourages tax evasion. This trafficking has implications for state revenues, depriving them of the flexibility to meet their public health objectives. The WHO protocol, in this context, provides a number of essential tools to combat this global phenomenon: international monitoring regime, increased traceability, creation of a central information exchange point. In the INTA committee and then in the plenary session, I therefore supported the ratification by the Union of this protocol, which is fully in line with its broader strategy against tobacco trafficking.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first World Framework Convention on Tobacco Trade Control (FCTC) was signed in 2005 by the World Health Organisation with 180 Contracting States, including the EU. Under this more general Convention, the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products under Article 15 of the FCTC Convention was also signed in 2012. This Protocol has not yet entered into force, since it is a prerequisite for its entry into force to be signed by at least 40 States. I believe it is our duty to combat the illegal trade in tobacco and cigarettes in the Union which is endangering the health of European citizens. At the same time, by combating the illegal tobacco trade, we are also helping to combat tax evasion, since the Union is losing a large part of its revenue from non-payment of tax by tobacco traders. Given that much of the illegal tobacco trade is carried out by non-EU countries, a global control regime is also the best and most effective solution to eliminate this phenomenon. I therefore vote in favour of this recommendation, since I believe that the EU should sign the Protocol on the elimination of illegal tobacco trade as soon as possible, so that it can be implemented immediately and in practice.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The FCTC Protocol includes measures to combat illicit trade in tobacco products. In Austria, this means that we lose EUR 10 billion in taxes every year. From my point of view, there is nothing to counteract this.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Protocol is to eliminate all types of illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol defines illicit trade in tobacco products as any practice or activity prohibited by law in connection with the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this problem, the Protocol applies to the supply chain of tobacco products, using various government instruments. It requires the establishment of a global labelling and tracing system within five years of the entry into force of the Protocol. The aim is also to establish a global contact point for information sharing within the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It will lead the development of national and regional labelling and tracing systems. The Protocol also contains additional provisions to combat the supply chain of illicit tobacco products. These include licensing, record-making requirements, as well as regulation of online sales, tax-free trade and international transit.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The World Health Organization's Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's first health treaty. It was developed in response to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to address some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. A protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products was established in 2012 and signed by the EU in 2013. In Europe, about one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. This illicit tobacco trade is a criminal activity that poses a serious public health risk and jeopardizes the success of tobacco control policies by facilitating access to products. In addition, it causes the Union to lose huge revenues in terms of taxes and customs duties, estimated at more than EUR 10 billion. The agreement of the European Parliament is necessary for the Union to ratify this protocol. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. We can only agree with the objectives of this protocol: combating smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products in order to protect public health and tax revenues. I simply regret that this text is signed by the Union and not by the Member States. As a result, I vote for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to the loss of important revenue for the EU with regard to unpaid taxes and customs duties, the illicit tobacco trade is a criminal activity that threatens public health by tearing up public tobacco control policies by increasing easy access to cheaper tobacco products. It is essential to strengthen the international fight against the illicit trade in tobacco, tax evasion and organised crime. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which will on the one hand contribute to a healthier society and on the other hand to a more efficient fight against organised crime and harmful substances.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The criminal activity of illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a serious threat to public health, as it not only undermines tobacco control policy, but allows access to cheap tobacco products. Such action causes huge revenue losses to the European Union in the form of unpaid taxes and duties. At the moment, the trend has spread with so-called cheap white cigarettes purchased outside the Union and brought in without paying tax and customs duties. The Protocol in question is a global regulatory initiative to combat the illegal trade in tobacco. It aims to establish a secure supply chain for tobacco, tobacco products and production facilities through the establishment of a global tracking and detection system. Other measures to ensure more effective control as defined in the Protocol include, in particular, the regulation of internet sales, licensing or record-keeping. I am convinced that the ratification of the protocol will ensure a more effective fight against the illegal trade in tobacco, which will not least be beneficial for public health. The proposal has my full support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because it is another tool to counter illicit trade in tobacco products. The report aims to eliminate all forms of illicit tobacco trade. In order to address this, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products via a series of measures by governments: creation of a global tracking and tracing regime and establishment of a global information sharing point. This report will establish offences, address liability and seizure payments as well and the disposal of confiscated products. It also concedes the irreconcilable conflict between the tobacco’s industry’s interests and public health’s interests.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) entered into force on 27 February 2005 and currently has 180 parties. The Protocol, based on Article 15 of the FCTC, was adopted in Seoul on 12 November 2012 and requires the ratification of the 40 Parties for its entry into force. The Protocol establishes a complex system of measures, rules and policies in the fight against illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to secure the supply chain of tobacco, tobacco products and production equipment by developing a global tracking and monitoring system. The ratification of the Protocol is in line with the eu's comprehensive steps to combat cigarette smuggling since 2013, proposed to improve supply chain security. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2003, a WHO framework convention on tobacco control was signed at the World Health Assembly. The WHO Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was signed on 20 December 2013 subject to its conclusion at a later date. It calls for the fight against smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The objective is to protect public health and recover tax revenues. This consensual text calls for support.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) represents the world's first health treaty. Illicit trade in tobacco products, especially cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health, as it undermines tobacco control policies, increases access to often cheaper tobacco products and causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. I would argue that the ratification of the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol) will make the supply chain of tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment safe and more control- possible by establishing a global tracking and tracking system.  I endorse the rapporteur's position that ratification will be beneficial to public health and will contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The objectives and text of this protocol seem useful to me, so I am voting in favour of the text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which seeks to approve the Council's conclusion of the Additional Protocol to the World Health Organization Framework Convention, which aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products. The fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, which kills 6 million people each year, aims to combat delinquency and is also a means of reducing consumption.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the ratification of the WHO Framework Convention on Combating Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products, the first multilateral legislative initiative in the health sector. In view of the volume of this phenomenon, which affects the consumption of one in ten cigarettes in Europe, we can only welcome the Szejnfeld report. Cigarette smuggling is a double threat. Firstly, by making tobacco products cheaper and more accessible, illegal trade is a source of great concern for citizens' health. Cheap white cigarettes escape European health controls by illegally importing cheap white cigarettes from non-EU countries. Furthermore, this criminal activity causes a great deal of damage to the treasuries by taking around EUR 10 billion a year from the revenues. Economic loss, by taking money away from anti-smoking policies and melanome research, also causes harm to the well-being of citizens. This phenomenon, because of its transnational nature, therefore requires a framework agreement at international level which, by promoting multilateral cooperation, can eradicate its source. In addition, the understanding will respond to the increasing interoperability and interconnection of supply chains with greater transparency. The rules laid down by it provide for greater cooperation between the competent customs agencies.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation as the World Health Organisation (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global health treaty. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a crime which poses a serious threat to public health by undermining tobacco control policies and increasing access to uncontrolled tobacco products. Not to mention that unpaid taxes and duties are causing the EU a huge loss of revenue. The ratification of the Protocol to the Framework Convention is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The World Health Organisation (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global health treaty created in response to the globalisation of the tobacco epidemic. I support this recommendation that aims to eliminate illicit trade of tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling that is a criminal activity posing a serious threat to public health.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is the world's most important initiative against illicit trade in tobacco products. One in ten cigarettes is sold illegally within the European Union. This is an annual loss of revenue of EUR 10 billion. Furthermore, the Protocol includes measures to combat illicit trade in tobacco products, and it will also be possible to trace the supply chain and manufacturing equipment.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order for the Protocol to enter into force, it must be ratified by 40 parties. Swift ratification by the EU and its Member States would make a significant contribution to the entry into force and implementation of the Protocol and would benefit public health and facilitate the international fight against tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of this Protocol.  The fight against illicit trade in tobacco products must be stepped up. In order to reduce the number of deaths associated with tobacco use, it is essential that uniform rules are applied globally.  It should be noted that tobacco use is a global problem not only health, legal, but also an economic problem. In this context, it is necessary to ensure a safe supply chain for tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment by establishing a global monitoring and tracking system.  Almost a third of all cigarettes exported worldwide are illegal, and the illegal trade in tobacco products hampers the smooth development of non-smoking policies. International cooperation, including administrative mutual assistance on customs matters, should therefore be encouraged.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP acknowledges the need to crack down on illegal tobacco products, both due to health risks and due to the need to enforce the law. We do not support the EU making this decision for us, albeit this report had laudable aims, therefore we did not oppose it, but abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to Mr Szejnfeld's proposal, I voted in favour because I believe that the rapid entry into force of the protocol can further demonstrate the European Union's commitment to combating smoking and the illegal trade in tobacco products in the Member States. The serious economic losses estimated annually as a result of illegal trade require greater regulation of the traceability of these products. Furthermore, given that the protocol strengthens the Eu ropean Union's overall strategy to combat cigarette smuggling, which has been in place since 2013, I believe that this proposal should be encouraged. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Eliminating the illicit tobacco trade in the EU is a crucial issue for several reasons. It harms public health policies and threatens a legitimate business which causes losses to all tobacco traders within the EU. The illicit trade of tobacco funds organised crime as taxation for such products is high and therefore generates high profits to the smugglers. The EU and Member States lose roughly EUR 10 billion in lost tax and customs revenue each year making this a serious problem that has to be dealt with. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The illegal trade in tobacco products and in particular cigarette smuggling pose a serious threat to public health. In addition, they result in significant losses for the EU in terms of tax avoidance and customs duties, amounting to around EUR 10 billion per year.  The World Health Organisation Framework Convention for the Fight against Smoking (FCTC) was drawn up to combat smoking and certain causes related to the illegal trade in tobacco products. Its Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products (FCT Protocol) also includes provisions on transparency and traceability.  Implementing acts and delegated acts on the future traceability system, to be adopted in accordance with Article 15 of the EU Tobacco Products Directive, must be compatible with the provisions of the Protocol on the same subject. This is the kind of instrument that we must support in order to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products and not the renewal of cooperation agreements with the large multinationals in the sector, for example Philip Morris, or the entrustment of traceability systems to these lobbies. That is why I am voting in favour, calling for the protocol to be ratified as soon as possible by all the Member States for its rapid entry into force.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products is doing damage to the budget of the Republic of Croatia due to unpaid taxes and customs duties. For this reason, cooperation between EU Member States is necessary in order to address this problem as effectively as possible, so I consider it very important that the European Union urgently ratifies the World Health Organisation Protocol on combating illicit tobacco trade.  Combating or reducing illicit sales and increasing prices would reduce consumption and premature death. Statistics show that one in three adults in the Republic of Croatia is a smoker, and the average Croatian smoker smokes 20-30 cigarettes a day. It is estimated that around 14,000 people die annually from smoking in Croatia. In order to better protect human health, international cooperation is necessary, in particular the exchange of technologies, knowledge and financial assistance and the provision of common expert knowledge, in order to establish effective tobacco control programmes, taking into account the culture of a particular community, as well as social, economic, political and legal factors.  Ratification of the Protocol can contribute to public health and the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, but also to tax avoidance and organised crime. As a result, I supported this Recommendation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but I want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. I abstain on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the world's first health treaty and a response to the global epidemic of tobacco addiction to combat some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol on eliminating illicit trade in tobacco products is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative that exists in this area. In order for the Protocol to enter into force with the Convention, it needs to be ratified by 40 parties and the EU would significantly contribute to its swift entry into force and implementation by immediately ratifying this Protocol. The Protocol to the Convention is the main global initiative in this area. The Protocol contains a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to make the global follow-up and monitoring system a supply chain for tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment safe. Other provisions to guarantee supervision include licensing, record keeping and regulating online sales, duty-free sales and international transit. The Protocol also contains provisions on infringements, liability and attachment payments, as well as the handling of confiscated products.  It also aims to enhance international co-operation, including through mutual administrative assistance in customs matters. I support the ratification of the Protocol, as I believe it will contribute to public health and the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, tax avoidance and organised crime.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity that, in addition to posing a serious threat to public health, violates tobacco control policies and is the cause of large revenue losses for the EU due to unpaid taxes and customs duties. The Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention is a major global initiative representing a large number of measures, rules and policies to combat illicit trade in tobacco products. Some of these measures include licensing, record keeping and regulating online sales, disabling duty-free sales and establishing control over international transit. The Protocol also regulates the provisions on infringements, liability and penalties in confiscation, as well as the treatment of confiscated products.  I support Representative Szejnfeld's recommendation, which aims to contribute ultimately to public health and the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, the prevention of tax avoidance and organised crime.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Council's decision to conclude this Protocol. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was signed in December 2013 as part of the Who Framework Convention on Tobacco Industry Control. The protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade, namely targeted at supply chains through a series of measures at government levels – creating a global regime for monitoring the movement of tobacco supplies and a hub for sharing this information, which should prevent the smuggling of goods. The protocol contains a series of specific measures (definition of offences, liability, payment, handling of seized goods, etc.). At the same time, the Protocol emphasises the incompatibility of the interests of the tobacco industry with those of public health.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation (FCTC) Framework Convention represents the first international health treaty. It is intended to counter some of its causes, including the illegal trade in tobacco products. This trade, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health, since it damages policies to combat smoking and promotes greater access to tobacco products at lower costs. The FCTC protocol is the most important international initiative in this area. It includes a complex set of measures, rules and strategies in the field of combating the illegal trade in tobacco products, with the aim of making the supply chain of tobacco, its derivatives and production equipment safe through the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability system. I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe it can benefit public health and promote the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft recommendation on the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The European Union negotiated the protocol on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products on behalf of the European Union and it was signed on 20 December 2013. From now on, the protocol must be ratified by 40 parties before it enters into force: its rapid ratification by the European Union and its Member States would therefore be timely.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP acknowledges the need to crack down on illegal tobacco products, both due to health risks and due to the need to enforce the law. We do not support the EU making this decision for us, albeit this report had laudable aims, therefore we did not oppose it, but abstained.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. 6 million people die worldwide, or one person every 6 seconds, 700,000 in the European Union, are the staggering figures for the damage caused by tobacco.  So YES, we must support all initiatives aimed at stemming this scourge of health! Ratifying the WHO protocol on the illicit trade in tobacco products is a requirement. So far only 5 out of 28 Member States have done so, which is not enough. But it is imperative to go further and stop hypocrisy, illicit tobacco remains a serial killer, it pays less in the "state coffers", that's all! The EU must make three commitments: to reject interference between public policy-makers and the tobacco industry, as our Parliament pointed out in its resolution of 9 March 2016, for example, by asking the European Commission not to renew the anti-trafficking agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI). Relaunching major tobacco awareness campaigns is also essential! Finally, the EU must get out of its negative prism with regard to e-cigarettes and listen to the 7 million regular vapers who, with their experience, claim the effectiveness of this tool in reducing their tobacco consumption.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation, which gives the Council the green light to conclude the agreement on the protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products, with the exception of its provisions under the third part, Title V, of the FUE Treaty, which concern the area of freedom, security and justice. This is a protocol to the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which I fully support. This protocol aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products through measures that I approve. These measures include securing the tobacco supply chain, defining offences, determining the responsibilities of those who commit these illegal acts, eliminating confiscated products, promoting international cooperation or improving traceability and monitoring. It is the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area and must enter into force as soon as possible. It will be a useful new tool to combat the public health risk posed by tobacco, and it will also help to combat the 10 billion euros of financial losses caused by its illicit trade.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity that threatens public health. It also causes huge losses of revenue for the EU in terms of taxes and unpaid customs duties. Estimates point to annual revenue losses for the EU and Member States of more than €10 billion. The sale of tobacco provides Member States with tax revenues of more than EUR 90 billion per year. One in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. The Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's leading initiative in this area, aimed at the security of the supply chain for tobacco and related products through the establishment of a global tracking and tracking system, licensing, record-keeping requirements, internet sales regulations , customs duties, etc. Ratification of the FCTC Protocol (in line with the EU strategy) will be beneficial to public health and will contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was adopted in November 2012 by the Conference of the Parties. This Framework Convention calls for effective measures to eliminate the illicit manufacture and trade of tobacco products.  The illicit manufacture and trade of tobacco products results in losses of around EUR 10 billion per year for the European Union and its Member States, but that is not all. This illicit tobacco trade is also a major public health issue. It is therefore important to combat these practices effectively. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution of the European Parliament which supports the ratification of this framework convention. I support the idea of establishing a global monitoring and traceability regime for all tobacco products. I also support the provisions contained in this resolution to implement effective controls on tobacco and tobacco products in free zones. In view of the major challenge of this fight, particularly in the area of public health, I strongly encourage Member States to ratify this protocol as soon as possible.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The document in question is an important step in restricting the illicit trade in tobacco products. The document is well designed, and I am convinced that we must support it without major debates or amendments. Reducing the illegal trade in tobacco, as it aims at this document, will achieve at least three objectives: on the one hand, it will ensure tax revenues for Member States, on the other hand, reduce the possibility of criminal activity, and thirdly, will enable it to control the quality of tobacco products entering the EU market, at least by contributing to the fact that those who cannot refuse smoking will be less harmful to their health.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. The World Health Organization's Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's first health treaty. The text came into force on 27 February 2005 and now has 180 parties. It aims to secure the supply chain of tobacco and tobacco-related products through the establishment of a global monitoring and traceability regime. It contains provisions on licensing, record-keeping, internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also deals with infringements and means of recovery and should enable better international cooperation. The ratification of this protocol is part of the European Union's comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling, adopted in 2013. By ratifying this protocol, the EU will facilitate its implementation and contribute to the effective fight against the illicit tobacco trade, a major public health problem. I voted in favour of that recommendation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) represents the world's first health treaty in force since 2005 to address the harms of tobacco and to combat the illicit tobacco trade. The illicit tobacco trade is a criminal activity that threatens public health, hindering the control policies of the products that are actually on their packaging and making these products more accessible. Moreover, there are also huge losses of revenue in terms of taxes and unpaid customs duties.  The European Union signed this protocol in 2013. However, to enter into force, it has to be ratified by 40 parties, so ratification by the EU (and its Member States) will make a significant contribution to its rapid entry into force and implementation. I agree with the rapporteur's position on the implementation of this Protocol (except for the provisions covered by Part III, Title V of the TFEU, dealt with in report 0198/2016), which will contribute to improving public health and combating the illicit trade in tobacco, tax evasion and organised crime, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the elimination of the illegal trade in tobacco products. The Protocol, negotiated under the WHO Framework Convention, aims to strengthen international cooperation in the fight against trade in and smuggling of these products, in order to protect the health of consumers even before the financial interests of the parties concerned. The WHO Framework Convention is the world's first and only initiative to combat smoking and aims to attack its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. For the health and protection of citizens, the protocol must be signed by all interested parties without further waste of time. Recently, the attention of the press and citizens has been directed towards other trade agreements, such as TTIP, but at the risk of forgetting that there are illegal trades from third countries that are really harmful to the EU economy and to the health of European citizens. That is why we need to work on strengthening international cooperation in order to detect, control and stop trade in these illicit products.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the problems arising from the illegal trafficking in tobacco products can only be tackled from an international and multilateral approach

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The illicit trade in tobacco needs to be tackled at global level with a series of measures including tracking and tracing applicable to the supply chain of tobacco products. I voted in support of this protocol which will establish and define offences and liability issues, and address the disposal of confiscated products. This is an important step in the ratification of this WHO protocol, and I urge all parties to complete this process as a matter of urgency.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. This agreement will give us another tool to tackle the illicit trade in tobacco. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol to Prevent Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as it will effectively curb illicit tobacco trafficking. Cigarette smuggling often takes place not only within the EU, but also from third countries into the EU. The WHO Protocol provides for better monitoring and control of the production and distribution of tobacco at a global level and sets penalties for illicit tobacco trafficking.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. Since 2004, as many as 180 parties (including the EU) have signed the World Health Organisation Framework Convention to Combat Smoking (FCTC), which is the world's first international public health treaty. The main objective of the Convention is to protect the parties from the health, social, ecological and economic consequences of active and passive smoking. The ratification of this protocol will benefit public health and will facilitate the international fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products, tax evasion and organised crime. Considering this protocol to be very important for the citizens of Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of its ratification.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol for the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products of the World Health Organisation aims at the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. This Protocol recognises the importance of creating an effective licensing system capable of better controlling the supply chain through the adoption by governments of measures to facilitate the localization and monitoring of products. The fight against illicit trade should be strengthened by international cooperation through information sharing, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the legal sphere. This implies the creation of a global information point set up at the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which should oversee the establishment of effective location and tracking control programmes. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Protocol because it advocates the creation of an action plan with new measures aimed at combating trade in illicit products on the European market, while establishing a criminal directive, declaring effective investigation and punishment, through the application of fines and sanctions, all in order to reduce the illicit marketing of tobacco products globally.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file as research into tobacco products consistently shows that it is detrimental to personal and public health. The health effects of the illicit trade in tobacco products are particularly great as it grants cheaper access to a greater number of tobacco products and also evades the protection that regulation provides, which makes the illicit trade in tobacco products particularly worrisome. This new treaty aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the ratification of the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It is necessary to protect ourselves against the health, social, environmental and economic impacts caused by this illegal trade. Trade in tobacco products must be controlled and regulated and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in this area must be deepened. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2005, the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control entered into force, which is the first global treaty of its kind and currently has 180 contracting parties. It also includes a protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products. I supported the conclusion of this protocol because I believe that combating the illegal trade in tobacco products is not only beneficial for public health, but also essential for the suppression of organised crime. It is estimated that up to one in ten cigarettes sold in EU Member States come from illicit trade. Cigarette smuggling costs Member States more than EUR 10 billion a year, with legal cigarette sales bringing more than EUR 90 billion to countries' budgets. A global strategy to combat cigarette smuggling is also needed in today's globalised world, also because a substantial proportion of illicit tobacco products in the EU come from third countries. The illegal trade in tobacco products is a cross-border crime that cannot be tackled only at local level. I therefore believe that this protocol, as a global initiative in this area, will strengthen international cooperation. In the future, it will be necessary to establish a secure supply chain for tobacco, tobacco products and production facilities through a global control system and also through administrative cooperation in customs matters.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The consequences of tobacco addiction cause serious health complications and a heavy burden on public health. The smuggling and illegal production of tobacco and tobacco products is not only a source of corruption, but also causes a deterioration in the health of the European population.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The world's first health treaty is the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC). The Convention is seen as a response to the global epidemic of tobacco addiction to combat some of its causes, but also to trade in tobacco products illegally. Illicit trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity, as it undermines tobacco control policies and measures.  It also causes heavy revenue losses for the EU due to unpaid customs revenues and taxes, estimated at more than €10 billion a year. The Protocol on eliminating illicit trade in tobacco products is the only multilateral regulatory initiative and aims to make the tobacco supply chain safe. Furthermore, it contains a number of policies, rules and measures to combat illicit trade, and by editing and establishing a global monitoring system, it can achieve the above objective.  Today, the EU tobacco market is dominated by cheap cigars of unknown brands, which were purchased in non-EU countries and entered into the European Union without paying customs duties and taxes. Also, €90 billion is the amount of Member States' annual fiscal revenues, which means that around one in ten cigarettes are sold illegally. Consequently, I support this recommendation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Illegal trade in tobacco poses not only great health concerns, but also economic and security concerns. Therefore, I fully support this report, providing the Council with the EP’s consent to ratify the WHO Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution. The EU is not a state, and therefore it should not ratify international agreements. That must remain the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The World Health Organisation Framework Convention was adopted in response to the growing epidemic of tobacco addiction, and as a tool to combat some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol on eliminating illicit trade in tobacco products is the only multilateral regulatory initiative currently existing in this area. The European Union, together with its Member States, would contribute to its entry into force and implementation by ratifying the Protocol. I support the ratification of the Protocol because I believe it will contribute to public health, as illicit trade in tobacco products is a criminal activity that poses a threat as such. It will also prevent huge losses of European Union revenues due to tax avoidance and enhance international cooperation in addressing customs issues.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control.  In addition to the harm to health of tobacco products, one person dies every six seconds, we also have very big problems with cigarette smuggling. This is, of course, a criminal offence, but it also causes a revenue short fall for the European Union of 10 billion a year.  That is why we need a protocol to the Framework Convention for Tobacco Control, which will improve the fight against illicit trade in tobacco products through much-needed measures.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report to give the Commission the green light to sign the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation. As Cyprus we have particularly poor experience, since the illegal trade in tobacco products continues from the occupied territories of the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Illegal tobacco products pose many risks to human health.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, based on Article 15 of the FCTC (FCTC Protocol), was adopted by the Conference of the Parties in Seoul on 12 November 2012. The Protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. The EU signed the FCTC Protocol on 20 December 2013. The entry into force of the Protocol requires ratification by the 40 Parties. A comprehensive EU strategy to combat cigarette smuggling has been in force since 2013. In this context, the EU has also strengthened the legal basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and enforceable anti-fraud agreements concluded by the EU and the Member States with the four largest tobacco producers (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, Imperial Tobacco Limited). The Tobacco Products Directive already contains provisions on tracking and tracking, which have been developed in accordance with the FCTC Protocol. Ratifying the FCTC Protocol is beneficial for public health and contributes to the fight against icing, tax evasion and organized crime, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation, which gives the green light to a draft Council decision on the illicit trade in tobacco products on behalf of the EU. As explained in the explanatory memorandum to the recommendation, the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty to enter into force on 27 February 2005. The EU signed the FCTC Protocol on 20 December 2013. The entry into force of the Protocol would require the ratification of the 40 Parties and its ratification without delay by the European Union would make a significant contribution to the smooth entry into force and implementation of the FCTC Protocol. Illicit trade in tobacco products causes a loss of revenue in the EU of around EUR 10 billion per year, only in the form of unpaid taxes and duties. However, illicit trafficking and smuggling also undermine tobacco control policies and increase access to cheaper tobacco products. All these processes involve serious health risks. According to the analysis, about 1 in 10 cigarettes are sold illegally. While 15 years ago the EU market for illicit tobacco products was dominated by products smuggled into the EU by the main manufacturers, the market is increasingly characterised by an ever-increasing proportion of 'cheap whites' (other brands purchased in non-EU countries and imported into the EU without paying tax or customs duties, without a legitimate distribution network). The risk is increased by the fact that a significant proportion of illicit tobacco products in the EU come from third countries.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Illicit trade in tobacco products is a serious problem for the European Union. This not only causes huge losses to the state budget from unpaid customs duties and taxes, but also serves to finance other areas of organised crime, such as trafficking in stimulants and legal highs, prostitution and racketeering. There are suspicions that, recently, immigrant smuggling and even terrorism have also been involved. In addition to social pathologies and criminal phenomena, the health effects of tobacco products of illicit origin are no less important. They are not subject to any sanitary, hygienic or certainly qualitative standards. The PROTOCOL to the WHO Convention provides in particular for the establishment of a worldwide system for the identification and tracking of tobacco products.  The rules include licensing, record-keeping requirements, regulation of internet sales, customs-free sales and international transit. It also defines the offences and liability and charges for seizing the goods, as well as the handling of confiscated products. It also aims to strengthen international cooperation, including mutual administrative assistance in customs matters. I am pleased that the European Parliament has agreed to the EU's accession to the International Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. This is the main global initiative to combat the illicit trade in cigarettes by increasing the security of the tobacco supply chain.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Additional Protocol to prevent the illicit trade in tobacco products. Illegal trade in tobacco products harms public health and causes loss of income within the EU when cheap illegal products are sold alongside legal tobacco products.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ It remains essential that the illicit trade in tobacco products be eliminated as a priority. This dangerous trade generates significant revenue flows for organised criminal gangs across the EU, and undoubtedly facilitates through finance wider international criminal enterprise. Some of these illegal cigarettes find their way to London, my own constituency. The illegal tobacco trade furthermore damages legitimate business and hampers international efforts to control tobacco circulation as a key public health measure. United Kingdom law enforcement agencies have spearheaded the fight against this illegality, with significant successes won against criminals – UK customs agents have to date seized in excess of 26 billion illegal cigarettes and 4 300 tonnes of rolling tobacco, leading to some 4 000 prosecutions. As such, due to the efficacy of existing domestic moves to stamp out the illicit tobacco trade, the UK government has opted out of the EU measure recommended in the Anderson report. The UK will enact JHA provisions as a separate party rather than on an EU-wide basis. Indeed, as a signatory to the FCTC, the UK already carries out many of the protocol’s stipulations. I therefore will be abstaining on this report, in line with Conservative delegation policy of abstention on issues in which Her Majesty’s Government have secured an opt-out.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of tobacco products is a practice posing serious risks to the health of citizens. The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (CCTC) is the first international framework document to combat the smoking epidemic, adopted in 2005. Cigarette smuggling outside the EU is a criminal activity that undermines control policies and brings huge financial losses as a result of non-payment of taxes and customs duties, estimated at more than EUR 90 billion per year.  The Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products was adopted on the basis of the CCTC in November 2012 as the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. However, its entry into force is conditional on ratification by 40 States, and ratification across the EU would be an important step in this regard.
