I believe that the ratification of this protocol will help to combat trafficking in tobacco products and to protect the health of European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The illicit trade in tobacco products, including cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that poses a serious public health risk as it jeopardizes the success of tobacco control policies by facilitating access to tobacco products, often at a lower cost. In addition, it causes the Union to lose huge revenues in terms of taxes and tariffs evaded. It is estimated that the EU and the Member States suffer annual revenue losses of more than EUR 10 billion. Licit tobacco sales bring in more than 90 billion euros in tax revenue to Member States annually. So about one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. Whereas fifteen years ago the illicit market for tobacco products in the Union was dominated by the smuggling of the major manufacturers, they are seeing their importance decline as the market today tends to be increasingly occupied by so-called "cheap whites" (other brands bought in third countries and introduced into the EU without paying taxes and tariffs; no legal distribution network within the Union).

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity seriously threatening public health and causing huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. Estimates indicate more than EUR 10 billion losses of revenue annually to the EU and Member States, in other words this means that roughly one cigarette out of 10 is sold illegally. I voted in favour of ratifying the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (FCTC Protocol) of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) as it is both a necessary step to improve public health, as well as to help fight illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime. The protocol’s main suggestion is to make the supply chain of tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment secure by establishing a global tracking and tracing system, and increasing international cooperation in customs matters.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the ratification of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products with the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as I believe it will contribute to public health and the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, tax avoidance and organised crime.  Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, poses a serious threat to public health, as it increases the availability of often cheaper tobacco products. The Protocol contains a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products, so I consider that effective rules with global impact are the best political option to combat smuggling.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as ratification of the Protocol to the Framework Convention would benefit public health and contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax avoidance and organised crime. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control has been in force since 27 February 2005 and has 180 signatories so far. The Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products is based on Article 15 thereof and shall enter into force when ratified by 40 signatories. The EU would contribute, through rapid ratification, to the entry into force and implementation of this Protocol as soon as possible. Illegal trade in tobacco products is a criminal offence, threatens health and causes revenue shorts for the EU, amounting to more than 10 billion annually in unpaid customs duties and taxes.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the problems arising from the illegal trafficking in tobacco products can only be tackled from an international and multilateral approach.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, it is a sensible proposal. The illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, constitutes a criminal activity and, moreover, a serious threat to public health.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The protocol calls for the fight against smuggling, illicit manufacture and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The objective is to protect public health and recover tax revenues. The text calls for licensing, monitoring and tracing of products, monitoring the entire manufacturing and transport chain, and putting in place sanctions against violators. Contrary to the usual texts of the European Union, this protocol respects the sovereignty of the parties, imposing principles but not the precise way to implement them and calling for satisfactory international cooperation.  I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The Convention was established in response to the global epidemic of tobacco and aims to address some of the root causes of the phenomenon, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. I voted in favour of S&D's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the problems arising from the illegal trafficking in tobacco products can only be tackled from an international and multilateral approach.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I welcome this protocol on tobacco illicit trade: this vote should serve to push the EU Commission for negotiations to begin and to implement this protocol.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with the exception of its provisions falling within the scope of Title V of Part Three of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty developed in response to the global tobacco epidemic and aims to tackle some of its causes, including illicit trade in tobacco products. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity posing a serious threat to public health because it undermines tobacco control policies and increases access to cheaper tobacco products. In addition, it causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. I am of the view that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and help the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organized crime.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products aims to reduce deaths and diseases as a result of tobacco worldwide and combat illegal tobacco trafficking, which causes huge losses to public administrations in terms of unpaid fees and customs duties. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global health treaty. The agreement aims to address the global tobacco epidemic by addressing a number of root causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. I fully agree with this because the protocol will contribute to public health and to the international fight against illegal tobacco trafficking, tax fraud and organised crime.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health and causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. Estimates point to annual revenue losses for the EU and Member States of more than €10 billion. In every ten cigarettes, one is sold illegally. A substantial part of illicit trafficking in tobacco products in the EU comes from third countries. Therefore, the best political option to combat this transnational phenomenon is to establish an effective global regime. The FCTC Protocol is the world's leading initiative in this area, containing a complex set of measures, rules and policies in the field of combating illicit trade in tobacco products. It aims to secure the supply chain of tobacco, tobacco products and manufacturing equipment by establishing a global tracking and tracking system. Support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft, in my view, makes a useful contribution to the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products, which is why I am happy to support it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my Labour Party colleagues in favour of this report because the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, the first Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), was adopted on 12 November 2012 and is currently open for ratification, acceptance, approval or accession by the Parties at the WHO FCTC. The new treaty aims at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licencing, record keeping requirements and regulation of internet-sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the approval of this resolution because I consider the illegal trade in tobacco to be very harmful for a number of reasons. As a doctor, I know that tobacco is very harmful to the human body. However, illegal tobacco products pose an even more serious risk to human health, as they often contain dangerous admes and chemicals. Moreover, the illegal trade and smuggling of cigarettes and tobacco products means a huge shortfall in states' tax revenues. In doing so, a large part of these taxes end up in health care and also helps to cover the costs of treating the consequences of smoking. The protocol on which we voted is currently the only international policy instrument that allows states to cooperate in the fight against tobacco trafficking.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Illegal tobacco products, which are unfortunately increasingly present in the Union, pose a serious public health hazard. In fact, they damage policies to combat smoking and introduce potentially very dangerous substances on to the market; in addition, they produce lower tax revenues, which results in further economic damage for EU countries. That is why I very much support the FCTC protocol, which will bring economic and health benefits to our communities.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is a central global initiative in this area. The illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal offence which poses a serious threat to public health by undermining tobacco control policies and facilitating access to often cheaper tobacco products. It also leads to a significant revenue short-term for the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. Revenue shorting for the EU and the Member States is estimated to be more than EUR 10 billion per year. For this reason, an effective global regime is the best political option to combat this cross-border phenomenon.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is responsible, among other things, for harmonising regulatory provisions on the elimination of technical barriers to trade in motor vehicles. A number of amendments to the original text of the agreement have extended the guarantees offered by these vehicles and improved safety and environmental protection levels. Benefits of market harmonisation are: reuse and recovery of parts, accessories and resources from end-of-life vehicles; removal of trade barriers; development and dissemination of new technologies. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation, by which Parliament will grant its approval to the third revision of the 1958 United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) Agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles, and equipment and parts that may be assembled or used thereof, and on the conditions for reciprocal recognition of approvals granted under those requirements.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define the uniform technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles. This is the third revision of the technical aspects of a first agreement dated 1958, with a view to the next meeting of the United Nations Assembly so that the EU can take a single stance.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this recommendation for uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. The European body (EEC-UN Economic Commission for Europe) aims to harmonize approvals, regulations on motor vehicles and spare parts (safety, theft, environmental protection, etc.).  In the case of this text, the aim is a global technological harmonisation with the aim of attracting China and India into this process. However, these different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It would therefore be harmful to remove them as it will intensify the global economic competition while allowing each party to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a technical report which was concerned with a simple consent procedure. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. This agreement aims to facilitate the trade in motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical requirements for the approval of vehicle equipment and parts and for the reciprocal recognition of these approvals. The automotive industry is a fundamental sector for the European economy. International regulatory cooperation must foster a transparent environment, as well as the development of higher standards of protection for consumers.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which aims to facilitate and liberalise trade in motor vehicles by establishing single technical specifications for the approval of vehicle equipment and components and for the mutual recognition of such approvals. International cooperation in regulations could help to promote a transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while ensuring high levels of health and safety protection.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The stated objective of this report is global technological harmonization. However, different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It is damaging to remove them because it will intensify global economic competition with China or India. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This concerns regulations about vehicles that have three wheels, and in that sense is rather far reaching. It looks to implement the recommendations of UN body UNECE and an independent Britain would probably sign up. However the EU should not be forcing the UK to sign up without our consent.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. As the committee recommended on its merits, I voted in favour of these technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. I am also pleased that these requirements are uniformly applicable in the EU.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that it is essential to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation in order to maintain and strengthen a competitive Europe. The automotive industry and its related auxiliary industries are the main sectors of the European Union's economy. The automotive sector generates EUR 12 million in aid. jobs and 4% of EU GDP. International regulatory cooperation can promote the development of a transparent, efficient, competitive economic environment, while improving and ensuring the highest level of health and safety.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a process of harmonizing approvals and regulations on motor vehicles and their spare parts. This process of harmonisation is supposed to take place through the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UN-EEC), in which the text aims to attract India and China by raising the majority threshold to 4/5 (from 2/3 previously).  Thus, this text endorses a catastrophic increase in global economic competition by advocating the removal of some of the rare non-tariff barriers that still protected our industries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In order to maintain its important position in the automotive sector, the EU must participate in global regulatory cooperation, which must contribute to the establishment of a transparent and competitive economic environment while ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection. Common technical requirements such as the EEC-UN framework are part of this framework. I approved of that point.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automotive sector is one of the key sectors for the continent's economy and is the leading private investor in research and development. 4% of the EU's entire GDP comes from the car industry employing more than 12 million workers. Given Europe's strategic position in this area, it is very crucial to preserve its leadership position, while at the same time supporting the process of global technological harmonisation. The Lange report, which I supported today, endorses the conclusion of the UNECE agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles, accessories and parts that can be installed and/or used on motor vehicles. This is an important text which, by laying down technical requirements, will help to reduce not only development, production and certification costs, but will also avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report. I cannot fail to draw attention to the fact that, in the explanatory point, the argument gives good the dogma that 'unnecessary barriers to trade' must be removed and more 'effective and cost-effective' rules created. Either way, what is being voted on here is not this argument, but the fact that the Council participates in a multilateral forum within the framework of the United Nations to advance the area of regulatory cooperation, and explicitly rejects the use of bilateral treaties to bridge multilateral for a.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. Given the growing interconnection of global markets and industrial production in global value chains, removing unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation on regulatory issues is critical to maintaining and strengthening a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe. The automotive sector, with related auxiliary sectors, is a key economic sector. Global technological harmonization is needed, and common technical requirements help reduce development, production and certification costs, as well as avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have taken a stand against the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of revision 3 of the agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. It should be remembered that the EEC-UN, which has been in place since 1947 to encourage economic cooperation between Member States, aims to harmonize approvals and regulations on motor vehicles and spare parts. If I am able to understand the benefits of such harmonization (one vehicle approved in one part is automatically approved in the other), which allows for some rationalization in light of safety or environmental protection issues, I reject the underlying objective, namely global technological harmonization. Indeed, the threshold for the majority of votes in the EEC-UN has just been increased, notably to attract countries such as China (which still does not have a recognized market economy status) and India. Moreover, these differences in rules allowed states to create non-tariff barriers, which is not without advantage if the country in question has more stringent standards, particularly environmental standards.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles is acceptable and well structured. I believe that it will facilitate the production and sale of motor vehicles on international markets. That is why I wanted to support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament will grant its approval to the third revision of the 1958 United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) Agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles and equipment and parts that may be assembled or used in wheeled vehicles, and on the conditions for reciprocal recognition of approvals granted in accordance with those requirements. This international agreement drawn up by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe will contribute to greater harmonization of requirements to remove technical barriers to trade in motor vehicles between the contracting parties to the Agreement and to ensure that these vehicles offer a high level of safety for consumers and environmental protection.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the conclusion of the UN Economic Commission for Europe agreement on the adoption of uniform technical standards for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted to and/or be used on wheeled vehicles. The interconnectedness of world markets is growing, and it is therefore essential to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation in order to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diverse European industrial base. The automotive industry and its related auxiliary industries are the main sectors of the European Union's economy. The automotive sector generates EUR 12 million in aid. jobs and 4% of EU GDP. It is important for the upstream industries and downstream industries. The EU is one of the world's largest manufacturers of motor vehicles, with the largest private investment in research and development in the sector. In order to ensure the vital position of the automotive industry, the EU must increase the competitiveness of the EU automotive industry and maintain its global technology leadership. International regulatory cooperation can promote the development of a transparent, efficient, competitive economic environment, while improving and ensuring the highest level of health and safety.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation in trade and regulatory matters and the removal of obstacles to it are essential conditions for maintaining and strengthening competitiveness and a diverse industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry and related ancillaments are a key economic sector of the European Union. The automotive industry provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of THE EU's GDP. There is a need for operational regulatory coherence and transparency in the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more organically aligned legislation. The EU must support global technological harmonisation. Global technological requirements such as the UNEA framework help to reduce development, production and approval costs and help to avoid re-ratification of administrative procedures.  I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed EP recommendation on uniform technical regulations for road vehicles, as I believe that barriers to trade and cooperation and in the field of the global automotive industry must be removed. The car industry is a central industry of the European Union, employing 12 million people and generating 4% of EU GDP. The sector has a wide range of activities, from steel, the chemical industry, to information and communication technology. The car industry provides a comprehensive value chain involving almost all Member States. It also creates exceptionally high added value along the whole chain and plays an important role in the trade equilib ming of the euro area. If the EU is to retain its important position in the automotive industry, it must increase its competitiveness and retain its place as a global technology leader. General technical requirements, such as the Framework of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, help to reduce the costs of developing, producing and obtaining certificates and prevent duplication of administrative procedures. Thus, more energy can be channeled into the development and production process itself.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In an increasingly interconnected and increasingly competitive world of production, removing excess barriers to the movement of goods and products is a priority, as is providing a harmonised regulatory framework that will ensure competitive conditions, while maintaining the highest standards of health protection. , safety and the environment.  The agreement to which the European Parliament has agreed today aims to achieve this objective within a key sector for European competitiveness, the automotive sector. It aims to further facilitate and liberalise trade in motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical requirements and requirements for the type-approval of vehicle components and the mutual recognition of such type-approval procedures. This is in order to create a more transparent and effective economic environment, cleansed of unnecessary additional burdens, but at the same time capable of guaranteeing uniform standards and therefore greater safety.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this agreement, which aims to facilitate and liberalise the trade in motor vehicles by establishing the same technical regulations for the approval of vehicle equipment and parts and for mutual recognition of such authorisations. The automotive industry is a fundamental economic sector for the European Union and international regulatory cooperation could help promote a transparent, efficient, pro-competitive economic environment, as well as develop and consolidate the highest level of health and safety protection.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The global standardisation of technical regulations, and approvals for safety, environmental protection and other products, as pursued by the UN Economic Commission for Europe, will increase global economic competition in this particularly important sector, particularly in terms of employment. This will be all the more felt since the objective of such an approach is to involve India and China in this process, in the context of lowering customs barriers. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a technical report which was concerned with a simple consent procedure. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must provide support for global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements such as the UNECE framework help to reduce development costs and production and certification costs, as well as to avoid duplication of administrative procedures: lighter and more rational bureaucracy means more efficient and competitive enterprises. In particular, we must be aware that the car industry and its related industries are a key economic sector for the European Union. The automotive sector provides employment for more than 12 million people and accounts for 4% of EU GDP, with important consequences both for upstream industries (such as, for example, the steel industry and the chemical industry) and for downstream industries (such as mobility services, production and design centres for roads, and the development of port areas). For several decades, the EU as a whole has been one of the world's largest motor vehicle manufacturers, and the sector has been the world's largest private investor in research and development.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to harmonize, within the member states of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, the approvals and regulations that govern the production and marketing of motor vehicles. This body includes member states of the European Union, the United States, Canada, Israel and the Central Asian republics.  On the one hand, we question the legitimacy of this body whose original objective was to promote economic cooperation between the Member States. On the other hand, this artificial harmonisation of regulations will serve as a pretext for these international organizations to permanently remove tariff and non-tariff barriers that protect us from savage globalization. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automotive industry is a fundamental economic sector for the European Union given the financial and social implications. This area provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4 % of the Union's gross domestic product.  In order to strengthen a competitive industrial base in Europe, international regulatory cooperation is needed to promote a competitive, transparent and stable economic environment that meets the highest standards of safety and health protection. As a result, uniform technical specifications for wheeled vehicles are intended to maintain the union's high-level vehicle manufacturer position and global technological leader. I believe that it is only by creating a coherent and transparent regulatory framework and by technological harmonisation that economic competitiveness and sustainable development of this sector can be achieved, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles because, in view of the growing interconnection of global markets (up to 40% of European industrial products are obtained from imported basic products), the removal of unnecessary trade barriers and cooperation in regulatory matters become essential to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe.  The EU is one of the world's largest motor vehicle manufacturers and the sector is the largest private investor in research and development. Regulatory cooperation at international level has the potential to promote a transparent, effective and competitive economic environment. In addition, regulatory coherence and transparency are necessary for the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more compatible rules.  This agreement provides support for global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements such as the UNECE framework help to reduce development costs and production and certification costs, as well as to avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)

This issue will be dealt with at the upcoming session of the UN’s General Assembly. Having a universal approach at UN level allows all interested parties to take place. Therefore I voted in favour.

Therefore I voted in favour of the report to speed up the establishment of a harmonised framework that regulates the industry and reduces unnecessary technical barriers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)

Furthermore, In my opinion, the European Union should support the development of global technologies because through the adoption of common technical requirements it is possible to reduce development costs and production costs, thus benefiting European entrepreneurs. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote on uniform technical prescriptions for wheeled vehicles.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)

In order to maintain a crucial position in the automotive industry, the EU must strengthen its competitiveness as well as preserve global technological leadership. International regulatory cooperation has the potential to promote a transparent, effective and competition-friendly economic environment by creating and ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection. The EU should support global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements, such as the framework of the Economic Commission of the Organization of Single Nations (UNECE), contribute to reducing development, production and certification costs by avoiding duplication of administrative procedures. For the above, I supported this recommendation.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP notes that this comes from UN body UNECE, which an independent Britain would probably adopt anyway. However, the EU should not be doing it in our name and, therefore, we voted against to register our objection.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)

I voted in favour of this measure because it is a step in the direction towards technological harmonisation and global regulation.

I therefore think that it stands to reason that the EU must strengthen the competitiveness of the EU automotive industry and preserve its global technological leadership.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. This is the third revision of the technical aspects of a first agreement dated 1958, in view of the next meeting of the United Nations Assembly, so that the EU can take a single stance.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)

The automotive sector accounts for 4% of EU GDP and generates 12 million jobs. The European Union is one of the largest manufacturers of motor vehicles. I voted to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation in regulatory issues that are essential for maintaining and strengthening a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles: UNECH Agreement.  At the June 2016 meeting of the UN Economic Commission for Europe, the EU must present its position on the third review of the agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts that may be used in these vehicles. Common technical requirements, such as those contained in the UNEE Framework for the Automotive and Related Sectors, contribute to reducing development and production and certification costs, avoiding duplication of administrative procedures and promoting a transparent, efficient and pro-competitive economic environment. In view of the above, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Common technical requirements for the automotive industry and its related industries help to reduce vehicle development costs, reduce the costs of production and administrative procedures and promote a transparent and competitive global car industry, so I support the endorsement of this agreement.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the automotive industry is a key economic sector for the European Union by providing employment for 12 million people and accounting for 4 % of EU GDP, the European Parliament has submitted a recommendation to the Council on its draft decision on the conclusion of Revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles. Given the increasingly wide interconnection of global markets (40 % of European industrial products are made from imported products), the removal of unjustified trade barriers and close regulatory cooperation are increasingly necessary to strengthen the competitiveness of the European car industry. The EU must therefore support UNECE's efforts to effectively harmonise international standards, which can help reduce production, development and certification costs and avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. With regard to the vote on the Lange report (Uniform Technical Prescriptions for Wheeled Vehicles: CEE-UN (INTA)," it should be noted that this non-legislative report deals with the harmonisation of regulations on the agreement of the Economic Commission for Europe and the United Nations (EEC-UN). This agreement, signed in 1958, has established a common basis for safety, environmental protection, and contributes to improving road safety worldwide. It avoids diverging legislation between states and duplication of administrative procedures.  Considering that it is essential that the Union be able to present clear and effective proposals at the EEC-UN meeting in June 2016 with a view to amending the 1958 agreement, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)

This report aims to take the necessary measures to amend the 1958 agreement and thus revive the automotive industry, which is a central economic sector for the European Union.

text: In writing. Regulatory cooperation in the automotive sector is being done globally within the framework of the United Nations. The relevant European body is the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (EEC-UN), established in 1947, which aims to harmonize approvals and regulations on motor vehicles and spare parts. By raising the majority threshold to 4/5 for votes in the EEC-UN, this text aims to include China and India in this process. These different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers and ensuring consumer safety. Their demise is damaging in that it will exacerbate global economic competition. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)

In my country, more and more automotive manufacturing is creating jobs, which only makes me happy. Given that this sector is one of those that creates the greatest added value and that production is also a key part of the budgets of member states as well as the EU, we have a duty to maintain and strengthen competitiveness in this sector and to maintain our global leadership in this sector.

text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of Revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles, accessories and parts that may be installed and/or used on motor vehicles and on the conditions for the mutual recognition of type-approvals issued on the basis of these requirements (revised 1958 Agreement). name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Road safety is an important issue for everyone – but especially for families who travel with children on our roads every day. And the automotive market has long been a global one – and that must also apply to safety regulations. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The automotive industry is a key sector of the economy for the European Union. Removing unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation is of fundamental importance to the European Union and ultimately creates jobs.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file aims to conclude Revision 3 of the Revised 1958 Agreement with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). Establishing uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles will clearly benefit the industry. The automotive sector is a core industry for the EU, and I voted in favour of the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The text proposes a harmonization of the technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles, their parts and equipment. If the text defends harmonization by claiming that it can improve European competitiveness and safety in the automotive sector, the opposite is likely to happen, since the absence of technical barriers risks making price the main discriminating criterion, with the risk that China and India will eventually enter into this process. For its reasons, I objected to this report which can deliver the French automotive sector to unfair competition from countries with low labour costs.

Either way, what is being voted on here is not this argument, but the fact that the Council participates in a multilateral forum within the framework of the United Nations to advance the area of regulatory cooperation, and explicitly rejects the use of bilateral treaties to bridge multilateral for a.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the adoption of the 3rd version of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe concerning the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which may be used in these vehicles and the mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of those requirements.  The automotive industry and its related industries are one of the main sectors of the European Union's economy. International regulatory cooperation is an opportunity to introduce transparent, effective rules for the automotive sector and related sectors.  In this way, it guarantees the development of this sector of the economy and ensures the highest levels of protection of the health and safety of consumers.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it aims to facilitate trade in motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles and for reciprocal recognition of such approvals. It aims to conclude Revision 3 of the Revised 1958 Agreement with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe – the UNECE agreement. The automotive industry is one of the largest employers and is incredibly important across Europe. Common technical requirements like the framework outlined in the UNECE agreement help to reduce developmental costs and reduce the cost of production and certification. And, most importantly, it does this while securing the highest levels of protection for health and safety.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The EU must provide support to global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements like the UNECE framework help reduce development costs, reduce costs of production and certification and avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because we are in favour over time of the introduction of uniform technical specifications at both European and international level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this motion for a resolution. The automotive industry and the related auxiliary industries are a core economic sector for the European Union and provides jobs for 12 million people as well as accounting for 4% of the EU’s GDP. In order to strengthen the competitiveness of this automotive industry, the EU must provide support to provide global technological harmonisation. The UNECE framework helps reduce development costs, reduce costs of production and certification and avoid duplication of administrative procedures. Therefore, the EU’s whole automotive industry would benefit from the UNECE resolution.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it contributes to the European automotive industry by removing unnecessary barriers to trade and strengthening the competitiveness of the industry within Europe. This will aid the industry to maintain a strong global presence.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation in trade and regulatory matters and the removal of obstacles to it are essential conditions for maintaining and strengthening competitiveness and a diverse industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry and related ancillaments are a key economic sector of the European Union. The automotive industry provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of THE EU's GDP. There is a need for operational regulatory coherence and transparency in the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more organically aligned legislation. The EU must support global technological harmonisation. Global technological requirements such as the UNEA framework help to reduce development, production and approval costs and help to avoid re-ratification of administrative procedures.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favour of this report, which aims to help foster a transparent, effective and competitive economic environment, while developing and ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection related to wheeled vehicles. It is also stressed that consistency of regulation and transparency are necessary for the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more compatible regulations.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file aims to conclude the 1958 Agreement with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). The aim of this agreement is to facilitate and liberalise trade in motor vehicles. This could be done by the establishment of uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles. Furthermore, there needs to be reciprocal recognition of such approvals.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ 32 - I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of Audit 3. Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the acceptance of uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts that may be installed and/or used on wheeled vehicles and the conditions for mutual recognition of type-approvals granted under those rules, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  I believe that the European automotive industry must strengthen its competitiveness and maintain the primacy of global technological leadership, as it is the same core ECONOMIC sector of the EU. In this context, I consider it essential to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation in regulatory matters in order to strengthen diversified and balanced industrial bases, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The goal is global technological harmonization. By raising the majority threshold to 4/5, it is hoped that China and India will be drawn into this process. These different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It is damaging to remove them because it will intensify global economic competition while allowing each party to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory. Hence my vote against the text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the revision of the agreement of the Economic Commission for Europe of the United Nations on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and spare parts.  The central objective of this text is to allow a wide dissemination of European vehicle standards, in order to strengthen international trade for the automotive industry as well as to eliminate non-tariff barriers to vehicle trade.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The automotive industry has a well-integrated value chain involving almost all European Member States. This report concerns a revision of the Convention on the Adoption of Uniform Technical Regulations for Vehicles and Parts. UNECE standards aim at harmonisation, which will sometimes reduce certification costs. This is clearly in the interests of business, and I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it aims to facilitate trade in motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles and for reciprocal recognition of such approvals.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation in trade and regulatory matters and the removal of obstacles to it are essential conditions for maintaining and strengthening competitiveness and a diverse industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry and related ancillaments are a key economic sector of the European Union. The automotive industry provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of THE EU's GDP. There is a need for operational regulatory coherence and transparency in the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more organically aligned legislation. The EU must support global technological harmonisation. Global technological requirements such as the UNEA framework help to reduce development, production and approval costs and help to avoid re-ratification of administrative procedures.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is the third revision of the Un Economic Commission (UN/EU) Agreement on Europe, with a view to updating and harmonising the technical specifications for wheeled vehicles and their equipment. As stressed, the adoption of common technological requirements should take place within the framework of the UN/EU Agreement, as this will contribute to strengthening the competitiveness of the automotive industry but also to creating a transparent, effective and competitively competitive economic environment.  I therefore voted in favour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we have approved some changes to the technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles. Given the growing expansion of global markets, it is crucial to provide for the removal of trade barriers and regulatory cooperation in order to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry is a key economic sector for the EU; It provides employment for 12 million people and accounts for 4 % of THE EU's GDP. For these reasons, supporting the car sector is important to strengthen the EU's competitiveness in the automotive industry and to preserve its global technological leadership; With this in mind, the reference to the UNECE Agreement helps to reduce development, production and certification costs and to avoid duplication of administrative procedures. I am therefore voting in favour of the UNECE agreement.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it promotes global technological harmonisation that will encourage the importation into Europe of Chinese and Hindu vehicles. However, I am in favour of intelligent protectionism in this area, both to preserve our manufacturers and to ensure the safety of consumers.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles (EEC-UN agreement). The automotive sector employs 12 million people and accounts for 4% of eu's GDP. Global regulatory cooperation is conducted within the framework of the UNITED Nations, the European body being the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UN-EEC). The purpose of this commission is the harmonization of approvals, regulations on motor vehicles and spare parts (safety, theft, environmental protection ...).  A vehicle registered in one part is automatically registered in another part. If there are probate problems for a party, correction mechanisms are provided. A party may withdraw from this process with one year's notice. The majority for votes in the EEC-UN will increase from 2/3 to 4/5. The goal is global technological harmonization. By raising the majority threshold to 4/5, it is hoped that China and India will be drawn into this process. These different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers, while allowing each party to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory. It is damaging to remove them.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Global regulatory cooperation is under the aegis of the United Nations. For example, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (EEC-UN) is working in conjunction with the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), of which it has been an active regional commission since 1947, to harmonize the approvals of motor vehicle and spare parts regulations. The aim is to obtain identical materials and vehicles worldwide. The main motivation for the text is to change the rules of votes in the EEC-UN and to increase the majority from 2/3 of the votes of the 56 Member States to 4/5. As a result, the commission hopes to seduce China and India and lure them into its fold. This seduction operation will remove the non-tariff barriers maintained by national regulations and harm national economies. I logically voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define the uniform technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles. This is the third revision of the technical aspects of a first agreement dated 1958, with a view to the next meeting of the United Nations Assembly so that the EU can take a single stance.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which removes technical barriers to trading motor vehicles.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given the growing interconnectedness of global markets and growing industrial production, there is a growing need to eliminate unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperate in regulatory matters. Regulatory issues are fundamental to strengthening and maintaining the competitiveness of a diversed industry in the European Union. The automotive industry and the activities that facilitate its functioning account for 4 % of the Union's total GDP.  It is important to note that the activity of the automotive industry reflects on industries such as the steel, chemicals, ICT and mobility services industries. The European Union is one of the world's largest manufacturers of motor vehicles. Internationally, the World Forum for the Harmonisation of Vehicle Regulations from the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is developing harmonised requirements designed to remove technical barriers in the motor vehicle trade.  The requirements are aimed at enabling greater safety and environmental protection. By a Council decision, the Union approached the revision of the Technical Regulation Treaty, which was still in place in 1958 and was agreed at the 2010 session. I supported the recommendation on the Council's draft decision, as the application of uniform technical regulations gives the possibility of reducing production and development costs, while avoiding duplication in administrative procedures.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this vote was to support the approval of the new text of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe Agreement on the approval of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. The agreement itself was concluded in 1958, when the sector in question began its perhaps most active development phase in the post-war years. The changes to version 3 under review will make it possible to contribute more actively to international regulatory cooperation in order to promote a more transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while developing and ensuring a higher level of health and safety protection. It is worth noting that the existing system and its modernisation efforts also help to reduce the costs of development, production and certification, as well as to avoid duplication of administrative procedures when it comes to bilateral trade agreements in the area under review. Given the importance of the wheeled vehicle sector to the Union economy, the environment and the health and well-being of its citizens, as well as to a number of other aspects of our daily lives, it was logical and also necessary to vote positively.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The automotive industry employs 12 million people in the EU and accounts for 4% of EU GDP. It thus maintains a leading role in industry and technology. In this area, a number of components are also produced from imported basic products. The agreement on uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles and parts thereof and on the conditions for mutual recognition of authorisations granted promotes global technological harmonisation, removes unnecessary trade barriers and duplication of administrative procedures. This creates a prerequisite for reducing development, production and certification costs, which will help to increase manufacturers and entrepreneurs' competitiveness and trade in products.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the completion of revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical specifications for wheeled vehicles, equipment and accessories which may be fitted and/or used in wheeled vehicles and the conditions for the mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these specifications ('revised 1958 Agreement') because they are not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The automotive sector accounts for 12 million people and 4% of the EU's GDP. Established in 1947 and comprising 56 member states, the UN-EEC is one of five committees of the United Nations Economic and Social Committee. With an annual budget of $50 million, it aims to harmonize vehicle regulations and registrations. Reform consists, in particular, of an increase in the majority required for votes from 2/3 to 4/5. The aim of this change is to increase the involvement of China and India. We are therefore concerned that this harmonisation, extended to these countries, will lead to an intensification of global competition to the detriment of European countries and, in particular, France.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a draft recommendation on uniform technical rules for wheeled vehicles within the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. The automotive industry is a key sector for Europe, employing over 12 million people and representing 4% of EU GDP. Not to mention the downstream sectors, it plays an important role for the steel industry, the chemical industry, etc. It should also be recalled that the EU is one of the world's largest producers of motor vehicles and the sector is the largest private investor in research and development. I supported the proposal for global technical harmonisation, because I believe that the EU must increase its competitiveness while preventing duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In approving the Lange report, the European Parliament has endorsed a common European Union position on the revision of an agreement of the UNITED Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE/EEC-UN) that sets uniform technical requirements for the automotive industry. This technical standardization at the international level will benefit French manufacturers, many of whom continue to consider that the multilateral route (unlike, for example, TTIP) is the most suitable way to engage in a process of regulatory coordination. The aim here is to harmonize safety standards to the highest level, while facilitating intra- and non-European exports, in so-called 'global value chains'. The stakes are high: more than 12 million European workers depend directly or indirectly on the automotive sector (steel, chemistry, IT, etc.). Since it is an intelligent example of regulatory harmonization on exclusively technical components - and more importantly, at the multilateral level: 56 countries are represented at UNECE - I supported the Lange report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Globalisation has created a growing interconnection of international markets, resulting in industrial production taking place through international markets. In this context, the EU must provide trade facilitations in order to enhance the competitiveness of the European market. The wheeled vehicle, equipment and parts industry provides great financial resources to the Union as well as a remarkable number of jobs for European citizens. This is also demonstrated by the fact that the EU is one of the world's largest vehicle manufacturers and the focus of private investment in vehicle technology.  For the above reasons, a regulatory international agreement in the automotive sector can help to ensure transparency and a healthy competitive environment in this sector. It is also important to increase the security of trade, since the rules will be uniform at global level. I would like to vote in favour of this recommendation on the harmonisation of technological techniques at global level as part of international regulatory cooperation within the United Nations Economic Commission (UN/ECE) for Europe, so that coordination can be made in this direction by the next UN/ECE meeting on the issue.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about reducing certification costs. This is to be achieved through uniform rules for wheeled vehicles under the UNECE Convention. I think that makes sense.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the agreement of the UN Economic Commission for Europe on harmonised technical standards for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts. This agreement aims to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and regulation, to maintain and strengthen a competitive European industry.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to establish uniform technical requirements in the automotive sector for member countries of the UN Economic Commission for Europe (UNSE). The aim is to remove non-tariff barriers between European countries but also the United States, Canada, Israel and the Central Asian republics. While this recommendation is aimed at enhancing security, it also joins the ongoing negotiations between the EU and the US under TTIP and between the EU and Canada under CETA in its pursuit to remove "unnecessary barriers to trade". I am abstaining on this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The objective of the recommendation is global technological harmonization. The difference in rules and approvals by continent had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers, particularly vis-à-vis India and China. The direct consequence of such a development will therefore be the increase in competition at a global level. That is why I objected to this recommendation.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for the draft Council decision on the conclusion of Revision 3 of the Agreement of the Economic Commission of the United Nations for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts likely to be assembled or used in a wheeled vehicle and the conditions for reciprocal recognition of approvals granted in accordance with those requirements ("Revised 1958 Agreement"). The automotive industry and its ancillary industries are a key economic sector for the EU. This sector gives jobs to 12 million people and accounts for 4% of EU GDP. It is important to remove unnecessary barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation so that a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe is maintained and strengthened. The EU must strengthen the competitiveness of its automotive industry as well as preserve global technological leadership. However, the EU must support global technological harmonisation in order to reduce development, production and certification costs.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal as it will lead to a more transparent economic environment, the highest possible level of protection of health and safety, while contributing to a reduction of costs and duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the Lange report adopted by the INTA Commission on the Council's draft decision on revision 3 of the agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform requirements for wheeled vehicles. The automotive industry plays a central role in the euro area economy, employing more than 12 million people, representing more than 4% of GDP. The EU remains the world's largest manufacturer of motor vehicles, and the sector is the leading private investor in research and development.  To maintain this crucial position, it is important to consolidate the competitiveness of our industry in order to maintain our global technological ascendancy. I believe that to do this we should invest in harmonizing technology at a global level and establish common technical standards as proposed by the EEC-UN. International regulatory cooperation would allow for a transparent and pro-competitive economic framework while maintaining a high level of protection of health and safety standards. Common technology requirements will also reduce the costs of administrative certification, production and development.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The automotive industry and related sectors are key sectors for the European Union. The sector employs more than 12 million people and accounts for 4% of the Union's GDP. In order to maintain the fundamental position of the automotive industry, the Union must strengthen its competitiveness and maintain its position as a technological leader. International cooperation in the field of control will promote a transparent, efficient, pro-competitive environment while ensuring the highest level of health and safety protection. I consider the anchoring of global regulatory cooperation within the UNECE to be beneficial, and I do not think that this necessarily means attaching less importance to bilateral trade agreements. I believe that the European Union must promote global technological harmonisation, which is why I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because this report aims to conclude Revision 3 of the Revised 1958 Agreement with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). This agreement aims to facilitate and liberalise trade in motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles and for reciprocal recognition of such approvals. The automotive industry is a core economic sector for the EU. International regulatory cooperation could help promote a transparent, effective, pro-competitive economic environment, as well as developing and securing the highest levels of protection of health and safety.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe proposes a further revision of the 1958 Agreement on the adoption of uniform technical specifications for wheeled vehicles and equipment and accessories which may be fitted to and used on wheeled vehicles and on the conditions for mutual recognition of approvals issued under those standards. The Council adopted a proposal for a decision on the conclusion of the revised agreement, for which it must obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on International Trade stresses that international regulatory cooperation has potential to promote a transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, and that regulatory coherence and transparency are needed to develop and implement effective, cost-effective and more organically aligned legislation, and that the EU should therefore support global technological harmonisation. In view of this, it proposes that Parliament agree with the Council's proposal for a decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The EEC-UN was established in 1947 to encourage economic cooperation between member states. It is one of five regional commissions of the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). The purpose of this commission is the harmonization of approvals, regulations on motor vehicles and spare parts (safety, theft, environmental protection, etc.). The majority for votes in the EEC-UN will increase from 2/3 to 4/5. The aim here is global technological harmonization. By raising the majority threshold to 4/5, it is hoped that China and India will be drawn into this process. These different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It is damaging to remove them because it will intensify global economic competition while allowing each party to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory. I'm voting against it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The automotive industry and ancillary industries are a key economic sector for the European Union, employing around 12 million people and representing 4% of EU GDP, being one of the world's largest producers of motor vehicles, representing the sector's largest private investor in research and development. I believe that the EU should strengthen the competitiveness of its automotive industry and preserve global technological leadership by removing unnecessary barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation with a view to strengthening a competitive and diversified industrial base. I am voting in favour of the report, considering that it is important to highlight that international regulatory cooperation has the capacity to promote a transparent, effective and competition-friendly economic environment, creating high levels of health and safety protection.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is global technological harmonisation. By raising the majority threshold to 4/5, it is hoped that China and India will be drawn into this process.  Different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It is damaging to remove them because it will increase global economic competition while removing every part of their ability to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The automotive industry is a core economic sector for the EU (4% of the EU’s GDP, 12 million jobs). Common technical requirements like the UNCECE framework help reduce development costs, reduce costs of production and certification and avoid duplication of administrative procedures, while securing the highest levels of protection of health and safety.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. Global technological harmonization in this area is a way to ensure user safety while promoting fairer competition among all industry in the sector.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The automotive industry and its related sub-industries constitute an important economic sector in the European Union, with the automotive industry itself providing a livelihood for 12 million people. Industrial production is increasingly happening on a global scale, so it is important to remove unnecessary obstacles to the regulatory process. Removing barriers can increase competitiveness in Europe. I voted in favour of this proposal, as I believe it is important for the European Union to protect the global leadership of the automotive industry in the field of technology.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union is among the world’s largest producers of motor vehicles. The automotive industry represents a well-integrated value chain where almost all Member States are involved. I support this recommendation that should maintain and strengthen the competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I also voted in favour of this report, as the report is, in principle, only a reduction in certification costs.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given the high weight of the automotive industry in the EU economy and the need to maintain the EU's competitiveness in this area in the rest of the world, it is important to promote global cooperation in the development of common standards and to participate in the UNECE Agreement.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the recommendation made.  In particular, effective, cost-effective and harmonised rules must be applied. Particular attention must be paid to the harmonisation and application of common technical requirements. It is essential to promote more effective regulatory cooperation, as well as to increase productivity and competitiveness.  It should be noted that manufacturing deficiencies can have serious consequences and increase existing costs.  In order to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diverse European industrial base, unnecessary barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation need to be removed. In addition, the development of a transparent, efficient, competitive economic environment must be promoted.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that this comes from UN body UNECE, which an independent Britain would probably adopt anyway. However the EU should not be doing it in our name and therefore, we voted against to register our objection.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that, in a context in which the competitiveness of European industries is under threat on several fronts, greater regulatory cooperation between Member States in the car industry, a key sector for the European Union, is necessary and urgent. In this respect, I agree with the need to develop a clear position with a view to the next meeting of the European Economic Commission for the United Nations in order to contribute to global technological harmonisation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Cars 2020 Action Plan suggests that more internationally harmonised vehicle regulations should be implemented, compared to the 1958 Agreement so that non-tariff barriers are removed. The automotive industry is an economic sector of great significance to European GDP, accounting for more than 12 million jobs thought the EU. I voted in favour of the revision of the 1958 Agreement, so that the European Union and its parties could achieve the necessary amendments.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given the growing connectivity of global markets (up to 40% of European industrial products are made from imported raw materials) and as industrial production increasingly takes place in global value chains, in order to preserve and consolidate europe's competitive and diversified industrial bases, it is crucial to end unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation on regulatory issues. This resolution is significant because the automotive industry and subcontracting industries form the fundamental economic sector of the European Union. The automotive sector employs 12 million people and occupies a share of 4% of the Union's GDP. This sector is also important for industrial enterprises at the beginning and at the end of the production chain. The European Union is one of the world's largest manufacturers of motor vehicles, the sector with the most private R&D investments. The automotive industry constitutes an integrated value chain involving almost all Member States. To preserve the key importance of the automotive industry position, the European Union must strengthen the competitiveness of its automotive industry and maintain global technological leadership.  The European Union must support global technological harmonisation. Uniform technical requirements such as the UNECE framework contribute to reducing development, production and certification costs and avoids the repetition of the same administrative procedures.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is global technological harmonisation. By raising the majority threshold to four-fifths, it is hoped that China and India will be drawn into this process. Different rules by continent or country had the advantage of creating non-tariff barriers. It is damaging to remove them because it will increase global economic competition while removing each party's ability to effectively control the safety of vehicles sold on its territory. I am voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I give consent for the conclusion of the UNECE agreement. Given the growing interconnectedness of global markets (up to 40 % of European industrial products are made from imported raw materials) and as industrial production increasingly takes place in global value chains, in order to preserve and consolidate europe's competitive and diversified industrial bases, it is crucial to end unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation in regulatory matters. The automotive industry and subcontracting industries form the fundamental economic sector of the European Union.
