The automotive sector employs 12 million people and occupies a share of 4% of the Union's GDP. This sector is also important for industrial enterprises at the beginning of the production chain (e.g. steel production, chemicals) and at the end of the production chain (e.g. ICT sector, mobility services). The European Union is one of the world's largest manufacturers of motor vehicles, the sector with the most private R&D investments. The automotive industry constitutes an integrated value chain involving almost all Member States. In addition, it creates great added value along the entire chain and plays an important role for the euro area trade balance. To preserve the key importance of the automotive industry position, the European Union must strengthen the competitiveness of its automotive industry and maintain global technological leadership.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The UNECE Agreement proposes the adoption of technical regulations for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts to be installed or used in vehicles, as well as a condition for mutual recognition of type-approvals granted under such regulations. I support Representative Lange's recommendation as it proposes universal rules for production eligible for the Union market as well as the international market, ensuring equal health and safety standards. With 40 per cent of European products produced from imported parts, removing unnecessary barriers between Member States is necessary for Europe to remain a competitor and have a diversified industrial base in Europe.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the Representative of the Czech Republic in the European Parliament, I follow the legislation concerning the automotive industry very closely, as it provides very high added value and plays an important role for the trade balance of both the Czech Republic and the entire euro area. In order to maintain this key position of the automotive industry, the EU must strengthen the competitiveness of the sector and maintain its global leadership in technology. International regulatory cooperation is therefore very important to promote transparency and competitiveness, while at the same time being able to ensure the highest level of health and safety protection. An example is global regulatory cooperation within the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE), which needs to be taken into account and strengthened. As a result, we will achieve common technical requirements that will help reduce development, production and certification costs and avoid duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The car industry and its related industries are a key economic sector for the European Union. The EU is one of the world's largest motor vehicle manufacturers and the sector is the largest private investor in research and development. Regulatory cooperation at international level has the potential to promote a transparent, effective and competitive economic environment, while developing and ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection. The EU must therefore provide support for global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements such as the UNITED Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) framework would help to reduce development costs and production and certification costs, as well as to avoid duplication of administrative procedures. I therefore believe that by voting in favour of this recommendation we can achieve the removal of unnecessary trade barriers and encourage cooperation in regulatory issues that are essential for maintaining and strengthening a competitive and diverse industrial base in Europe.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At a meeting of the UN Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE), the EU must present its position on the third revision of the agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts that may be used in these vehicles. Given that common technical requirements, such as those contained in the UNEE Framework for the Automotive sector and related sectors, contribute to reducing development and production and certification costs, and to avoiding duplication of administrative procedures and to promoting a transparent, efficient and pro-competitive economic environment, while developing and ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection, I am in favour of the EP agreeing to this agreement. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Internationally, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNSE) Global Vehicle Regulation Harmonization Forum is developing harmonized requirements (including safety and environment) to remove technical barriers to vehicle trade.  I voted in favour of this text, which is a continuation of the CARS 2020 action plan, of which I was rapporteur, and which establishes that the acceptance of internationally harmonised vehicle regulations by the European Union's trading partners will be an effective way of removing non-tariff barriers to trade in vehicles. The central objective is therefore to promote the dissemination of these European standards to the maximum number of countries that would gradually join the Global Forum for the Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations, in order to strengthen international trade for the automotive industry.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that this comes from UN body UNECE, which an independent Britain would probably adopt anyway. However the EU should not be doing it in our name and therefore, we voted against to register our objection.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The automotive industry is essential to the economic sector of the European Union. It accounts for 12 million jobs and enters with 4% of EU GDP. The EU is among the largest vehicle producers and the sector represents the largest private investor in research and development. In order to maintain this vital position of the automotive industry, the EU must strengthen the competitiveness of its industry and preserve its technological leadership. Cooperation in international regulation has the potential to promote a transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while ensuring high levels of health and safety protection. Global regulatory cooperation within the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) should be strengthened and not weakened by bilateral trade agreements.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The automotive industry and related ancillary sectors are an important economic sector for the European Union. Unfortunately, this sector was hit hard during the crisis, and many workers were hit hard by the many restructurings. This is particularly the case in my country, Belgium. In order to preserve the position of the European automotive sector but also to give its workers a future, the Union must strengthen the competitiveness of its car industry. In this sense, establishing a transparent and competitive economic environment can be an asset. But beware, there is no question of harming the health and safety protection of workers. The EU must support global technological harmonisation and common technical requirements such as the EEC-UN framework reduce development, production and certification costs and avoid redundancy of administrative procedures.  In order to allow the European Union to present its position at the EEC-UN meeting on this issue, the European Parliament has decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europeans live, work, develop their business in a single market. It is therefore strange why there are different competitive conditions in some areas so far. Today, we are correcting one of these inequalities– different technical standards for vehicles. I am convinced that the Single Market will only become better and that eu citizens will be made easier. I hope that the time will come soon when we are correcting the shortcomings of market regulation in other areas where the EU's single market is being distorted even more. I am thinking, in particular, of painful areas such as direct payments to farmers.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The increasing interconnection of the world market and industrial production on a global scale creates the need to remove barriers to trade and regulatory cooperation to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry is a key economic sector for the European Union and a good example. The automotive sector provides employment to 12 million people, representing 4% of EU GDP and making it one of the world's largest producers. Almost all Member States have a connection to the automotive industry more or less directly, and it is therefore a valuable sector with an important role in the trade balance of the euro area. In order to maintain the crucial position of this industry, the EU needs to strengthen internal competitiveness and preserve global technological leadership. Common technical requirements, as the UNECE framework suggests, contribute to reducing development, production and certification costs by avoiding duplication of administrative procedures and contributing to EU support in global technological harmonisation. International regulatory cooperation will promote economic transparency by ensuring levels of health and safety protection, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of revision 3 of the agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts that may be mounted or used on a wheeled vehicle and the conditions for the reciprocal recognition of approvals issued in accordance with these requirements ("revised 1958 agreement"). By this vote, the European Parliament approves the conclusion of this agreement. The automotive industry and its associated ancillary activities constitute a central economic sector for the European Union. This sector employs 12 million people and accounts for 4% of the EU's GDP. That is why the Union, as a contracting party to the agreement, must take the necessary steps to adopt the proposals to amend the 1958 agreement.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the recommendation discussed in the Committee on International Trade proposes a number of amendments to the 1958 UNECE Agreement. The text of the agreement provides for harmonisation in the field of vehicles, in order to remove technical barriers to trade in motor vehicles between the parties to the agreement and to ensure that the vehicles in question offer a high level of safety and environmental protection. I voted in favour of the recommendation because I support the European Commission's position in favour of an agreement that attracts new countries such as India, China, the ASEAN countries and Brazil.  Let us remember that the European market is number one in the production of the highest quality cars and vehicles, the car industry has 12 million workers and represents 4 % of the EU's GDP. Harmonisation that would allow the recognition and acceptance of EU vehicle regulations worldwide by the agreement partners would not only be a way of removing non-tariff barriers to trade, but would be a very important milestone for the EU.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report. I cannot fail to draw attention to the fact that, in the explanatory point, the argument gives good the dogma that 'unnecessary barriers to trade' must be removed and more 'effective and cost-effective' rules created. Either way, what is being voted on here is not this argument, but the fact that the Council participates in a multilateral forum within the framework of the United Nations to advance the area of regulatory cooperation, and explicitly rejects the use of bilateral treaties to bridge multilateral for a.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ International regulatory cooperation is vital to the automobile trade and helps to ensure common technical standards in road transport. The recent emission scandals involving the car industry highlight the urgent need to improve implementation and monitoring of regulations, including at international level, in order to ensure safety and performance for consumers and deliver genuine environmental benefits.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 The agreement facilitates and liberalises the trade in motor vehicles. This should be done by harmonising the technical descriptions for the approval of equipment and spare parts for the motor vehicle. Harmonisation is positive as it ensures transparency for both consumers and retailers. In addition, we ensure that all equipment and spare parts can only be approved if it meets the safety requirements in place in the EU.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the recommendation to adopt uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts that can be installed and/or used in wheeled vehicles, as this could improve safety and environmental protection. The agreement on the harmonisation of the rules for motor vehicles, as adopted by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, is intended not only to facilitate trade in motor vehicles, but also to ensure a high level of safety and the environment. By adopting this recommendation, we are taking a further step towards adapting the rules to the current international market and also to the needs of citizens.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define the uniform technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles. This is the third revision of the technical aspects of a first agreement dated 1958, with a view to the next meeting of the United Nations Assembly so that the EU can take a single stance.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the June 2016 meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE), the EU will present its proposal for the third revision of the UNECE Agreement on the adoption of uniform technical requirements applicable to motor vehicles, accessories and parts that may be installed and/or used on motor vehicles. Since the UNECE agreement provides for a reduction in development, production and certification costs for the car industry and in the same way seeks to avoid repetitive administrative procedures so as to encourage the development of a transparent and effective economic environment, I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament approving the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Non-Legislative Enactment because it aims to conclude Revision 3 of the Revised 1958 Agreement with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe – the UNECE agreement – which seeks to facilitate the trade of motor vehicles by establishing uniform technical prescriptions for the approval of equipment and parts of vehicles and for reciprocal recognition of such approval. In my constituency especially, the automotive industry is one of the largest employers and is incredibly important across Europe. Common technical requirements like the framework outlined in the UNECE agreement helps to reduce developmental costs and reduce the cost of production and certification. And, most importantly, it does this while securing the highest levels of protection for health and safety.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Common technical requirements such as those of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe for the automotive industry and related industries help to reduce development, production and certification costs. They also help avoid double administrative procedures and promote a transparent, efficient and market-based economic environment, developing and ensuring high levels of safety and health protection.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed with the conclusion of the agreement on uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles because it is part of efforts to remove trade barriers for the European automotive industry. This agreement will be presented to the next meeting of the UN Economic Commission for Europe, where it is important for the EU to speak with a unified position. The EU is still one of the world's largest motor vehicle manufacturers, and the sector is also the largest private investor in research and development. Up to 40% of European industrial products are made from imported basic products, and industrial production is increasingly dependent on the global value chain framework. In order for the European car industry to maintain its global position, it is important that the EU promotes global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements should reduce development, production and certification costs, but also avoid doubling administrative procedures. I also support the unification of technical regulations in this area because international cooperation has the potential to promote a transparent, efficient economic environment that should have a positive impact on competition. In this way, the European car industry would have a chance to maintain its global leadership in technology.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unification of technical regulations will improve the conditions for international trade and will also open up additional markets for Slovak automotive manufacturers. It is important that the standards are set to the highest possible level of safety for the crew and other road users.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The fundamental economic sector of the European Union is the automotive industry and subcontracting industries. This is the sector with the most private R&D investments. Namely, one of the world's largest manufacturers of motor vehicles is the European Union and as such 12 million people are employed in the automotive sector, which accounts for 4% of the Union's GDP.  The same sector is important for industrial enterprises throughout the production chain (spare parts services, mobility, steel and chemical manufacturing, etc.). I believe that such uniform technical requirements contribute to reducing production and development and certification costs. In this regard, I believe that the European Union should support technological harmonisation.  Also, a very important fact is that the automotive industry constitutes one integrated value chain, in which Member States participate. Therefore, I believe that the European Union should strengthen the competitiveness of the automotive industry and thus maintain global technological leadership, the way it would also preserve the key importance of the automotive industry. Consequently, I support this recommendation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as the automotive industry is a core economic sector for the EU (4% of the EU’s GDP, 12 million jobs). Common technical requirements like the UNCECE framework help reduce development costs, reduce costs of production and certification and avoid duplication of administrative procedures, while securing the highest levels of protection of health and safety.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal. The adoption of uniform technical rules for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which can be installed and/or used in wheeled vehicles and the conditions for mutual recognition of licences granted under those rules make perfect sense within the framework of the internal market.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The automotive industry and all related auxiliary industries are the central economic sector of the European Union. The automotive sector provides jobs for over 12 million Union citizens and contributes up to 4% of the EU's GDP. The European Union is among the leading manufacturers of motor vehicles, and this sector is the largest private investor in research and development. The automotive industry represents a well-integrated value system involving almost all Member States of the European Union. In order to preserve the essential position of the automotive industry in the European economy, the European Union must strengthen the competitiveness of the European automotive industry and preserve its technological dominance in the world. Global regulatory cooperation within the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) should serve as an example and be strengthened by bilateral agreements. I support this report, as I believe that removing unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation is essential to maintaining and strengthening a competitive and diverse European industry. I believe that international regulatory cooperation has the potential to strengthen and promote greater transparency, better efficiency and a more competitive economic environment, while at the same time developing and ensuring the highest standards of health and safety protection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision closing revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical prescriptions for road vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or be used on vehicles and on board vehicles and on the conditions for mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these prescriptions.  By employing 12 million people and generating 4% of the European Union's GDP, the car industry represents an extremely important industry of the European Union, so it is our duty to adopt a regulation that will facilitate access to trade and participation in global chains. Of course, in addition to promoting a transparent and efficient economic environment, we must not forget safety and health protection.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the completion of revision 3 of the UN/ECE Agreement on the adoption of uniform technical rules for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted or used on wheeled vehicles and on the conditions for mutual recognition of type-approvals granted under these rules. This revision is intended to form the basis for an international vehicle-wide approval system not yet known to the UN/ECE, to facilitate the introduction of new technologies in which industry is interested (autonomous vehicles) and to allow access to new markets. Common technical requirements help reduce development, production and certification costs and prevent duplication of administrative procedures.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to simplify the procedures for trade in the automotive sector, which is also directly linked to the supply industry.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation in trade and regulatory matters and the removal of obstacles to it are essential conditions for maintaining and strengthening competitiveness and a diverse industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry and related ancillaments are a key economic sector of the European Union. The automotive industry provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of THE EU's GDP. There is a need for operational regulatory coherence and transparency in the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more organically aligned legislation. The EU must support global technological harmonisation. Global technological requirements such as the UNEA framework help to reduce development, production and approval costs and help to avoid re-ratification of administrative procedures. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation with my vote. I agree with the report's finding that industrial production is increasingly happening in global value chains, and therefore removing unnecessary barriers to cooperation on trade and regulatory matters is essential to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diverse industrial base in Europe. As is known, the automotive industry and related ancillaments are a key economic sector of the European Union. The automotive industry alone provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of the EU's GDP. With this, the EU is one of the world's largest car manufacturers and the sector is the largest investor in research and development. I think it is important to point out that the automotive industry offers very strong added value at all stages of the chain and plays an important role in ensuring a trade balance in the euro area. I support the EU strengthening the competitiveness of the EU automotive industry and safeguarding its global leadership in technology in order to maintain the vital position of the automotive industry. Together with the Recommendation, I believe that international regulatory cooperation has potential to promote a transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while at the same time setting and guaranteeing the highest levels of health and safety protection. In addition, regulatory coherence and transparency are needed in the development and implementation of legislation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Given the increasing interconnected isation of global markets (up to 40% of European industrial products are made from products imported from raw material suppliers) and the fact that world production is increasingly taking place within global value chains, removing unnecessary barriers to trade and working together on regulatory issues are essential to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry and its related industries are one of the main sectors of the European Union's economy. It is also important for industries that are upstream and next in the production chain. In addition, the automotive industry is a well-integrated value chain covering almost all Member States. International regulatory cooperation has the potential to promote a transparent and efficient economic environment by developing and ensuring the highest levels of health and safety protection. Furthermore, regulatory coherence and transparency is essential for the development and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more compatible rules.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automotive industry and related sectors are an important part of the European Union's economy, providing jobs for 12 million people and accounting for 4% of EU GDP. Globally, EU Member States are among the leading car manufacturers, with an important contribution in the field of research and development and in the euro area trade balance. In this context, it is in the EU's interest to support the removal of barriers to trade, regulatory cooperation and the interconnection of global markets. In this way, common regulations will promote transparency, effectiveness and competition in the economic environment, ensuring health and safety protection.  The global regulatory framework provided by the UN Economic Commission for Europe (UNCE) contributes to technological harmonisation, reducing production and certification costs and avoiding duplication of administrative procedures. Supporting Revision 3 of the UNECE Agreement on the adoption of uniform specifications for wheeled vehicles and the conditions for mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these specifications is an essential condition for supporting the European automotive industry, which is why I believe that the current recommendation should be adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I share the idea that the Eu must support global technological harmonisation. Common technical requirements such as the EEC-UN framework reduce development, production and certification costs and avoid redundancy of administrative procedures. It is essential that the European Union is able to present its position at the EEC-UN meeting in June 2016. For this reason, the Council submitted a request in its letter to this effect, calling for a plenary vote in May. In view of the rapporteur's desire to respect the principle of multilingualism and to give this approval as much publicity as possible, it is proposed to vote at the plenary session in June.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the growing interconnectedness of global markets, and the increasing globalisation of our production processes, I believe it is key to remove any unnecessary regulatory barriers to trade and cooperation, to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe. The automotive industry in particular, which provides jobs for 12 million people and accounts for 4% of the EU’s GDP, is a core economic sector for the EU and represents the largest private investor in research and development. This is why I voted in favour of uniform technical prescriptions for wheeled vehicles, as I hope that this will strengthen the competitiveness of the EU automotive industry and preserve its global technological leadership. I believe that other industries should see this an example to follow. Increasing technological harmonisation and international regulatory cooperation can promote a transparent, effective, pro-competitive economic environment while developing and securing the highest levels of protection of health and safety.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union must strengthen the competitiveness of this industry and maintain global technological leadership in order to preserve the crucial importance of its position. The automotive industry plays an important role for the euro area trade balance and forms an integrated value chain in which almost all Member States participate.  The European auto industry must be ready to adapt to the ever-faster changes in the world market and must therefore have the support of European legislation that will allow it to have unfettered access to overseas markets that are essential for the survival and development of the European auto industry. Regulatory coherence and transparency are necessary for the design and implementation of effective, cost-effective and harmonised rules, and I have therefore supported uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Council Decision closing revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical prescriptions for road vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or be used on to road vehicles and on the conditions for mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these prescriptions. Global markets are increasingly intertwined and industrial production is increasingly taking place in global chains, so it is essential to remove barriers to trade, in this way to strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base. The car industry is a core industry in the EU, generating 4% of EU GDP and employing 12 million people. It provides a comprehensive value chain, creates extremely high added value and plays an important role in the trade equilib ming of the euro area. The EU must increase its competitiveness and retain its position as a global technology leader in so far as it wishes to maintain its important position in the automotive industry. International regulatory cooperation is an opportunity for a transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while establishing and ensuring the highest level of safety and healthcare. It is important for the EU to provide support for global technological harmonisation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report. I cannot fail to draw attention to the fact that, in the explanatory point, the argument gives good the dogma that 'unnecessary barriers to trade' must be removed and more 'effective and cost-effective' rules created. Either way, what is being voted on here is not this argument, but the fact that the Council participates in a multilateral forum within the framework of the United Nations to advance the area of regulatory cooperation, and explicitly rejects the use of bilateral treaties to bridge multilateral for a.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to harmonize technology on a global scale, in the hope of attracting China and India to this process.  Different rules by continent or country could have the advantage of protecting homogeneous markets and maintaining sovereign security standards.  The risk in increasing global competition through harmonization of standards is the reduction of quality standards and therefore the safety of users and consumers.  I voted AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Efforts to harmonise the rules in the automotive industry, with the aim of adopting more compatible rules, should be regarded as commendable. The automotive sector employs 12 million people and generates 4% of EU GDP. Further development of the automotive market is in the interest of the European Union as a whole.  I support measures to increase the competitiveness of the European automotive industry, which is why I voted in favour of uniform technical requirements.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given the increasing interdepending links between global markets (40% of European industrial products are made using imported products from the upper levels of the supply chain) and the increasing use of industrial production in global value chains, removing unnecessary barriers to trade and cooperation on regulatory matters is essential to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diverse industrial base in Europe. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report. I cannot fail to draw attention to the fact that, in the explanatory point, the argument gives good the dogma that 'unnecessary barriers to trade' must be removed and more 'effective and cost-effective' rules created. Either way, what is being voted on here is not this argument, but the fact that the Council participates in a multilateral forum within the framework of the United Nations to advance the area of regulatory cooperation, and explicitly rejects the use of bilateral treaties to bridge multilateral for a.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I support the (largely) European dominated internationalisation of standards through UNECE in areas of highly integrated industrial products. While the ‘diesel-scandal’ sheds light on the failures which UNECE standards would need to take into due account, this is not a reason to enlarge UNECE membership and to strengthen consensus procedures through voting thresholds.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of Revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe concerning the adoption of uniform technical prescriptions for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or used on wheeled vehicles and the conditions for the reciprocal recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these prescriptions (‘Revised 1958 Agreement’). The automotive industry and the related auxiliary industries are a core economic sector for the European Union. This industry represents a well-integrated value chain in which almost all Member States are involved. Therefore, global regulatory cooperation in the framework of UNECE as a model should be reflected and strengthened. I believe that, in order to maintain the vital position of the automotive industry, the EU must strengthen the competitiveness of the EU automotive industry and preserve its global technological leadership.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The advancement of uniform technical requirements for wheeled vehicles is a step forward in ending barriers to trade in motor vehicles while obtaining a higher level of safety and environmental protection. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The automotive industry and its associated supply industries are a core economic sector for the European Union. The automotive sector employs 12 million people and accounts for 4% of THE EU's GDP. The sector is important for upstream (e.g. steel, chemicals) and downstream industries (e.g. ICT, mobility services). The EU is one of the largest motor vehicle manufacturers worldwide, and the sector is the largest private investor in research and development. I agreed with this recommendation because international agreements at UN level can only contribute to equal standards and transparency.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The automotive industry and its ancillary industries are a key economic sector for the European Union. The automotive sector provides employment to 12 million people and accounts for 4% of EU GDP. It is important for upstream (including steel and chemicals) and downstream (ict and mobility services) industries. The EU is one of the world's largest producers of motor vehicles, representing the sector's largest investor in research and development. Around 40% of european industry products are manufactured from upstream imported products. Industrial production is increasingly being carried out within global value chains. Approvals granted under the UNECE Regulations are considered EC approvals — thus duplication of technical requirements but also administrative and certification procedures are avoided, thereby reducing the bureaucratic burden, resulting in benefits for industry and national authorities. Support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is about reducing certification costs through uniform technical regulations for wheeled vehicles under the UNECE Convention. From my point of view, there is nothing to counteract this.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. My congratulations to rapporteur Bernd Lange. I voted in favour of revision 3 of the UNSPA agreement on uniform technical requirements applicable to wheeled vehicles for a number of reasons, all of which respect and value the importance of the car industry to the Union, to Spain, and especially to Navarra.  This sector employs thousands of Navarrese, and accounts for around 30% of the Community's GDP, which places it among the largest producers of motor vehicles at national level, and a great opportunity for investment in R&D.  In order to continue to maintain this leadership position in Navarra, and in general in the rest of Europe, I value that it is necessary to strengthen the competitiveness of this industry, through regulations that promote a transparent, efficient economic environment that incites healthy competition, in turn to seek the quality and safety of its products.  I am confident that by supporting THE UNSPA we will promote these measures, and we will promote the coordination of the technological sector that has so much value for the European Union.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which marks the approval of the European Parliament on the European Council decision of 9 February 2016 to standardise the technical requirements for wheeled vehicles. The automotive sector in Europe employs some 12 million people and accounts for 4 % of Europe's GDP. All Member States contribute to this value chain, which must now strengthen its leadership at world level. Political action is needed to remove all unnecessary trade barriers and to encourage cooperation between Member States in regulatory matters and to create a transparent, effective and pro-competitive economic environment.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision closing revision 3 of the Agreement of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe on the adoption of uniform technical prescriptions for road vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or be used on vehicles and on board vehicles and on the conditions for mutual recognition of approvals granted on the basis of these prescriptions. The car industry and its sub-industries are the core industries. In order to maintain and strengthen a competitive and diversified industrial base in Europe, it is necessary to actively engage in international regulatory cooperation, which offers opportunities for an encouraging, transparent, efficient and competitive economic environment, while establishing and ensuring the highest level of safety and healthcare. In addition, regulatory coherence and transparency must also be ensured for the design and implementation of effective, cost-effective and more coherent rules.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TRADE Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 with the aim of establishing new trade relations. In September of the same year, the Commission was authorised to conclude an additional protocol which would also take account of Croatia's accession in the trade agreement. The liberalisation of trade and certain regulatory provisions on the origin of goods, health, intellectual property and competition are the key points of the agreement. Croatia's participation is therefore a logical consequence of the accession procedure. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour, because on 30 June 2015, Peru, Colombia and the EU signed an additional protocol for Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement signed in 2012. In order for it to enter into force, the three parts of the agreement - EU, Colombia and Peru - need to conclude their internal ratification procedures. In the case of the EU, it is necessary for the European Parliament to give its approval in advance. There is no option to modify the content of the protocol, simply accept or reject it, by single vote and with a simple majority of votes cast.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement by rejecting such trade agreements, which do not take into account economic asymmetry between the parties and which involve the expansion of a neocolonial economic model based on the deregulation and exploitation of third-country resources by European transnationals. Since the entry into force of the European Union Agreement and Colombia and Peru, the human rights situation in these countries has worsened, especially in those territories where European multinationals linked to the exploitation of natural resources have been installed, without the European Union having complied with the second clause which makes them subject to respect and guarantee of human rights. I therefore vote against Croatia's accession, considering that what this Parliament should approve is the suspension of the agreement, because it is not guaranteed compliance with human rights, the security of political and social leaders, trade unionists and human rights defenders.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the additional protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, with a view to taking into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This agreement allows Croatia to be added to the 2012 trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. I abstained on this text because, although the agreement does not affect France, I am opposed to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical recommendation, which aims to adapt the additional protocol to the eu-Colombia-Peru trade agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the adaptation of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia/Peru taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote of this agreement, which allows Croatia to join the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement, which we are opposed to.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical update to the existing deal. I abstained.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these recommendations on trade agreements that naturally take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed on 26 June 2012. This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in this trade agreement is a self-evident consequence of its accession to the EU. I therefore welcome the legal action to be taken by the Commission and the Council in order for Croatia to be able to participate in the implementation of this agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation does not directly concern France but aims to integrate Croatia into the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. I abstained on this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report, which aims to incorporate an additional protocol into the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2012, the European Union concluded an agreement with Colombia and Peru providing for the liberalisation of trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. The text also contains a number of rules on competition, intellectual property and public procurement and other provisions relating to the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade and sanitary and phytosanitary measures. This is a technical measure that allows the Balkan country, which joined the EU in July 2013, to make full use of the possibilities offered by its entry into the EU area.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution, because despite the updating of an agreement already in force by Croatia's accession to the European Union, we consider that the free trade agreement between Peru, Colombia and the European Union is having dramatic consequences for people by contributing to the impunity of international companies for human rights violations. In Podemos, we advocate a fair, balanced and sustainable international trade that prioritizes the dignity of people and human rights, for the profit of a few.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement on Croatia. The participation of this country is a logical consequence of its accession to the EU and the necessary legal measures should simply be taken by the Commission and the Council in order to enable this participation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union under the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. Indeed, this additional protocol to the trade agreement is in itself only a legislative coherence to update the agreement already reached between the Union, Peru and Colombia. However, I reject the very principle of these trade agreements made by the Union on behalf of the Member States with third countries: not only do they not allow the defence of the commercial interests of each Member State and its people, but they are often anchored in an ultra-liberal logic detrimental to the well-being of the people.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that free trade negotiations with countries in South America can generate risky trade dynamics for the production system of our territories. That is why, even though it is the subject of a vote, it is an additional protocol to an existing agreement, I have decided to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. I do this simply because it is a logical consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU, then it should also join the existing EU trade agreements. However, I do not believe that the EU-Colombia/Peru trade agreement is a good agreement, which is an opinion that I share with many trade union and popular movements in Colombia. My party voted against the agreement when it was dealt with in the European Parliament. However, this vote is not about the agreement itself, but about the consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. That is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 30 June 2015, Peru, Colombia and the EU signed an additional protocol for Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement, signed in 2012. Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported the conclusion of an additional protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, which takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in 2012. In Brussels and in accordance with Article 330 of the Agreement, certain provisions of this Agreement shall apply to the European Union and Peru and Colombia from 2013. This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. The rapporteur is of the opinion that Croatia's participation in this trade agreement is a self-evident consequence of its accession to the EU.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the possibility of Croatia participating in a trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. In 2014, the Commission opened negotiations with Colombia and Peru with a view to concluding an additional protocol to the trade agreement in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The agreement provides for the liberalisation of trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Since Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU, it is understandable that the Commission and the Council have taken the necessary legal measures to facilitate this cooperation. The european Parliament's approval of that Council decision is necessary for the final ratification of the Additional Protocol. I have no reason to oppose it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to amend this trade agreement to take account of Croatia's accession. I am not opposed to this amendment, but I would like to point out that I am strongly opposed to the basic trade agreement. Therefore, I abstained on this proposed amendment.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a technical report which was concerned with the Croatia joining the EU-Colombia/ Peru Free Trade Agreement. As I oppose the free trade agreement, and am also concerned about serious human rights violations in Colombia, I abstained on this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, now that it is fully part of the European Union, should also participate in the trade agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following its accession to the European Union, Croatia is obliged to ratify the agreements that the Union has concluded with third countries. The trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, signed in 2012, therefore requires the approval of the European Parliament to enter into force in Croatia. Although there is no reason to oppose this report, which, from a legal point of view, is the logical consequence of Croatia's accession, we would like to reaffirm our opposition to the endless enlargement of the European Union and to the tariff concessions granted to emerging countries. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and, with Croatia's accession, it will be allowed to participate in that agreement. It has a positive impact in the two countries, Colombia and Peru, favouring socio-economic development, integration into the global economy and increasing the quality of life. As a result, the agreement includes a number of provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement with a view to strengthening a transparent, benefit-based partnership for both parties. It is necessary to take legal measures so that Croatia is allowed to participate in the EU-Colombia and Peru free trade agreement in order to ensure equal and fair premises for all Member States, which is why I have spoken in favour of this agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The agreement provides for the liberalization of trade in agricultural and industrial products, but also in services. It is clear that Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, which would see Croatia acceding to the EU-Columbia and Peru Trade Agreement. As I opposed the FTA in the first instance, I abstained on allowing Croatia to join.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I recommend Parliament to consent to including Croatia in the enforcement of the Trade Agreement which is signed between EU and Colombia and Peru. The adjustment of the Agreement enables Croatia to trade with other Member States more efficiently in the internal market. I voted in favour of the report because taking part in the Trade Agreement is a natural consequence after Croatia’s accession to EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union implies a natural acceptance of the acquis communautaire and therefore also the necessary participation in trade agreements already concluded by the Union with third countries. In view of this, I voted in favour of the additional protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we consider Croatia's participation in the trade agreement to be a natural consequence of its accession to the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Although this debate concerns the enlargement of existing agreements, I believe that exclusively targeting economic issues and areas is not an appropriate way of deepening relations between the two parties nor does it benefit European citizens. Therefore I decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By voting positively to the measure, I considered the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru, which was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, to be important. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Colombia and Peru with a view to concluding an additional protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 agreements between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, represent an important link in trade between the old continent and Latin America. Since european enlargement to include Croatia, it is natural for me that croatia should take over from all the current agreements, and that is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote. Following the accession of Croatia to the EU, the Trade Agreement between the European Union, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, needs to take account to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The Council Decision lays out an additional Protocol adjusting the commitments made by the EU and Member States to the accession of Croatia as the multi-party Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Peru/Colombia has been concluded before the accession of Croatia to the EU Council to enable its participation.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP notes that this is essentially a technical modification of an already existing agreement that simply updates the fact that Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was concluded. We therefore saw no need to oppose a largely technical update so abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's participation in the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru, is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the agreement, which provides for the liberalisation of trade in agricultural and industrial products, as well as services. It also includes provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report says that the human rights situation in Colombia has been the focus of EU attention as part of the institutional dialogue on human rights since 2008. The visa facilitation agreement will make it possible to cooperate further in the field of human rights and to pursue a balanced, regular, in-depth political dialogue on more specific issues such as impunity, human rights defenders and security for women and children in armed conflicts, issues which remain priorities. I understand that this is a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Agreement will also strengthen regional coherence, given that Colombia is one of the minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa and is of considerable importance in bringing the peoples of Europe and Colombia closer together.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement by rejecting such trade agreements, which do not take into account economic asymmetry between the parties and which involve the expansion of a neocolonial economic model based on the deregulation and exploitation of third-country resources by European transnationals. Since the entry into force of the European Union Agreement and Colombia and Peru, the human rights situation in these countries has worsened, especially in those territories where European multinationals linked to the exploitation of natural resources have been installed, without the European Union having complied with the second clause which makes them subject to respect and guarantee of human rights. I therefore vote against Croatia's accession in considering that what this Parliament should approve is the suspension of the agreement, as compliance with human rights, the security of political and social leaders, trade unionists and human rights defenders is not guaranteed.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. The agreement liberalises commercial transactions in agricultural and industrial products as well as in the field of services. It contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. I voted for the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, following Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. Certain provisions of the Agreement have been applied (in accordance with Article 330) between the EU and Peru since 1 March 2013 and between the EU and Colombia since 1 August 2013. The European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution on 11 December 2012 in which it agreed to the conclusion of this Agreement. Croatia's participation in this trade agreement is a natural consequence of croatia's accession to the EU. It is mandatory for the European Parliament to give its consent to this Council Decision. Without seeing the negative consequences, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical file to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia / Peru, taking into account of the accession of Croatia to the EU. I have supported this procedural file with my vote.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report proposes to support providing Croatia with the legal means to access the trade agreement already in place with Colombia and Peru and as such I can support it.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament voted on the technical update to take account of the republic of Croatia's accession to the European Union, with reference to the entry into force of the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru. I would remind you that the agreement between these countries, which has been in force since June 2012, establishes an important legal framework for the liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital between the two parties and may in future, if the conditions are met, be extended to the other two members of the Andean Community, Ecuador and Bolivia. The Treaty represents an important step forward in strengthening our trade relations and investment with these countries, especially in times of economic crisis, where trade can help development and employment by encouraging sustainable and quality business for both sides.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report focuses on Croatia's inclusion as a member of the Union in the implementation of the trade agreement negotiated by the European Union with Peru and Colombia. Considering that, as part of its accession to the European Union, Croatia must be taken into account and recognised as a partner in this trade agreement, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. Since Croatia joined the European Union after the signing of the trade agreement, croatia must take into account Croatia's accession and Croatia must participate in the agreement.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of a Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union, annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement aims to add Croatia, the last country to join the European Union, to the 2012 trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. It's not about France. Nevertheless, I abstained in expressing my disapproval of this trade agreement, while respecting Croatia's sovereignty.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – There is nothing more natural than that, once a country joins the EU, it will be included in the trade agreements that the Union signed before its accession. In this order of thought, I support this recommendation and the signing of the Additional Protocol.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, because once again the EU with its decisions on free trade with third countries does so to the detriment of its Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement in question liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as services. It also includes provisions on the origin of products, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement, and is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. It is entirely normal that the Commission and the Council have taken the necessary legal measures to make this participation possible.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention to express our disapproval of the EU trade agreement between Colombia and Peru.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels in June 2012, and some of its provisions have been applied in accordance with Article 330 between the EU and Peru since 1 March 2013, and between the EU and Colombia , since 1 August 2013. The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty. The Act of Accession determines Croatia's accession to these conventions and protocols. This is merely a legal procedure to conclude the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. As a so-called partnership and cooperation agreement, it fits into the EU's strategy of materialising its trade policy and foreign policy, and aims to enshrine a free trade agreement, which we reject. Despite its eminently technical nature, the assessment of that report still weighs its objection to the basic act.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this recommendation as I believe that Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The commission's and the Council's implementation of the necessary legal procedures to allow such participation is therefore a simple act due.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstained. No opinion.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement in question concerns the liberalisation of trade in agricultural, industrial products and services. It contains provisions on the origin of goods, barriers to trade, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. I agree with the rapporteur's recommendation to give his consent to the conclusion of an additional protocol on Croatia's participation in this agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report as some trade agreements with non-EU countries could be detrimental to our production system.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation, because once again the EU, with its decisions on free trade with third countries, is doing so to the detriment of its Member States.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia was signed in June 2012, prior to the accession of Croatia to the EU. The participation of Croatia in this Trade Agreement is a result of it joining the EU and this Regulation simply puts this on a firm legal basis. My Conservative colleagues and I welcome the accession of Croatia into this free trade agreement, and voted in favour.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical file to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia/Peru, taking into account of the accession of Croatia to the EU. I supported the dossier and it was adopted by a large majority.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation which includes Croatia in the existing Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Colombia and Peru, which was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. Since September 2012, the Council has authorised the opening of negotiations between the Member States and Colombia and Peru to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. The agreement provides for the liberalization of trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Trade with Peru and Colombia is no less important for the EU – it amounts to around €30 billion a year. That is why we have concluded the trade agreement with the Andean countries. It only makes sense to add Croatia. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, as well as Colombia and Peru, liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of EU accession.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This technical file adapts the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia/Peru – given Croatia’s accession to the EU. Clearly, this Agreement had to be updated to reflect the accession of a new Member State, and for this reason I voted in favour of this file.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.
