I abstained in this resolution, because despite the updating of an agreement already in force by Croatia's accession to the European Union, we consider that the free trade agreement between Peru, Colombia and the European Union is having dramatic consequences for people by contributing to the impunity of international companies for human rights violations. In Podemos, we advocate an international, fair, balanced and sustainable trade that prioritizes the dignity of people and human rights for the profit of a few.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical file because it adapts the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia/Peru – given Croatia’s accession to the EU. Clearly, this Agreement had to be updated to reflect the accession of a new Member State.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as in services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We have decided to abstain, since we are against the EU-Colombia and Peru agreement for economic and political reasons.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Peru seeks to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union. It liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as in services. It contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. This protocol will aide Croatia’s integration as a Member State of the European Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it supports the full participation of Croatia within the European Union after its accession.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the Additional Protocol.  At issue is a process of a technical nature, namely that the Commission and the Council take the necessary legal steps to enable Croatia to participate in the Agreement, which naturally stems from its accession to the EU. The agreement enables the liberalisation of trade in agricultural and industrial products and contains a number of other measures and technical adjustments that are necessary in this sector, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement allows Croatia to be added to the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. I have decided to abstain to express my disapproval of the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural products and industrial products, as well as services. It contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. The vote concerned Croatia's accession to the Trade Agreement and is only a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the Additional Protocol.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to take into account Croatia's accession under the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is purely technical and concerns the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is simply a technical file to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia/Peru, taking into account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive concerns the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement with Croatia. It is a mixed trade agreement and so far Belgium and Greece have not signed the agreement.  The European Left, like me, believes that such trade agreements are more damaging to the states that sign them politically, socially and economically than bringing about improvements, making these agreements undesirable in my view. But the directive focuses on approving Croatia's participation in the trade agreement, because Croatia as an EU Member State has the right to participate if it so wishes.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Columbia-Peru agreement has been provisionally applied with Peru since 1 March 2013 and with Colombia since 1 August 2013. The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as in services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Looking from this perspective, it could be argued that it opens up markets for EU, Colombian and Peruvian exporters, eventually bringing annual savings of more than EUR 500 million.  However, in order to take into account Croatia’s accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, the parties had to agree on the additional protocol to the EU-Colombia/Peru Trade Agreement. In 2015, Colombia and Peru signed the additional protocol to the trade agreement. In light of this, we should work to ensure that respective internal ratification procedures are completed by the Commission and the Council in order to enable Croatia to benefit fully from the wide network of trade agreements the EU has with third countries. In addition, we should work together with Peru and Colombia to extend free trade agreements to other members of the Andean Community (Ecuador and Bolivia) This is an important step for enhancing trade between the two geopolitical regions (Europe and Andean).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru aims at liberalising trade in agricultural and industrial products, but also at trade in services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. We are voting today for Croatia's accession to this agreement. It is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and, therefore, the initiation of legal procedures by the Commission and the Council to ensure such participation is a due act. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained because this agreement just allows Croatia to join the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. This agreement allows Croatia to join the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. I abstained to express my disapproval of this agreement.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text aims to endorse on behalf of the European Union the additional protocol to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. It allows the Republic of Croatia to be included in this trade agreement, signed in 2012 between the EU, Colombia and Peru. Although the text is the logical continuation of Croatia's EU accession process, I disapprove of the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru. That's why I ABSTAINed.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement by rejecting such trade agreements, which do not take into account economic asymmetry between the parties and which involve the expansion of a neocolonial economic model based on the deregulation and exploitation of third-country resources by European transnationals. Since the entry into force of the European Union Agreement and Colombia and Peru, the human rights situation in these countries has worsened, especially in those territories where European multinationals linked to the exploitation of natural resources have been installed, without the European Union having complied with the second clause which makes them subject to respect and guarantee of human rights. I therefore vote against Croatia's accession in considering that what this Parliament should approve is the suspension of the agreement, as compliance with human rights, the security of political and social leaders, trade unionists and human rights defenders is not guaranteed.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The agreement confirms Croatia's participation as a new EU country in the trade agreement with Peru and Colombia. The agreement slightly liberalises trade between the EU and these South American countries. I agree with Croatia's assignment to this agreement.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Trade Agreement between the Union and its members, on the one hand, and the Republic of Peru and Colombia, on the other hand, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. The provisions signed between the European Union and Peru have started to apply since March 2013, while the provisions signed with Colombia have only been applied since August 2013.  On 24 September 2012, the Council gave the Commission the power to start negotiations with Peru and Colombia in order to conclude an additional Protocol complementary to the Agreement on Trade between the Union and its members and the parties mentioned for the purpose of the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The agreement enabled the liberalisation of trade in industrial and agricultural products and services, and also contains clear provisions on sanitary and phytosanitary measures, the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade and intellectual property.  I supported the recommendation on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the vote was to support the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union a few years ago. In other words, given the specificity of the approval of such additional protocols and the absence of any other amendments, it was logical to vote positively. I would like to add that almost three years have passed since Croatia's accession to the European Union, but there are still many agreements that have not been amended in the light of the Territorial Changes of the Community. It is hoped that they will all be properly modernised in the near future, so that croatia can be fully involved in the functioning of the issues covered by these agreements.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, takes account of Croatia's accession to the Union. The procedure is in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and the Rules of Procedure. I support this agreement.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union , because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. This report consists of Croatia's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru, the additional protocol of which was signed in 2012. It's not about France. Nevertheless, in line with our opposition to the European Union's trade policy we abstain on this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This agreement, signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, provides a solid legal framework for important sectors, such as public procurement, services and investment, and is a key instrument for the growth and development of regional integration, as well as for strengthening political and economic relations. An additional protocol to this trade agreement, which takes account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, is therefore a logical and natural consequence, thus ensuring that croatia, like all other Member States, assumes the obligations and benefits of that agreement.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a proposal to approve Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. Of course, I am not against Croatia being the newest member of the EU to participate in this agreement. However, we are negotiating a trade agreement with these countries, the content of which is the liberalisation of trade in agricultural, industrial and other goods. The agreement also focuses on competition and technical barriers to trade. It neglects entirely social and other important areas, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Fisas Ayxelà report aimed to endorse the update of the trade agreement, which came into force in 2013, between the European Union on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other, with the aim of taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, which was carried out in the meantime. If I have voted in favour of this procedural development, I will remain attentive to the initial assessments of the implementation of the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement, in particular on the impact of trade liberalization of goods and services on human rights, social rights, reducing inequalities and the environment.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union, its Member States and Colombia and Peru was signed in 2012 and entered into force in 2013 for both countries. The Additional Protocol to the above Trade Agreement is a consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union, so that Croatia as a Member State can enjoy the rights and obligations arising from the Agreement.  The Agreement concerns trade in agricultural and other industrial products between the Contracting Countries and includes regulatory provisions of the trade framework such as clauses on competition, copyright, the origin of goods and health conditions. In voting in favour of the recommendation, I believe that Croatia has the right to participate in this agreement, which also binds the other Member States of the Union, otherwise it would constitute discrimination against an equal EU member country.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the EU-Colombia trade agreement and Peru. As Croatia is a new member of the EU, it should also be able to participate. I therefore vote in favour of the Council taking the necessary legal action.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of Croatia's accession to the European Union, there is an additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part.  This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. The rapporteur is of the opinion that Croatia's participation in this trade agreement is a self-evident consequence of its accession to the EU.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This so-called "technical" vote concerns the addition of Croatia, now a member of the EU, as part of the EU-Colombia-Peru agreement signed one year before its accession.  First mischief: this agreement with Colombia and Peru has already largely entered into force, even though not all Member States have yet ratified it. Secondly, I denounce this agreement from the beginning both for economic reasons for promoting a particularly destructive free trade and for political reasons aimed at weakening the Andean Community of Nations (CAN: Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru). Finally, I am opposed to the latest waves of enlargement orchestrated with the sole aim of amplifying the social and fiscal dumping movement in the Union. And without ever 20 many people ever being consulted on these integrations. So I have not one but three good reasons to vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement allows Croatia to be added to the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. It doesn't affect France. However, disapproving of the trade agreement itself, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement is a natural consequence of EU membership.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as the proposal extends the already active Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru to the European Union’s most recent Member State, Croatia, and so reduces barriers to trade and services.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The trade agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in June 2012. The agreement aims to liberalize trade in agricultural, industrial and service products. It also includes provisions relating to the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, health and plant health measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Given that Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the UNION in July 2013, Parliament had to approve the conclusion of the additional protocol on Croatia's participation in the trade agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I am in agreement with this dossier to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia/Peru, taking into account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. On 11 December 2012, the European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution agreeing to conclude the agreement. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union (hereinafter referred to as "the Protocol"). In order to ratify the Additional Protocol, the Council adopted a draft decision, for which it must obtain Parliament's consent.  In its report, the Committee on International Trade stresses that Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the Additional Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement allows Croatia to be added to the 2012 EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. Forbearance.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in 2012. In view of the Authorisation granted by the Council to the Commission to negotiate with Colombia and Peru with the aim of concluding an Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, this agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products , as well as services. I endorse the rapporteur's position on Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement, as it is a natural consequence of EU membership.  In view of the foregoing, I am in favour of concluding the Additional Protocol on Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. As I am against the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, I abstain on this text which brings Croatia into it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as this protocol is needed to ensure that the EU’s Common Commercial Policy applies to all EU Member States in the same way.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. Since Croatia joined the European Union only from 1 July 2013, it was not a party to the Convention, although as a Member State it has a full place in it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was first and fore over the purpose of liberalising agricultural and industrial products and services in 2012 and has been operating successfully ever since. Croatia became the 28th Member State of the European Union a year later, in 2013, and today I supported the new Member State being included in the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade Agreement between Colombia, Peru and the European Union Member States was signed on 26 June 2012. I support this recommendation of including Croatia in this Trade Agreement as a natural consequence of its accession to the European Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with Croatia's participation in the trade agreement as a natural consequence of EU accession. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The need to conclude the Protocol stems from Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that this is essentially a technical modification of an already existing agreement that simply updates the fact Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was concluded. We therefore saw no need to oppose a largely technical update so abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Parliament approved the conclusion of the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States in December 2012, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other; whereas the European Commission has conducted negotiations with the two countries for the conclusion of an additional protocol to the trade agreement to include Croatia between the Contracting Parties; whereas, following Croatia's accession to the European Union, its participation in the trade agreement is quite natural; Finally, given that the approval of the European Parliament is necessary for the ratification of the additional protocol, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As officially an EU Member State it is only normal that Croatia undergoes the legal steps to enable its participation and open its market to the Trade Agreement. This accession will highly benefit both the country of Croatia, Colombia and Peru and will show development in the relationships between the parties of the agreement. Hence, I vote in favour of the report.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal to conclude the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, and Colombia and Peru, taking account of the accession of Croatia to the EU, which took place after the conclusion of the previous agreement. The additional protocol includes Croatia in the commitments made in sectors such as government procurement, trade in services, establishment and electronic commerce and rules of origin, and takes account of the Croatian language for the implementation of the agreement.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Agreement on Trade between the European Union, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, should also take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Council decision, to which the European Parliament is invited to give its consent, also includes the Croatian commitment to fulfil its obligations in the areas of public procurement, commercial services, establishment of electronic trade, rules of origin of products and to take into account the implementation of the obligations of the agreement in The Croatian language.  I supported the approval of croatia's agreement, as this trade agreement is a natural consequence of EU accession. This is an agreement aimed at improving the process of economic and social transition, promoting regional co-operation and economic integration of the country, the global economy, and extending to the liberalisation of bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. Just as Croatia has responsibilities arising from this agreement, it also achieves certain advantages.  The agreement also establishes a regular political dialogue on issues of common interest at bilateral and regional level. In this sense, it regulates the relations of the Republic of Croatia as a Member State of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, which represents the possibility of establishing more efficient partnerships and more profitable trade ties with this part of the world, which is significant for many Croatian companies.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I oppose the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru in principle. But the text put to the vote is only a technical adjustment related to Croatia's accession to the Union. Therefore, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, On the one hand, the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other hand, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and some of its provisions apply in accordance with Article 330 between the European Union and Peru as of 1 March 2013, and between the European Union and Colombia as of 1 August 2013. On 11 December 2012. The European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution giving its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to start negotiations with Colombia and Peru to conclude an Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (the 'Protocol').

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament gives its consent to the conclusion of the Additional Protocol on Croatia's Accession to the EU in the Trade Agreement, so it is necessary to concreteise legal steps to make Croatia's participation possible. The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural, industrial products and services.  Supported by the recommendation of Santiago Fisas Ayxelà on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, both Colombia and Peru, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report. This was merely a technical proposal for an existing trade cooperation treaty linked to Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that Croatia's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru represents a further step forward in the alliance with important and rapidly growing countries and regions. Furthermore, the text of croatia's protocol of accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru fulfils the ambitions of both the EU and Croatia. This agreement will increase and diversify trade and investment on both sides, act as an important factor for economic and social development and help alleviate poverty and reduce inequalities. I hope that this agreement will enter into force quickly and fully.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed in June 2012. I voted in favour of this recommendation, approving the conclusion of the additional protocol on Croatia's participation in this trade agreement, as the country's participation is a natural consequence of its accession to the European Union in 2013.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that this is essentially a technical modification of an already existing agreement that simply updates the fact Croatia has joined the EU since the original agreement was concluded. We therefore saw no need to oppose a largely technical update so abstained.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted this afternoon in favour of Croatia's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. The provisions of the agreement have been in place since 1 March 2013 with Peru and since 1 August 2013 with Colombia. This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural, industrial and service products between the EU and these two South American countries. The agreement opens up new trade opportunities for the EU's major exporting industries, which benefit from the abolition of tariffs. For example, the rights savings amount to more than 33 million euros for the automotive and automotive parts sector and more than 60 million euros for textiles.  These agreements also help to ensure respect for human rights, social rights and promote environmental protection and regional integration in Latin America.  Croatia's participation in this trade agreement through the conclusion of an additional protocol is a natural continuation of its accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is only an additional protocol to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru, taking into account Croatia's accession to the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. It is necessary to adopt an additional protocol to the agreement between the European Union and its member states, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru on the other, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. This is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of this act. As a reminder, the agreement liberalizes trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also includes provisions relating to the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, health and plant health measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not require much discussion. Croatia's EU membership has slightly changed our trade agreements with Peru and Colombia. Today, we are simply legitimising the newly created situation. As far as I know, our trading partners are also satisfied with the proposal put forward, so I am unequivocally voting in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels in June 2012, and some of its provisions have been applied, pursuant to Article 330, between the European Union and Peru since March 2013, and between the European Union and Colombia , since August 2013. The agreement creates a common trade area between the EU and the two Einan countries referred to (which Ecuador recently joined) for agricultural and industrial products and services, including provisions on the origin of products, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in this Trade Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and, as such, Parliament has approved the conclusion of the Additional Protocol on Croatia's participation in it. As this measure is a mandatory element for completing the process of ratifying the Additional Protocol, I voted in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows Croatia's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States to be taken into account on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other.  With this vote, the European Parliament approves the Council's decision to include Croatia in commitments made in sectors such as public procurement, trade in services, establishment and e-commerce, rules of origin and takes the Croatian language into account in the implementation of the agreement.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote in favour of the protocol presented by Mr Syp/ Fisas Ayxelà will make it possible to extend to Croatia, the last country to become a member of the Union, the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. The signing of this agreement dates back to 2012. Although Peru and Colombia represent secondary outlet markets for European exports (around 0.6 % of exports), the agreement is a springboard to the whole of Latin America. This point is evidenced by the fact that the format of the agreement leaves the doors open to other countries in the region, such as Ecuador and Bolivia. The sectors that have benefited most from trade liberalisation are agri-food, while for the EU, the automotive, machinery and chemicals sectors in particular.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution, because despite the updating of an agreement already in force by Croatia's accession to the European Union, we consider that the free trade agreement between Peru, Colombia and the European Union is having dramatic consequences for people by contributing to the impunity of international companies for human rights violations. In Podemos, we advocate an international, fair, balanced and sustainable trade that prioritizes the dignity of people and human rights for the profit of a few

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade agreements between the EU and international partners can bring important economic opportunities. Moreover, negotiating the terms of such agreements can help to promote human rights and environmental principles around the world. The addition of Croatia to this protocol formalises the participation of another EU Member State in this important trading agreement with two key Latin American countries.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement ensures that Croatia, as the newest Member State, becomes part of the EU trade agreement with Colombia and Peru. This is a positive thing, as all Member States must have a level playing field for international trade. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'trade agreement between the EU and its Member States on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other hand on the occasion of Croatia's accession to the EU', as it is logical to conclude from Croatia's accession to the EU that the country will also become part of the trade agreement. The agreement regulates, inter alia, trade in agricultural and industrial products and trade in services.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Croatia's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement by rejecting such trade agreements, which do not take into account economic asymmetry between the parties and which involve the expansion of a neocolonial economic model based on the deregulation and exploitation of third-country resources by European transnationals. Since the entry into force of the European Union Agreement and Colombia and Peru, the human rights situation in these countries has worsened, especially in those territories where European multinationals linked to the exploitation of natural resources have been installed, without the European Union having complied with the second clause which makes them subject to respect and guarantee of human rights. I therefore vote against Croatia's accession, considering that what this Parliament should approve is the suspension of the agreement, because it is not guaranteed compliance with human rights, the security of political and social leaders, trade unionists and human rights defenders.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The trade agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru was signed back in June 2012. This was before Croatia joined in July 2013. I voted in favour of this consent procedure which takes account of the accession of Croatia to the EU. While I know that Labour MEPs opposed the agreement with Colombia and Peru when it was first signed in 2012 because of our concern for the human rights situation in Colombia, in view of the agreement having been signed and provisionally implemented since 2013, it should be applied to all EU Member States.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Additional Protocol to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement has been negotiated to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. As I agree with the rapporteur's view that Croatia's participation in the trade agreement naturally results from its accession to the EU, I supported the approval of the protocol. I can only agree that it is appropriate for the Commission and the Council to take the necessary legal steps to enable this participation. The EU-Colombia-Peru agreement itself was signed in June 2012 and already in September of the same year the Commission started negotiations on an additional protocol in favour of Croatia. The aim of the agreement is to liberalise trade in agricultural and industrial products, as well as services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary measures or also on public procurement. I believe that Croatia's accession to this trade agreement will be beneficial to the country's economy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Expanding the scope of European companies is an important element of our foreign policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. Croatia's accession to the EU naturally results in Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement. The same agreement provides provisions on competition, intellectual property and public procurement, technical barriers to trade, provisions on the origin of goods, as well as sanitary and phytosanitary measures.  The same agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru was signed in Brussels in 2012 and some of its provisions have been in place since 2013. It is therefore necessary for the Commission and the Council to take certain necessary legal steps to make Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement possible. Consequently, I support this recommendation.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other hand, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural, industrial products and services. The agreement also contains provisions on the division of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's accession to the European Union required the adoption of a protocol by the Council to adjust the commitments made by the Union and its Member States to the other party before its accession, and it is necessary to involve Croatia in participating in the obligations arising from the Agreement. I support the proposal for a Council decision because I believe that Croatia's participation in the Trade Agreement naturally stems from its accession to the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an additional protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.  In September this year, it will be four years since the Commission opened negotiations with Colombia and Peru with a view to concluding an additional protocol for Croatia's entry into the EU. With Croatia's accession to the European Union, it is, of course, logical for it to join an agreement that provides for the liberalisation of trade in agricultural and industrial products, as well as services.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This Accession Protocol to the Trade Agreement with Peru and Colombia constitutes an international treaty regulating the trade agreement with Peru and Colombia to take account of Croatia's access to the EU. The point is that Croatia, too, can benefit from duty-free and non-tariff access to the countries' markets.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU with its decisions on free trade with third countries acts to the detriment of its Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union annexed to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The Agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, veterinary and phytary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. The European Parliament's agreement with this Council Decision is a binding element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation as it accepts that the trade agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru should be amended to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. The adoption by the EP of this Council Decision is a mandatory element of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol. Thus, by adopting the Recommendation, we will facilitate the process of bringing the Republic of Croatia, which joined the EU on 1 July 2013, to the agreements concluded or signed with third countries before its accession.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the main supporters of free trade worldwide. In this context, the EU has in recent years concluded a number of free trade agreements with certain countries of the world with which it has common economic interests. Colombia and Peru are two of those states, with which the Commission signed those agreements in 2012, documents approved by the European Parliament. The agreements liberalise trade transactions in agricultural and industrial products and in the field of services, also regulating a number of technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.  The current recommendation calls for Croatia to be included in this agreement after its accession to the EU in 2013. I believe that the current document enshrines a state of affairs and, therefore, I support its adoption in its current form.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. In the eyes of the European Parliament, Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the European Union. It was only time for the Commission and the Council to take the necessary legal steps to enable this participation.  In view of these elements, your rapporteur recommends that Parliament give its approval to the conclusion of the additional protocol on Croatia's participation in the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other. The approval of the Council's decision by the European Parliament is essential if the ratification procedure for the additional protocol is to be completed.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as in services and contains provisions on other issues such origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. This is a necessary step on the way to full integration of Croatia into the EU.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Croatia's participation in the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru naturally stems from Croatia's accession to the European Union.  This agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products and services.  Since this Agreement contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement, I consider that Parliament should give its consent to the conclusion of the Additional Protocol on Croatia's Participation in the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Colombia and the Republic of Peru, on the other.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, and I supported, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The European Union signed a trade agreement with Colombia and Peru in Brussels on 26 June 2012. On 11 December 2012, the European Parliament approved the conclusion of an agreement on the basis of a legislative resolution. The European Commission, with the mandate of the Council on 24 September 2012, opened negotiations with Colombia and Peru on the conclusion of an additional protocol concerning Croatia's accession to the European Union. The agreement provides for the liberalisation of trade in agricultural, industrial products and services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. In the rapporteur's view, Croatia's participation in this agreement is a natural continuation of its EU accession, which makes it understandable that measures have been taken by the Commission and the Council to facilitate this cooperation. The rapporteur also recommends that Parliament approve the conclusion of a protocol on Croatia's participation in a trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The final ratification of the Additional Protocol requires the approval of a Council decision.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution, because despite the updating of an agreement already in force by Croatia's accession to the European Union, we consider that the free trade agreement between Peru, Colombia and the European Union is having dramatic consequences for people by contributing to the impunity of international companies for human rights violations. In Podemos, we advocate an international, fair, balanced and sustainable trade that prioritizes the dignity of people and human rights for the profit of a few.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much support this report. I am in favour of trade and opening new markets for European SMEs. Europe can only grow with trade and not any more with public deficit. The level of debt in several EU Member States is already too high.  The EU and its Member States should do its utmost to facilitate future trade agreements in all areas of the world.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed on 26 June 2012. It concerns the liberalisation of rules on trade in agricultural, industrial and services products. Following croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, it is a natural process to join croatia in the abovementioned trade agreement, and I have therefore agreed to draw up an additional protocol on Croatia's participation in the agreement of 22 June 2012.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and some of its provisions have been applied since 1 March 2013 between the European Union and Peru in accordance with Article 330 of the Agreement and between the European Union and Colombia on 1 August 2013. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution, because despite the updating of an agreement already in force by Croatia's accession to the European Union, we consider that the free trade agreement between Peru, Colombia and the European Union is having dramatic consequences for people by contributing to the impunity of international companies for human rights violations. In Podemos, we advocate an international, fair, balanced and sustainable trade that prioritizes the dignity of people and human rights for the profit of a few.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural and industrial products as well as in services. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. I believe that the participation of Croatia in the Trade Agreement is a natural consequence of its EU accession.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a Council decision which includes Croatia in the commitments made in the trade agreement and incorporates the Croatian language into the implementation of the agreement. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. The European Parliament gave its approval on 11 December 2012. The agreement liberalises trade in agricultural products and industrial products, as well as trade in services. In addition, the Agreement contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property rights and public procurement. I agreed, of course, with croatia being an integral part of this agreement through its accession to the EU.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty. The Act of Accession determines Croatia's accession to these conventions and protocols. The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, and some of its provisions have been applied, pursuant to Article 330, between the European Union and Peru since 1 March 2013, and between the European Union and Colombia , since 1 August 2013. This is merely a legal procedure to conclude the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. It is a partnership and cooperation agreement and, as a rule, the agreement specifically referred to is part of the European Union's strategy of materialising its trade policy and foreign policy, and it aims to enshrine a free trade agreement, which we reject.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. "The rapporteur considers Croatia's participation in the trade agreement as a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. It is only appropriate that the Commission and the Council have taken the necessary legal steps to enable this participation." – I fully agree with that.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the recommendation of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, in order to take account of Croatia's accession.  The trade agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. This agreement liberalises trade transactions in agricultural and industrial products as well as in the field of services. The agreement also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The accession of new Member States to the EU also requires that international trade agreements between the EU and third countries be modified. This also applies to Croatia. Although today's vote may seem a formality at first sight, this is a step that needed to be taken in order for Croatia to be able to fully reap the benefits of its membership. I therefore supported Parliament's approving resolution in the vote.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the draft resolution, because it is logical for Croatia to join this agreement in the EU and Peru and Colombia.  It is simply an additional Protocol, which will expand trade in agricultural and industrial products, as well as services between the EU of 28 and Peru and Colombia.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the conclusion of a protocol on Croatia's participation in the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. Croatia's participation in the trade agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. It is therefore understandable that the Commission and the Council have taken the necessary legal measures to facilitate this cooperation.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Enhanced cooperation consists of a procedure that allows at least nine Member States to carry out more stringent integration or cooperation in a particular area of European law. In this way, the Member States in agreement are allowed to move at different speeds in order to achieve objectives that are considered urgent. In this case, cooperation was requested on decisions on property regimes between spouses, against which the countries of Eastern Europe showed some scepticism. In view of the existence of the requirements of the Treaties for this procedure, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the aim of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the enhanced cooperation proposed by the Council in two Regulations establishing a common European framework for the rules applicable to property schemes in international de facto marriages or couples.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report grants authorisation for enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered partnerships. I voted in favour of it, since this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this text on enhanced cooperation in the field of matrimonial regimes of international couples.  Indeed, enhanced cooperation is undoubtedly a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. There are fears of future interference in national family legislation, an area exclusively within the competence of member states.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The file concerns opening of enhanced cooperation between 17 Member States to define rules applicable for jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions for international couples. The content of any agreement has not been agreed yet, however the participating countries have stated that any rules will not seek to change the content of family law applicable in each of the participating Member States, nor affect their right to define what is considered as a registered partnership or the right to gay marriage. The agreement merely hopes to set out rules governing procedural rights in case of a conflict between jurisdictions. It was disappointing that Ireland and Britain have opted out as it is conflicts such as these which can cause unnecessary delays which led to obstructions and excessive legal costs.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. With this vote, I have given my consent to the enhanced cooperation proposed by the Council on two regulations establishing a common European framework for the applicable rules on the heritage regimes of international couples.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision approving enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property relations of international couples, covering both the matrimonial property and the property relations of registered partners, because the lives of international couples will benefit significantly as they gain legal certainty.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Between December 2015 and February 2016, Belgium, together with 16 other Member States, submitted an application to the Commission on the wish for greater cooperation between each other on the legal situation of property regimes in a marriage or registered civil partnership. The aim is to address the issues of jurisdiction, application, recognition and enforcement in a clear legal framework. In border areas in particular, closer cooperation with neighbouring countries is needed. International couples are not uncommon there. Until now, they have been left in the dark as to which authority is responsible for them or what the status of foreign documents is. This problem arises not only in cases of separation or death of the partner, but even in everyday matters of property. This report now aims to simplify the lives of those affected by a clear legal framework, which I very much welcome.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides for enhanced cooperation as a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the enhanced co-operation process in the area of property regimes of international couples. "Enhanced co-operation" is nothing more than a means by which sovereign member States are pressured into falling into line when they are able to exercise an effective veto on such legislation applying to them. The matter also presages the development of pan-EU law of family property and law of succession in relations thereto which will supersede national law. I remain committed to opposing in principle all legislative acts by the EU.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, the result of a long work by my colleague Jean-Marie Cavada, because it adopts new rules on the matrimonial regimes of international couples. The aim is to legally clarify the situation of these couples in the event of divorce or death. It was time for a European instrument on the rules governing matrimonial regimes. Now, international couples from all forms of unions will benefit from legal certainty, better access to justice and harmonization of rules. This applies to the 16 million international couples living in the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Decision to benefit from enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments applicable to the legal regime of international couples in the area of recognition and enforcement of judgments was taken in the event of stalling negotiations between all Member States on 2011. the initial proposals submitted by the Commission. Therefore, at the beginning of 2016, the Commission presented new proposals for acts based on the compromise text previously agreed through the enhanced cooperation procedure. In the context of enhanced cooperation, a number of conditions must be fulfilled: this must be a last resort where the objectives of such cooperation cannot be achieved by the Union as a whole within a reasonable time if at least nine Member States are involved; it must comply with the Treaties and Union law and respect the competences, rights and obligations of the Member States which have not been included in it; it must contribute to the achievement of the Union's objectives, to protect its interests and to strengthen the integration process; it must not weaken the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion, constitute an obstacle to or discriminate against trade between Member States or distort competition between them.  I support this recommendation, which proposes that Parliament should support enhanced cooperation in this area.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Regulations proposed by the rapporteur establish enhanced cooperation on the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of judgments in respect of the property regimes of international couples, both in matters relating to matria matriity property regimes and in the property aspects of registered partnerships.  The critical element is same-sex marriage and its property implications. If adopted, all Member States, including Hungary, will be obliged to apply the property consequences of a same-sex couple, which otherwise stipulates at constitutional level that marriage can only take place between a man and a woman. Several Member States have expressed concern that, even if future legal instruments do not require the introduction of unknown legal institutions into their national legal systems, the recognition of the property consequences of such foreign legal institutions in their countries would have a direct impact on their national family law system and family policy.  For all these reasons, I abstained in the vote.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation focuses on the standardisation of the heritage regimes of international couples, calling on Parliament to approve "enhanced cooperation" in this area.  However, this "enhanced cooperation" seems to me above all to be a prerequisite for the standardisation of the courts, effectively authorising the Commission's interference in national family laws. I have therefore voted against this report, by which the Commission is once again trying to force its way into areas that are not supposed to fall within its competence.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The aim here is to use enhanced cooperation on the heritage regimes of international couples, as 23 member states are in favour of it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Cavada report on enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples. This is a procedural measure approving an earlier Council decision authorising the development of enhanced cooperation in the areas concerned, in accordance with Article 20 TEU and Articles 326 and 327 TFEU. Enhanced cooperation appeared necessary given the refusal of some countries to support two projects proposed by the Commission in 2011. The initiation of this procedure, overcoming the deadlock, will allow 23 Member States to continue their integration on issues relating to the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, the property regimes between spouses and the property effects of registered partnerships.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to give its consent to the Council for the opening of enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the ownership regimes of international couples, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered unions. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on enhanced cooperation in the field of economic regimes of international couples. The decision to use this cooperation is taken following the stalling of negotiations between all Member States on the Commission's initial proposal for 2011. By 2013 Parliament had already given its favourable opinion, but in 2015 it was seen that there would be no agreement between the States. With this in mind and the requirements for opting for enhanced cooperation are met, the acts to be adopted do not infringe the rights of non-participating Member States or affect the internal market.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on enhanced cooperation in the area of the matrimonial regimes of international couples. This system is in effect in the direction of a harmonisation of the rules of conflict of laws, courts and enforcement of decisions relating to the matrimonial regimes of international couples, which carries the risk of leading to a submission of national law to European law in this matter. In this case, there is yet another example of a move by Brussels, since Hungary and Poland managed to block the Commission's initial proposals in 2011. It is therefore a question of circumventing the blocking of 'embarrassing states' in order to be able to impose on the other Member States a single family policy, a brutal procedure which we refuse.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples responds to a request made by 18 Member States, including Italy. This proposal is not dropped from the top of the EU institutions, but comes directly from the Member States to improve cooperation in this specific area. I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation by which Parliament grants its approval to enhanced cooperation in two Regulations establishing a common European framework for rules applicable to property schemes in international marriages or de facto couples.  The decision to resort to enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in the field of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered partnerships, is taken as a result of the impasse in negotiations between Member States on the initial proposals made by the Commission in 2011. In a Decision of December 2015, the Council recognised that it was not possible to achieve the unanimity of the 28 Member States for the adoption of the two Regulations. Eighteen Member States requested the Commission to propose a text of a Decision authorising enhanced cooperation between them to regulate homogeneously the ownership regimes of international couples, a proposal it submitted at the beginning of the year. The Recommendation is strictly formal and merely consents to the procedure, as Parliament will later vote on the Commission's proposed regulations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, law and enforcement of the property regime of international couples (matrimonial property regime and the property consequences of registered partnerships). The decision to benefit from enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments applicable to the property regime of international couples (matrimonial property regime and the property consequences of registered partnerships) was taken in the event of stalling of negotiations between all Member States on 2011. the initial proposals submitted by the Commission. Indeed, in the area of family law, legislative acts are adopted unanimously by the Council after consulting Parliament. 2013 Parliament approved the draft acts for 2011, but at the end of 2015 it became clear that Member States could not agree on proposals. Enhanced cooperation therefore seemed to be the best solution if the 23 Member States agreed in principle to the adoption of these two acts. Therefore, at the beginning of 2016, the Commission presented new proposals for acts based on the compromise text previously agreed through the enhanced cooperation procedure.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Visa-free travel within the EU, freer resettlement than before, has made the emergence of international couples more frequent. At the same time, negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. In 2013, Parliament gave a favourable opinion on the draft legislation for 2011, but at the end of 2015 it became clear that all Member States in the Council would not be able to agree with the proposals.  In view of this, enhanced cooperation has emerged as an ideal solution, provided that 23 Member States agreed in principle to adopt the two acts. At the beginning of 2016, the Commission therefore prepared proposals for new acts using the enhanced cooperation procedure, based on the agreement reached earlier on the content. In the present case, the conditions for a strengthened cooperation procedure are fulfilled and Parliament's agreement is justified for enhanced cooperation in this field. This decision will be the subject of a separate decision(s) "only" for a procedural decision, the related reports and the assessment of their detailed content. I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Council recommendation on enhanced cooperation in the area of the property regimes of international couples. The decision to strengthen cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the matrimonial property regime of international couples covering both matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships was taken after a deadlock in negotiations between all Member States on the initial proposals presented by the Commission in 2011. In early 2016, the Commission prepared new draft acts using the enhanced cooperation procedure, which is based on the content of the compromise text previously reached. Since the matter is procedurally in accordance with the agreement, I did not object to it.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the text voted on today, in which the European Parliament gave its approval to the establishment of enhanced cooperation between eighteen Member States of the Union, including Italy, in the field of competence, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, with reference to property regimes between spouses and the property effects of registered partnerships.
