The need for enhanced cooperation stems from the desire to provide a clearer and more complete legal framework for many international couples who often face problems arising from different national capital regimes, sometimes even conflicting with each other. The main aim of enhanced cooperation is therefore to deal coherently with the property regimes of couples, to provide greater certainty in the identification of the competent judicial authority, while at the same time including the possibility for the parties to enjoy a certain margin of autonomy in the choice of the applicable legislation. It is a question of avoiding the addition of parallel proceedings or the adoption of conflicting judicial decisions, offering legal certainty, simpler procedures and greater predictability for international couples, which are now increasingly numerous within the Union.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation is undoubtedly a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. There are fears of future interference in national family laws.  So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The file concerns opening of enhanced cooperation between 17 Member States to define rules applicable for jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions for international couples. The content of any agreement has not been agreed yet, however the participating countries have stated that any rules will not seek to change the content of family law applicable in each of the participating Member States, nor affect their right to define what is considered as a registered partnership or the right to gay marriage. The agreement merely hopes to set out rules governing procedural rights in case of a conflict between jurisdictions. It was disappointing that Ireland and Britain have opted out as it is conflicts such as these which can cause unnecessary delays which led to obstructions and excessive legal costs.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Enhanced cooperation in the area of property regimes of international couples is a decision made following the deadlock in negotiations between all Member States on the Commission's initial proposals in 2011. Enhanced cooperation is seen as the appropriate solution, being an option of last resort, where the objectives pursued by such cooperation cannot be achieved within a reasonable time by the Union as a whole, and the participation of at least nine Member States is necessary. This form of enhanced cooperation must be a lever to achieve the Union's objectives, protecting its interests and contributing to the integration process. I believe that enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimonial and property aspects of registered partnerships, is necessary in so far as certain bottlenecks cannot be overcome and the objectives pursued cannot be met in terms of the objectives pursued, which is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the field of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, with reference to the property regimes between spouses and the property effects of registered partnerships. Clear rules are laid down in the event of divorce or separation and an end to parallel and potentially conflicting proceedings in several Member States, offering greater legal clarity for international couples.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerned opening enhanced cooperation between 17 Member States in order to define the rules applicable for jurisdiction, applicable law and the enforcement of decisions for international couples. Although the content for any potential piece of legislation has not been agreed yet, preliminary frameworks state that future rules would not seek to change the content of family law in any participating EU country, or affect their right to define marriage or registered partnerships. Therefore, I am disappointed that Ireland opted out. Solving these kinds of procedural problems for international couples would have gone a long way to reducing unnecessary bureaucracy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with the Union and the citizens, enhanced cooperation regarding property regimes of international couples is proved to be an ideal solution. Therefore, I consent to the protocol of applying enhanced cooperation measure to tackle related issues.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 If the legal criteria for establishing enhanced cooperation are in place, I voted in favour of its activation. The call for enhanced cooperation comes from the fact that some countries, mainly in Eastern Europe, do not want to continue integration with regard to the movement of decisions on property regimes between spouses (with particular reference to those on civil unions).

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the progress made by the Process of European Integration, millions of citizens linked by marriage or international registered partnership encounter practical problems in the management of their assets. In fact, it is often difficult for such couples to know which court has jurisdiction and what property regime is applicable to the situation of their assets, especially in the event of separation or succession. In the field of family law, legislative acts are adopted by the Council unanimously. However, in this particular case, in the absence of unanimous approval of the proposals, 18 Member States requested a strengthened cooperation procedure.  I supported the vote of this House, which gave its agreement to the Council to authorise enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples, so as to provide states party to Community legislation with a clear and complete legal framework relating to competence, applicable law, recognition and implementation of decisions on property regimes, which will facilitate the resolution of problems in this area for many international couples.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as the acts to be adopted do not affect the rights of Member States that do not participate and do not affect the internal market. We believe that this enhanced cooperation in the field of the property law of international couples is fully in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the recommendation for the adoption of enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property relations of international couples, covering both the matrimonial property relations and the property relations of registered partners, is an attempt to optimise the existing rules and institutional framework. At the same time, it lays the foundations for speeding up judicial proceedings. I therefore believe that it is moving in the right direction and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as the Commission, at the beginning of 2016, presented, using the enhanced cooperation procedure, new proposals for acts based on the content of the compromise reached previously.  Enhanced cooperation must fulfil several conditions: to be the last remaining resource, when the objectives of such cooperation cannot be achieved within a reasonable period of time by the Union as a whole, provided that at least nine Member States participate; respect the Treaties and Union law, as well as the competences, rights and obligations of member states that do not participate in them; promote the achievement of the Union's objectives, protect its interests and strengthen its integration process; not prejudice either the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion; it does not constitute an obstacle or discrimination against trade between Member States, nor to distort competition between them. This enhanced cooperation in the field of the property law of international couples is therefore clearly in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal stems from the deadlock in negotiations between Member States which do not find a common meeting point for all. I therefore agree with the proposal for enhanced cooperation as an ideal solution, since it is fully in line with the objectives of the European Union and is intended as a last resort when the objectives of cooperation cannot be achieved within a reasonable period of time. These are the reasons why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote on enhanced cooperation in the area of property regimes of international couples.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Commission presented a proposal for the recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes of international couples, including matrimonial property regimes and the property effects of registered partnerships – a much-needed measure, given the higher frequency of transnational couples. However, it was not possible to reach a consensus in the Council, which was solely competent in these matters and bound by unanimity. Thus, a group of 18 Member States were prepared to move forward with the measures, thus taking care of the enhanced cooperation mechanism. It is this enhanced cooperation that is adopted today – a purely procedural decision, in so far as it seeks only to assess the legal criteria for its use, which take place without any uncertainty, but also because Parliament had already shown its agreement with the substance of the compromise reached earlier. I therefore support this report.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the enhanced co-operation process in the area of property regimes of international couples.  Firstly, ‘enhanced co-operation’ is nothing more than a means by which sovereign Member States are pressured into falling into line when they are able to exercise an effective veto on such legislation applying to them. Secondly, this matter presages the development of a pan-EU law of family property and law of succession in relation thereto which will supersede national law. Thirdly, this matter is the precursor to legislation by the EU. UKIP remains committed to opposing, in principle, all legislative acts by the EU.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report grants authorisation for enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered partnerships. I voted in favour of it, since this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the field of family law, after consulting Parliament, legislative acts are adopted by the Council unanimously. However, it soon became clear that not all Member States would agree to the proposals. Enhanced cooperation has thus established itself as an ideal solution, in so far as 23 Member States have in principle agreed to adopt the two acts. Such enhanced cooperation must be an option of last resort, respect the Treaties and Union law, facilitate the achievement of the Union's objectives and not prejudice the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion. I voted for the introduction of enhanced cooperation, so that there would be no more deadlock in negotiations between all Member States.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The decision to apply enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property regimes of international couples (covers both matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships) is a purely procedural decision. Both of the above-mentioned Council Regulations concern jurisdiction and applicable law. Issues relating to the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, as well as maintenance obligations and the succession of the estate of the deceased spouse are excluded from their scope. Your rapporteur proposes that Parliament agree to enhanced cooperation in this area. The main controversy with this proposal is that the decision authorising enhanced cooperation is precedent-setting. For the first time, it obliges Member States to bind themselves simultaneously to two instruments, one on civil partnerships and the other on marriage. This solution also raises concerns in the context of Article 4(2) of the IU guaranteeing Member States respect for their national identity, in this particular case as regards the definition of family law institutions. Furthermore, states will also be required to be bound by a regulation on the property consequences of civil partnerships in order to benefit their citizens from the application of the Matrimonial Property Regimes Regulation. In view of the controversy surrounding this regulation, I voted against it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this formal consent procedure giving Parliament’s go-ahead for enhanced cooperation proposed by the Council on two regulations establishing a common European framework for rules applicable to property regimes for international married couples or registered partnerships.  Parliament will be called upon at a later stage to give its opinion on the Commission proposals for regulations regarding the jurisdiction applicable for property aspects related to matrimonial regimes and registered partnerships.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report examines the possibility of enhanced cooperation between 23 Member States on the matrimonial regimes of international couples. This is a sensitive issue as long as national legal regimes are different in Europe on this subject. If enhanced cooperation must always be a choice of last resort after trying to reach an agreement with all Member States, if cooperation with all 28 Member States is impossible.  I would like to point out that enhanced cooperation is very much regulated by the European treaties in order to respect the rights of the citizens of the Member States who do not participate in this cooperation. Considering that more than 14 million European citizens live in a Member State different from their Home State, and that they face tedious administrative procedures in the event of international marriages, and that it is necessary to ease these administrative obstacles, I have supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows for enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage regimes of international couples, on issues relating to both matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships. I believe it is essential to ensure legal certainty for international couples, as well as a simplification of the circulation of authentic acts throughout the European Union.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because international couples face too many difficulties, both in the management of their property and in the time of community sharing in the event of separation or death of one of the two spouses. It is therefore necessary to achieve a harmonisation of EU rules in this area.  I supported this report to make the management of the assets of these international couples easier, and to provide them with more legal certainty. This report simplifies administrative procedures and provides equal treatment for all couples, regardless of the form of marriage or union by which they are linked.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation.

text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules regarding the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. For these reasons, I voted against this text, which follows the non-participation of Denmark, Ireland, the United Kingdom and the blocking of Hungary and Poland in the negotiations on the initial proposals made by the Commission in 2011.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decision to resort to enhanced cooperation in the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments on the issue of the property regime of international couples covers both matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships, and this is only a procedural decision. The main problem here is that the decision to authorise enhanced cooperation for the first time requires Member States to join the two instruments (partnerships and marriages) at the same time. However, a number of Member States are not familiar with the institution "partnerships" (Cyprus, Bulgaria, Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia), Bulgaria is one of those countries, but they will have to adopt the two regulations on the implementation of enhanced cooperation if they want to adopt the Regulation on matrimonial property regimes to be applicable in the Member State concerned.  Furthermore, they will have to recognise the effects coming from the institution 'partnerships', which is not recognised by their domestic law and may possibly be considered to be contrary to their public policies, particularly in the field of private international law and their domestic law, in accordance with the fundamental principles of the legal system of the Member State. For these many reasons, and the ambiguity as to why these two proposals go hand in hand, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, because family law must be respected in any case, in order to protect the rights of international couples.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. In the present case, the conditions for a strengthened cooperation procedure are fulfilled and Parliament's agreement is justified for enhanced cooperation in this field. This decision will be the subject of a separate decision(s) 'only' and the detailed content of the related reports will be the subject of a separate decision(s). I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. A number of studies have revealed the high number of transnational couples in the Union and the practical and legal difficulties faced by these couples, both in the day-to-day administration of their assets and in their division when the couple separates or one of its members dies. These difficulties are often the result of the wide disparity of applicable rules, both substantive law and private international law, which regulate the economic effects of marriage. The objective of this proposal is therefore to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for the determination of jurisdiction and the law applicable to matrimonial economic schemes, and to facilitate the movement between Member States of judgments and other acts in this area.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented new proposals for an act at the beginning of 2016 through the enhanced cooperation mechanism, based on the content, on the commitment previously reached. Enhanced cooperation should be an option of last resort where the objectives of the cooperation in question cannot be achieved within a reasonable time by the Union as a whole; must comply with treaties and Union law; it should promote the achievement of the Union's objectives, preserve its interests and strengthen its integration process, and must not prejudice the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I'm voting against it. Enhanced cooperation is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this is a purely procedural decision, which is necessary for the establishment of enhanced cooperation, we would like to express our support for the Council's decision. The procedure will make it possible to unblock negotiations in an area of great importance, in our opinion, such as competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, with regard to property regimes between spouses and the property effects of registered partnerships.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation suggests enhanced cooperation between Member States with regard to Family Law, specifically the property regime of international couples. This international cooperation within the EU was requested by 17 Member States, one of which was Portugal. Participating Member States may continue to make use of their law, in particular with regard to registered partnerships and same-sex marriages. In 2007, around 300 000 international marriages were celebrated in the EU and around 500 000 international marriages were dissolved (by divorce or the death of one of the spouses). Currently citizens face different practical problems with the management of the ownership regime when they are in an international marriage or partnership. It is usually very difficult for people to know which courts are competent and what laws apply to their personal situation and the situation of their property. As a result of this problem, they face unintended and disadvantageous consequences, not only in the daily management of their assets, but also when the couple is apart or a member of the couple dies. Strengthening cooperation in this area will bring some advantages. The rights of non-participating Member States are safeguarded with regard to the priority of implementing their national law. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Positive for citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Legislative acts in the field of family law must be adopted unanimously by the Council. The decision to make use of enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of property regimes for international couples seems to be an ideal solution, as in principle the Council of 23 Member States agreed to adopt these acts. Enhanced cooperation must fulfil a number of conditions, including respect for the Treaty and European Union law and the competences, rights and obligations of Member States not participating in them. The acts adopted do not therefore infringe the rights of non-participating Member States and do not affect the internal market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which is the result of a free choice of cooperation between certain States on the property regime of couples.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation, because family law must be respected in any case, in order to protect the rights of international couples.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. This decision will be the subject of a separate decision(s) 'only' and the detailed content of the related reports will be the subject of a separate decision(s). I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Enhanced Cooperation Recommendation, considering that twenty-three Member States agree, in principle, to adopt such acts and do not harm the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion, nor do they constitute an obstacle or discrimination for trade between Member States, nor do they cause distortions of competition between them. The acts to be adopted do not infringe the rights of non-participating Member States. This enhanced cooperation in the field of international couples' economic law is clearly in line with the objectives of the Union and is in the interests of its citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the field of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, with reference to property regimes between spouses and the property effects of registered partnerships.  Parliament strongly supported the authorisation of this enhanced cooperation, provided for in the TFEI, in an area of close concern to European citizens and clearly in line with the Union's objectives, but above all it intervenes after the deadlock in negotiations between all Member States on the initial proposals presented by the Commission in 2011 and allows most Member States in favour of enhanced cooperation to move forward in this important area. , without harming the interests of Member States that are not in favour of greater integration. I supported this resolution because it fulfils important conditions such as promoting the achievement of the Union's objectives, protecting its interests and respecting the Treaties and Union law, as well as the competences, rights and obligations of Member States that do not participate in it, protecting its interests and strengthening its integration process.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on enhanced cooperation in the area of property regimes for international couples, as it leaves many unanswered questions: firstly, I do not consider the area to be an EU competence – so it must be left to the Member States to decide which types of partnership they officially recognise and which do not. For example, child marriages – concluded in other European countries, are unfortunately still recognised in some EU countries. It would be a devastating signal if all EU Member States suddenly had to accept this inhumane form of forced marriage. Furthermore, I do not understand how, in such a report, amendments can be rejected in the relevant committee and a debate on them cannot even be held in plenary. That is not my idea of parliamentary culture at European level.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Cooperation in the field of property regimes of international couples needs to be improved. This concerns, inter alia, the regulation of jurisdictions, the applicable law and recognition and enforcement. The term international couples refers to matrimonial property regimes and estate regimes of registered partnerships.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to clarify the rules applicable to the property regimes of international couples in the European Union. Today, there are approximately 16 million international couples living in the European Union and accounting for a fifth of the unions registered on Eu ropean territory. The costs of parallel legal proceedings in different countries are estimated at over EUR 1 billion per year. The decision to use enhanced cooperation in the area of applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, I believe is the best way to act to reach agreement between all Member States on the proposals presented by the Commission.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to give its consent to the Council for the opening of enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the ownership regimes of international couples, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered unions. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The decision to have recourse to enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the matter of property regimes of international couples, covering both matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships, has been taken since negotiations between all Member States, on the Commission’s initial proposals of 2011, reached stalemate.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report, since it facilitates the residence of foreign/international couples in a Member State of which they are not nationals and that this enhanced cooperation between Member States will be determined between them.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation between Member States in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, covering both matters of matrimonial property regimes will benefit international couples and facilitate for them a clear and comprehensive legal framework which ensures adequate solutions for them in terms of legal certainty, predictability and flexibility. It would also enable couples from different Member States to have various procedures handled by the same court and thereby avoid parallel proceedings and conflicting judicial decisions.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections in relation to the final result.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on enhanced cooperation in the area of the estate of international couples. While I welcome approaches that make it easier for some 13 million bi-national families and permanent citizens living abroad to obtain recognition of their personal documents and documents. However, this must not lead to undermining subsidiarity and undermining national law, for example in the legal recognition of different forms of partnership. But that is the case here. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. In 2013, Parliament gave a favourable opinion on the draft legislation for 2011, but at the end of 2015 it became clear that all Member States in the Council would not be able to agree with the proposals.  In view of this, enhanced cooperation has emerged as an ideal solution, provided that 23 Member States agreed in principle to adopt the two acts. At the beginning of 2016, the Commission therefore prepared proposals for new acts using the enhanced cooperation procedure, based on the agreement reached earlier on the content. In the present case, the conditions for a strengthened cooperation procedure are fulfilled and Parliament's agreement is justified for enhanced cooperation in this field. This decision will be the subject of a separate decision(s) "only" for a procedural decision, the related reports and the assessment of their detailed content. I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this document which underlines the recognition and enforcement of resolutions on the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of unions registered in EU Member States

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to establish a common European framework for rules applicable to property regimes for international married couples or registered partnerships. It is important to mention that Member States that do not want to be affected by this procedure opted out. We hope that this report will make the life of European international couples much easier and offer them legal certainty.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to authoraly authorane enhanced cooperation in the area of competence and applicable law and to recognise and enforce decisions on the property regimes of international couples, including in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes and property consequences of registered partnerships, as this gives consent to that draft Council decision.    I support the new proposals for acts submitted by the Commission and based on the enhanced cooperation process. That procedure implies that it is applied as a last resort that complies with legal obligations and texts, while improving the Union's objectives and not harming EU cohesion. Accordingly, I consider that, in this particular case, the conditions of that procedure are met, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules regarding the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. I have voted against this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to authorise the establishment of enhanced cooperation between 17 Member States on the heritage regimes of international couples. Such cooperation should create a clear and comprehensive legal framework and better protect European citizens.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report aims to strengthen cooperation among 18 Member States in order to regulate more effectively the areas of case law, recognition and implementation of decisions on the ownership of 'international' couples. Given that the enhanced cooperation instrument is voluntary and that the remaining 10 EU Member States cannot be forced to harmonise in this way, this extension of private international law is particularly useful. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on enhanced cooperation in the area of the estate of international couples. While I welcome approaches that make it easier for some 13 million bi-national families and permanent citizens living abroad to obtain recognition of their personal documents and documents. However, this must not lead to undermining subsidiarity and undermining national law, for example in the legal recognition of different forms of partnership. But that is the case here.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 concerning jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, have reached a deadlock. In 2013, Parliament gave a favourable opinion on the draft legislation for 2011, but at the end of 2015 it became clear that all Member States in the Council would not be able to agree with the proposals.  In view of this, enhanced cooperation has emerged as an ideal solution, provided that 23 Member States agreed in principle to adopt the two acts. At the beginning of 2016, the Commission therefore prepared proposals for new acts using the enhanced cooperation procedure, based on the agreement reached earlier on the content. In the present case, the conditions for a strengthened cooperation procedure are fulfilled and Parliament's agreement is justified for enhanced cooperation in this field. This decision will be the subject of a separate decision(s) 'only' and the detailed content of the related reports will be the subject of a separate decision(s). I therefore voted in favour of authorising cooperation

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Recommendation, which deals with the use of enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property relations of international couples. The enhanced cooperation mechanism is designed to deal with paralysis situations, enabling a set of countries to make enhanced integration in certain areas, in this case, in the area of property law. In this way, it can contribute to the modernisation of the system of application of this law in Europe but also facilitate procedural procedures for unmarried or even same-sex couples.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I have supported the council's long-awaited recommendation on a draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of married couples and registered partnerships (08112/2016 - C8-0184/2016 - 2016/0061 (NLE)). The package took several years to work on, and its content is the harmonisation of legal standards for matrimonial property regimes. It determines how to deal with conflicts of property law of individual Member States, lays down rules for the recognition and declaration of enforceability of judgments, court settlements and authentic instruments in those cases.  I very much regret that Poland is not in a broad coalition of countries that have agreed to common solutions. In support of the government's position on the matter of 11 March 2016, we read that the reason for non-cooperation is that the regulation also applies to same-sex marriage and civil partnerships. Although the regulation does not refer in this passage Polish countries that do not have legislation for same-sex couples, the government in 2015 vetoed and thus prevented thousands of Poles who have decided to dissolve their international marriages from benefiting from enhanced cooperation between EU countries in this area.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This recommendation requires Parliament to give its approval to enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples. These proposals will make it possible to lay down precise rules that will enable very long proceedings to be terminated in the event of divorce or separation, in accordance with the objectives and interests of EU citizens. I am therefore in favour of this recommendation.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it promotes EU interference in national family legislation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is to obtain Parliament's approval to use the enhanced cooperation procedure concerning the jurisdiction of the matrimonial regimes of international couples. However, this procedure is intended to be used as a last resort, in order to respect the treaties and EU law.  However, since the non-participation of Denmark, Ireland, the United Kingdom, and the blocking of Hungary and Poland on the negotiations of the initial proposals made by the Commission in 2011, the Commission is trying to force through. Acceptance of the text will pave the way for the standardisation of the rules on matrimonial regimes, which is a violation of the sovereignty of Member States in the family domain. I voted AGAINST IT firmly.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report grants authorisation for enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered partnerships. I voted in favour of it, since this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on enhanced cooperation in the area of the estate of international couples. While I welcome approaches that make it easier for some 13 million bi-national families and permanent citizens living abroad to obtain recognition of their personal documents and documents. However, this must not lead to undermining subsidiarity and undermining national law, for example in the legal recognition of different forms of partnership. But that is the case here.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I have no objection to some States launching so-called enhanced cooperation with each other, that is to say, to adopt common regulations as regards the recognition of judicial decisions, in particular in the area of division of property in mixed marriage divorces. The Czech Republic and 16 other countries also want to participate in enhanced cooperation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Enhanced cooperation between Member States in this area must be a last resort, which applies when the Union as a whole cannot achieve the objectives of such cooperation within a reasonable timeframe and must be attended by at least nine Member States. It must also comply with treaties and UNION law and respect the competences, rights and obligations of those Member States not participating there. As these conditions are met and the acts adopted do not harm the rights of Member States which do not participate in enhanced cooperation or affect the internal market, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This vote concerned a proposal for a Council Regulation under which 18 Member States of the European Union could establish a platform for closer cooperation in the field of property relations between international couples. The aim of enhanced cooperation is to develop judicial cooperation in civil matters having cross-border aspects on the basis of the principle of mutual recognition of court judgments and to ensure the compatibility of the rules applicable in the Member States with regard to conflicts of law in those matters. Given that an increasing number of international couples are registered in the Union every year, this type of legal framework based on common principles is very necessary. It is, however, of principle that citizens of the 10 Member States who chose not to participate in this partnership are not legally restricted in the case of further registration of couples of this type or existing couples.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. So far, there are no European standards for matrimonial regimes. No European instrument therefore applies to the heritage consequences of registered partnerships. The Council's two proposed regulations aim to define harmonised Community rules on matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships, with regard to conflicts of laws, judicial jurisdiction, mutual recognition and enforcement of decisions in these matters.  These texts, which are submitted to the European Parliament for advice, are likely to provide better legal certainty for couples married or united by registered partnership and to guarantee easier access to justice and greater predictability in the management of their assets. They are therefore an important step forward in the dissolution of matrimonial regimes and partnerships because they put all forms of marriage or union on the same level, thus enabling equal treatment for all couples. I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision approving enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property relations of international couples, covering both the matrimonial property relations and the property relationships of registered partners, because it is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 17 Member States decided to introduce a system of so-called enhanced cooperation (including the Czech Republic) in order to bring clear rules that would adjust the property conditions of international married couples and registered partnerships. The aim is to provide higher legal certainty for such couples, whose number is constantly increasing. It is clear that in the event of a divorce or the death of a partner, a person living in an international union, of which there are around 16 million in the EU, may find himself in a difficult situation facing an uncertain legal situation. The purpose of the proposals is, for example, to clarify the jurisdiction of the national court, the applicable law, to facilitate the enforcement and recognition of judicial decisions, etc. I believe that this will make life easier for couples and save them additional costs, which amount to up to EUR 400 million per year. I therefore agreed with the proposal put forward.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Union legislative acts in the field of Family Law are adopted following a unanimous decision of the Council and in cooperation with the European Parliament. With regard to international couples, the Commission has proposed in early 2016 a plan for enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on property relations between spouses and registered spouses. In order to reach agreement on enhanced cooperation between Member States in the field of international couples, there are some prerequisite criteria that should be met. For example, the agreement should be compatible with and respect the rights of non-participating States. Finally, enhanced cooperation in relation to the property rights of international couples should not affect the internal market and create problems in the trade of the Member States of the Union or unfair competition between them in such matters. Looking at the Commission's proposal, I believe that the above conditions are met, so I would like to vote in favour of this recommendation to approve enhanced cooperation in the field of property law for international couples, since it is in line with the principles of the Treaties of the Union.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, the European Parliament gives its assent to enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of ownership of international couples. This seems to me to be useful, and so I have voted in favour of this.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support enhanced cooperation in the area of the property regime of international couples, applicable jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments.  In the area of family law, legislative acts are adopted unanimously by the Council after consulting Parliament. This Parliament's decision is therefore more procedural.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliament here supports the Council's proposal to establish enhanced cooperation between 17 voluntary Member States in order to facilitate the recognition of a marriage or a PACS between two citizens of different nationalities at home. This principle of mutual recognition will have concrete consequences beneficial for the daily lives of more than half of the European population in terms of matrimonial regimes and the heritage consequences of the separation of couples.  The couples' heritage regimes will be treated under a single law, the law of the state with which the couple has the closest ties and they will be able to choose the law to be applied to their property in the event of separation on the same principle. This cooperation will therefore cover same-sex marriages when the two states have recognized these rights, which has obviously awakened the reactionaries of "La Manif pour Tous". I vote for this collaboration between states, a factor of increased legal certainty for millions of couples in Europe, regardless of their gender or nationality.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules regarding the heritage regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. Therefore, I objected to that report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to this proposal as it stands, as the enhanced cooperation in this particular area of family is in the interest of citizens and in accordance with the objectives of the European Union.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and in the Protocol on the application of the principles, form the basis for the functioning of the EU and the guiding principles on which European law is built. They regulate the system for taking specific decisions at EU level in order to ensure a precise definition of the cases in which the Union is responsible for issuing binding legislative acts. Such a mechanism contributes to making decisions as close as possible to the citizens. In the current period of deep crises, it is more necessary than ever to rediscover our common European identity, including through closer integration in various areas. One such area is cooperation in internal matters which, by reason of their sensitivity, a priori belongs to the Member States. I believe that we must be particularly vigilant in defining cases in the area of the interior where cooperation is functional and useful, as the measures in question will directly affect citizens' lives. I consider that the matrimonial property settlement falls within the scope of areas to be left to the exclusive competence of the Member States and where measures taken at EU level pose a serious risk. Moreover, the Council's proposal for a reference to registered partnerships forcibly pushes this issue, despite the fact that it has a serious conflict with the interests of some Member States, including Slovakia. I consider such action unacceptable and I am strictly voting against the recommendation tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of report, which aims to give Parliament’s consent to the enhanced cooperation proposed by Council on two regulations establishing a common European framework for rules applicable to property regimes for international married couples or registered partnerships.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By the end of 2015, it became clear that the Commission's 2011 proposal on matters affecting the property regimes of international couples, supported by Parliament, could not be adopted in the Council. However, since 23 Member States agreed in principle to the proposal, the Council adopted a proposal for a decision authorising enhanced cooperation, which requires Parliament's consent.   Enhanced cooperation is a last resort with the participation of at least nine Member States when the objectives of cooperation cannot be achieved within a reasonable timefram by the Union as a whole. It must respect EU treaties and Union law, as well as the powers, rights and obligations of Member States that do not participate in cooperation. It should promote the achievement of the Union's objectives, protect its interests and strengthen its integration process. Finally, it must not adversely affect the internal market and economic, social and territorial cohesion, discriminate or impede trade between Member States and distort competition between them. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, it is clear that these conditions are fulfilled in this case and therefore proposes that Parliament give its consent to enhanced cooperation in this area. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The enhanced cooperation proposed to be ratified here is a prerequisite for the standardization of the rules on conflict of laws, courts and enforcement of decisions on the matrimonial regimes of international couples. It is therefore an interference in national family legislation, an area where it is necessary to keep full sovereignty to states, given the significant differences that may exist in this area with our neighbours. As a result, the vote is negative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decision to use enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes of international couples was taken in 2011 and Parliament issued a favourable opinion in 2013. Enhanced cooperation was considered the ideal solution, and in 2016 the Commission presented new proposals for an act through the enhanced cooperation mechanism: last resort option; respect for treaties and Union law; objectives and does not undermine the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion. I believe that this enhanced cooperation in the field of property law for international couples is in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation in the field of matrimonial regimes is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since this file does not relate to the UK, and will not have any effect on British citizens, I voted to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's proposal for a decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on international couples' regimes. In a European Union that is trying to put in place common legislation in order to avoid conflicts of law and jurisdiction as much as possible, the adoption of such a report is part of this process which I support.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for enhanced cooperation on property regimes affecting international couples. It is of the utmost importance that regulations concerning property regimes for international couples, including matrication property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, can be applied in full respect of EU treaties and EU law.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Negotiations have been taking place between EU Member States regarding the establishment of a common European Framework for rules applicable to property regimes for international couples and registered partnerships following the Commission’s initial proposal in 2011. I support this recommendation that will give the European Parliament’s consent regarding the enhanced cooperation proposed by the Council.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is perfectly understandable that enhanced cooperation with all Member States in the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of ownership of international couples must be regulated.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The free movement of persons within the EU should also be accompanied by legal certainty for people from different countries who have wished to marry. The current system creates situations where it is difficult for people who are divorcing or otherwise ended to have a partnership to understand which country they should be able to do in the judicial and legal system. Enhanced cooperation in this area is therefore important and I hope that Estonia will also join it.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The draft Council Decision approving enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property relations of international couples covering both the matrimonial property and the property relations of registered partners was approved by Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs and was therefore put to a vote in plenary. As can be seen from the text of the explanatory memorandum, although family law requires unanimity within the Council, Parliament's intervention triggers enhanced cooperation. The above vote was therefore procedural in nature and with my vote in favour I simply confirmed Parliament's earlier decision to resort to this cooperation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the enhanced cooperation process in the area of property regimes of international couples. Firstly, ‘enhanced co-operation’ is nothing more than a means by which sovereign Member States are pressured into falling into line when they are able to exercise an effective veto on such legislation applying to them. Secondly, this matter presages the development of a pan-EU law of family property and law of succession in relation thereto which will supersede national law. Thirdly, this matter is the precursor to legislation by the EU. UKIP remains committed to opposing, in principle, all legislative acts by the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to this proposal, I voted in favour. Following a stalemate in negotiations between the Member States on the property rights of international couples, the use of enhanced cooperation, a hypothesis provided for in Article 20 of the Treaty on European Union, seems to be the only way forward for this issue to date. In view of the fact that closer cooperation complies, in this case, with the conditions laid down in the Treaty, I felt it necessary to express my support.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Bulgaria is one of the 17 Member States that addressed a request to the Commission to propose a decision authorising the establishment of enhanced cooperation between themselves in the field of property regimes of international couples. The proposal brings more clarity for international couples managing their property and I fully support it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The fact is that citizens who are married internationally face various practical problems of a property-legal nature. Different countries have different legal regulations for the regulation of property rights of international couples. Spouses may have different nationalities, live in countries whose nationality they do not have, have assets in different Member States, and may also find themselves in a legal dilemma over the relevant property system as a result of the death.  I therefore consider that enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property regimes of international couples would contribute to simplifying the resolution of property-legal problems. In particular, I would highlight giving international couples the opportunity to choose the law to apply to their property and allowing different citizens' actions to be dealt with by the same court, thus avoiding parallel proceedings and conflicting judicial decisions.  However, I am concerned about the explicit wording that equates a registered partnership with marriage in a Commission proposal, as it is not and cannot be the same. This restores the Commission's competence to the Member States and attempts to redefine the institution of a family based on marriage between a man and a woman, which is unacceptable to me, and therefore I have not been able to support this Recommendation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Enhanced cooperation in the field of matrimonial regimes is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The application of enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property regimes of international couples, including matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships, was decided after the blocking of negotiations between all Member States on the original Commission proposals of 2011. Enhanced cooperation must meet certain conditions: it must be a last resort, which applies when the Union as a whole cannot achieve the objectives of such cooperation within a reasonable timeframe and must be attended by at least nine Member States; must comply with the Treaties and Union law and respect the competences, rights and obligations of those Member States that do not participate in it; must improve the Union's objectives, protect its interests and strengthen its integration process; it must not harm the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion, nor constitute an obstacle or discrimination in trade between Member States or distort competition between them. I agree with Parliament's decision to give its consent to the Council's draft decision authorisation of enhanced cooperation in the area of competence and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, including in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes and property consequences of registered partnerships.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The bottom of this recommendation is to recommend enhanced cooperation between Member States with regard to Family Law, specifically the property regime of international couples. Currently, citizens face different practical problems with the management of the ownership regime when they are in an international marriage or partnership. Strengthening cooperation in the area of jurisdiction with respect to applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes of international couples, covering both matrimonial and property-related regimes of registered partnerships, will bring citizens benefits according to the recommendation: - to treat the ownership regimes of couples consistently under a single applicable legislation and by a single authority; - allow international couples to choose the law applicable to their property; - increase legal certainty for international couples through the application of the state law with which the couple has the most close connection; - allow citizens to have several procedures handled by the same court and thus avoid parallel proceedings and conflicting judicial decisions;  - improving predictability for international couples by simplifying procedures for the recognition and enforcement of decisions and the circulation of authentic acts across the EU; We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Enhanced cooperation concerns the property rights of international couples and this proposal is unequivocally in line with the Union's objectives and in the interests of its citizens. At the beginning of 2016, using the enhanced cooperation procedure, the Commission submitted new proposals for acts, substantially based on the agreement previously reached with the Member States.  Enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples, including matrimonial property regimes and property consequences of registered partnerships, has imposed itself as an ideal solution, as 23 Member States have agreed in principle to adopt these acts. I supported Representative Cavada's recommendation, as enhanced cooperation meets the conditions set by the Commission and the proposed acts do not harm Member States that do not participate in enhanced cooperation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decision to use enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples comes as a result of the deadlock in negotiations between Member States. At the beginning of 2016, therefore, the Commission presented, using the enhanced cooperation procedure as a last resort, new proposals for acts based on the compromise reached previously. I voted in favour of approving enhanced cooperation in this area.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The decision to apply enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property regimes of international couples covers both matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships. The Regulations concern the recognition and enforcement of judicial decisions in the field of matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships and apply to cross-border cases. Issues relating to the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the estate of the deceased spouse are excluded from their scope. The main controversy with this proposal is the fact that, for the first time, Member States are committed to binding on two instruments at the same time – one on civil partnerships and the other on marriage. A number of Member States still do not know the institutions of the civil partnership (Cyprus, Bulgaria, Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia) and, in order to be covered by the Matrimonial Property Regimes Regulation, they must accede to both regulations implementing enhanced cooperation and agree to recognise the effects of partnership institutions which they do not recognise under their internal law and which may be considered contrary to their public policy in the field of private international law , and in the field of internal law with the fundamental principles of their legal system, including constitutional status. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome a higher degree of cooperation in matters of private international law. In particular, the area of international couples dealt with here is, in my experience, a field where specific people will feel the specific benefits of this legislation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage regimes of international couples, i.e. of two different nationalities. This enhanced cooperation will address both issues relating to matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships. This demonstrates the usefulness of cooperation between states at European level to further protect EU citizens.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the enhanced cooperation process in the area of property regimes of international couples. Firstly, ‘enhanced co-operation’ is nothing more than a means by which sovereign Member States are pressured into falling into line when they are able to exercise an effective veto on such legislation applying to them. Secondly, this matter presages the development of a pan-EU law of family property and law of succession in relation thereto which will supersede national law. Thirdly, this matter is the precursor to legislation by the EU. UKIP remains committed to opposing, in principle, all legislative acts by the EU.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Love knows no borders, and that is what Parliament reminded us of in voting this afternoon by a large majority. It will allow married couples and legal cohabitants living in another EU country to have their relationship recognised and the administrative maze simplified. Some Member States have slowed this process, which began in 2011. Belgium and 17 other countries are now deciding to move forward and achieve their mutual recognition of legal marriages and cohabitations through enhanced cooperation. In these Member States, heritage regimes will be harmonised and couples will be able to choose the law that will govern their heritage (that of their country of election or that of which they are nationals). This cooperation also increases legal security and predictability, especially when one of the spouses or partners dies.  Every year, 300,000 new international marriages are celebrated in Europe, and 500,000 are dissolved due to divorce or death. These figures increase to 41,000 and 10,000 respectively for civil partnerships, now authorised in 20 EU countries.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This enhanced cooperation in the field of property law of international couples is clearly in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens. I would like to point out that "enhanced cooperation" is a last resort option, applicable where the objectives of the cooperation in question cannot be achieved within a reasonable period by the Union as a whole and on condition that at least nine Member States participate in the cooperation. In this case there are 23.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. 18 Member States were calling for enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage regimes of international couples, on issues relating to both matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships. These Member States are Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Spain, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal, Slovenia, Finland and Sweden.  Although I voted in favour of this enhanced cooperation, I nevertheless regret the deadlock in negotiations between all Member States on the Commission's initial proposals in 2011. Let us hope that this enhanced cooperation will be the first step towards more Europe in this area.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Families, or in broader terms – couples who originate or live in different countries – are becoming more and more a phenomenon of everyday life. It is therefore necessary to ensure the specific, clear and transparent regulation of civil relations between such couples, cooperation between States, the protection of property interests, as well as standards for the protection of children's rights and international mechanisms.  I welcome this initiative, I invite colleagues to vote in favour and the Commission and the Member States to continue their dialogue with stakeholders on improving regulation in this area.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Enhanced cooperation between the Member States of the European Union was considered the ideal solution, as 23 of the 28 Member States agreed to adopt these two acts. The Commission presented new proposals for legislative acts in the field of family law at the beginning of 2016 through the enhanced cooperation mechanism, based on the above-mentioned compromise. Enhanced cooperation must fulfil a number of conditions, of which I would like to note: respect for the Treaties and the acquis communautaire, as well as the competences, rights and obligations of non-participating Member States, favouring the achievement of the Union's objectives and preserving their interests, alongside the strengthening of the integration process; not to undermine the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion, nor to constitute a restriction or discrimination on trade between Member States; and ultimately not to distort competition between them. The acts to be adopted do not affect the rights of the Member States that do not affect or affect the internal market. This enhanced cooperation in the area of property law for international couples is clearly in line with the union's objectives and the interests of its citizens, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Cavada authorises enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples. With the full movement of people in Europe, marriages between citizens of different nationalities have also increased. The report published some time ago on the number of couples born under the Erasmus programme, while it may make one smile, also highlights the figures of an increasingly widespread phenomenon in Europe. In the face of a stalemate on the part of the Member States in the field of family law, closer cooperation has established itself as an ideal solution in this area. In line with the position of the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to give its consent to the Council for the opening of enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the ownership regimes of international couples, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered unions. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This procedure will allow those Member States wishing to establish common rules for property regimes relating to international married couples to do so. Other Member States may opt out if they prefer to continue applying specific national legislation in this area. I support this flexible approach.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 A number of Member States in the Council have chosen to cooperate more closely in the rules governing the property of international couples and registered partnerships. The Group of Member States has chosen to conclude this cooperation because the Council cannot agree on the two regulations presented by the Commission in this area. It is, of course, essential that registered partnerships are fully recognised with married couples. Denmark does not participate in cooperation on property law, but as this is about a number of Member States that have chosen to cooperate more closely, I will not stand in the way of it.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report grants authorisation for enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction, the applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered partnerships. I voted in favour of it, since this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a Council decision addressing matrimonial property settlements as well as the property consequences of registered partnerships, I voted against this resolution. I find it very sad how the pressure is constantly being exerted on all of us, who, as a matter of principle, reject the constant strengthening of the rights of same-sex couples. How is it that we cannot help our families deal with their property situation without having to deal with the pushing of the rights of this minority group of people? Across Europe, we are seeing an increase in extremist right-wing political parties. This is also due to the fact that standard politicians have long ignored the voice of their citizens, for example in this area of human rights.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Back in 2011, the Commission proposed two regulations intended to establish a common regime concerning the assets of international couples. After lengthy negotiations, it became clear last year that no clear consensus would be reached in the Council. The Commission has therefore proposed that matters of matrimonial property regimes should be dealt with by enhanced cooperation. This procedure has been requested by 18 Member States, while the other countries will be exempted from these measures (among them Should be Slovakia). As negotiations on the Commission's original proposals have been blocked by all Member States, I am glad that at least a compromise has been found between most states.
