This enhanced cooperation is intended to enable the countries joining it to enable the national authorities to deal with the property situation of married couples and registered partnerships on the basis of the application of a single legal order. International couples will be able to choose the law that will apply to their assets. This will increase the legal certainty of married couples, as the law of the country closest to them will apply to their relationship. The various processes in cases of divorce or death of one of the spouses will be dealt with by the same court in order to avoid parallel and contradictory judicial decisions. For these reasons, I agreed with the proposal for a Council decision and, at the same time, I hope that other Member States will take it in the future.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's recommendation for the approval of enhanced cooperation between Member States in the area of the property conditions of international couples. I am also pleased that the Czech Republic has acted actively in requesting the Commission to participate in this enhanced cooperation. The increase in the number of marriages and registered partnerships with the so-called international element is an unquestionable reality of the current Union, which is also supported by the increasing mobility of students and workers across the Union. In 2007, 300,000 international marriages were concluded in the EU and around 41,000 registered partnerships had an international element with regard to property. Although the settlement of assets entails daily practical pitfalls, eu rules do not yet exist in this area. For example, international couples cannot determine with certainty what court has jurisdiction to settle their assets or what law a particular property situation will govern. Enhanced cooperation is intended to create a clear legal framework for almost 16 million international couples in the participating Member States. The property conditions of international couples will be dealt with in a coherent manner, within one applicable law and by one body. This will prevent parallel proceedings, opposed court decisions or high costs of proceedings. At the same time, enhanced cooperation does not limit the sovereignty of the State to establish or not to establish a registered partnership institute. He only counts on it where it already exists.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The decision to strengthen cooperation in the area of competence in the area of competence in respect of the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the matrimonial property regime of international couples was taken following the stalemate of negotiations between all Member States on the initial proposals presented by the Commission in 2011.  Enhanced cooperation must fulfil a number of conditions, namely the involvement of at least nine Member States, and where the Union as a whole cannot achieve the objectives of such cooperation within a reasonable time, it must be the last possible option.  Cooperation must respect the Treaties and Union law and the competences, rights and obligations of member states which do not participate in it. Furthermore, cooperation must pursue the Union's objectives, protect its interests and strengthen its integration processes. At the same time, cooperation must not harm the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion and must not constitute an obstacle or discriminate in trade between Member States or distort competition between them.  In order to support the proposal for a Council decision for enhanced cooperation in this area, I therefore voted in favour of ing the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on enhanced cooperation in the area of the estate of international couples. While I welcome approaches that make it easier for some 13 million bi-national families and permanent citizens living abroad to obtain recognition of their personal documents and documents. However, this must not lead to undermining subsidiarity and undermining national law, for example in the legal recognition of different forms of partnership. But that is the case here.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By converging legislation on property settlements of international couples, we will help to shorten often unnecessarily lengthy legal processes.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this recommendation for enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of property character for international couples, including matrimonial property regimes and other property consequences. Such a decision on enhanced cooperation has come up as a last resort and ideal solution, while at the same time being in the interest of union citizens and is unequivocally in line with the Union's objectives.  Also, the decision meets all the conditions, i.e. enhanced cooperation is proposed because the Union as a whole cannot achieve within a reasonable time the objectives of such cooperation and such a solution does not harm the internal market or economic, territorial and social cohesion. Furthermore, I consider that this decision respects the rights, obligations and competences of all Member States that do not participate in it and complies with treaties and UNION law. Ultimately, the decision does not create any barriers or discriminate against trade between Member States or distort competition between them.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution. The EU is not concerned about the mutual recognition of marriage and family between Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The Council adopts legislative acts relating to family law issues unanimously, after consulting the European Parliament. However, at the end of 2015 it became clear that it would not reach the agreement of all Member States with the proposals. Enhanced cooperation has imposed itself as an ideal solution in the area of jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property regimes of international couples, including matrimonial property regimes and property consequences of registered partnerships. Enhanced cooperation must also correspond to certain conditions such as: that it applies exclusively as a last resort when the Union as a whole cannot achieve the objectives of cooperation within a reasonable timeframe, must participate in it at least nine Member States, must comply with both the Treaties and Union law, must improve the Union's objectives, must not harm the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion , nor constitute or distort competition between Member States in barriers or discrimination in trade between Member States. I support the adoption of this recommendation because I consider that in this case all the necessary conditions are met. This enhanced cooperation in matters relating to the property rights of international couples is unequivocally in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of property regimes of international couples, covering both the area of matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships.  I welcome the decision to continue, after negotiations between Member States have failed, with enhanced cooperation in the area of the financial relations of international couples. On the basis of the views of the Member States, the Commission therefore made a new proposal earlier this year, which is a compromise of all proposals.  By supporting this recommendation, which is procedural in nature, we approved the Council's proposal for enhanced cooperation in this area.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's acceptance by the European Parliament of enhanced cooperation on the property situation of international couples, as this is an agreement to enhanced cooperation between the Member States that have come to this cooperation in the Council, and this enhanced cooperation does not in any way oblige states not participating in it to follow the procedure to be followed by the Member States participating in this enhanced cooperation.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on enhanced cooperation in the field of the property relations of international couples, because it will generally facilitate their residence in a Member State of which they are not nationals. The report also stresses that Member States will define this enhanced cooperation with each other and will not be imposed by a directive from Brussels.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Family law must be respected in any case, in order to protect the rights of international couples.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation to authorise enhanced cooperation in the property systems of international couples, as it gives the 18 Member States the opportunity for closer cooperation. As the Recommendation will not have any negative impact on Member States who do not wish to participate in this enhanced cooperation, there is no impediment to its adoption. I welcome the need for enhanced cooperation in this area, as there are a number of practical problems affecting property rights for citizens who are in international marriage or civil partnerships. In everyday cohabitation, but also in a possible divorce, it is often difficult to decide which court has jurisdiction and what laws apply to the case. It follows that these citizens must suffer unintended and adverse consequences. With regard to cross-border civil cases, the development of judicial cooperation based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions is in order to improve this situation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The modern world is a world of mobile people. Elsewhere we are born, elsewhere we teach, where else we live or work. It is not surprising, therefore, that nationally mixed relationships are an increasingly common phenomenon, couples living in a Member State of which they are not nationals, having property in different Member States or divorcing or dying in a country other than their country of origin. The problems for international couples arise primarily from the fact that it is very difficult to know which courts have jurisdiction and what laws apply to a couple's personal situation and assets. It is therefore necessary to ensure equal treatment of couples throughout the European Union. In my opinion, this regulation should be introduced as soon as possible, and I therefore welcome the initiative to establish enhanced cooperation between seventeen Member States in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property regimes and jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judicial decisions on the property consequences of registered partnerships. At the same time, I hope that other EU countries, including Poland, will join the group of countries participating in this initiative in the near future so that all EU citizens can benefit from these facilities.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the fair procedure proposed in this report, under which the 18 Member States that agreed with the enhanced cooperation proposed by the Council have requested the Commission to propose a decision authorising the establishment of enhanced cooperation between themselves on the property regimes of international couples, and the 10 Member States that did not agree with the Council’s proposal will not be affected by this procedure. The 10 Member States that have opted out will not be legally bound by this report and will continue applying national laws. Furthermore, I welcome enhanced cooperation and I believe that this report will be beneficial for the international couples living in the Member States that have agreed with the Council’s proposal.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the rapporteur. The acts to be adopted do not infringe the rights of non-participating Member States, and do not affect the internal market. This enhanced cooperation in the area of the heritage law of international couples is clearly in line with the objectives of the Union and in the interests of its citizens. Parliament therefore gives its approval to enhanced cooperation in this area. This decision is only procedural.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In times of intense cooperation and exchange between all Member States of the EU, it seems only natural to adjust the legal rights on property regimes for international couples. Since it was impossible to reach an agreement between all Member States within a reasonable period, an agreement was now reached between 18 Member States of the Union wishing to establish enhanced cooperation: Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Spain, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal, Slovenia, Finland and Sweden. This agreement will authorise enhanced cooperation between these Member States in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, covering both matters of matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support the European Parliament's position on the authorisation of enhanced cooperation in the area of competence and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, including in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships, as I believe that this issue should fall within the competence of each Member State.  I believe that any obligations imposed on Member States through decision-making based on this position would constitute a breach of the principle of proportionality enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council decision. In 2011, the European Commission presented proposals relating to the field of international couples. The Member States have not adopted the aforementioned proposals, so it has become clear that enhanced cooperation in this area is an ideal solution. Earlier this year, the EC drafted new proposals for legislative acts using the enhanced cooperation procedure. The latter must fulfil several conditions: it must be the last possible option where the EU as a whole cannot achieve the objectives of such cooperation within a reasonable time, and at least 9 Member States must be involved; it must respect the Treaties and Union law and the competences, rights and obligations of member states not participating in it; it must pursue the objectives of the Union, protect its interests and strengthen its integration processes and must not harm the internal market or economic, social and territorial cohesion and must not constitute an obstacle or discriminate in trade between Member States. In the present case, the conditions were met, since enhanced cooperation was indeed a last resort. The proposed acts shall be without prejudice to the rights of non-participating Member States and shall not affect the internal market. This enhanced cooperation in the area of the property regimes of international couples is clearly in line with the Union's objectives and in the interests of citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to give its consent to the Council for the opening of enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the ownership regimes of international couples, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered unions. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The decision to use enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage regimes of international couples, concerning issues relating to both matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships, comes after the non-participation of Denmark, Ireland, the United Kingdom, and the blocking of Hungary and Poland from the negotiations on the initial proposals made by the Commission in 2011. Enhanced cooperation is a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. It is therefore an interference in national family laws. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Although the enhanced cooperation document is not binding on all Member States, there is a danger that it will have negative consequences for the areas reserved to the Member States, i.e. family law or the definition of marriage. I could not support a document that posed such a threat and I decided to vote against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The decision to apply enhanced cooperation in respect of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property regimes of international couples, including both matrimental property regimes and the property aspects of registered partnerships, was taken after negotiations between all Member States on the original proposals made by the Commission in 2011 were deadlocked. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to give its consent to the Council for the opening of enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the ownership regimes of international couples, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered unions. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this procedural decision aiming at giving consent to the draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, covering both matters of matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regimes of international couples, covering both matters of matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships. I believe that all criteria for enhanced cooperation are met in this case. The enhanced cooperation in the area of the property regimes of international couples is undoubtedly in accordance with the objectives of the Union and in the interest of its citizens.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a much-needed document, since negotiations between all Member States on the initial proposals made by the Commission in 2011 remain stalled. Enhanced cooperation mechanisms need to be used as a tool for those countries wishing to advance cooperation on the economic regimes of international partners. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Because there was no agreement with the 28 Member States on a Commission proposal on clearer rules on the wealth system of international couples, closer cooperation proved to be the best solution, as 23 Member States agreed in principle. I voted in favour of this recommendation for closer cooperation because I believe that we should indeed find solutions to the wealth system of international couples.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The bottom of this recommendation is to recommend enhanced cooperation between Member States with regard to Family Law, specifically the property regime of international couples.  This international cooperation within the Union was only requested by 17 Member States, one of which is Portugal. Participating Member States may continue to make use of their law, in particular with regard to registered partnerships (pictured having doubts that exist in Portugal) and same-sex marriages, in order to safeguard the rights of these specific citizens, who are the subject of various legal systems.  Strengthening cooperation in the area of jurisdiction, with regard to applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes for international couples, covering both matrimonial property regimes and property effects of registered partnerships, will bring a number of advantages to citizens and we support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. According to this report, the European Parliament gives its consent to enhanced cooperation (between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Spain, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal, Slovenia, Finland and Sweden) so that those Member States can regulate with each other the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of ownership of "international" couples. This seems perfectly understandable to me.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union allows Member States to agree on enhanced cooperation in certain areas. Such cooperation must also be approved by the European Parliament, although it does not apply to all EU Member States. If it is approved, other states can join it later, but this is a voluntary step. I voted against the resolution on enhanced cooperation in the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property regimes of international couples, relating to matters relating to matrimonial property regimes, as well as to the property consequences of registered partnerships. I consider property relations in marriage to be part of the protection of the family, which has gradually evolved into European law. The purpose of this increased protection is to compensate for the higher vulnerability of families with children in crisis situations, which may be caused, for example, by the death of one of the spouses or their break-up. In the case of registered partnerships, such protection is not necessary. Although Slovakia has not signed up to this enhanced cooperation, I consider its creation to be a step towards reducing the importance of the natural family, and I therefore could not support the resolution tabled.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. Since 2012, the European institutions have been trying to reach agreement on an issue of great importance to families: this is the proposal to standardise Member States' legislation on the capital regime, in order to facilitate the fulfilment of bureaucratic tasks for couples composed of citizens of different nationalities. Since some Member States, by not recognising same-sex unions, do not allow the European Council to reach agreement unanimously, a text has been approved in Parliament allowing 18 Member States, including Italy, to sign enhanced cooperation on the subject. I voted in favour, hoping that the compromise reached by the 18 states will soon extend to the whole of the European Union.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision for enhanced cooperation in the area of the property regimes of international couples. I believe that the simplification of the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the matrimonial property regime of international couples is consistent with the union's objectives and in the interests of citizens.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Framework Protocol issued by the World Health Organisation on tobacco products aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. To this end, it calls for the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability regime that has its effects both at national and regional level. The protocol also aims to strengthen international cooperation and information sharing, as well as to provide for a set of rules aimed at improving controls on the supply chain. In view of the fundamental value of citizens' health, I voted in favour of the proposal to ratify this protocol.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour since 2013 because since 2013 there has been a general Union strategy to combat cigarette smuggling which proposes action in four key areas: (a) reducing incentives for smuggling; (b) improving supply chain security (in particular through ratification of the FCTC Protocol); (c) strengthening compliance control by tax, customs, police and border control authorities; (d) strengthening sanctions. The Union has also strengthened the legislative basis with the Tobacco Products Directive, supplemented by binding and mandatory anti-fraud agreements concluded between the Union and the Member States, on the one hand, and the four main tobacco manufacturers, on the other (Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco International, British American Tobacco (Holdings) Limited, and Imperial Tobacco Limited).  It is therefore an international agreement that develops and complements Article 15 of the FCTC and is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. The Commission has participated in the negotiations on the FCTC Protocol on behalf of the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products.  Indeed, if I support the fight against this type of trade and cooperation between sovereign states in this regard, I am opposed to any measure aimed at the creation of a European criminal law and a European federal police.  On the other hand, I voted in favour of the Szejnfeld report, which, still in the context of the fight against the illicit tobacco trade, aims to combat smuggling while respecting the sovereignty of countries.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I authored this report and I was delighted that the report successfully passed through the European Parliament today. This is a huge step in the right direction in the fight against smuggled and illicit tobacco products. Tobacco products, both illicit and legal, cause unfathomable harm to the health and well-being of citizens. Smoking has recently been identified as the single greatest cause of preventable illness and premature death in the north of Ireland. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a scourge that effects all of Europe and Ireland is no exception. It costs the north of Ireland UKP 450 million each year. Internal company documents reveal that smuggling became an integral part of tobacco companies’ business strategies and according to Customs, Imperial Brand, the world’s fourth-largest international cigarette company, accounted for 55% of the 17 billion cigarettes smuggled into ‘Britain and the north’ every year. The passing of this report means that the European Union is now under pressure to ratify and enforce the World Health Organisation’s Protocol on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products. When ratified this protocol will see countries collaborate in the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which is intended to send a signal to Member States to ratify, as soon as possible, the additional protocol of the World Health Organization on the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with regard to its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences , because this Protocol aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation on mutual legal and administrative assistance.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU signed the World Health Organization Protocol for Tobacco Control to Eliminate the Illicit Tobacco Trade in 2013. The protocol must be ratified by 40 parties for it to enter into force. The illicit trade in tobacco products, including cigarette smuggling, causes the EU (and Member States) huge revenue losses in terms of evaded taxes and tariffs. It is estimated that the EU and the Member States suffer annual revenue losses of more than EUR 10 billion. Legal tobacco sales bring in more than 90 billion euros in tax revenue to Member States annually. About one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. This report deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters. We support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but we do not want the EU to use this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported. I therefore abstained on the vote of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to give the European Union the legitimacy and the weapons to effectively combat the illicit trade in tobacco products. This illicit trade often funds illegal practices and is done to the detriment of the consumer through random application of standards for the health of users of these products.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Union should ratify without delay the Protocol of the World Health Organisation on illicit trade in tobacco products.  The purpose of the Protocol is to eliminate all types of illicit trade in tobacco products.  It requires the establishment of a global labelling and tracing system within five years of the entry into force of the Protocol. The aim is also to establish a global contact point for information sharing within the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It will lead the development of national and regional labelling and tracing systems. The Protocol also contains additional provisions to combat the supply chain of illicit tobacco products. These include licensing, record-making requirements and regulation of online sales, tax-free trade and international transit.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation concerns accession to the Protocol of the European Union to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on the Elimination of Illegal Trade. The stated aim of the Protocol is to ban all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products.  The concept of illicit trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as follows: any practice or conduct related to the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products and prohibited by law. In order to address this problem, the Protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products through measures taken by governments. This also requires the establishment of a global tracking and tracking system within five years of the entry into force of the Protocol. A global information sharing point will therefore be established within the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It will be responsible for managing the establishment of national and regional tracking and monitoring systems.  The above constitutes positive steps in all respects, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, including cigarette smuggling, which is both a public health problem - in that it facilitates access to tobacco products often at a lower cost - but also financial in that each year more than ten billion tariffs are evaded across the EU.  In order to eradicate this smuggling, the Commission encourages in this text the development of judicial cooperation in criminal matters; this measure, as well as the migrant crisis and the attacks that have bloodied Europe, show this, is unfortunately ineffective and is only a pretext put forward by the Commission to set up a European criminal law and a kind of European federal police. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of this report and abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global treaty in this area of tobacco control. The protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products is the main global tobacco initiative. It contains a set of measures, rules and strategies to combat this illicit trade. To address this phenomenon, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption of a series of measures by governments. I approved this report.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization protocol on the illegal trade in tobacco products was signed in 2013. The Anderson report, which I supported with my vote, approves this protocol, which focuses in particular on the size of the supply chain. This is an important instrument with the main objective of establishing a global traceability and traceability regime for tobacco products. Among the measures taken are rules on the issue of licences, new obligations concerning the keeping of records, the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. The central point, however, is the creation, in the secretariat of the WHO Convention on Tobacco Control, of a global centre for information sharing. The protocol is undoubtedly an important step forward in encouraging and strengthening international cooperation, encouraging not only technical cooperation but also mutual assistance between signatories in the legal and administrative fields.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Anderson report calls for the adoption of the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. To this end, it is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products through a number of government measures, such as a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime, the prevention of money laundering, the introduction of a licence and the maintenance of a register and the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid information exchange, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported the report on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products. The protocol will aim to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, the exchange of valid information, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. In addition, the industry itself also has a responsibility to act effectively and unequivocally address the illicit trade in its products.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products through the protocol to the WHO Framework Convention. Of course, it seems to me imperative to cooperate in order to eliminate the illicit tobacco trade, which not only poses a serious danger to public safety, but also heavy losses of tax revenue for the Member States. It is estimated that more than 10 billion euros will be lost each year, due in part to cigarette smuggling. At the same time, the legal sale of tobacco brings in around 90 billion euros in tax revenue to the Member States. However, I fear that the Union will take over this legitimate fight by WHO only for the purpose of Europeanising criminal law. As in many other areas, the solution is to cooperate sovereign states and not in the creation of a criminal law and a European federal police.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Anderson report is balanced and acceptable. I have always fought against counterfeiting in all its forms, and the illegal trade in tobacco products is a huge detriment to our producers to the consumers themselves. This text is a step forward in the fight against counterfeiting and I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which was dealt with in accordance with the simplified procedure. Eminently technical in content, in addition, it consents to the EU accepting the protocol that vetoes trade in tobacco products within the framework of the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. The conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control on the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The European Union should ratify without delay the Protocol of the World Health Organisation on illicit trade in tobacco products. The purpose of the Protocol is to eliminate all types of illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol defines illicit trade in tobacco products as any practice or activity prohibited by law in connection with the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this problem, the Protocol applies to the supply chain of tobacco products, using various government instruments. It requires the establishment of a global labelling and tracing system within five years of the entry into force of the Protocol. The aim is also to establish a global contact point for information sharing within the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It will lead the development of national and regional labelling and tracing systems. The Protocol also contains additional provisions to combat the supply chain of illicit tobacco products. These include licensing, record-making requirements, as well as regulation of online sales, tax-free trade and international transit.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the European Union must immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. That is why we voted today for the Council to be able to negotiate the conclusion of the protocol on the part of the Union. This Protocol contains actions and strategies to combat the icing of tobacco trafficking, which in the long term contributes to the fight against money laundering, the fight against cross-border organised crime and the enforcement of tax and customs obligations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like the previous resolution on the conclusion of a protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products, I also supported this resolution, which thus calls for the ratification of the Protocol of that Protocol. The Protocol focuses on the supply chain of tobacco products and provides that a global monitoring and tracking system should be established within five years of its entry into force. In accordance with the Protocol, additional provisions will also be necessary to address the illicit supply chain of tobacco products, such as licensing, recording requirements, regulation of internet sales, sales in duty-free shops and international transit. In addition, the Protocol also pays great attention to the promotion and strengthening of international cooperation, information exchange and cooperation in the field of law enforcement, and mutual legal and administrative assistance. The protocol also draws attention to the duties of the tobacco industry. It is obliged to take a strong approach and address the issue of illegal trade in its products. The Parties to the Protocol must also ensure that any cooperation with the tobacco industry is fully transparent and must not transfer any of its agreed monitoring and tracing obligations to the tobacco industry. The fight against illegal trade in tobacco products must really become a priority, not only in European but in global politics.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this decision because it is in relation to the FCTC Protocol of the World Health Organization, which joins the EU's global efforts to combat the smuggling of tobacco products. The damage from tobacco smuggling is twofold, as it negatively applies to public health and the public budget.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but I want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a huge step in the right direction in the fight against smuggled and illicit tobacco products. Tobacco products, both illicit and legal, cause unfathomable harm to the health and well-being of citizens. Smoking has recently been identified as the single greatest cause of preventable illness and premature death in the north of Ireland. The illicit trade in tobacco products is a scourge that effects all of Europe and Ireland is no exception. It costs the north of Ireland UKP 450 million each year. Internal company documents reveal that smuggling became an integral part of tobacco companies’ business strategies and according to Customs, Imperial Brand, the world’s fourth-largest international cigarette company, accounted for 55% of the 17 billion cigarettes smuggled into ‘Britain and the north’ every year. The passing of this report means that the European Union is now under pressure to ratify and enforce the World Health Organisation’s Protocol on the elimination of the illicit trade in tobacco products. When ratified this protocol will see countries collaborate in the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The illegal trade in tobacco products is a serious phenomenon which has extremely negative effects on the health of European citizens, as well as significant losses to the EU and its Member States, amounting to more than EUR 10 billion per year. Bearing in mind that most of the illegal tobacco products introduced into the EU come from third countries, I believe that the conclusion of multilateral international agreements is one of the privileged instruments capable of effectively combating this phenomenon. Therefore, in conjunction with the EU's comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling in 2013, I wholeheartedly support the conclusion and ratification, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products drawn up under the World Health Organisation Framework Convention to Combat Smoking. Indeed, by promoting measures such as the establishment of a global traceability and traceability system, as well as common rules to promote greater control of licences, stricter regulations than sales on the Internet or by promoting greater customs cooperation, I believe that this protocol can actually help to combat tax evasion, crime and better protect public health.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products; it was ratified on 20 December 2013 subject to its conclusion at a later date. It aims to combat illicit manufacturing and to eradicate counterfeit tobacco products in order to contribute to the protection of public health and to recover the tax revenues associated with this trafficking.  We are fully in line with the philosophy and objectives of this protocol. However, I abstained on this report, which deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Indeed, we do not want the European Union to use the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products as a pretext to develop a European criminal law as well as a European federal police force. On the other hand, we are in favour of closer cooperation between the Member States, which respects our national sovereignty.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Illicit trade in tobacco products is an activity with a negative impact on both public health and revenues to state budgets. Cigarette smuggling undermines tobacco control policies, thereby favouring access to tobacco products at lower prices which result in significant loss of revenue for the European Union, since taxes and customs duties are not paid.  The Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention includes a complex set of measures, rules and policies to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, with a view to a safer process on the tobacco supply chain, creating a global tracking and location system. The Protocol emphasises the importance of judicial cooperation in criminal matters by regulating licensing, internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. I was in favour of this report because I consider it essential to ensure the highest standards in order to protect public health, and judicial cooperation in criminal matters at international level is necessary in order to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's vote, I welcomed the agreement reached on this protocol with regard to the provisions relating to obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of tobacco offences. The illegal trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that seriously threatens public health, as it damages anti-smoking policies and promotes greater access to often cheaper tobacco products. This activity also entails significant tax losses to the DETRIMENT of the EU in terms of tax avoidance and customs duties. It is estimated that each year the EU and its Member States suffer revenue losses of more than EUR 10 billion. A considerable proportion of the illegal tobacco products introduced into the EU come from third countries, so the best strategic option for combating this cross-border phenomenon is to implement an effective regime at world level. The agreement reached aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, effective information sharing, technical cooperation and cooperation for law enforcement purposes, as well as mutual assistance in both the legal and administrative fields.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was authored by my Sinn Féin comrade Martina Anderson. The report is aimed at putting pressure on the EU to ratify and enforce the World Health Organisation’s Protocol on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products. International collaboration is necessary in order to clamp down on illegal smuggling, which has become an integral part of business strategies in order to avoid customs duties. With smoking as a leading cause of premature death and illness in Ireland, I was happy to support this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the protocol aiming at clearing up illegal tobacco products trade through a worldwide tracking and tracing scheme of the supply chain of tobacco products. I especially welcome the proposal of international cooperation and information exchange to ensure a transparent and legitimate tobacco industry.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure as useful in combating and effectively sanctioning the illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the majority of illicit tobacco products comes from outside of the EU area, strengthened international cooperation focused on clear legislative procedures and better law enforcement is much needed to face this issue. I believe that the main tool to fight illicit trade activities, counterfeiting of tobacco products and tax evasion should be enhanced multilateral regulatory instrument such as the WHO’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. I am glad that we have agreed on the use of such a tool and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report as we believe that the European Union should immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit tobacco trade, which will encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid exchange of information, cooperation in the fields of technology and law enforcement and mutual legal and administrative assistance.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with regard to its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences, offers an opportunity to combat more effectively offences committed which burden the health of citizens and the economies of States. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of the measure because it is aimed at eliminating the illegal trade in tobacco products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention to combat smoking, with regard to the provisions relating to obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of crimes. In addition, the adoption of a non-legislative resolution is suggested to include other very important points such as the fight against smuggling and counterfeiting by indicating the origin of tobacco.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against the smuggling of tobacco products cannot be done only in words but must involve concrete actions. I voted whole much in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the introduction of global location systems and the tightening of sanctions are effective steps to control products entering Europe and discourage illegal behaviour. I believe that this agreement can help to safeguard the health of the citizens of the European Union directly.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Protocol which covers areas related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters, the definition of criminal offences and police cooperation in relation to tobacco smuggling.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The illicit trafficking of tobacco is a phenomenon observed in much of the world. Their combat must therefore also be done on a global scale. This Protocol to the Framework Convention of the World Health Organisation for Tobacco Control precisely fills this gap. A concerted approach is intended, in particular in the typification of crimes and preventive administrative measures, such as vessel control. The Protocol also aims to stimulate judicial and police cooperation in this area.  According to the Treaties, Parliament needs to give its consent to the signing and ratification of international instruments, such as this protocol. You are therefore given your consent, which I support.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP acknowledges the need to crack down on illegal tobacco products, both due to health risks and due to the need to enforce the law. We do not support the EU making this decision for us, albeit this report had laudable aims, therefore we did not oppose it, but abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the protocol because the aim is to eliminate all forms of illegal trade in tobacco products. The Protocol provides for the adoption of a series of measures by governments to combat the illegal trade in tobacco, focusing in particular on the product supply chain. It is planned to establish a global traceability and traceability regime, which will make it possible to share information on trade in this sector globally. In order to protect public health as a fundamental value, it is necessary to strengthen controls and cooperation between customs authorities.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization Protocol on the illegal trade in tobacco products aims to eliminate all forms of such trade, understood as any practice prohibited under the Law on the production, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. The Protocol provides for a number of measures that can be taken by governments, such as the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability regime, measures to control the supply chain of illegal tobacco products, the strengthening of international and technical cooperation, as well as mutual assistance in both the legal and administrative fields. The protocol addresses a primary issue for European citizens: the irreconcilable conflict between the interests of the tobacco industry and the interests of public health. I therefore believe that the EU must ratify this protocol as soon as possible. I therefore supported the European Parliament's approval of the draft Council decision on the elimination of illegal trade in tobacco products under the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of crimes.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the world's first international public health treaty. This treaty was created after four years of negotiations and discussions between members of the World Health Organisation. By 2004, as many as 180 parties (including the European Community) had signed the Convention, officially entered into force in February 2005. The main objective of the Convention is to protect the parties from the health, social, environmental and economic consequences of smoking and inhaling tobacco smoke. The Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products is based on Article 15 of the FCTC and was adopted by the Conference of the Parties on 12 November 2012 in Seoul. The EU signed the FCTC Protocol on 20 December 2013. The Protocol has so far been ratified by 9 of the 40 parties needed for its entry into force. This is a mixed agreement, with ratification by the EU and its 28 Member States, as a result, adding 29 pages to the FCTC Protocol. I believe that the legislative resolution is substantive and correct. I agree with the rapporteur that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and support the international fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, tax evasion and organised crime. The European Parliament should give its consent to this ratification. In view of the above, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, welcoming the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of The World Health Organisation protocol on the Illicit Trade in Tobacco, as I believe that the protocol should be immediately ratified by the European Union. The protocol serves to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products in relation to production, shipping, receiving, being in possession of, distributing, selling or buying tobacco products that are prohibited by law. Because such illicit trade is dangerous for industry and public health, I voted in favour of the recommendations

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products in the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It is important to strengthen measures on police and customs cooperation in criminal matters in the face of this illicit trade, which poses a real danger to public health in Europe.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union signed the protocol of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (CCLAT) on 20 December 2013 to end the illicit tobacco trade. This is a worrying public health issue and results in losses of around 10 billion euros in taxes and customs duties. Legal tobacco sales bring in more than 90 billion euros in tax revenue to Member States annually. As a result, one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. This report deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  It is not desirable for the EU to use this global fight led by WHO as a pretext for the development of a European criminal law and a European federal police force. However, cooperation between sovereign states should be supported. Also, I preferred to abstain on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the EU's accession to the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This report concerns in particular the provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the determination of criminal offences itself. The protocol in question will benefit public health and strengthen the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime.  To this end, the measures proposed by the Protocol and implemented by the Governments of the States will focus on the chain of manufacture and distribution of tobacco products. The Protocol requires the establishment of a dedicated global supply tracking system within 5 years of the entry into force of the Protocol, the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control will be the centre and main administrator of this information exchange system.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Illegal trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or conduct prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. That is why we voted today for the Council to be able to negotiate with the Union on the conclusion of the protocol. This Protocol contains actions and strategies to combat the icing of tobacco trafficking, which in the long term contributes to the fight against money laundering, the fight against cross-border organised crime and the enforcement of tax and customs obligations.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation should be immediately ratified by the European Union, as it provides for the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products and the development of additional provisions to deal with the supply chain of illicit tobacco products. Those provisions include, inter alia, licensing, record-keeping requirements and regulations on internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I have chosen to abstain: this report deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters. In the LIBE committee, we abstained as a precaution. We support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but we want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The illicit trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or behavior prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, reception, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this issue, the Protocol aims at the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption by governments of a number of measures, and requires the creation, within five years of their entry into force, of a localization and follow-up system. This implies the creation of a global information sharing point located in the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which will oversee the establishment of national and regional localization and follow-up systems. Furthermore, the Protocol will aim at encouraging and strengthening international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every effort must be made to eliminate the illegal trade in tobacco products. I voted in favour of each Member State strengthening international cooperation and information sharing, thus facing a major common challenge affecting the economic, political and legal sphere of each EU country.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted because it forces the tobacco companies into line.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Ratification of the WHO Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products is important to eliminate all forms of illicit trade. Such trade is defined as any activity or activity connected with the manufacture, transport, reception, sale or purchase of tobacco products prohibited by law. The Protocol defines criminal offences, addresses their liability, securing payments as well as disposing of seized products. It is the responsibility of the tobacco industry to act to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products effectively and unequivocally.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which aims to combat and eliminate all forms of illegal trade in tobacco products.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Illegal trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or conduct prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to tackle the illegal trade in tobacco products, the Protocol aims against the tobacco supply chain through a series of measures on the part of governments. It requires the establishment of a global tracking and monitoring regime within five years of the protocol's enter into force. This will create a global information exchange point located in the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This will guide the creation of national and regional tracking and monitoring systems. For these reasons I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a consent file for ratifying the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, FCTC Protocol. This protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this field. Not only is illicit trade in tobacco products harmful to public health, but it also results in huge losses in revenue to the EU. This protocol consists of a complex set of measures and rules to tackle illicit trade, such as establishing a global tracking and tracing system to make the supply chain more secure. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licensing, record keeping requirements and regulation of internet-sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products. I welcome the achievement of the first multilateral initiative to tackle illicit trade of tobacco and cigarette smuggling by securing supply chains. This is also a very important from the side of public health as well as fight against tax evasion.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union must immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. That is why we voted today for the Council to be able to negotiate with the Union on the conclusion of the protocol. This Protocol contains actions and strategies to combat the icing of tobacco trafficking, which in the long term contributes to the fight against money laundering, the fight against cross-border organised crime and the enforcement of tax and customs obligations.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation fully convinced of the need to ratify as soon as possible the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organization. To address this issue, the Protocol is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products through a number of Government measures. The Protocol will aim to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, the exchange of valid information, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention for the Fight against Smoking, with regard to the provisions relating to obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of crimes.  Indeed, I am convinced that the vote by a large majority in the Strasbourg plenary on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of this agreement is a fundamental contribution to international initiatives aimed at eliminating all forms of illegal trade in tobacco products and thus combating the circumvention of taxes and customs duties.  According to the available data, following the entry into force of the three previous agreements concluded between the EU and tobacco producers, controls on production, customers, transport and the type of payment for cigarettes have been stepped up, resulting in an overall decrease in important illegal products within the EU. Finally, I would like to see a further effort to trace products from SMEs and to make effective civil and criminal sanctions in the event of seizure of illicit products.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As a non-smoker and family man, I am basically not a friend of smoking. But I am even less so when it comes to combating illegal international cigarette smuggling. That is why I voted in favour of this report out of conviction.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. All forms of illicit trade in tobacco products must be stopped. To this end, the WHO Protocol must be ratified by the EU as soon as possible.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation which gives consent to the Council to ratify the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, FCTC Protocol. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. At present, the illicit tobacco trade leads to huge revenue losses in the EU, and this framework will go some way towards addressing that.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Anderson report calls for the adoption of the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. To this end, it is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products, through a number of government measures, for example, a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime, the prevention of money laundering, the introduction of a licence and the maintenance of a register and the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid information exchange, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation which gives consent to the Council to ratify the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, FCTC Protocol. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. At present, the illicit tobacco trade leads to huge revenue losses in the EU, and this framework will go some way towards addressing that.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Protocol’s main objective is to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Also it introduces the principle of due diligence which sets up an effective licensing system with a view to controlling the supply chain as well as including provisions on a tracking and tracing regime and on the prevention of money laundering.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. The Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the Council's decision to hold negotiations on the conclusion of the protocol by the Union. This Protocol contains actions and strategies to combat icing on the icing of tobacco, which in the long term will contribute to the fight against money laundering, the fight against cross-border organised crime and the enforcement of tax and customs obligations.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of judicial cooperation between Member States when they so wish under the Protocol on enhanced cooperation in the field of tobacco products. The Protocol also refers in particular to the responsibilities of the tobacco industry for both illegal trade and public health, presupposes specific clauses for industry.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution for the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. Cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity which poses a serious threat to public health and causes huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. The ratification of the FCTC Protocol will benefit public health and help the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime. Lung cancer is a serious health issues for millions of EU citizens and this convention would help to curtail smoking induced cancer as well as augment Member States’ via additional taxes and custom duties.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this protocol, as it will aid the eradication of the illegal trading of tobacco products, whilst also encouraging international cooperation in the area.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must immediately ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. That is why we voted today for the Council to be able to negotiate with the Union on the conclusion of the protocol. This Protocol contains actions and strategies to combat the icing of tobacco trafficking, which in the long term contributes to the fight against money laundering, the fight against cross-border organised crime and the enforcement of tax and customs obligations.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favour of this report on the ratification by the European Union of the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organization.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of the protocol is the elimination in the future of all forms of illicit trade. This could be done by the creation of a global tracking and tracing regime and establishment of a global information sharing point. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products with the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control as regards its provisions on obligations related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  I believe it is essential to establish a global monitoring system and enhance international, national and regional cooperation, as well as information sharing and technical cooperation. It is certainly necessary to define provisions concerning infringements, liability and payments in the context of attachment. Added to this is the problem of the illicit tobacco supply chain, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters. In the LIBE committee, our Members abstained as a precaution. We support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but we want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported. As a result, I abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The WHO Protocol to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products also calls on states to cooperate within judicial authorities to effectively combat owners, distributors, sellers and other actors cooperating in the illegal sale of tobacco products. I believe that the promotion of international cooperation, sufficient exchange of information, cooperation in the field of law enforcement and mutual legal and administrative assistance are necessary to effectively combat these illegal practices. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal, which calls for the swift ratification of the Protocol, but also for the introduction of a tracking system for sales in the tobacco industry and for further improvements.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the ratification of the WHO protocol to eliminate the illicit tobacco trade. This is a great victory for the health of Europeans and a great defeat for the tobacco lobby. The WHO Protocol "to eliminate the illicit tobacco trade" will help control the flow of tobacco, from its manufacture to its delivery, by establishing a traceability strictly independent of tobacco manufacturers but paid for by them. It will take 40 ratifications for it to become legally binding, so the Union's ratification is a strong signal for the Member States to follow suit. Knowing that at the moment only 5 Member States have already ratified it.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the ratification of the World Health Organisation Protocol on the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. The aim of the Protocol is to prevent all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. As he is in favour of curbing the illegal trade in tobacco products, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade. In order to address this, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products via a series of measures by governments: creation of a global tracking and tracing regime and establishment of a global information sharing point.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the directive is to eliminate illegal trade in tobacco products, according to the World Health Organization.  The World Health Organization developed the Protocol to eliminate the illegal trade in tobacco products.
