I voted in favour of the directive, since in addition to combating illegal trade it aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, information exchange and law enforcement.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution on the conclusion of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. Illicit trade in tobacco products is harmful to both the EU and Member States' budgets in the form of unpaid taxes and customs duties. Restricting the illicit trade in tobacco products, which are for the most part obscure, manufactured outside the EU and contrary to tobacco control policies, will contribute to the regulated distribution of tobacco products within the European market. This will ensure a higher level of public health protection for European citizens while helping to combat tax and customs liabilities. I believe that the envisaged international cooperation based on specific legislative procedures and the establishment of a global monitoring and tracing regime will enable countries to control tobacco products manufactured and imported into their territory. This will limit illegal imports and create a prerequisite for preventing tax fraud and organised crime.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Eliminating illicit tobacco trade should be a top priority because it is related not only to tax avoidance but also to the health of EU citizens. So far the fight against illicit tobacco trade has been conducted on the basis of the 12-year anti-illicit trade agreement between the European Commission, Member States and Philip Morris International (PMI). Our shared efforts have delivered an 85% reduction in counterfeit cigarettes. Unfortunately, the agreement ends at the end of this year and the reduction in the flow of counterfeit cigarettes has been replaced by a huge increase in so-called illicit-whites – branded cigarettes manufactured outside the EU for the sole purpose of smuggling. Nowadays tobacco smuggling represents the foundation of illicit trade of tobacco products in Europe and in order to address these issues we should immediately ratify the World Health Organisation protocol on the illicit trade in tobacco. The protocol aims to tackle tobacco smuggling in particular by encouraging and enhancing international cooperation, valid information sharing, technical and law enforcement cooperation, mutual legal and administrative assistance. Some 16 countries have ratified the WHO protocol, including five EU Member States; it is time for the EU to join the international fight against illicit tobacco trade and to make tobacco industry fully transparent.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of this protocol is to eliminate any form of illegal trade in tobacco products. For this very reason, the World Health Organisation protocol on illegal trade in these products must be ratified by the European Union as soon as possible. This is a very serious and threatening issue for our society from a healthy, political and even economic point of view. What is being called for in the following protocol is therefore the adoption of a series of measures and alternatives that governments should implement immediately in order to resolve this major problem. From the moment the protocol is implemented, a regime will be required that is able to define its traceability and traceability for the sharing of useful information. Furthermore, the same, which recognises the existence of an illegal trade in tobacco products, aims to introduce the existence of certain crime figures, addressing the issue of liability and disposal of confiscated products. Therefore, in order to ensure greater security for citizens, I am in favour of the protocol.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because I certainly support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but I want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on judicial cooperation in criminal matters to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products (protocol to the WHO Framework Convention). I support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products (which is why I voted for the Szejnfeld report), but I would like to avoid the EU using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote focuses on judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is part of the World Health Organization's Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (CCLAT), signed on 20 December 2013, which aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products. It is true that fraud in this area is doing great economic damage to states, which lose 10 billion of revenues each year normally from tobacco taxes. In addition, illicit trade impacts public health because it opens up access to cheaper products to a wide audience, which encourages their consumption. I support the fight against these illegal activities and cooperation between sovereign states. Nevertheless, in order to overcome the risk of the EU developing a European criminal law and a European federal police force, I got ASBTENU.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the conclusion of the protocol on combating cigarette smuggling, which concerns judicial and criminal matters. The Protocol requires the setting up of an international monitoring regime, calls for strict licensing of the trade in cigarettes and uniformly defines crimes, thereby encroaching on the criminal law of individual countries. I am also against the Czech Republic joining the protocol.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of the World Health Organization Protocol is to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Illicit trade in tobacco products is defined as any practice or conduct prohibited by law, related to the manufacture, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. This issue is being addressed through a number of measures, so it is necessary for the European Union to urgently ratify this Protocol.  Following the entry into force of this Protocol, a global information sharing centre will be established, managing the establishment of national and regional tracking and monitoring systems. The Protocol also establishes an effective licensing system to control the supply chain and provisions on the follow-up and monitoring system and on anti-money laundering.  All Signatory States of the Protocol must act transparently and fulfil their obligation to follow and monitor each cooperation with the tobacco industry. The Protocol aims to encourage and enhance international cooperation, proper exchange of information, technical and law enforcement cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. This Protocol is a key contribution to international efforts to remove all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products and thus combat the avoidance of payment of tax and customs obligations, so I supported this recommendation on the Draft Council Decision.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Approximately one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally in EU Member States. The European Parliament approved by a large majority the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control.  The protocol in question is one of the main global initiatives in this field and seeks to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. It provides new tools to combat cigarette smuggling, aiming to establish a global tracking and tracking system. The majority of illicit tobacco products in the EU come from third countries. For this reason, effectiveness in combating this cross-border problem requires global and coordinated action. I believe that Bulgaria, as well as the EU, have a duty to fight tobacco smuggling, which leads to tax evasion and an increase in the health risk posed by the lack of control. Ratification of the Protocol is therefore a step in the right direction.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like another vote today, this concerned the WHO Protocol to the Framework Convention on the Prevention of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. Unlike the first vote, this was specifically about judicial cooperation in criminal matters, that is to say, the Community area of freedom, security and justice. All other forms of cooperation were affected in the first vote. As has already been noted, this protocol makes an important contribution to international efforts to eradicate illicit trade in tobacco products, thereby contributing to the fight against circumvention of excise duties and customs duties. Consequently, in view of the positive aspects of such enhanced cooperation, it was quite logical to vote in favour of the conclusion of that protocol.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Protocol addresses the criminal law side of tobacco trafficking and smuggling. It defines criminal offences, liability and destruction of seized products. I agree with the proposal because it promotes international cooperation and coordination in detecting this crime. This will ultimately help the economies of the parties involved and reduce the risk of public health threats.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, with regard to its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences , because it is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention for the Fight against Smoking, with regard to the provisions relating to obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of offences.  This protocol makes a strong contribution to the elimination of all forms of illegal trade in tobacco products and an instrument to combat the avoidance of taxes and customs duties, and also to introduce certain crimes, issues relating to the liability and disposal of confiscated products.  In order to ensure the full achievement of the objectives of this protocol, greater cooperation between Member States is essential, through an automated data exchange system, as well as the establishment of a comprehensive traceability and traceability regime.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This calls for the objectives of the FCTC protocol to be implemented. An action plan is expected by the end of 2016. It is intended to address the problem of how to prevent illegal tobacco products from third countries. This goes against the illegal trade in tobacco products, and I therefore support this protocol.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Protocol is to eliminate all types of illicit trade in tobacco products. The Protocol defines illicit trade in tobacco products as any practice or activity prohibited by law in connection with the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this problem, the Protocol applies to the supply chain of tobacco products, using various government instruments. It requires the establishment of a global labelling and tracing system within five years of the entry into force of the Protocol. The aim is also to establish a global contact point for information sharing within the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It will lead the development of national and regional labelling and tracing systems. The Protocol also contains additional provisions to combat the supply chain of illicit tobacco products. These include licensing, record-making requirements, as well as regulation of online sales, tax-free trade and international transit.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution accompanies the European Parliament's decision to engage the EU in the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products through the WHO protocol.  While the tobacco industry is strongly affected by this phenomenon, it is primarily a public health issue. As such, the protocol recognizes the irreconcilable conflict between the interests of the tobacco industry and public health. The protocol also prohibits the delegating of obligations related to the control of these products to tobacco manufacturers. I am voting for the EU to join this protocol.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The illicit trade in tobacco products is causing serious problems in tax matters, but especially in public health. While we obviously support the fight against these criminal and dangerous practices for our fellow citizens, we also ensure that a European criminal law and a European federal police do not develop, which are detrimental to the sovereignty of our nations. Thus, we would be in favour of good intelligence cooperation between the Member States. That's why I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. In addition to the loss of significant EU revenue stemming from unpaid taxes and customs duties, illicit tobacco trade is a criminal activity that threatens public health by tearing up public tobacco control policies by increasing easy access to cheaper tobacco products. It is essential to strengthen the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I lend my support to this report, as it opens the way for the Member States to use additional provisions aimed at disrupting the supply chain of illicit tobacco products.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am positioning myself in favour of the adoption of the Protocol to Eliminate the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products (CCLAT Protocol), which is the only global and multilateral initiative in the field of tobacco smuggling. It is important to note that most of the illicit tobacco products circulating on our European territory come from third countries. To deal with this cross-border criminal activity, it is imperative to establish an efficient global mechanism. In addition to the fact that this illicit trade results in immeasurable loss of customs costs - we are talking about more than 10 billion euros each year - this activity constitutes a very high risk to health.  The protocol proposed by the CCLAT provides a set of effective strategies against the illicit tobacco trade by aiming to secure the tobacco supply chain and by establishing a global traceability system. A system of control over licensing, online sales, duty-free sales and international transit will be put in place. This protocol will facilitate administrative cooperation in customs matters and will more accurately define the responsibilities and offences required after the seizure or disposal of illicit products.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The WHO Protocol on Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Illegal trade is considered to be an activity linked to the production, transport, reception, owning, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products prohibited by law. As one of the measures to combat illicit trade, it is proposed to establish a global search and tracing system, which will create an information sharing contact point based in the secretariat of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This contact point will guide the development of national and regional search and tracing systems. I also consider the protocol to be very beneficial in order to promote international cooperation in the field of law enforcement and the effective exchange of information. At the same time, I believe that the tobacco industry is equally responsible for tackling the illegal trade in tobacco products, and I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls to eliminate all forms of illicit trade. In order to address this, the protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products via a series of measures by governments: creation of a global tracking and tracing regime and establishment of a global information sharing point. The protocol will establish offences, address liability and seizure payments as well and the disposal of confiscated products. It also concedes the irreconcilable conflict between the tobacco industry’s interests and public health’s interests. It is essential to have another tool to counter the illicit trade in tobacco products. That is why I supported this report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This draft Council decision aims at ratifying the provisions of the Protocol already referred to in point 1 concerning obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the determination of criminal offences. The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with this draft Council decision, with an argument very similar to that set out in the Report of the Committee on International Trade on the ratification of the Protocol, referred to in point 1 on the ratification of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but the EU must not use this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police, which is why it is appropriate to abstain on this text. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organization aims at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products and aims at the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption by governments of a number of measures and requires the creation within five years of their entry into force , of a tracking and tracking system. The Protocol will define infringements, the issue of liability, payments arising from seizure, as well as the disposal of seized products, and will encourage and strengthen international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields. In view of the foregoing, I am in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. I support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but I want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. I abstain on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which gives the Council consent to ratify the WHO Protocol. The WHO protocol aims at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licencing, record keeping requirements and regulation of internet-sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which seeks to approve the Council's conclusion of the Additional Protocol to the Framework Convention of the World Health Organization, which aims to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products. This report concerns only the provisions of the protocol relating to judicial cooperation between states. In this context, I support, among other things, the creation of a global monitoring and traceability regime, a global information sharing point, and the keeping of records and regulation of internet sales. The fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, which kills 6 million people each year, is also aimed at combating delinquency, a means of reducing consumption.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Union should strengthen the World Health Organisation (WHO) Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products. The purpose of the Protocol is to ban all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products, which have a number of health and criminally questionable harmful effects. The Protocol provides for the monitoring of the supply chain of tobacco products, which will be ensured by establishing a global tracking and monitoring system set up within five years of its entry into force. The protocol also aims to encourage and improve international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and law enforcement cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The World Health Organisation (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the first global health treaty created in response to the globalisation of the tobacco epidemic. I support this recommendation that aims to eliminate the illicit trade of tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling by enhancing judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as, together with further measures, an important step is being taken against the illegal trade in tobacco products. It also calls for an open standard in which all traceability systems can be integrated.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The purpose of the Protocol is to eliminate all illegal forms of trade in tobacco products, including their production, transport, reception, possession, distribution, sale and purchase.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to the Parliament. Whilst UKIP are not opposed to tackling the illicit trade in tobacco products we do have reservations regarding judicial cooperation on behalf of the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of Mrs Anderson's proposal, as I believe that the European Union should immediately ratify the WHO Protocol on the illegal trade in tobacco products. As this is prohibited by law, new traceability measures, which are also extended to tobacco products, and the exchange of information between national governments seem useful and necessary. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which recommends supporting the Decision on the conclusion of an agreement to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products with the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control concerning those provisions of the Protocol covered by the content of Part 3 of Title V of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  The Protocol itself proposes a number of measures relating to the supply chain of tobacco products and to be implemented by member state governments. This requires the establishment of a global tracking and monitoring system, and a global information sharing hub will be established to this end. This will govern the establishment of national and regional follow-up and monitoring systems. Provisions aimed at addressing the supply chain of illicit tobacco products will also be insisted on. These provisions include licensing, record-keeping conditions and regulation of online sales, duty-free sales and international transit.  As the existence of illicit trade in tobacco products is a evident problem, the Protocol also establishes provisions on infringements, liability and attachment payments, as well as the treatment of confiscated products. For all of the above, I supported this Recommendation with a view to eliminating illicit trade in tobacco products as effectively as possible.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I support the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products, but I want to prevent the EU from using this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. I abstain on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is the world's first health treaty. It is designed in response to a global epidemic of tobacco addiction to combat some of its causes, including the illicit trade in tobacco products. It entered into force on 27 February 2005 and has so far been joined by 180 parties. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products adopted by the Conference of the Parties on 12 November 2012 in Seoul is based on Article 15 of the FCTC. The Protocol is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative that exists in this area. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to public health.  It undermines tobacco control policies and increases the availability of often cheaper tobacco products. In addition, it is the cause of huge revenue losses for the EU due to unpaid taxes and customs duties. Revenue losses for the EU and Member States are estimated at more than €10 billion per year. For this reason, I welcome the European Parliament's decision to give its consent to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The illicit trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or behavior prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, reception, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this issue, the Protocol aims at the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption by governments of a number of measures and requires the creation, within five years of their entry into force, of a tracking and tracking system. This implies the creation of a global information sharing point, located at the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which will oversee the establishment of national and regional localization and follow-up systems. Furthermore, the Protocol will aim at encouraging and strengthening international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. The Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention shows the link between tobacco industry interests and public health interests and lists certain obligations relating to the tobacco industry. All Signatory States of the Protocol shall act transparently in any cooperation with the tobacco industry.  Provisions aimed at addressing illicit tobacco supply chains are insisted on, including licensing, record-keeping conditions and regulation of online sales, duty-free sales and international trade. I supported Mp Anderson's recommendation, as she urges all tobacco industry participants to act effectively in accordance with laws to address the illicit trade in tobacco products.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recognizing the existence of an illegal trade in tobacco products, the World Health Organisation protocol aims to address other aspects as well. It introduces certain criminal offences and addresses issues relating to liability and payments in the event of confiscation, as well as the disposal of confiscated products. The protocol also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, effective information sharing, technical cooperation and cooperation for law enforcement purposes, as well as mutual assistance in both the legal and administrative fields. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to conclude the Protocol to Eliminate the Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products in the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, regarding its provisions on criminal judicial cooperation obligations and the definition of criminal offences. This text is part of the ongoing and necessary struggle to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. For this to happen, technical cooperation between law enforcement authorities needs to be strengthened, particularly at the international level.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) is the first global agreement in the field of health and aims to address the global smoking epidemic by seeking to address the problem by eliminating the causes, including illicit trade in tobacco products. In view of the conclusions of the FCTC, the rapporteur gives its assent to the terms of the agreement, and considers that the ratification of the FCTC Protocol will be beneficial to public health and will contribute to the international fight against illicit tobacco trade, tax evasion and organised crime. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to the Parliament. Whilst UKIP are not opposed to tackling the illicit trade in tobacco products we do have reservations regarding judicial cooperation on behalf of the EU.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which gives the Council the green light to conclude the agreement on the protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products, with regard to its provisions under the third part, Title V, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union which concern the area of freedom, security and justice. This is a protocol to the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which I fully support.  Like the vote on the same protocol for the non-freedom, security and justice provisions, I agree with the measures contained here, as they will help to combat the public health risk that tobacco poses to our societies, just as they will help to combat the EUR 10 billion in financial losses caused by its illicit trade.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products (any practice or behaviour prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, reception, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products). This involves strengthening international cooperation, sharing information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields, as well as the supervision of national and regional product tracking and tracking systems. The tobacco industry has a responsibility to act effectively and unequivocally combat the illicit trade in its products. The Protocol recognises the irreconcilable conflict between the interests of the tobacco industry and the interests of public health and defines specific obligations with regard to the tobacco industry.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was adopted in November 2012 by the Conference of the Parties. This Framework Convention calls for effective measures to eliminate the illicit manufacture and trade of tobacco products.  Illicit manufacturing and trade in tobacco products results in losses of around EUR 10 billion per year for the European Union and its Member States, but that is not all. This illicit tobacco trade is also a major public health issue. It is therefore important to combat these practices effectively. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution of the European Parliament which supports the ratification of this framework convention.  In my view, it is imperative to strengthen cooperation between Member States, through an automatic information exchange system. I also support the implementation of enforcement measures, including fines and other appropriate civil and criminal sanctions. In view of the major challenge of this fight, particularly in the area of public health, I strongly encourage Member States to ratify this protocol as soon as possible.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The document in question is an important step in restricting the illicit trade in tobacco products. The document is well designed, and I am convinced that we must support it without major debates or amendments. Reducing the illegal trade in tobacco, as it aims at this document, will achieve at least three objectives: on the one hand, it will ensure tax revenues for Member States and, on the other hand, reduce the possibility of criminal activity, and thirdly, it will enable it to control the quality of tobacco products entering the EU market, at least by contributing to the fact that those who cannot refuse smoking are less harmful to their health.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the primary objective of eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products, the European Union needs to ratify the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the World Health Organisation, as described by the rapporteur. This Protocol focuses on the chain of production and sale of tobacco products through the adoption by governments of measures on the development of additional provisions to deal with illicit tobacco products.  Aware of the existence of illicit trade in tobacco products, this report aims at the part of the protocol on combating this criminal action, defining infringements and addressing the issue of liability and paymentstemming the seizure, as well as the elimination of their seized products. In addition, this Protocol will encourage and strengthen international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields. The tobacco industry has a responsibility to act effectively and unequivocally combat the illicit trade in its products. As I said earlier, I voted in favour of this report (which relates exclusively to the provisions covered by Part III, Title V, TFEU).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Anderson report calls for the adoption of the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. To this end, it is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products through a number of government measures, for example, a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime, the prevention of money laundering, the introduction of a licence and the maintenance of a register and the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid information exchange, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted for it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 With the agreement, we can welcome the fact that we have now achieved the first multilateral initiative to combat the illicit trade in tobacco and cigarette smuggling. The agreement ensures control of the supply chain. At the same time, the agreement also wants to improve public health and the fight against tax evasion. Denmark is covered by the opt-out, but I see this as a positive step and have therefore voted 'yes'.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report gives Parliament's consent to the signing of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products from the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illegal tobacco trade. It introduces measures to prevent the illicit trade of the same, ensuring the supply chain. At the same time, the protocol includes obligations for the tobacco industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The stated objective of the World Health Organisation protocol is to eliminate all forms of illegal trade in tobacco products. To this end, the Protocol defines measures to control the supply of tobacco products, licensing rules, registration requirements and regulation of Internet sales. It also introduces certain offences and addresses issues relating to liability and payments in the event of confiscation, as well as the disposal of confiscated products. Since the ratification of the protocol will benefit public health and at the same time make a strong contribution to the international fight against the trade in illegal tobacco, tax evasion and organised crime, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the ratification of the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It is necessary to protect ourselves from the health, social, environmental and economic impact caused by this illegal trade. Trade in tobacco products must be controlled and regulated and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in this area must be deepened. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is high time that the World Health Organisation Protocol on Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products ratified the EU without delay. I am glad that the protocol will also insist on additional provisions aimed, in particular, at combating the supply chains of illicit products with a series of measures to be taken by the governments of individual Member States. I welcome the challenges taken on by the tobacco industry in order to tackle the illegal trade in products effectively and unequivocally. I have a positive view of the financial contributions made by producers of more than EUR 2 billion to support measures to combat smuggling and counterfeiting, while preventing money laundering. Health and economic interests must become a priority, so I expect the Commission and the Member States to create measures at European level in the near future so that there is no regulatory gap in the illicit trade in tobacco and tobacco products.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am extremely satisfied that today we voted in favour of the ratification of the Protocol.  Illicit trade in tobacco not only causes billions of lost revenue to the budgets of Member States. More importantly, it undermines our public health policies and violates the rules that the EU and Member States have on manufacturing, distribution and sale of legitimate goods. Cigarette smuggling makes possible the circumvention of legislative restrictions and pricing policies that are designed to deter smoking, especially among youngsters. Therefore, the control of the supply chain is of fundamental importance not only for combatting illicit trade, but also for reducing tobacco use in general. The illicit tobacco trade is also a main source of revenue for organised crime, and, in some cases, terrorist groups. The global and highly complex nature of the illicit tobacco trade makes it hard to tackle. This is why a coordinated international response and improved global regulation of the legal tobacco trade is such an imperative. I hope that with the ratification and later the implementation of the Protocol we will succeed in changing this situation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to cooperate the European Union's action with other states and international organisations in combating illicit trade in tobacco and tobacco products.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Union and the Member States, in addition to Sweden, have concluded legally binding and enforceable agreements with the world's four largest tobacco producers to address cigarette counterfeiting and smuggling. In my view, the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products with the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is a major and crucial contribution to international efforts to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products.  I also think it is very important that this is the way to reduce the avoidance of customs and tax obligations. Together, the world's four largest tobacco producers must pay out more than €2 billion to the Union and the Member States party to those agreements to provide assistance and support to anti-counterfeiting and smuggling instruments and measures.  So far, 16 countries have ratified the Protocol, including five Member States, and it should enter into force on the twentieth day from the date of storage of the fortieth instrument for the ratification of the authorisation or certificate of accession with the Depositary. Consequently, I support this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote. The EU is not a state. That is why it cannot sign or ratify international agreements. That is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of the Protocol is to combat illicit trade in tobacco products. Any practice or conduct related to production, receipt, distribution, possession, sale, purchase prohibited by law is considered illicit trade. The tobacco industry is responsible for effectively addressing illicit trade in tobacco products but also mitigating irreconcilable conflict between its interests and those of public health. The protocol provides for the supervision of the tobacco product chain, which must be achieved through a number of measures taken. It also envisions a global monitoring regime that would allow information to be exchanged at World Health Organisation level, leading to the creation of a national and regional monitoring system. I support the adoption of this Protocol because I believe it encourages and strengthens international cooperation, encourages information sharing, technical and police cooperation and joint legal and administrative assistance.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol for the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products to the Who Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, on behalf of the European Union, as regards the provisions of that Protocol on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences.  We need a Protocol to end the illegal trade in tobacco products, which makes an important contribution to ending the illegal trade in tobacco products and, consequently, to combating tax avoidance and customs duties.  We must not forget that the European Union loses €10 billion in revenue every year at the expense of cigarette smuggling. We therefore urgently need a global monitoring and tracking system, licensing and regulating sales in duty-free shops.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of judicial cooperation between Member States that wish to do so under the Protocol on enhanced cooperation in the field of tobacco products. The Protocol also refers in particular to the responsibilities of the tobacco industry for both illegal trafficking and public health, presupposes specific clauses for industry.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Illegal trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or conduct prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to tackle the illegal trade in tobacco products, the Protocol aims against the tobacco supply chain through a series of measures on the part of governments. It requires the establishment of a global tracking and monitoring regime within five years of the protocol's enter into force. This will create a global information exchange point located in the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. This will guide the creation of national and regional tracking and monitoring systems.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation deals with certain provisions of the World Health Organisation Protocol on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products, namely judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. In order to clarify the definition, the concept of illicit trade in tobacco products is laid down in the Protocol: any practice or conduct related to the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products and prohibited by law. In order to eradicate this phenomenon, the Protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products through measures taken by governments, for example by establishing a global tracking and tracking system. The Recommendation points out that the Protocol encourages and improves international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and law enforcement cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I agree that the tobacco industry also has a responsibility in all this process, and that is to act effectively and unequivocally in relation to the treatment of illicit trade in their products. The Protocol recognises that there is an irreconcilable conflict between the interests of the tobacco industry and public health. In this sense, with public health interests in mind, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The decision to use enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on international couples' heritage regimes, on issues relating to both matrimonial regimes and the heritage effects of registered partnerships, comes after negotiations between all Member States on the commission's initial proposals in 2011 were stalled. I deeply regret, however, that the rapporteur has made a distinction and segregation on same-sex couples.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular cigarette smuggling is a criminal activity seriously threatening public health and causing huge losses of revenue to the EU in terms of unpaid taxes and customs duties. Estimates indicate more than EUR 10 billion in lost revenue annually to the EU and Member States. This is why I voted in favour of the provisions on obligations related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences of the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. Through this provision, special efforts will be made to encourage and enhance international cooperation, valid information sharing, technical and law enforcement cooperation, mutual legal and administrative assistance. It will establish offences, address liability and seizure payments as well and the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that the European Union should ratify the World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit tobacco trade aimed at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Illicit trade in tobacco products is defined as any practice or conduct prohibited by law, related to the manufacture, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. The Protocol should cover provisions covering licensing, record-keeping conditions and regulation of online sales, duty-free sales and international transit. I believe that a number of measures relating to the tobacco supply chain will address the illegal trade in tobacco and that the tobacco industry is ready to act to address this problem.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards the provisions of that Protocol on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The protocol aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The latter Protocol defines as any practice or practice relating to the production, dispatch, reception, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products prohibited by law. The Protocol defines infringements, deals with liability and payments in the event of seizure, as well as the disposal of seized products. Its main objective is to promote and strengthen international cooperation, the exchange of valid information, technical and law enforcement cooperation, and mutual legal and administrative assistance. It also provides that a global monitoring and tracking system must be established within 5 years of its entry into force. There is an inseparable contradiction between the interests of the tobacco industry and the interests of public health, which the protocol does not deny. It states that the Contracting Parties must ensure that any cooperation with the tobacco industry is transparent.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Anderson report calls for the adoption of the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. To this end, it is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products through a number of government measures, for example, a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime, the prevention of money laundering, the introduction of a licence and the maintenance of a register and the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid information exchange, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union signed the protocol of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (CCLAT) to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products on 20 December 2013. The protocol must be ratified by 40 parties for it to enter into force. The illicit trade in tobacco products, including cigarette smuggling, is a criminal activity that poses a serious public health risk as it facilitates access to tobacco products, often at a lower cost. In addition, it causes the EU (and Member States) huge revenue losses in terms of taxes and tariffs evaded. It is estimated that the EU and the Member States suffer annual revenue losses of more than EUR 10 billion. Legal tobacco sales bring in more than 90 billion euros in tax revenue to Member States annually. About one in ten cigarettes is sold illegally. This report deals with judicial cooperation in criminal matters. However, we do not want the EU to use this global fight led by WHO as a pretext to develop a European criminal law and a European federal police. On the other hand, cooperation between sovereign states must be supported. I therefore choose the abject for this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Fight is a first global response to smoking and aims to combat the causes of this scourge. The Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products is currently the only multilateral regulatory initiative in this area. On 20 December 2013 this protocol was signed by the European Union, but it still needs to be ratified by 40 parties involved in order to enter into force. This protocol aims to reduce mortality and diseases related to tobacco consumption worldwide. Furthermore, illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular the smuggling of cigarettes to or within the EU, is considered a criminal activity which is at the root of significant loss of revenue, in particular taxes and customs duties for the EU and the Member States. It is estimated that the European Union and the Member States suffer losses of more than EUR 10 billion each year. Therefore, given that most illegal products originate in third countries, the report stresses that enhanced international cooperation is essential to counter illicit trade. In this respect, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Fighting.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The discussion on the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control shows that action by the European Union is not sufficient. The Protocol was signed by the EU on 20.12.2013 and there is no reason to oppose the convention. Its main goal is to eliminate the illegal trade in tobacco, which causes health risks. Another reason for adopting the recommendation is the tightness of the tax system. In the vote, I supported measures to reduce harmful practices that undermine public order and voted in favour of the Convention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Protocol on illicit trade in tobacco products should be confirmed by the European Union without delay. The stated aim of the Protocol is to ban all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The concept of illicit trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as follows: any practice or conduct related to the manufacture, transport, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products and prohibited by law. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Anderson report calls for the adoption of the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. To this end, it is oriented towards the supply chain of tobacco products through a number of government measures, for example, a comprehensive monitoring and tracing regime, the prevention of money laundering, the introduction of a licence and the maintenance of a register and the regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It also aims to encourage and strengthen international cooperation, valid information exchange, police and technical cooperation and mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted for it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this non-controversial agreement on international cooperation against the illicit trade in tobacco. The measures related to criminal law are only harmonising what is already being done at national level in terms of liability, prosecutions, sanctions and information exchange, and they leave considerable latitude for national laws. I am in favour of increasing international cooperation in the fight against the illicit tobacco trade.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, as regards its provisions on obligations related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. The objective of the protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The protocol targets the supply chain of tobacco products via a series of measures by governments. In addition, the protocol aims to encourage and enhance international cooperation, valid information sharing, technical and law enforcement cooperation, mutual legal and administrative assistance. I voted in favour because I believe that the Protocol to Eliminate Trade in Tobacco to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control is a crucial contribution to the international efforts to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products and thereby fight the circumvention of tax and customs duties obligations.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The protocol for eliminating the illicit trade in tobacco products aims to reduce deaths and diseases as a result of tobacco worldwide and combat illegal tobacco trafficking, which causes huge losses to public administrations in terms of unpaid fees and customs duties. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my Labour Party colleagues in favour of this report because the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, the first Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), was adopted on 12 November 2012 and is currently open for ratification, acceptance, approval or accession by the Parties at the WHO FCTC. The new treaty aims at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licencing, record keeping requirements and regulation of internet-sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The World Health Organisation Protocol on the illicit trade in tobacco products aims to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. Illicit trade in tobacco products shall be defined in the Protocol as any act or conduct prohibited by law in connection with the production, dispatch, receipt, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. I voted in favour of this recommendation because the Protocol encourages and strengthens international cooperation, and contributes to secure information exchange, technical cooperation in law enforcement, and mutual legal and administrative assistance. This is a formidable weapon against crime and for our health.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The stated objective of the Protocol is the elimination of all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The illicit trade in tobacco products is defined in the Protocol as any practice or behavior prohibited by law and related to the production, dispatch, reception, possession, distribution, sale or purchase of tobacco products. In order to address this issue, the Protocol aims at the supply chain of tobacco products through the adoption by governments of a number of measures and requires the creation, within five years of their entry into force, of a tracking and tracking system. This implies the creation of a global information sharing point, located at the Secretariat of the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which will oversee the establishment of national and regional localization and follow-up systems. Furthermore, the Protocol will aim at encouraging and strengthening international cooperation, the sharing of valid information, technical and police cooperation and mutual assistance in the administrative and legal fields. Support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This recommendation is, in my view, a useful contribution to the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products, which is why I am happy to support it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my Labour Party colleagues in favour of this report because the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, the first Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), was adopted on 12 November 2012 and is currently open for ratification, acceptance, approval or accession by the Parties at the WHO FCTC. The new treaty aims at eliminating all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. This proposal is in line with the EU’s comprehensive strategy to combat cigarette smuggling. Other provisions include licencing, record keeping requirements and regulation of internet sales, duty-free sales and international transit. It establishes offences, and addresses liability and seizure payments, as well as the disposal of confiscated products.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of this report for a number of reasons. First, the illicit tobacco trade poses a threat to public health, as it dismisses control policies on this product, and in turn favours the entry of new cheaper tobacco products, which hinders the responsible competition sought so hard by euro area institutions.   On the other hand, this unlawful activity results in large loss of revenue to the Union as a result of non-payment of the taxes established, since it is estimated that Member States no longer receive more than EUR 10 billion each year.   I am confident that through effort and coordination between member states we will be able to overcome this obstacle which greatly harms the tobacco industry in Europe, as well as other parties concerned, in order to ensure fair and transparent trade within the European Union.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol for the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, on behalf of the European Union, as regards the provisions of that Protocol on obligations relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and the definition of criminal offences. I support the purpose of the protocol, which is to eliminate all forms of illicit trade in tobacco products. The Parties to the Protocol must ensure that any cooperation with the tobacco industry is therefore fully transparent. In order to effectively eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products, it is important to promote and strengthen international cooperation, the exchange of valid information, technical cooperation and law enforcement cooperation, and mutual legal and administrative assistance.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that I voted in favour of both reports dealing with financial instruments on the commercial market. For me, it is essential that the European Union continues to move towards an efficient internal market, so that the internal market operates regardless of whether member states put additional barriers into that internal market. I firmly believe that the European Union will push for a revision of financial instruments on the commercial market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the new and past scandals of the financial world, Europe needs more stringent regulation with regard to the markets for financial instruments. The report calls for an extension for the entry into force of MIFID and MIFIR, citing a failure to provide regulatory technical standards and delegated acts within the deadline set by ESMA and the Commission. It seems unreasonable and unjustified to postpone any further legislation in this regard. In addition, an exemption for high-frequency trading (HFT) has been included. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the MIFID II entry period by one year to carry it back to 3 January 2018. This package consists of better defining investor protection rules, enacting minimum sanctions requirements or improving the organisation of markets.  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is in charge of collecting this data, in partnership with the relevant national authorities and the trading platforms themselves. In 2015, the Commission indicated its inability to put in place the necessary systems for the scheduled date: 3 January 2017. The reasons are various: delay on the part of market players to provide the right information or ESMA to produce the standards required for the implementation of the directive. This extension is therefore the result of a lack of serious cooperation between the players concerned (ESMA and major international banks). This respite seems to be granted to institutional actors, who are not diligent, who should be exemplary. At a time when any measure to reduce financial instability in the EU should be a priority, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFID II, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFID II in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFID II by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the positive results of the trilogue, I voted in favour of this legislative proposal on financial instrument markets.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EC on the markets in financial instruments, because it contains improvements in the specifications of certain non-financial corporations and the treatment of securities financing transactions.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive adopted in 2014 states that the European Securities and Markets Authority,ESMA for short, should work with the competent national authorities of each Member State to develop a common data system. According to the directive, this must be done by 3 January 2017. However, in order to ensure efficient and harmonised data collection, a completely new infrastructure must be created for this. Currently, ESMA and national authorities cannot guarantee that these infrastructures will be in place and ready for use by the date requested. In order to make this possible, the relevant deadlines for the directive must therefore be postponed. The amendment to the directive postpones these deadlines for another year. I welcome this extension of the deadline, as it is necessary to create an effective infrastructure.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the MIFID II entry period by one year to carry it back to 3 January 2018. To achieve these objectives, it is the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority to collect data from some 300 trading platforms. ESMA must thereby work closely with the relevant national authorities and the negotiating platforms themselves. However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017, when the MIFID II package was initially due to come into force. This situation is scandalous because the project has been under development since 2011. The root of the delay lies mainly in the procrastination of market players to provide information and to put in place the control tools, and in the inability of ESMA to produce on time the Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) necessary for the development of the regulations. I have objected to this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has demanded more data than it can chew from financial institutions. There is no such thing as perfect knowledge, this has been both a waste of time and British taxpayer´s money. The primary purpose of this report is for the Commission to appear as if they are doing something. If implemented, this report will have serious consequences for the financial services industry.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as recommended by the Committee on the merits

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which proposes to postpone the date of entry into force of Directive 2004/39/EC by 12 months until 3 January 2018, in view of exceptional circumstances and in order to allow national competent authorities and interested parties to complete the practical implementation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the MIFID II deadline by one year, i.e. to 3 January 2018. This package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, including increasing the transparency of derivatives markets and the supervision to which these markets are subject.  However, it was the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to collect a certain amount of data from trading platforms, which it announced could not be achieved by 3 January 2017, when the MIFID II package was originally due to come into force.  This situation is scandalous at a time when the project has been under development since 2011 and political approvals were obtained in April 2014. One of two things, either ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or it gives the major international banks an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations.  In any case, in this and other areas, untenable promises should not be made. For to the impossible no one is bound. So I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of revising the Financial Instruments Markets Directive. The MiFID 2 Directive, which reviews MiFID 1, addresses the shadowy areas of the markets. Indeed, MIFID governs investment services in the field of financial instruments provided by banks, as well as the operation of traditional exchanges and other trading platforms. The main elements are: improved market structure; Transparency of trading activities in equity markets will be strengthened; Framing high-frequency trading Limit the risk of destabilizing speculation in commodity markets; strengthen investor protection. The European Parliament's debates have focused on the issue of the remuneration of financial management boards and how to prevent the risk of conflicts of interest. Parliament has adopted the principle of remuneration by fees for independent advisers, without leaving an option for The Member States. The standards will not come into force until 2018 instead of 2017, as originally planned!

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This Directive represents an important step in building a true monetary and fiscal union. The tax information practiced by multinational companies severely erodes our public coffers, as it represents a huge loss of revenue for the Member States.  I would like to point out that despite being in favour of borrowing costs which cannot be deducted in the current fiscal year under the provisions of the Directive, they are deductible up to a maximum of 10% of EBITADs. I voted against it, because it was the consensus reached between the groups. I think we should be more ambitious, but any step in this direction seems positive to me.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Ferber report on the market in financial instruments. This is a technical measure amending certain dates in Directive 2014/65/EU which, after the outbreak of the international financial crisis, established a new regulatory framework for securities markets, securities intermediaries and trading venues. The amendment of the directive was necessary to extend the date of application of the entire regulatory framework by one year, including all the delegated and implementing acts envisaged, giving the Member States time to transpose it correctly.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive on certain dates. It provides that a third-country market is equivalent to a regulated market if certain requirements and procedures are met. At the request of the competent authority of a Member State, the Commission shall take equivalent decisions determining whether the regulatory and supervisory framework of a third country ensures that an authorised regulated market in that third country satisfies legally binding requirements which are equivalent to the requirements arising from other Regulations.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have chosen to vote against this report on the proposed directive by Parliament and the Council amending, with regard to certain dates, the 2014/65/EU directive on financial instrument markets. This request for an extension for the implementation of the MiFID II package is scandalous and is either a total incompetence of the European institutions or a collusion on their part with the major international banks reluctant to the MiFID II package. It is understandable why when we know that this "paque" follows the financial crisis of 2008 and that it aims to better regulate the securities markets, investment companies and intermediaries. However, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has so far been unable to ensure that the relevant authorities or market participants have the necessary platforms to collect data on some fifteen million financial instruments; However, the project has been developed since 2011 and received the necessary political approvals in 2014. It is therefore unthinkable that an additional time could be given to an authority that clearly does not have jurisdiction to establish serious financial regulation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with an interesting and shareable topic that is unfortunately dealt with in an unclear way and that could leave room for future manipulations and critical issues. That is why I preferred to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to validate the interinstitutional agreement reached in trilogue.
