In the context of the extension until January 2018 of the second-level regulation of MIFID (Markets in Financial Instruments Directive), some technical adjustments are introduced at the first regulatory level, in terms of qualification financing operations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the future directive amending directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments and delays it by half a year for objective reasons in order to keep up the development and implementation of the necessary IT platforms.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of data has consequences in several areas of the financial instruments market. As far as market regulation is concerned, it is clear that most market rules cannot be applied until reference data are available and the infrastructures with which additional data for calculating transparency and reporting positions are collected are not produced. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to communicate certain reference data for financial instruments to the competent authorities in such a way that such data describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of the financial instruments covered by the MiFID II package. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported minor amendments to the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive, which equals the financial markets of third countries with a regulated EU market, provided that certain requirements of the Directive are met. It is more a question to specify the requirements applicable to investment firms, regulated markets, data communication service providers and third-country undertakings providing investment services or transactions in the Union. It also harmonised the regime for limiting the position for commodity derivatives in order to improve transparency, support proper pricing and prevent market abuse. The deadline for transposition of the Directive is early July 2016.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 MIFIR and MIFID are the cornerstone of financial market regulation, seeking to encourage their competitiveness through the creation of a single market in financial services and investment activities and through a high degree of harmonisation of investor protection in Europe. Stabilising financial markets and being transparent to consumers is our priority, but we must consider the timing necessary to ensure that the implementation of reforms in this area is effective and realistic. I therefore support Mr Ferber's report, which accepts the Commission's request to delay the application of MIFID II by one year, postponing it until January 2018. In this way, among other things, reasonable and realistic deadlines are set for ESMA and the national authorities.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to delay the implementation of the MIFID II package and the MIFIR regulation by one year to 3 January 2018. However, this directive and regulation have the following objectives: to make the use of regulated platforms mandatory for certain transactions; Introduce rules on high-frequency trading; Increase transparency and supervision of financial markets, particularly on derivatives; strengthen investor protection, all necessary and urgent measures in a context of financial insecurity. The excuses made by ESMA, in charge of the implementation of this directive, concerning the complexity of the task at hand, are not admissible, as political approvals have been obtained as early as April 2014. Either ESMA's experts are incompetent or they want to give the major international banks hostile to MFID an extra respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFID II, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFID II in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFID II by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU regulate securities markets and intermediaries with a view to improving the transparency and supervision of financial markets, as well as the conditions of competition in the trading and clearing of financial instruments. With this in mind, the new regulatory framework introduced provides for the trading venues and systematic internalizers to provide the competent authorities with reference data on financial instruments that uniformly describe the characteristics of each financial instrument falling within the scope of the regulatory framework. For the efficient and harmonised collection of data, the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority is developing, in cooperation with the competent national authorities, a financial instruments reference data system. Given the complexity of drawing up this mechanism and in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid any market disruption, I support the proposal to extend the time taken for the entry into force of the regulation and the directive in question.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2014/65/EU together with Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 600/2014 covers securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues, known as MiFID II. The role of these provisions concerns the extension of the number of financial instruments covered by the trading rules, but also aim to increase transparency and ensure supervision of financial markets. However, the lack of complete data, in particular those relating to reference data and those that make up the data infrastructure for transparency calculations, hinders the application of market rules. Information on transaction reporting, transparency framework, microstructural regulation is absolutely necessary in order to improve the conditions of competition in the field of trading and clearing of financial instruments.  In the context of some lacunare data, I consider it appropriate to postpone the date of entry into force of the instruments included in MiFID II, so I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report amending the directive in question, as I believe that the lack of data collection infrastructure has important implications for the whole scope of Directive 2014/65/EU. Without data, it is not possible to establish precisely which financial instruments fall within the scope of the new regulatory framework.  A new infrastructure is being developed for efficient and harmonised data collection. To this end, the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority, in cooperation with the competent national authorities, is in the process of creating a system of reference data on financial instruments.  The Deadline of January 2017 cannot be met by the Member States that have to implement the measures transposing the directive. It is therefore more than appropriate to extend by one year the date of application of the entire regulatory framework, including all delegated and implementing acts. There is no point in me focusing on the danger to legal certainty and market disruption, the failure to comply with this transposition by the date.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating of some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFID II, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFID II in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFID II by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it is clear that more time is needed before this regulation may be effectively implemented. Time should be taken given the importance of the issue – well implemented and clear regulations will allow for greater consumer protection and competition. The new deadline should be sufficient to allow for enforcement of the directive as it should be.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the request to postpone the entry into force of the MIFD and MIFIR from 3 January 2017 to 3 January 2018. That delay is in fact justified solely by the inefficiency of the institutions to produce the relevant second-level acts.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that Directive 2014/65/EU should be amended

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EC on the markets in financial instruments, with regard to certain dates. This is an attempt to delay the implementation of the Financial Instruments Markets Regulation by one year. As I believe that the additional delay will create additional problems and also the possibilits of irregularities, I have decided to vote against.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU lay down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, in order to improve transparency, promote orderly price formation conditions and prevent market abuse, and also introduce rules on high-frequency trading and improve financial market supervision through the harmonisation of administrative sanctions. In addition, by developing the existing rules, the new regulatory framework also strengthens investor protection by introducing strict requirements on organisation and rules of conduct.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal for a directive because I am convinced that the centrality of the financial system in the European economy justifies further controls compared to those required of companies in other sectors (yes, often excessive!). Companies must be free to make their own choices and prosper through them, but on condition that they take full responsibility for the direct and indirect effects. Since this is often not the case in the financial sector, it is good that controls should be stepped up for the benefit of the sector itself and of all those downstream.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote to provide harmonised regulation for investment services across the EU. The directive's main objectives are to increase competition and consumer protection in investment services.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process, the solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated, but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to improve transparency and facilitate orderly pricing conditions and prevent market abuse, regulated financial instruments are needed. Rules on high-frequency trading should be introduced and financial market supervision improved through the harmonisation of administrative sanctions. I voted in favour because, by improving the existing rules, the new regulatory framework would also strengthen investor protection by introducing stricter requirements.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report proposes collection of data in an efficient and harmonised manner while a new data collection infrastructure is being developed as part of a process which harmonises position-limits regime for commodity derivatives. The main scope is positive, that is, to improve transparency, support orderly pricing and prevent market abuse. I agree with the introduction of rules on high-frequency trading which improve oversight of financial markets by harmonising administrative sanctions. Building on the rules already in place, the new framework also strengthens the protection of investors by introducing robust organisational and conduct requirements.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution because changing the transposition date is essential and urgent for the European Authority ESMA and the national authorities to be put in a position to complete the construction of data collection infrastructures, avoiding the risks of market disruption and improving the competitiveness of financial markets. However, I believe that in future we should be more careful and cautious in setting the time targets for the entry into force of the regulations, because postponing a transposition date could have a negative impact on the guarantee of legal certainty, all the more so in a sensitive and well-monitored sector, such as the markets for financial instruments. Investors and savers need to find a healthy financial environment, free from uncertainties in which to develop their potential. At the same time, the Member States must be in a position to transpose the directives in a linear manner, without additional costs and procedural uncertainties. It is up to us co-legislators to ensure these certainties, putting the Commission services in the best position to do their best.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In accordance with Article 93 of Directive 2014/65/EU, Member States should apply measures implementing that directive from 3 January 2017. However, due to the complexity of the data that needs to be collected and processed for the new framework to work, in particular for transaction reports, transparency calculations and position reporting for commodity derivatives, stakeholders such as trading platforms, ESMA and national competition authorities are unable to ensure that the necessary data collection infrastructure is set up and operational within a certain period of time. In the light of these exceptional circumstances and in order to enable ESMA, national competition authorities and interested parties to terminate their obligations, the deadline by which Member States were to apply the measures implementing Directive 2014/65/EU and the deadline repealing Directive 2004/39/EC should be postponed by 12 months, i.e. until 3 January 2018. I fully agree with the proposals put forward, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote deals with financial instruments and a new overall legislative package referred to as MiFID/R. It has been developed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the Commission over the last two years.  It is the single largest exercise ESMA has undertaken since it was founded in 2010.  However it has become apparent that ESMA and national authorities will not have the IT systems that they need in place in time for the market to comply with the intended ‘go live’ date of 3 January 2017. After seeking reassurances that this is the minimum delay necessary, and that it really is unavoidable, both Parliament and Council negotiating teams have agreed to approve this one-off delay.  Today’s vote deals which changes that have been done during the period of this extension with a view to improve the text. The changes include technical fixes about the treatment of package transactions, on the requirements for certain non-financial firms, and on the treatment of Securities Financing Transactions. These issues are not politically controversial, have been approved by all the groups and are aimed at improving the final package. Hence I supported them with my vote.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement reached in trilogue, which extends the existing legislation developed in the financial crisis to support key financial instruments. With the planned IT infrastructure changes not yet in place, it is therefore prudent to extend the deadline. Getting these regulations right is vital for a long-term prosperous financial sector both in the UK and across Europe.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate the fact that a compromise has been reached for this directive. It is time to review and implement effective legislation that protects investment, prevents speculation and restores the confidence of European citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on the decision to postpone the effective dates of regulations on financial instrument markets due to the delay in implementing implementation measures (delegated acts and technical standards). Considering that this report makes no substantive changes, and that this postponement is necessary for the proper establishment of regulations on financial instrument markets, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report on the Commission's proposal to amend the 2014/65/EU directive on financial instrument markets. The aim is to postpone the date of transposition of the directive by one year in order to guarantee legal certainty and to enable the implementation of delegated acts and technical standards.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of data has consequences in several areas of MiFID II. As far as market regulation is concerned, it is clear that most market rules cannot be applied until reference data are available and the infrastructures with which additional data for calculating transparency and reporting positions are collected are produced. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to communicate certain reference data for financial instruments to the competent authorities in such a way that such data describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of the financial instruments covered by the MiFID II package. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The lack of data has consequences in several areas of MiFID II. As far as market regulation is concerned, it is clear that most market rules cannot be applied until reference data are available and the infrastructures with which additional data for calculating transparency and reporting positions are collected are produced. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to communicate certain reference data for financial instruments to the competent authorities in such a way that such data describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of the financial instruments covered by the MiFID II package. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the deadline for the implementation of the MIFID II package by one year until 3 January 2018. It makes it mandatory to use regulated platforms for certain transactions, introduces rules on high-frequency trading, and increases transparency and supervision of financial markets. It strengthens investor protection with strict organisational and good behaviour requirements.  The European Securities and Markets Authority must collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from 300 trading platforms and in consultation with national authorities. However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017. However, the project has been under development since 2011 and political approvals have been obtained since 2014. I therefore voted against this extension, which is due to the procrastination of market participants and the inability of the authority to produce the standards necessary for the development of regulations on time.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I supported the report, which is essentially aimed at extending the transposition of this measure after 3 January 2017, and I am aware that this will most likely not be the last extension. However, this is not due to member states' reluctance to do so, but to the complexity of the data collected and the creation of the new framework. Markets in financial instruments are complex matter and there must be worked carefully and with very high precision.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of large banking giants and governments, in order to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Regulation on this subject requires that trading platforms and systematic internalisers provide the competent authorities with reference data on financial instruments describing uniformly the characteristics of each financial instrument covered by that Directive. To this end, a new data collection infrastructure is being developed to enable efficient and harmonised data collection. The proposed amendments are in line with the guidelines proposed by the competent authorities.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I vote against: under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to MIFID an extra respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the proposal for a Directive to amend the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive, which aims only at amending specific dates of the basic Directive. The criticisms we have made to the basic directive in due course and which led us to vote against it remain entirely. These changes do not touch the substance, which is the very existence of these markets and their instruments. They keep untouchable the "financialization" of the economy and all productive activity as its hostage as a central part of the EU's development strategy, always seeking to meet the profit rates of large economic and financial groups, which the production of real goods and services could not and cannot satisfy. This is the instrument that is part of this strategy, which is inseparable from the existence of tax havens, the increasing crushing of public expenditure and investment, privatisation and the liberalisation of public services and companies essential to economic and social development.  For these reasons, I vote against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I consider it appropriate to extend the period within which Member States will have to apply the measures transposing Directive 2014/65/EU and consequently the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC. This is due to the size and complexity of the data, which ESMA and the competent national authorities are called upon to collect and process, not allowing the construction within the established time limits of the infrastructure necessary to ensure its proper functioning, and consequently by achieving legal certainty, creating possible market disturbances.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because I disagree with the changes to MIFID.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because in some areas the supervisory instruments have proved insufficient to prevent speculation and dominant positions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of major banking giants and governments to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares. The European Securities and Markets Authority must first and foremost enforce transparency rules and best rules for the execution of transactions. More importantly, however, a sanctions framework must be established for those who use unfair means, even misinformation, resulting in market distortions and the losing of money for private investors.   For these reasons I am voting against the report on the markets in financial instruments.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The MiFID/R overall legislative package is enormous, and is accompanied by a vast array of secondary legislation, which has been developed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Commission over the last two years. It is the single largest exercise ESMA has undertaken since it was founded in 2010. During those two years, it has become apparent that ESMA and the national authorities will not have the IT systems that they need in place in time for the market to comply with the intended ‘go live’ date of 3 January 2017. After seeking reassurances that this is the minimum delay necessary, and that it really is unavoidable, I agree with this one-off delay. I also agree that the directive shall not apply to persons dealing on own account in financial instruments other than commodity derivatives or emission allowances or derivatives.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of data has consequences in several areas of MiFID II. As far as market regulation is concerned, it is clear that most market rules cannot be applied until reference data are available and the infrastructures with which additional data for calculating transparency and reporting positions are collected are produced. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to communicate certain reference data for financial instruments to the competent authorities in such a way that such data describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of the financial instruments covered by the MiFID II package. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it represents an important piece of financial legislation adopted in the wake of the financial crisis in terms of stock markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The new framework harmonizes the position limitation regime for commodity derivatives in order to improve transparency, promote orderly price formation and prevent market abuse. It also introduces rules on high-frequency trading and improves financial market supervision by harmonizing administrative sanctions. Similarly, the new framework also strengthens investor protection by introducing rigorous organizational and behaviour requirements.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement to postpone until 3 January 2018 the entry into force of the Financial Instruments Market Directive (MiFID II), the Related Regulation (MiFIR) and related second-level acts, because I believe that these two pieces of legislation, which are as complex as they are important, are two fundamental pillars for supporting the stability of the financial markets and, at the same time, ensuring that the supervisory authorities of the Member States and ESMA are able to ensure uniformity in their application.  The legislation in question lays down the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated financial markets and data communications service providers, harmonising existing legislation, and in particular the legislation on the derivatives of goods, in order to prevent market abuse. They were dismissed at the end of the last parliamentary term, in response to the financial crisis, which originated in the United States in 2008 and subsequently also spread throughout the EU. However, the complexity of the matter and in particular the need to enable data collection IT infrastructures to be fully operational made referral necessary. As a result, the European Parliament and the Council have accepted ESMA's call for the entry into force to be postponed and for the entire implementation timetable provided for in the two legislative acts to be remodulated.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the financial services markets report today. This report postpones the entry into force of the so-called MiFID II directive by one year, giving us more time to do everything we can to step up the fight against the avoidance and evasion of taxes by trickery by large corporations. This is an important contribution to full tax justice for families and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. With the help of MiFID II, financial markets are to become safer and stronger. This should help financial markets to contribute even more to growth and employment. For investment firms and trading venues, this means that new and stricter transparency standards apply.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. Therefore, it is fair that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this must be the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union and on central securities depositories for certain dates. The postponement of the application of Regulation 600/2014 until 3 January 2018, i.e. 12 months, is necessary to ensure legal certainty and to avoid possible distortions in the financial market.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. Therefore, it is fair that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this must be the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The directive’s aim is to improve the competitiveness of EU financial markets by creating a single market for investment services and activities, and ensuring a high degree of harmonised protection for investors in financial instruments, such as shares, bonds, derivatives and various structured products.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we disagreed with the 'MiFID' Directive and the 'MiFIR' Regulation, which supposedly answered the crisis by changing rules on financial instrument markets, market abuse and securities settlement. In keeping with this position, we also voted against the changes being promoted in the tripartite dialogue between Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments as regards certain dates. Pursuant to Article 93 of Directive 2014/65/EU, the Member States were to apply the measures transposing that Directive from 3 January 2017. However, due to the size and complexity of the data to be collected and processed for the new framework to become operational, in particular for transaction reporting, transparency calculations and reporting of positions in commodity derivatives and stakeholders, ESMA and NCAs are not in a position to ensure that the necessary data collection infrastructures will be in place and become operational by that date. In light of the exceptional circumstances and in order to enable ESMA, NCAs and stakeholders to complete the operational implementation, it is appropriate to defer the date by which the Member States need to apply the measures transposing this directive and the date by which the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC is to take effect by 12 months until 3 January 2018.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it provides for harmonised regulation for investment services within the EU, allowing for increased competition and consumer protection in the area of investment services.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The points that were voted concerned certain technical fixes to the treatment of package transactions, on the requirements for certain non-financial firms, and on the treatment of Securities Financing Transactions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on financial instrument markets on specific dates (COM(2016)0056 - C8-8 2016/2016 - 2016/0033(COD)), given the lack of necessary data collection infrastructure that should become operational, all in view of the fact that member states must transpose the Directive into national law by 3 October 2016. Date: 31 July 2016, measures must apply from 3 January 2017. In this regard, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid market distortions, it is necessary to urgently move the deadlines for the start of the application of the overall framework including delegated and implementing acts and to move the deadlines for the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC by 12 months to 3 January 2018.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The MIFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. To achieve the objectives of the package, it is the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from some 300 trading platforms. ESMA must thereby work closely with the relevant national authorities and the negotiating platforms themselves.  However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017, when the MIFID II package was initially due to come into force. The project has been under development since 2011 and since April 2014 political approvals have been obtained. I have therefore objected to this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the organisation of financial markets, which aims in particular to tackle the shadowy areas of the rapidly developing over-the-counter markets. The main objective of the two Ferber reports is to extend the implementation date of the new directive to January 2018 due to the exceptional complexity of the rules to be applied.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report covers the licensing and management requirements of investment firms, market regulation and related data provision services. As it is not possible to ensure that the necessary data infrastructures will be in place and operational by 3 January 2017 in order to create the necessary legal certainty and prevent potential market disruptions, the start of the entire legal framework will be postponed by 12 months. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of data has consequences in several areas of MiFID II. As far as market regulation is concerned, it is clear that most market rules cannot be applied until reference data are available and the infrastructures with which additional data for calculating transparency and reporting positions are collected are produced. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to communicate certain reference data for financial instruments to the competent authorities in such a way that such data describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of the financial instruments covered by the MiFID II package. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposed Directive on the markets in financial instruments. The Directive aims to harmonise the launch of financial instruments for all EU countries. However, I must stress that the directive has some legal loopholes which can be used inappropriately.  That is why I voted against the directive.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Democracy is, in principle, one of the cornerstones of the European Union, with elected leaders and citizens' right of say. In fact, the latter is mostly limited to 1-2 days every 4-5 years, the former being overridden daily by the power of international financial institutions. In this context, it is already progress that the directives in the proposal can dampen speculation and reduce the uncertainty of the financial system. The partial postponement is supported by objective reasons.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – Directive 2004/39/EC, also known as the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MIFID), provides harmonised regulation for investment services across the EU. It lays down requirements in relation to a number of elements, such as investor protection, market integrity, strengthening competitive mechanisms, market efficiency and improving the governance systems of investment firms. The MIFIR (Markets in Financial Instruments Regulation) sets out, among others, uniform requirements in relation to the communication to the public of trading data, the reporting of transactions to the competent authorities and the trading of derivative instruments in organised locations.  I believe that it is a priority, in a very technical discipline such as this one, to draw up a coherent framework for the creation of an integrated and competitive financial market, through the identification of uniform European rules, which is why I am voting in favour of Mr Ferber's report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it proposes to delay the implementation of the Financial Instruments Markets Directive, MIFID, voted in 2014, by one year. However, I am opposed to this additional delay because the delay is more due to a complacency of the European Markets Authority (ESMA) and the procrastination of the players in the financial markets than to an obvious and predictable technical complexity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on financial instrument markets. The text proposes to delay the implementation of the Financial Instruments Markets Directive, MIFID, which was voted on in 2014, by one year. This proposal is motivated by the fact that the competent authorities and market players would not have the information and control systems, personnel and procedures necessary to implement the regulation by January 2017.  The delay is due more to a complacency by the European Markets Authority (ESMA) and the procrastination of financial market players than to obvious and predictable technical complexity. In addition, these regulations have been in the works since 2011 to address the problems uncovered by the 2008 financial crisis. Therefore, I do not want to tolerate another year and 10 years of delay in financial product regulations.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The financial crisis of 2008 weakened the real estate market, investment firms and intermediaries. To address this problem and promote better regulation, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has instituted a legislative package entitled MIFID II, consisting of two projects: a directive called MIFID and a regulation, MIFIR. The package provides practical solutions such as the introduction of rules on high-frequency trading, or the requirement to use regulated platforms for certain transactions. However, the project, which has been under development since 2011, has significant delays due to foreseeable difficulties since its inception. The inability of market agents to provide information is the main cause, which is unacceptable. The report proposes to grant a one-year reprieve to the implementation of the MIFID II package, and thus to ignore this unjustifiable fact. I can't accept it and vote AGAINST.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. This amendment to the Directive postpones the effectiveness of financial market regulation until 3 January 2018. The Commission is asking for time to be able to prepare the infrastructure for processing all the data it wants financial institutions to process. Overall, I am against the new regulations introduced by the Financial Markets Directive 2014/65. I consider the agreement to postpone the validity as a chance to reject the directive in its overall form.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. —Regulation 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU lay down requirements related to the approval and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers. Under this regulation and directive, Member States are obliged to apply the Financial Instrument Reference Data System (FIRDS) by 3 January 2017, but the problem arises in the volume and complexity of the data to be collected and processed.   The European Securities and Markets Authority and NCAs are unable to ensure that the necessary collection infrastructure is in place by a defined date. I supported the Report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on financial instrument markets on specific dates. In my view, it is necessary to ensure greater legal certainty and avoid market distortions, and the only way to achieve this is to take valid measures that will allow for an extension of the deadline for the start of application of the whole system.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As you know, directives 2014/65/EU and (EU) 600/2014 were adopted following the recent financial crisis, the scope of which included securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The aim of the new framework is therefore to strengthen and replace the current but all-obsolete Directive 2004/39/EC. Given that the new legislative package came out structurally rather complex, particularly in terms of further implementation, a 30-month implementation period was consistently foreseen between its adoption period and its entry into force, which is known to differ from the normal 18-24-month period. In other words, in line with today's vote, the new rules will enter into force on 2 January 2017, not on 3 July this year. Since the primary objective of the Financial Instruments Markets Directive is to contribute to the stability and transparency of the EU financial market and to prevent potential crises, it was logical to vote in favour of Parliament's amended Commission proposal.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council governing securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues were adopted in 2014 as a result of the financial crisis. These modifications included deadlines for their transposition by Member States and deadlines for the implementation of individual measures, in particular the collection of data and data necessary to define individual financial instruments. Given the size and amount of data, the original deadlines are proving unrealistic, therefore the proposed proposals are postponing their deadlines for their effectiveness and thus the date of repeal of directive 2004/39/EC in force from 3 January 2017 to 3 January 2018.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EC on the markets in financial instruments, on certain dates, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 7/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The MiFID II package consists of the Directive (MIFID) and a Regulation (MIFIR). It aims to improve the regulation of securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. This package regulates high-frequency trading, transparency of financial markets and strengthens investor protection by setting strict requirements for organisation and good conduct. To achieve these objectives, the European Securities and Markets Authority must collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from some 300 trading platforms. However, the relevant market authorities have been slow to put in place the appropriate systems. We therefore oppose this unjustifiable extension in the context of current financial instability.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on the markets for financial instruments with regard to certain dates. The postponement of the date will allow you to have the data collection system ready and operational, also supporting the information and operational system. Quoting the text: "In order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market disruptions, urgent action is needed and justified to extend the date of application of the entire regulatory framework, including all delegated and implementing acts."

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The regulation of financial markets is an imperative shared by the vast majority of citizens, who have suffered from the mistakes of financial innovation, poor ratings, toxic derivatives that have contaminated the world economy even in the smallest bank.  The MiFID Directive was the European Union's first reaction after the crisis. This needed to be reinforced as quickly as possible by MiFID 2 ... which is still not in force due to lack of resources made available by the Commission. Regulations must be postponed until 2018 because of the lack of technical and human preparation by the competent services of the European Commission. It is also a boon for financial markets.  However, opposing the postponement of the application of the text would only expose the Commission and national authorities to legal uncertainty. So act. I voted in favour of deferral, according to a broad consensus in the European Parliament, but reminding the Commission that this was in no way a blank-seing to slow the pace of regulation, in particular 'delegated acts', decrees on which Parliament's rights are minimal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This concerns the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. However, the data infrastructure will not be completed until early 2017. I am therefore voting in favour of postponing the date of application by 12 months.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's proposal to delay the date of entry into force of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments in order to allow for the development and implementation of the necessary IT platforms.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In order to increase the transparency of financial markets, the EU has adopted new provisions. Thus the framework established by Regulation (EU) 600/2014 and the 2014/65/EU Directive sets requirements for the accreditation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data communication service providers. These regulations also introduce rules on high-frequency transactions and improve financial market supervision by harmonizing administrative sanctions.  And as soon as these directives are put in place, a state will be able to introduce limits on the contracts that an investor holds on derivatives of raw materials (wheat, soybeans, sugar), given their potential impact on price formation. The report introduces certain exemptions and postpones the implementation of these regulations by one year. I am voting against this text which rejects the few attempts to regulate the financial markets.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The MFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. ESMA is responsible for collecting data in collaboration with national authorities and trading platforms. However, ESMA is slow to develop the RTS and market participants are slow to provide the requested information. We therefore oppose this unjustifiable extension in the context of current financial instability; evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions. As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to this report as it proposes valuable amendments to current legislation with regards to financial instruments.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – As regards securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues, Regulation No 600/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of the EU and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council are the main financial regulations. These legal acts lay down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers and harmonise the position reduction regime for commodity derivatives in order to increase transparency, promote orderly pricing and prevent market abuse. A new data collection infrastructure has been developed reflecting more harmonious and efficient data collection. Without such data, it would not be possible to establish a precise definition of the financial instruments falling within the scope of the new framework. Furthermore, it will not be possible to adapt the rules on pre- and post-trade transparency to determine which instruments are liquidating and when a derogation or deferment of publication should be granted. As a result of not reporting positions for commodity derivatives, it will be difficult to enforce the restriction of positions to those contracts. If position reporting does not occur, the capacity to effectively detect breaches of position limitations is limited. Many requirements related to algorithmic trading also depend on data. The proposal has my full support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report that deals with financial instruments and a new overall legislative package referred to as MiFID/R. It has been developed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the Commission over the last two years. It is the single largest exercise ESMA has undertaken since it was founded in 2010. However, it became apparent that ESMA and national authorities will not have the IT systems that they need in place in time for the market to comply with the intended ‘go live’ date of 3 January 2017. After seeking reassurances that this is the minimum delay necessary, and that it really is unavoidable, both Parliament and Council negotiating teams have agreed to approve this one-off delay. Today’s vote deals with changes that have been made during the period of this extension in order to improve the text. The changes include technical fixes concerning the treatment of package transactions, on the requirements for certain non-financial firms, and on the treatment of Securities Financing Transactions. These issues are not politically controversial and have been approved by all the groups and are aimed at improving the final package.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to amend Directive 2014/65/EC on markets in financial instruments for certain dates. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament support the Commission's proposal with two amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the MIFID II entry period by one year to carry it back to 3 January 2018. This package consists of a directive (MIFID) and a regulation (MIFIR). The MiFID II Directive regulates the activities of investment firms, sets out investor protection rules and enacts minimum sanctions requirements. The MiFIR Regulation deals with the organisation of markets, access to the European market by companies from third countries and the powers of supervisory authorities. The MIFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. We therefore oppose this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS Market at EU level has become increasingly important due to the investment needs that exist at European level. I am voting in favour of this proposal because I consider it essential to deepen the European market for financial instruments, provided that products and their derivatives do not create problems for the various economies of the Member States

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to MIFID an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation.  I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report amends certain dates of regulations relating to financial instruments, market abuses and the improvement of securities regulation in the European Union. This report does not touch on the substance of all the texts it amends. That is why I voted for it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the financial instruments market. Although it is an area in which regulation is, out of necessity, difficult to understand because of its extreme complexity and the level of detail achieved, the regulation of the products that are the subject of the activity of banks and investment firms. The MiFID legislative package, together with the legislation necessary for its application, has been designed and developed by the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority together with the European Commission over the last two years. The market in financial instruments has not yet been harmonised between the countries of the European Union, despite the fact that it is one of the keys to achieving a single market. MiFID is a set of rules that aims at fair markets in consumer protection, transparency and simplicity of financial products. Among the specifications of the legislative package in question is also a set of rules designed to prohibit or limit the use of potentially dangerous or harmful instruments to market stability.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend certain dates of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive. The dates need to be amending in order for the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to establish a system of reference data for financial instruments. This is necessary for the purpose of effective data collection. The basics of this system are new IT systems that will be built on the basis of new parameters. Esma estimates that the five-step implementation process for data infrastructure could be completed by January 2018 and therefore needs to be re-dated.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EU Regulation No 600/2014 alongside Directive 2014/65/EU have both been adopted at the start of the financial crisis by the European Council and European Parliament as an important part of financial legislation. I support this report that aims to put in place a new framework that will improve transparency, support orderly pricing and prevent market abuse.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal of extending the entry into force of Directive 2014/65/EU, a component of the new framework also including Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, concerning securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The new framework was adopted in the aftermath of the financial crisis to reinforce and replace existing financial legislation. The proposal rightly concludes that with the amount of data that needs to be collected and processed across EU Member States for the Directive 2014/65/EU to function as rightfully intended, an extension of the entry into force of it is justified. Otherwise, the consequences may be that we run the risk of compromising the functioning of the market and the legal foundation regulating it.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported extending the application of the entire set of MiFID II rules until 3 January 2018, a period that should be sufficient for ESMA, the competent national authorities and operators to put in place infrastructure for data collection, reporting and calculation of transparency thresholds. I am convinced that this will avoid the risk of confusion and unnecessary costs for stakeholders as a result of graduated implementation. Building different infrastructures simultaneously – and not in stages – will make the process more cost-effective. This will avoid, for example, situations where investment firms implementing orders would have to implement organisational requirements or rules for managing business in stages, which would be complicated, expensive and costly.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFID II, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFID II in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFID II by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this draft as the report deals with the requirements relating to the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. It is expected that the data infrastructure will not be operational until the beginning of January 2017, so there would be only a limited operational data infrastructure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid possible market disruption, it is necessary to postpone the deadline for the application of the entire framework.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process, the solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that Directive 2014/65/EU and Regulation (EU) 600/2014 are key acts for European financial legislation and promote detailed collection of data and information on the various financial instruments, Given that the collection of such complex data makes it difficult for Member States to transpose the European directive within the time limits laid down by it, given, moreover, that my colleague's proposal to postpone the date of transposition of Directive 2014/65/EU by one year and the date of repeal of the previous directive allows States to provide themselves with the necessary infrastructure for data collection, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive ('MiFID') and the Markets in Financial Instruments Regulation ('MiFIR') were adopted in light of the financial crisis. MiFID and MiFIR, collectively called MiFID II, cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The new framework strengthens and replaces the existing MiFID framework (Markets in Financial Instruments Directive), which I certainly support.  The extremely high level of complexity of the MiFID II package and the need for a large number of implementing measures logically led to the need to prolong the start of application. In this regard, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid possible market distortions, urgent measures are needed to adjust the start date of application of MiFID II. The report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive on certain dates also lists some exceptions to the application of the directive and a proposal to extend the time limit by which a transposition into national legislation must be made. I support these proposals, as well as the proposed amendments to the directive, and have therefore supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to MIFID an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal to amend Directive 2014/65/EU on financial instrument markets on specific dates. The lack of data collection infrastructure has implications for the entire scope of Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013. 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU. Without data, it will not be possible to clearly distinguish between financial instruments that fall within the scope of the new framework.  Furthermore, it will not be possible to adjust the before and after-trade transparency rules necessary to determine which instruments are liquid and when exemptions or deferral of disclosure should be granted. In order to collect data efficiently and in a coherent manner, new data collection infrastructure is being developed. To this end, the European Securities and Markets Authority ("ESMA") and the NCAs are obliged to establish a system of reference data on financial instruments ("FIRDS").  It will cover a wide range of financial instruments fall within the scope of Regulation No 1000/2013. 600/2014 and will link data flows between ESMA, NCAs and trading venues from across the EU. In order to ensure legal certainty and avoid possible market distortions, immediate measures should and justified to extend the deadline for the start of the application of the overall framework, including all delegated and implementing acts.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Directive 2014/65/EU is one of the most important parts of financial legislation adopted in light of the financial crisis introducing clearer rules on securities markets and rules for investment intermediaries. In order to improve transparency, the regime of restriction of positions in commodity derivatives, support for proper pricing and prevention of market abuse is being agreed. High-frequency trading rules are also introduced and market surveillance is improved. The Directive prescribes markets and systematic internalisers to provide competent authorities with information on financial instruments that uniquely describe the characteristics of each financial instrument. To this end, the European Supervisory Authority (ESMA) and the competent national authorities are obliged to establish a system of reference data on financial instruments.  The measures transposing this Directive into national law are obliged to apply by Member States from 3 January 2017. However, due to the volume and complexity of the data to be collected and processed, ESMA realized at the end of last year that the industry would not be able to complete the necessary systems for the new reporting rules, so it proposed changes to the deadlines. I supported Representative Ferber's report to ensure legal certainty and avoid market distortions. I emphasise that the proposed measures are aimed at protecting citizens investing in securities by introducing strict organisational and business conduct requirements.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 93 of Directive 2014/65/EU on the markets for financial instruments, Member States are required to apply the measures transposing the Directive as from 3 January 2017. However, due to the size and complexity of the data to be collected and processed, neither the competent national authorities nor ESMA (The European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority) are able to ensure that the necessary data collection infrastructures will be implemented and operational by that date. Therefore, in the light of exceptional circumstances and in order to allow ESMA, competent national authorities and stakeholders to complete operational implementation, it is appropriate to extend by 12 months, until 3 January 2018, the date by which Member States must apply the measures transposing Directive 2014/65/EU. In order to allow this, I voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, citing technical changes in the entry into force of the Directive to improve the efficiency and transparency of financial instruments (MiFID 2). It will come into force in January 2018 and will allow financial markets to stabilise. To return to sustainable growth, these markets must gain investor confidence, not distrust.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process, the solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Text change only (due to the collection and processing of reference data) with a view to postponing the date on which Member States have to implement the transposition measures of Directive 2014/65/EU and the date on which the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC takes effect for a period of 12 months until 3 January 2018.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the proposed regulation amending the 2014/65/EU Financial Instrument Markets Directive on certain dates.  With regard to exemptions, the report states that the directive should not apply to persons trading on their own account financial instruments other than commodity derivatives or emission allowances, derivatives on the latter and which do not provide any other investment services or engage in any other investment activity in connection with financial instruments other than commodity derivatives or emission allowances or derivatives on them unless they are either members or participants of a regulated market or MTF, or have direct electronic access to a trading platform, trading, trading platform, trading, and if, in both cases, these people apply a high-frequency algorithmic trading technique on this type of trading platform. I thought it was important to point that out.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The document in question is one of the more important issues in this session. The recent financial crisis and the various speculations it has seen have long led to the introduction of proper regulation of the financial transaction sector. The proposed amendments impose requirements on trading venues and systematically provide internalisers with basic data on transactions executed to the competent authorities.  Those data are also used for other purposes, such as the calculation of transparency and liquidity thresholds and reporting of positions in commodity derivatives, and I hope will contribute to ensuring the stability of markets.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with a draft legislative resolution aimed at amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments by laying down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data communication service providers. This new framework requires trading platforms and systematic internalisers to provide the competent authorities with reference data on the financial instruments covered by that Directive and to describe uniformly the characteristics of each directive. The new data collection structure, which is under development, will allow for efficient and harmonised collection of data, even though its completion is not foreseen until after January 2017, when Member States should implement the transposition measures of the Directive.  Given the implications that the lack of a data collection infrastructure has on the implementation of the financial instrument markets directive as a whole, it is necessary and justified to extend the period to the implementation of the whole framework so that legal certainty is guaranteed and possible market disruption stems from. For this reason, My vote was in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Ferber's report provides for a number of changes to the date of implementation of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive. In April 2014, the European Parliament approved both MIFID II, an updated version of MIFID, and MIFIR, the accompanying report of MIFID, which was expected to be implemented by Member States by January 2017.  Due to some difficulties encountered during the implementation of these measures, the Commission has proposed postponing the implementation of MIFID II and MIFIR until 2018. By voting in favour of the report presented to plenary, I have given my approval to this postponement, which will clarify certain points of the legislation and will also allow the construction of complex IT systems for the application of the new package. These measures represent an important step forward in the financial field, in the direction of greater harmonisation of investment services throughout the European Union. I would like to remind you of the importance of these packages, which aim to increase competition and consumer protection in the area of investment services. I am therefore of the opinion that the implementation of these measures cannot be postponed beyond 2018.
