name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. It is regrettable that problems with IT systems mean that the implementation of MiFID/R must be postponed by one year, but the postponement is necessary to ensure as correct and smooth implementation as possible. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments in relation to certain data', because this will create clear responsibilities for companies active in financial markets. These undertakings shall be controlled and authorised by the Member State in which they are established. MIFIR creates the necessary transparency in the financial market and better protection for the company's customers. Both Directives are due to enter into full force in all EU Member States on 3 January 2017, provided that the technical conditions are met. Otherwise, an extension of the encommissioning is expected to be extended for one year.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of extending for 12 months, i.e. until 3 January 2018, the transposition for Member States of Directive 2014/65/EU on the markets in financial instruments. Given that neither stakeholders nor national authorities are able to ensure the operation of data collection infrastructures by that date, I believe that the entire regulatory framework needs to be extended.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending the Market in financial instrument Directive and the Markets in Financial Instruments Regulation because it is clear to me that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will and should be delayed. The reforms introduced by the aforementioned Directive and the Regulation are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I agree that, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market distortions, urgent measures need to be taken to delay the application of the new legal framework in its entirety, including all delegated and implementing acts adopted on the basis the same thing.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive 2014 is part of the key legislative measures adopted by the EU in the wake of the financial crisis. This is one of the main financial regulations concerning securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. Together with other regulations, they lay down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers. They also introduce rules on high-frequency trading and improve the supervision of financial markets by harmonising administrative sanctions. This new regulatory framework was developed by the Commission together with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), which was only established in 2010, and these legislative texts were its first major task. The whole new control system was due to be operational on 3 January 2017, but in recent years it has become clear that neither ESMA nor the national authorities have managed to set up the necessary IT systems. As this proposal is intended to extend once the implementation period of individual measures for 2018, I have decided to support it. Both Parliament and the Council have been assured that one year is the necessary time to fine-tune the systems. However, I hope that there will be no further postponement in the future.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Financial instruments should be traded, but at the same time this trade must be controlled by independent authorities in order to prevent illegal activity.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Directive 2014/65/EU lays down requirements related to the operation and approval of investment firms, data reporting service providers and regular markets. Harmonisation of administrative sanctions improves supervision of financial markets, and introduces rules on high frequency trading. Already regulated rules that strengthen investor protection by introducing strict organisation and business behaviour requirements underpinning the new framework.  The consequences of the lack of data collection infrastructure are significant in the entire scope of the Regulation and the Directive. Without data, it will not be possible to adjust the before and after-trade transparency rules necessary to determine the liquidity of instruments and when exemptions or deferral of disclosure should be granted. Furthermore, it will not be possible or clearly distinguishable financial instruments that fall within the scope of the new framework. Consequently, I support this report amending Directive 2014/65/EU.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In light of the financial crisis, Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council, as well as Regulation (EU) No 2014/65/EU 600/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, are considered to be the most important parts of financial legislation concerning securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. This report deals with a proposal to amend Directive 2014/65/EU on financial instrument markets on specific dates.  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the competent national authorities are obliged to establish a Financial Instrument Data System (FIRDS). It will cover a wide range of financial instruments and will link data flows between national authorities, ESMA and trading venues from across the Union. The new framework also develops new data collection infrastructure.  Parliament considers that quality implementation of these decisions takes more time, so the amendments to the Directive relate to extending the deadlines by one year, while the substance of the Directive remains unchanged.  The new rules are due to apply from 3 January 2017. I support the proposal to amend Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council, as I believe that the new framework strengthens investor protection due to the introduction of stricter requirements in organisation and business behaviour.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive with regard to certain dates.  The European Securities and Markets Authority, together with the national competent authorities, should establish a system of reference data on financial instruments. With this Directive, we postpone by one year the date on which Member States should apply the measures transposing the Directive into national law and the date on which the repeal of the Directive enters into force.  This is necessary in order to enable the competent national authorities and other stakeholders to complete the operational implementation.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we disagreed with Directive 2014/65/EU ('MiFID') and Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 600/2014 ('MiFIR'), which allegedly answered the crisis by changing rules on financial instruments markets, market abuse and securities settlement. In keeping with this position, we also voted against the changes being promoted in the tripartite dialogue between Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of major banking giants and governments, in order to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares. The European Securities and Markets Authority must first and foremost enforce transparency rules and best rules for the execution of transactions. More importantly, however, a sanctions framework must be established for those who use unfair means, even misinformation, resulting in market distortions and the losing of money for private investors.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on markets in financial instruments, which advises postponing the application by Member States of measures to transpose Directive 2014/65/EU and the entry into force of Directive 2004/39/EC 12 months later, until 3 January 2018. The new framework introduced by Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to provide the competent authorities with data on the financial instruments covered by this Directive. However, the new data collection infrastructure has not yet been developed. Thus, although Article 93 of Directive 2014/65/EU provides that Member States should apply the measures to transpose the Directive from 3 January 2017, its implementation is not appropriate as the lack of data collection infrastructures would have an impact on the full scope of both Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU. It is therefore reasonable to postpone the deadline by 12 months, as recommended in the report, until the competent national authorities and stakeholders have fully carried out the necessary operational tasks.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The legislative package for financial instrument markets is very voluminous and is accompanied by a wide range of secondary legislation, developed over the past two years by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Commission. Today's vote refers to certain technical changes to the first level of the text on financing operations through financial instruments, in particular the requirements for certain non-financial enterprises. I support by my vote the proposals set out in the text.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and The Council's proposal for a directive amending the 2014/65/EU Financial Instrument Markets Directive on certain dates.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In April 2014, in the wake of the financial crisis, we believed to have adopted a cornerstone of European financial market regulation to better shield the Union from another crisis. MiFID and MiFIR, collectively referred to as MiFID, were supposed to increase the transparency of markets and improve their oversight for businesses and consumers. While I find it regrettable that, two years later, we need to delay the implementation date of this important package after an already unusually long period of work by one year, I am aware of the complexities and technical challenges this package represents, which is why I voted in favour of the delay. It is more important to lay out good, workable rules than to rush things too quickly and to disturb the good functioning of the market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the amendment of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive on certain dates, as the purpose of this proposal is to extend the starting date of both technical implementation instruments encountered by competent authorities and stakeholders. In my view, a one-year extension will allow the competent authorities a sufficient and reasonable period of time to establish new infrastructure, ensure legal certainty and avoid possible market distortions, and take immediate measures to extend the deadline for the start of the application of the overall framework, including all delegated and implementing acts.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets for financial instruments on certain dates, as Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council are the main acts of financial legislation relating to securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues adopted as a result of the financial crisis. They lay down requirements concerning authorisations for investment firms and their activities, regulated markets and data communication service providers. They shall coordinate the position limits regime for commodity derivatives in order to improve transparency, support proper pricing and prevent market abuse. They also introduce rules on high frequency trading and improve the supervision of financial markets by coordinating administrative sanctions. The new framework requires trading venues and systematic internalisers to provide financial instrument reference data to competent authorities. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) should establish, together with the competent national authorities, a system of financial instrument reference data (FIRDS). In order to enable ESMA, national authorities and stakeholders to complete operational implementation, it is appropriate to postpone the date on which Member States are required to apply the measures transposing Directive 2014/65/EU into national law and the date on which the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC enters into force by 12 months, i.e. to 3 January 2018, and consequently amend the Directive accordingly.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my support to this text, as it is my belief that we should keep going forward in building a financial regulation that avoids (or minimises) new crises.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The MIFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. To achieve its objectives, it is the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from some 300 trading platforms. However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017, when the MIFID II package was initially due to come into force. The root of the delay lies mainly in the procrastination of market players to provide information and put in place the control tools, and in the inability of ESMA. We therefore oppose this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to MIFID an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The financial crisis that began in 2007 showed inefficient control of the financial sector. The lack of adequate regulation and regulation has caused perturbations in the financial market. Provision should therefore be made to effectively limit the possibility of a repeat of a similar situation in the future. I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal to amend the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A new data collection infrastructure has been developed to ensure efficient and harmonised data collection. To this end, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), in cooperation with the competent national authorities, shall establish a system of reference data for financial instruments. I voted in favour of the relevant document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The trilogue result is unacceptable on procedural and content grounds so I voted against the report but in favour of the Commission’s proposal, which was merely to postpone implementation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments as regards certain dates. Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council establish requirements in relation to authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting services providers. Moreover, the new framework strengthens the protection of investors by introducing robust organisational and conduct requirements. I believe that, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market disruption, it is necessary and justified to take urgent action to extend the entry into application of the whole framework, including all delegated and implementing acts.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a technical report with the aim of extending the entry into force of MIFID and MiFIR from 3 January 2017 to 3 January 2018, since ESMA and the European Commission did not provide the technical regulatory standards and delegated acts within the deadline set by the legislation.  In addition, this report provided a good opportunity to present a further amendment to the MIFID/MiFIR text. In fact, some exemptions from transparency requirements for transactions with own-account derivative contracts have been proposed through amendments co-signed across the board by various political parties (S&D, PPE and ALDE). Firstly, it seems to us unreasonable to extend it by one year because it is essentially due to the inefficiency of the EU institutions in producing second-level acts. Secondly, we are firmly opposed to the inclusion of exemptions for derivative contracts and other financial contracts as this could undermine the stability of the financial system. That is why we voted against it in plenary.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The new framework strengthens investor protection by introducing robust organisation and business requirements by July 2016. However, stakeholders such as trading platforms, ESMA and national competent authorities cannot guarantee that the necessary data collection infrastructures will be up and running by then. Without data, trading platforms and investment firms will not be able to report transactions carried out to the competent authorities. In order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid potential market distortions, I have voted in favour of urgent measures to delay the date on which the full framework becomes applicable.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 These amendments do not alter the essential question, which is the very existence of these markets and their instruments. They keep untouchable the "financialization" of the economy and all productive activity as its hostage, as a central part of the EU's development strategy, always seeking to meet the profit rates of large economic and financial groups, which the production of real goods and services could not and cannot satisfy. This is the instrument that includes this instrument, which is inseparable from the existence of tax havens, the growing contraction of public expenditure and investment, the privatisation and liberalisation of public services and companies essential for economic and social development.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. As a sufficient data infrastructure is not expected to be operational until the beginning of January 2017, the start of application is to be postponed by 12 months. Since only an operational data infrastructure can guarantee the desired legal certainty and the prevention of market disruptions, I am voting in favour of this draft.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Market For Financial Instruments Directive with regard to certain dates. That Directive postpones for one year the date on which Member States are to apply the measures transposing the Directive into national law and the date on which the repeal of the Directive enters into force. In order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid possible market disruption, it is justified to take action to postpone the date of application of the whole framework, including all delegated and implementing acts. This is necessary in order to enable the competent national authorities and other stakeholders to complete the development of a new data collection infrastructure.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this also applies to mr Ferber's report. I supported it, the same as I said on the previous point.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we have a Regulation and a European Union directive setting out the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers. The aim is to improve transparency and prevent market abuse. Without the collection of such data, the rules on transparency cannot be adapted, either before or after transactions. That is why I believe that it is a matter of legal certainty to act urgently to postpone the entry into force of the entire framework until a new data collection infrastructure is developed. It is about efficiency, transparency and avoiding market abuse.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the new and past scandals of the financial world, Europe needs more stringent regulation with regard to the markets for financial instruments. The report calls for an extension for the entry into force of MIFID and MIFIR, citing a failure to provide regulatory technical standards and delegated acts within the deadline set by ESMA and the Commission. It seems unreasonable and unjustified to postpone any further legislation in this regard. In addition, some exemptions for derivative contracts transactions have been included. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because, in the context of the extension to January 2018 of miFID's second-level regulation, some technical adjustments have been made at the first regulatory level, in terms of qualification financing operations.  Pointing out that this is the case, there has been general agreement of the large groups, since the objective of the vote is to validate the trilogue agreement.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a proposed regulation to amend three others, relating to the implementation of financial regulations, such as the requirement to use regulated platforms for certain transactions, the introduction of rules on high-frequency trading or the increased transparency of financial markets (derivatives etc.). For reasons similar to those that presided over the decision to postpone the implementation of the Financial Instruments Markets Directive, several date changes are proposed. Delaying such measures, at present, under the pretexts of the complexity of their implementation is an exaggeration. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating of some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFIR, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFIR in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFIR by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the progress made during the trilogue, particularly on transparency issues, I voted in favour of these regulations on financial instrument markets and market abuses.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation concerns markets in financial instruments, market abuse and securities settlement. The overall legislative work of the proposal is enormous and is accompanied by a wide range of secondary legislation, which has been developed by the European Commission and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) over the past two years. During these two years it became clear that ESMA and the national authorities would not be able to have at their disposal the IT systems necessary for the implementation of the project. That is why the European Parliament and the Council have agreed that there should be a temporary delay. The vote in which I voted in favour of this report concerns a number of technical corrections to the text to address the trading package and the conditions for certain non-financial corporations. In this vote we did not attempt to open up any new controversial element, which may create friction in the different political groups.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. For the same reasons as for the vote on the A8-126/2016 report, I objected to this report because it is the same request for a one-year extension of the period of application of the regulations contained in the MIFID II package.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report will increase the power of EU institutions by authorising the issuing of Delegated Acts by the Commission and Regulated Technical Standards by the ESMA. I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which proposes to postpone the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 by 12 months until 3 January 2018, in view of exceptional circumstances and in order to allow national competent authorities and stakeholders to complete the practical implementation.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns amendments to previous regulations on markets in financial instruments, as the deadlines imposed cannot be aeded. It has already become apparent during the legislative procedure that a significant number of measures will be required for the implementation of the Directives, and therefore a period of 30 months has been prescribed between adoption and application, rather than the usual 18 to 24 months. Since then, however, it has become clear that basic data infrastructures will not be operational even on 3 January 2017. In practice, this means that if the date of application remains unchanged, neither the competent authorities nor operators will be able to apply the new rules. The instability of the financial system is the result of a process of deregulation and liberalisation that began in the early 1990s and is also a consequence of the rise of the power of international financial institutions over the influence and power of nation-state democratic structures, elected leaders. The directives referred to in this submission may dampen speculation and reduce uncertainty in the financial system, but do not eliminate it. In the present particular case, it is essentially a question of postponing the introduction of certain measures, since the necessary information system could not yet be established. I supported this postponement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In particular, the MIFID Directive aims to prevent banks from continuing to sell anything to anyone, i.e. high-risk assets to uninformed and vulnerable customers. The report we will vote on just now intends to postpone the implementation of this directive until 2018, 10 years after the subprime crisis! Thus, we still want to give extra time to banks that abuse the credulity of individuals and companies sometimes fragile. One of two things, either the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or it gives the major international banks an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation. In any case, in this and other areas, untenable promises should not be made. For to the impossible no one is bound. How can the Commission combat the rapacity of banks when it is constantly encouraging the most unbridled free trade? In reality, beyond the big statements of principle, it is your ultra-liberal software that prevents you from better framing the activities of speculative finance.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European regulation on market abuse. In particular, the regulation provides for the extension of the market abuse regime to unregulated markets and new types of financial instruments. The widening scope of this regime means that issuers listed on the open market will be subject to preventive measures aimed at combating market abuse (publication of privileged information, establishment of insider lists, obligation to notify executive transactions, etc.).

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the Ferber report on the financial instruments market, market abuse and securities regulation. This is a technical measure amending certain dates in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on the markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on the improvement of the previous securities regulation in the European Union and central securities depositors. After the outbreak of the international financial crisis, these instruments had established a new regulatory framework for securities markets, securities brokers and trading venues. The amendment of the provisions was necessary in order to extend by one year the date of application of the entire regulatory framework, including all the delegated and implementing acts envisaged, and to improve certain parts.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the Financial Markets Regulation, market abuse regulation and securities settlement regulation. It speaks of the development of market governing bodies and investment firms operating a trading venue to make public the buying and selling prices and the depth of trading positions at those prices that are disseminated through their systems with regard to bonds and bonds, securitisations , issuance rights, derivatives traded at a trading venue and order packages.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In line with the report on the proposed directive by Parliament and the Council amending, with regard to certain dates, the 2014/65/EU directive on financial instrument markets, I voted against this text, which also calls for the approval of an additional period of time, this time for the regulations contained in the MiFID II package. As a reminder, these two reports want to postpone the implementation of the MiFID II package until 3 January 2018, a year behind a project launched since 2011. The MiFIR regulation contained in MIFID II deals with the organisation of markets, access to the European market by third-country companies and the powers of supervisory authorities. It is therefore too serious a subject for a small pat on the head of the AEMF without questioning its incompetence, or even its dubious conciliation with regard to the big banks. Achieving the main objectives set out in the package, such as the introduction of high-frequency trading rules or increasing the transparency of financial markets, particularly derivatives markets, therefore does not seem to be a priority for the European institutions.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem raised by the report on the markets in financial instruments, market abuses and securities settlement is a concrete and acceptable one. Unfortunately, it is dealt with in an unclear way and that could leave room for future manipulation and criticality. That is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to validate the interinstitutional agreement reached in trilogue. In the context of the extension until January 2018 of the second-level regulation of MIFID (Markets in Financial Instruments Directive), some technical adjustments are introduced at the first regulatory level, in terms of qualification financing operations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the future regulation, amending the date of Entry into force of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving securities settlement in the European Union and central securities depositories by delaying it by half a year without the need for the development and implementation of the necessary IT platforms.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the draft proposal is to postpone the application of the two acts forming the Market in Financial Instruments Directive Package (MiFID II) due to the fact that the European Securities and Markets Authority, the competent national authorities and stakeholders have faced certain challenges in relation to technical implementation. These challenges are of such magnitude that basic data infrastructures will not be operational on 3 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed amendments to the regulations on the market in financial instruments, on market abuse and on improving securities settlement arrangements. Those Regulations also lay down the conduct and position of investment firms in carrying out transactions for clients. Investment firms often conduct, on their own behalf or on behalf of their clients, transactions in derivatives and other financial instruments or assets consisting of several interconnected and conditional transactions. Those bundled transactions enable investment firms and their clients to better manage risks, since the price of each element of the package transaction reflects the overall risk profile of the whole package, rather than the prevailing market price of the individual elements. Batch transactions may take different forms, such as a swap for physical assets, trading strategies performed at trading venues, or specially tailored batch jobs, and it is important to take these specificities into account when calibrating the applicable transparency regime. The proposed amendments therefore explicitly specify when pre-trade transparency should not apply to parcel transactions or to their individual elements.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The key element of these reforms is to make financial markets more stable and better monitor them, in line with the commitment to strengthen the global financial system taken during the G20 in Pittsburgh. There are no substantial changes to the proposals of two years ago, but technical amendments have been drawn up to the package which improve its provision and make its application more consistent with the regulatory framework. Of course, since these are very detailed legislative provisions, which require the collection of a huge amount of data and the use of complex technological systems, it is important that there is an agreement between the Commission, Parliament and the Council to ensure that the second-level legislation necessary to complete the regulatory framework is adopted quickly and to give operators time to adapt the IT and technical infrastructures for data collection and implementation of the new provisions. That is why I support this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to delay the implementation of the MIFID II package and the MIFIR regulation by one year to 3 January 2018. However, this directive and regulation have the following objectives: to make the use of regulated platforms mandatory for certain transactions; Introduce rules on high-frequency trading; Increase transparency and supervision of financial markets, particularly on derivatives; strengthen investor protection, all necessary and urgent measures in a context of financial insecurity. The excuses made by ESMA, in charge of the implementation of this directive, concerning the complexity of the task at hand, are not admissible, as political approvals have been obtained as early as April 2014. Either ESMA's experts are incompetent or they want to give the major international banks hostile to MFID an extra respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating of some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFIR, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFIR in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFIR by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU regulate securities markets and intermediaries with a view to improving the transparency and supervision of financial markets, as well as the conditions of competition in the trading and clearing of financial instruments. With this in mind, the new regulatory framework introduced provides for the trading venues and systematic internalizers to provide the competent authorities with reference data on financial instruments that uniformly describe the characteristics of each financial instrument falling within the scope of the regulatory framework. For the efficient and harmonised collection of data, the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority is developing, in cooperation with the competent national authorities, a financial instruments reference data system. Given the complexity of drawing up this mechanism and in order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid possible market disruption, I support the proposal to extend the time taken for the entry into force of the regulation and the directive in question.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2014/65/EU together with Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 600/2014 covers securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The role of these provisions concerns the extension of the number of financial instruments covered by the trading rules, but also aim to increase transparency and ensure supervision of financial markets in order to prevent market abuse. However, the lack of complete data, in particular those relating to reference data and those that make up the data infrastructure for transparency calculations, hinders the application of market rules. Information on transaction reporting, transparency framework, microstructural regulation is absolutely necessary in order to improve the conditions of competition in the field of trading and clearing of financial instruments.  In the context of some lacourdata and the difficulties faced by the European Securities and Markets Authority, I consider it appropriate to postpone the date of entry into force of the instruments included in MiFID II, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful analysis and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report amending these regulations, as I believe that placing limits on positions on derivatives on goods, introducing rules on high-frequency trading and introducing strict requirements on organisation and behaviour, improves the transparency of financial markets and strengthens investor protection. Investment firms often carry out, on their own initiative or on behalf of their clients, transactions in derivative contracts or activities that include several interconnected tied transactions. Such a package of transactions allows investment firms and their clients to better manage risks, since the price of each element of the package of transactions reflects the overall risk profile of the package, rather than the current market price of each element.  The package of operations can take various forms, from trading strategies performed in trading venues to tailor-made trading packages. When calibrating the applicable transparency regime, it is important to take these specificities into account. It is therefore appropriate to specify the specific circumstances in which pre-trading transparency should not apply to packages of transactions or to any individual element of such transactions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and to postpone the dates of entering into force of the directive so that the relevant authorities have more time to prepare for the enforcement of the new package. Harmonised regulations for investment services are an important issue and need to be considered carefully.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, which contains the request, which is totally inappropriate and not in the interests of the citizens of the European Union, to postpone the entry into force of the MIFD and mifir for a year. My vote against is also due to my opposition to the inclusion of the numerous exemptions for derivative contracts and other financial contracts that are dangerous to the stability of the financial system.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, following the financial crisis, the European Union adopted a new regulatory framework to regulate securities markets, regulating financial intermediation operations. This package of rules, called MIFID II, strengthens investor protection by introducing strict investor protection requirements. The legislation was supposed to enter into force on 3 January 2017, but technical difficulties in adapting electronic data collection networks through the link between trading venues, national regulatory authorities and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) suggest that the application of this new system should be postponed. I considered voting in favour of the directive because I agree that the challenges posed by the technical implementation of the reform are of such magnitude that it does not allow for the effective collection of data necessary for the operation of the system and therefore neither the competent authorities nor market operators would, in fact, be able to apply the new rules on 3 January 2017. Such a situation would lead to a situation of legal uncertainty potentially detrimental to market developments.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we consider the regulations contained therein to be important legislative acts adopted in the wake of the financial crisis for securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 600/2014 on the markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union and central securities repositories on certain dates. This is an attempt to delay the implementation of the Financial Markets Regulation by one year. As I believe that the additional delay will create additional problems and also the possibility of irregularities, I have decided to vote against.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it was important to vote in favour of the measure since Regulation (EU) No. 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU lay down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data communication service providers, harmonise the system of limits on commodity derivatives, in order to improve transparency, promote orderly price formation conditions and prevent market abuse, and improve the supervision of financial markets through the harmonisation of administrative sanctions. Investment firms often carry out, on their own initiative or on behalf of their clients, transactions in derivative contracts and other financial instruments or activities that include several interconnected tied transactions. Such a package transactions package allows investment firms and their clients to better manage risks, since the price of each item in the package reflects the overall risk profile of the package, rather than the current market price of each item. It is therefore appropriate to specify for the purposes of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 the specific circumstances in which pre-trading transparency should not apply to either packages of transactions or any single element of such transactions.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 When it comes to sensitive sectors such as finance, where transparency plays a key role and errors have enormous costs, prudence is a must. In this particular case, I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because, given the current state of technology, it makes perfect sense to wait a few months for a secure computer system instead of completing everything quickly and risking on the skin of savers.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process. The solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated, but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the Regulation on the markets in financial instruments, because it introduces a new regulatory framework that will become effective with the creation of data collection infrastructures. The Regulation ensures greater transparency of financial instruments by providing for the trading venues and systematic internalizers to provide the competent authorities with reference data on financial instruments that uniformly describe the characteristics of each financial instrument falling within the scope of the regulatory framework.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is financial legislation adopted in the wake of the financial crisis as regards securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. I agree with a new framework which harmonises a position-limits regime for commodity derivatives to improve transparency, support orderly pricing and prevent market abuse. The introduction of rules on high-frequency trading and the improvement of oversight of financial markets by harmonising administrative sanctions is a step in the right direction by building on the rules already in place to strengthen the protection of investors towards a robust conduct requirement which transmits accountability.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution because changing the transposition date is essential and urgent for the European Authority ESMA and the national authorities to be put in a position to complete the construction of data collection infrastructures, avoiding the risks of market disruption and improving the competitiveness of financial markets. However, I believe that in future we should be more careful and cautious in setting the time targets for the entry into force of the regulations, because postponing a transposition date could have a negative impact on the guarantee of legal certainty, all the more so in a sensitive and well-monitored sector, such as the markets for financial instruments. Investors and savers need to find a healthy financial environment, free from uncertainties in which to develop their potential. At the same time, the Member States must be in a position to transpose the directives in a linear manner, without additional costs and procedural uncertainties. It is up to us co-legislators to ensure these certainties, putting the Commission services in the best position to do their best.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new framework established by Regulation 600/2014/EU and Directive 2014/65/EU requires trading venues and regular exchange-traded venues to provide the competent authorities with reference financial instruments that describe in a uniform manner the characteristics of each financial instrument within the scope of that Directive. In order to collect data in an efficient and harmonised manner, work is on the development of new infrastructure. The data infrastructure deployment process involves five stages: business requirements, specifications, development, testing, and deployment. ESMA estimates that these steps should be completed by January 2018, provided that the In the light of these exceptional circumstances and in order to allow ESMA, national competition authorities and stakeholders to complete their obligations, the date of application of Regulation 600/2014 should be 12 months, i.e. until 3 January 2018. I believe that, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid possible market distortions, it is necessary to extend this deferral to the application of the entire framework, including all delegated and implementing acts. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote to provide harmonised regulation for investment services across the EU. The directive's main objectives are to increase competition and consumer protection in investment services. In April 2014, the European Parliament approved both MiFID II, an updated version of the original MiFID law, and MiFID II's accompanying regulation, MiFIR.  Both MiFID II and MiFIR and must generally apply within Member States by 3 January 2017. However, in February 2016 the European Commission formally proposed delayed the implementation date by a year. The new deadline is January 2018. The extension allows for the building of complex IT systems to enable enforcement of the new package.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s position to extend the date of application of transposition of the the MiFD II package  by Member States. This is because, due to technical implementation challenges met by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), national competent authorities (NCAs) and stakeholders, it would be impossible to ensure full transposition by 3 January 2017.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement reached in trilogue, which extends the existing legislation developed in the financial crisis to support key financial instruments and also tackles the issue of market abuses potentially distorting the market. Supporting free, safe markets and reducing regulations wherever possible is vital for a long-term prosperous financial sector both in the UK and across Europe.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that making data collection at European level more efficient from trading venues and independent operators, as well as harmonising procedures, will enable the development of a new data collection infrastructure, which will contribute to the establishment of a reference data system on financial instruments.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on the decision to postpone the effective dates of regulations on financial instrument markets due to the delay in implementing implementation measures on market abuses and securities regulations. Considering that this report makes no substantive changes, and that this postponement is necessary for the proper establishment of market abuse regulations in financial instrument markets, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Commission's proposal to amend regulation on financial instrument markets, market abuses and securities regulation. The report specifies the circumstances under which pre-negotiation transparency would not apply to transaction packages, nor to any element of this individual package.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the draft proposal is to postpone the application of the two acts constituting the MiFID II package, given that the European Securities and Markets Authority, the competent national authorities and stakeholders have faced certain challenges in relation to technical implementation. These challenges are of such magnitude that basic data infrastructures will not be operational on 3 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The aim of the draft proposal is to postpone the application of the two acts constituting the MiFID II package, given that the European Securities and Markets Authority, the competent national authorities and stakeholders have faced certain challenges in relation to technical implementation. These challenges are of such magnitude that basic data infrastructures will not be operational on 3 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against extending the deadline for the application of the regulations contained in the MIFID II package by one year. The latter makes it mandatory to use regulated platforms for certain transactions, introduces rules on high-frequency trading, and increases transparency and supervision of financial markets. It strengthens investor protection by setting strict requirements for organisation and good conduct. The delay is due to the procrastination of market participants and ESMA's inability to produce the Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) needed to develop regulations on time. However, the project has been under development since 2011 and political approvals have been obtained since 2014.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I fully agree with the proposed actions in this report and supported it. It is crucial to be careful when it comes to new framework proposals for new data collection infrastructures. Legal certainty and expediency are a top priority and it would be careless of us, as co-legislators of this framework, not to take into account the duty of care we have towards European markets, especially consumers, if we had rushed this report and therefore with the timetables. I therefore fully support the proposal to postpone the time limits and the application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 by 12 months.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of large banking giants and governments, in order to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this directive, but welcome the Commission’s proposal to postpone implementation. The exemptions listed are potentially harmful, and driven by financial intermediates’ demands. My constituents in Wales deserve transparency on financial markets, whilst this directive proposes to narrow the scope.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The date of application of the Regulation has been postponed by 30 months from the date of entry into force. Despite this unusually long period, stakeholders are not in a position to ensure that the necessary data infrastructures are set up and operational by 3 January 2017. This is due to the quantity and complexity of the data to be collected and processed in order for the new framework to become operational, in particular with regard to the reporting of transactions, transparency calculations and reporting of positions relating to commodity derivatives. I agree with the proposed amendments so that the Regulation can be effectively safeguarded.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I vote against: under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to MIFID an extra respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report and the accompanying one refer to proposals for a Directive to amend the Directive on markets in financial instruments and associated regulations, with only the aim of amending specific dates of the basic legislation. We maintain the criticism so we have made in due course of the basic acts and which led us to vote against them. These changes do not touch the substance, which is the very existence of these markets and their instruments. They keep untouchable the "financialization" of the economy and all productive activity as its hostage, as a central part of the EU's development strategy, always seeking to meet the profit rates of large economic and financial groups, which the production of real goods and services could not and cannot satisfy. This is the instrument that is part of this strategy, which is inseparable from the existence of tax havens, the increasing crushing of public expenditure and investment, privatisation and the liberalisation of public services and companies essential to economic and social development. For these reasons, I vote against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is appropriate to extend the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets and financial instruments, as well as the extension of the application of the entire sector regulatory framework, as, by express indication of ESMA, the infrastructure designed for the efficient and harmonised collection of reference data of financial instruments cannot be completed before January 2018. The extension ensures legal certainty and avoids potential market distortions.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because apart from the new implementation dates I disagree with the changes to MIFIR.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because I am sceptical about the application of supervisory instruments that have proved insufficient to prevent speculation and dominant positions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of major banking giants and governments to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares. The European Securities and Markets Authority must first and foremost enforce transparency rules and best rules for the execution of transactions. More importantly, however, a sanctions framework must be established for those who use unfair means, even misinformation, resulting in market distortions and the losing of money for private investors.   For the above reasons I am voting against the report on the markets in financial instruments, market abuse and securities settlement.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The MiFID/R overall legislative package is enormous, and is accompanied by a vast array of secondary legislation, which has been developed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Commission over the last two years. After seeking reassurances that this is the minimum delay necessary, and that it really is unavoidable, I agree with the proposed one-off delay. I also agree that the Directive shall not apply to persons dealing on own account in financial instruments other than commodity derivatives or emission allowances or derivatives. Moreover, for the purpose of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, I believe there are specific circumstances in which pre-trade transparency should not apply to package transactions, nor to any individual component of such transactions. Investment firms often execute, on their own account or on behalf of their clients, transactions in derivatives and other financial instruments or assets that comprise a number of interlinked, contingent trades. I agree that such package transactions enable investment firms and their clients to better manage their risks.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the draft proposal is to postpone the application of the two acts constituting the MiFID II package, given that the European Securities and Markets Authority, the competent national authorities and stakeholders have faced certain challenges in relation to technical implementation. These challenges are of such magnitude that basic data infrastructures will not be operational on 3 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report to promote transparency, orderly price formation and prevent market abuse. It also introduces rules on high-frequency trading and improves financial market supervision by harmonizing administrative sanctions. Building on the rules already in place, the new framework also strengthens investor protection by introducing rigorous organizational and behaviour requirements for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on markets in financial services, market abuse and securities deliveries and settlements. This report postpones the entry into force of the so-called MiFID II directive by one year, giving us more time to do everything we can to step up the fight against the avoidance and evasion of taxes by trickery by large corporations. This is an important contribution to full tax justice for families and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. With the help of MiFID II, financial markets are to become safer and stronger. This should help financial markets to contribute even more to growth and employment. For investment firms and trading venues, this means that new and stricter transparency standards apply.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. Therefore, it is fair that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this must be the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. Therefore, it is fair that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this must be the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. It harmonises the position limits regime for commodity derivatives to improve transparency, to support orderly pricing and to prevent market abuse. It also introduces rules on high-frequency algorithmic trading and improves the oversight of financial markets by harmonising administrative sanctions.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we disagreed with the 'MiFID' Directive and the 'MiFIR' Regulation, which supposedly answered the crisis by changing rules on financial instrument markets, market abuse and securities settlement. In keeping with this position, we also voted against the changes being promoted in the tripartite dialogue between Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving securities settlement in the European Union and on central securities depositories as regards certain dates. These regulations are major pieces of financial legislation that were adopted in the wake of the financial crisis as regards securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. They establish requirements in relation to authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting services providers. In order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market disruption, it is necessary to take urgent action to defer the entry into application of the whole framework, including all delegated and implementing acts by 12 months until 3 January 2018.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal as the delay will allow for a more compressive package to be enforced due to the creation of a more complex accompanying IT system

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The points that were voted concerned certain technical fixes on the treatment of package transactions, on the requirements for certain non-financial firms, and on the treatment of Securities Financing Transactions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for an EP-Council regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013. 600/2014 on markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 100/2014 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the EU and on central securities depositors on certain dates, as as such, Regulation (EU) 909/2014 of the EP and the Council contains references to the date on which the Regulation (EU) no. 909/2014 of the Ep and the Council began. 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU.  As with the vote for the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on financial instrument markets on specific dates, it is that unfortunately all the preconditions necessary for the quality application of the new financial instrument market legislation are not ready. Therefore, the application should be postponed and quality documents should be made that will allow for more transparency, more security for consumers, more cooperation between national regulatory authorities and prevent as much abuse and harmful manipulation as possible.  I hope that the Commission will seriously prepare the application of this document and above all ESMA will introduce a quality system of collecting, using and reporting the necessary financial information. I hope that this delay in terms of deadlines will be respected and will not lead to the "weakening" of the legislative document.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The MIFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. To achieve the objectives of the package, it is the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from some 300 trading platforms. ESMA must thereby work closely with the relevant national authorities and the negotiating platforms themselves.  However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017, when the MIFID II package was initially due to come into force. The project has been under development since 2011 and since April 2014 political approvals have been obtained. I have therefore objected to this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the EU institutions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the organisation of financial markets, which aims in particular to tackle the shadowy areas of the rapidly developing over-the-counter markets. The main objective of the two Ferber reports is to extend the implementation date of the new directive to January 2018 due to the exceptional complexity of the rules to be applied.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report covers the licensing and management requirements of investment firms, market regulation and related data provision services. As it is not possible to ensure that the necessary data infrastructures will be in place and operational by 3 January 2017 in order to create the necessary legal certainty and prevent potential market disruptions, the start of the entire legal framework will be postponed by 12 months. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
