text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the draft proposal is to postpone the application of the two acts constituting the MiFID II package, given that the European Securities and Markets Authority, the competent national authorities and stakeholders have faced certain challenges in relation to technical implementation. These challenges are of such magnitude that basic data infrastructures will not be operational on 3 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to have a sufficiently clear legal situation by mid-2016 with respect to the final requirements laid down in the regulatory technical standards concerned.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objectives of the directive are the possibility of increasing competition and consumer protection in investment services. These are important principles, especially in times of serious crisis, and we are therefore in favour of the negotiations being conducted quickly, in order to give concrete answers and avoid market abuses.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it proposes to delay the implementation of the Financial Instruments Markets Directive, MIFID, voted in 2014, by one year. However, I am opposed to this additional delay because the delay is more due to a complacency of the European Markets Authority (ESMA) and the procrastination of the players in the financial markets than to an obvious and predictable technical complexity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on financial instrument markets, market abuse and securities regulation. The text proposes to delay the implementation of the regulation on financial instrument markets, MIFIR, voted in 2014, by one year. This proposal is motivated by the fact that the competent authorities and market players would not have the information and control systems, personnel and procedures necessary to implement the regulation by January 2017. This delay is due more to a complacency by the European Markets Authority (ESMA) and to the procrastination of financial market players than to obvious and predictable technical complexity. In addition, these regulations have been in the works since 2011 to address the problems uncovered by the 2008 financial crisis. Therefore, I do not want to tolerate another year being added to the 10-year delay in financial product regulation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The financial crisis of 2008 weakened the real estate market, investment firms and intermediaries. To address this problem and promote better regulation, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has instituted a legislative package entitled MIFID II, consisting of two projects: a directive called MIFID and a regulation, MIFIR. The package provides practical solutions such as the introduction of high-frequency trading rules or the requirement to use regulated platforms for certain transactions. However, the project, which has been under development since 2011, has significant delays due to foreseeable difficulties from its inception. The inability of market agents to provide information is the main cause, which is unacceptable. The report proposes to grant a one-year reprieve from the implementation of the MIFID II package, and thus to ignore this unjustifiable fact. I cannot accept it and vote against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of the Member States, which have completely deregulated the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. This amendment to the Directive postpones the effectiveness of financial market regulation until 3 January 2018. The Commission is asking for time to be able to prepare the infrastructure for processing all the data it wants financial institutions to process. Overall, I am against the new regulations introduced by the Financial Markets Directive 2014/65. I consider the agreement to postpone the validity as a chance to reject the directive in its overall form.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The regulated market for financial instruments is based on mutual trust of all participants from investment firms, investors, publishers and other intermediaries on the market. Therefore, one of the priorities is to prevent any form of market abuse. Preventing market abuse entails actions to prohibit and prevent the use, referral and disclosure of inside information. This includes preventing and prohibiting manipulative acts by the financial market. On the basis of the arguments put forward, I supported the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 600/2014 on markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 100/2014 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union and on central securities depositors on specific dates.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of this vote, three regulations were amended (on markets in financial instruments : 600/2014, on market abuse – No 596/2014 and on improving securities settlement in the European Union and central securities depositories – No 909/2014). The amendments initially included new [later] dates under which the new legislation would enter into force. In view of what has been said in this and the previous report and what has been said, I agree that there is indeed a need for the subsequent deadlines for the entry into force of the renewed regulation so that all relevant actors can fully adapt to the new rules. Consequently, in particular, recalling the potential consequences of abuse of the market and the rather fresh examples of memorable in Europe and other parts of the world, I voted positively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 600/2014 on the markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union and central securities repositories, on certain dates, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this Report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This is the same request for a one-year extension of the application period for the regulations contained in the MIFID II package.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on the improvement of securities regulation in the European Union and central securities depositors, with regard to certain dates. Given the complexity of the new regulatory framework and the need for a particularly large number of delegated and implementing acts, this date shift is necessary. Therefore, given the exceptional circumstances, in order to allow ESMA, the competent national authorities and interested parties to complete operational implementation, I am in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is once again a question of the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. However, the data infrastructure will not be completed until early 2017. As with A8—0126/2016, I am voting in favour of postponing the date of application by 12 months.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Commission's proposal to delay the date of entry into force of the Regulation on improving securities settlement in the European Union and central securities depositories, given that the necessary IT platforms have not been prepared and implemented in the Member States.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The MIFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. ESMA is responsible for collecting data in collaboration with national authorities and trading platforms. However, ESMA is slow to develop the RTS and market participants are slow to provide the requested information. We therefore oppose this unjustifiable extension in the context of current financial instability, evidence of the weakness of the power of the Union's institutions. As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal as it sets out needed reforms to existing legislation on market abuse and securities settlement.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The absence of data collection infrastructures has implications for the whole scope of Regulation 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU. Without data, it will not be possible to establish a precise definition of financial instruments falling within the scope of the new framework. Furthermore, it will not be possible to adapt the rules on pre- and post-trade transparency to determine which instruments are liquidating and when a derogation or deferment of publication should be granted. Trading venues and investment firms shall not be able to report transactions carried out to the competent authorities in the absence of data. As a result of not reporting positions for commodity derivatives, it will be difficult to enforce the restriction of positions to those contracts. If position reporting does not occur, the capacity to effectively detect breaches of position limitations is limited. In the absence of data collection infrastructures, it will also be more difficult for investment firms to apply the rules for executing the order in the best way. Trading venues and systematic internalisers will not be able to publish data on the quality of transaction performance at those trading venues. Investment firms will not be provided with important performance data to help them determine the best way to execute client orders. In order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid potential market distortions, it is necessary and justified to take urgent measures to postpone the application of the whole framework, including all delegated and implementing acts. I agree with the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported this report to extend the date of application of transposition of the MiFD II package by Member States. This is because, due to technical implementation challenges met by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), national competent authorities (NCAs) and stakeholders, it would be impossible to ensure full transposition by 3 January 2017. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving securities settlement and depositories in the European Union for certain dates. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament support the Commission's proposal with a few amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In February 2016, the Commission proposed to extend the MIFID II deadline by one year to carry it back to 3 January 2018. This package consists of a directive (MiFID) and a regulation (MiFIR). The MiFID II Directive regulates the activities of investment firms, sets out investor protection rules and enacts minimum sanctions requirements. The MiFIR Regulation deals with the organisation of markets, access to the European market by companies from third countries and the powers of supervisory authorities. The MiFID package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. We therefore oppose this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the Union's institutions. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Investment firms often execute, on their own account or on behalf of their clients, transactions of derivatives and other financial instruments or assets that include a set of interconnected and conditional transactions. I vote in favour of this report, which aims at greater aggregation of data. In the absence of data, trading platforms and investment firms may not communicate transactions to the competent authorities. In the absence of communication of positions relating to commodity derivatives, it will be very difficult to impose limits on positions in commodity derivative contracts. Without communication of positions, the ability to effectively detect violations of position limits will be limited.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to the MIFID package an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report amends certain dates of regulations relating to financial instruments, market abuses and the improvement of securities regulation in the European Union. This report does not touch on the substance of all the texts it amends. That is why I voted for it.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend certain dates of the Regulation on markets for financial instruments, market abuses and improving securities settlement within the EU. The dates need to be amending in order for the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to establish a system of reference data for financial instruments. This is necessary for the purpose of effective data collection. The basics of this system are new IT systems that will be built on the basis of new parameters. In view of the exceptional circumstances and in order to ensure that ESMA and the competent authorities can complete operational implementation, it is recommended that the application of the Regulation be postponed until one year later, i.e. January 2018.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EU Regulation No 600/2014 alongside Directive 2014/65/EU have both been adopted at the start of the financial crisis by the European Council and European Parliament as an important part of financial legislation. I support this report that aims to put in place a new framework that will improve transparency and support orderly pricing through a market abuse and security settlement.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which aims to amend a directive regulating of some of the financial instruments that contributed to the global financial crisis. The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) and the Regulation on Markets in Financial Instruments (MiFIR) were adopted in the aftermath of the crisis. MiFID and MiFIR (collectively referred to as MiFID II) cover securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. The initial intention of this directive was to ‘quick fix’ the date of entry into application of MiFIR, which is scheduled to be applied in January 2017 after Member States transpose it by July 2016. But a number of Delegated Acts have been delayed and the Commission has proposed to postpone the application date by one year, until January 2018. While I understand the reasons for the postponement, the finance lobby, backed by Conservative MEPs and the Council, have tried to use the delay to revisit the content of the MiFIR in order to water down regulation of financial instruments. I oppose any further changes to the text of MiFIR by the European Parliament and the Council because deregulation of these instruments is exactly what caused the financial crisis.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report sets out the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. Since only an operational data infrastructure can guarantee the desired legal certainty and the prevention of market disruptions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to ensure legal certainty and to avoid possible market disruption, it is necessary to postpone the deadline for the application of the entire framework.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process, the solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to extend the date of application of Regulations (EU) 600/2014, (EU) 596/2014 and (EU) 909/2014 because, despite the current rule granting 30 months for the application of Regulation (EU) 600/2014 to enable interested parties to equip themselves with the necessary data infrastructure, the complexity of the data in question does not allow Member States to meet the deadlines. Given the importance of this information, I agree with my colleague's proposal for a change in the dates previously set. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of the draft proposal to amend the Markets in Financial Instruments Regulation is to extend the start date for both instruments that make up the MiFID II package, due to technical implementation challenges. I believe that ESMA, NCAs and stakeholders should be allowed to complete operational implementation and therefore it is appropriate to postpone the start date of application of the Regulation by 12 months until 3 January 2018.  I believe that the extension will allow for a sufficient and reasonable period for the establishment of infrastructure for data collection, reporting and calculation of transparency thresholds. I note that the time limits for the start of the Markets regulation of financial instruments and the Financial Instruments Market Directive should be taken into account and the Market Abuse Regulation and the Regulation on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union should be adjusted accordingly.  This report on the proposal for a regulation also specifies specific circumstances concerning trading transparency and risk management, is well designed and adopted by the committee responsible almost unanimously. For all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to the MIFID package an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulation. I therefore vote against this scandalous text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒In 2012, taking into account the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council, and the report of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee, the European Parliament adopted a report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 600/2014 on markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 100/2014 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 909/2014 on improving the settlement of securities in the European Union and on central securities depositors on specific dates.  I welcome the European Parliament's decision, as MiFID II will increase the number of financial instruments covered by trading rules and ensure that trading takes place on regulated platforms. High-frequency trading rules will also be in place. Transparency and supervision of financial markets, including derivatives markets, will be improved and volatility in commodity derivatives prices will be addressed.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Directive 2014/65/EU is one of the most important parts of financial legislation adopted in light of the financial crisis introducing clearer rules on securities markets and rules for investment intermediaries. In order to improve transparency, the regime of restriction of positions in commodity derivatives, support for proper pricing and prevention of market abuse is being agreed. High-frequency trading rules are also introduced and market surveillance is improved. The Directive prescribes markets and systematic internalisers to provide competent authorities with information on financial instruments that uniquely describe the characteristics of each financial instrument. To this end, the European Supervisory Authority (ESMA) and the competent national authorities are obliged to establish a system of reference data on financial instruments. The measures transposing this Directive into national law are obliged to be applied by Member States from 3 January 2017.  However, due to the volume and complexity of the data to be collected and processed, ESMA realized at the end of last year that the industry would not be able to complete the necessary systems for the new reporting rules, so it proposed changes to the deadlines. I supported Representative Ferber's report to ensure legal certainty and avoid market distortions. I emphasise that the proposed measures are aimed at protecting citizens investing in securities by introducing strict organisational and business conduct requirements.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on the markets for financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving the securities regulation in the European Union. In order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market disruptions, urgent action is needed to extend the date of application of the entire regulatory framework, including all delegated and implementing acts. The extension will be 12 months, thus moving the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 to 3 January 2018.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on financial instrument markets, market abuse and securities regulation, in line with the text of technical changes in the entry into force of the directive to improve the efficiency and transparency of financial markets (MiFID 2).

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has demanded more information from financial services firms than it can process, the solution is not a delay to make the IT systems ever more complicated but to reduce the information burden on industry.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Text amendment only with a view to postponing the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 for 12 months until 3 January 2018.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the proposed amending regulation, with regard to certain dates, Regulation (EU) 600/2014 on financial instrument markets, Regulation (EU) 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) 909/2014 on improving the regulation of securities in the EU and central custodians of securities.  Investment firms often conduct transactions on their own or their clients' behalf on behalf of their clients involving derivatives or other financial instruments or assets that include a set of related or subordinated transactions. These transaction packages allow investment firms and their clients to better manage risk, with the price of each item in the package reflecting the overall risk profile of the package instead of the current market price for each item. I thought it was important to point that out.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The document in question is one of the more important issues in this session. The recent financial crisis and the various speculations it has seen have long led to the introduction of proper regulation of the financial transaction sector. The proposed amendments impose requirements on trading venues and systematically provide internalisers with basic data on transactions executed to the competent authorities.  Those data are also used for other purposes, such as the calculation of transparency and liquidity thresholds and reporting of positions in commodity derivatives, and I hope will contribute to reducing abuses, which should lead to the stability of markets.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, like the previous one, concerns the need to extend the deadline for the application of a Regulation – in the specific case of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets for financial instruments for a period of twelve months (until 3 January 2018), as well as other additional reports and analyses, looking at the need to complete operational applications for the creation of data collection infrastructure. Only through this new reference data system for financial instruments, which will be created from scratch, will it be possible, inter alia, to carry out transactions such as transaction reporting, transparency calculations and reporting of positions relating to commodity derivatives.  That is why I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulations and the directive that are to be amended through the proposal put forward by Mr Ferber are key elements of the legislation adopted following the financial crisis and with regard to securities markets, securities brokers and trading venues. This new regulatory framework is very complex, so much so that it originally provided for a very long deadline for its application, equal to 30 months from the date of entry into force of the regulation. However, the complexity of this new regulatory framework means that data collection and processing infrastructures will not be able to be operational by January 2017, as originally planned. For this reason, I voted in favour of the proposal to extend the date of implementation of the entire regulatory framework, including all delegated acts. I believe that this new regulatory framework, although very complex, represents an important milestone in the investment sector. The framework provides for measures, such as package transactions, which allows investment firms and their clients to better manage risks, since the price of each element of the package reflects the overall risk of the package and not the market price of each element.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, mainly because it approves the delay, for one year, of its implementation, which will not be effective until 2018. This delay in its implementation is not coincidental and is in line with the interests of the sector. Despite the complexities created by the financial sector, with the collusion of Member States that have completely deregulate the financial sector, political will is necessary to end the opaque and speculative practices prevailing in the sector. The delay of one year in the implementation of this Directive will allow the main financial institutions to continue operating in the opaque universe of speculative transactions to which they are accustomed, without having to abide by any regulation. These speculative activities have resulted in the explosion of the crisis europe has faced since 2008 and, in order to tackle it, these practices need to be put to an end. Because approving this delay sinks the credibility of this institution, which claims to try to put solutions to the crisis, that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure effective enforcement of laws and at the same time to avoid potential market disruptions, this proposal for a regulation suggests extending by 12 months, to 3 January 2018, the date of application of Regulation 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on financial instruments and market abuse. In order to prevent malfunctions in the collection of data by the competent authorities, I have decided to vote in favour of extending the entire regulatory framework.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I agree that, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market distortions, urgent measures need to be taken to delay the application of the new legal framework in its entirety, including all delegated and implementing acts adopted on the basis the same thing.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulations on markets in financial instruments, on market abuse and on improving the settlement of securities transactions of 2014 are part of the key legislative measures adopted by the EU in the wake of the financial crisis. These are the main financial regulations concerning securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. Together with another Directive, they lay down requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers. They also introduce rules on high-frequency trading and improve the supervision of financial markets by harmonising administrative sanctions. This new regulatory framework was developed by the Commission together with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), which was only established in 2010, and these legislative texts were its first major task. The whole new control system was due to be operational on 3 January 2017, but in recent years it has become clear that neither ESMA nor the national authorities have managed to set up the necessary IT systems. As the main aim of this proposal is to extend the implementation period of individual measures for 2018 one time, I have decided to support it. Both Parliament and the Council have been assured that one year is the necessary time to fine-tune the systems. However, I hope that there will be no further postponement in the future.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The misuse of financial mechanisms to cover up illegal transactions must be monitored and severely punished.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In order to uniquely describe the characteristics of each financial instrument to which Directive 2014/65/EU applies, it is necessary for trading venues and systematic internalizers to provide reference information on financial instruments to the competent authorities. This data is also useful and serves other purposes, such as reporting positions in commodity derivatives, calculating liquidity thresholds and transparency, etc.  The volume and complexity of the data to be collected and processed in order for the new framework to become operational, in particular as regards transparency calculations or transaction reporting, is why trading platforms, ESMA (European Securities and Markets Authority) and NCAs did not allow the necessary data infrastructure to be in place by 3 January 2017.  The new framework, namely the new data collection infrastructure, will bring together a wide range of financial instruments covering the scope of the Regulation, as well as data from NCAs, trading venues from across the Union and ESMA data. Position constraints will be difficult to apply without reporting positions in commodity derivatives, just as competent authorities will not be able to report transactions made without trading venue data. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending MiFID II and MiFIR because it is clear that the significant IT infrastructure needed to implement these wide-ranging reforms will not be ready in time to meet the original 2017 deadline. It is therefore right that the competent authorities have another year in order to prepare. However, this is the one and only time that this legislation will be delayed. The reforms introduced by MiFID II and MiFIR are vital for stabilising our financial system following the crisis, and it is important that they come into effect as soon as they possibly can.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In light of the financial crisis, Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council, as well as Regulation (EU) No 2014/65/EU 600/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, are considered to be the most important parts of financial legislation concerning securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues. However, given the complexity of the new framework and the need for a large number of delegated and implementing acts, the date on which the Regulation (EU) No 2007/2013 began. 600/2014 has been postponed by 30 months from the date of entry into force. Stakeholders are unable to ensure that the necessary data infrastructure is in place and operational by 3 January 2017 due to the complexity of the data to be collected and processed to make the new framework operational. The lack of data collection infrastructure will make it difficult for investment firms to apply the best execution rules. Parliament considers it appropriate to postpone the start date of application of Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 600/2014 for 12 months, until 3 January 2018. I support the proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 600/2014 on the markets of financial instruments of the European Parliament and the Council, as I consider that the new framework strengthens investor protection due to the introduction of stricter requirements in organisation and business conduct.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on markets in financial instruments, the Regulation on market abuse and the Regulation on improving securities settlement arrangements in the European Union and on central securities securities companies as regards certain dates.  I support the postponement of the application of the Regulation on markets in financial instruments for one year, as this will enable the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and other stakeholders to complete the operational implementation. ESMA considers that the implementation of a data collection infrastructure covering the requirements for the pursuit of activities, specifications, development, testing and use should be completed by the beginning of 2018.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we disagreed with Directive 2014/65/EU ('MiFID') and Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 600/2014 ('MiFIR'), which supposedly gave a response to the crisis by changing rules on financial instruments markets, market abuse, and securities settlement. By holding this position we have also voted against the changes being promoted in the tripartite dialogue between Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Investment service providers, regulated markets and data reporting service providers operate under specific rules and outside the framework of any concerted practice. They often act as a crutch of large banking giants and governments, in order to raise money for citizens who are not depositors. A tragic example is the Simitis government and the scandal of the Athens Stock Exchange, when thousands of citizens, seduced by a climate of euphoria created by the then government with lies and false hopes, invested their efforts in ghost companies and bubble shares. The European Securities and Markets Authority must first and foremost enforce transparency rules and best rules for the execution of transactions. More importantly, however, a sanctions framework must be established for those who use unfair means, even misinformation, resulting in market distortions and the losing of money for private investors.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, which, in addition to advising the Member States to postpone the application of the measures implementing Directive 2014/65/EU and the repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC 12 months later until 3 January 2018 due to a lack of technical conditions, also proposes to amend Regulations (EU) No 596/2014 and (EU) No 909/2014.  Regulations (EU) No 596/2014 and (EU) No 909/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council contain references to the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU. Thus, in order to ensure legal certainty, in agreement with the Recommendation, I believe that it is appropriate to amend the above Regulations in such a way as to refer to Directive 2004/39/EC until Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU become deferred.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendments to this proposal. Investment firms often conduct transactions on their own or their clients' behalf on behalf of their clients involving derivatives or other financial instruments or assets that include a set of related or subordinated transactions. These transaction packages allow investment firms and their clients to better manage risk, with the price of each item in the package reflecting the overall risk profile of the package instead of the current market price for each item. Transaction packages can take different forms, such as cash instrument exchange (EFP), trading strategies on trading platforms, or custom trading packages, and it is important to consider their different characteristics for calibrating the applicable transparency regime. It should therefore be clarified, for the purposes of Regulation (EU) 600/2014, the specific circumstances in which pre-negotiation transparency would not apply to transaction packages or to any of their individual elements.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Package transactions enable investment firms and their clients to better manage their risks, with the price of each component of the package transaction reflecting the overall risk profile of the package rather than the prevailing market price of each component. I voted in favour of deferring the implementation of the specific circumstances in which pre-trade transparency should not apply to package transactions, nor to any individual component of such transactions. While I am fully supportive of transparency measures in the financial sector, package transactions can take various forms, and it is important to consider those specificities when applying the transparency regime.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a proposal to amend the Financial Instruments Markets Regulation, which lays down requirements related to the approval and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting service providers. In addition to Directive 2014/65/EU, this Regulation is the most important part of financial legislation adopted in light of the financial crisis in relation to securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues.  With a view to collecting data in a new and efficient manner, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the NCAs are obliged to establish a system of reference data on financial instruments. The process of establishing infrastructure includes five steps: business requirements, specifications, development, testing and commissioning. According to ESMA estimates, these steps should be completed by January 2018, provided that legal certainty is in place by June 2016 at the latest as regards final requirements under regulatory technical requirements.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 1303/2014 I supported Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as the main financial legislation relating to securities markets, investment intermediaries and trading venues adopted as a result of the financial crisis. They lay down requirements concerning authorisations for investment firms and their activities, regulated markets and data communication service providers. They shall coordinate the position limits regime for commodity derivatives in order to improve transparency, support proper pricing and prevent market abuse. They also introduce rules on high frequency trading and improve the supervision of financial markets by coordinating administrative sanctions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my support to this text, as it is my belief that we have to keep going forward in building a financial regulatory framework that avoids (or minimises) new crises.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The MIFIR package was presented in response to the financial crisis in order to better regulate securities markets, investment firms and intermediaries. To achieve its objectives, it is the responsibility of the European Securities and Markets Authority to collect data on some 15 million financial instruments from some 300 trading platforms. However, it informed in 2015 that neither the relevant authorities nor market participants would have the necessary systems for 3 January 2017, when the legislative package was originally due to come into force. The cause of the delay is mainly due to the procrastination of market players to provide information and put in place the control tools, and the inability of ESMA. We therefore oppose this extension, which is unjustifiable in the context of current financial instability and is evidence of the weakness of the power of the Union's institutions. Under the pretext of obvious technical complexity from the outset of the project, the Commission's request proves either that ESMA is not competent to establish serious financial regulation, or that it gives the major international banks that are reluctant to the MIFIR package an additional respite to continue to take advantage of the shortcomings of the current regulations.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The financial crisis that began in 2007 showed inefficient control of the financial sector. The lack of adequate regulations and regulations has caused enormous perturbations in the financial market. Provision should therefore be made to effectively limit the possibility of a repeat of a similar situation in the future. I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal to amend the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of data collection infrastructure also makes it difficult for investment firms to apply the best performance rules. Trading venues and systematic internalisers will not be able to publish data on the quality of execution of transactions on those venues. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The initial intention of this vote was to postpone the implementation of the MiFid2 directive within one year. However, large groups have taken advantage of this circumstance to introduce changes that point to the sense of further deregulation. I voted against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The trilogue result is unacceptable on procedural and content grounds so voted against the report but in favour of the Commission’s proposal, which was merely to postpone implementation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving securities settlement in the European Union and on central securities depositories as regards certain dates. Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 and Directive 2014/65/EU establish requirements in relation to authorisation and operation of investment firms, regulated markets and data reporting services providers. In addition, the new framework harmonises a position-limits regime for commodity derivatives to improve transparency, support orderly pricing and prevent market abuse. However, the absence of data collection infrastructures will also make it difficult for investment firms to apply best-execution rules. I believe that, in order to ensure legal certainty and avoid potential market disruption, it is necessary and justified to take urgent action to defer the entry into application of the whole framework, including all delegated and implementing acts.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a technical report with the aim of extending the entry into force of MIFID and MiFIR from 3 January 2017 to 3 January 2018, since ESMA and the European Commission did not provide the technical regulatory standards and delegated acts within the deadline set by the legislation.  In addition, this report provided a good opportunity to present a further amendment to the MIFID/MiFIR text. In fact, some exemptions from transparency requirements for high-frequency trading (HFT) have been proposed through amendments co-signed across the board by various political parties (S&D, PPE and ALDE). Firstly, it seems to us unreasonable to extend it by one year because it is essentially due to the inefficiency of the EU institutions in producing second-level acts. Secondly, we strongly opposed the inclusion of exemptions for HFT contracts because of their high risk, as this could undermine the security of the financial system. That is why we voted against it in plenary.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This legislative resolution is closely linked to the Ferber report on which we voted earlier today. In the interests of legal certainty, I have also voted positively here.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 These amendments do not alter the essential question, which is the very existence of these markets and their instruments. They keep untouchable the "financialization" of the economy and all productive activity as its hostage, as a central part of the EU's development strategy, always seeking to meet the profit rates of large economic and financial groups, which the production of real goods and services could not and cannot satisfy. This is the instrument that includes this instrument, which is inseparable from the existence of tax havens, the growing contraction of public expenditure and investment, the privatisation and liberalisation of public services and companies essential for economic and social development.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the requirements for the authorisation and operation of investment firms in the context of regulated markets and data provision services. As a sufficient data infrastructure is not expected to be operational until the beginning of January 2017, the start of application is to be postponed by 12 months. Since only an operational data infrastructure can guarantee the desired legal certainty and the prevention of market disruptions, I am voting in favour of this draft.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on markets in financial instruments, the Regulation on market abuse and the Regulation on improving securities settlement arrangements in the European Union and on central securities securities companies as regards certain dates. I agree with postponing the application of the Financial Markets Regulation for one year, as this will allow the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and other stakeholders to complete the establishment of a system of financial instrument reference data (FIRDS). The proposed Regulation aims, inter alia, at increasing competition and protecting consumers in the field of investment services.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The procedure for appointing members of the Court of Auditors is governed by Article 286 TFEI. According to the wording of the article, persons who have cooperated with audit institutions and who have the required guarantees of independence may be applied for. The Council shall adopt the list of members after non-binding consultation of Parliament. In short, it is a purely political procedure, without any real democratic control by the parliamentary body. For these reasons, I voted against. Not only do I consider the procedure to be totally unsuitable, but above all there is still a major gender imbalance in the composition of the Court, which the Member States should resolve as soon as possible.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour, because the new Lithuanian member of the Court of Auditors, made an impeccable hearing before the Committee on Budgetary Control, which resulted in a final result of 16 votes in favour and 3 against. Rimantas Sadzius is currently Minister of Finance of the Social Democratic Government of the Republic of Lithuania.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposed candidate to be a member of the Court of Auditors, as I also did with the remaining five, for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of auditing, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Rimantas 'Alaius' as a member of the Court of Auditors. The Social Democratic Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. I therefore objected to his appointment for these reasons. In addition, the candidate has no audit experience, unlike the vast majority of members of the Court who are former magistrates or auditors. His profile was therefore, in my opinion, not suitable.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as there were concerns raised that the candidate who was previously a politician in Lithuania, would not able to ensure that he would be able to perform the duties in the Court of Auditors with the necessary degree of independence. Moreover, I was further concerned that the Court of Auditors is gender unbalanced, as the majority compromising the board are male. This nomination further aggravates this existing imbalance, as the candidate is a man. My colleague Lynn Boylan has been actively involved in shaping the EU directive on Improving Gender Balance on Boards. Sinn Féin has called on the Irish Government to follow the example of other European countries in introducing legislation to ensure that gender balance on boards is addressed. Gender quotas are a crude instrument but are a necessary tool in the kit to begin addressing the gender imbalance. Women making up just 10% of Irish corporate boards is not good enough. 36% representation on state boards, while an improvement, still falls short of a target of 40% that was set in 1993. We must do better and with these concerns in mind, I voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. As a reminder, the Court of Auditors operates as a collegial body of 28 members, one of each Member State. Members are appointed by the Council, after consultation with the European Parliament, for a renewable six-year term. Members elect one of them as President for a renewable three-year term. I supported that candidacy. The candidate responded satisfactorily to our questions at his hearing by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. This hearing demonstrated that he is a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This was the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on their appointment. The candidate is the Social Democratic Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania; he has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. I voted against the appointment of this socialist apparatchik.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I wish to confirm I voted against this nomination. These nominations should be based on expertise and merit. They should not political appointments for 'the boys'.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this appointment, as advocated by the relevant committee on the merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal by which the EP expresses a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimant as a Member of the Court of Auditors of Shad. Since 23 May A hearing was held at the Committee on Budgetary Control and expressed strong support for his candidacy, and I welcome his appointment as an AR member. Since 2003 R. Šadžiaus' professional activities were always closely related to public finances. The candidate is former Minister of Social Security and Labour, Health Protection and Minister of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I cannot give a favourable opinion to the candidacy of Mr Rimantas Alaius to the Court of Auditors: as Social Democrat Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania, he presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the management and control of EU funds as his main successes. Mixed "success" ...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the favourable recommendation of our Budget Committee, I approved this designation.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is an important European institution which plays the role of external and independent auditor of the Union. Founded in 1977, it only became a fully-capacity EU institution in 1993, continuing to provide support for improving the management of the Community budget. It shall consist of one member from each State of the Union, each of whom shall be appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament and shall remain in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius. Having taken note of the content of the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the advice of my political group, the S&D, I voted in secret on the proposed name.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against, like the rest of the GUE/NGL, this candidacy of Lithuanian Rimantas Sadzius for a number of reasons. It persists in the presentation of male candidates, in an organization without gender balance. He is a candidate with little social sensitivity, as evidenced by his participation in successive governments of the country, and shows in his professional career numerous conflicts of interest.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported the report and the appointment of Mr .ad.iius as a member of the Court of Auditors after analysing his résumé and the answers he has given to the questions before him. I think he's fit for that appointment.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to the appointment of Rimantas Sadzius to the European Court of Auditors. First of all, I am concerned that the European Parliament is only consulted for advice on the appointment of the members of the Court of Auditors: elected representatives of the people, we are the only body of democratic control of the European institutions. On the other hand, as far as the specific case is concerned, Mr Sadzius is a pure product of the European oligarchy. In the face of almost his entire career in the European Union (he was, in Lithuania, the minister for the introduction of the euro and the banking union), I doubt that he has sufficient hindsight to control the financial management of European agencies and institutions.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This morning, the Plenary of the European Parliament put to a secret vote the proposal to appoint Rimantas as a member of the Court of Auditors following the evaluation of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 23 May before the Committee on Budgetary Control, a vote in which I participated.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimant as a Member of the Court of Auditors of Shad. When a hearing was held at a meeting of Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control on 23 May 2016, the committee on budgetary control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, taking into account in particular the requirements laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report as there were concerns raised that the candidate who was previously a politician in Lithuania, would not able to ensure that he would be able to perform the duties in the Court of Auditors with the necessary degree of independence. Moreover, I was further concerned that the Court of Auditors is gender unbalanced, as the majority compromising the board are male. This nomination further aggravates this existing imbalance, as the candidate is a man. My colleague Lynn Boylan has been actively involved in shaping the EU directive on Improving Gender Balance on Boards. Sinn Féin has called on the Irish Government to follow the example of other European countries in introducing legislation to ensure that gender balance on boards is addressed. Gender quotas are a crude instrument but are a necessary tool in the kit to begin addressing the gender imbalance. Women making up just 10% of Irish corporate boards is not good enough. 36% representation on state boards, while an improvement, still falls short of a target of 40% that was set in 1993. We must do better and with these concerns in mind, I voted against this report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Rimantas 'Alaius' as a member of the European Court of Auditors. Deeply Europeanist, Lithuania's Social Democratic Finance Minister presents the introduction of the euro in his country and the creation of the banking union as his main successes. Moreover, his appointment is not obvious to me, as he has virtually no professional experience outside of politics.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr S. S. I remain as a member of the Court of Auditors because I believe he is a high-profile person. The current Minister of Finance of the Republic of Lithuanian Republic (a role already held from 2007 to 2008), he has repeatedly assumed managerial positions in the public sector, gaining a long experience in the financial field. As Finance Minister, he took an active role in creating a more efficient institutional framework for the management of EU funds 2007-2013. From 2004 to 2006 he was Deputy Minister of Health and in 2003 Deputy Minister of Social Security and Labour. At the hearing in the CONT Committee, Parliament noted its seriousness and competence. He was casual and prepared, exhibiting a very good level of English and German. His profile is completed by knowledge of Russian and Polish and a first degree in chemistry followed by scientific studies in the field of quantum chemistry.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this nomination, for the same reasons as I voted against the other nominations earlier this year. Gender Diversity is something that Sinn Féin is committed to, and as not a single nomination was for a female candidate, in addition to serious questions around the qualifications and suitability of those put forward, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment that nominates Mr Rimantas Šadžius as a Member of the Court of Auditors. The hearing and evaluation demonstrate a positive opinion on this candidate. I believe that he qualifies for the position.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the appointment of Rimantas Sadzlus as a member of the Court of Auditors. Under Article 286 TFEU, members of the Court of Auditors should be chosen from persons who can offer adequate guarantees of independence. Rimantas Sadzius has a purely political record, as he has held various positions as Minister in Lithuania. On the basis of this fact, I did not consider it appropriate to appoint you as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius, as according to the Committee on Budgetary Control, it has the necessary qualifications.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because, having examined his resume and his excursus work, I believe that he is the right person for this prestigious assignment.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to keep my ballot private to respect this secret ballot

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this nomination as Mr Šadžius is highly political. He is currently the Finance Minister for the socialist government in Lithuania. He helped Lithuania join the Euro and wants more EU integration. He is a pro-EU politician and UKIP questions his neutrality when auditing the EUs accounts. We seriously doubt he will want to criticise or root out bad or illegal EU spending.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The candidacy of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors has been successfully assessed by the Committee on Budgetary Control. Congratulating him on the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius, I wish him well in his work.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the favourable opinion on the Council’s nomination of Rimantas Šadžius as a Member of the Court of Auditors after the necessary assurances were given by the responsible committee to grant the nomination endorsement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposed candidate to be a member of the Court of Auditors, as I also did with the remaining five, for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of auditing, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Mr Rimantas Šadžius was nominated by the Lithuanian Government as a candidate for a member of the Court of Auditors. He graduated in law from vilnius University's Faculty of Law, as well as studies in chemistry at the Faculty of Chemistry at moscow University. He was Deputy Minister of Social Affairs and Labour ( 2003-2004), Deputy Minister in the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Lithuania, December (2004-2006), Deputy Minister in the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania (2006-2007). He is currently Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania (second time; first in 2007-2008) since 13 December 2012. Mr Šadžius has very good credentials and presented his candidacy well at the CONT Committee hearing on 23 May. Cont members highlighted, among other advantages, its linguistic competence - Mr Šadžius speaks four languages fluently (English, Russian, Polish and German). I personally supported the Lithuanian candidate for the ECA.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Lithuanian nomination of Rimantas Šadžius to the European Court of Auditors, since I consider him to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has voted on the appointment of Rimantas Sadzius to the Court of Auditors. The former Lithuanian finance minister was considered highly qualified by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). Considering that the candidacy of Rimantas Sadzius corresponds perfectly to the stakes and needs of the Court of Auditors, I voted in favour of his appointment.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text concerns the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors. The European Parliament is consulted on appointments. The candidate, Minister of Social Democratic Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It considers as its main successes the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union. To the extent that this person has always lived in politics and is neither a former magistrate nor an audit professional, I voted against this appointment.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to appoint Rimantas Shadjus as a Member of the Court of Auditors, as I believe that he has the necessary qualities to be part of this institution.  He is a former Minister of Finance in Lithuania, before that he was Deputy Minister of Finance, Deputy Minister of Health, Deputy Minister of Social Security and Labour.  I wish him a fruitful job as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control held the hearing of the candidate proposed by the Council for the post of member of the Court of Auditor and gave its assent to the nod of Rimantas Šadžius for the post. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: profile of apparatchik who has always lived from politics.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECA operates as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each Member State. The Members are appointed by the Council after consultation with the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. Members elect one of their number as president for a renewable term of three years. I supported this candidacy: the candidate gave a good hearing at the committee stage, receiving a large majority in favour of his appointment (16-3). His hearing showed him to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not have any party-political blinkers for good candidates – I know that many colleagues from the major parties will hardly understand this, but: I voted today for Rimantas 'ad'ius as a member of the European Court of Auditors because he has the qualifications: he was, among other things, Deputy Finance Minister and since December 2012 Minister of Finance of Lithuania.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. After a thorough examination of the candidacy, I support the appointment of Rimantas adaius as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Mr Šadžius gave a good hearing at the committee stage, receiving a large majority in favour of his appointment. In his hearing he showed himself to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate for the role at the European Court of Auditors – and his experience as a minister in Lithuania would stand him in good stead in this role.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against, like the rest of the GUE/NGL, this candidacy of Lithuanian Rimantas Sadzius for a number of reasons. It persists in the presentation of male candidates, in an organization without gender balance. He is a candidate with little social sensitivity, as evidenced by his participation in successive governments of the country, and shows in his professional career numerous conflicts of interest.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the candidacy of Rimantas for the role at the ECA. He gave a satisfactory hearing at the committee stage and this is reflected in the large majority in favour of his appointment. He showed himself as competent, well-prepared and motivated.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the nomination of Rimantas Šadžius as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this appointment as I had no objections to the candidate.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament on the proposed appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors on the basis that I believe that Mr. Šadžius has the necessary knowledge and professional experience to perform this function. His work in the Ministry of Finance, Health, Social Welfare and Labour of the Republic of Lithuania indicates that Mr. Šadžius had the opportunity to acquire the necessary skills and competences, especially taking into account the duties of the Minister of Finance, which he has held since December 2012. I believe that Mr. Shadjius will conscientiously and responsibly serve as a member of the aforementioned court, and therefore I support his appointment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The candidate, Minister of Social Democratic Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. This gentleman having an apparatchik profile who has always lived from politics, I logically voted against the appointment.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the Committee on Budgets verified the credibility and appropriateness of Rimantas Shajius and recommended him to Members as a credibility candidate in the light of the requirements laid down in the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, I voted in favour of his membership of the Court of Auditors.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the appointment of the Lithuanian member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the nomination of the former Lithuanian Minister of Finance as a member of the European Court of Auditors. There is nothing to oppose this candidacy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the candidacy. The candidate gave a good hearing at the committee stage, receiving a large majority in favour of his appointment. His hearing showed him to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate for the role at the ECA.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors, and taking into account the reference to Article 286 TFEI, it is stated that the appointment of those members must be made on the basis of a choice to be made between persons who are part or who have been part, in the States of origin, of the external audit institutions or who have a specific qualification for that function. The candidacy proposed by the Council to appoint Rimantas Sadzius as a member of the Court of Auditors was considered valid following a thorough analysis of the candidate's credentials and personal background.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Mr Rimantas 'Adaius' to the Court of Auditors. Minister of Social Democratic Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, he has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. He is a politician, whereas in general the members of the Court of Auditors are former magistrates or auditors with considerable experience in auditing.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposed candidate to be a member of the Court of Auditors, as I also did with the remaining five, for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of auditing, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Members of the Court of Auditors are appointed for a period of six years. In accordance with Article 286 of the TFEU, following consultation with Parliament, the Council adopts a list of members drawn up in accordance with the proposals of each Member State.  I supported the Report on the proposed appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors, because I believe that with my competences and experience he meets the set criteria.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Court of Auditors functions as an independent external auditor, which regularly monitors the management of the Union budget by the European Commission and consistently reports on the current financial situation, together with recommendations for their improvement. Although that institution has no legal power, its importance in terms of financial verification is undeniable. This, in turn, means that, with the European Court of Auditors, consisting of 28 members , one from each EU Member State, it employs the most qualified financial professionals who have proven themselves in their home country for many years, and that their primary task is, in fact, to monitor the Union's finances in such a way as to guarantee the interests of our citizens, i.e. taxpayers.
