I voted positively when examining and analysing Mr. Sgiaus's candidacy and paying the utmost attention to his professional experience and a number of other factors.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to appoint Rimantas Shajius as a Member of the Court of Auditors for Lithuania. Mr Šadžius's previous experience in finance in several senior public administration posts in Lithuania creates the preconditions for his high-quality performance of tasks in the field of control of EU funds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposed appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors, as I do not agree with key points in that report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The opinion of the European Parliament on the appointment of the Social Democratic Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania: he initiated the introduction of the euro in his country, and impelled the banking union. A profile we cannot support.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the appointment of Rimantas Sadzius for the six-year term as a member of the Court of Auditors. After consultation with the European Parliament, the impressions were positive.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. He is the former Lithuanian Minister of Finance and has not been guilty of anything. He made a trustworthy impression at the CONT hearing.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Council's proposal to appoint Rimant as a Member of the Court of Auditors of Shad because he has the appropriate qualifications, experience and skills for this work.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes the appointment of Mr. Rimantas Sadzius to the Court of Auditors. The Lithuanian, a member of the Social Democratic Party, was one of the actors in budgetary discipline when he was finance minister. Its main strength is that it has succeeded in reducing salaries in the public service and the private sector by 10%. He said some time ago that he had always given "great importance to the reduction of public spending". A whole program... I'm voting against his nomination.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is being consulted for advice on the appointment of a member to the Court of Auditors. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control has assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate in compliance with the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Following the opinion in favour of the nomination of the candidate, I have presented my concordant vote.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I congratulate Mr Rimantas Sadzius on his appointment as a member of the European Court of Auditors. His experience as Finance Minister in Lithuania since December 2012 and the work he did while in this position to bring his country into the eurozone as the 19th member demonstrate his willingness to put all his experience at the service of the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Lithuanian nomination of Rimantas Šadžius to the European Court of Auditors because I consider him to be a competent and motivated candidate.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council nominated Lithuanian Finance Minister Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors. Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the capabilities of the proposed candidate, heard the candidate at its meeting on 23 May 2016 and, on that basis, recommends in its report that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimantas Šadžius as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of candidate Rimantas Šadžius as to the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and following the hearing at the meeting of 23 May 2016, I am in favour of the nodžius Council for the post of member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The candidate, Minister of Social Democratic Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. It is totally ubuesque to consider rewarding him with this appointment, so I object.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The candidate gave a good hearing at the committee stage, receiving a large majority in favour of his appointment. His hearing showed him to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate for the role at the ECA.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the appointment of Rimantas Alaius as a member of the Court of Auditors. Rimantas was heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The members of this committee approved this nomination by a very large majority.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control always does a thorough job before nominating anyone as a member of the Court of Auditors. The conversation with Mr Rimanatas Šadžius shows that he is a professionally prepared candidate with years of experience who has won the support of the strict committee and myself.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the nomination of Rimantas Sadzius as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Each EU Member State shall appoint a representative to the Control Chamber.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this nomination as Mr Šadžius is highly political. He is currently the Finance Minister for the Socialist government in Lithuania. He helped Lithuania join the euro and wants more EU integration. He is a pro-EU politician and UKIP questions his neutrality when auditing the EU’s accounts. We seriously doubt he will want to criticise or root out bad or illegal EU spending.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the basis of the assessments of the Committee on Budgetary Control, concerning both the candidate's curriculum vitae and the answers he gave during a hearing, I voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Rimantas Šadžius has extensive professional experience in public finance, foreign policy and international law and this makes him an acceptable candidate for this appointment. I am convinced that Shadius' experience working in the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, first as Deputy Minister and then as Minister, is invaluable for his appointment, as the Court of Auditors audits EU revenues and expenditures and checks whether EU funding has been used correctly and with the expected impact.   I believe that its membership will improve the audit of the entire accounts of revenues or expenditures of the European Union or its bodies, as Šadžius himself has contributed to the reform of accounting and financial statements in the Lithuanian public sector. As an independent external auditor of the EU, I believe that Rimantas, as a member of the Court of Auditors, will protect the interests of EU taxpayers and thus the interests of the taxpayers of the Republic of Croatia.  Given his experience so far, I believe that the appointment of Rimantas, as well as other candidates of similar qualifications, contributes to a better functioning of the EU audit system as a whole and I supported his appointment as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Social Democratic Finance Minister of the Republic of Lithuania, Rimantas Alaius has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It prides itself mainly on the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union. It is clear that I do not share his analyses and solutions for the future of the European Union. So I vote logically against his appointment.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the EIA. agreement on the functioning of the European Union and since the Committee on Budgetary Control gives a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors, I support the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Rimantas Šadžius, the current Minister of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, has been nominated as a member of the Court of Auditors whose role is to contribute to better management of the Finances of the European Union and to verify the correctness of the collection and use of funds.  Based on his professional experience as Minister of Finance and responsibility as Deputy Minister of Social Welfare and Labour, Rimantas Šadžius' professional activities are closely linked to public finances. Accordingly, I supported Representative Staes' report and agreed with the Commission's proposal to appoint Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Court of Auditors acts as a college of 28 members, with one candidate nominated for each EU Member State. The initial nominations are followed by a hearing in the European Parliament (in the Committee on Budgetary Control of which I am a member). I unequivocally supported Mr Sadijius's candidacy, both on the basis of hearings and on the basis of written replies to additional questions from members of the Committee on Budgetary Control. I am convinced that he is an excellent expert, and I am happy to be able to work with him more closely in the coming period as a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors is a collegiate body composed of 28 members, one for each Member State. The members shall be appointed by the Council, after consultation with the European Parliament, for a renewable period of six years. I welcome the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors and wish him well in his work, in the hope that he will be able to play his role with the utmost independence and transparency in the general interest of the European Union.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We were asked to rule on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors. This procedure demonstrates the usefulness of Parliament in exercising its control over the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this nomination as Mr Šadžius is highly political. He is currently the Finance Minister for the Socialist government in Lithuania. He helped Lithuania join the euro and wants more EU integration. He is a pro-EU politician and UKIP questions his neutrality when auditing the EU’s accounts. We seriously doubt he will want to criticise or root out bad or illegal EU spending.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, Parliament voted in favour of the appointment of Mr Rimantas 'Adaius' to replace Mrs Rasa Budbergyt as Lithuania's representative member of the European Union Court of Auditors.  MEPs support the appointment of Mr' Alaius in view of his experience as Lithuania's finance minister since December 2012. Thanks to his work in this position, Mr. Alaius has enabled his country to enter the euro zone. Parliament recognises this experience and the ability of Mr 'Alaius' to defend the interests of European taxpayers and to improve the management of the Union's budget.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of appointing Rimantas 'Alaius' as a Lithuanian member of the Court of Auditors. This appointment was made following the evaluation by the Committee on Budgetary Control of the qualifications of the candidate proposed by the Council and its hearing conducted at a meeting on 23 May 2016.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I invite colleagues to support the nomination of a member of the Court of Auditors.  Rimantas Šadžius is known as a financial specialist who chooses evolutionary rather than revolutionary tools, is able to bring together experts, choose the right solutions for public finance management. I believe that such a specialist is really appropriate for the Court of Auditors, a conservative body that checks the eligibility of EU funds.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Rimantas Sadzius to the post of Member of the Court of Auditors, since, at the hearing held by the Committee on Budgetary Control, the candidate showed that he had the appropriate skills and professional experience for the performance of those functions. Following the Council proposal, we have seen that the selection process has been carried out in a transparent manner, so I have no objection to this appointment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against, like the rest of the GUE/NGL, this candidacy of Lithuanian Rimantas Sadzius for a number of reasons. It persists in the presentation of male candidates, in an organization without gender balance. He is a candidate with little social sensitivity, as evidenced by his participation in successive governments of the country, and shows in his professional career numerous conflicts of interest.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 Rimantas Šadžius has received strong support in parliament. However, it is essential to always choose the candidate with the best qualifications. During rimantas Šadžius's hearing he showed great competence, was well prepared and motivated. That is why I support the appointment.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposed candidate to be a member of the Court of Auditors, as I also did with the remaining five, for various reasons: because of their lack of independence, the possibility of conflict of interest, the lack of professional knowledge in the field of auditing, as well as the lack of gender balance, since they are all men.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Rimantas gave a satisfactory hearing at the committee stage and this is reflected in the large majority in favour of his appointment. He showed himself as competent, well-prepared and motivated. I support his candidacy for the role at the ECA.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the appointment of Romantas Shajius as a Member of the Court of Auditors as the Committee on Budgetary Control approved his qualifications. The candidate made a convincing appearance during the committee hearing and was approved by a majority of its members. He has proven himself to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate. It has been in the area of public finances since at least 2003. He first served as Deputy Minister for Labour and Social Security, where his duties included issues relating to social security and social assistance budgets. At this time, its specific tasks included the implementation of projects financed by EU pre-accession assistance funds and preparation for the start of the use of structural assistance in Lithuania's first programming period. He later moved to the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Lithuania, where he worked in the field of health care financing through the National Health Insurance Fund. He then worked at the Ministry of Finance, first as deputy minister and later as a minister. Among other things, he also addressed the integration of EU structural aid into the general context of the state budget. At the time, he also participated in the creation of a better audit system for the EU Structural Funds, which included the National Audit Office of Lithuania. This suggests that Romantas Shajius has extensive experience in using public funds. That is why I supported his candidacy and I believe that he will thrive in his new role.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that the Members of the Court are people with practical experience. As Latvia's two-time finance minister, Romantas Shajius is undoubtedly such a man.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report in view of the fact that the qualifications of the proposed candidate were assessed by the competent Committee of Parliament, in particular as regards the conditions set out in Art. Paragraph 286(1) of the E.S. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. A hearing of the same candidate was also held at a session of the Committee on Budgetary Control, at the Court of Auditors on 23 May 2016.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The candidate gave a good hearing at the committee stage, receiving a large majority in favour of his appointment. His hearing showed him to be a competent, well-prepared and motivated candidate for the role at the ECA.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against the candidate.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, assessing the qualifications of the proposed candidate, within the meaning of the conditions set out in Article 286(1) of the Code of Health. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and after the hearing of the Candidates of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors, gave a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors. I support the proposal for a decision on the proposed appointment, as I consider parliament's Committee competent to give an relevant opinion on the qualifications of candidates.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of Rimantas Shajius as a Member of the Court of Auditors.  The Lithuanian candidate has a great deal of experience in the field of public finances, as he was minister of finance and multiple deputy ministers responsible for public finances. In addition, in the second half of 2013 he served as President of the Council for Economic and Financial Affairs of the European Union during the Lithuanian Presidency, where he worked intensively on the adoption of the EU budget for 2014 and on cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.  It gave good answers to the questions, including the question of independence and on improving cooperation between the Court of Auditors, national audit institutions and the European Parliament in auditing the European Union budget.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for positions of responsibility and Union interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Parliament has given a favourable opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Rimantas 'Adaius' a member of the Court of Auditors. The President will forward this decision to the Council and, for information, to the Court of Auditors as well as to the other institutions of the European Union and the supervisory institutions of the Member States.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of nominating of Rimantas Šadžius as a Member of the Court of Auditors as suggested by the Committee on Budgetary Control. I trust that Mr Šadžius’s professional experience as a minister of Finance in Lithuania from 2007 to 2008, and his second term as minister of Finance in the cabinet of Algirdas Butkevičius since 2012 will qualify him to deliver on the requirements of this position.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported the appointment of Rimantas Šadžius as a member of the Court of Auditors, since I believe that Mr. Shadžius, given his professional experience in public finances, will be guided by the principle of independence, which is the basis in the performance of daily audit duties and in the adoption of strategic decisions. The Court of Auditors plays an important role in the process of promoting a culture of sound financial management, and I believe that members of the Court of Auditors should be qualified experts who can improve the added value of business efficiency audits. The ECA should provide the European Parliament with audit reports that address topics relevant to Parliament and are timely and relevant. To this end, the auditor must exhaustively review specific business processes, choose comparable best practices and identify what could be best done.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the appointment of a Member of the Court of Auditors – Rimantas Šadžius, as the candidate is very competent. He first took the educational career to the University of Moscow, where he graduated in chemistry and later to the Faculty of Law of the University of Vilnius. After that, he served in various ministries in Lithuania, where he was also minister of finance twice. His professional experience in the field of public finances and budgetary planning is of paramount importance in appointing a candidate as a Member of the Court of Auditors. He also has experience of the Presidency of Lithuania to the Council of the EU, because he held the post of President of the Council in the composition at the time. The candidate has demonstrated both his theoretical and practical competence, which is of paramount importance in his work at the Court of Auditors.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against, like the rest of the GUE/NGL, this candidacy of Lithuanian Rimantas Sadzius for a number of reasons. It persists in the presentation of male candidates, in an organization without gender balance. He is a candidate with little social sensitivity, as evidenced by his participation in successive governments of the country, and shows in his professional career numerous conflicts of interest.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The candidate, Minister of Social Democratic Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, has been a member of the political bureau of the Social Democratic Party since 1990. It presents the introduction of the euro in Lithuania, the creation of the banking union and the improvement of the efficiency of the management and control of funds by the Union as its main successes. Profile of apparatchik who has always lived from politics. I'm voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Mr Rimantas Šadžius, who has held positions in the Government of the Republic of Lithuania several times, has shown that he is a specific and experienced politician. I am convinced that his candidacy as a Member of the Court of Auditors of the EU will strengthen this institution and improve its effectiveness.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The cv of Rimantas Šadžius, a member of the Court of Auditors, is impressive. He earned a law degree and a master's degree in law from the University of Vilnius, but also a chemist's degree in Moscow. He also worked as Finance Minister, Deputy Minister of Health and Deputy Minister for Social Affairs and Labour in the Lithuanian Government. I voted in favour of his appointment.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against, like the rest of the GUE/NGL, this candidacy of Lithuanian Rimantas Sadzius for a number of reasons. It persists in the presentation of male candidates, in an organization without gender balance. He is a candidate with little social sensitivity, as evidenced by his participation in successive governments of the country, and shows in his professional career numerous conflicts of interest.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the nomination a member of the Court of Auditors Rimantas Šadžius because there are no legal, political or personal reasons on the grounds of which an objection to his nomination would be founded.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the appointment of Rimantas Sadzius as a member of the Court of Auditors, because the Committee on Budgetary Control delivered a positive opinion after examining his credentials.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 No comment on personality and skills. Only our deep reservations about a body that is at the service of the integration process that we condemn.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: Written. 'The PVV voted against the appointment of Remantas Sadzius, a Lithuanian EU-minded Social Democrat, to be a member of the European Court of Auditors. The European Union has no shortage of politicians who always think positively about all expenditure: the entire European Commission, the European Parliament, the European Council, all more than 50 agencies, the parliaments of almost all the Member States. There is no need for another member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the appointment of Rimantas Shajius as a Member of the Court of Auditors. I supported the candidate for Member of the Court of Auditors because he has the appropriate education and years of professional experience in the leading positions related to public finances. As a member of the Court of Auditors, I believe that he will comply with the requirements of the Founding Treaty, the ethical guidelines of the European Court of Auditors, the code of ethics for court judges and the Rules of Procedure of the Court of Auditors and the rules for its implementation.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on the need for coherent policies for international development cooperation. Evaluating and optimising policy tools to create a well-thought-out and consistent policy is important. This is largely handled correctly and in the final vote I voted in favour of the report. At the same time, I find certain sections of the report problematic, which I highlighted in separate votes. This applies in particular to the proposal to introduce transaction taxes to finance development.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every two years, a report on the coherence of development policies is drawn up with the aim of monitoring progress, making improvements to strategies and giving greater impetus to sustainable development. There are several issues covered in the report, such as security, trade, finance, migration and food security. Following a wide-ranging discussion with some NGOs, there was a demand for improved cooperation, especially at the level of bilateral agreements between the EU and third countries, focusing on the need to ensure greater transparency and control, especially with regard to European investment in developing countries. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because it proposes in broad lines: - a more dynamic policy and action correlation between CPD and SDGs. - greater participation of local and regional governments, as well as civil society organizations and expert groups. - set quality targets and develop clearer CPD indicators. - ex-ante impact assessments, as well as the establishment of a reporting mechanism. - more resources in Union delegations and in the focal points of national ministries to implement national and European strategies in terms of CPD. - a specific European Council on the CPD and its coordination with the SDGs. Considering that the refugee crisis and destabilization in the union's neighbouring countries is questioning the pillars of the Union itself, the CPD stands as a key element in foreign policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The principle of coherence for development, first enshrined as European legislation in 1992, states that no Union policy, whether commercial, economic or migration, can be contrary to international development objectives.   Despite considering it positive, I have not been able to support this report by containing a constant link between security and development and, further inclusion of the Union's External Action Service in development policies. It would also have been necessary for all references to the need for assessments on the impacts of Union policies on third countries to be in line with making them binding and mandatory.  On the other hand, I do not share his approach to the migration phenomenon, focusing on security-related aspects and not on the human right that everyone has to migrate.  However, the report contains positive elements such as the need to improve coordination between the Union institutions and also between them and the Member States in order to improve compliance with this principle, which should be the central axis of any Union policy.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this EU report on policy coherence for development.  This text, in the run-up to the UN development summits, is the encouragement of the Committee on Development and Parliament to continue the EU's support for the development policies of UN agencies and programmes. However, in addition to having a very ideological view of development, this report poses several problems: little or no questioning of the effectiveness of development policy and the 30 years of failures of the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models. In reality, the aim of this text is to beg states for resources and budgets. Furthermore, I believe that the EU does not have to use development to gain power at the expense of the Member States.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this report contained some positive provisions specifically in relation to human rights, the environment, refugees, tax avoidance and the rights of individual countries to determine their own development policies, it also contained some very regressive provisions regarding the proposed Common Security and Defence Policy. There was an entire section on security and development within the report which promotes the importance of the ‘security-development nexus’ and EU external action in defence and security. It calls for reinforcing links between the Common Security and Defence Policy and development instruments. I strongly believe matters of defence and security are the competency of established national authorities and no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a Common Security and Defence Policy. Therefore, whilst the report contained some progressive elements these failed to mitigate the worst excesses of the report, and therefore, I abstained on the report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Despite difficulties in implementing the coherence of development policies (CPD), the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies between EU policies. A meeting of the specific European Council on the CPD, before the publication of the Commission's next report in 2017, would help to better define the responsibilities of the various actors.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This 2015 report on the coherence of development policy shows that its achievement involves many difficulties. However, the EU should try to ensure greater cooperation between European policies. Furthermore, it would be important before the adoption of the Commission's latest report to have a meeting of the European Council in order to communicate and raise awareness of this issue and to clarify the responsibilities of the different bodies. This report, which I voted in favour of, proposes, among other things, more involvement of local and regional governments as well as social organisations and think tanks, the establishment of a complaint mechanism, a clearer analysis of data-based policy, etc.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'Under the guise of sustainable development, additional taxes are proposed, a common asylum and migration policy is proposed and a proactive role for the EU and an infringement of the sovereignty of the Member States and the third countries concerned.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed report is a naïve text that does not question the concept of development, does not question the current relationship of the populations of the southern states to this notion, does not take stock of 30 years of failures of promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models with no conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month.   In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. That reason alone was enough for me to refuse to vote on the report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report extends the power of the Commission President to the point where they could possibly step in and use disagreements between political groups to further their own personal agenda. I voted against this report as it is an incoherent combination of wishful thinking and behavioural economic illiteracy.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, carried out by my colleague Charles Goerens, with the aim of preventing inconsistencies resulting from EU policies in order to avoid negative repercussions on developing countries.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, in which the EP expresses its position on the Commission's biennial pcod 2012 report.  I agree that, given that the refugee crisis and the unstable situation in the EU's neighbourhood are beginning to call into question the principles on which the EU itself is founded, pcd should focus on external action. The EU should give an indisputable priority to stabilising the EU's neighbourhood. Significant progress has been made in the area of THE EU's external action on the joint role of the HR/Vice-President in order to achieve PCD. The EU's comprehensive approach is realistic, although serious problems are still being faced.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which calls on the EU to continue its support for the development policies of UN agencies and programmes, a text which in particular supports unbridled immigration without questioning the consequences for countries of origin and countries hosting migration flows.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. One and a half billion people live in poverty and do not have access to health care, education or a decent income. This demonstrates the importance of policy coherence for development (CPD). In this report, which I approved, Parliament believes that the CPD must contribute to the establishment of the rule of law and impartial institutions and to the challenge of good governance in developing countries. In this regard, it deplores the lack of progress in the implementation of the CPD principles and calls for a debate in this area within the framework of sustainable development by 2030. The report also calls on the Commission to consult systematically with human rights organisations at an early stage in development decision-making and calls for more institutional coordination between EU institutions and Member States.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. One of the biggest challenges we have in the field of development cooperation is the coherence between our policies. While positive steps have been taken, we are far from achieving real coherence between policies that most affect development, international trade, foreign affairs, financial and agricultural policy.  The report, in addition to being critical of the current situation, includes interesting initiatives. That's why I voted for it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2016, more than 1.5 billion people live in poverty, suffering from health, education and living standards. A large part of them are women. The adoption by the United Nations of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was an important moment in the definition of strategic objectives to combat this and other serious problems that threaten our planet. The Dan Preda report, which I supported today with my vote, not only assesses the progress made in terms of policy coherence for development, but also makes concrete proposals to make the EU take the lead in promoting a universal agenda for the PSC. The text focuses on a number of priority areas for action: migration, trade and finance, food security, health, climate change and gender, but the most important aspect is that linked to the definition of a link between security and development. The EU must implement the PSC within the framework of the Union's foreign policy. Only by creating an effective link between humanitarian aid, development cooperation and disaster resilience will a more flexible and effective response to growing global needs be achieved.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the Union must take the lead in promoting policy coherence for development, as Article 208 of the Lisbon Treaty points out, we voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission to effectively increase its efforts through concrete measures the coordination and coherence of its external policies to align with the Objectives of the Union (eradication of poverty and reduction of inequalities).

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I do not know whether it is a good thing that the European Union dictates to the countries of what was once called the Third World what their development policy should be and whether or not they have the right to propose incentives and tax exemptions to attract or retain investors. Similarly, it is inappropriate to impose our vision of human rights and rights on Africa. Such an attitude can rightly be seen as a form of neocolonialism that does not take into account African traditions and customs that are not ours. And it is precisely there that this report, full of good intentions, fishes a little too much for my liking. It is good that this report insists that aid alone is not enough to solve the problems of developing countries. But, please, let us not adopt a paternalistic attitude.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the coherence of development policies, which states that more emphasis should be placed on institutional coordination, both between the EU institutions and with the Member States. An adequate level of resources and personnel will also be needed for the proper development of policy coherence for development. Moreover, it should not be forgotten that aid alone is not sufficient and it is considered necessary to take into account innovative and diversified sources of funding such as the tax on financial transactions, the tax on coal, the solidarity rate on air tickets and income from natural resources, among others.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I vehemently opposed this report, which unfortunately does not draw the consequences of 30 years of failures of the development models carried by the IMF and the World Bank. Mr Preda's report merely chants the notion of 'development policy' and uses this incantation to call for an increase in the powers and means of the European Union. At the same time, there is no questioning of the obstacles to the success of a genuine co-development policy since the report clings to immigrationist and free-trade totems, despite a timid recognition of the potential harms of such an ideology. Finally, the only usefulness of this report is to demand ever more financial contribution from Member States, which are called upon to finance a "non-project".

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's development policies lack effectiveness and coherence, and this report does not put forward any proposals that we can support in order to get out of the stagnation of these failed policies. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As established by the Lisbon Treaty, the EU must ensure coherence in development policies in order to more effectively connect domestic policies and foreign policy. Following the adoption of the 2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the need arises for the EU to continue to take into account the new development objectives set out in its policies and to continue to generate synergies between its policies, to benefit developing countries and to increase the effectiveness of cooperation. This report proposes greater participation by regional and local governments as well as civil society organizations to assist these issues. In addition, it proposes to set quality objectives and develop clearer indicators to assess coherence in development policies. In line with the proposal, delegations of the European Union in third countries are urged to provide more resources to be able to carry out these tasks and to strengthen the CPD as one of the key elements of foreign policy, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the Commission's biennial pcd report on policy coherence (PCD). In the world, EUR 15 billion will be invested in people still live in poverty and deprivation, are unable to access healthcare and education and to achieve a standard of living, and most of them are women. Meanwhile, the possibility of fiscal manoeuvring in developing countries is actually limited by the requirements of global investors and financial markets, and developing countries are offering various tax incentives and exemptions to attract or retain investors, leading to harmful tax competition and starting to race for lower taxes. In its report, Parliament expressed its regret that, although policy coherence for development was adopted in the UN Millennium Declaration, the Treaty of Lisbon and the Busan Forum on aid effectiveness, in particular, little progress has been made in ensuring it. Parliament therefore calls for an EU-wide debate on PCD in the context of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its 17 new global and indivisible Sustainable Development Goals, in order to better understand how this concept can be reconciled with a more comprehensive approach to sustainable development.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030 (PCD). The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider closer cooperation between the EU institutions and the Member States to be important. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the EU Report on PCD. The EU's coordinated PCD programme has existed since 2005, when it became clear that more needs to be done to achieve development objectives than simply to provide development aid, and that far-reaching strategies are needed between EU development and other policies. The 2009 Lisbon Treaty underlined the EU's legal obligation to implement PCD and put the EU's external and internal policy coherence even more at the centre. The proposed report analyses five priority areas (trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security) and makes concrete recommendations for them. The current refugee crisis and destabilisation in the EU's neighbourhood undermine the very foundations of the EU, such as the Schengen system and the principle of solidarity, and therefore PCD should focus on external action. Stabilising the EU's neighbourhood should be at the top of the EU's list of priorities. Due to the combined role of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, significant progress has been made in the area of PCD, which applies to EU external actions. While the EU's comprehensive approach still faces serious challenges.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this PCD Report. I believe that despite the difficulties in implementing development policy, the EU needs to make additional efforts to ensure more synergies between European Union policies.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the EU's capacity to support the development policies of UN agencies and programmes.  While I am in favour of efforts to promote the development of the countries that need it, I cannot support the free-trade and immigrationist tendencies of this report, which does not take stock of 30 years of failure of the policies followed in this area. I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Whilst this report contained some positive provisions specifically in relation to human rights, the environment, refugees, tax avoidance and the rights of individual countries to determine their own development policies, it also contained some very regressive provisions regarding the proposed Common Security and Defence Policy. There was an entire section on security and development within the report which promotes the importance of the ‘security-development nexus’ and EU external action in defence and security. It calls for reinforcing links between the Common Security and Defence Policy and development instruments. I strongly believe matters of defence and security are the competency of established national authorities and no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a Common Security and Defence Policy. Therefore, whilst the report contained some progressive elements these failed to mitigate the worst excesses of the report, and therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must act in a coordinated and coherent manner in its development policies, whether they are aimed at territories within the Union or external territories. Policy coherence presupposes agreement on values and principles to be complied with and converged on. Multi-level governance and coordination are therefore essential and on different scales to promote dialogue and foster the agreement and political commitment of each institution to transform its policies, integrate them, apply them and monitor them as planned, into a constant process of review and renewal. We cannot risk promoting values of democracy, respect for human rights, the fight against poverty and then implementing, in certain areas, trade policies or agreements with third countries which indirectly create the conditions under which the commitments made are violated or disregarded. In particular, for the coming years, attention must be paid to partnership and cooperation agreements with non-democratic developing countries where, without an appropriate procedure for reporting the aid provided, there is a risk of unwittingly strengthening the darker parts of those same countries that we would like to help.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Development Policy Coherence Report aims both to assess the progress reported by the Commission and to identify areas for improving existing EU mechanisms on policy coherence for development. Even though the Union's political commitment to CPD has always been manifested, there are still difficulties in implementing this commitment through concrete measures. Policy coherence for development is a fundamental element for the implementation of the new agenda for sustainable development, but also in areas such as trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. However, attention needs to be focused on the Union's foreign policy in view of the context of the refugee crisis and the absence of stability in the Union's neighbourhood.  Policy coherence for development must therefore be reflected in the Union's external actions with a view to stabilising the EU's neighbourhood and developing the best solutions in response to external challenges, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Policy coherence for development (CPD) is a pillar of the new Sustainable Development Agenda, but it needs to be implemented in the Commission's commitment in the fifth biennial report. In view of the unparalleled migratory context with which the European Union is facing and the link between migration and development policies, this link is needed to have control over this phenomenon. EU policies should focus not only on immediate issues, but on implementing a long-term poverty reduction strategy, concrete actions to stimulate economic, political and social development and good governance in countries of origin. I support this report because it supports the application of essential instruments to ensure the effective and systematic implementation of CPD through EU policies and in areas such as food health and safety. The EU needs to promote the creation of sound regulatory frameworks with clear criteria to protect the food rights and security of vulnerable groups, but also to support the creation of concrete health systems, sustainable health infrastructures and the provision of basic quality health and care services.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The coherence of development policies is essential in order to achieve the various development objectives that international and European bodies have set for themselves. The European Union must take particular care of this coherence given the multitude of European development policies and the complexity of the European governance system (composed of different levels of power). However, we must put in place the necessary tools to ensure this consistency. We must also ensure inter-institutional dialogue in the field of development. An analysis of the inconsistencies in development policies and their costs may also be necessary. I voted in favour of this report, which will advance the concept of coherence of development policies.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 The coherence of European policy and the search for a more prosperous and dynamic future for the European Union will have to go through a profound reform of the European budget, which cannot continue to depend solely on the contributions of the Member States. It is important to incorporate new revenue in order to move towards a Union capable of absorbing economic shocks and offering a minimum degree of income convergence. The reason that led me to vote against paragraph 30 has nothing to do with the specific use that is intended to be attributed to the tax on financial transactions or CO2, but because I believe that the revenue from those taxes should be used to create a more effective European budget.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report calling on the Commission to give coherence to development policies (PSC). Although provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, this strategy still lacks a shared interpretation. I share the view of the report, which advocates a human rights-based approach, because it would make it possible to better understand the coherence of development policies. Indeed, if we do not tackle the obstacles to achieving rights, there can be no progress towards sustainable development and the eradication of poverty. The main instrument for implementing the PSC is impact assessments, but more investment is needed from the Eu ropean Union, as studies are currently scarce and do not adequately address the potential impact on developing countries. The report calls for future impact assessments to focus on identifying inconsistencies and to develop appropriate mechanisms for monitoring and monitoring progress on PSC, including proposals on how to avoid and address inconsistencies between policies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. While it raised some positive provisions in relation to human rights, the environment, refugees and tax avoidance, it contained some very regressive provisions regarding the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). Sinn Féin is committed to Irish neutrality, and ensuring that any decisions taken with regard to security and defence are taken at a national level. As this report is aimed at exporting these decisions to intergovernmental meetings held behind closed doors, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it sheds light on some of the crucial social issues such as poverty, lack of access to education or healthcare that concern millions of people around the world. In the context of the EU 2015 Report on Policy Coherence for Development it is rightly pointed out that a proactive and collective action from the European Union as a whole is needed if we want our methods to be effective. I also agree that there are also parts of our Policy Coherence for Development that need to be improved and where cooperation with the developing countries can be stepped up in order to achieve our common goals more effectively.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The biennial report on policy coherence for development, drawn up in the DEVE Committee, takes stock of the progress reported by the European Commission in this area. In addition, the report also aims to identify ways of improving existing European coherence mechanisms and to stimulate debate on this concept at Union level. The amendments of the 5-Star Movement, which call for greater coordination in bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries, as well as greater transparency and control of the investments of European companies in the various developing countries, have been widely included in the compromises. I therefore fully support the report and I voted in favour of it in plenary.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from a vote on this report as it included some of provision not directly linked, in my view, to development policy itself and its coherence with other Union’s policies. It mainly called for greater harmonisation of migration and asylum policies with international partners and single common asylum and immigration policies within the EU. Also, I could not agree with the statement that trade liberalisation is not positive for a poverty eradication and has negative effects on sustainable development. I believe exactly the opposite, and although I am convinced that there is a constant need for policy coherence in development area, I could not support this report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Development policies in third countries play a major role in the work of the European Union, which is the main donor on the international stage. In order to make action in these countries more effective, however, there needs to be a better understanding of coherence between development policies (PSC). The European Union and the OECD were among the first to bring this issue to the attention of key international players such as the United States, Japan and the BRICS countries so that there is agreement on the concept of PSC needed to define policies and actions for action. The migration crisis can be an important moment in the implementation of European development policy and in order to deal more fully with the root causes of the phenomenon: in this sense, coherence between foreign, trade, economic and fiscal policies is needed. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that policy coherence must be the basis for action by the EU and other international actors towards third countries.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline the significant progress in the coherence of development policy applicable to the EU's external action. The priority for the EU should be to stabilise its neighbours.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the coherence of development policy is a useful instrument to focus on the prospects for the European economy and growth, but also to understand the dysfunctions that are presented and called upon to resolve. I believe that the results of such reports are important and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as the Council conclusions on the Commission's fifth biennial report, adopted in October 2015, underline that the PSC will be an important part of the EU's contribution to achieving the wider objective of coherence of sustainable development policies (PSC). In addition to taking stock of the progress reported by the European Commission and identifying areas for improving existing European PSC mechanisms, the report aims to boost the debate on the future of this concept at EU level. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development represents a unique opportunity to address the interrelated challenges of poverty eradication and sustainable development. The PSC remains both a political and an economic imperative for the European Union.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current European Development Framework does not have the necessary mechanisms to prevent and remedy inconsistencies arising from policies conducted by the European Union. I agree with calling for a debate at European level on the coherence of development policies (PSC) so that they are fully integrated into the Eu ropean Union's decision-making process. I also believe that we need to improve institutional coordination, so that the Member States include the PSC in a legally binding act and define an action plan to this effect.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, of which the main objective is to take stock of the progress made, identify areas to improve existing EU mechanisms on PCD, and stimulate the debate about the future of the concept at EU level. The previous EP reports have played a pivotal role in advancing the concept of PCD by institutionalising a standing Rapporteur on PCD in the Committee on Development, affirming that PCD is a matter for which the EP is politically responsible (as co-legislator and in its role as the democratically elected institution), and putting forward concrete proposals to operationalise further the concept at EU level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through Policy Coherence with a Development Perspective, the Union seeks to take account of development objectives in all policies that may affect developing countries, thereby minimising contradictions and generating synergies between its different policies in order to benefit those countries and increase the effectiveness of development cooperation. In the context of the fifth biennial EU report on PCD, the European Parliament once again proposes a set of concrete recommendations in the fields of trade and finance, food security, climate change and migration, taking into account the recent refugee crisis that is rife with Europe. I support the Dan Preda Report and the recommendations expressed therein, and it is only with a coherent and strong Cooperation Policy that we can achieve the new goals of sustainable development and poverty eradication.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against because, however well-intentioned,  the thinking in this report is economically illiterate and would waste taxpayers’ money.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Coherence of development policies is an important contribution by the European Union to the implementation of sustainable development policies. However, it should be considered that this European commitment should be put into practice by adopting wide-ranging measures and synergies between EU development and non-development policies. It is necessary to optimise the use of existing instruments in order to ensure efficient and systematic implementation of policy coherence for development. I voted in favour of this report because it is a useful tool for raising awareness of the subject of the PSC, and I hope that the debate on the PSC will take shape in the future.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree the EU needs greater harmonisation of migration and asylum policies, both within the Union itself and with its international partners, something we have been harping on about for years. A truly efficient and holistic migration and asylum policy has to fully integrate EU internal and external policies, in particular within EU working structures underlining the importance of developing a single common asylum and immigration policy. But unless we have an inclusive approach to tackle the root causes of migration that are closely linked to development in order to achieve a sustainable settlement of the current migration crisis, the situation will hardly improve. The EU and its Member States remain the most important Aid for Trade donor in the world with EUR 11.7 billion in 2013. I agree that we need to improve the monitoring and implementation of its objectives in all EU external action, including in EU-funded projects at country level.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must ensure the coherence of its development policies (PSC), working to ensure that there are strong synergies between development objectives and other European policies. The report before us is intended to improve the coherence of European development policies, which has often been the subject of debate.  The Union's commitment to policy coherence for development is mainly based on issues such as trade, the environment, climate change, security, agriculture, the social dimension, employment, decent work, migration and energy. Europe must improve coherence at regional, national and European level and must increase its potential in the production and use of knowledge in order to provide concrete solutions to the challenges it faces today. With regard to this report, we have tabled a number of amendments and we have had the opportunity to engage with more NGOs, and our expectations are directed towards greater coherence in bilateral agreements with third countries. I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The principle of coherence for development, first enshrined as European legislation in 1992, states that no Union policy, whether commercial, economic or migration, can be contrary to international development objectives.   Despite considering it positive, I have not been able to support this report by containing a constant link between security and development and, further inclusion of the Union's External Action Service in development policies. It would also have been necessary for all references to the need for assessments on the impacts of Union policies on third countries to be in line with making them binding and mandatory.  On the other hand, I do not share his approach to the migration phenomenon, focusing on security-related aspects and not on the human right that everyone has to migrate.  However, the report contains positive elements such as the need to improve coordination between the Union institutions and also between them and the Member States in order to improve compliance with this principle, which should be the central axis of any Union policy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon included for the first time the legal obligation to pursue policy coherence for development, further strengthening it between the EU's internal and external policies. The adoption of the 2030 Agenda introduces a single set of development objectives, surpassing the donor-beneficiary model. The EU should therefore take a leading role in promoting a universal agenda that shifts the concept towards sustainable development. The report introduces important innovations, which must be supported, including a closer link between development policies and the Sustainable Development Goals and greater involvement of local and regional governments and civil society organisations. In particular, I am very much in favour of an ex ante impact assessment, which can become an important tool in defining strategies and in the approach to be taken in the future to the issue of migrants and refugees and in trying to build mechanisms that can limit or stem the recurrence of humanitarian crises at source.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Policy coherence for development will be an important part of the EU's contribution to achieving the broader objective of fostering sustainable development policies. Although the EU has often reaffirmed its political commitment to this political coherence, the challenge still facing the Union lies in how to implement this commitment.  I voted to focus policy coherence in favour of development on the field of foreign policy, given that the refugee crisis and the absence of stability in the EU's neighbourhood call into question the very fundamental principles of the EU. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development represents a unique opportunity to address the interconnected problems of poverty eradication and sustainable development.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Through policy coherence for development, the EU seeks to include development objectives in all its policies that could have an impact on developing countries. This is to minimise contradictions and build synergies between different EU policies and to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation for the benefit of developing countries. The European Commission, on the basis of its two-year report on PCDs, monitors progress in cohesion policy for development in the EU and its Member States. The latest report (published in August 2015) covers both cross-cutting and thematic issues and presents examples of progress in PCD in various policy areas. The European Parliament has maintained its support for PCDs. The report makes concrete proposals to strengthen political engagement in practice. The report plays an increasingly important role in raising awareness of PCDs in certain policy initiatives. In view of the above, I support the approach to PCD and its improved version in the light of the recently adopted SDGs, but at the same time I stress that we must pay close attention so that the new provision does not become an additional means of regulation and a burden on citizens and businesses. With this in mind, I voted to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the sustainable development goals in developing states and the donor-recipient paradigm. The Lisbon Treaty included for the first time in any treaty the EU´s legal obligation to pursue policy coherence for development (PCD) and further strengthen the overall focus on achieving consistency between the EU´s internal and external policies. Today, there is an increasing consensus on the need to move beyond this paradigm. The adoption of the 2030 Agenda challenges this vision by establishing a single, universal set of development goals applicable to all, overcoming the donor-recipient paradigm. This report proposes measures by which the EU should take the lead in promoting a universal PCD agenda that moves the concept forward towards sustainable development. I agree with this approach and thus I supported it with my vote.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which could potentially add additional regulatory burdens for Member States in addition to passing through amendments on certain issues which I cannot support. Member States themselves provide the best means to address these issues, rather than an EU top-down approach.  I also note that supporting attempts to tackle poverty and encourage development through aid, trade and investment is a key issue and the UK is playing an important role in supporting these efforts through continuing to meet its aid budget targets and working closely with its international partners.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current context in which the European Union is facing the refugee crisis, I believe that it is important to strengthen the link between migration and development policies in order to address the root causes of this phenomenon. I believe that the European Union should use all the tools at its disposal to address migration and hence the root causes of migration by ensuring that EU migration policies are compatible with poverty reduction policies.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report takes stock of the European Commission's progress on its development policies and identifies areas and mechanisms for better coherence of European development policies (CPD). The CPD aims to take development goals into account in all policies that could have an impact on developing countries. The aim is to minimize contradictions and create synergies between the different EU policies so that they benefit developing countries and increase the effectiveness of development cooperation. The report stresses the need to develop and promote this coherence of development policies. Considering that, without coherence, development policies have a very limited effect and that it is the duty of the European Union to participate effectively in global development efforts, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development takes stock of progress and makes concrete recommendations on the following areas, considered to be priorities: climate change, food security, migration, security, trade and finance. I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the Union's foreign policy in order to stabilise the situation in the vicinity of the Union.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'Development policy is one of the most important areas of foreign policy for the European Union and its Member States. Europe's contribution to international development is not only the level of the EU development aid budget (ODA), but also the efficiency with which it is spent. The N-VA delegation is therefore pleased that the report underlines the added value of policy coherence. However, it considers that the report lacks focus by certain paragraphs. For example, the proposed taxes on financial transactions would increase the costs of Belgian companies to finance themselves, thereby harming their competitiveness. In addition, N-VA is sceptical about the creation of an intergovernmental body for international cooperation in the field of taxation. Fiscal policy is, after all, one of the national competences. Finally, it believes that stricter recommendations for boosting the business world's own responsibility for corporate social responsibility are more realistic than developing internationally binding frameworks. The N-VA delegation therefore abstained from voting on this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015 before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In this text, development serves as a pretext for a new scope of EU powers and resources. This report, above all ideological, does not question the notion of development. It does not take stock of 30 years of failures in the PROMOTION by the EU, with the IMF and the World Bank of models not showing conclusive results. It encourages the Committee on Development and Parliament to continue the EU's support for the development policies of UN agencies and programmes. Finally, this report itself is in the post-Cotonou post and seems to have no critical vision of the free trade strategy with Africa. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Policy Coherence Programme for Development is of utmost importance because it will make the institutions better co-ordination and more effective in their programmes and policies in developing countries. It is essential that this programme is implemented in all policies related to the achievement of the UN Millennium Declaration implemented in the UN Agenda for Sustainable Development by 2030, because the main problem at international level is the lack of coordination and inconsistency in development policies. Despite the importance, I have decided to abstain on the report on policy coherence for development, as I fear that the implementation of the new programme will increase regulatory measures and impose new burdens on our citizens and businesses.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that poverty, inequality, as well as deprivations in terms of health, education and living, plague many European countries due to the economic crisis. That is why there must be fiscal transparency, accountability of development finance institutions, so as to better monitor money flows, as well as binding climate and renewable energy rules. Nevertheless, we are obliged to vote against the 2015 EU report on the coherence of development policy, since we are in favour of a traditional society that does not defend LGBT rights or support an immigration refugee policy, at all costs.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "This report highlights the importance of all EU policies contributing to the union's development policy objectives and to achieving the international sustainable development goals. Unfortunately, the report highlights things that, in my opinion, are not fundamentally seen as a problem for international development. In my opinion, it is bad that the report highlights free trade as problematic for poverty alleviation and highlights, for example, international financial transaction tax as a positive option. I voted against these negative elements.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Council conclusions on the Fifth Biennial Report of the Commission on Policy Coherence (PCD), adopted in October 2015, highlighted that PCD will be an important element of the EU's contribution to achieving the broader objective of policy coherence for sustainable development.
