While the Union has often reaffirmed its political commitment to PCD, the challenge remains related to how to achieve that commitment in practice. In addition to taking stock of the progress reported by the European Commission and identifying areas for improving EU PCD mechanisms, this report aims to stimulate debate on the future of this concept at Union level.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. This reason alone is enough to refuse the report

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report analyses the European Commission's fifth biennial report on Policy Coherence for Development (PCD). It focuses on trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security, highlighting THE EU's foreign policy, taking into account the refugee crisis. Advocating fair principles and objectives, such as combating poverty and exclusion, ends up giving an excessive, not innocent or neutral focus to the private sector in areas such as health and education services, the promotion and protection of children's rights or the promotion of gender equality. The report lacks reference to the instruments that promote the cycle of increasing impoverishment, dependence and subordination of developing countries, as well as to the relationships of asymmetric interdependence, typical of globalized capitalism, which generate unequal development on a global scale. This is the case of foreign debt. Official Development Assistance is crucial and should increase, even in line with commitments made. But it's not enough. Nor hides the disastrous effects of trade liberalisation, the deregulation of the financial system, tax havens, etc., without forgetting the attempt to export and impose models of economic and political organisation, which disregard the sovereignty, needs and legitimate choices of developing countries.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ the report included some very positive issues and therefore I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is already the European Commission's fifth report on European policy coherence in this particular case. Since 2005, the European Union has been constantly trying to improve the implementation of the coherence of individual European policies. Improving the implementation of PCD will require an increase in existing financial resources and staff. The contact points in national ministries and EU delegations should be allocated the necessary resources to implement national and European strategies on policy coherence. Most contact points in EU delegations do not have the necessary capacity to work exclusively on PCD-related issues. The European Parliament resolution in question addresses five priority areas. These are, in particular, trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which does not make any substantial changes to a framework of 'empasses' of the Union's development policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that poverty, inequality, as well as deprivations in terms of health, education and living, plague many European countries due to the economic crisis. That is why there must be fiscal transparency, accountability of development finance institutions, so as to better monitor money flows as well as binding climate and renewable energy rules. Nevertheless, I am obliged to vote against the 2015 EU report on the coherence of development policy, since I am in favour of a traditional society that does not defend LGBT rights or support an immigration refugee policy, at all the costs it entails.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which is now more needed than ever, considering the adoption of the new 17 SDGs (Sustainable Development Goals) in the Framework of the Agenda 2030. Today the implementation of the principle of policy coherence requires solid political commitment at all levels, adequate institutional mechanisms, and willingness to use them, with the ultimate goal to avoid pursuing policies that may have negative effects on the well-being of people in developing countries, the respect of their human rights and the protection of the environment. We need more policy coherence in external and internal policies and a revision of the political impact of our policies not only abroad but also at home, in order to ensure that national policies do not affect developing countries in a negative way and, ultimately, that our resources are spent in a coordinated and efficient way.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report convinced that development policies are essential and essential, as well as a responsibility of all EU countries. In 2015, there was positive development policy development as the Sustainable Development Goals were adopted. Now it's time to move from words to deeds. From the EU we must continue to work to improve the effectiveness and coherence of pro-development policies.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on the 2015 EU report on the coherence of development policies, as I consider it essential and useful to open a debate on this issue in the European Council, in order to facilitate an inter-institutional debate both at European and Member State level. As we will recall, the Treaty of Lisbon provides that any legal obligation assumed at international level within the framework of the Union's objectives is consistent with development policies (PSC). However, today it is more necessary than ever to go beyond this paradigm, since the adoption of the 2030 Agenda envisages establishing a single and universal set of objectives and therefore overcoming the donor-recipient paradigm on which the Union's development policy has settled, in order to promote an agenda on the coherence of development policy based on sustainable development.  I strongly supported the S&D Group's point of view based on a strong link between the coherence of EU development policies and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs), substantial involvement of local and regional authorities and organised civil society. Only greater coherence between EU policies will achieve the Agenda 2030 SDRs and thus the definitive eradication of poverty in developing countries.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I abstained from voting on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The report sets many correct priorities, but it clearly goes too far in some areas – for example, in the area of taxation or gender policy. All the more I miss clear emphasis on greater EU project and significantly less budget support in developing countries.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Although the EU has repeatedly reaffirmed its political commitment to policy coherence for development, it still faces the challenge of putting this commitment into practice. The aim of the report is to make further progress in this area.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which includes a stronger linkage between policy coherence for development (PCD) and sustainable development goals (SDGs). Greater involvement for local and regional governments, as well as civil society organisations, is particularly welcome. This is another example where the EU can, and should, take the lead in promoting a universal PCD agenda - with sustainable development being the key goal.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Full support for this report on the coherence of development policies, which has become essential for creating synergies between development cooperation and other policies to strengthen the action that the Union and the Commission already take mainly through the policy of the Funds and Cohesion. On this front, we also need a more pragmatic and timely approach to address in a timely manner not only the objectives already outlined in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, but above all the challenges that everyday life poses to us today. I am talking, firstly, about the issue of migrants, about the exodus from south to north of thousands of people seeking peace and rights in the first place. The refugee crisis and destabilisation in the EU's neighbourhood are questioning the foundations of the EU itself and I, as an Italian and Sicilian, live in daily contact with this phenomenon. I believe it is extremely urgent that, in addition to the five priority areas already identified (trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security), a system should be found to harmonise and strengthen the Community's efforts in the field of reception and migration policies.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the coherence of development policies is never just a moralist text that announces great intentions without ever questioning the failure of development policies in recent decades. While some principles seem to be struck at the corner of common sense (e.g. aid in the setting of populations through development), this report nevertheless has obvious anti-sovereignist impulses: the adoption of a "binding legal act" to integrate Member States into the CPD, in particular.  On the other hand, the reference to 'new budgetary appropriations' makes it clear that it is, once again, the Member States that will have to go to the cash register, and by no means the readjustment of European policies. For these reasons, I objected to this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the Union must take the lead in promoting policy coherence for development, as Article 208 of the Lisbon Treaty points out, we voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission to effectively increase its efforts through concrete measures the coordination and coherence of its external policies to align with the Objectives of the Union (eradication of poverty and reduction of inequalities).

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It includes stronger links between policy coherence for development (PCD) and sustainable development goals (SDGs), greater involvement for local and regional governments and civil society organisations. This is another example where the EU can, and should, take the lead in promoting a universal PCD agenda - with sustainable development being the key goal.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I welcome PCD e—training for the delegations as a positive development. To involve the EU delegations more, not only in reporting but also in implementation, the issue should be on the agenda of the yearly meeting of EU Heads of Delegations in Brussels.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report contains several positive elements but has very problematic issues, such as the association of development policies with the CFR (Common Security and Defence Policy). There are no key positions such as increasing funds for development and also that the wealth that exists in third countries must be exploited by them and not by foreign states and companies. Some groups have tried to further weaken the text with the changes they have proposed in plenary. In view of the above, we considered this abstention to be an appropriate attitude.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on Policy Cohesion for Development as it is a key element for delivering and achieving the new sustainable development agenda. The sustainable development goals that apply to both developed and developing countries need to be comprehensively integrated into the EU’s decision-making process at both internal and external levels. In particular, I was pleased that the report emphasised the need for institutional coordination both between EU institutions and with Member States. I was also pleased that the report acknowledged that the EU is facing its biggest refugee crisis since World War II and stressed the need to strengthen the link between migration and development policies in order to address the root causes of the crisis. I believe that the EU should use all the tools at its disposal to tackle the crisis, including security and diplomatic instruments.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to the final document.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of mr Preda's report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. I believe that this report touches on one of the most important issues with regard to development policy, because it is extremely important that the policy actions we take are consistent with the objectives we have previously set. I am convinced that this is a prerequisite for sustainable development. I also believe that the report correctly identifies priority areas for development policy, in particular with regard to migration.  Indeed, development policy is undoubtedly one of the key tools for solving the migration crisis, and I agree with the rapporteur that eu migration policy must be in line with policies aimed at reducing poverty and must effectively and effectively support economic, political and social development in partner countries.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A European Council meeting regarding the PCD before the publication of the Commission’s report in 2017 is instrumental. The PCD must revolve closer to the SDG and it is clear that governments and civil society must get more involved in this process.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the 2015 EU PCD report, and I believe that the European Parliament should play a key role in promoting this important topic. Clear coherence between development policies and sustainable development programmes is needed. The SDGs should be integrated into the decision-making process at internal and external level. European development policy needs to have clear objectives to actually achieve progress as a result of European aid. There are a number of instruments in this regard that should be used more efficiently, such as, for example, a better impact assessment. Greater efforts to harmonise development policies should be made not only by the European institutions but also by Member States, i.e. presidents of governments and heads of state. Development policy should be effective and this is not possible without coherence between all policies from trade to agricultural. It is important to pay attention to trade policy and financial investment, food security, climate change, investment in improving health conditions, humanitarian aid and other aspects of EU action.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text does not question the concept of development, does not question the current ratio of the populations of the former Southern states to this concept, does not take stock of 30 years of failures in the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models without conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month.   In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. That reason alone is enough to vote against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Policy coherence for development (PCD) is a simple but powerful premise: no policies should detract from a country’s international development goals. This PCD report takes into account the outcomes of the September 2015 UN Summit, where the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was formally adopted, including a target to ‘enhance policy coherence for sustainable development’ (target17.14). Hence, the report reiterates that PCD is a key element for delivering and achieving the new sustainable development agenda and calls for proactive action based on a common understanding of PCD, while pointing out that a HHRR-based approach should lead to a deepened understanding of PCD.  Moreover the report acknowledges the impact of trade and investment issues and recalls that trade liberalisation is not per se positive for poverty eradication, since it can have negative effects on sustainable development; and notes the importance of development effectiveness and of gender equality and focused on migration-related issues. Nonetheless, the report contains some references to the security and development and poverty eradication nexus that, although being framed on the PCD logic, are problematic for EH Bildu as we aren’t in favour of the CFSP and militarisation in general; and hence we have abstained in the final vote.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report, which takes stock of the European Union's actions to promote the coherence of its actions with the objectives of development policy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur links the migration crisis with the call for greater policy coherence in the interests of progress. It sometimes supports the European Agenda on Migration, which is currently being implemented, and calls for a harmonised migration and asylum policy. It also pushes for a European response to the refugee crisis, which must not be geared solely to security concerns. However, these aspects must be criticised. I therefore do not agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Following the signing of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) last year, the need for development principles to run through all EU policy is greater than ever. The principle of Policy Coherence for Development (PCD) represents the EU’s commitment to take account of the impact of its policies on international development. Despite the difficulties to implement PCD, the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies among EU policies, and this report represents the commitment to uphold and enhance the principle of PCD in light of the SDGs.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the European Parliament's resolution on the EU report on policy coherence for development for 2015. I am glad that we are currently focused on sustainable development issues. It shows me that hopefully we'll finally be able to solve the problems that burn us comprehensively and without the pink glasses. In the final text, for example, there is a point which states that: 'trade liberalisation is not in itself positive in terms of reducing poverty and inequalities, as it could have negative consequences for sustainable development'. Translated into colloquial Czech, this means that if developing countries open their markets to multinational corporations, they run a significant risk of being looted, and poverty and inequality will increase in society as poor ghettos far from luxury residences are built. I also very much appreciated that the resolution calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to participate actively in the work of the UN Human Rights Council in order to make multinational supranational companies accountable for human rights violations, but there is still a lot of work to be done to correct the fact that 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty and are not getting proper healthcare, education and living standards. But this is a step in the right direction.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the 2015 EU report on policy coherence for development. The Commission document was published in August 2015, before the adoption of the UN Development Agenda for 2030. The EU was a co-legislator involved in the development of the PCD concept. The report summarises the progress made so far and initiates a debate on future directions.  It analyses five priority areas: trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security. Given the migration crisis, stability in the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority.  I consider it important to cooperate more closely between the EU institutions and the Member States. I agree with the reporter's suggestion that a European Council meeting on PCD should be held before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017 to promote interinstitutional and national debate within the EU. It is necessary to define the PCD commitments of each EU institution.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – This report is an elusive thing cleverly wrapped in a communication robe, the essence of which is that there is no concrete assessment of what needs to be done and, of course, of what resources are required from whom to achieve the objectives. This is largely true of the UN's 2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development. There remains continued regret for the "little progress made in implementing it" style, and the fact that few studies have been done and are controversial. We finally need concrete solutions to the real problems.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against paragraph 30 of the REPORT on policy coherence for development, as it provides for the financing of development aid from carbon taxes and fees for the exploitation of natural resources. Understanding the need for clean environment and alternative energy sources and the search for new sources of funding for the necessary development aid, the excessive burden on EU countries in this regard cannot be accepted, as this puts European countries in a situation of low competitiveness with economies that do not have or have a lower level of regulation and burden.  Paragraph 30 is particularly disadvantage Polish, which bases its energy policy on coal and its extraction from national resources. Therefore, the proposals contained in paragraph 30, which are neutral for nuclear-friendly and green-sounding countries, the Polish delegation always rejects.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because the EU does not have to use development to gain power at the expense of states.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the 2015 report on policy coherence for development. It is a naïve text that does not question the concept of development, does not question the current relationship of the populations of the former Southern states to this notion, does not take stock of 30 years of failures of the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models without conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month. In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. That reason alone is enough to deny the report.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The Committee on Development and the European Parliament support the development policies of the United Nations (UN) agencies and programmes through this text. It turns out that the substance of the text is turned to an ideological vision of development and dilutes the very conception of the term into a demagogic concept. Development is above all a public policy that must make improvements in some parts of the world. However, the latest report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows that the UN's development models have been failing for 30 years. Thus, the meaning of the text is biased and tends mainly to demand budgets and resources from the Member States. I refused to agree with this text by voting AGAINST.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The principle of coherence for development, first enshrined as European legislation in 1992, states that no Union policy, whether commercial, economic or migration, can be contrary to international development objectives.   Despite considering it positive, I have not been able to support this report by containing a constant link between security and development and, further inclusion of the Union's External Action Service in development policies. It would also have been necessary for all references to the need for assessments on the impacts of Union policies on third countries to be in line with making them binding and mandatory.  On the other hand, I do not share his approach to the migration phenomenon, focusing on security-related aspects and not on the human right that everyone has to migrate.  However, the report contains positive elements such as the need to improve coordination between the Union institutions and also between them and the Member States in order to improve compliance with this principle, which should be the central axis of any Union policy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report criticises developing countries for using "tax incentives and tax exemptions to attract or retain investors, leading to harmful tax competition and a race for the lowest possible taxes" while celebrating subsidy "cohesion policies". I think we need to give developing countries the freedom to cut taxes and entice investors, instead of teaching them how to draw subsidies. On the contrary, I consider tax competition to be healthy. The report also calls for new taxes: "it is necessary to consider innovative and diversified sources of financing, such as a financial transaction tax, a carbon tax, a ticket surcharge, annuities from natural resources". I am against introducing such new taxes.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Council conclusions on the European Commission's fifth biennial report, adopted in October 2015, highlighted that PCD would contribute to achieving the EU's broader objective of this topic. This report looks at progress and identifies areas where existing policy coherence mechanisms need to be improved, but also seeks to stimulate debate on the future of this concept. PCD is a key element for achieving and delivering a new agenda for sustainable development, and seeks a proactive approach based on consensus. The concept of PCD is primarily a European concept, but seeks to find a common universal approach to make progress globally in integrating this concept. The rapporteur welcomes the new organisation of the Juncker Commission and the establishment of a group of Commissioners dealing with external relations. The EU needs to improve a results-oriented approach, define quality targets and set clearer indicators of PCD. The European Parliament is an important factor and should play an important role in promoting PCD policies, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Promoting sustainable development is one of the key aspects of The European Union's policy, which can actually be implemented at all levels of its functioning. Consequently, policy coherence for development, which includes things such as migration policy, trade and finance, private sector development, food security, climate change, security and a number of other things, is very important. I therefore welcome the adoption of the regular report. Since effective policy coherence for development is not really possible without correlation of efforts with foreign policy realities and thus with foreign partners, it is quite welcome that the role of Union delegations in other parts of the world has increased considerably, particularly in terms of information. Given the importance of development policy for the Union's internally and externally feasible activities, as well as the fact that it is the EU that is the world's largest financial donor to developing countries, I support that policy coherence for development become a legally binding aspect of the policies to be pursued by the EU and its Member States.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union and its Member States are the world's leading aid providers. They provide more than half of the funds to help developing countries. This report on policy coherence for development (CPD) takes stock of the progress the Commission has made and identifies areas where the CPD mechanisms in place in the EU can be improved.   Promoting a better articulation between the CPD and the sustainable development goals, creating synergies between development policies and other EU policies, and increasing resources dedicated to the evidence-based analysis of the CPD are all effective ways to improve European development policy. The broad contribution of the Socialist Group has enabled us to draw up a quality report, in line with our positions on sustainable development, which is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the 2015 EU report on development policy coherence, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report takes stock of the European Union's development policies in the run-up to the UN summits. We do not like the strong ideological connotation of the report, which also advocates a strengthening of the prerogatives of the European Union. In addition, it avoids the root causes of disparities in economic development around the world. Responsibility lies with the European Union, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, in particular - the latest IMF report amply demonstrates this.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU's 2015 report on policy coherence for development (PSC). The PSC is a key element of the EU's contribution to achieving the objective of policy coherence for sustainable development, and also contributes to the consolidation of the rule of law and impartial institutions. The coherence of development policies is indeed one of the European Union's primary objectives in order to increase the effectiveness of its development aid, and has become a necessary instrument for seeking synergies between development cooperation and other policies, as well as for correcting existing inconsistencies. In order for the PSC to spread internationally and not just remain a European concept, greater efforts are needed on the part of the EU, taking the lead in promoting a universal agenda for the PSC and working towards a common approach so as to make the concept universal.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the 2015 report on policy coherence for development. The report contains several key ideas with which I fully agree, such as the fact that impact assessment is an important tool for achieving policy coherence for development, but development impact assessments and impacts on developing countries are not very numerous. Referring to the 2030 Agenda, the ambitious targets set, such as food security for the whole world, the complete elimination of hunger and the prevention of all forms of malnutrition, are recalled. Furthermore, it is necessary to link the impact of EU policies on developing countries, e.g. in the case of agriculture, trade or energy. I also welcome the commitment to promote sustainable and agro-ecological practices. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's report on development policy coherence published last August concerned the Agenda for Sustainable Development until 2030, part of which is development policy coherence. Development Policy Coherence (SSP) is an EU initiative that has yet to spread internationally. It is mainly based on the idea that developed countries should be friendly to developing countries and not introduce policies that are hostile to them. Our aim must be to disseminate such policies at international level. Since the issue is purely political, there should be an effort to cooperate with joint programming and coordination on the part of the Union, so that recommendations on SSP issues are directly introduced by the Member States. The 2015 report is a positive step in the right direction to improve legislation on the issue. At the same time, new tools for promoting the SSP have begun to be created, such as impact assessments of development policies. In voting in favour of this initiative, I consider it a priority area, with regard to the SSP, the area of trade, security and migration with the ultimate aim of stabilising the union's neighbouring countries.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report outlines the need for policy coherence for development (PHE). There is no objection to this in principle, but the current migration crisis is also analysed far from any reality. I cannot therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the provisions set out in the EP report on 'EU 2015 for development coherence', in which the European Parliament evaluates the report submitted by the European Commission. The EC presents such a report every 2 years and provides an overview of the various policy areas – trade, migration, health, climate change – and the impact of these policies on the development of third countries.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission carried out an evaluation of its policies for the development of third countries, shortly before the adoption by the United Nations of the 2030 sustainable development agenda. This report supports the work of the United Nations, including a binding mechanism for respecting human rights by multinationals, and calls in the EU for an independent system for registering complaints from individuals or communities affected by EU policies. He criticises the all-liberal EU agreements and calls on the Commission to go beyond the simple principle of corporate social responsibility, to develop coherent development policies for the eradication of poverty, quality social services and diversification of domestic markets, despite the 'demands of investors and international financial markets'. It supports far more ambitious targets than COP21, particularly for public investments in renewable energy. Although the report does not denounce the growing weight of private actors and the common European security and defence policy at the expense of development aid, I therefore vote in support.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In the run-up to the UN development summits, this text is an encouragement to continue EU support for the development policies of UN agencies and programmes. Without a critical examination of past failures in free trade, this report aims to free up new funds at the expense of Member States. Without depth of reflection on the very notion of development, the text pursues a stale logic. I voted against this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the 2015 EU Report on policy coherence for development. The European Union must take the lead in promoting Policy Coherence for Development (PCD), as it is a key element in achieving the new sustainable development agenda. We must move towards sustainable development and poverty eradication. The European Parliament has a very important role in promoting PCD, giving it priority on its agenda, fostering exchanges of views with partner countries and promoting dialogue with civil society.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I give my support to this report, as it both analyses the current situation with regards to policy coherence and seeks to stimulate the debate about the future of policy coherence for sustainable development at the EU level.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The 2015 report is an important part of the EU's contribution to greater policy coherence for sustainable development. While the Union regularly reaffirms its political commitment to the CPD, it has yet to find ways to put this commitment into practice. This report not only takes stock of the progress made by the Commission, but also identifies areas where the mechanisms for policy coherence in the service of development in place in the Union can be improved. There is a need to stimulate debate on the future of the concept of policy coherence at EU level, particularly within the framework of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda adopted by the United Nations last September.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The formally adopted 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted in New York at the 2015 Summit, aims to strengthen policy coherence for sustainable development. Ensuring that policies in developed countries are more development-friendly and do not have a negative impact on developing countries remains a key aspect within the Union. However, there is now a growing consensus on the need to go beyond this model. I am of the opinion that the Union should be more proactive in promoting a universal programme on policy coherence for development. Efforts should be made to establish the universal nature of this concept and to be seen at international level. I therefore very much welcome the discussions in the Union on PCD under the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in order to clarify how it could be included in a more universal concept of PCD, while involving international key actors. I consider policy coherence for development to be an important political issue and it is therefore essential to raise awareness in this area. This is closely linked to the allocation of the necessary funds and quality staff. In view of the above, I agree with the report in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on policy coherence for development because I believe that despite the difficulties to implement PCD, the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies among EU policies. A specific European Council meeting on PCD before the publication of the next Commission’s report in 2017 would contribute to raise awareness of PCD and to better define the responsibilities of the different actors involved.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission publishes its report on policy coherence for development (PCD) every two years. The most recent fifth report was published in August 2015, shortly before the adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development at the UN Summit in New York in September, which includes the objective of "strengthening the coherence of sustainable development policies". Since 2013, the commitment of EU Member States to PCD has increased significantly, according to a report by the Committee on Development. The resolution for 2016 analyses and makes specific recommendations in five priority areas (trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security). At the same time, the report points out that the refugee crisis and the uncertainty in the EU's neighbourhood are fundamentally questioning the EU (e.g. European solidarity and the Schengen system), so stabilising the EU neighbourhood should be the EU's top priority and the PCD should focus on external action. It notes that, given the combined role of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, significant progress has been made with regard to the use of PCD in EU external action.  I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's fifth biennial report on PCD has highlighted that policy coherence for development (PCD) will be an important CONTRIBUTION of the EU to achieving the broader objective of policy coherence for sustainable development (PCDS). The adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development represents a new challenge for the achievement of PCD, as it establishes a single and universal set of development objectives applicable to all. I believe that the EU should take the lead in promoting PCD and that the current European development framework lacks effective mechanisms to prevent and correct the inconsistencies resulting from the policies pursued by the EU. It is important to note that the sustainable development objectives concern both developed and developing countries and should be incorporated into the Union's decision-making process internally and externally. I support the rapporteur's recommendation on the importance to be given to the Union's foreign policy in view of the refugee crisis and the instability in the Union's neighbourhood, which calls into question the fundamentals of the Union itself, such as European solidarity and the Schengen system, making external action a priority area within the PCD.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a naïve text that does not question the notion of development, does not question the current relationship of the populations of the former Southern states to this notion, does not take stock of 30 years of failures in the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models without conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month.   In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. I must therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as following the signing of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) last year the need for development principles to run through all EU policy is greater than ever. The principle of Policy Coherence for Development (PCD) represents the EU’s commitment to take account of the impact of its policies on international development. Despite the difficulties to implement PCD, the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies among EU policies, and this report – supported by all sides of the Parliament – represents the commitment to uphold and enhance the principle of PCD in light of the SDGs.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, on the coherence of development policies, gives us an overview of the Actions of the European Union to promote the coherence of its actions with the objectives of development policy. In particular, I support the positions of the rapporteur, who calls on the Commission and the Member States to do more to help developing countries as well as the least developed countries, particularly through aid-for-trade programmes, which are still insufficient today.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague PREDA's report. In August 2015, the European Commission (EC) published its fifth biennial report on policy coherence for development (CPD), shortly before the adoption of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, which includes the aim of "strengthening the coherence of sustainable development policies". While the Union has frequently reaffirmed its political commitment to the CPD, it has yet to find ways to put this commitment into practice. Previous reports from the European Parliament have played a major role in advancing the concept of the CPD by institutionalising a permanent rapporteur on CPD in the Committee on Development, affirming that the CPD is within the political competence of the European Parliament and putting forward concrete proposals to move forward in the application of this concept at EU level. The main objective of this report is to take stock of the progress made by the European Commission, to identify areas where existing CPD mechanisms in the Union can be improved and to stimulate debate on the future of the concept at EU level.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the 2015 report on policy coherence for development. In accordance with the commitments made with the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Union is moving towards the convergence of Community rules within the framework of a coherent set of policies between them. The report presented today illustrates the progress of the work carried out so far with the aim of bringing about the convergence of European policies, organisational mechanisms in the Union and Europe's development objectives. In this context, the progress made by the European Union in the coherence of policies in twelve areas, such as trade, the environment, climate change, security, agriculture, fisheries, the social dimension of globalisation and employment, migration, research, the information society, transport and finally energy, is underlined. In particular, in the field of trade, the Union aims to promote more effectively the conclusion of economic and trade partnership agreements, as well as the Generalised System of Preferences (known as GSP+) and trade measures, in order to initiate a process of economic integration with developing countries.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report as the EU must play a real leading role in promoting policy coherence for development. In meeting the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, it is of the utmost importance that the Union act proactively with a human rights-based approach, as it is not possible to move towards sustainable development and poverty eradication without overcoming obstacles to the implementation of human rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s 2030 Agenda represents the new framework that should tackle the issue of poverty and should achieve sustainable development. Policy coherence appeared on the EU agenda at the beginning of the 1990s, being institutionalised through the Maastricht Treaty in 1992. I support this report, which aims to further address challenges such as poverty eradication and sustainable development.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting against or in favour of this report, because the themes addressed by it are of great interest to Romania and the EU, but I believe that they must be analysed individually in order to be able to include a greater number of details, opinions and possible strategies for action. Also, although I support some aspects of this report, with regard to certain ideas expressed, I cannot support them in my vote today.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which takes a holed-up position on development policy issues. Developing countries need to be assisted in strengthening their fiscal, financial and public finance management capacities and in curbing illicit financial flows. We should ensure that multinational supranational companies pay taxes in countries where value is obtained or generated. In this respect, the establishment of a new UN-led intergovernmental body to deal with international cooperation in taxation could be useful. It is the EU's task and responsibility to work towards deepening international cooperation in tax matters.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report mentions sub-arguments, such as the current migration crisis, which are analysed far from any reality and draw conclusions that are totally unacceptable.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. There are ways to better use the instruments for the effective and systematic implementation of EU policy coherence for development. Greater involvement of EU delegations is also important, as they often have country-specific information that is still used and valued too little. I also consider it important to focus on the EU's external policy, as stabilising the EU's neighbourhood must be a priority for the EU.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because, however well-intentioned, the thinking in this report is economically illiterate and would waste taxpayers’ money.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to Mr Preda's proposal, I voted in favour because I agree with the need for greater synergy between the objectives of sustainable development and the Union's policies. In my opinion, coherence of development policies is essential in order to pursue the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and therefore greater harmonisation between the PSC and the SDOs seems to me to be appropriate. Similarly, including the PSC in the global debate and promoting the involvement of other key actors can contribute effectively to achieving development goals. Convinced that greater awareness of coherence for development policies at both European and national level and of priority importance, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 663 million people do not have access to drinking water, and that's one in ten people, twice the population of the United States. One third of schools do not have access to drinking water and adequate sanitation. There are more cell phone users in the world than people who have access to the toilet. 795 million people in the world are malnourished, that's one in nine.  Did you know that if women farmers had as much access to resources as men, the number of hungry could be reduced by 150 million. Development policies are among the most important policies of the European Union. The issue of development is not a question of luxury, but of ensuring basic living conditions and fundamental human rights. Eradicate malnutrition and hunger, ensure access to drinking water, ensure adequate sanitation, health protection, education... These are fundamental human rights.  We need to invest in development policies, and the coordination of development policies will certainly contribute to their efficiency. In addition to ensuring basic, it is also important to encourage poor producers and trade in developing countries, and the safety aspect is also important. Integrating development policies and aligning it, as well as linking development aid to humanitarian aid, will contribute to the goals we all pursue, so I supported this resolution, which provides for PCD mechanisms.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is confusingly naïve. It does not question the concept of development, does not question the current ratio of the populations of the recipient states with this concept, does not take stock of thirty years of failures of the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models without conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month. In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union should do much more to ensure greater coherence and synergy of its development policies, both horizontally between different sectors such as trade, agriculture and immigration, and vertically between global, regional and national levels. In addition, it should work to ensure that the other key players on the international stage (the US, Japan and the BRICS countries) also adopt a similar strategy, in order to make the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals truly possible. The Treaty of Lisbon provides for the obligation to pursue the coherence of development policy (PCD) and to strengthen the objective of coherence between the Union's internal and external policies. Today there is a growing consensus on the need to go even further than this paradigm. The adoption of the 2030 Agenda, in fact, establishes a single and universal set of development objectives, applicable to all, that exceeds the donor-beneficiary scheme. The EU should therefore lead the way in promoting a universal PCD agenda, which is aimed at achieving sustainable development. A specific Meeting of the European Council on the PCD, before the publication of the next Commission report in 2017, would make an important contribution to raising awareness of the importance of the PCD and to better defining the responsibilities of the different actors involved.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The idea of PCD was first mentioned in the Union's development policy in 2006. And from then until today it has become an important tool in the union's policy-making, also mentioned in the Lisbon Treaty. The aim of political coherence in the interests of development is to prevent inconsistencies arising from European policies in order to avoid negative consequences for developing countries. I welcome the establishment of a group of Commissioners acting in the field of external relations, and ask that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy report regularly to the Development Committee on the work of this group. I recall the importance of considering the impact of fisheries agreements on food security in developing countries, and call on the EU to contribute to preventing the snatching of arable land by supporting developing countries in implementing the UN voluntary guidelines on responsible land, fisheries and forestry management at national level. I regret that while impact assessments are an important instrument for achieving PCD, development impact assessments remain few and do not adequately take into account the potential impact on developing countries. I hope that the Better Regulation Package and its guidelines will correct this problem by taking account of development and human rights.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Priority areas of development policy are, inter alia, migration and security, trade and finance, food security, health and climate change. In addition to priority areas, In the report, MeP Preda emphasises the importance of establishing EU policies on respect for human rights, the rule of law and the fight against poverty, all with a view to achieving the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. In particular, we call for the coherence of development policy decision-making with the new EU Global Strategy to be presented by High Commissioner Mogherini and the process of revising the Multiannual Financial Framework.  I supported MeP Prede's report, as the refugee crisis and destabilisation in the Neighbourhood of the European Union threaten the foundations of the Union - solidarity and the Schengen system.  It is in the area of external action that the greatest attention should be paid to PCD, and stabilising the situation adjacent to the European Union should be at the top of our priorities.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The magnitude of the current migration crisis has shown us how far a situation first caused by a lack of development in the outside world and its ignoring developed states can go. I therefore voted in favour of the 2015 report on policy coherence for development. It is essential that the European Union implements its policies coherently with its commitments it has made in the past with regard to development aid and assistance. At present, it is clear that the commitments made so far have not been sufficient and that it would be appropriate to create new development concepts and objectives that do not exclusively follow the original paradigm of cooperation. Local and regional administrations, expert groups and civil society organisations need to be even more involved in the assistance process. Furthermore, to ensure deeper coordination between the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States. It is crucial that European countries do not forget their commitment to provide 0.7% of their GNP to official development assistance and ensure the exchange of best cooperation practices. I have also supported a systematic evaluation of the impact of other European Union policies on the food and other security of emerging countries. For example, the poorly designed biofuel policy system in modern countries makes the livelihoods of the poorest on other continents more vulnerable to global climate change at risk.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Social Democrat, I decided to support the European Commission's fifth two-year report on policy coherence for development (SPR), published in August 2015. It is a very important instrument that ensures harmonious development in all parts of the European Union at a similar level. It is a very important concept that uses solidarity between rich EU states and poorer EU states so that there are no major differences in economic development. The EP resolution on the 2016 SPR analyses and formulates specific recommendations on five priority areas (trade and finance, food security, climate change, migration and security). However, the rapporteur proposes that attention should be paid to the EU's external policy, which I agree with in principle, but that any new policy setting for the coming period should be viewed in a comprehensive way, so that the solution to the problem in one area does not arise in another. All EU policies depend on the budget available to the EU. I believe that, in the current circumstances and with increasing demands for European solutions to a number of parallel crises, an overall increase in the EU budget will be needed.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals, 2015 was an important moment in the evolution of the PSC (coherence of development policies). The Sustainable Development Goals have called for a more integrated approach to policy-making, focusing more on coherence. The achievement of the PSC will thus have a very decisive impact on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The PSC, however, is not yet widely used at international level, but remains a purely European concept. The EU and the OECD (Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development) are the forerunners of the CPS debate. In an increasingly interconnected world, efforts must be made towards a common approach in order to make this concept more universal. Therefore, I believe that Parliament should call for a debate on PSC at EU level within the framework of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in order to understand how the PSC can fall within the more universal concept of PSC (coherence of sustainable development policies). For this reason, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Through policy coherence for development, the EU seeks to include development objectives in all its policies that could have an impact on developing countries. This is to minimise contradictions and build synergies between different EU policies and to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation for the benefit of developing countries. The European Commission, on the basis of its two-year report on PCDs, monitors progress in cohesion policy for development in the EU and its Member States. The latest report (published in August 2015) covers both cross-cutting and thematic issues from 2013-15, and presents examples of progress in PCD in various policy areas. However, close attention should be paid to ensure that the new provision does not become an additional means of regulation and a burden on citizens and businesses. I have hereby abstained.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In voting on this report, I rejected proposals that included calls for a common migration and asylum policy. I have long believed that such proposals undermine citizens' trust in the European Union. In this area, the Union must act in a way that does not undermine the foundations of European integration.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Development policy is one of the key areas of action for European external action, with the EU being the world's leading provider of development aid. I voted in favour of this text, which takes stock of the progress made by the European Commission on the coherence of development policies. It is now essential that all the mechanisms of this policy are part of the objective of achieving the new sustainable development agenda.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because, however well-intentioned, the thinking in this report is economically illiterate and would waste taxpayers’ money.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Previous reports by the European Parliament have played a central role in promoting the concept of Policy Coherence for Development (PCD), declaring that this is a matter for which Parliament is politically responsible (as a co-legislator and democratically elected institution) and presenting concrete proposals to implement the concept concretely at EU level. In addition to taking stock of the progress reported by the European Commission and identifying areas for improving EU PCD mechanisms, this report aims to stimulate debate on the future of this concept at Union level with a view to the Sustainable Development Agenda 2030. Some of the priority areas include migration, trade and finance, food security, health, climate change, gender issues or security. As was also expected, there was some controversy in the references to sexual and reproductive rights, in addressing the issue of refugees, the role of the private sector and the use of military means to implement humanitarian development policies. The Socialist Group has succeeded in introducing amendments that mirror its values and yet to reach balanced agreements. Despite the difficulties in implementing PCD, the EU should strive to achieve more synergies between its policies.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, one and a half billion people live in poverty and do not have access to health care, education or a decent income. In order to provide the most effective assistance possible to these people, it is important to ensure a coherence of development policies (CDP), particularly in the context of the design and implementation of the new sustainable development programme.  Through this report, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to consult systematically with human rights organisations at an early stage in the decision-making process. This is an important element given the experience of these players in the field.  The report was also an opportunity for the European Parliament to identify areas it considers to be priorities, namely immigration, trade and finance, food security, climate change and security.  In line with many elements, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question is a large and valuable document illustrating the eu's importance in the world. The Commission and the other institutions are working hard to reduce global poverty, while also ensuring our security. It is even more important to reconcile the efforts of the different EU institutions.  Unfortunately, peaceful efforts are not always successful, as illustrated by the long-running Syrian crisis or the renewable problems of some African countries. After hearing the report, I could only recommend that development professionals work more closely with conflict management specialists to turn the resolved conflicts in a calm, developmental direction. Although I have been missing somewhat in the latter aspect report, this is the only more important deficiency that does not prevent the vote in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's fifth biennial report on development policy coherence (PCD) of August 2015 includes the specific target "improving policy coherence for sustainable development". PCD is an important part of the EU's contribution to achieving the objective of policy coherence for sustainable and inclusive development. While the EU has often reaffirmed its political commitment to PCD, the challenge it still faces is how to make this commitment. Bearing in mind that the refugee crisis and instability in the Union's neighbourhood are creating serious (internal) political problems for the Union itself, external action and very specifically the EDF (European Development Fund) are indispensable tools for the proper implementation of PCD and for the resolution of these new challenges facing the Union. This report aims to take stock of progress made, identify areas to be improved and existing mechanisms in the EU on PCD and encourage debate on the future of this concept, and should therefore take the lead in promoting a universal agenda in this area, which puts this concept at the service of sustainable development, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 Some 1.5 billion people are still living without adequate health care and education. Most of them are women. A low standard of living is not just a problem for developing countries. The EU is facing the worst refugee crisis since the Second World War. The link between migration and development policies must therefore be strengthened. Only in this way can we tackle the causes of international migration, poverty and the instability it causes. In this work, it is very important to ensure consistency between the various measures supporting development. For example, we need to assess how the Union's agricultural and trade policy affects food security in developing countries and the livelihoods of the most disadvantaged people. It is important to have a rule of law and good governance. Such development should also be promoted in developing countries. In particular, an effective, fair and transparent tax system should be promoted. Without tax revenue, public services will not be implemented. The report points out that developing countries have the right to create their own growth strategies. These countries also have a duty to take care of their own citizens as best they can. Developing countries must give priority in their budgets to the creation of functioning health systems. Development aid has not always been the best incentive for this reform work. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the coherence of European development policies and identifies areas where existing mechanisms can be improved. This text is part of the 2030 Sustainable Development Programme and its 17 new targets.  It is a welcome to welcome the public consultation on the roadmap to determine the outcome of policy coherence for development and its impact on developing countries, but also to call on the European Commission to immediately identify inconsistencies and publish an analysis of their cost.  I supported this text which identifies certain priority areas such as immigration, trade, food security, climate change, gender equality and security. In terms of funding, development assistance alone is not enough; new and more diverse sources of funding need to be considered. Finally, the report calls on the Commission and Member States to continue to strengthen the links between humanitarian aid and development cooperation to enable a flexible and more effective response to growing needs in these areas.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of the European Parliament is increasingly important in advancing the concept of policy coherence for development (PSC), the primary objective of the European Union and a key point of the United Nations 2030 Agenda. The report presented to this House on this subject aims to take stock of the progress made by the European Commission in the field of development policies. It also identifies areas in which the existing mechanisms of the PSC can be improved and strengthened. I have chosen to vote in favour of the text presented because I agree with the call for an active Union within the framework of the PSC. Europe has always been a key player in development and in aid to developing third countries. I also agree with the rapporteur's calls for the Commission to make known the inconsistencies and costs in the PSC, as well as to develop appropriate instruments for monitoring the progress made in this area, in order to better assess the impact of European policies in terms of development.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the Union must take the lead in promoting policy coherence for development, as Article 208 of the Lisbon Treaty points out, we voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission to effectively increase its efforts through concrete measures the coordination and coherence of its external policies to align with the Objectives of the Union (eradication of poverty and reduction of inequalities).

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon included for the first time a commitment to seek a consistent policy line in development policy. However, it has proved difficult to implement. That is why the European Union should take the lead and take the lead in the fight to ensure a consistent and coherent policy in this area.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU's 2015 Report on Policy Coherence for Development. It is important that EU development policy has a coherent policy towards the third countries of the South in all areas. Only in this way can we make development policy better and ensure acceptance among the EU population, but also in the developing countries.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The principle of coherence for development, first enshrined as European legislation in 1992, states that no Union policy, whether commercial, economic or migration, can be contrary to international development objectives.   Despite considering it positive, I have not been able to support this report by containing a constant link between security and development and greater inclusion of the Union's External Action Service in development policies. It would also have been necessary for all references to the need for assessments on the impacts of Union policies on third countries to be in line with making them binding and mandatory.  On the other hand, I do not share his approach to the migration phenomenon, focusing on security-related aspects and not on the human right that everyone has to migrate.  However, the report contains positive elements such as the need to improve coordination between the Union institutions and also between them and the Member States in order to improve compliance with this principle which should be the central axis of any Union policy.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. There are 1.5 billion people still living in poverty and lack of health, education and living conditions. This obliges us to act, but it is necessary to do so consistently and consistently. I believe that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is a priority. The 17 universal and indivisible sustainable development goals set out in the Agenda need to be achieved. As is recognized in 15 of these objectives, when addressing the most deprived territories we cannot assume paternalistic positions, in which we define with which models should others act. It is also essential not to torpedo the creation and emergence of endogenous production capacities and it is important to ensure that developing countries are not strongholds of the dumping of products overproduced by our economies. On the other hand, I call for firm action by all to comply with the recent climate agreement reached at COP21. The so-called developed countries must act, thereby preventing the increase in asymmetries and suffering. I believe that this report is a good problem and includes the strategic tools for the implementation of many solutions. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the need for development principles to run through all EU policy is particularly great, especially since the signing of the Sustainable Development Goals in 2015. The principle of Policy Coherence for Development represents the commitment by the EU to take account of the impact of its policies on international development, despite difficulties in its implementation. The EU should make an effort to ensure that there is a greater synergy among EU policies and this report – supported by all sides of the Parliament – represents the commitment to uphold and enhance the principle of having Policy Coherence for Development.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union must take into account the objective of development cooperation in the policies it implements which may have an impact on developing countries. I welcome, for example, policies aimed at helping developing countries to build their domestic systems in the area of resources. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on this current report, but I want to express my dissatisfaction that there has been little progress in policy coherence in 2015 in terms of its concrete implementation. It regrets that better results in the implementation of cohesion policy for development (PCD) have not occurred, despite the fact that since 2005 the EU has introduced a number of key instruments to ensure the effective and systematic application of PCD through EU policies. For this reason, too, I consider it extremely important that the policy-to-development contact points in national ministries and EU delegations be allocated the necessary funds to implement national and European strategies on policy coherence. Although PCD is not yet widely perceived at international level, it remains largely a European concept and, in an increasingly interconnected world, it is necessary to start working more intensively on a common approach and to introduce its more universal character. I believe that, in order to make real progress in the inclusion of PCD, it is essential that other key international actors (the US, Japan and the BRIC countries) adopt this concept.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Commission's fifth two-year report on PCD was published in August 2015, shortly before the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted at the UN Meeting in New York in September. The adoption of the SDGs marked a turning point in the development of PCD.  The SDGs will require a more comprehensive approach to policy-making, with greater emphasis on coherence. Although the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development will continue to have a very strong impact on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. A single and general set of development goals has been established, which applies to all and goes beyond the donor and recipient paradigm.  The European Commission's report is in itself a useful tool for raising awareness of PCD, and it would be even more useful if we looked more analytically at its progress. I also believe that concrete recommendations on addressing the challenges of PCD should be an integral part of the report.  For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European cohesion policies were affected by the migration crisis last year. Nevertheless, we have made progress in a number of areas, including health, safety and trade.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because I believe that the European Union needs to take a major and leading role in promoting PCD. PcD should be an important element in the EU's contribution to achieving the broader objective of policy coherence in the interests of sustainable development, as outlined in the Council conclusions on the Fifth Biennial Report of the European Commission.  An essential element for this report, unfortunately, is the fact that 1.5 billion people still live in poverty and are deprived of living standards, health and education. I believe that the EU has a direct obligation and responsibility in relations with partner countries. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which establishes a universal and unique set of development goals that apply to all, poses a major and new challenge for achieving PCD.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution. There is nothing new in this than in the previous resolutions on the same subject. The resolution of 25 October 2012 on policy coherence for development (2012/2063(INI)) contains very important points, such as paragraphs 141, 144, 146 and 147. The Commission would first have to implement these demands. But it does not. So why the reporting activism?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
