text: Written. ‒ PCD is a key element in achieving and delivering a new sustainable development agenda. A proactive approach based on consensus on PCD is needed. While PCD is supported in the United Nations Millennium Declaration, as well as in the Lisbon Treaty, its concrete application has progressed poorly. Parliament calls for a European Union-wide debate on PCD under the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its new 17 Universal and Indivisible Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for better understanding. The SDGs apply to both developed and developing countries and should be integrated into the decision-making process in the European Union at internal and external level.  I support this report and the guidance outlined there because I believe that PCD should contribute to the establishment of the rule of law, as well as of independent institutions. I also believe that it will help address the challenges that good governance poses in developing countries.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU report for 2015 on PCD.  It is important that we build sustainable development through coordinated policies for development at global level. The 2015 PCD resolution analyses seven priority areas, namely migration, trade and finance, food security, health, climate change, gender and security.  The European Council meeting on PCD would also be crucial for defining the responsibility of individual EU institutions in achieving commitments in this area. When we talk about the sustainable development goals, we should involve third countries more intensively in the EU decision-making process. PcD is a key element in the implementation and achievement of the new Sustainable Development Agenda.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's report on the 2015 EU Report on Policy Coherence for Development, as it addresses the generally important issue of policy coherence in order to promote sustainable development, and also because it mentions the importance of development aid in the context of the current migration crisis. Development aid is now a tool to combat the migration crisis in the long term, as it is clear that only the comprehensive development of the countries that are now the source countries of migration will ensure that the number of migrants is gradually reduced and that they find a safe and meaningful life in their own countries. In particular, this objective assumes that development aid will not only be humanitarian aid, but also increasingly an investment that will lead to the further development of countries receiving such development aid.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that poverty, inequality as well as deprivations in health, education and living are plagued by the economic crisis in many European countries. That is why there must be fiscal transparency, accountability of development finance institutions, so as to better monitor money flows as well as binding climate and renewable energy rules. We are in favour of a traditional society that does not defend LGBT rights, nor does it support an immigration refugee policy, at all the costs it entails from it.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it actually points to a number of long-standing shortcomings in interinstitutional and interpolitical coordination in the wider field of development policy. I have considered that, although the PCD as a European concept was born long before the refugee crisis, it can be said that, in the current situation, the creation of a close consistency between development and migration policy has become a vital issue for the effective functioning of the Union.  It is included in the report, but I would have stressed even more the urgency of the involvement of the common foreign and security policy in improving coherence: in this context, stabilising the EU neighbourhood should be a priority for the USSR, putting Community development goals and instruments at the service of managing and preventing the refugee wave.  As a positive element of the compilation, I considered that, like many other EU development objectives and documents, gender mainstreaming is a priority. In addition, in the future, I would like to see children treated with a similar horizontal and coherent approach as the most vulnerable and vulnerable group, whether it be the treatment of food, poverty, epidemics, refugees or war situations.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The 2030 Agenda presents itself as a new challenge for the establishment of policy coherence for development (PCD), as it puts forward a universal set of development goals applicable to all. This agenda gives the European Union the opportunity to be a leader in promoting a universal policy coherence for development, as there are 1.5 billion people still living in poverty around the world, most of which are women. The report in question calls for stronger linkage between PCD and the Sustainable Development Goals, better involvement of local and regional governments, civil society organisations and think tanks, impact assessment on the action being taken, the establishment of a complaint mechanism, an evidence based analysis of PCDs, the establishment of national and European strategies and the organisation of a specific European Council meeting on PCD. I am satisfied with the content of this report and I also believe that the European Union should make an effort to ensure more synergies among EU policies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I am in favour of the text. Previous reports from the European Parliament have played a major role in advancing the concept of the CPD by institutionalising a permanent rapporteur on the subject in the Committee on Development, affirming that the CPD is within the political competence of Parliament (as a co-legislator and a democratically elected institution) and by putting forward concrete proposals to move forward in the application of this concept at EU level.  This report not only takes stock of the progress made by the European Commission and identifies areas where the mechanisms of the CPD in place in the Union can be improved, but it also seeks to stimulate debate on the future of the concept at EU level.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda represents a unique opportunity to review the coherence of our development strategies to ensure that they actually improve people’s lives. While I appreciate and agree with many of the proposals made in this report, I however decided to abstain because there are some elements that I cannot compromise on. While it is crucial that we agree on a holistic and efficient migration and asylum system, I do not believe that developing a single common system is at the moment feasible. Furthermore, I don’t believe in using instruments such as a financial transaction tax, a carbon tax, an air ticket levy, rents from natural resources as sustainable sources of financing. Finally, if the market rules are fully respected, I do believe that trade liberalisation is a very efficient tool to combat poverty and encourage development, unlike what the report states.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. The 2015 European Union Report on PCD aims to improve existing mechanisms for achieving PCD and to stimulate debate on the future of the concept at European level. The European Union has repeatedly expressed its political commitment to achieving PCD, but has not yet found a way to put it into practice. I believe that policy coherence is one of the political and economic priorities of the European Union and that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is an opportunity for poverty eradication and sustainable development. While I agree with most of the proposals for this report, I voted abstaining because I believe that the proposed approach will create additional regulatory measures and barriers for citizens and businesses of the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the EU Report 2015 on PCD, stressing the importance of policy coherence for sustainable development. PCD was institutionalised with the Maastrichst Treaty, but it was only the Treaty of Lisbon that it was only the Treaty of Lisbon that it emphasised the EU's legal obligation to implement PCD, achieve coherence between external and internal policies, and put the EU even more in the spotlight. The adoption of the SDGs in 2015 marks a turning point in the formulation of sustainable development policies that will require a more comprehensive approach to policy-making. The adoption of the 2030 Agenda established a single and general set of development objectives. The EU still has difficulties in implementing PCD, as the latter requires the establishment of synergy between horizontal and vertical policies. The Commission's report is a useful tool for raising awareness of policy coherence and should contain concrete recommendations on addressing challenges. The process of implementing PCD should involve all stakeholders, including civil society. The proper implementation of PCD requires sufficient resources and staff to have the necessary resources at its disposal to develop European and national PCD strategies.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the event that the Union must take the lead in promoting policy coherence for development, as Article 208 of the Lisbon Treaty points out, we voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission to effectively increase its efforts through concrete measures the coordination and coherence of its external policies to align with the objectives of the Union (eradication of poverty and reduction of inequalities)

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because I have some crucial comments on the report. For example, the proposal concerns the harmonisation of migration policy, gender dimensions, taxes on financial transactions or the involvement of the UN in tax controls – all of which are to be addressed primarily in the individual Member States to which they relate.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In the run-up to the UN development summits, this text is the encouragement of the Development Commission and Parliament to continue the EU's support for the development policies of UN agencies and programmes.  This report has a strictly ideological view of development. However, development does not declare itself it is a public policy not a slogan. Moreover, it appears that development is merely a pretext for a further increase in the powers and resources of the EU.  It should also be noted that this report is itself in the post Cotonou era and apparently without a critical examination of the free trade strategy with Africa. He is, of course, an immigrationist.  This text is naïve and does not question the notion of development, does not question the current ratio of the populations of the former Southern states to this notion, does not take stock of 30 years of failures of the promotion by the EU, the IMF, the World Bank of development models without conclusive results according to the latest IMF report released this month.   In fact, the real purpose of this text is to beg for the resources and budgets of the Member States. That reason alone is enough to deny the report.  I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fifth Biennial Report of the European Commission (EC) on Policy Coherence for Development (PCD) was published in August 2015, shortly before the adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development at the UN Summit in New York in September, which includes the objective of "strengthening the coherence of sustainable development policies". I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the Union must take the lead in promoting policy coherence for development, as Article 208 of the Lisbon Treaty points out, we voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission to effectively increase its efforts through concrete measures the coordination and coherence of its external policies to align with the Objectives of the Union (eradication of poverty and reduction of inequalities).

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Some other political groups’ attempts to weaken the report failed, except on one request unfortunately, namely its calls for a UN body on tax matters to enable developing countries to participate on equal footing in the global reform of existing international tax rules. Nevertheless, paragraphs that highlight the challenge of harmful tax competition; the need to develop innovative sources of financing (through an FTT; carbon tax; ticket levy; rents from natural resources, etc.) were maintained, as in the case of the paragraph that trade liberalisation is not per se positive for poverty eradication.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2015 Report on policy coherence for development. I believe that that PCD (policy coherence for development) is a key element for delivering and achieving the new sustainable development agenda. The report emphasises that the EU needs greater harmonisation of migration and asylum policies, both within the Union itself and with its international partners. The report suggests that a truly efficient and holistic migration and asylum policy has to integrate fully EU internal and external policies.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report reflects progress in pro-development policies, identifies areas where existing mechanisms can be improved and stimulates debate on the future of this concept at European level, calling for development policies to be discussed and coordinated at Community level and between Member States, stressing the need to promote interinstitutional debate between the Commission , SEAE, Council and European Parliament, as well as the debate at national level. We are talking about a constructive report which has been the subject of broad consensus, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because there is often a lack of coherence when it comes to EU development policy. The emphasis placed in this report on the EU's external policy is absolutely necessary. As the refugee crisis and destabilisation in the EU's neighbouring countries put pressure on the EU's foundations, the emphasis should be placed, among other things, on external action. Stabilising the EU's neighbours must be an absolute priority for the EU.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 We voted today in the European Parliament on the EU report on the coherence of policies affecting development. This is a key issue in development policy and the report as a whole is to be supported. The report included a reference to the need for the EU to take further harmonisation in immigration and asylum politicians. I voted against this paragraph. I do not believe that decision-making on immigration and asylum should be taken further away from the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since 1992, the EU has developed the concept of 'policy coherence for development' (CPD). The CPD's objective is to bring policies in this area together. It must also ensure that development policies remain favourable to the countries concerned. This report is about the Commission's fifth biennial report on the CPD. Since I have been an MEP, I have denounced the neoliberal logics of these policies and their negative impact on economies and local people, even preventing the sustainable development of certain countries. It would be imperative that companies operating abroad ensure that human rights are respected within their structures and to be held accountable for violations.  It is also recommended that development policies primarily help poor producers, promote the diversity of the internal market of the countries concerned, reduce income gaps or promote gender equality.  Finally, the report calls for the opening of legal migration routes and the improvement of the reception of refugees. It supports a common asylum policy that is essential to overcome the current difficulties. Without any illusions about the real impact of the report, however, I voted to consider that it was going in the right direction.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to assess the extent to which the European Union's sectoral policies contribute to the objectives it says to pursue in the field of development aid, in particular the fight against poverty. The truth is that many of these policies not only do not contribute but also contradict the good intentions proclaimed. Moreover, the deregulation and liberalisation of international trade, which the European Union still wants to impose through the so-called "Economic Partnership Agreements", in practice only foster and perpetuate underdevelopment. All this, not forgetting the attempt to export and impose models of economic and political organization, which most often disrespects the sovereignty, needs and legitimate choices of developing countries. The infernal cycle of impoverishment, dependence and subordination of these countries has causes, inseparable from the nature of capitalism, that these reports rarely face head-on.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. There would be nothing to counteract the promotion of policy coherence and thus the basic idea of this report. However, if, as here, partial arguments such as the current migration crisis are analysed so far from any reality and conclusions are drawn from them, which are simply intolerable, then I cannot, unfortunately, agree with this in good conscience.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because following the signing of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) last year, the need for development principles to run through all EU policies such as environment, agriculture, trade, education, culture, etc., is greater than ever. The principle of Policy Coherence for Development (PCD) represents the EU’s commitment to take account of the impact of its policies on international development. To truly achieve sustainable development, the policies we pursue in agriculture, trade, security and defence, must clearly correspond and compliment sustainable development, and this is what this report aims to achieve. Despite the difficulties to implement PCD, the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies among EU policies, and this report – supported by all sides of the Parliament – represents the commitment to uphold and enhance the principle of PCD in light of the SDGs. A specific European Council meeting on PCD before the publication of the next Commission’s report in 2017 would contribute to raise awareness of PCD and to better define the responsibilities of the different actors involved.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I support this PCD (policy coherence for development) report because I believe that policy coherence is necessary to achieve sustainable development. In this regard, the EU can set an example for the rest of the world. The European Parliament plays a great role in this. In that respect, we need to correct existing inconsistencies. This is important if we want to implement the 2030 Agenda For Sustainable Development correctly. Moreover, in order to succeed, our international partners also need to be convinced. The overall goal here, is to establish universal development goals and to overcome the outdated idea of donor-recipient. PCD promotes synergies and cooperation across different policy areas. Therefore, I welcome the rapporteur’s efforts on promoting the PCD debate and the need for involving many different stakeholders, such as the institutions, civil society and think tanks. In addition, he recognises the need for a stronger focus on EU External Relations, which will be needed to solve the various crises at the EU’s borders. PCD will be an important contribution to this.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on my colleague Cristian Preda's report on the EU report for 2015 on policy coherence for development. I agree with the rapporteur's view that the Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation is an essential element for the development and implementation of the new Sustainable Development Agenda. I also welcome the fact that the report noted that the EU needs greater harmonisation of migration and asylum policies, both within the Union and with its international partners, suggesting that a truly effective and comprehensive migration and asylum policy must fully integrate the EU's internal and external policies , especially within the EU's working structures.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the present report because, as a long-time member of the EP's Committee on Development, I am very concerned that European policy in this area does not contain internal contradictions. The report contains a number of recommendations which give feedback to the Commission when evaluating its programmes and make it possible to further increase the efficiency of the funds spent. I consider it a good signal that the report does not contain calls for support for abortion and so-called reproductive rights, and I would like this to become the norm for other resolutions in this House as well.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the report presented, as I believe that trade and direct financing are one of the main priority areas for policy coherence and the path to sustainable development. However, it must be stressed that trade liberalisation is not in itself positive in terms of reducing poverty and inequalities. I am of the opinion that private funding for individual climate action funding cannot replace public funds.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Preda report because I believe that, despite the difficulties in implementing policy coherence for development, the EU should make an effort to ensure more synergies between its policies as set out in this report. I would remind you that policy coherence for development is essential for the implementation of the new sustainable development agenda. This needs to be developed by governance processes that promote it not only within European law but also internationally.  I would like to point out the need for the European Socialist Group to schedule a specific European Council on policy coherence for development before the publication of the next Commission's report in 2017, with a view to raising awareness among Member States of the coherence of these policies and better defining the responsibilities of the different actors involved.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Report on the EU Report 2015 on PCD. I believe that PCD is a key element in the realisation and achievement of the new Sustainable Development Agenda. The report highlights some topical strategic priority areas, including migration and security, where measures for sustainable development and poverty eradication need to be strengthened. National parliaments also play a key role in the implementation of policy coherence for sustainable development by ensuring regular oversight of political commitments, monitoring and full involvement of civil society organisations, as well as supervising the impact assessment reports prepared by governments.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is a step in the right direction, that of an alliance for food and nutrition, for absolutely sustainable agriculture, which I believe must be the objective of this Europe, which has its typical features, its typical products, especially in this sector that we have illustrated today, one of the extraordinary potentials and strengths.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, particularly where it calls for countries to put in place binding national measures against land grabbing., and I also want to acknowledge that it is very important that agriculture is now firmly on the agenda for development policy. Clearly food security and nutrition are very much linked to agriculture policy. So this is particularly welcome.  I think there are sensitivities on what technologies we would allow, or say that developing countries should, or should not, use. I think we should allow them to make those choices rather than us insisting that they are restricted in the use of any technologies; I include in that plant breeding technologies. The developing world needs an agriculture policy to encourage its farmers to give them the tools and knowledge to produce food, so that they will have food security and nutrition.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the G8-funded giant organisation, such as the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition, would bring farmers in Africa to their knees, as farmers in countries where agriculture is obsolete, underfunded and, as such, uncompetitive would bring to their knees farmers in countries where agriculture is obsolete, underfunded and, as such, uncompetitive. We want to help Africa get out of poverty. Help local producers protect jobs, giving Africans the chance to farm at fair prices! I call on the G8 countries not to support genetically modified plant crops and to support local farmers. African governments also have themes to do: investing in the local food industry, boosting the rural economy and transparent resource distribution.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, having worked myself on a voluntary basis in Malawi a few years ago, I have seen the poverty there and I see the way forward. And that is why I welcome this report. I support the EPP vote in favour as it is hugely important to support family farming and local agriculture in order to support a developing country.  Ireland is a strong agricultural economy, and I am happy to be able to support an initiative that aims to improve the livelihoods of the farming community in sub-Saharan Africa. Agricultural investment policies in Africa should be linked to and support the development of the local economy, including family farming and smaller landholders, along with bigger commercial farms. The New Alliance has made a commitment to promote inclusive agricultural-based growth that supports small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty, hunger and under-nutrition in countries in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The G8 held in May 2012 kicked off the new alliance for food security and nutrition, a public-private partnership, aimed at stimulating private investment in sub-Saharan agriculture. The EU has so far invested EUR 1.2 billion, in particular in cooperation with the territories of Malawi and Côte d'Ivoire. The report presented, however, highlights a number of critical issues linked to the new alliance, believing that it does not lead to a real improvement in the living conditions of millions of families of farmers and small holders. In the wake of these considerations, the EU is urged to review its participation in this alliance. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, it highlights several critical aspects of "the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa", sponsored and promoted in 2012 as a public-private agreement that has led to structural liberalization reforms in African countries, being one of the main mechanisms guilty of land grabbing, marginalization of small producers and support for an unsustainable farming and livestock model , contrary to the principles of food sovereignty.  Thus, the report, among other points, criticizes the negative impacts on the development of public-private agreements and, despite not turning them down, includes the need for strict regulation.  Another positive aspect is the call to support local economies and small holdings, references to the positive aspects of agroecology and the commitment to support these practices with an explicit rejection of the introduction of GMOs in Africa.  The report also highlights clear points on the need to combat land grabbing, recognizing traditional community-owned figures of land, including the right of indigenous peoples.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new alliance for food security and nutrition.  This text is indeed very critical of the NASAN system (a programme that repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s) and advocates food sovereignty, ecological diversity for local populations, in order to avoid their emigration.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ By way of background information, the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) is a huge agricultural public—private partnership which is used in sub—Saharan Africa with the stated aim of improving food security and reducing hunger. In reality however, the NAFSN, whose main private actors are multinationals, underpins and promotes an agricultural model based on monoculture and production of export crops, and has been reported as a risk factor in the facilitation of land grabs and ultimately failing to achieve its objectives. Small-scale farmers have been side-lined in favour of the will of much larger agribusinesses. This report from a Green rapporteur highlights the problems with this PPP and the need for stronger governance structures which currently are lacking in the implementation of NAFSN as well as the need to support family farms and smallholders as a more sustainable way to achieve food security and elimination of hunger. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as it contained some very positive and progressive provisions and proactively worked to implement sustainable solutions.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. In this report, we call for more support for agricultural investment policies to support the development of the local economy and small farmers. It is essential to establish an independent accountability mechanism for the actors involved. In addition, we recall that the projects of the new alliance for food security and nutrition must comply with the voluntary guidelines of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, with responsible governance of land tenure, fisheries and forest tenure.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN) in Africa was launched in May 2012 under the auspices of the G8 with the aim of improving agricultural production and expanding the agricultural sector by attracting private investment. This report, which I voted in favour of, recognises nafsn's weaknesses and calls for them to be addressed immediately. In particular, the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament argues, inter alia, that rural investment policies should be linked to the development of the local economy and small farmers. In addition, an independent accountability mechanism should be set up, land grabbing should be combated and more stringent regulations and monitoring of public and private partnerships, as well as respect for human rights, land rights and social, environmental and labour standards.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The New Alliance for Food Security and Food in Africa, or NAFSN for short, was launched in 2012 with the aim of complementing private agricultural investment to improve food security and nutrition in African countries. As a result, the EU and its Member States became the world's largest donor of development aid. NAFSN has already benefited more than 8.2 million smallholder farmers and created more than 21,000 jobs, more than half of which are for women. However, it should be borne in mind that agriculture accounts for at least 14% of total greenhouse gas emissions per year. The main reason for this is the use of nitrogen fertilisers. In this way, I agree with Parliament's calls to ask NAFSN to limit as far as possible the use of artificial fertilisers and pesticides because of their environmental and health consequences. Finally, however, in addition to the environment and health, attention must also be paid to the human rights of workers in Africa. EU-based investors must respect the rights of small farmers and the local community and not take advantage of their economic benefits. Social responsibility is required here.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) has been the source of much criticism since its entry into force in 2012.  It is a broad public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union, with a programme to develop African agriculture. A dozen African countries are involved, from Ethiopia to Côte d'Ivoire to Senegal.  Nearly 180 companies are participating in the $8 billion investment program. The tax, land and trade measures taken must provide a favourable framework for businesses.  But it repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s (dependence on fertilizers, monoculture, export crops...). Unsustainable agriculture is therefore favoured, with smallholder farmers sidelined.  This report proposes to counterbalance these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies, combating poverty and food insecurity. In particular, it is the overriding issue of food sovereignty that is highlighted in this report, which does not fail to point out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations.  I have spoken in favour of this excellent report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained on this issue. This report highlights how small farmers are being cheated out of improving their livelihoods by big businesses and governments who wish to put profit before the welfare of citizens.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims in particular to promote an agricultural model that improves resilience and creates sustainable agri-food systems.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  The G8, now G7, created the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) in 2012 to leverage investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in Africa. NAFSN aims to replicate the 1960s ‘Green Revolution’ in Asia that was successful through biotechnology, monoculture, and distribution networks among other tools. The policies and reforms in these African countries are meant to create business-friendly environments through changes in tax, trade, and infrastructure policies. NAFSN has a long way to go and must be reformed in order for it to become a successful tool in the fight against poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. I voted in favour of this resolution because the EU and Member States have a key role to play in investing in a model of agriculture that is sustainable, equal, and unlocks the potential of regional markets to benefit family farmers in Africa. The support of NASFN must be conditional on the improvements set out in the resolution and the EU and Member States must ensure effective programmes that are pro-smallholder farming, pro-women, and of benefit to providing safe and secure quality food at accessible prices.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security was established in 2012 as a major public-private partnership (PPP) to leverage private investment in agriculture to improve food and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa.  Each participating African country has adopted a programme of cooperation between the parties setting out the commitments of each contracting party. These commitments relate to legislative reforms in the african countries concerned, the plans for funding g7 donors and the pledge of 180 participating companies to invest a total of EUR 8 billion. Usd. I agree that the EU and the Member States have an important role to play in transforming the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security into a genuine support tool for sub-Saharan African family farms and the local economy to combat poverty, food shortages and their inability to provide for it.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) is a broad public-private partnership involving a dozen African countries to set up a programme to develop African agriculture through tax, land and trade measures. But it repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s and based on dependence on fertilizers, monoculture, or export crops. Unsustainable agriculture is therefore favoured and smallholder farmers are sidelined. The aim of this report is to counterbalance these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies, combating poverty and food insecurity. He thus highlights the overriding issue of food sovereignty, pointing out that a good agricultural and food policy in African countries would help to reduce the emigration of populations. So I voted for him.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa lift poverty by 2020. Participating countries negotiated frameworks for cooperation in which they pledged to encourage private investment in Africa's agriculture sector.  I approved this resolution calling for a review of investment strategies in agriculture taking into account the springs of the local economy, particularly smallholders and family farms. The text denounces the fact that small farmers, agricultural workers, fishermen and indigenous peoples are too little taken into account in the decision. It therefore calls for a review of all projects that directly promote land grabbing.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 One in four people in sub-Saharan Africa suffers from malnutrition, which causes the deaths of about half of children under the age of five. This is a very serious situation in which the EU has decided to take action by launching the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition with the G8 in 2012. This project aims to strengthen food security and nutrition, helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020, making changes to the legislation of the countries involved in seed, land and foreign investment. I supported the Heubuch report because I believe it fully highlights the risks associated with the application of NAFSN, particularly for small producers and women. The text expresses the need to make cooperation frameworks for different countries monitorable and accessible, including performance indicators and forcing private companies to publish annual reports. The Union's priority must above all be to protect family farms and smallholders, who are largely excluded from the negotiations by avoiding the adoption of models based on large-scale industrial production, which have negative consequences for health and the environment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Considering that the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020; and that the participating countries have negotiated national cooperation frameworks, which set out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agriculture sector in Africa, we voted in favour of this Resolution, which warns of the risks of the role that the private sector can play in this particular if it is not well regulated.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition of the Committee on Development. Agricultural investment policies focus mostly on large-scale land acquisitions and export-oriented agriculture that is rarely related to local economies. Rural communities, agricultural workers, smallholder farmers, fishermen and indigenous peoples have been snruffy in their right to participate in decision-making in the framework of cooperation. I voted in favour of others urging the G-8 Member States not to support the crops of genetically modified organisms in Africa.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wished to support this report and I welcome the work of Maria Heubuch, who fully underlines in this text the harms and dangers of the new alliance for food security and nutrition in Africa. Unfortunately, this large public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union for the development of African agriculture has only encouraged unsustainable farming methods, including the mistakes of investment in Asia with a high dependence on fertilizers and farm crops, all of which impoverish smallholder farmers. The report therefore calls for the deployment of family farming that would promote local economies and help combat food insecurity. The text also has the merit of recalling that this sustainable agricultural policy would enable an effective fight against emigration, and it constitutes a real plea for food sovereignty that will enable a genuine development policy.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the new alliance for food security and nutrition is well articulated and has no problematic passages. That is why I wanted to support you with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported with my vote this report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition which aims, by increasing private investment and boosting agricultural growth, to remove 50 million people out of poverty in Africa by 2022. This initiative, which already covers 10 African states, will make an investment of ten billion dollars and call for major changes to different regulations with the aim of incentivating investment. Instruments used to promote development will design cooperation agreements, create new tools to mobilize private capital and formulate national investment plans.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is in Parliament's opinion on the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security. The alliance was established in 2012 as a major public-private partnership (PPP) to leverage private investment in agriculture to improve food and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. Specific G7 partners have been given the responsibility to coordinate the implementation of the initiative in a specific African country. The EU is responsible for coordination in Côte d'Ivoire and Malawi. Parliament's report recognises the need for African countries to invest in agriculture and that the aim of the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security is justified, but there are many shortcomings. Parliament criticises the report for almost not consulting small holders of small holdings when developing cooperation programmes between countries, even though they should be the final beneficiaries of the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security. The new Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security has also been heavily criticised by civil society and public figures. They warn that the New Alliance risks facilitating land grabbing, further marginalised small farmers and women, while supporting unsustainable farming. Parliament believes that the EU and the Member States have an important role to play in transforming the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security into a genuine support tool for sub-Saharan African family farms and the local economy to combat poverty, food shortages and inability to provide for it.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to avoid migration from Africa, I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency. Taking into account its shortcomings, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed report on the Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8. It aims to increase private investment in agriculture in order to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. It involves a number of countries, and the EU is responsible for coordinating the policies of action in Côte d'Ivoire and Malawi. The report therefore calls on African governments to invest in family farming and agroecology, and calls for greater efforts by countries to effectively implement international standards in their responsible investment in agriculture. I agree with the rapporteur on the role of aid for large public-private partnerships, such as NAFSN, and its contribution to poverty reduction and food security in Africa. There is a risk that the poorest communities will be hardest hit by the social and environmental risks associated with it. Instead of EU support to NAFSN, donors and also national governments should invest in a sustainable model of agriculture that supports small-scale farming and women and exploits the potential of domestic and regional markets. Both family farms and consumers would benefit from this, providing them with quality food at affordable prices.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), founded in 2012, aims to innovate, develop and modernize African agriculture, unlocking important investments thanks to a broad public-private partnership. The agreed policies are aimed at overcoming the limits and risks of the African agricultural system, creating a more business-friendly environment, easier and more controlled access to land and a more sustainable use of resources, with the aim of combating food and nutrition poverty. However, the strategy has shown some gaps that need to be filled, and in particular calls for a more careful inclusion of the local economy and small farmers in investment choices. Greater transparency on public-private cooperation is also crucial, as is the commitment to empower companies to respect human rights, the right to land, environmental sustainability and gender equality. I therefore agree with Mrs Heubuch's report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. I believe the New Alliance should be supported, despite the shortcomings it contains. I believe that agricultural investment policies must be linked and support the development of a small-scale local economy, and the New Alliance projects must comply with the FAO's voluntary guidelines on responsible land tenure management, fisheries and forests.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report criticises the provisions of the "New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition" (NASAN) which came into force in 2012. 10 African countries, 180 companies are affected by NASAN, for an investment of 8 billion dollars.  Instead, the report emphasizes the need to promote small family structures, short circuits, self-sufficiency, limiting food imports, abandoning plant protection products, and independence from foreign seeds. So I voted for this report

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – By way of background information, the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) is a huge agricultural public-private partnership which is used in sub-Saharan Africa with the stated aim of improving food security and reducing hunger. In reality however, the NAFSN whose main private actors are multinationals underpins and promotes an agricultural model based on monoculture and production of export crops, and has been reported as a risk factor in the facilitation of land grabs and ultimately failing to achieve its objectives. Small-scale farmers have been side-lined in favour of the will of much larger agribusinesses. This report from a Green rapporteur highlights the problems with this PPP and the need for stronger governance structures which currently are lacking in the implementation of NAFSN as well as the need to support family farms and smallholders as a more sustainable way to achieve food security and elimination of hunger. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as it contained some very positive and progressive provisions and proactively worked to implement sustainable solutions.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the growing and continuous increase in population, Africa needs adequate investment in agriculture in order to meet the growing demand for food. With this in mind, the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa, developed under the G8, could be an interesting opportunity to mobilise private investment in African agriculture, thus contributing to the improvement of living conditions and nutrition of the population. However, this particular device has been developed on an ecologically and socially unsustainable model, that of the Asian "Green Revolution" of the 1960s and 1970s, based on dependence on fertilizers, intensive crops for export, biotechnology and long distribution channels. A production scheme, the son of outdated development logics, which do not adapt to the culture, needs and reality of the territory in question. A model whose implementation is expressed in paternalistic logics, which is also the subject of widespread criticism by important figures, such as the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the right to food, which leave little room for discussion with small holders and civil society and which, for these reasons, must be deeply rethought and updated.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The new alliance for food security is a broad public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union with a programme for the development of African agriculture. A dozen African countries are involved, from Ethiopia to Côte d'Ivoire to Senegal. Nearly 180 companies are participating in the programme for an investment of 8 billion euros; in return, they will benefit from favourable tax, land and trade measures. However, this scheme, which favours unsustainable agriculture, has already proved ineffective in the past, especially in Asia, as smallholder farmers are sidelined. In this context, the report aims to stimulate family farming and local economies by combating poverty and food insecurity. In this regard, we consider it essential to favour short circuits by, for example, limiting the import of food, in favour of local products. A good agricultural and food policy in African countries will help stem the emigration of their populations. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Africa's new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition aims to mobilise private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. This New Alliance must become a support tool for family agriculture and local economies to combat poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. It becomes necessary to approach a model of agriculture by which food systems are generated, with increased attention to family farms and small farm owners who are the main investors in agriculture in Africa. Another objective of this alliance must also focus on fostering access to land and ensuring land security, especially since 1.2 million people still live either without permanent access to land or occupying a property over which they do not have a legitimate right. At the same time, it is necessary to develop policies that generate sustainable family farming, which implies the targeting of official development aid to family farms. I believe that the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is a fundamental tool for reducing poverty and combating hunger, creating the prerequisites for sustainable and sustainable agriculture, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this initiative.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) is based on Asia’s ‘Green Revolution’ of the 1960s and 1970s and was created in order to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. This will include the creation of business-friendly environments through reforms of infrastructure and trade policies, easier access to ‘idle’ land for longer-term lease, and regulatory reforms to strengthen intellectual property rights of plant breeders. To ensure the sustainability of this program, the NAFSN must benefit small-scale farmers and small family businesses to secure and strengthen their role in the food supply chain, establish regionally adapted agricultural structures and water-conserving agronomic techniques, and emphasize the importance of a high-quality, balanced nutrition. The NAFSN’s commitment to food security is commendable, and so I voted for this report so that development aid will be focused on directing support to small-scale farming in order to reduce and eventually eradicate poverty. By passing this, we will be able to enhance the transparency and governance of the NAFSN and, most importantly, support the establishment of farmers’ cooperatives to enable the delivery of affordable means of production and aid farmers in processing and marketing their products in profitable way.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it raises constructive criticism of the way in which the objectives pursued by the public-private partnership, which goes by the name of 'New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa', are being achieved. It is right to invest in agriculture in the countries of sub-Saharan Africa in order to improve the food security of african populations, but we must avoid reproducing a model based on monocultures, biotechnology, dependence on fertilizers, as well as on long distribution channels.  Cooperation frameworks by country need to be reviewed in order to improve contractual arrangements between buyers and local suppliers, and to provide a favourable legal framework from the point of view of price agreements, respect for women's rights, the establishment of appropriate dispute settlement mechanisms, and the strengthening of farmers' organisations to improve their negotiating position under agricultural contracts.  It is the task of the Union and the Member States to ensure that the public-private partnership in question becomes a genuine instrument of support for family-scale agriculture and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, with the aim of combating poverty and food and nutrition insecurity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN) in Africa. This is basically a huge agricultural public-private partnership, used in sub-Saharan African with the stated aim of improving food security and reducing hunger. In actual fact though, the NAFSN, which deals with large multinationals, promotes an agricultural model based on monoculture and the production of export crops. Small-scale farmers have been side-lined in favour of much larger agribusinesses. This report highlighted these problems and calls for greater governance structures for the implementation of the programme, as well as the need to support family farms and smallholders. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because its objective is to attract agricultural investment which can enhance food security and nutrition in Africa. This report proposes in detail how to make use of the investment assisting local economic growth, regarding the revolution of farming, poverty, job creation and so on. I am particularly satisfied with the recommendation that the spending of the investment should be reported to the public and receive supervision.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is a partnership launched in 2012 by the G8 with the aim of stimulating private investment in the agricultural sector in sub-Saharan Africa. The EU participates in the New Alliance for the sum of EUR 1.2 billion, leading the cooperation frameworks with Malawi and Côte d'Ivoire. The report on this initiative, drawn up by the DEVE Committee, correctly highlighted its critical issues and controversial aspects and, therefore, I voted in favour of adopting this text. In fact, the New Alliance is highly criticized by NGOs and civil society as it seems to promote only the entry of corporate agrobusiness led by multinationals such as Monsanto, Cargill and Unilever.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the EU to address all nafsn weaknesses, as mentioned in the report, to act to enhance transparency and governance and to ensure the coherence of actions undertaken in this context and development policy objectives.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is a clear attempt to identify the risks and also to put forward proposals to address food risks that exist and threaten a large part of the world's population and in the long term for all of us. I therefore consider this to be an important effort and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote positively after examining that the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), launched in 2012 under the aegis of the G8, is a broad public-private partnership that aims to mobilise private investment in agriculture, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. Each participating African country has adopted a country-by-country cooperation framework (CCF) setting out the commitments of each party involved. These commitments relate to legislative reforms in their African countries. The EU and its Member States are called upon to play an essential role in ensuring that the NAFSN becomes a genuine support instrument for family-scale agriculture and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, with the aim of combating poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. The rapporteur believes that, on the other hand, donors and national governments should invest in an agricultural model that is sustainable, favourable to smallholders and women, and able to exploit the potential of national and regional markets in order to benefit small farmers and provide consumers with quality food at affordable prices.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme of agriculture in sub-Saharan Africa is very delicate. Years ago, the "New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa" was launched, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition through private investment. However, the main private players in this area are multinational companies that benefit from a dominant market position to the detriment of the poorest communities. That is why I am convinced that the European Union must suspend its current support for this alliance so that we can focus on the local private sector, especially on family farmers and smallholders, so that they can get out of poverty. In addition, this would lead to better exploitation of the potential of national markets by farmers. These are the reasons why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for resolution, which emphasises that agricultural investment policies in Africa should be linked and support the development of the local economy, including smallholders and family farming. In this respect NAFSN has made a commitment to promoting inclusive, agriculture-based growth that supports small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty, hunger and under-nutrition. Therefore the parties to NAFSN should submit annual reports on the action taken under NAFSN and to make those reports public and accessible to local people and communities. Moreover, the report calls on African governments to invest in local food systems in order to boost rural economies, ensure decent jobs, equitable social safety nets and labour rights and to improve arrangements for democratic scrutiny of access to resources.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the rapporteur's criticisms and suggestions. The new alliance, established in 2012, is an important tool for achieving better food security in Africa. NAFSN's approach is good, but family farms and smallholders need to be given greater focus as important investors and employers in agriculture in sub-Saharan Africa. These make a significant contribution to sustainably improving food production and diversifying production.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained because there is much validity in the criticisms in this report, even if the solutions are not ours.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree we should invest in local food systems in order to boost rural economies and ensure decent jobs, equitable social safety nets and labour rights. This will improve arrangements for democratic scrutiny of access to resources, including farmers’ seeds, and to ensure the effective engagement of small-scale producers in policy processes and implementation. In developing countries there has been an emphasis on food security which shifted from merely increasing the production of agricultural commodities to ensuring that countries have the capacity to feed themselves and improve their food sovereignty. The people have the right to decide upon their own agricultural and food policies and production. We know that family farmers and smallholders are the main investors in African agriculture, and provide over 60% of employment in Sub-Saharan Africa. They have demonstrated their ability to increase food production sustainably (often through agro-ecological practices), to diversify production, to contribute to rural development, to increase incomes and, in turn, to help reduce poverty.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to strengthen the two sectors mentioned, helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020. Over the past thirty years, small-scale agriculture has been neglected in Africa, while the dependence of low-income countries on food imports has grown, which has made them vulnerable to price changes on international markets. Private investment under the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa has affected more than 8.2 million small farmers and created more than 21 000 jobs, more than half of which are for women. It is necessary to ensure the transparency of all funding from private sector companies and public aid must be in accordance with the principles of development effectiveness. The fight against poverty in Africa is one of the greatest challenges we must face. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it highlights several critical aspects of 'the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa', sponsored and promoted in 2012 as a mega Public-Private Agreement that has led to structural liberalization reforms in African countries, being one of the main culprit mechanisms for land grabbing, the marginalization of small producers and the support of an unsustainable model of agriculture and livestock , contrary to the principles of food sovereignty.  Thus, the report, among other points, criticizes the negative impacts on the development of public-private agreements and, despite not turning them down, includes the need for strict regulation.  Another positive aspect is the call to support local economies and small holdings, references to the positive aspects of agroecology and the commitment to support these practices with an explicit rejection of the introduction of GMOs in Africa.  The report also highlights clear points on the need to combat land grabbing, recognizing traditional community-owned figures of land, including the right of indigenous peoples.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to end the poverty of 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020, in line with the Sustainable Development Goals. Poverty is closely linked to food insecurity and malnutrition. The New Alliance aims to promote inclusive and sustainable growth based on local and small-scale agriculture, overcoming the structural deficiencies of the various country cooperation frameworks and export-oriented agricultural investment policies characterised by the exclusion from decision-making processes of social groups that are victims of food insecurity.  EU Member States, as major donors of development aid and in the name of their trade relations with the African continent, have a key role to play in supporting and promoting local businesses and stakeholders in Africa. By voting in favour, I intend to support the actions envisaged by the New Alliance in the areas of sustainable family farming, access to land and funding for agricultural investment in Africa. In particular, I believe that the European Union can make a major contribution to the development of transparent international governance that supports African businesses, governments and farmers in reducing poverty and hunger.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A public-private partnership aimed at mobilising private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa was launched in 2012 as the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa. The engaged African states should carry out legislative reforms to support the project. Although the objective of the Alliance is good, there are many shortcomings.  Due to the poor results achieved by the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition on Poverty Reduction, as well as food security, I voted to end the support currently provided. Rather, funders and national governments should invest in a model of sustainable agriculture favourable to small farmers in order to increase the potential of domestic and regional markets for the benefit of family farms and to provide consumers with quality food at affordable prices.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8, as a major public-private partnership aimed at attracting private investment in agriculture, with a view to improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. It seeks to address the drastic shortfall in funding for achieving global food security through cooperation with the private sector, G8 countries and other international donors. It also aims to create entrepreneurial conditions in the alliance countries through systemic infrastructure reforms, taxes, good governance, as well as land and trade policies. I am of the opinion that it is essential to boost investment in African agriculture, to support private investment and to stimulate innovation in this sector. The report stresses that agricultural investment measures in Africa should in particular support the development of the local economy, including small-scale family farming. In addition, the report calls on African governments to invest in local food systems to boost the rural economy, provide social security and labour law networks and improve arrangements for democratic control of access to resources. In view of the content of the report, I have decided to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) launched in May 2012 under the auspices of the G8 aims to create the conditions that will allow the African countries concerned to improve agricultural productivity and develop their agrifood sector by attracting more private investment in agriculture. While the general objective of the NAFSN is sound, certain deficiencies remain which are underlined in the report: the need to shift to sustainable modes of agricultural production and to support farmers' seed systems, the dangers associated with the emergence of a market for land rights, the regulation of contract farming; and they are weak on nutrition as well as on the recognition of women's rights and gender empowerment. This report suggests measures that help reach these goals. I am confident that the measures that are suggested in this report will improve this project, hence I supported it with my vote.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In principle I support NAFSN and the need to address the issue of global food security and create agriculture-based growth through public-private partnerships. The key aims are undisputed in calling for a reduction in poverty and hunger, whilst also supporting African farmers to help themselves lift local communities out of poverty. However, I abstained on this report because of concerns over specific amendments which are unlikely to support the objectives originally agreed upon. The UK Government has committed heavily in tackling world hunger, leading on international efforts to meet the WHO’s international target to reduce stunted growth through malnutrition by 40%.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. According to recent studies, women account for up to 50% of the family farm workforce in sub-Saharan Africa, and the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition contributes to increasing gender inequality and increasing the marginalisation of African women. I believe that sufficient attention must be paid to gender issues through the effective participation of women in the development and implementation of agricultural research and development policies.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the European Union's privileged food and nutrition relationship with Africa, and in particular the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NASAN). Launched in 2012, NASAN aims to develop financial support from developed countries and help large companies invest in African agriculture. In return, the ten African states commit to amending their land, seed and foreign investment laws. The report stresses that investment strategies in agriculture in Africa must support the development of the local economy, especially smallholders and family farms, considering that this is the best way to combat hunger in many parts of Africa. Considering that NASAN must support the local African economy and local agricultural producers while encouraging reforms to agricultural legislation in these countries to enable them to support themselves, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a public-private partnership (PPP). NASAN aims to attract private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges that, while NASAN's objective is laudable, it has many flaws. The EU and Member States have a crucial role to play in transforming NASAN to further integrate smallholders into the development of cooperation frameworks and support local economies.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the HEUBUCH report on the new alliance for food security and nutrition created at the initiative of the G8 in 2012. It aims to foster public-private partnerships in sub-Saharan African countries. By my vote, I say that investments in agriculture are crucial because they contribute to the fight against hunger and malnutrition. These investments are also supporting the economy and creating decent jobs for the population. I give my full support to small producers and family farms, investing in the local economy is essential in the context of the fight against poverty in which the European Union must have a major role.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa established in 2012 to boost private investment in agriculture. There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocult culture production, which offers limited opportunities for growth.  I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of the report, which is critical of the new Food Security and Nutrition Alliance (NAFSN). It goes without saying that Africa needs investment in agriculture. Food security is and remains a major problem that needs to be addressed. However, the alliance does not take the right approach. It is essential for N-VA that good conditions of subsistence for African farmers can contribute to a more favourable local economy. There are also fewer push factors for migration to the EU. The alliance recognises that smaller farmers do not have the capacity to compete with multinationals. The report therefore rightly calls for a more central place in this cooperation for family businesses and local economies. At the heart of nasfn's encouragement of large-scale monocultures, the NASFN also poses environmental risks (erosion problems, biodiversity loss, a decline in the diversity of seed supply) – risks that in turn undermine food security.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa, established in 2012, to boost private investment in agriculture. There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocult culture production, which offers limited opportunities for growth.  I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) has been the subject of much criticism since its entry into force in 2012. It is a broad public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union, with a programme to develop African agriculture. A dozen countries are affected, such as Ethiopia, Côte d'Ivoire or Senegal. Nearly 180 companies are participating in the program for an investment of $8 billion. The tax, land and trade measures taken must provide a business-friendly framework. But it repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s (dependence on fertilizers, monoculture, export crops...). Unsustainable agriculture is favoured, with smallholder farmers sidelined. The report's aim is to counterbalance these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies, combating poverty and food insecurity. I voted for this text which defends food sovereignty, short circuits, local agriculture, ecological diversity and respect for the environment.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the motion for a resolution on the New Alliance for improving food security and nutrition. This public-private partnership is particularly important for revitalising public investment in agriculture in sub-Saharan Africa, as well as for providing support for private investment and promoting innovation in the agricultural sector.  The motion for a resolution underlines that agricultural investment policies in Africa must support in particular the development of the local economy, including small producers and family farms. I abstained because of some points in this proposal that I do not fully agree with, such as the assertion that large public-private partnerships can pose a risk of creating dominant positions for large agricultural companies in Africa to squeeze local business.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that poverty, inequality, as well as deprivations in terms of health, education and living, plague many European countries due to the economic crisis. That is why there must be fiscal transparency, accountability of development finance institutions, so as to better monitor money flows, as well as binding climate and renewable energy rules. Nevertheless, we are obliged to vote against the 2015 EU report on the coherence of development policy, since we are in favour of a traditional society that does not defend LGBT rights or support an immigration refugee policy, at all costs.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa established in 2012 to boost private investment in agriculture.
