There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocult culture production, which offers limited opportunities for growth.  I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, as it highlights the New Alliance’s record of undermining sustainable small-scale production and benefiting big corporations while local farms have lost both land and money. Through our membership of the EU, Wales has a voice on the international stage, and this is one example of positive work done on a global level. In Wales we know the importance of small family farms, and the need to support them for the sake of the whole economy and rural communities.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "This report highlights the importance of investment and development efforts for agricultural holdings in the context of international development work must also be targeted at SMEs and help to strengthen entrepreneurship. Unfortunately, the report also contains wordings that discourage free trade and confirms that protectionist measures should be allowed to be taken. Unfortunately, it also contains wordings which have a sceptical and in some part hostile attitude towards new technologies in agriculture. To the extent that it was possible, I voted against such wordings.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security in Africa (NASAN) was launched in 2012 to mobilise private investment in the agricultural sector in order to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. Each African country has adopted a Country Cooperation Framework (CCF) setting out the commitments made by each of the parties involved. There are, however, serious doubts as to the capacity of large-scale PPPs, such as NASAN, to contribute to poverty reduction and food security, as it may be the poorest to bear the burden of the social and environmental risks associated with them.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: it is in particular the overriding issue of food sovereignty that is highlighted in this report, which does not fail to point out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. [2012" Launched by the G8 summit in 2012, this alliance brings together the G8 countries, the African Union and several other African governments with the multinational private sector (represented by more than 150 companies, including Syngenta). The "alliance" consists of public-private partnerships that they say aim to take away more than 50 million poverty and hunger by 2022. From the outset, this alliance has provoked a number of criticisms and objections, from the decision-making process to the imposition of inappropriate agricultural policies that serve the interests of multinationals. The report integrates a number of concerns and criticisms that we share. During the whole process, the main targets have never been heard, i.e. the starving populations, small farmers, fishermen, indigenous peoples, women and other marginalized groups. It is understood: at the heart of the strategies are not their interests, but those of private groups and G8 countries. This has ensured that, in many cooperation frameworks, basic and human rights are not even guaranteed, be it the right to participation, the right to food and nutrition, the right to land and to produce, social protection and income, among others. In the Committee on Agriculture, we made several proposals which were eventually welcomed in the final report. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it was positive overall.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new Food Security and Nutrition Alliance was created mainly to invest in agriculture by African countries, thus contributing to the creation of a favourable business environment through reforms of policies on infrastructure, taxes, land or trade, easier access to long-term renting of unused land. I firmly believe that the European Union and its Member States will play a key role in supporting family farms and local economies in Africa in the future, thus helping to do their part in combating poverty, food and nutrition insecurity, which is why millions of people on the African continent are suffering.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which seeks to protect the rights of African resident populations and positively calls into question the role of EU Member States.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that malnutrition, poverty, inequality, are problems plaguing African countries. This, of course, is contributed by unequal taxation, the exploitation of investors, the incorrect management of natural resources, but also the loss of biodiversity, soil erosion and illiteracy. That is why I am voting in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the New Alliance on Food Security and Nutrition, in order to combat corruption, to stimulate agricultural production, always defending human rights, in order to avoid mass migration.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), launched in May 2012 under the auspices of the G8, aims to create the conditions that will allow the African countries concerned to improve agricultural productivity and develop their agrifood sector by attracting more private investment in agriculture. While the general objective of the NAFSN is sound, certain deficiencies remain which are underlined in the report. African governments should invest more in local food systems in order to boost rural economies, ensure decent jobs, equitable social safety nets and labour rights; to improve arrangements for democratic scrutiny of access to resources, including farmers’ seeds; and to ensure the effective engagement of small-scale producers in policy processes and implementation. The EU should address all NAFSN deficiencies outlined in the report, including enhancing its transparency and governance, so as to ensure that actions taken under the New Alliance are consistent with development policy goals. I supported the report in the plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa, established in 2012, to boost private investment in agriculture. There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocultural production, which offers limited opportunities for growth. I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue. I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm determination that the food drama in many countries can be re-filled with the means at our disposal. Initiatives such as this, where public-private cooperation for a greater objective prevails, must be supported by the EU.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on the new alliance for food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, a G8 initiative launched in 2012 and supported by the EU to develop partnership with local businesses, because I believe it is necessary for the initiative to integrate environmental protection measures and, above all, guarantees against land grabbing. Confirmation for the coming years involves a review process that cannot but take account of transparency and governance, of the need for support for sustainable agriculture, capable of achieving a fundamental objective: to help combat hunger in many regions of Africa. This can only happen if this new alliance focuses on sustainable, local and human-scale food production, if private land grabbing, often detached from local needs, is put to an end.  The European Parliament is calling for a change of pace and a link between investment policies in agriculture and local development. Finally, I strongly supported the need for greater involvement of small holders who have so far been excluded from the negotiations, greater transparency, the need for future investments to be subject to prior impact analysis, robust regulation and monitoring of public-private partnerships.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. It is true that the text sets a real focus – even if it critically discusses the use of genetically modified plants in development policy. At the same time, it completely omits another aspect of food security: the importance of breastfeeding in developing countries. This would require a much stronger commitment to maternal and child health.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Investment strategies in the field of agriculture in Africa should be better interlinked. This will help to support the development of the local economy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, about the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN). However, while the overall objectives of the report are sound, there are still some issues which I feel need to be dealt with. For example, I believe agricultural investment policies should be linked and support the development of the local economy and small scale farmers. In addition, there needs to be an effort to stop land grabbing. I would also welcome better regulation and monitoring of public-private partnerships, as well as making undertakings accountable for human rights, social environmental and labour standards, etc.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), launched in 2012 under the aegis of the G8, is a broad public-private partnership that aims to mobilise private investment in agriculture, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. Investment in agriculture is a priority for these countries. However, together with some of my fellow Members, we share the fear that mistakes of the past will be repeated. That is why I support this report, to ensure that European investors respect and encourage the alliance's other partners to respect the rights of local communities and the needs of small farms, following a human rights-based approach within the cooperation frameworks, including the maintenance of environmental, social, land, labour and human rights rights safeguards and the highest standards of transparency in their investment plans. In particular, I welcome the call for the European Union to promote, in agreement with the United Nations, the binding adoption of the Milan Charter and the commitments contained in it by all countries and the Milan Urban Food Policy Pact.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NASAN) is a broad public-private partnership that includes the G8, the African Union and 180 companies. It is an African agriculture development programme that has edsted in a dozen countries since 2012. This programme promotes unsustainable agriculture on the model of the one that wreaked havoc in Asia in the 1970s. However, in this model, smallholders no longer survive. This is why this report aims to stimulate family farming and the local economy by combating both farmers' poverty and food security.  The report also defends proximity by focusing on short circuits and local agriculture. It promotes security of supply by limiting the import of food to local foodstuffs in a spirit of self-sufficiency. This security of supply would, in particular, solve the problem of African migration to the European Union. In addition, it would allow them to obtain quality products at affordable prices. The report also denounces the fight against the excessive use of plant protection products as well as fertilizers that wash soils and cause ecological disasters. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote for this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The G8 programme for food security in Africa, which aims to boost investment in the agricultural sector, appears at first glance to be a good idea. But the rapporteur is right to point out the shortcomings, and I must welcome the relevance of his remarks. The food problem in Africa will not be solved by favouring large farms owned by private companies, intensive agriculture consuming chemical fertilizers, export monocultures, the use of certified or genetically modified seeds... On the contrary, Africans will be placed under the tutelage of large multinational groups, since this "new alliance" is a public-private partnership, whose profits and logics of the private sector will benefit more than the public interest and that of the local populations. The first step would be to encourage rural exodus and then to the international exodus of impoverished and dispossessed populations. That is why I share many of the rapporteur's proposals to promote 'sustainable' local agriculture, respecting the specificities of both agronomic and legal (e.g. land law) of African countries, in order to boost the rural economy and encourage the greatest possible food independence. I say this without cynicism: an essential way to combat mass immigration to our countries is to combat the causes of emigration.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Considering that the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020; and that the participating countries have negotiated national cooperation frameworks, which set out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agriculture sector in Africa, we voted in favour of this Resolution, which warns of the risks of the role that the private sector can play in this particular if it is not well regulated.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Agricultural investment policies should be linked to, and should support, the development of the local economy, including smallholders and family farming.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because it contains important elements and positions on food security and nutrition in third countries. It stresses the need to support the development of local communities, for measures to protect the environment, and opposes the reckless exploitation promoted by large enterprises. Finally, it sets out all the development and measures for food security and nutrition within the framework of the development objectives set by the international community.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion for resolution on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is an invaluable strategy for sustainability and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The new alliance will promote security, nutrition and sustainable family farming practices which boosts food security through healthy living soils and productive agro—ecosystems. The alliance will also support the funding of agricultural investment in Africa, calling on donors to align Official Development Assistance (ODA) with the development effectiveness principles, support education, training and technical counselling for farmers, and promote the forming of farmers’ organisations of a professional and economic nature. The Alliance plan aims to reduce and ultimately eradicate poverty by focusing on the development of small scale farmers.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to its final form.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. Today we are voting on the new Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security in sub-Saharan Africa. Millions of people are still starving in southern Africa and malnutrition is a contributing factor to more than half of all deaths among the world's children. That is something we must take very seriously. Therefore, the new initiative to reduce hunger based on the Asian model is often referred to as the 'Green Revolution' good. We cannot support the European Parliament's criticism of the initiative or the call for the whole of southern Africa to become a test rabbit for the small-scale, non-mechanised, ecological and GMO-free agriculture that the Green Party usually advocates in Sweden. This risks causing millions of people to starve completely unnecessarily. Those who now want to deny Africa's agriculture modern technologies and methods are also responsible for the famine and misery in which such a policy will inevitably cement millions of poor people. That is why we are voting against the report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa established in 2012 to boost private investment in agriculture. There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocult culture production, which offers limited opportunities for growth.  I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which addresses deficiencies in the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN) including the need to prioritise food security and nutrition over export opportunities and growth along with effective action towards hunger and poverty alleviation. Safeguarding farmers’ land rights and protecting their environment from concentrated land ownership is vital, so I welcome the fact that this report calls on private companies to create appeal mechanisms and publish publicly—accessible annual reports.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), which was launched in 2012, has the aim to create the conditions that will allow the African countries concerned to improve agricultural productivity with more private investment. We agree with most of the objectives of NAFSN. However, certain deficiencies remain which are underlined in the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (2015/2277(INI)), as in addition to all the positive assumptions contained in the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition, this document also lists problems that should be remedied. First and foremost, the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa, launched in 2012. under the auspices of the G8 as a major public-private partnership to strengthen private investment in agriculture to improve food supply and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, aims to support efforts to combat poverty, provide sufficient food, help local and family farms, and become a true instrument of sustainable development and an instrument to assist sub-Saharan Africa. The problem arises that large multinational companies operating under the New Alliance prioritise large-scale contract agriculture, putting small producers in a subordinate position. Also funding member states provided to the New Alliance violates the objective of supporting domestic and local businesses that cannot compete with multinationals that already benefit from a dominant position. It is necessary to put small manufacturers in a better position.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report highlights the overriding issue of food sovereignty. This report does not fail to point out, among other things, that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of local populations. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report, which criticises the new alliance - a G8 initiative launched in 2012 to support public-private partnerships in developing countries to combat hunger - and calls for greater transparency and attention to small farmers in the countries concerned. The different investment strategies in agriculture in Africa should be more connected and better support the development of the local economy.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Ensuring food security is a great challenge for European agriculture. As a well-developed continent, meeting our needs, we should be responsible for third world countries where development is slower and conditions are much more difficult for it. This human solidarity should determine support for those who are unable to cope on their own. Africa is a particularly difficult area due to climate, limited water resources and the state of education.  However, the work done so far in this area is not satisfactory. It is good that improvements are taking place in the legal or tax systems of these countries, but the most commitment requires work at the root, and this is lacking. The biggest beneficiaries should be small producers, not business tycoons, who for the time being receive the most facilitation. Current solutions facilitate land grabbing, marginalise small producers and hinder women's access to the labour market, and promote unsustainable agriculture.  The European Union must play a key role in the process of genuinely supporting family farms and economies, in particular by creating sound governance structures ensuring a fair distribution of profits and losses between the parties.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with the issue of sustainable development in the context of the food gap in Africa. It contains important approaches to improve food security in African countries. Although the rapporteur assigns limited self-competence to these countries, the report as a whole must be judged to be balanced. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it calls on the EU to address all the New Alliance’s deficiencies, including enhancing its transparency and governance, so as to ensure that actions taken under the New Alliance are consistent with development policy goals.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is tasked with improving food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa to escape poverty by 2020, which is why I supported it in the vote. This issue is, of course, also important for the future of Europe in many ways. Africa should be as self-sufficient as possible. However, the situation is complicated as there is a risk of further migration waves in the future due to global warming. Africa is becoming increasingly soer, limiting the possibility of survival in certain areas. Moreover, the continent, like the world as a whole, should meet the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to meet them by 2030, in particular those related to the elimination of hunger and poverty. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I appreciate that the report 'urges the G8 Member States not to support GM crops in Africa'. I wonder how some G8 countries, especially the US, will deal with this when gmos are trying to impose on the EU at all costs, but fortunately it has the strength to oppose it. But what chance do states facing economic instability and significant social problems have against such an important lobby?

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the partnership of the New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa established in 2012 to boost private investment in agriculture. There are shortcomings in the objectives, as they are mainly based on the 1960 green revolutionary model, monocult culture production, which offers limited opportunities for growth.  I think it is important to create agricultural investments in Africa that support local farmers and family farms. The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance is committed to development based on agriculture and aims to create a business-friendly environment. The shortcoming of the partnership is that, while cooperation should be based on small producers, it is the small producers who have barely participated in the dialogue.  I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses the importance of governance and ownership, accountability, support for sustainable family farms and land access. It also calls on African governments to invest in the local food system, create new jobs and ensure transparency.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the report on the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition, which I supported, I voted against paragraph 72, which calls on the G8 countries not to support GMO crops in Africa.  Aware of the controversy caused by the use of GMOs in agriculture, and of the need to control and monitor and the strict rules to which such crops should be subject, I believe that Africa is one of those places on Earth where GMOs are simply a necessity. Unlike a Europe whose fertile soils and climate give us choice, Africa – affected by drought, high soil salinity, diversity and pest multiplicity – without GMOs has very little agricultural production capacity. This is compounded by a demographic explosion; Africa's population growth is exacerbated by the need for effective solutions related to the need to feed the population.  I am opposed to the automatic transfer of European philosophies and solutions to continents where other climatic, natural, political and cultural conditions determine different solutions. In the EU, the use of GMOs is a matter of freedom of choice. In Africa, the use of GMOs is the only effective means of combating hunger currently available. The humanitarian alternative blocks Africa's development, its own potential, is a dead end and an example of the protectionist treatment by the Western world of countries that should find their own way of development.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) aims to leverage private investment in agriculture in order to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020. The EU and Member States have a key role to play in transforming NAFSN into a genuine instrument of support for family farming and local economics in sub-Saharan Africa. Investment in family farming aims before all to boost domestic food production in order to build self—sufficiency, which consequently will decrease the level of food imports /humanitarian aid dependency. I supported the resolution because the EU and Member States should support agriculture in sub-Saharan Africa through national development funds which grant subsidies and loans to family farms. In order to facilitate the process even further, the Union should provide education and training to family farmers. Last but not least, the EU should work to promote the formation of farmers’ organisations that help farmers possess on the market their production in a way that safeguards the profitability of their production. Fighting hunger is a priority enshrined in the first Millennium Development Goal. The EU should continue to contribute significantly to this goal.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we are voting on a report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. It aims to guarantee private investment in agriculture, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, although there are many problems. For this reason, each African country has adopted a framework for cooperation (CCF) with which it determines the commitments undertaken by the parties involved with regard to the various legislative reforms of the same. Many improvements are possible, but this certainly has an excellent working basis, to allow better living conditions and greater guarantees of food safety. I therefore believe that the agricultural sector is of fundamental importance to our country and that it is the global reference point for high-quality products, which is why innovation in agricultural management must be supported and encouraged.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is as hostile as I am to the NASAN device. It is for food sovereignty, for ecological diversity and for local people in order to avoid their emigration as well.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report entitled 'The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition'. Since its entry into force in 2012, the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) has been the source of much criticism. It is a public-private partnership of the G8, the African Union, with a programme for the development of African agriculture. A dozen African countries are involved, from Ethiopia to Côte d'Ivoire to Senegal. Nearly 180 companies are participating in the $8 billion investment program. Tax, land and trade measures must create a business-friendly environment. But it repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s (dependence on fertilizers, monoculture, export crops...). Unsustainable agriculture is therefore favoured, with smallholder farmers sidelined. The aim of this report is to counterbalance these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies, by combating poverty and food insecurity. In particular, the crucial issue of food sovereignty is highlighted in this report, which points out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Indeed, it proposes to change the dynamics of the NASAN program. The programme for the new alliance for food security and nutrition in Africa is not fulfilling the promises set in 2012. Although it is innovative, since it is a broad public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union and combines 180 partner companies and a dozen African countries, it reiterates the destructive pattern put in place in Asia in the 1970s (unsustainable agriculture, monoculture, etc.). That is why the report wants to reverse this logic, by revaluing family and local agriculture, food sovereignty, local economies, access to quality products at low cost... This text, with remarkable common sense, defends our vision of agriculture.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it highlights several critical aspects of 'the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa', sponsored and promoted in 2012 as a mega Public-Private Agreement that has led to structural liberalization reforms in African countries, being one of the main culprit mechanisms for land grabbing, the marginalization of small producers and the support of an unsustainable model of agriculture and livestock , contrary to the principles of food sovereignty.  Thus, the report, among other points, criticizes the negative impacts on the development of public-private agreements and, despite not turning them down, includes the need for strict regulation.  Another positive aspect is the call to support local economies and small holdings, references to the positive aspects of agroecology and the commitment to support these practices with an explicit rejection of the introduction of GMOs in Africa.  The report also highlights clear points on the need to combat land grabbing, recognizing traditional community-owned figures of land, including the right of indigenous peoples.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the one hand, the report calls on the EU to remove tariffs on African products, which I agree with. On the other hand, the report criticises the tax incentives that African countries provide. I think we should leave it up to African countries what taxes they have. The report also calls on Member States to ensure that EU-based firms doing business in Africa apply a 'social responsibility policy' in Africa and to ensure respect for 'environmental, social, land, labour and human rights and the highest standards of transparency' and to promote 'local African businesses'. This is not what our government can do, law enforcement in Africa has to be provided by African governments. For these serious reasons, I voted against it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The new Food Security and Nutrition Alliance in Africa was launched in 2012 as a major public-private partnership aimed at strengthening private investment in agriculture to improve food supply in sub-Saharan Africa. Instead of supporting the model of modern agriculture underpinning the New Alliance, based on large-scale industrial agriculture, more should be invested in family farms.  Family farmers and smallholders are major investors in African agriculture and provide over 60% employment in Africa. The EU must play a key role in transforming the New Alliance into the right instrument, and this needs to address governance and property rights, promote sustainable family farms, access to land and property security. The EU should not use official development assistance to support transnational companies operating as monopolies or cartels, thus contributing to the undermining of the local private sector.  Given the existing shortcomings, the rapporteur believes that the EU should suspend its current support for the New Alliance, and donors and national governments should invest in a sustainable model of agriculture. I supported this report because in this way family farmers would benefit the most and consumers would be provided with quality food at affordable prices.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As you know, the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN) in Africa became operational in 2012, when it was launched under the leadership of the G8 group of countries, with the aim of reinining the usefulness of private investment in agriculture and thus improving food security and nutrition in Black African countries. In particular, the European Union is responsible for the coordination of the efforts to be implemented in Côte d'C and Malawi. Nafsn's general idea is to implement, under African conditions, a model of agricultural development that includes monoculture, mechanisation, biotechnology, dependence on fertilisers, long distribution routes and the production of products for export. Eradicating widespread family poverty is very important in this context, as family farmers and small-country farmers provide more than 60% of employment in the region. In order to achieve the implementation of such a model, particular attention shall be paid to aspects of the policy to be implemented, such as governance and accountability, accountability framework, promotion of sustainable family farming, access to land and property security, seed regulation, promotion of gender equality and also funding investment in Agriculture in Africa. Africa's development potential is likely to be quite high, which is particularly relevant for agriculture. It would therefore be essential to provide the countries of the continent with the necessary support to enable them to carry out these fundamental development efforts on their own in the future, on the basis of their own and the forces of the regional partners. The main threat to NAFSN is, and is likely to be, further environmental pollution. Hopefully this problem will also be resolved soon.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Launched in 2012, the new alliance is an agricultural development programme funded by the G8 countries and the European Union. The aim of this programme is to lift 50 million people out of poverty in 10 African partner countries by investing private companies in intensive agriculture. The extensive and trade-friendly agriculture model encouraged by the new export-based alliance risks creating dominant positions and thus threatening the survival of Africa's agricultural fabric, which is 90% family farms. Moreover, in its current form, this international initiative is more focused on opening up a new market for the benefit of large seed companies. The text therefore rightly points out that G8 members are not using the new alliance as a means of promoting GMO production.  This text therefore conditions the Union's participation in such an initiative in the achievement of a whole range of prerequisites, including transparency of funding, respect for biodiversity, access to land or water. In order for the Union not to participate in the plundering of agricultural resources on the African continent, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition, because it is comprehensive and documented and because this report addresss the issues I raised in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016 in relation to the action of the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Written by German ecologist Maria Heubuch, who is also an opponent of TTIP and glyphosate, the report harshly criticises the "new alliance for food security and nutrition in Africa" programme that came into force in 2012. It affects a dozen African countries and involves some 180 companies for an investment of up to $8 billion. This program ultimately harmed modest farms in favour of large industrial production.  On the other hand, this report recommends a number of interesting avenues: short circuits, local agriculture and the limitation of the use of plant protection products.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the New Alliance for Food Safety and Nutrition supports me. The primary aim of the New Alliance is to accelerate responsible investment in African agriculture and to lift 50 million people out of poverty, hunger and malnutrition, aiming at actions that mainly concern the increase in private investment, and to open up natural resources and African markets to multinationals.  Over the past thirty years, small-scale agriculture in Africa has been neglected, in this way favouring large-scale, highly capitalised and mechanised forms of production. Family farms and small landowners can provide diversified products and increase food production in a sustainable way. There is therefore a need for greater cooperation between the EU and the Member States, by empowering companies in the field of human rights, by ensuring that Member States fulfil their extraterrestrial obligations, by supporting and promoting African companies, and by removing tariff barriers that discourage African countries.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report addressing the objectives of the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. The issue of nutrition is and will be extremely topical. It is estimated that 70% of the world's population will live in cities in 2050, and that the issue of nutrition will still require a response at both global and regional level. The new alliance aims to improve this issue by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa escape poverty by 2020. Investment in small-scale agriculture has been severely neglected in Africa in recent years, and this needs to be rectified. I also agree that food security in developing countries depends to a large extent on the sustainable use of natural resources. Access to water needs to be improved and nutrition education intensified and best practice strategies shared. The report contains a number of ideas with which I can only identify, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa is an initiative to provide financial support for investment in agriculture by partnering both private and public bodies to ensure food security and nutrition in Africa. Each Member State of the Alliance essentially assumes responsibility for implementing the initiative in an African country and thus a framework for cooperation between them is established. I believe that the EU can play a key role in achieving the above objective, while also contributing to the strengthening of family farming by African small farmers and, on a broader plan, to the fight against poverty. We must not forget the need to create resilient and sustainable production systems and the participation of small farmers in production, who make up 60% of agricultural employment in Africa according to the rapporteur's report. I therefore agree with the report that we should deal mainly with agroecology and family farming, taking into account the needs of the local population, rather than purely with far-reaching technocratic industrial agriculture. For these reasons I would like to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft contains good approaches to food security in these African countries. Many correct measures are called for. The right problems are also addressed. I therefore support this draft.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa aims to improve food security in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020 and to help people get out of poverty. Specific G7 partners have been given the responsibility to coordinate the implementation of the initiative in a specific African country. The EU is responsible for coordination in Côte d'Ivoire and Malawi. Each of the eight African countries participating in this programme has adopted a cooperation programme setting out the commitments of each Contracting Alliance. These commitments relate to legislative reforms in the african countries concerned, the plans for funding g7 donors and the pledge of 180 participating companies to invest a total of EUR 8 billion. Usd. The European Parliament's report on the functioning of this food security alliance raises various concerns, such as the disproportionate power of foreign corporations in African countries, violations of land ownership rights, and the fact that small, individual African farms are not reaching support, and they continue to be poor.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) is a programme to help people in African countries improve food security and nutrition. While NASAN's objective is laudable, it has many flaws that the report details. Thus the report opposes the logic of "green revolution" advocated by NASAN, which increases "dependence on chemical fertilizers and pesticides, causes serious soil degradation and contributes to climate change". The report also reiterates the need to 'protect the right of farmers to multiply, use, exchange and sell their seeds'. The text also denounces the fiscal, land and trade policies that contribute to land grabbing and deprive people of the usual food crops. In fact, this programme mainly helps multinationals to develop their markets and few African farmers. The report has understood this and believes that the Union and its Member States should withdraw their support for NASAN. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) is a broad public-private partnership (PPP) of the G8, African Union, with a programme to develop African agriculture. NASAN repeats the same mistakes as in Asia in the 1970s: unreased agriculture favoured and smallholders sidelined. The report aims to offset these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies. As the issue of food sovereignty is paramount, with a direct impact on migration, I voted for this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I presented my vote in favour on the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security. The New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security in Africa (NASAN) was launched in 2012 under the aegis of the G8 as a broad public-private partnership (PPP) aimed at mobilising private investment in the agricultural sector in order to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. The EU and the Member States have a key role to play in transforming NASAN into a genuine tool to support family farming and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa in order to combat poverty and food and nutrition insecurity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition, as it aims to leverage private investment in agriculture in order to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, which is a successful way to combat poverty among farmers in this part of the world.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The new Food Security Alliance aims to mobilize private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. As a result, each participating African country has adopted a framework of cooperation setting out commitments for legislative reforms, G7 donor funding intentions and corporate pledges to invest a total of $8 billion. In this context, the European Union is responsible for coordination in Côte d'Ivoire and Malawi. If the objective of the new alliance is noble, it has many flaws, which this report has the merit of pointing out. The new alliance must not replicate the model of the Asian Green Revolution in Africa, marginalize small-scale African farmers, and undermine unsustainable agriculture. In my view, the Union must make the new alliance a support for family farming and local economies, with the ultimate aim of combating poverty and food and nutrition insecurity.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa is a public-private partnership aimed at attracting private investment in agriculture to increase food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. Agreed policies in host countries aim to create a favourable business environment through reforms of policies relating to infrastructure, taxes, land, easier access to long-term leases of unused land, as well as through regulatory reforms in the field of seeds in order to strengthen the intellectual property rights of plant breeders. In this context, I consider it important to note that the interests of POs and local groups are not represented in the Alliance. It is small family farms and smallholder farmers that are the main investors in African agriculture and provide more than 60% of jobs, and I therefore believe that this is what support should be given. Until recently, support for agriculture was often focused on export crops, the production of which is the responsibility of men, while the tasks associated with producing food for the subsual of families were mostly left to women. Priority should also be given to eliminating all forms of discrimination against women in access to land, improving women's access to programmes and services, as well as effectively involving women in the design and implementation of agricultural research and development policy. The proposal has my support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition because, in my opinion, it is important that African governments invest more in local food systems in order to boost rural economies, ensure decent jobs, equitable social safety nets and labour rights in order to improve arrangements for democratic scrutiny of access to resources, including farmers’ seeds and to ensure the effective engagement of small-scale producers in policy processes and implementation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa (NAFSN) initiative was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a public-private partnership (PPP) aimed at boosting private investment in agriculture in order to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. NAFSN aims to replicate in Africa the model of the "green revolution" implemented in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s, based on monoculture crop production, mechanisation, biotechnology, dependence on fertilisers, long distribution chains and the cultivation of export crops. The limitations of this method are well known, in particular the environmental risks involved. The Committee on Development report calls into question the ability of large-scale PPP, such as NAFSN, to contribute to poverty reduction and food security, as there is a high risk that the poorest communities will have to bear the bulk of the social and environmental risks that come with them. It argues that the EU and its Member States should stop supporting NAFSN and instead invest in an agricultural model that is sustainable, supports small agricultural production and women, and which brings to light the potential of domestic and regional markets in such a way that family farmers can benefit from it and provide customers with high-quality food at affordable prices. I supported the motion.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security in Africa (NASAN) was launched in 2012, under the aegis of the G8, as a broad public-private partnership (PPP) aimed at mobilising private investment in the agricultural sector in order to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. I endorse the rapporteur's position in recognising the need for African countries to invest in agriculture. While its goal is to welcome, NASAN still has many shortcomings. The European Union and the Member States play a key role in transforming NASAN into a genuine tool to support family farming and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa in order to combat poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. It is vital that the EU tries to address the NASAN shortcomings outlined in the report, strengthen transparency and governance and ensure that the actions implemented by the Alliance are consistent with the objectives of development policy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The overriding issue of food sovereignty is highlighted in this report, and it is essential. This report does not fail to point out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations. I vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls on the deficiencies identified in the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition on public-private partnerships, land rights, chemical fertilisers and support for small farmers and the local economy to be rectified, whilst still maintaining support for the New Alliance aims and ambition. Labour MEPs will remain vigilant and do what we can to address the problems identified in the New Alliance in order to make sure that actions taken under the NAFSN are consistent with development policy goals.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new Global Food Security Alliance, which was decided in 2012 at the Camp David Summit by the G8 to promote public-private partnerships in developing countries to combat hunger. This report calls for greater transparency in the implementation of this alliance and, on the other hand, greater attention for small farmers in the countries affected by this initiative, which should not be forgotten for the benefit of private partners.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report as it aims to improve food security and food security in Africa, helping 50 million people out of poverty in the sub-Saharan region by 2020. So far, not all stakeholders, including rural communities, farm workers, fishermen and indigenous peoples, have been involved in the decision-making processes of the cooperation framework, but have been excluded from them and their right to participate has been disregarded. The New Food and Nutrition Security Association would change this situation. It would contribute to ensuring that EU-based investors respect the rights of local communities and the needs of small producers, and encourage other partners in the Alliance to do so, within the framework of cooperation, by applying a human rights-based approach that includes environmental, social, land-related, labour and human rights safeguards and the highest level of transparency in their investment plans.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN) was launched in 2012, bringing a new phase of global investment in food security and nutrition. I support this report that aims to achieve sustained and inclusive agricultural growth, raising 50 million people out of poverty in the next years.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the deficiencies shown by the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) since its launch in 2012, I support the withdrawal of EU support from it. The NAFSN was created as a large public-private partnership with the sound objective of leveraging much needed private investment in agriculture in South Africa and thus contributing to poverty reduction and food security. However, so far it has failed to meet such goals. Among the main reasons underlying the NAFSN’s failure are the fact that is has mainly supported large-scale industrial farming, further marginalising small-scale producers and women, as well as inefficient accountability mechanisms.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the authors of the report, I believe that every effort must be made to improve nutrition, food security and combat hunger in developing countries. The data show that stability is higher and emigration rates are lower in areas where food is secured on the basis of healthy and living land and productive, climate-resilient agricultural ecosystems. Ways should be sought to move from over-reliance on food imports to ensuring reliable domestic food production, with priority given to local crops that meet nutritional requirements. I believe that, regardless of the position of the EU and individual Member States on the cultivation of GM crops within the EU, we should not prevent the cultivation of GM crops in developing countries facing food insecurity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the draft contains very good approaches to food security in the African countries mentioned. The draft mentions risks affecting national agricultural economies and the dangers of water supply for small farmers and export-oriented investors.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important to invest in an agricultural model that promotes small farmers, supports women and promotes the opportunities of domestic and regional markets in Africa.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The "New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa" (NAFSN) concerns a huge public-private partnership within the G8, which literally gives "land and water" to business groups for their uninterrupted profitability. Huge monopolies have already been interested and involved, as the relevant agreements will bring them untold profits. The resolution, by pressing on a number of existing problems, such as 'land grabs' which risk further marginalisation and extermination of small producers, the 'exclusion of land workers', the 'seeds' of monopolies, 'racial discrimination', supports and premiums the necessity of the agreement, moving to the logic of a so-called fixation. It is provocative that the business groups involved are given in addition to financing and even tax exemptions for the 'creation of special economic zones' in order to invest funds supposedly to provide food to the peoples of Africa.  The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against this resolution, the only real aim of which is to disorient and conceal the relentless truth: thousands of acres are given north to monopolies for exploitation and the conditions for their profitability are guaranteed, while poor living conditions, hunger and migration to avoid them are the harsh everyday life for the peoples of Africa.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because there is much validity in the criticisms in this report, even if the solutions are not ours.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the original objectives of the New Food Security Alliance in Arica for African agricultural development and support for the fight against malnutrition, given that, to date, it seems that the interventions implemented have facilitated PPPs and consequently larger farms, to the detriment of small family-run businesses, given that attitudes that respect human rights and aimed at combating social exclusion , although essential, are still not widespread, given, finally, that the NAFSN, as implemented, does not reflect the principles and values that favoured its birth, although I do not agree with some points of the proposal, I believe that it should be voted on on the whole positively. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Investing in the development of the agriculture sector is a key step in achieving a better sustainable future. Agriculture-based growth supports small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty, hunger and under-nutrition. This is why I welcome the report on the proposal of calling the African governments to invest in local food systems so that they boost rural economies and ensure more jobs opportunities and equitable social safety nets.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a public-private partnership (PPP), which aims to attract private investment in agriculture to improve food and nutrition safety in sub-Saharan Africa. The European Union's experience in the successful implementation of the Small Farms-based Common Agricultural Policy is valuable knowledge and experience that needs to be shared with developing countries in order to ensure a sufficient supply of quality food to their populations as well.  In my view, agricultural investment policies in Africa need to be targeted to support the development of the local economy, including small producers and family farms. I welcome the commitment to promote including growth based on agriculture and supports small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty, hunger and malnutrition. In addition, it is important to invite African governments to invest in local food systems to improve the economy in rural areas, ensure decent jobs, fair social protection networks and labour rights, and improve conditions for democratic control of access to resources.  I supported this resolution, because helping this part of the world depends not only on money and donations, but also on the care of their independent, inclusive and sustainable economic growth that begins in the agricultural sector.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The overriding issue of food sovereignty is highlighted in this report, and it is essential. This report does not fail to point out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations. I therefore vote for this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) is a broad public-private partnership that aims to mobilise private investment in agriculture, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. While the overall objective of the NAFSN is more than valid, there are several shortcomings, which are highlighted in this report. The most obvious problems are: the need for a shift to sustainable forms of agricultural production and support for the systems used by farmers for seeds; risks related to the emergence of a securities market; the ineffectiveness of combating malnutrition and the recognition of women's rights. Agricultural investment policies should therefore be conditional on the development of the local economy and small producers. Cooperation projects should be completely transparent and subject to strict control mechanisms, including forms of redress for the local populations concerned. The FAO guidelines on responsible land, fisheries and forest ownership management must apply to each project. Other basic principles must be the fight against land grabbing and, finally, the responsibility of contractors with regard to human rights and social, environmental and labour standards.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020.  As investment in small farms has been neglected in Africa over the past 30 years and dependence on food imports by low-income countries has increased significantly, making them vulnerable to price fluctuations in international markets, I call on governments and donors to suspend or review all policies, projects and advisory activities that directly encourage and enable the race for arable land through highly unfair projects and investments or indirectly encourage increased pressure on the country and natural resources and which can be the cause of serious human rights violations, and I call for support to therefore be provided to policies that protect the needs of small producers, in particular women, and promote sustainable land use. I also encourage EU Member States to seek to transform the New Alliance into a sustainable development instrument and instrument to support family farms and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, and I recall that family farmers and smallholders produce around 80% of the world's food and are responsible for more than 60 % of employment in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Marie Heubuch's report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa. In order to improve food supply and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, private investment in agriculture needs to be stepped up. The new alliance, launched in 2012, covers G8 members, the African Union, the New Africa Development Partnership (NEPAD) and the Comprehensive African Agriculture Development Programme (CAADP). One in four people in sub-Saharan Africa is malnourished. As the world's leading humanitarian aid donor, the European Union plays an important role in transforming the New Alliance into an efficient mechanism for providing financial and operational assistance to local economies and family farmers in sub-Saharan Africa. By effectively implementing international standards, we will help reduce poverty levels and increase food security in this area.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to see such positive efforts being made by the European Union in restructuring NAFSN to further promote human rights, reduce poverty, and cooperate effectively with local farmers and families in sub-Saharan Africa to mitigate the inadequacies which currently exist. This motion encapsulates the spirit of ‘true’ external affairs and highlights honest international cooperation between states. The pivot from a modern, business-oriented approach to wiser investments in family farming and agro—ecology clearly underlines this. As a result of such focus, we are able to move in line with previous agreements on climate change and sustainable agriculture as well as diversify crop production, increase living standards and develop rural areas – effectively reducing poverty. I will echo the acknowledgement of gender equality in the agricultural sector as integral to development – socially, economically, and politically. I would go even further and state gender equality as one of the most important issues in the fight against poverty as it utilises the full potential of women. That is why I support this motion and welcome even more progress in supporting our developing partners in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Launched in 2012, nafsn (New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa) aims to enhance financial support from donor countries to help large companies invest in African agriculture. In return, the ten participating sub-Saharan African states are required to amend their land, seed and foreign investment legislation. In defining cooperation frameworks by country, however, consultation of small holders was minimal, despite the fact that they should be the final beneficiaries of the NAFSN. For this reason, the NAFSN has been the subject of severe criticism. It is considered that the NAFSN risks facilitating land grabbing and further marginalizing small producers and women, while supporting unsustainable agriculture. Agricultural investment policies are intended to support the development of the local economy, allowing African governments to invest in local food systems to increase rural economies, ensure decent jobs and the right to work. In order to identify the best development objectives, the EU should address a number of shortcomings, including transparency and governance. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a major public-private partnership aimed at attracting private investment in agriculture with a view to improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. It seeks to address the drastic shortfall in funding for the pursuit of global food security through cooperation with the private sector, G8 countries and other international donors. It also aims to create entrepreneurial conditions in the alliance countries through systemic infrastructure reforms, taxes, good governance, as well as land and trade policies. The key issue is to boost investment in African agriculture, support private investment and stimulate innovation in this sector. Focusing solely on the granting of land titles often results in uncertainty for small food producers and indigenous peoples. Large public-private partnerships will give large agricultural companies a dominant position in African agriculture, which will help to crowd out local businesses. I therefore abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) was established in 2012 as part of the G8 and aims, through public-private partnerships, to attract private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. I voted in favour of this resolution, which stresses the need to invest in the local African economy. NASAN will also be required to provide an annual report assessing the effectiveness of its programs in the fight against poverty, hunger and undernutrition.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because there is much validity in the criticisms in this report, even if the solutions are not ours.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security in Africa (NASAN) is a broad public-private partnership aimed at mobilising private investment in the agricultural sector to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. NASAN's strategy is based on monoculture, mechanization, biotechnology, fertilizer dependence, long distribution channels and crop production for export. The limits of this approach are well known, in particular the environmental risks it entails. The EU and the Member States have a key role to play in transforming NASAN into a genuine tool to support family farming and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa in order to combat poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. The rapporteur believes that the EU should suspend support for NASAN and that donors and national governments should invest in a sustainable farming model for smallholder farmers and women in order to benefit farmers on a family farm and provide consumers with quality food at affordable prices. In line with the Socialist Group, I voted to continue support for NASAN, on condition that the shortcomings identified are resolved.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which notes that multinationals operating under the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NASAN) are promoting large-scale contract farming, at the risk of marginalizing small local producers, and that it is essential to strengthen farmers' organisations, for example, in order to give them more clout in the negotiations. I also supported an amendment which deplores the fact that in the African context companies are calling for harmonization of seed laws which is destined to hinder the establishment and development of peasant seed systems because they do not meet the criteria of distinction, homogeneity and stability (DHS).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Food security and food quality are key issues of the present. The current technological development is starting to threaten food quality, as it has become possible to replace all natural ingredients with artificial ingredients. From here, we have food overproduction and an endless crisis, and a lot of unhealthy people.  My colleague Mary has produced an excellent report on this issue, which I call on everyone to support it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2012, the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security (NASAN) was created under the aegis of the G8, with the aim of improving food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa, with the aim of supporting these countries in combating poverty by 2020.  To this end, the participating countries negotiated cooperation frameworks, setting commitments to facilitate private investment in the agricultural sector in Africa - unfortunately quite neglected in the last thirty years, which has increased their dependence on food imports as soon as price fluctuations on international markets. This motion for a resolution, with which I generally agree, warns of the need for African countries to resume investment in the agricultural sector. However, the model proposed by NASAN has some shortcomings with regard to expropriations, small producers and agricultural practices considered unsustainable. For this reason, I support the proposals put forward on the need for Member States to play an active role in improving the model adopted by NASAN so that it is a genuine tool to support family farming and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, effectively combating poverty and food and nutritional insecurity.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN), which aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa. NASAN plays a fundamental role in Africa in achieving the poverty reduction target by 2020. Investment in the agricultural sector and the achievement of sustainable development goals are NASAN's two goals. It is committed to promoting inclusive, agriculture-based growth that promotes small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty and undernutrition.  I supported this text because it calls for NASAN to focus on governance, ownership, responsibility, access to land, land security, regulatory reform of the seed sector and, above all, food security. The latter goes hand in hand, in particular, with the issue of sustainable agriculture. The EU needs to continue and strengthen its commitment to food security in order to pursue an effective poverty reduction policy in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Considering that the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020; and that the participating countries have negotiated national cooperation frameworks, setting out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agriculture sector in Africa, we voted in favour of this Resolution, which warns of the risks of the role that the private sector can play in this area if it is not well regulated

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Heubuch report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a large-scale public-private partnership (PPP) aimed at mobilising private investment in agriculture to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. Unfortunately, its actions are far from solving the problem of food security, and malnutrition still affects a significant part of the population of sub-Saharan Africa. The EU and the Member States must contribute to the transformation of the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition into a real support tool for family agriculture and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, with a view to combating poverty and food and nutrition insecurity.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement commits the EU and Africa to promoting sustainable growth in African agriculture. Such an agreement is necessary if we want to ensure a sustainable and future-proof solution for Africa's economy.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the new Alliance for Food Security and Food, as it can not only improve our cooperation with African institutions and governments – such as the African Union or countries such as Burkina Faso and Nigeria – but can also work in the long term against poverty and hunger in many sub-Saharan countries. With this alliance, the EU is coordinating efforts in Ivory Coast and Malawi, where it wants to promote small farmers and farms, but at the same time places various requirements on governments, such as decent jobs and workers' rights. Overall, this is a step towards better living conditions for many people in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I chose to vote against some controversial points, not least because of my belief that trade creates prosperity and that the removal of trade barriers is therefore beneficial. With regard to the other positions, I agree with the report and, consequently, I voted in favour.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it highlights several critical aspects of 'the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa', sponsored and promoted in 2012 as a mega Public-Private Agreement that has led to structural liberalization reforms in African countries, being one of the main culprit mechanisms for land grabbing, the marginalization of small producers and the support of an unsustainable model of agriculture and livestock , contrary to the principles of food sovereignty.  Thus, the report, among other points, criticizes the negative impacts on the development of public-private agreements and, despite not turning them down, includes the need for strict regulation.  Another positive aspect is the call to support local economies and small holdings, references to the positive aspects of agroecology and the commitment to support these practices with an explicit rejection of the introduction of GMOs in Africa.  The report also highlights clear points on the need to combat land grabbing, recognizing traditional community-owned figures of land, including the right of indigenous peoples.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I argue that we must behave reciprocity in terms of environmental and social requirements with regard to agro-industrial investments made in third countries. The objectives we have set in terms of development policy must be the guiding line of the other policy areas we have undertaken in relation to these countries. Local communities should continue to dispose and decide on options for future progress. With regard to natural resources, recognising that they can be an economic asset, it is imperative to defend the ownership and preservation of natural heritage for the benefit of the populations that depend directly on them. This should be possible within a well-defined regulatory framework, which provides real possibilities for recourse to local communities and under the aegis of the right to food, nutrition, property and participation. These are basic and elementary rights, which should not yet be claimed in our day. Because we enjoy progress in Europe at the material and political levels, we have an obligation to promote more and better progress in other parts of the world with which we have developed approximations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
