text: in writing. ‒ The final report, authored by the Green Group and supported by MEPs across the political spectrum called on the deficiencies identified in the New Alliance on public-private partnerships, land rights, chemical fertilisers and support for small farmers and the local economy to be rectified, whilst still making support for the ambition and the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. However, I do recognise the concerns raised in many quarters about the New Alliance and will remain vigilant and do what I can to address the problems identified in the New Alliance in order to make sure that the actions taken are consistent with development policy goals.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition so that 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa are out of poverty by 2020. This proposal is of great importance, as family farms and small farmers are major investors in African agriculture.  Investment in small farms has been neglected and dependence on food imports has increased as a result. I believe that resilience to over-food imports must be developed and organic production and diversification at local level must be encouraged. I also believe that the proposal is of great importance, as by 2050 around 70% of the world's population is projected to live in large cities and aims to create opportunities for better jobs in rural areas as well. Bearing in mind that in the future international markets will be more volatile and that not all countries should take the risk of excessive dependence on imports but encourage investment in domestic production, I supported the proposal for a New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Millions of people in Africa, especially children, are suffering from hunger and poor quality and poor nutrition, which are the main causes of mortality on the continent, and that hunger is one of the main reasons why people are fleeing their homes, in addition to land-use and climate change. I agreed to the creation of a new alliance on food security and nutrition in Africa (NAFSN), which became operational in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a large public-private partnership, and I also agree with its work to date. What worries me, however, is that investments that should be directed to agriculture in order to increase food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa often become more of an interest to EU trade politicians. That is also why I fully share the rapporteur's view that the EU should not use official development aid to support multinational companies that act as monopolies or cartels and contribute to the weakening of the local private sector, thereby endangering family farms and smallholder farmers. I support all the actions and measures that will benefit small farmers and small family businesses so that they can find their place and strengthen their role in the food chain.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament voted on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. This initiative was launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a public-private cooperation to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. The EU participates in the project as coordinator for Malawi and Côte d'Ivoire. Food and nutrition security is certainly a commendable objective, but the project itself shows a number of shortcomings to which this resolution is currently responding. In it, for example, the European Parliament warns against a repeat of the so-called Green Revolution, namely by increasing productivity using chemical fertilisers, mechanisation and monocultures, as this approach can have serious environmental consequences. It also calls for greater support for smallholder farmers to avoid prioritising the interests of large firms and land grabs. However, in paragraph 72, the resolution 'urges the G8 Member States not to support GM crops in Africa'. I find this export of the ideology of a professional problem beyond the EU's borders unacceptable. Nor does the EU have a strict ban on the cultivation of GM crops. That is why I did not support the resolution as a whole.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Food in Africa was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a large public-private partnership aimed at increasing private investment in agriculture, improving food security and food in sub-Saharan Africa.  I note with regret that not all stakeholders participated in the decision-making process. Thus, rural communities, farm workers, small farmers, fishermen and aboriginal people were more than excluded, which means that their right to participate has not been respected.  On the other hand, the report has more good content. For example, it highlights the risks of public-private partnerships and the need to develop the local economy, including family agriculture. The report also calls for increased investment in agri-ecological practices and, at the same time, the rejection of genetically modified crops in Africa. What is also good in the report is that it calls for the establishment of independent complaint mechanisms for those communities that may have been harmed by the expropriation of the land. What is more, the report also calls for full transparency in the financing of private sector companies and warns that tax reforms must not exempt investors from paying taxes and give them unfair advantages over small farmers.  For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'We don't want GMOs in Europe, but we don't want GMOs in Africa either. Yet that is exactly what is happening through the so-called New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. This private-public partnership was launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8. Private investment in agriculture aims to improve food security and the quality of food in sub-Saharan Africa. NGOs have repeatedly rejected this approach by encouraging land grabs, restricting the freedom of seed exchange (while farmers should be able to grow their own seed independently) and pushing GMOs down the throats of African farmers, whether they like it or not. To be clear, introducing new GMOs into the environment creates serious problems for farmers who want to grow GMO-free, as these organisms spread freely and uncontrollably in nature. Mr Heubuch's report lists all these points and is opposed to any promotion of GMOs in Africa at taxpayers' expense. Monsanto finds the report neocolonial, which is ironic, since the industry itself is using this New Alliance to turn African legislation around land ownership, seeds and GMOs to their advantage. I therefore voted with conviction in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our assistance to countries suffering from food shortages should consist mainly of supporting domestic farmers, supplying new technologies and greater openness of European food markets to products from these regions of the world.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ With 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa in poverty, I believe that the New Alliance can improve food security and thus help them. The participants agreed on cooperation frameworks for states setting out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agricultural sector in Africa. Following the 2008 food crisis, the need to support small farmers producing food for domestic markets was recognised globally. In view of this, I support this report on the New Alliance for Food Security. Also, investment in small farms has been neglected in Africa over the past 30 years and food imports by low-income countries have increased significantly. In developing countries, food security is highly dependent on the sustainable exploitation of natural resources. In fact, states should invest in domestic food production in order to develop resilience rather than take the risk of excessive dependence on imports.  Ultimately, given predictions that 70% of the world's population will live in big cities by 2050, I think the issue of nutrition will require an answer both locally and globally.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution. There is nothing new in this than in previous resolutions. The European Parliament wants to make rules for Member States and companies involved in development cooperation. The EU's desire to manage values and norms institutionally does not stop at development cooperation either: "Our money – our values". I don't support that.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa is designed as a major public-private partnership aimed at strengthening private investment in agriculture to improve food supply and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. When developing a framework for cooperation, states have hardly consulted smallholders at all, although they should be the end-users of the New Alliance. The European Union and the Member States play a key role in transforming the New Alliance into a genuine instrument to support family farms and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa in order to combat food and nutrition poverty and insecurity. The main private actors of the New Alliance are multinationals that already benefit from a dominant market position and are often granted business, customs and tax benefits in host countries through investments.  I support the proposal for a Resolution, as I believe that the European Union should suspend its current support for the New Alliance, as its ability to contribute to reducing poverty and food security has been seriously challenged. Donors and national governments should invest in a sustainable model of agriculture, which supports women and the agricultural activity of smallholders and unleashes the potential of the domestic market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition.  We need the removal of all barriers to private investment in the African agricultural sector, only in this way will we effectively follow the objective of a new alliance for food security in Africa, which aims to improve food security and help 50 million people in Africa find a way out of poverty by 2020. Unfortunately, not all stakeholders participated in the decision-making process, nor was african civil society organisations consulted.  I support that, in addition to promoting small-scale agriculture, the new Alliance for Food Security in Africa restricts, as far as possible, the use of chemical fertilisers and pesticides, which cause health and environmental consequences for local communities.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that malnutrition, poverty, inequality are problems plaguing African countries. Of course, unequal taxation, the exploitation of investors, the incorrect management of natural resources, but also the loss of biodiversity, soil erosion and illiteracy contribute to this. We must fight corruption, stimulate agricultural production, always defending human rights, in order to avoid mass migration.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as the aim of the title alliance in Africa is to improve food security and food security and help 50 million people out of poverty in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020. The report highlights the neglect of investment in small-scale farming in Africa over the last 30 years, while the dependence of low-income countries on food imports has increased significantly, making them vulnerable to price changes on international markets. The Alliance may be able to contribute to poverty reduction and food security (after a few technical amendments). It is also necessary to invest in a further agricultural model that is sustainable, supporting small agricultural production and women's empowerment in a way that benefits local farmers and provides customers with high-quality food at affordable prices. The aim of the alliance is to replicate in Africa the model of the "green revolution" carried out in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s, based on monoculture crop production, mechanisation, biotechnology, dependence on fertilisers, long distribution chains and the cultivation of export crops. In addition, the policies adopted in host countries aim to create a business-friendly environment through infrastructure, tax, land or trade policy reforms, facilitating access to fallow land for long-term rental purposes, and regulatory reforms in the field of seeds.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NAFSN), launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8, is to mobilise private investment in agriculture to improve food security in the sub-Saharan African region. The countries involved were required to adopt a national cooperation framework setting out political commitments and identifying the companies involved in the project.  In its resolution, the European Parliament rightly stresses that agricultural investment measures in Africa should be linked and support the development of local economies, including small farms and family farming. It is necessary to promote inclusive growth, agriculture supporting small farmers, reducing poverty, hunger and malnutrition.  The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition is a notable initiative that promotes public-private partnerships and engages both african countries and the G8 group of countries on a mutually beneficial basis. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Alliance for Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) is a large-scale public-private partnership (PPP) launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 to mobilise private investment in agriculture to achieve the food security of sub-Saharan Africa. The Alliance is intended to replicate the Asian "Green Revolution" model on the African continent, promoting monocultures, mechanisation, biotechnology, fertilisers and crop production for export. The total amount invested by the G8 states is US$8 billion and is channelled into good governance and property guarantee, public responsibility, promotion of sustainable family farming, land access and land security, seed legislation, gender perspective and financing of agricultural investments in Africa.  However, the document notes a number of shortcomings of this structure, such as the dominance of multinational companies, the undermining of the local private sector and the perpetuation of poverty. That is why a nuance of the agreement is needed to support small farms, access to land for small farmers, organic farming, agroecology, agro-forestry, access to nutritious food and water. It is also necessary to regulate and monitor public-private partnerships in order to respect human rights and European social and environmental standards. Only in this way will the alliance achieve its objectives.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Each participating African country has adopted a framework for cooperation that sets out the commitments of each of the parties concerned. These commitments include legislative reforms in african countries, the financing intentions of G7 donors and the promises of the 180 participating companies to invest a total of $8 billion. Two companies are at the fore in terms of their share of investments in agriculture: the Swiss seed producer Syngenta and the Norwegian fertilizer manufacturer Yara International.  I recognize the need for African countries to invest in agriculture. While NASAN's goal is laudable, it has many flaws. The text voted today is a good tool for cooperation and improvement of the agricultural situation in the context of enhanced cooperation

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ When it was launched in 2012, the aim of the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa by leveraging private investment in agriculture. However, monoculture, mechanisation, biotechnology, dependence on fertilisers, long distribution channels and the production of export crops have proven to be harmful to the poorest communities and pose a risk to the environment. I voted in favour of this report, as I agree that, if we want to make it a genuine instrument of support for family farming and local economies in sub-Saharan Africa, we need to invest in a model of agriculture which is sustainable, pro-smallholder farming and pro-women, and which unlocks the potential of domestic and regional markets. Only if we manage to do that will we realistically be able help 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ A new alliance for food security and nutrition in Africa was launched in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 as a major public-private partnership aimed at strengthening private investment in agriculture to improve food supply and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. The Alliance aims to involve private partners to invest in African agriculture and to set a framework for simplifying private investment.  However, it calls into question how extremely large public-private partnerships such as the New Alliance can contribute to reducing poverty and food security, as they are the poorest communities and risk taking on the burden of social and environmental risks. I therefore believe that the European Union and its Member States should suspend their current support for the New Alliance and instead invest in an agricultural model that is sustainable in order to provide consumers with quality food at affordable prices and I voted abstaining.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8. Each participating country has adopted a framework of state cooperation. The latter contains commitments from participants relating to legislative reforms in the African countries concerned, the intentions of the G7 donors to finance and the commitment of the 180 undertakings involved in relation to investments totalling USD 8 billion. Large foreign companies and donors require strong governance structures in partner countries in order to ensure a fair sharing of risks and benefits between the parties involved. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change of December 2015 underlined the need to develop a model of agriculture that strengthens resilience and creates sustainable food systems. A certain degree of independence of farmers from the commercial sector should be supported by donors with a view to preserving the genetic diversity of seeds.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Considering that the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020; and that the participating countries have negotiated national cooperation frameworks, which set out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agriculture sector in Africa, we voted in favour of this Resolution, which warns of the risks of the role that the private sector can play in this particular if it is not well regulated.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NASAN) has been the source of much criticism since its entry into force in 2012.  It is a broad public-private partnership between the G8 and the African Union, with a programme to develop African agriculture. A dozen African countries are involved, from Ethiopia to Côte d'Ivoire to Senegal.  Nearly 180 companies are participating in the $8 billion investment program. The tax, land and trade measures taken must provide a favourable framework for businesses.  But it repeats the destructive pattern imposed in Asia in the 1970s (dependence on fertilizers, monoculture, export crops...). Unsustainable agriculture is therefore favoured, with smallholder farmers sidelined.  The aim of this report is to counterbalance these negative effects by stimulating family farming and local economies, by combating poverty and food insecurity. In particular, it is the overriding issue of food sovereignty that is highlighted in this report, which does not fail to point out that good agricultural and food policy in African countries reduces the emigration of populations.  Some of the thrusts of this report clearly condemn the large-scale PPP policy within NASAN. So I voted FOR.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A new alliance for food security and nutrition in Africa was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8. As a large public-private partnership, it was intended to increase the share of private investment in the agricultural m.in to improve food security. Unfortunately, consultations with small agricultural producers were rudimentary, even though they should be the ultimate beneficiaries of the new alliance. As a result, the new alliance has come under m.in criticism from civil society. For reasons of divided reasons, I abstained.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The New Food and Nutrition Security Alliance in Africa (NAFSN) initiative was established in 2012 under the auspices of the G8 group as a large-scale partnership between the private and public sectors, with the aim of boosting private investment in agriculture in order to improve food and nutrition security in sub-Saharan Africa. The EU is responsible for coordinating implementation in Côte d'Ivoire and Malawi. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Considering that the New Partnership for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020; and that the participating countries have negotiated national cooperation frameworks, which set out commitments to facilitate private investment in the agriculture sector in Africa, we voted in favour of this Resolution, which warns of the risks of the role that the private sector can play in this particular if it is not well regulated.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Attempts to weaken the report through split/separate failed. The report sends strong criticisms on mega PPP and covers strong provisions regarding land grab. It warns against pure focus on land titling to ensure land tenure security, but calls for the respect of FAO Land Tenure Guidelines. It calls for ex ante impact study on land rights and implementation of Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC), which shall be obtained from ALL communities concerned by transfer/control of land PRIOR to the development of the project by the private sector. It also calls on participating countries to New Alliance to enact binding legislation against land grabbing. Food sovereignty is acknowledged, and the right of African countries to protect their agriculture through tariff and tax regimes is equally acknowledged.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. The New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN) aims to improve food security and nutrition by helping 50 million people in sub-Saharan Africa out of poverty by 2020. The report calls on governments and donors to suspend or review all policies, projects and consultancy arrangements that directly encourage and facilitate land grabbing by supporting highly harmful projects and investments or indirectly increase pressure on land and natural resources and which can result in serious human rights violations. The report urges the EU and its Member States to ensure that EU-based investors implement a social responsibility policy when drawing up employment contracts and do not exploit their economic advantage over workers from local communities. I voted in favour of this report because I strongly believe in inclusive, agriculture-based growth that supports small-scale farming and helps reduce poverty, hunger and under-nutrition.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The document highlights the need for investment policies in Africa to be linked to supporting the development of the local economy, including small producers and family farms to help reduce poverty, hunger and malnutrition. African governments are also required to invest in local food systems, to boost rural economies, ensure decent jobs and labour rights. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because the new alliance for food security and nutrition, despite its shortcomings, is of the utmost importance in Africa. The report clearly stresses that official development assistance (ODA) should be at the service of poverty alleviation, not in the service of the interests of EU trade policy. The ODA should not be used by the EU to support transnational companies operating as monopolist or cartels, thereby undermining the local private sector and crowding out family farms and small farms.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report concerns the new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition (NASAN), established in 2012 under the aegis of the G8. The theoretical goal is to improve food security and nutrition in sub-Saharan Africa. While this objective is of course essential, the means employed are more than critical, as many NGOs point out. Indeed, FOR example, NASAN obliges the African countries concerned to reduce the taxation of partner companies, or worse, farmers to sign contracts with companies that force them into debt and take responsibility for bad harvests. Words are lacking to condemn such practices. The point of this report is precisely to be very critical of these kinds of practices. Among other things, there are formulations that contradict the public-private partnership put in place by NASAN and accuse the program of first helping multinationals to develop their markets rather than local companies and farmers. In short, the report denounces NASAN's methods and urges the European Union to remedy them. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This initiative involves the G8, several multinationals and public-private partnerships, through which, they assure us, it is intended to remove millions of people from poverty and hunger in Africa. The statements do not hide their purposes: "accelerate the flow of private capital", but for this the alleged charity of multinationals requires political changes that facilitate their business and create conditions to accumulate profits of millions. This initiative assumes (by verifying, because wrong) that more production, through investment from large private corporations, will solve the problem of hunger and malnutrition in Africa. Now these corporations produce for profitable markets, not for the poor and hungry. This initiative will be a useful way to facilitate access to land and agricultural insums, encouraging the change of agricultural practices, in the interests of multinationals, favoring intensive export production models, with high incorporation of agrochemicals and GMOs.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft contains good approaches to food security in these African countries. It recognises the dangers of the water supply of small farmers by export-oriented investors and emphasises the risks to national agricultural economies by multinationals. He also advocates a transparent system against land grabs and corruption.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I believe that measures should be taken to minimise the existence of unfair commercial practices on the food market. It should be for the European Union to ensure transparent rules that create an appropriate level of cooperation between suppliers, food producers and distributors. A situation where there is an imbalance between income and receipts in the food supply chain must be prevented. Serious abuses of products below their production costs are a threat to the functioning of a sustainable trade policy in the European Union. It is important to be aware of the fact that the retail sale of a very large quantity of goods as well as access to outlets by suppliers are under the constant control of supermarkets. I am in favour of introducing new rules that should help to stop unfair practices, essentially leading to excessive costs and too low revenues generated by companies with lower competitive capacity.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this parliamentary resolution. In 2012 we launched the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa (NAFSN). This alliance is aiming to offer significant support to a variety of African countries. In order to do this we need to learn from mistakes from the past. This Parliamentary resolution identifies many of these mistakes.  With regard to governance and ownership, I agree that efforts need to be made to help these nations to avoid corruption. In addition, it needs to be monitored whether the Country Cooperation Frameworks (CCF) are actually implemented. For this to happen, they need to be made public and be fully transparent.   In order for the farmers to participate in farming, we also need to ensure that they maintain access to land and that malicious practises such as land-grabbing are prevented. But what I most strongly welcome is the rapporteur’s call on including women in all of our actions, to promote gender equality.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur, I have paid a great deal of attention to this report. The new Food Security and Nutrition Alliance is a public-private partnership project whose ambition is to reduce the burden on public budgets. However, the use of private resources to achieve the public interest must leave room for profit, otherwise it would be taxation. At the same time, the level of profits of private investors in these partnerships should be thoroughly discussed. It should take into account the interest for which governments borrow on the financial markets and the level of risk borne by the private party. This also applies if profit is defined as a trading opportunity. The present report seeks to increase control over the conditions of public-private partnerships on food production in Africa. I have tried to push for Parliament to strengthen the positions of small producers, family farms and sustainable land use in the resolution. In the end, however, I had to vote against the final text, because the final text did not take into account the need to find a compromise between private and public.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The "New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa" (NAFSN) concerns a huge public-private partnership within the G8, which literally gives "land and water" to business groups for their uninterrupted profitability. Huge monopolies have already been interested and involved, as the relevant agreements will bring them untold profits. The resolution, by pressing on a number of existing problems, such as 'land grabs' which risk further marginalisation and extermination of small producers, the 'exclusion of land workers', the 'seeds' of monopolies, 'racial discrimination', supports and premiums the necessity of the agreement, moving to the logic of a so-called fixation. It is provocative that the business groups involved are given in addition to financing and even tax exemptions for the 'creation of special economic zones' in order to invest funds supposedly to provide food to the peoples of Africa.  The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against this resolution, the only real aim of which is to disorient and conceal the relentless truth: thousands of acres are given north to monopolies for exploitation and the conditions for their profitability are guaranteed, while poor living conditions, hunger and migration to avoid them are the harsh everyday life for the peoples of Africa.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report and appreciate the fact that the New Alliance is committed to promoting agricultural-based growth. At the same time, it focuses on supporting smallholder farmers and helping to alleove poverty, hunger and malnutrition. The new alliance should limit the use of chemical fertilisers and pesticides as much as possible, given their health and environmental impacts on local communities. All funding should be as transparent as possible. Personally, I am in favour of donors focusing their activities on promoting education, training and technical advice for farmers. In addition to promoting private investment, public investment in African agriculture needs to be revived. I prefer innovation in agro-ecology in order to increase food security and reduce poverty and hunger. However, these measures must be taken hand in hand with the protection of biodiversity and respect for the knowledge and innovation of indigenous peoples.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Heubuch report because I believe that, despite the shortcomings of the New Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security which may affect developing countries, it is necessary to support this initiative and address its shortcomings as proposed in this report.  I would like to see the need to support the development of the local economy and small-scale farmers in the framework of this initiative. I would also stress that, in order to improve the governance of the New Alliance, an independent accountability mechanism is needed, that the New Alliance projects be in line with FAO's guidelines on responsible governance of land, fisheries and forest ownership and an end to land acquisition policy. I also regret that African civil society organisations were not consulted at the launch of the New Alliance, as the participation of groups whose food security is not guaranteed in the policies affecting them should become the cornerstone of all food security policies.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The New Alliance is a broad public-private partnership launched in 2012 by the G8 with the aim of stimulating private investment in the agricultural sector in sub-Saharan Africa. In fact, the New Alliance ends up making the lives of millions of families of local farmers and small holders worse by promoting the entry of multinational agribusiness. Studies show that the implementation of this programme puts more than 60 % of jobs at risk and that the ecosystem of these countries, which would be oversized by GMOs and fertilisers, is also under threat. The EU is committed to the New Alliance for the sum of EUR 1.2 billion and leads the cooperation frameworks with Malawi and Côte d'Ivoire. In both countries, the lack of transparency and the lack of information available to local populations has been criticised. This report, which I voted in favour of, calls on the European Commission to invest only in sustainable projects and to encourage local farms. We in the M5S do not want genetic engineering projects to be promoted with citizens' tax money.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. I agree that investments in agricultural policy in Africa must be linked and must support the development of the local economy, including small farmers and family farms. Food security must be based on healthy and living soils and productive agricultural ecosystems resilient to climate change. The proposed measures are necessary to establish political stability in Africa and to improve living standards that will effectively halt the mass exodus of the population.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, large-scale falsification of firms' accounting threatens the economic and financial stability of a country. That is why we need accepted accounting standards at European level, applied in each Member State. We need clear and simple rules that can be applied and controlled quickly and correctly. These standards are issued by the Council for International Accounting Standards and the European Union contributes 14% to the budget of this institution. He's the biggest contributor. That is why we must be involved, including Parliament, in setting and reassessing accounting standards on a regular basis.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Finance needs effective controls and international accounting standards (IFRS). To this end, the Internation Accounting Standards Boards (IASB) was established to standardize the definitions used in the financial field worldwide. However, their effectiveness is called into question by the high complexity and recent financial scandals. Since I cannot share some positions, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive references to understanding international accounting standards as a public good, it does not delve sufficient into its necessary public regulation. International Accounting Standards are standards set by the private sector, which have enabled the development of speculative bubbles that have led to this financial crisis. This demonstrates the need for public control over these standards and the need for democratic organizations to establish them. Despite some positive references, the report does not delve into the necessary and immediate public participation in their determination and that is why I have not been able to vote in their favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world. These standards are called the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). During the recent financial crisis, certain standards were pointed out. IFRS standards are based on principles, not rules. This gives free accounting interpretation and complicates the comparison of companies. IFRS also provides an accounting view that is too favourable to investor interest. In this way, they tend to favour a short-term strategy, which is detrimental to markets. The report highlights these points and also criticises the IASB for a lack of progress in seeking transparency, preventing conflicts of interest or diversifying the experts involved.  However, this report is too favourable to the generalization of IFRS standards. If we accept the principle of common accounting standards, those standards remain questionable. Indeed, accounting regulation, previously attributed to states, is now entrusted to an international organization over which they will have little control. So I decided to abstain.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for accounting standards that ensure financial stability and sustainable growth. We also call for a major overhaul of the process for developing and approving accounting standards to ensure greater transparency and accountability for economic actors.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report on the evaluation of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS), the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Supervisory Board (PIOB) is an attempt to integrate internationally agreed standards into European legislation. I voted in favour of this report alongside the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, as it promotes accounting standards to ensure financial stability and sustainable development and the profound reform of the process of processing and implementing Accounting Standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) is a neutral and independent body that prepares high-quality accounting standards and establishes a common terminology for global financial reporting. Since 2005, listed companies in the EU have been obliged to prepare their annual accounts in accordance with these accounting standards. These standards are particularly important for building a single capital market in the EU. However, the complexity of financial reporting is steadily increasing, which makes it difficult for smaller companies in particular to enter the stock market. I therefore welcome the Commission's intention to work with the IASB to review whether accounting standards can be developed specifically for smaller companies. I also agree with Parliament's proposal, which provides for the formulation of a common European position on the development of standards, because it would be detrimental if national and European institutions were to follow different lines in the negotiations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world, and thus to create a common language for global financial reporting. These standards are called the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).  Despite relevant observations and recommendations, I abstained on this report because it parallels the use of IFRS in a globalised economy. While we accept the principle of common accounting standards in order to facilitate the exchange of information, IFRS standards are highly critical of various key points that may make them illegitimate. First, the concept of "fair value" for the valuation of the company's assets gives a vision that corresponds mainly to the interests of investors, but not necessarily those of employees, customers or even the state. This concept leads to short-term strategies. IFRS is determined by institutions that threaten our sovereignty since accounting regulation, previously attributed to states, is now entrusted to an international, private and non-community organization.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. This report contains some good ideas but as usual the European Union seeks to extend its control and own agenda into individual country´s taxation laws.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to develop a set of high-quality accounting standards applicable around the world, and thus to create a common language for financial reporting at the global level. The rapporteur recognises the importance of such global standards to improve competition and remove barriers to global investment.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS).  The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), headquartered in London, develops a set of high-quality accounting standards worldwide, thus developing a common global financial reporting language. Since 2005, listed EU companies have been required to comply with these standards when preparing their consolidated financial statements. The inclusion of international accounting standards in EU law is subject to the validation mechanism set out in the IAS Regulation. International accounting standards are an important part of the EU framework for regulating and supervising financial services. They relate to a number of other EU legislation on financial services, including in the area of prudential regulation. However, the financial crisis has shown that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 International financial reporting standards are principle-based approach accounting standards, interpretations and frameworks issued by the London-based International Accounting Standards Board, creating a common language for global financial reporting. As of 2005, standards are also mandatory in the European Union for consolidated consolidated accounts of companies whose securities have been placed on a regulated market in a Member State of the Union. The rapporteur invites the creator of the standards to ensure their coherence within existing accounting standards and to promote consistency at international level. It also calls on the Commission to urgently comply with the recommendations on the extension of the common good criterion, i.e. that accounting standards do not jeoped the financial stability of the EU or hinder the EU's economic development. This is therefore a technical issue, the application of international financial standards in the EU, which I supported. However, it should be noted that the existence of these standards only reduces, but does not stop, the financial instability resulting from the financial liberalisation and deregulation measures of the 1990s.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world. Since 2005, the IAS Regulation therefore requires EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards (also known as IFRS).  However, the financial crisis has shown the need to improve them: the report points out that major problems have been highlighted with regard to accounting standards in the head of the crisis; it also criticizes the IASB for the lack of progress in terms of transparency, conflict of interest prevention and diversity of committed experts. Despite these relevant observations, I abstained on this report, which is the champion of a globalised economy, especially since IFRS standards are highly critical of various key points that may render them illegitimate: thus they offer freedom of interpretation on the accounting of certain commitments and complicate the comparison of companies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Since 2005, publicly traded EU companies have been required to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with international accounting standards. The incorporation of international accounting standards into EU law is governed by an adoption mechanism described in the IAS Regulation. Two key points are made up of this report: the need to develop consistent financial reporting standards. Harmonization and coherence must be guaranteed in the existing body of international accounting standards, but also in other EU financial services regulations; Call for a further strengthening of European influence in the early stages of the development of accounting standards.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of high-quality accounting standards, applicable worldwide, is an important factor in improving competition and removing obstacles to investment on a global scale. Although overall it appears that these rules have fostered the development of a single capital market in the Union, strengthening the competitiveness of the European economy, the financial crisis has shown that these financial disclosure principles need to be reviewed and improved. The EU has delegated their definition to an independent body, the International Accounting Standards Board, but it needs to influence all stages of their development.  The Stolojan report, which I supported, reiterates the need to formulate a common European position on this subject and at the same time underlines the important developments promoted by the Commission in the process of reforming the European Advisory Group on Financial Reporting, which already plays important role in assessing, qualitatively and quantitatively, the impact of the financial reporting principles. However, appropriate measures must move from the essential involvement of the European Parliament, which must act from the earliest stages of the type-approval procedure, following the path already started by the ECON Committee with the creation of the permanent ifrs team.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report, which seeks to homogenise at European level the common criteria for the accounting of companies. While I am not opposed to this process, the report incorporates positive references to processes to which I do object, such as the Capital Markets Union, which is why I have opted for abstention.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the evaluation of international accounting standards. Certainly, the text has the merit of raising relevant observations and recommendations. This is how the serious problems that had already been pointed out before the 2008 crisis concerning accounting standards are recalled: notably off-balance sheet accounts, the procyclicality created by the principle of market price valuation or the accounting of losses and profits. The report also highlights the fact that risk accumulation has been underestimated during the economic recovery and also points to the lack of a common and transparent methodology for assessing against liquid and depreciated assets. However, this lucidity on the persistent problems does not prevent the rapporteur from continuing to blindly advocate the use of international financial reporting standards (IFRS), which, while based on a good principle of common accounting standards, remain illegitimate due to numerous failures, notably on the notion of "fair value" for the valuation of the company's assets, which favours investors more than employees or clients.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stolojan report is partisan and has strong critical elements that I do not agree with, in particular the call for the validation of a new objective in favour of European financial governance dropped from above on the Member States. That is why I did not want to support the text we are voting on.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International Audit Standards (NIA) are a necessary component for the efficient functioning of the internal market and capital markets. Both rules are in the public interest, their objective is to strengthen accountability, protect investments, provide transparency and allow investors and other market participants to make informed economic decisions, and should therefore not jeopardize financial stability or impede economic development. In this report, which I supported, Parliament welcomes the report on the commission's evaluation of IAS on the application of IFRS rules in the Union, and welcomes the conclusion that the objectives of the IAS Regulation have been achieved. It regrets, however, that the Commission has not yet proposed the legal changes required to address the gaps pointed out and urges it to submit legislative proposals diligently and to comply with the Maystadt recommendation on the extension of the 'public interest' criterion, that is to say, that accounting rules should not jeopardize the Financial Stability of the Union or impede its economic development.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it advocates the assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Council (PIOB). The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), headquartered in London, develops a set of high-quality accounting standards worldwide, thus developing a common global financial reporting language. Since 2005, listed EU companies have been required to comply with these standards when preparing their consolidated financial statements. The inclusion of international accounting standards in EU law is subject to the validation mechanism set out in the IAS Regulation. International accounting standards are an important part of the EU framework for regulating and supervising financial services. They relate to a number of other EU legislation on financial services, including in the area of prudential regulation. However, the financial crisis has shown that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved. In particular, discussions are still ongoing on the impact of the use of 'fair value' on financial stability. The assessment of the IAS Regulation also provides an opportunity to address issues related to the process of approving IFRSs in the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on weaknesses in current accounting standards, including off-balance sheet accounts, valuation of reporting assets and depreciated assets. It also criticizes the lack of transparency of the International Accounting Standards Board, the IASB, and highlights the risks of conflicts of interest of its experts. While I agree with these findings, the fact remains that this report continues to be a champion of the use of IFRS and the concept of 'fair value', while these are strongly criticised on various key points, notably the fact that they give free rein to various interpretations making it difficult for companies to compare. For these reasons, I abstained on this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this own-initiative report that evaluates 10 years of implementation of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and the international standards on auditing (ISA) set by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) in the EU. The report is a response to the Commission’s evaluation of the implementation and makes proposals to the IASB, which is in the process of creating a globally applicable standard for financial reporting. There are positive aspects to this in terms of regulating financial instruments so that they provide more accurate and transparent information to investors (for example about risk) and in challenging the ability of companies to falsify their records. However, I believe this report should have also called for improving the governance of the standard-setting organisations to ensure their independence from corporations, which was opposed by conservatives at committee level, meaning it was not included in the final report. I also object to the overall goal of the report which states the proposals on standards are primarily aimed at ensuring the efficient functioning of the Capital Markets Union, a concept I am strongly opposed to. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Accounting Standards Board develops a set of high-quality accounting standards that are applied worldwide, creating a common language for global financial reporting. It is therefore noted that these globally applicable standards are important to improving competition and removing barriers to investment. Publicly traded EU companies have been required since 2005 to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. Therefore, according to the provisions of the IAS Regulation, the drawing up of international accounting standards in EU law is governed by an adoption mechanism. I voted in favour of the report on the Assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS) because I believe that this assessment contributes to strengthening the single market, but also to the competitiveness of the European economy by allowing businesses to attract investment capital from the world market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and debate in this House, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I believe that the creation of a harmonised regulation on the application of high-quality accounting standards, to be applied to financial reporting, is an indispensable requirement for regulating competition and an effective method of removing obstacles to investment on a global scale.  I am also convinced that this correction, which is consistent with the area of prudential regulation, proves to be all the more necessary in times of financial crisis. The model of financial reporting principles must therefore be strengthened in order to develop a Capital Markets Union, to the point where they then inform the internal governance rules of financial institutions. It should be stressed that, when the level of financial responsibility has risen, the single market and the competitiveness of the economy have been facilitated, allowing companies to attract capital and investment.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that aims to secure the stability of internal market and capital markets. It is a pity that no legal changes are proposed by the Commission to solve the shortcomings identified in the evaluation on the application of IAS and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). I welcome the involvement of democratic scrutiny in the enforcement of new accounting and reporting standards.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) is one of five economic committees reporting to the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). This Agreement promotes international regulatory cooperation in this field and promotes its technological harmonisation. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline the importance of International Accounting Standards to improve competition and remove investment barriers on a global scale.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the evaluation of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS), the European Advisory Group on Financial Reporting (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Supervisory Board (PIOB) offers an opportunity to focus on technical issues of a financial nature, with a view to reducing the risks of irregularities and illegal conduct carried out to the detriment of the public interest and citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this rule because I believe that the application of international financial reporting standards in the European Union has had positive effects by helping to strengthen the single market and its competitiveness. I recognise the importance of having principles applicable worldwide in order to facilitate the internationalisation of investment. I also agree to delegate the development of these international financial accounting standards to a private body, the International Accounting Standards Board, so that the latter can develop, from the top of its competence in this field, consistent and applicable financial reporting standards at world level.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The report calls on the Commission to act, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 International accounting standards form an important part of the EU's financial services regulatory and supervisory framework, given also their interaction with other EU financial services legislation, such as prudential regulation. By applying these principles worldwide, it is possible to improve competition and remove obstacles to investment on a global scale. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which stresses that accounting standards must be adopted in order to develop a single capital market in the European Union, within the framework of the project for a Capital Markets Union.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that in the interest of the public good we should not endanger financial stability or hinder the economic development of the Union, which should serve the common good and not only the interests of investors, lenders and creditors. Since 2005, publicly trading EU companies are obliged to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. The incorporation of the international accounting standards into EU law is governed by an endorsement mechanism as outlined in the IAS Regulation. This reinforces the reliability, comparability and transparency of financial information is an overarching objective; focus efforts on complete implementation since such a step is needed to enable the Capital Markets Union and to contribute to processes leading to a fully-fledged single market. I therefore agree with the call for a standard setter to ensure that the IFRS are coherent within the existing body of accounting standards and to promote convergence at international level. We need a more coordinated approach in developing new standards with mandatory country-by-country reporting under IFRS. The latter can play a decisive role in combating tax avoidance and fraud.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive references to understanding international accounting standards as a public good, it does not delve sufficient into its necessary public regulation. International Accounting Standards are standards set by the private sector, which have enabled the development of speculative bubbles that have led to this financial crisis. This demonstrates the need for public control over these standards and the need for democratic organizations to establish them. Despite some positive references, the report does not delve into the necessary and immediate public participation in their determination and that is why I have not been able to vote in their favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 International Financial Reporting Principles (IFRS) and International Audit Principles (ISAs) are an essential component for the effective functioning of the internal market and capital markets. The European Parliament resolution examines how the Eu ropean Union's influence should be increased within the International Accounting Standards Board and how to reform the process of developing international financial reporting standards (IFRS). I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that international accounting standards must promote transparency for investors and businesses by improving international comparability and the quality of financial reporting, protect investments, allow investors and other market participants to make informed economic decisions and thereby influence the behaviour of the actors in the financed markets and the stability of those markets.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Accounting Standards Board develops a set of high-quality accounting standards applicable worldwide, thus creating a common language for global financial reporting. These Standards are an important part of the EU's financial services regulations and supervisory framework. I voted for the development of a single capital market in the European Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report assesses the activities of the IFRS, EFRAG and PIOB Foundations and raises fundamental questions about the process of adopting IFRS financial reporting standards into European law. The EU is an important contributor to the financing of these organisations. In previous reports, the EP was concerned about the degree of European involvement and the activities of certain mechanisms of the IFRS Foundation and EFRAG. Furthermore, the report builds on a broad consensus between the political groups. stresses that the process of adopting IFRSs must comply with the criteria set out in the IAS Regulation. This requires, in particular, that financial statements be kept in a genuine, fair and clear manner. Further aspects of the report are devoted to the responsibility of the International Accounting Standards Board. In view of the amendments made to the report m.in that the implementation of IFRSs must not delay or lead to the equalisation or distortion of competition between market participants, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on ISAs. The report makes proposals on the way the standards are endorsed, on the governance of the different standard-setter institutions, and others. The report considers that the democratic scrutiny is an important element and that Parliament, the Commission and the Council must be involved in the development of financial reporting standards and the endorsement process in order to guarantee the overall coherence and appropriateness of accounting and reporting principles.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it promoted accounting standards that ensure financial stability and sustainable growth. This report is the first European Parliament report on the International Accounting Standards regulation which incorporates the standards agreed at the international level within the International Accounting Standards Board into EU law. This report reflects the deep reform of the process of elaboration and it is also an endorsement of the Accounting standards which ensure transparency and accountability, which is of utmost importance.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the proper functioning of the internal market and capital markets through international accounting standards. These international accounting standards are part of a process of harmonizing global accounting systems. This harmonisation is based in particular on the convergence of the two main systems, the US Gaap system and the international IFRS system, with the European Union adopting THE IFRS standards in 2003. The report welcomes the Commission's assessment of the application of international accounting standards, but regrets that it has not yet tabled the necessary legal changes. In particular, it calls for the implementation of the nine IFRS financial instruments to promote this international accounting. Finally, the report makes proposals on good collaboration between the European and international institutions in the decision-making process. Considering that the current process of globalization implies a need to harmonize standards between the two largest economic powers in the world, the European Union and the United States, including accounting standards, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the evaluation of national accounting standards. These standards are developed by the International Accounting Standards Board and are applicable around the world. It is essential that these standards are incorporated into EU law, as this contributes to the strengthening of the single market and financial stability within the European Union and to the development of the European economy.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which defends the use of IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards) in a globalised economy. Although it is necessary to develop a common nomenclature for global financial reporting, the concept of "fair value" for the valuation of the company's assets gives a vision that is more in line with the interests of investors than employees, customers or even the state. This concept would also tend to favour short-term strategies related to financial market volatility. Finally, IFRS standards are subject to a freedom of interpretation in accounting for certain commitments, which complicates cross-company comparisons.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the international accounting standards assessment report because the report set out greater accountability of three organisations partially funded by the EU – the Foundation for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Supervisory Board for reporting and reporting on the public interest. It also addresses some general questions about the process of approving ifrs financial reporting standards in European law.  The EQF's position is that the application of IFRS cannot delay or lead to a distortion or distortion of competition between market participants. I agree that the process of approving IFRS must comply with the criteria set out in the International Accounting Standards Regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 European public and private sector entities at national and European level have different views and interests in the development of accounting standards. International Financial Reporting Standards as part of EU law impose a level playing field for a single market that is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the corresponding weak.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2005, EU listed companies have been required to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with international accounting standards. These standards are an important part of the EU regulatory and supervisory framework for financial services. However, the financial crisis has shown that international financial reporting standards need to be reviewed and improved. In particular, the consequences of using the notion of 'fair value' in financial stability have opened a debate that is still ongoing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: IFRS is determined by institutions that threaten our sovereignty since accounting regulation, previously granted to states, is now entrusted to an international, private and non-eu community organization.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report evaluates the International Accounting Standards (IAS) of the Foundation for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), the Advisory Group on Financial Information in Europe (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Supervisory Board (PIOB). It is part of the evaluation of the working group on the issue of accounting standards, also aiming at the activity of the institutions that define them, recommending reforms in the definition of these standards. IAS play a key role in the EU's financial regulatory and financial supervision services. The issue of the convergence of international norms in this context does not pose any major problems in an internationalized commercial context. However, the framework of these specific rules raises some questions, which the report points out, not always critically, as they are, among others: their need in the context of the internal market and the capital market; the need to strengthen democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and public access to documents, public dialogue between stakeholders and the prevention of conflicts of interest; or the transformation of EFRAG into a public agency. The report has positive points, although it is of little criticism to the issues of the internal market and the single capital market, which gives it a negative framework.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the development of high-quality accounting standards, applicable worldwide, can lead to an improvement in competition by promoting the removal of obstacles to investment on a global scale. The report also has the merit of emphasising the need for the bodies responsible for drawing up accounting standards to strike the right balance between the needs linked to complex markets and financial instruments and the need to provide for high-quality, transparent and comparable global principles.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 International Accounting Standards form an important part of the European Union's financial services rules and supervisory framework. They intersect with many other parts of European Union financial services legislation, including prudential supervision. Although the rules in question are largely positive and their contribution is considered positive, the financial and economic crisis has exposed the weaknesses of the system and its necessary reform in certain areas.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which, in my opinion, is unclear and will not lead to certain and defined objectives.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 European public and private sector entities at national and European level have different views and interests in the development of accounting standards. International Financial Reporting Standards as part of EU law impose a level playing field for a single market that is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the corresponding weak. For the above reasons I am voting against the report on the Evaluation of International Accounting Standards (IAS).

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the desire to bring international regulations, which are an important part of EU financial services legislation, to be equated. This equalization will be very positive as it recognizes the importance of such rules, applicable worldwide, to improve competition and remove investment barriers on a global scale.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Non-Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the assessment of IAS/IFRS accounting standards, on the activities of the IASB (the International Accounting Standards Foundation) and on the activities of EFRAG (the High Level Advisory Group on Financial Reporting) because I shared the spirit behind this first report by Parliament incorporating internationally shared standards (IASB) into European law and calling for the full implementation of the recommendations contained in the report prepared by the Belgian-led working group Maystadt on the governance of EFRAG. International accounting standards are essential for the proper functioning of financial markets and indispensable for communicating financial information for investors, companies and supervision. Hence the need to arrive at common or equivalent rules concerning the budgets of financial institutions at international level. I therefore supported the S&D Group's position that international accounting standards should not undermine the EU's financial stability, but should help sustainable growth, and are to be considered as public goods. Furthermore, I believe that greater control and transparency are particularly important in order to prevent conflicts of interest. The EU must have greater influence at international level. This is the most significant approach that the European Parliament is addressing to EFRAG.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Report on the Assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS). The technical text discusses very well the necessary measures to achieve internationally comparable accounting.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The International Accounting Standard (IAS) is essential for the effective functioning of the European internal and capital markets. As the IAS is a public good, it should not hinder the financial stability or economic development of the Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to see accounting standards that ensure financial stability and sustainable growth, along with a meaningful reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards. This will ensure both transparency and accountability. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report, which seeks to homogenise at European level the common criteria for the accounting of companies. While I am not opposed to this process, the report incorporates positive references to processes to which I do object, such as the Capital Markets Union, which is why I have opted for abstention.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved to remove investment barriers, as well as to enable the development of a single capital market in the European Union. Harmonising international accounting standards will increase the competitiveness of the European economy, allowing sMEs to be easily listed and traded on growth markets. At the same time, consistent compliance with and application of international standards, applicable in multiple jurisdictions, will ensure a level playing field in the single market.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stood in committee. Labour MEPs support the promotion of accounting standards which will ensure financial stability and sustainable growth and a deep reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards, in order to ensure better and greater transparency and accountability where it didn’t exist before.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. International accounting standards form an important part of the EU financial services regulation and supervisory framework. The application of the international financial reporting standards in the EU has contributed to a strengthening of the single market and also strengthened the competitiveness of the European economy by allowing companies to attract capital and investments on global capital markets.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which assesses European influence in the formation of international accounting standards and their subsequent reception in European law, which emphasises the importance of financial stability in setting accounting standards.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on International Accounting Standards (IAS) evaluation and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB).
