The IFRS and the ISA form an important part of the EU financial services regulation and supervisory framework and interact with a multitude of other pieces of EU financial services regulation, inter alia in the area of prudential regulation. I was pleased that the report underlined the important role of accounting standards for the development of a single capital market in the European Union, in particular in the context of the Capital Markets Union (CMU) project. I was also pleased that the report also stressed how IAS strengthened the competitiveness of the European economy by allowing companies to attract capital and investments on global capital markets. The effects of applying IFRS in the European Union in the last ten years have therefore been positive overall.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it approves the use of high-quality globally applicable accounting standards which have led to improvements in the industry on a global scale.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is necessary to promote accounting standards that ensure financial stability and sustainable growth. We also need a deep reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the evaluation of international accounting standards and activities of the Foundation for International Financial Reporting Standards, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Oversight Committee, as I consider that there is no single or competitive market without coherence.  The European Union framework for the regulation and supervision of financial services should be based on consistent and harmonised international standards in the development of the Single Capital Market and to make the European Union a leader in the global market. It is also necessary to take into account the public interest that all companies on the labour market are treated equally and to provide credible information on company creditworthies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite relevant observations and recommendations, I abstained on this report because it parallels the use of IFRS in a globalised economy. It is fair to accept the principle of common accounting standards in order to facilitate the exchange of information, but IFRS standards are strongly criticised on various key points that may make them illegitimate.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve and strengthen the process for the development of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International Audit Standards (ISA). They are essential to the proper functioning of the internal market and financial markets, and must not jeopardised financial stability or hinder the economic development of the Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report on international accounting standards deals with the important part on the financial services supervisory framework. The application of international accounting standards strengthens the internal market and the competitiveness of enterprises (inflow of capital and investment). I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – As I have repeatedly suggested, all financial instability is the oro of financial liberalisation and deregulation measures of the 1990s. Since then, there have been various trials to promote stability, but by the logic of things, they can only mitigate problems. Of course, this technical report, which facilitates the simplification of the rules, should also be supported, but only radical solutions can really be taken against instability.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because, despite some good recommendations, it is a champion of the use of international IFRS accounting standards in a globalized economy. However, these IFRS standards are under the control of large Anglo-Saxon audit firms.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite very relevant observations and recommendations, I abstained on the report on the evaluation of international accounting standards, as it parallels the use of international ACCOUNTING standards IFRS in a globalized economy. However, these IFRS standards suffer from many criticisms related to the notion of "fair value" for the valuation of the company's assets, the use of principles and not rules, and the lack of legitimacy and democratic control of the IASB, the private and non-communal institution that defines IFRS and is under the control of the major Anglo-Saxon audit firms.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text in question focuses on the standards created by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB). The organization produces international accounting standards, known as the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), with the aim of developing a common base for global financial reporting. However, the 2008 crisis highlighted the need to improve these rules. In particular, the report notes a lack of progress in transparency and conflict prevention within the IASB. It particularly deplores the lack of a common and transparent methodology in certain areas, such as the valuation of 100- and depreciated assets. While I support the creation of a common accounting standard base, I cannot accept the dysfunctions of the IASB and IFRS, which, after all, do not respect the sovereignty of states in terms of accounting regulation. So I voted against the text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive references to understanding international accounting standards as a public good, it does not delve sufficient into its necessary public regulation. International Accounting Standards are standards set by the private sector, which have enabled the development of speculative bubbles that have led to this financial crisis. This demonstrates the need for public control over these standards and the need for democratic organizations to establish them. Despite some positive references, the report does not delve into the necessary and immediate public participation in their determination and that is why I have not been able to vote in their favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report calls for mandatory reporting of accounting data by country as part of the "fight against tax avoidance and evasion". I see this as a sustained effort by Western EU states to prevent companies from taxing in the Czech Republic. Uniform accounting standards and mandatory reporting are a step towards uniform taxation of companies and the transfer of taxes to countries with high corporate tax rates at the expense of the Czech Republic.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 IFRS standards change according to dynamic changes in the environment such as uneven economic and economic development, volatility of financial markets and institutions. According to the environment, standards are also supplemented or put out of service. IFRS together with international audit standards (ISAs) form a key component for the efficient functioning of capital markets and the internal market.  The fundamental purpose of IFRS is to strengthen accountability by investing efforts to reduce the information gap that arises between companies and investors, improving international comparability and the quality of financial data, as well as introducing greater transparency. In order to facilitate the movement of global capital, it is necessary to have a single global system of accounting standards on the harmonisation of different standards.  In the European Union, long-term investors and various stakeholders have already highlighted several times the problem of mismatches between international accounting standards and the legal requirements set out in the Accounting Directive.  Mismatches are most common in the principles of governance and wariness, which hampers global capital movements. The need arises to define and develop harmonised financial reporting standards as well as ensure compliance and consistency. Given all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 International accounting standards are a fundamentally important part of the EU financial services regulatory and supervisory framework. Since 2005, listed EU companies have had to prepare consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. A certain problem, however, is that these rules have largely been in force for more than a decade – thus also going through the recent financial crisis – but much-needed large-scale legislative changes have still not been initiated, which would increase the effectiveness of these standards. The current system of accounting standards is too complex and therefore agree that it needs to be streamlined, with a particular focus on the awareness of users – including investors, companies and ordinary Community citizens). It is worth noting that the introduction of international accounting standards has taken place in all or part of 116 jurisdictions, which makes rationalisation efforts rather difficult. It is likely that the introduction of common, or at least closely correlated international accounting standards, is a good thing, but not in itself, but as an effective tool for preventing their own financial crises. Of course, this is only one possible means of combating the factors causing the crisis, which must be closely coordinated with other means, firstly, the appropriate efforts of each government of the country concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the evaluation of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS), the European Advisory Group on Financial Reporting (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Supervisory Board, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. International accounting standards (so-called IFRS standards) have been imposed on Companies in the European Union since 2005. This situation is not entirely satisfactory: the choice of "fair value" for the valuation of asset values has been one of the causes of the instability of financial markets observed in recent years. Other issues need to be raised: the issue of off-balance sheet accounts, the lack of a common methodology for assessing reporting assets and depreciated assets.  Finally, the impartiality of the IASB, the body behind IFRS standards, also raises questions: dominated by large private companies, it leaves no room for representatives of SME/SMEs.  We therefore do not criticize the appropriateness of harmonized accounting standards. However, our reservations about IFRS are too great for us to support this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the report on the evaluation of international accounting standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS), the European Advisory Group on Financial Reporting (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB). It remains essential to regard the forgery of companies in the budget as a threat to economic and financial stability. Internationally recognized accounting standards, oriented towards the public interest, are also needed. Transparency and positive reforms are intended to improve a reality as important as that of international accounting standards.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This concerns international accounting standards, the activities of the Foundation for International Accounting Standards (IFRS) and the European Accounting Advisory Group on the Financial Services Supervisory Framework. The application of international accounting standards simplifies the comparison of annual and consolidated financial statements. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the EP's position on the assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS). International accounting standards are an important part of the EU framework for regulating and supervising financial services. They relate to a number of other EU financial services legislation.  However, the financial crisis has shown that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The economic and financial crisis has made reform of international financial reporting standards (IFRS) essential for greater transparency, governance of economic systems and greater comparability. The European Union has delegated the development of international accounting standards to the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), a private independent self-regulatory body. At present, 116 countries, with different legal, regulatory and economic structures, already impose the use of IFRS standards, so there is limited room for manoeuvre in taking european specificities into account. The report calls for a strengthening of European influence in the early stages of the development of accounting standards. The report also criticises the governance of the IASB, stressing that it is "dominated by private actors", that "SMEs are not represented at all" and that "the risk of conflicts of interest" is present. I abstain to encourage this awareness.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The IASB develops global accounting standards (IFRS), a common language for fluid global financial reporting. The IAS Regulation requires publicly traded EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. The financial crisis has shown that there is a need to improve them. The report highlights major problems, such as off-balance sheet accounts. The report also criticises the IASB for the lack of progress in terms of transparency, conflict of interest prevention and diversity of experts (SMEs without representation). However, IFRS standards are therefore illegitimate in some respects, such as the notion of "fair value", a short-term vision and too much freedom of interpretation. So I abstained.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. The International Accounting Standards Board is providing financial services sectors with valuable tools to better assess and compare data from across the world, by creating a common language for global financial reporting.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International Audit Standards (ISA) make a significant contribution to the functioning of the domestic and capital markets by facilitating investor decision-making. These standards ensure, among other things, better exchange of information between investors and companies and better protection of investments. The consistency of these standards is therefore elementary. In this report, Parliament calls on the Commission to follow a series of recommendations and calls on the standards body to ensure that these standards are in line with those set at the global level. The clarity of these standards will enable us to strengthen investor confidence in our market, a significant source of growth.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – International accounting standards form an important part of the European Union's financial services rules and supervisory framework. The European Union has entrusted the International Accounting Standards Board with the development of international financial accounting standards. They overlap with many other parts of Union financial services legislation, inter alia, in the field of prudential supervision. I believe that the use of international financial reporting standards in the Union has contributed to strengthening the single market and has also increased the competitiveness of the European economy, as it has enabled businesses to attract capital and investment to global capital markets. However, I consider it necessary to carry out a review of financial reporting standards and to improve them, in particular the implications of the use of fair value for financial stability. The set of existing accounting standards needs to achieve consistency and consistency, including with regard to Union financial services legislation. In view of the above, I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which promotes accounting standards that ensure financial stability and sustainable growth, and a deep reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability, which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) develops high-quality, globally applicable accounting standards, thereby creating a common language for global financial reporting. Since 2005, publicly traded Union companies have been required to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. According to the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the application of international financial reporting standards in the EU has contributed to strengthening the single market and strengthening the competitiveness of the European economy by giving companies the opportunity to attract capital and investment in global capital markets. However, the financial crisis has also shown that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved. The report underlines the need to develop coherent financial reporting standards and considers it of the utmost importance to ensure European influence at all stages of the standard-making process, and in particular at an early stage, in order to ensure that international accounting standards represent European economic interests. I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world. These standards are called the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Since 2005, the IAS Regulation has required publicly traded EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. However, the financial crisis has shown that there is a need to improve them. The use of the term "fair value" and its consequences on financial stability, in particular, has sparked an ongoing debate. The report points out that major problems have been identified with regard to accounting standards in the run-up to the crisis, such as off-balance sheet accounts, the procyclicality created by the principle of market-price valuation and the accounting of losses and profits, the underestimating of the accumulation of risks during the economic recovery and the lack of a common and transparent methodology for the valuation of non-liquid and depreciated assets. However, despite relevant observations and recommendations, we are abstaining from this report, as it parallels the use of IFRS in a globalised economy.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International Audit Standards (ISA) are key elements for the effective functioning of the internal market and capital markets and can be seen as a public good and thus should not jeopardise financial stability or undermine the economic development of the Union and should be at the service of the common good and not only in the interests of investors , lenders and creditors. I believe that international accounting standards are a key part of the EU regulatory and supervisory framework for financial services, interacting with a wide range of eu financial services regulatory acts, in particular in the field of prudential regulation.  It is important to note that the falsification of business accounts is a threat to economic and financial stability and calls into question citizens' confidence in the social market economy model. I endorse the rapporteur's position in recognising the importance of such globally applicable standards to improve competitiveness and remove barriers to global investment.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The principle of common accounting standards, in order to facilitate the exchange of information, is not a bad principle, but IFRS standards are strongly criticised on various key points. For example, IFRS is based on principles, not rules, principles that provide freedom of interpretation on the accounting of certain commitments and complicate the comparison of companies. I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, on the evaluation of international accounting standards, supports the work of the International Accounting Standards Board, which aims to develop a set of high-quality accounting standards applicable around the world for the purpose of simplification. I voted for it.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we adopted a proposal supporting the work of the IASB on the development and approval of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Publicly traded Union companies are required to prepare their financial statements in accordance with global accounting standards. These standards are an important part of the development of a single capital market within the European Union and strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy. The overall impact of IFRS in the European Union over the last ten years has been positive.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) was founded on the 1 April 20012 and is an independent accounting standard body of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation. I support this report, which aims to further address issues regarding the endorsement process of IFRS in the European Union.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am of the opinion that only simple accounting rules can be effectively implemented by users and controlled by supervisors. In this context, the G20's call for simplification of accounting standards for financial instruments and the achievement of a consistent approach in the international application of valuation standards in cooperation with supervisors can be recalled. Given that most companies are Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs), the Commission should assess the possibility of developing common, high-quality and simplified accounting standards for SMEs.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this own-initiative report, which evaluates 10 years of implementation of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and the international standards on auditing (ISA) set by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) in the EU.  The report is a response to the Commission’s evaluation of the implementation and makes proposals to the IASB which is in the process of creating a globally applicable standard for financial reporting. There are positive aspects to this in terms of regulating financial instruments so that they provide more accurate and transparent information to investors (for example about risk) and in challenging the ability of companies to falsify their records. However, I believe this report should have also called for improving the governance of the standard-setting organisations to ensure their independence from corporations, which was opposed by conservatives at committee level, meaning it was not included in the final report. I also object to the overall goal of the report which states the proposals on standards are primarily aimed at ensuring the efficient functioning of the Capital Markets Union, a concept I am strongly opposed to. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is an objective assessment of international accounting standards. The application of international accounting standards simplifies annual and consolidated financial statements and, in my opinion, also makes sense. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Financial reporting standards need to be improved, compliance with them and consistent application are essential to ensure a level playing field in the Single Market.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the Commission to act; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal as it underlines the role of international accounting standards in European financial services legislation. In the current economic and financial context, however, a revision of these principles, in the sense of their modernisation and adaptation, is necessary. Consequently, the European Union has an important role to play in this process. Similarly, the European Parliament is called upon to play a more active role in the process of homologation of international financial reporting standards. Convinced of the usefulness of these changes, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – International Financial Standards are a key component for the effective functioning of the internal market as well as the capital markets. In order for them to continue to do so, Parliament, the Commission and the Council should develop standards for reporting and endorsing the processes. Such a development will result in much better results of the appropriateness of the accounting and reporting principles. I voted in favour of the report and support the International Accounting Standards evaluation.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International accounting standards have been introduced to increase the transparency and comparability of financial statements by increasing the efficiency of the European capital market. Today, these standards are applied in over 100 countries by private individuals and companies when compiling their financial statements.  The European Commission assessed how the application of the standards accomplished their task - the creation of a common accounting language. However, according to the report, there is still room for further improvement: to harmonise them internationally, simplify them, improve comprehension and consistency in application.  I welcome the expressed will to make further progress in standardising accounting rules and addressing detected shortcomings, and for the utmost importance of standardisation in removing barriers to new investment, and in developing the Single Capital Market in the Union in general, I support this report. However, I call on the Commission to verify that existing accounting standards allow for any tax fraud.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The principle of common accounting standards, in order to facilitate the exchange of information, is not a bad principle, but IFRS standards are strongly criticised on various key points. For example, IFRS is based on principles, not rules. These principles provide freedom of interpretation on the accounting of certain commitments and complicate the comparison of companies. I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of international financial reporting standards is to strengthen accountability by reducing the information gap between investors and businesses, protecting investment and introducing transparency by improving international comparability and the quality of financial data, and enabling investors and other market participants to make sound economic decisions and thereby influence the behaviour of stakeholders in financial markets and to act on the stability of those markets. Financial statements are of particular importance for the protection of shareholders, members and third parties and do not provide guarantees above the amount of their net assets to third parties. For the sake of the described importance, I note that the accounting model of 'usefulness for decision-making' does not fully comply with the accounting function of 'capital adequacy' as described in the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union and in the Accounting Directive, which leads to the conclusion that the conceptual basis of the accounting framework for international financial reporting standards does not cover the purpose of financial statements in EU law for which the standard of truthful and accurate representation of the indicated figures applies, as set out in Lord Hill's written reply E-016071/2015 of 25 February 2016, whereas a holistic assessment of the importance of individual figures and qualitative explanations is needed to achieve the principle of truthfulness and accuracy of the display.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Stolojan's report underlines the importance of the role of accounting standards in the development of the Single Capital Market in the Member States, especially in the context of capital markets, which will help further strengthen European influence in the world. By adopting international financial reporting standards, we ensure that they are in compliance with the interests of the European economy. I supported The Stolojan MeP's report, which welcomes the evaluation of international accounting standards implemented by the Commission, but also reminds the Commission that it is necessary to present the legal changes needed to address the shortcomings and mismatches identified by the evaluation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which assesses international accounting standards, overseen by the International Financial Reporting Foundation (IFRS), which has been in force in the European Union for ten years. These international standards are important elements of the proper functioning of the EU's internal market and financial markets.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the Commission to act; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In particular, this report was an opportunity to assess international accounting standards, which are one of the essential elements for the proper functioning of the internal market and capital markets. THE ifRS standards aim to reduce the lack of information between investors and businesses, protect investments, promote transparency by improving the comparability and quality of financial reporting internationally, and enable investors and other market participants to make informed economic decisions.  However, ten years after their implementation, the time has come to take stock... corrections. Unfortunately, I note that the Commission has not yet proposed the necessary legislative changes to address the deficiencies identified in its own assessment.  As far as I am concerned, I support the European Parliament's requests to follow the Maystadt recommendation on the extension of the public interest test. These standards cannot jeopardise financial stability or hinder the economic development of the European Union. I also support the Commission's request to make a proposal to include in the IAS regulation the definition of the 'general interest' test also contained in the Maystadt report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report on the assessment of international accounting standards and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Supervisory Board appears to be very recitalal in principle. We all agree that harmonising standards around the world is an important task. Statistics show that they are largely harmonised, although there are important exceptions. The report is also discussing the guidelines for continuing the harmonisation of standards, and unfortunately I am missing out on the Commission's specific ambitions in this area.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the need to review and improve International Accounting Standards (IAS), both within their regulatory framework or to address questions relating to the process of approving International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in the European Union. Currently, the IAS Council develops a set of high-quality accounting standards and global application through the creation of a common language for the global financial lexicon. And it is here that it is necessary to strike a balance between the complexity inherent in the inclusion of financial reporting in accounting standards with the requirement to make them more transparent and understandable to users and other stakeholders. It is important to ensure compliance with the principle of proportionality with regard to the application of IAS, which should be uniform, consistent and adapted to companies trading on the markets, growing SMEs and smaller companies that want to be listed on the stock exchange. As the objective is to assess the current regulation on accounting standards and the standardisation of EU financial services, providing them with greater transparency, rigour and effectiveness and, above all, greater European participation and influence at all legislative procedural stages on a global scale, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the evaluation of international accounting standards. International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International Audit Standards (ISA) are essential to the proper functioning of the domestic and capital markets.  This report aims to make IFRS standards more consistent at the international level, always with the same concern for clarity and efficiency. This requires strengthening impact assessments, particularly in the macroeconomic field, and assessing the different needs of the wide variety of stakeholders, including long-term investors, businesses and the general public. The text also calls for the development of simplified and high-quality common accounting standards for SMEs, which is a priority for us. It also advocates the association of Parliament and stakeholders in the development of these standards.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report entitled 'Evaluation of international accounting standards'. These principles, called ISA and IFRS, are an essential component for the proper functioning of the internal market and capital markets. They represent an important regulatory and regulatory framework for the European Union in the field of financial services. These principles can be understood as a public good, thus serving the common interest and not just the interests of investors, lenders and creditors. Once again, we are seeing the EU's efforts to create a financial environment that is as stable and as risky as possible. European policies aim to create a climate of confidence and stability that can stimulate investment. A major push in this direction has been given by the European Commission through the development of the Juncker Plan, the balance sheet of which, one year after its entry into force, can be described as entirely positive.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report, which seeks to homogenise at European level the common criteria for the accounting of companies. While I am not opposed to this process, the report incorporates positive references to processes to which I do object, such as the Capital Markets Union, which is why I have opted for abstention.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. In order to achieve financial stability and sustainable growth, it is important that we can effectively control and regulate the financial sector. With international accounting standards, we create more transparent company accounts, reduce costs for businesses and thus improve competitiveness. It is particularly important that the agreement ensures transparency. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Report on the Assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the Foundation for International Accounting Standards (IFRS Foundation), the European Accounting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB)" as both IAS and IFRS are instruments that are essential for international trade. International accounting standards are applied by more than 100 countries and ensure that all companies present their financial information to the same standard. This ensures greater transparency and security for everyone.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive references to understanding international accounting standards as a public good, it does not delve sufficient into its necessary public regulation. International Accounting Standards are standards set by the private sector, which have enabled the development of speculative bubbles that have led to this financial crisis. This demonstrates the need for public control over these standards and the need for democratic organizations to establish them. Despite some positive references, the report does not delve into the necessary and immediate public participation in their determination and that is why I have not been able to vote in their favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we live in a globalised world, where businesses are free to move to every continent to look for new business. This economic scenario, however, requires that there be internationally recognised accounting standards in order to avoid fraud or wrongdoing. The own-initiative report adopted today recognises that the balance between the mandatory scope of the International Accounting Standards (IAS) Regulation and the possibility for Member States to benefit from the use of IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation) at national level must ensure adequate subsidiarity and proportionality. This report also assesses the activities of the IFRS Foundation, EFRAG (European Financial Reporting Advisory Group) and PIOB (Public Interest Oversight Board) and addresses general issues regarding the process of homologation of IFRS accounting standards in European law. International accounting standards are an important part of the EU's financial services regulatory and supervisory framework and, for this reason, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stood in committee. I want to see the promotion of accounting standards which will ensure financial stability and sustainable growth and a deep reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards in order to ensure better and greater transparency and accountability and introduce it where it didn’t otherwise exist.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Accounting standards should not jeopardise financial stability in the EU or hamper its economic development. It is necessary for the standard-maker to ensure that IFRS complies with the existing set of accounting standards and to promote convergence at international level. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I believe that a globalised economy requires internationally recognised accounting standards. I am glad that international financial reporting standards in the EU play a very important role in building the single capital market and, thanks to them, it is also gradually increasing the competitiveness of the European economy. Although international accounting standards (IAS) are generally assessed positively and the objectives on IAS have been achieved, I would like to point out that the financial crisis has also revealed very clearly and clearly certain shortcomings that need to be addressed. It regrets that the Commission has not yet proposed the legal changes that are necessary to address the shortcomings identified in the evaluation. Like the rapporteur, I am concerned about the great complexity of financial reporting and EU financial services legislation, for which consistency and consistency need to be achieved. I appreciate that the IAS has created a common language in the field of financial reporting worldwide in order to improve competition and remove investment barriers. I expect that intensive dialogue will continue between the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and the accounting standard-setter from the Member States, despite slow progress in the convergence process.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Accounting Standards Board, based in London, is developing a range of accounting standards to create a common language for global financial reporting.  The report recognises the importance of such globally applicable standards to improve competition and remove barriers to investment at global level. International accounting standards are an important part of the regulation on financial services and the EU supervisory framework and interact with a whole range of other regulations under the EU financial services regime, including in the area of prudential regulation.  The report highlights concerns about the increasing complexity of financial reporting. The standards-setting bodies should seek the right balance between the need for accounting standards to reflect complex financial markets and instruments and the need for high-quality, transparent and comparable global standards that are understandable to a large group of different stakeholders. The principle of proportionality must be followed on the grounds that smaller companies are also allowed to be listed on the stock exchange.  The report calls for further strengthening of European influence in the early stages of the development of accounting standards. The process involves different entities of the European public and private sector at national and European level, sometimes with different views and interests.  The report on the assessment of international accounting standards is thus appropriate to my view, which is why I supported it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unification of accounting standards and procedures is one of the important tools in the fight against international money laundering and tax fraud.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The vulnerability of economic and financial stability and the decrease in citizens' trust in the social market economy model occurs as a result of the distorted presentation of company accounting data. I support this report because international accounting standards and international audit standards are one of the key components necessary for the efficient functioning of capital markets and the internal market.  Also, the important fact is that reducing the information gap between investors and companies as well as enabling investors, as well as other market participants, to make well-founded economic decisions are some of the objectives and purposes of the International Accounting Standard.  Furthermore, a global system of accounting standards is essential for global capital movements. Finally, I believe that this report is relevant, as the focus is also on strengthening Europe's position to ensure that principles are embedded in the overall standard setting process as well as the recognition thereof.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EU Parliament resolution on the evaluation of international accounting standards (IAS) and on the activities of the Foundation for International Accounting Standards (IFRS Foundation), the European Accounting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB). It calls for binding reporting by country under IFRS, known as country-by-country reporting. It is not the job of companies to shape their balance sheets in such a way that states can more easily enforce their right to tax. It would be right for states to shape their tax laws in such a way that they themselves succeed in this because of clever tax legislation. Misplaced tax legislation must not be at the expense of companies.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International accounting standards form an important part of the EU framework for the regulation and supervision of financial services. The importance of accounting standards in the development of the Single Capital Market in the European Union is of great importance, especially in the context of the Capital Markets Union project. The application of international financial reporting standards in the EU has contributed to strengthening the single market and has also strengthened the competitiveness of the European economy by enabling companies to attract capital and investment on global capital markets. International accounting standards must be approved before they become part of Union legislation, ensuring that they are in the interest of the European economy.  I support this Resolution because I believe that compliance with financial reporting standards and their application must be ensured in order to ensure a level playing field in the single market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the assessment of international accounting standards and activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Protection Committee.  The recent economic and financial crisis has shown the need to review and improve financial reporting standards. We also need good accounting standards for the development of a single capital market in the European Union and the strengthening of the single market, and, consequently, for the competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 European public and private sector entities at national and European level have different views and interests in the development of accounting standards. International Financial Reporting Standards as part of EU law impose a level playing field on a single market that is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the respective weak.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of international accounting standards, as I believe it rightly points to the importance of financial reporting standards and summarises in detail the areas where, as the financial crisis has made clear, it is inevitable to review and correct the standards. I expressly support the part of the report calling for country-by-country reporting to be introduced under IFRS, as it can play a crucial role in combating tax evasion and fraud. Indeed, it is necessary to examine as soon as possible whether accounting standards allow for tax fraud and avoidance and to identify measures to avoid and prevent possible abuses. It is now also essential, as highlighted in the report, to be fully aware of the effects of accounting standards. Therefore, both the International Accounting Standards Board and the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group should prioritise strengthening its impact assessments, in particular as regards macroeconomics. Finally, I also endorse the view that only simple rules can be applied effectively and monitored effectively. Thus, the complexity of IFRSs must also be reduced in order to ensure a greater degree of transparency and comparability between corporate financial data that has long been advocated.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The european Union's influence on International Accounting Standards (IASB) has contributed to the development of common high-quality accounting standards worldwide. For its part, the Union began as early as 2005 to incorporate these standards into European legislation, which contribute to the development of the single capital market, financial services and the supervisory framework. At the same time, the development of those standards was intended to ensure greater transparency and accountability and to prevent conflicts of interest. The adoption of common accounting standards also contributes to the EU's financial stability and sustainable economic development. Last but not least, harmonising these standards with those existing in partner countries, such as the United States, will strengthen relations between the two parties. I believe that the adoption of this document will enshrine the existence of common accounting standards worldwide, facilitating a wide range of economic activities beneficial to EU Member States and European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. International accounting standards are an important component of financial services regulation and the EU's supervisory framework. They are linked to many other aspects of European financial services regulation, particularly in the area of prudential regulation. The rapporteur therefore stresses the importance of accounting standards for the establishment of a single capital market in the European Union, particularly in the context of the Capital Markets Union (CMU) project. According to him, the application of international financial reporting standards in the European Union has contributed to the strengthening of the single market and the competitiveness of the European economy by enabling companies to attract capital and investment to global capital markets. The application of IFRS standards in the European Union over the past ten years has therefore had a generally positive effect. However, the financial crisis has shown that financial reporting standards need to be reviewed and improved. The use of the term "fair value" and its consequences on financial stability, in particular, has sparked an ongoing debate. This text is therefore a good signal

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ International standards in accounting and auditing are essential for the efficient functioning of the internal market and of the capital markets. They strengthen accountability by reducing the information gap between investors and companies, protect investment, bring transparency and allow stakeholders to make informed economic decisions. This is why I voted in favour of the report, which assesses the application of these standards in the EU 10 years after their endorsement. I am particularly supportive of the Commission’s intention to possibly develop common high-quality and simplified accounting standards for SMEs. I also believe that an impact assessment for every new accounting standard or change of a current accounting standard would be very useful. Finally, I agree that Parliament should have an active role in setting and implementing these standards.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Evaluation Report on International Accounting Standards and activities of the Foundation for International Financial Reporting Standards, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Oversight Board.  I believe that internationally accepted accounting standards are necessary in a globalised world and that, in interaction with other legislative acts on the regulation of financial services, they form an important part of the Union framework for the regulation and supervision of financial services. I would also like to stress the importance of the role of accounting standards in the development of the Single Capital Market in the European Union, in particular in the context of the Capital Markets Union project. I believe that the application of international financial reporting standards in the European Union contributes to strengthening the single market but also strengthening the competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Assessment of International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS Foundation), the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Protection Committee (PIOB) as international standards are important for improving competition and removing barriers to investment at global level. They are an important part of the regulation on financial services and the EU supervisory framework. The crisis has shown the need to recast and improve them. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), which is an independent body, is responsible for the development of international accounting standards. The principle of proportionality should apply to international accounting standards in order to allow smaller companies to be listed on a stock exchange as well. Consistency and consistency must be ensured within the existing international accounting standards set, while respecting other arrangements on EU financial services. In order for European accounting standards to be in the interest of the European economy, it is necessary to approve IFRS in order to become part of EU legislation. In order to ensure a level playing field in the single market, it is necessary to ensure compliance with financial reporting standards and their consistent implementation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report, which seeks to homogenise at European level the common criteria for the accounting of companies. While I am not opposed to this process, the report incorporates positive references to processes to which I do object, such as the Capital Markets Union, which is why I have opted for abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The introduction of international accounting standards is necessary in order to increase competition and remove investment barriers worldwide. Accounting standards are very important in the further development of the single capital market in the European Union. I voted in favour of the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The London-based International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) develops high-quality, globally applicable accounting standards, thereby creating a common language for global financial reporting. Your draftsman recognises the importance of such globally applicable standards in improving competition and removing investment barriers at global level. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report, which seeks to homogenise at European level the common criteria for the accounting of companies. While I am not opposed to this process, the report incorporates positive references to processes to which I do object, such as the Capital Markets Union, which is why I have opted for abstention.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the report provides a welcome clear set of principles and priorities as regards the future required developments of international accounting standards and their implementation in EU law, whereby the promotion of the public good and transparency represent a cornerstone.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on International Accounting Standards (IAS) evaluation because I believe that a core component of achieving the true and fair view of the figures set out in the accounts is prudent evaluation. The report emphasises that only simple rules can be effectively applied by users and controlled by supervisors. Moreover, the report supports the Commission recommendations that the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation should shift the focus of its attention from the issue of internal organisation to discussing matters of public interest.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 International accounting standards are an essential component necessary for the efficient functioning of the internal market and capital markets. While the evaluation has shown that the objectives of the regulation have been achieved, this report sets out the need for the Commission to propose the necessary legal changes to correct the faults identified in the Commission's assessment. We are therefore talking about a report which recognises progress in the rules and which at the same time proposes improvement actions, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the issue of international accounting standards (IFRS) which form an important part of the financial services regulatory and supervisory framework. These principles are developed by the International Accounting Standards Boards (IASB), a private and independent self-regulatory body that is creating a common language for financial reporting on a global scale. IFRS have already been in place for 10 years but the financial crisis has shown their total inefficiency. This is because these standards are too complex and their management unclear. Other critical issues: the principle of mandatory reporting between states is lacking. Although they were conceived as global standards, there are some counterparts, such as the US, who do not use them at all and others, such as the EU, who are not involved in the processing process. We do not agree with the urgent need to adopt harmonised accounting standards at EU level, because this is aimed at greater and better development of the single capital market, a project that we are strongly opposed to as it would increase the financialisation of the economy to the detriment of the real economy. The report, on the one hand, highlights the major shortcomings of this system, but on the other hand calls for further development of the general framework. That is why we have chosen to abstain.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because the international financial reporting standards (IFRS) and international audit standards (ISA) are indispensable for the proper functioning of the internal market and capital markets. The purpose of this report is not to jeopardise financial stability or to impede the economic development of the Union. It aims to serve the public interest, not just the interests of investors, lenders and creditors.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 International accounting standards are an important part of the EU regulatory and supervisory framework for financial services. These standards interact with a wide range of EU regulatory acts on financial services, notably in the field of prudential regulation. We follow the report on the central role of accounting standards in developing a more transparent and community-readable market.  What we do not follow is this association of the need to improve international accounting standards with the current financial crisis. International accounting standards are important, but they cannot replace the basic measures that are required to control the world of finance, avoiding this speculation without a rule and without brake and which leads to crises whose costs end up being borne by them as always. In this way, let us not confuse the intervention plans. The crisis will be resolved when there is political will to take the necessary measures. They are under public control of the financial system as well as the large oligopolies they currently have in the European Union.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is a very factual assessment of international accounting standards and the activities of the Foundation for International Accounting Standards (IFRS), the European Advisory Group on Accounting (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB). These are an important part of the financial services supervisory framework. The application of international accounting standards simplifies, for example, the comparison of annual and consolidated financial statements. I think this makes sense.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it reiterates Parliament’s view that public country-by-country reporting can play a decisive role in combating tax avoidance and fraud. The report also welcomes the fact that the Commission is encouraging Member States to follow the ESMA guidelines on the enforcement of financial information and calls on the Commission to assess whether ESMA’s powers make it possible to ensure consistent and coherent enforcement across the EU and, if not, to explore other ways to ensure proper application of enforcement.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on my colleague Theodor Stolojan's own-initiative report on the evaluation of international accounting standards. In the initiative, the rapporteur underlines the important role of accounting standards for the development of a single capital market in the EU, in particular in the context of the Capital Markets Union project. The rapporteur considers that the application of international financial reporting standards in the EU has helped to strengthen the single market and has also strengthened the competitiveness of the European economy, as it has enabled businesses to attract capital and investment from global capital markets. The rapporteur also notes that the financial crisis has shown that financial reporting standards need to be revised and improved.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the assessment of international accounting standards and activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Protection Committee. International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and International AuditIng Standards (IAS) are elements for the effective functioning of the internal market and capital markets. International financial reporting standards are intended to protect shareholders, shareholders and third parties or market participants. In order to protect investments, transparency should be ensured by improving international comparability and the quality of financial information and enabling investors and other market participants to make informed business decisions.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the emergence of terrorist and guerrilla groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahara region of the Sahel/Sahara has led to a dramatic change in the security climate. We contribute, the Member States contribute almost eur 2 billion through the Financial Instrument for Peace in Africa. The Member States of the Union together constitute the most important financial contributor to the UN peacekeeping budget. However, there is a lack of transparency in the European Union's peacekeeping operations and, as such, we do not know exactly what is happening with the money and that peace support tool that we are funding is not sustainable, it is not controllable. We don't know where it leads and what the consequences will have. So we want more transparency and we want to report what happens to money. The African Union should also be encouraged to take greater responsibility for security in Africa.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís ní raibh aon deacracht tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo le mo ghrúpa agus a lán daoine eile. The report looks at the current state of peace support operations in Africa supported by the UN and the African Union. It focuses in particular on the contribution from the European Union. The report outlines that the United Nations is the main guarantor of peace and security internationally, with over 120 000 personnel deployed across the world, the vast majority of whom are currently serving in Africa on peacekeeping missions.  The EU’s primary mechanism for cooperation with Africa is the African Peace Facility (APF). The APF action programme addresses shortcomings, places stronger emphasis on exit strategies and increased burden sharing with African countries, targeted support and improved decision—making procedures. The report considers APF to be an entry point and potential lever for creating a stronger partnership between the EU and the African Union in the future.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peace support operations are generally the answer to crisis situations, aimed in particular at restoring, maintaining or creating peace. Given the essential role it has played in development policies, it is clear that the stability of africa's territory is a priority. In this regard, Member States and the EU were invited to strengthen cooperation, in terms of financial assistance, logistical support and political dialogue. I voted against, however, because, over and above provisions that I certainly support, the strong militaristic imprint cannot be endorsed, particularly with regard to the renewal of the European armed forces on the ground.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on peace-support operations aims to increase the EU's contribution to peace operations, and collaboration with the UN and the African Union. The report calls for Member States to significantly increase their contributions from military and police to UN missions. I am opposed to this report as, inter alia, it calls on the EU to make greater efforts to strengthen international security, and maintains that European security must be the principle of EU interventions. Moreover, the report does not recognise the negative role and destabilization that the operations of the 'good of the West' have brought to different parts of the world, and does not take into account that many of the EU's missions in recent years have not been successful in terms of long-term peace and stability of countries. For all this, I voted against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on peace support operations and the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. These are operational recommendations following the various feedback from mission experiences that have seen "low" "European" participations in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic. Despite a technically well-done text, the fact that the Union claims its military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort or of our soldiers injured or killed is unacceptable. The Union does not have to play a military or international role or to phagocyte that of the States.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as while there were positive aspects in relation to supporting peacekeeping, the progressive elements failed to mitigate the worst excesses of the report, and therefore I could not support it. The report demanded that EU Member States significantly increase their military and police contributions to UN missions which is completely unacceptable. Moreover, it proposed increased cooperation between the United Nations, African Union, NATO and EU which my party would fundamentally oppose. In my view NATO is nothing more than a Cold War relic that needs to be disbanded. European countries need to increase their spending on social programmes, on job creation programmes, on education, and on healthcare. They certainly don’t need to spend more money on weapons of mass destruction. Sinn Féin is fully committed to Irish neutrality and firmly opposes the erosion of Irish neutrality by consecutive governments. We will continue to resist the militarisation of the European Union and any attempts by Irish governments to join military alliances.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the new security climate in Africa in recent years, including the emergence of terrorist groups in Somalia, Nigeria, the Sahel and the Sahara.  European action in Africa is mainly through the financing of the African Peace Facility, mainly through the European Development Fund. However, the Commission must set up alternative sources of funding as has already been requested by the Council's conclusions. In addition, the training of local forces must be strengthened in order to be able to follow up on trained soldiers. In addition, there is an urgent need to rebalance our action towards the Sahel. Finally, it is fundamental to respect human rights in our ranks. Sexual abuse by UN forces in Central Africa is unacceptable and must be properly punished!

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the issue of European cooperation in the context of UN initiatives for peace support operations in Africa, including security and defence missions and operations in the region. I voted in favour of the report, because Africa and the security of the wider region are a priority for the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'This report is more about an EU military development than peace support on the African continent. It goes against the idea of a civil Union.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The united nation's peace support missions aim to contribute to the long-term creation of stable and secure, prosperous environments. Key players in this are not only the United Nations, but also the African Union and the EU. Together, they agree on objectives for security and development in Africa. Although the EU has spent a total of EUR 1.5 billion over the past 20 years to contribute to the processes of mine clearance and mine casualties, the EU countries together represent only 5 000 out of a total of 92 000 soldiers. This amounts to only 5% in UN peacekeeping operations. I agree with Parliament's decision that the individual Member States should participate with significantly more military forces and police officers. Furthermore, the development of European military cooperation would benefit the efficiency and effectiveness of the contribution. Cooperation between the EU countries is important here, which is why it is not desirable for the individual countries to act alone.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report consisted of operational recommendations following the various feedback from mission experiences that had "low" "European" participations in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic.  This report is technically well done and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the European Union is non-existent militarily and is intended to remain so. It does not have to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort (Operation Serval and Sangaris are 90% supported by France and its African allies in terms of investment, equipment and men) and our soldiers wounded or fallen to the enemy. As this report did not take place, I spoke unfavourably.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at the current level of EU contribution to peacekeeping and humanitarian operations, in particular in Africa and the potential for further EU involvement. It calls for greater EU facilitation of Member State´s financial contributions to the UN and AU. It also calls for increased use of the Common Security and Defence Policy, ultimately a move towards a European Army. Participation in the funding of humanitarian and peacekeeping operations should solely be the responsibility of independent states and the relevant international institutions. I am against the current and further intervention by the European Union into the defence and security issues of the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to increase the European Union's contribution to peace support operations and cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. The United Nations peace-support operations are one of its most important instruments. The UN's collaboration with the African Union should be supported by the European Union and this report contains important recommendations for this support to be carried out more effectively. I would like to highlight the concern with the coordination between the various actors in order to avoid the overlap of actions and better manage the allocated resources. The United Nations has the largest peacekeeping force in the world, with the vast majority of which are in Africa. The European Union contributes more than 35% of these forces and, as written in the report, it is important that Member States are prepared to significantly increase their contributions in this way if investment in conflict prevention can be improved. For these reasons I will vote positively on the adoption of this report.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this resolution because of the strategic importance of coordinated external actions to safekeeping and peace within Africa. Early communication and enhanced procedures between the EU, United Nations, African Union as well as other organisations like NATO are necessary for peace and security. European military cooperation increases the efficiency and effectiveness of Europe’s contribution to UN peacekeeping. Clarifying EU engagement boundaries on peace support operations (PSOs) is important for recognizing the primary objective of EU development policy is the reduction and eradication of poverty. The EEAS needs to develop a much more efficient and strategic approach to the UN and its agencies, specifically with regard to external financial instruments. Peace and security are necessary preconditions for development, and fighting the root causes of conflicts paves the way for long-term development. The rise of terrorism in Africa has stressed the importance for effective anti-terrorism policies in developing countries. The importance of political, humanitarian, and development efforts supported by civilian peacekeeping operations cannot be understated in the peace—building process.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which advocates peace support operations and eu activities together with the UN and the African Union.  The aim of peace support operations is to contribute to a stable, secure and prosperous environment in the longer term; whereas good governance, justice, greater respect for the rule of law, protection of civilians, respect for human rights and security are essential conditions for this, and successful reconciliation, reconstruction and economic development programmes will contribute to sustainable peace and prosperity. I support the calls for the EU to seek a proper distribution of activities and to focus on those areas where it can bring the most benefits. A number of Member States are already involved in operations in Africa and the EU could add value by supporting these operations more closely.  I welcome the UN-EU Strategic Partnership on Peacekeeping and Crisis Management and its priorities for 2015-2018.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report brings together various operational recommendations following the various feedback from mission experiences that have seen European participation in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic.  This report is technically well done and the competence of its author remains to be commended; nevertheless, the European Union does not have to claim a military role and to boast of it at the expense of the Member States, their war effort and their soldiers who died in operation when we know that Serval and Sangaris are supported, in terms of investment, equipment and men, 90% by France and its African allies. I could only vote against the impostor that this report manifests.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which reiterates that peace operations (PSOs) are a form of response to crisis situations, usually in support of internationally recognized organizations with a UN mandate to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or establish peace, and respond to emergencies. In this context, MEPs recall in particular the need for coordinated external operations implementing diplomatic, security and development tools. They also stress the need for coordination with other organisations in order to focus on areas where the Union can bring the greatest added value

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of the stability of the African and European neighbourhood is, increasingly, a matter of close topicality. Peace support operations, conducted under a United Nations mandate, intervene precisely in situations where external support is required to restore, build or maintain peace in those contexts where states are dissolute or markedly fragile. The Van Orden report, which I supported today with my vote in favour, recognises the need to evaluate and rationalise existing structures, avoiding too many overlaps of operations that persist in the same areas. Lack of coordination is often also linked to difficulties in the use of funding and the proper use of resources. Without prejudice to the importance of eu contributions, in particular through the African Peace Fund and African Union funding, more ambitious measures are needed. Strengthening European military cooperation could increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the European contribution to the UNITED Nations and African Union peacekeeping missions by providing better assistance with regard to training, equipment, logistical support and the establishment of rules for the engagement of troops.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.
