I abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I recognise the importance of the development of certain EU-in-house peace and crisis management missions, which have managed to save hundreds of thousands of human lives, I oppose the systematic use of the military route for crisis and conflict management, and what this leads to in terms of diversion of European funds that should be focused on the development of African countries. I understand that peace on the continent cannot depend so much on the presence of foreign troops in these countries, and on conjunctural action plans and a structural and comprehensive response based on the revision of the terms of trade, the strengthening through enhanced cooperation of productive, technological capacities and the formulation of development plans adapted to the needs and capacities of the populations of these countries.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Let us beware of interventions in the internal affairs of other countries in the name of human rights and an alleged right of interference. It is enough to mention the Libyan case to know what the negative consequences of a so-called "humanitarian" operation can have for a region like the Sahel, which is now completely destabilized. That is why I voted against Mr Van Orden's report. The European Union, like the United States, is not meant to be the world's policeman. But the rapporteur gives the impression that this is the role that the Union must play in the years to come. As in the Preda report we voted on today, this report by the Committee on Development goes too far in imposing a framework of universal values on developing countries. In the name of what ideology can we claim to embody universal values? Europe better sweep a little in front of its own door.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on peace-support operations on the EU's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. The importance of Union instruments in the field of security and in the missions and operations of the common security and defence policy is underlined. Strengthening European military cooperation would improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the European contribution to United Nations peacekeeping missions. In addition, a comprehensive approach by the Union, which is the main instrument for mobilizing the Union's full potential for action in the context of peacekeeping operations and the stabilisation process, as well as for activating different ways of supporting the development of African Union countries, must be supported.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Van Orden report, while sustainable as a whole, contains some critical issues which led me to abstain.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which, if it can claim great technical mastery on the part of the British General Van Orden, which can be welcomed, falls into the trap of building a European defence which, as we know, would only become the lieutenant of NATO. I would like to remind you that the army remains one of the regal powers that defines the very notion of the state; the real objective of the European Union's operations was only a marketing promotion campaign to the detriment of European nations and in particular France, which, it should be noted, supported with its African allies almost 90% of the investment in equipment and man on the ground for the Serval and Sangaris operations.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Peace-support operations (SPGs) are a way to respond to crises, usually in support of an internationally recognized organization such as the United Nations or the African Union (AU), endowed with a United Nations mandate, and aimed at preventing armed conflict, restoring or maintaining or consolidating peace, ensuring respect for peace agreements and dealing with emergencies.  As this report points out, which I have supported, the security landscape has changed radically over the past decade, particularly in Africa, with the emergence of terrorist and insurgent groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahara-Sahel region, and with peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations now the norm and not the exception in many areas. The report urges the EU to continue to support the SPGs and stresses the need for neither the EU nor its Member States to act in isolation, but to take into account the contributions of other international actors, to improve their coordination with them, to speed up their response and to focus their efforts on certain priority countries.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on peace support operations and on the EU's relations with the United Nations and the African Union. Peace relief operations are a way of responding to the crisis, with UN mandates, usually with the support of internationally recognised organisations, and aim to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or strengthen peace, ensure the implementation of peace treaties and respond to complex emergencies and the challenges posed by failing or weak states. Stability in the neighbouring countries of Africa and Europe would have a very positive impact on all our countries. However, africa is growing in fragile states and unmanageable areas, and many people are affected by poverty, disregard for laws, corruption and violence, and perishable borders on this continent facilitate incitement to violence, security and enable criminal activities to be carried out. In its report, Parliament stresses the need for coordination of external actions using diplomatic, security and development instruments in order to restore confidence and address the problems of war, internal conflict, insecurity, vulnerability and transition. He also believes that the deployment of several UN-mandated missions, with the participation of different actors and regional organisations in the same area, is becoming an increasingly frequent phenomenon in modern peacekeeping operations. Considers, therefore, that managing these complex partnerships without duplicating activities or missions is essential for the successful conduct of operations, and therefore calls for the evaluation and rationalisation of existing structures.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report's finding that the UN is one of the main keepers of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. Over the past decade, the situation has changed dramatically, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the African Union, in which the EU must play a major role, must also be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. At the same time, I would like to stress that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report addressing european cooperation under the UN Peace Operational Initiative. This initiative comes with recommendations for the EU to improve their engagement in Africa in peace support operations. The European Union is tasked with helping Africa ensure its own security.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is technically well written by its author, whose mastery deserves to be praised, even if it is only feedback from the meagre European participation in The efforts made by France in Mali and the Central African Republic. I would like to remind you, however, that the Union is relatively weak in military matters and is intended to remain so. It does not have to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States, much less to pride itself on it. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report as while there were positive aspects in relation to supporting peacekeeping, the progressive elements failed to mitigate the worst excesses of the report, and therefore I could not support it. The report demanded that EU Member States significantly increase their military and police contributions to UN missions which is completely unacceptable. Moreover, it proposed increased cooperation between the United Nations, African Union, NATO and EU which my party would fundamentally oppose. In my view NATO is nothing more than a Cold War relic that needs to be disbanded. European countries need to increase their spending on social programmes, on job creation programmes, on education, and on healthcare. They certainly don’t need to spend more money on weapons of mass destruction. Sinn Féin is fully committed to Irish neutrality and firmly opposes the erosion of Irish neutrality by consecutive governments. We will continue to resist the militarisation of the European Union and any attempts by Irish governments to join military alliances.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the most important area of freedom, democracy and peace in the world. Most developing countries see Europe as a model and a guide. That is why, in addition to the trade and diplomatic relations we have with them, we have a moral duty to help them. Today, unfortunately, ungoverned spaces are spreading, both in the so-called 'failed states' and in large areas of Africa and Western Asia, which are out of the control of the state authorities. These spaces make it possible to thrive on crime, religious fundamentalism, land and sea brigandage. It is in these spaces that the weakest people are exploited, sold and killed. Reducing these spaces means improving people's lives, protecting the weakest and working for a better society. It is not a waste of resources to help the African Union. It's not just fair. Making African states fairer and safer is one way to make the European Union fairer and safer. Let us remember, as Zygmunt Bauman says, that "Locks and chains certainly cannot tame or weaken the forces that cause emigration; they can help to conceal problems with vision and mind, but not to make them disappear."

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peacekeeping Operations (PSOs) are forms of crisis response in support of an organisation such as the UN or the African Union (AU) designed to prevent armed conflict, maintain or build peace, respect peace agreements, but not least, and deal with emergencies and complex challenges. The aim of the PSO is to contribute to the creation of climates of stability, safety and long-term prosperity. Good governance, justice, respect for the rule of law, civil protection, respect for human rights and security are essential conditions for this, and the success of reconstruction, reconciliation and economic development programmes will contribute to sustainable prosperity, but at the same time lead to peace. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the stability of the European and African neighbourhood is very beneficial to all EU Member States, and the EU's cooperation with the UN and the AU is only strengthening this peace which in recent times is very fragile because of terrorist and guerrilla groups.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on peacekeeping operations – the European Union's engagement with the United Nations and the African Union. Africa is the point of greatest commitment to the difficult peace-building effort. The current action of the United Nations must be strengthened and strengthened by the contribution of all countries with technical and economic resources. The African Union must also be progressively strengthened not only to build peace but also to promote the economic cooperation and policies necessary for the future of the continent. Europe and the international community must be able to meet this challenge not only through peace missions, but above all through the necessary action to prevent conflicts.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which although dealing with EU contribution to peace support operations, also contained many calls for closer cooperation between the UN, African Union and NATO. As Ireland is not a member of NATO, and Sinn Féin is committed to defending Irish neutrality, I could not support the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I believe that we all have the responsibility to assist the UN in protecting the world. The report points out the severe situation in Africa, fighting against terrorism and insurgent groups and calls for more contribution, especially military and police contribution, of the Member States. I support the motion to establish strengthened cooperation among the EU, UN and the African Union defending peace and security. Among many of the proposed aspects of assistance, helping Africa build its own modern security system should be one of our priorities.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is concerned with multilateral cooperation between the European Union, the United Nations and the African Union, with a view to preparing operations to ensure peacekeeping in African regions. I have followed the report in the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, of which I am a member, and I have noted from the first draft some fundamental problems that have not been overcome even after my amendments to the report have been tabled. I am thinking, in particular, of the excessive reference to the use of military means in the context of operations and the use of the concept of 'imposition of peace' rather than maintaining it. These are highly at odds with my view of the support that the European Union should provide for the stability of African regions, and I have therefore voted against it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union makes support for the activities of the UN and the African Union a staple of its foreign policy. In the light of such a vast and complex phenomenon as that of the current migration crisis, it is clear that the European Union is once again called upon to play an important role in supporting several African states in order to create stable, safe and prosperous environments in the long term. There are too many open conflict situations on the African continent which contribute to further weakening the already suffering and unstable country. We therefore need a strong partnership between the EU, the African Union and the UN, a real policy of support for peace in order to respond in a global and coherent way to the needs of the area. Security and development are the combination to refer to. There can be no stabilisation of the area without cohesion and development policies. Alternative sources of funding for the 'Peace Fund in Africa' must therefore be found if we really want to help the country in the peace processes. The security of the Union and of the African continent itself can only be achieved if we are able to make Africa a political and action priority. I voted in favour of this resolution because it denounces the need for a greater effort on the part of all international actors for the peace process.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and note that the problem is often not the lack of funding, but rather the way in which funds are allocated and what other resources are used.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on peace support operations and EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union is part of the effort to promote peace on a global scale. Although the initial targeting is positive, I believe that the strategy pursued is clearly conservative, as it pushes for tighter surveillance, cooperation between military organisations and the EU, while at the same time avoiding dealing with the negative impact of the presence of Western military forces in the region. I therefore voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, agreements between the European Union, the United Nations and the African Union have brought multiple benefits to the African country. A number of crisis management activities have been carried out in Africa, peacekeeping and strengthening international security. However, much work still needs to be done and I am convinced that the EU cannot and should not back down now. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which outlines that the United Nations is the main guarantor of international peace and security with over 120 000 personnel dispatched, a vast majority of which is serving in Africa. The deteriorating international environment influences significantly the very nature and operational requirements of these missions (counter-terrorism in particular).  It reminds about the constraints, challenges and limitations related to such operations. Due to frequent multi-deployment of operations in the same theatre it calls for enhanced communication, planning, analysis of missions and coordination between regional and international actors as to achieve an effective division of labour and sufficient levels of added value.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peace Support Operations (OAP) are a form of crisis response, seeking to avoid armed conflicts, restoring, maintaining or consolidating peace, ensuring respect for peace agreements and responding to emergencies and complex challenges associated with failed or fragile states.  Unfortunately, the security situation, especially in Africa, has changed profoundly over the past decade due to the emergence of terrorist and rebel groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahel and Sahara region. The main European cooperation mechanism with the African Union (AU) is the peace facility in Africa, originally established in 2004 and providing around €1.9 billion through the European Development Fund (EDF). This report, which has received my support, highlights the need to invest more in conflict prevention, taking into account factors such as political and religious radicalisation, election-related violence, population displacement and climate change. I would like to say that support for border management should be a priority for EU intervention in Africa. Border porosity is one of the main factors in the rise of terrorism in Africa.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I consider our contribution to peacekeeping operations on the ground in Africa to be very important. In view of the crises around the world and the number of refugees heading from Africa to Europe, we should be very committed to supporting Africa to take more ownership and to use and expand its existing own capacities.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This report looks at the current level of EU contribution to peacekeeping and humanitarian operations, in particular in Africa, and the potential for further EU involvement. In particular, it calls for greater EU facilitation of Member State financial contributions to the UN and AU. Furthermore, it calls for increased use of Common Security and Defence Policy measures in these types of operations and more EU coordination of member state policies. Participation in and funding of humanitarian and peacekeeping operations should solely be the responsibility of independent states and the relevant international institutions. We are against current and further EU participation in issues related to defence and security.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the peace support operations promoted in Africa by the United Nations is to help create stable and safe environments in the long term, in which fundamental and civil rights are respected and in which the economy can be more prosperous. In order to develop effective reconciliation, reconstruction and development programmes, the European Union should cooperate more with the UN and partner organisations, sharing information, establishing synergies and offering training, equipment and resources in order to help local actors manage crises themselves. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the UN, with a view to mutual sharing of information, in the planning of activities and in the conduct of missions.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that we need to enhance our support to partner countries and organisations, through the provision of training, advice, equipment and resources, so that they can increasingly prevent or manage crises by themselves. This moves in parallel with the clear need for mutually reinforcing interventions in the areas of security and development in order to achieve this goal. We need more coordinated external actions that make use of diplomatic, security and development tools to restore confidence and tackle the challenges of wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition. It is only through this that the EU could generate real added value in the regions. The increasingly complex security environment, UN and AU missions are in need of a comprehensive approach and requires exchanges of intelligence and information and modern technologies which will help our counter—terrorism and to fight crime in conflict and post-conflict areas.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report stresses the need to implement coordinated external actions that use instruments of diplomacy, security and development to restore confidence and to meet the challenges posed by wars, internal conflicts, insecurity and the fragility of the African situation. Peacekeeping operations are increasingly characterised by military missions authorised by the United Nations, and the report is also too 'militaristic'. The European Union should focus on better conflict resolution. Let us remember that the importance of the EU-Africa partnership lies primarily in the political dialogue that must guarantee peace and security and not new military actions. We therefore recommend that there should be agreements that can enclose shared objectives for Africa's security and to ensure the protection of civilians and the end of any armed conflict. Member States are already engaged in operations in Africa. It is time for the European Union to bring real added value by supporting dialogue more. For the reasons highlighted, I am voting against the report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on peace-support operations aims to increase the EU's contribution to peace operations, and collaboration with the UN and the African Union. The report calls for Member States to significantly increase their contributions from military and police to UN missions. I am opposed to this report as, inter alia, it calls on the EU to make greater efforts to strengthen international security, and maintains that European security must be the principle of EU interventions. Moreover, the report does not recognise the negative role and destabilization that the operations of the 'good of the West' have brought to different parts of the world, and does not take into account that many of the EU's missions in recent years have not been successful in terms of long-term peace and stability of countries. For all this, I voted against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peace support operations are key to creating stable, safe and human rights-respecting environments in the long term, as prerequisites for economic development and society as a whole. In this regard, the United Nations remains an important point of reference as guarantors of international peace and security, while the EU cooperates with the African Union mainly through the African Peace Fund. Given that the crises in Africa require a coordinated approach between the various actors present and transversal with regard to the sectors involved, with my vote in favour I intend to support the European Union's action alongside the UN, NATO and the African Union for greater information sharing aimed at crisis management and the organisation of missions. I believe that this resolution takes account of an essential aspect, namely that in an increasingly complex global context we need a global approach to security and peace, which can make use not only of military instruments, but also of humanitarian, diplomatic, economic and technological means. All these elements together contribute to the knowledge of the territories and to the fight against common critical factors, primarily terrorism and crime.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the increase in the number of fragile states and ungoverned spaces, the security climate in Africa has changed dramatically in recent years. The UN remains the main guarantor of international peace and security and has the most comprehensive framework for multilateral cooperation in crisis management. There are 16 UN peacekeeping operations, with staff exceeding 120,000. 8 of these missions, but 87% of the UN peacekeeping forces are also on the African continent. I voted for a coherent long-term approach to peace and for an ongoing dialogue between the EU and the African Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Geoffrey Van Orden's report on the Involvement of the European Union in UN and African Union peacekeeping missions analyses the added value of the EU's involvement in missions related to complex and multifaceted challenges in conflict and failed areas. In the report, Mr Van Orden notes that the phenomenon of sending numerous UN-approved missions to the same areas is on the rise, each comprising different regional actors and organisations. The rapporteur believes that EU involvement should focus on areas where added value can be ensured, e.g. training, equipment supply and logistical support. According to the rapporteur, the problem is not money in itself, but rather the way it is spent and the use of other sources. While I support the EU's cooperation with international partners in order to guarantee sustainable stability and sustainable security and peace in conflict areas, what added value, if any, the EU's involvement in peacekeeping operations organised by local or UN actors remains a key issue. I believe that the report raises very important issues concerning these peacekeeping operations and the consequences of involving the EU in them, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a politician coming from Malta I am concerned with the security threats that are present in the Sub-Saharan Africa including human trafficking, arms trafficking, terrorism and poverty. Terrorist acts in this region are on the increase, with tragic outcomes. Support for the creation of good governance structures, the respect for rule of law and human rights, education, food security, the prevention and fight against radicalisation and climate change should be kept a high priority when responding to the current situation in Sub-Saharan Africa. I believe that EU-UN Cooperation is central to conflict prevention, conflict resolution and peacekeeping efforts. Furthermore, the EU-AU cooperation is crucial in addressing the issue of democratisation and political dialogue as a strategic choice for peace. For these reasons and also because I believe that stability in Africa is a priority I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the purpose of peacekeeping operations (SOPs) is a form of response to crisis situations in order to contribute to the creation of climates of greater stability, security and prosperity in the long term, I consider it vital to respect peace agreements for the stability of African and European neighbourhoods.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to take stock of the European Union's contribution to peace support operations (PSOs) in Africa in support of the United Nations and the African Union. The report stresses that the United Nations remains the main guarantor of international peace and security, with more than 120,000 people deployed to its service, and stresses the need for better collaboration and coordination between actors on the ground and international actors in order to achieve greater added value from these peace support actions. Finally, the report urges Member States to significantly increase their military and police contributions to UN peace support missions. Considering that the European Union has an international responsibility for peacekeeping and that France alone cannot carry out this mission for the whole of Europe, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report on peace support operations in Africa highlights the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. It underlines the crucial role of the United Nations in restoring, maintaining or establishing peace and the importance of the UN-EU strategic partnership in peacekeeping and crisis management. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the African Union to contribute more to peace support operations so that, in the long term, it can manage security in Africa independently.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. It has changed dramatically over the past decade, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the AU, in which the EU must play an important role, must be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of the report.  The security situation has deteriorated dramatically over the last decade as a wake-up figure has led to the emergence of new terrorist and rebel groups. N-VA has therefore welcomed the request to Member States to increase their military and police participation in UN peacekeeping missions. She would like to emphasise two things. Firstly, there must always be an eye for efficiency and the added value that Member States can offer. Secondly, in addition to a police and military contribution, attention must also be paid to civil protection. For example, due to its limited size, the Belgian army cannot always participate militarily. However, this does not mean that Belgium cannot make a valuable civil contribution.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. There are many threats of destabilization in Africa, particularly as a result of terrorist groups such as Boko Haram in Nigeria and Ansar Dine in Mali. The peace and security of this continent is a strategic objective for the Union and requires a comprehensive response from the various actors.  European engagement in this area continues to intensify. It translates into support for African capacity building and regional organizations on the continent. Thus, the African Union aims to build a force that enables Africans to take control of their own security and respond more quickly and effectively to crises such as those in Somalia, Mali or CAR for which troops have been deployed with the support of the international community.  The European Union also provides funding for 32.03% of the peacekeeping budget over the period 2015-2016, making it the largest donor to the United States with 28.5% Finally, the EU's cooperation with the United Nations on international peace and security must be promoted. This cooperation is reflected in the integration of UN perspectives from the outset of the preparations for the Union's actions.

The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text contains operational recommendations that follow missions that have experienced "low" "European" participations in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic. However, the European Union does not have to claim any military vocation, to the detriment of the Member States, to justify self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort. The aforementioned operations are 90% supported by France and its African allies in terms of investment, equipment and manpower. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on peacekeeping operations, the commitment made by the European Union to the UN and the African Union, examines the EU's participation and contribution to peacekeeping operations in conflict zones and declined countries. I have decided to support this report because I share the rapporteur's position that the European Union must contribute where its contribution will provide the greatest added value, such as training, equipment provision and logistical support.  It is essential that the EU continues to cooperate with its international partners in order to ensure long-term stability, security and peace in conflict zones, but this should under no circumstances be done by extending the competences of the European External Action Service to areas such as security and defence or the creation of a common European military contingent. Any increase in the competences of the European institutions in such areas will take away from the sovereignty of the Member States and I will vote firmly against this.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negative, because when the EU, in cooperation with other international organisations, intervenes in the internal affairs of third countries, it always creates problems greater than those that existed. In the name of democracy, he has committed crimes.

There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peace support operations are a form of crisis response and aim to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or consolidate peace, ensure respect for peace agreements and respond to emergencies and complex challenges associated with failed or fragile states. There are 16 UN peacekeeping missions underway for which more than 120 000 people have been deployed, an unprecedented number of which 87% of UN personnel on peacekeeping missions are involved in eight missions in Africa. I believe that crises in Africa require a comprehensive and coherent response, which must go beyond purely security aspects and I agree with the need for coordinated external actions using instruments in the fields of diplomacy, security and development in order to restore confidence and respond to the challenges posed by wars, internal conflicts, insecurity , fragility and transition processes.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against: these are operational recommendations following the various feedback from mission experiences that have seen "low" "European" participations in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on peace-support operations in Africa, addressing the EU's commitment to the UN and the African Union. It does so without disguising a certain neocolonialist and militaristic stance, instead of seeking to contribute to the effective guarantee of peace on the continent under the auspices of the UN. It advocates a greater contribution from Member States in military and policing terms to the region. It advocates greater collaboration between the UN, the African Union and NATO, alongside faster forms of intervention in these African countries, proposing coordination between the different countries that intervene there, putting the most experienced countries on the ground in the lead. In other words, those who already have a colonial past in the countries in question. As you would expect, the role of the EU (and NATO) in destabilising the region is hidden. A role always justified with the defense of human rights, but whose real motivations are the control of important natural resources and riches of these countries. The report advocates the financing of military operations using the European Development Fund. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's commitment to peacekeeping missions together with the United Nations and the African Union, supporting the importance of a review of how the funds used for these missions are used. The EU must necessarily focus on humanitarian interventions that can bring real added value, for example through training and logistical support.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against more honey for the weapons industry bees.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Several Member States are already involved in operations in Africa and the European Union could create real added value by further supporting these operations in the future. I therefore welcome the new APF action programme, which addresses shortcomings and places emphasis on exit strategies, increased engagement of African countries, more targeted support and better decision-making procedures. Strengthening European military cooperation would increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the European contribution to UN peacekeeping missions. In order to support peace support operations, neither the European Union nor its Member States should act in isolation, but rather take into account the contribution of international actors, better coordinate with them, respond more quickly and focus their efforts on certain priority countries, putting the Member States and African states with the most experience at the foremov.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because despite supporting peace operations, the EU spending plan is not always effective and transparent.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on peace support operations - EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union, because when the EU, in cooperation with other international organisations, intervenes in the internal affairs of third countries, it always creates problems greater than those that existed. In the name of democracy, he has committed crimes.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is tackling the issue of the European cooperation in the framework of the UN initiatives for Peace Support Operations in Africa, including as well the EU CSDP missions and operations in the region. This initiative report comes with recommendations for the EU to improve its engagement in Africa in the field of the peace support operations. Having in mind the spectacular security changes in Africa over the past decades and its consequence for the EU, the report seeks to describe how the EU can help Africa ensure its own security. I supported the report as I consider Africa a priority, including as well the aspects related to security.

The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. It has changed dramatically over the past decade, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the AU, in which the EU must play an important role, must be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the premise that peace-support operations (SPGs) are a way to respond to crises, usually in support of an internationally recognized organization, and to help create stable, safe and more prosperous long-term environments. Since its founding, the EU has been a forerunner of peace and precisely because of this fundamental objective we must actively combat any alteration of this principle.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to adopt this report on the basis that the EU’s relationship with the African Union needs to evolve to counter security and stability threats facing Africa and indirectly Europe; and to get the best effective results with the resources provided to supporting peace operations on that continent. It is in the interest of the EU that the African continent is as stable as possible and in order for the EU to cooperate with the African Union in the most effective manner there are several issues that this report addresses. We need better cooperation and a clearer division of labour with our African partners and to increase our military commitments to UN peacekeeping operations and for the EU to facilitate these.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on peacekeeping operations – the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union, because I consider the strong and shared commitment to provide an effective response to international crisis situations to be of paramount importance. The success of these operations, to be conducted necessarily under the aegis of international organisations, primarily the United Nations, and regional organisations, such as the African Union, cannot be separated from the serious involvement and constant commitment of the European Union.  Over the past decade, political instability and lack of security in many areas of the world, especially on the African continent, have led to the emergence and strengthening of numerous terrorist groups, more or less already active in Somalia, Nigeria and the Saharan-Saharan region. The fragile governments of these countries have not been able to contain the advance of these groups, which are, moreover, well armed and trained in all kinds of brutality, making civilians pay the most price.  I therefore agree with the need for external peace keeping and peace building actions aimed at restoring stability and security in the countries concerned, as well as protecting the civilian population from violence and ensuring their access to food and care.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report "Peace Support Missions - EU Cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union". As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I have long called for much stronger EU cooperation with the AU and the sustained use of European troops in peacekeeping operations on the neighbouring continent.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In order for the AU to independently monitor the security situation in Africa, both the EU and the UN should prioritise capacity-building and strengthening Africa's ownership.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my role as an MEP I support this report not only because peace is one of the founding objectives of the Union, but is a cornerstone of my country's constitutional charter and personal value. The African continent has been torn apart by wars for decades, and the instruments developed by Europe to support the work of the United Nations and the African Union succeed in achieving useful coordination of human, economic and diplomatic forces. There is no doubt that the stability of the African and European neighbourhood would be of great benefit to all our countries. The crises in Africa require a coherent global response that goes beyond just security aspects, because peace and security are prerequisites for development in the long term. The African Peace Fund is an effective instrument whose full use is essential to maintain the close involvement of the Institutions and Member States of the European Union. It is also essential for the African Union to demonstrate higher levels of efficiency and transparency in the use of funds, focusing on more structural support.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Van Orden Report on Peace Support Operations provides operational recommendations on missions in Africa. These recommendations concern the military and diplomatic means implemented, but also the exchange of information and technology, the training of personnel, logistical support, or the financial assistance that European countries provide or should provide to the operations of the United Nations and the African Union. France is particularly concerned, with operations such as Serval in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic. While only 5% of the UN peacekeeping force comes from European countries - or 5,000 out of a total of 92,000 - France trains 25,000 African troops each year and deploys more than 4,000 troops in peacekeeping operations in Africa at the same time. The French example shows that the action of the European Union is marginal: it is the Member States who decide whether or not to commit themselves financially or militarily to resolve these conflicts. In reality, the European Union's intervention in this area should not be allowed, so that it does not hinder decision-making and feed an unnecessary bureaucracy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I recognise the importance of the development of certain EU-in-house peace and crisis management missions, which have managed to save hundreds of thousands of human lives, I oppose the systematic use of the military route for crisis and conflict management, and what this leads to in terms of diversion of European funds that should be focused on the development of African countries. I understand that peace on the continent cannot depend so much on the presence of foreign troops in these countries, and on conjunctural action plans and a structural and comprehensive response based on the revision of the terms of trade, the strengthening through enhanced cooperation of productive, technological capacities and the formulation of development plans adapted to the needs and capacities of the populations of these countries.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report, as my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, believes that engaging with Africa should be a priority. This report tackles the issue of European cooperation in the framework of the UN initiatives for Peace Support Operations in Africa, including as well the EU CSDP missions and operations in the region. This initiative report comes with recommendations for the EU to improve its engagement in Africa in the field of peace support operations, which I cannot oppose.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The deployment of multiple UN-authorised missions in the same theatre of operations, with different actors and regional organisations, is increasingly the reality of modern peace operations. That is why managing these complex partnerships, while not duplicating work or missions, is essential to successful operations.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. Dramatically over the past decade, peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations in many regions have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. Crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects. The role of the AU, in which the EU must play a significant role, should also be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report refers to Peace Support Operations and the EU and UN commitment to cooperation with the African Union through a militaristic and neo-colonial perspective. It calls on the States parties to increase their contributions in order to better police the African continent and develops a neo-colonial view of Africa based on the logic that there can be no development – meaning capitalist development of course – without security, which of course we disagree with, since this is the pretext that leads to interventions in third countries. , which is why we are voting against the Report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the fact that the security landscape in Africa has changed dramatically in the last decade with the emergence of several terrorist groups throughout the region, coordinated external actions that make use of diplomatic, security and development tools are necessary to restore confidence and tackle the challenges of wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition. In this regard, I support the Peace Support Operations (PSOs) as a response to crises and designed to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or build peace, enforce peace agreements and tackle the complex emergencies and challenges posed by failing or weak states. These PSOs help to stabilise and secure regions which are experiencing conflict.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls for procedures which will increase the efficiency of peace support operations.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. It has changed dramatically over the past decade, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the AU, in which the EU must play an important role, must be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The issues concerning European cooperation in the framework of the UN initiatives for Peace Support Operations in Africa, including as well the EU CSDP missions and operations in the region are tackled in this report. Considering the security changes in Africa over the past decades, the report seeks to describe how the EU can help Africa ensure its own security. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Peace Support Operations Report – EU cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union (2015/2275(INI)) as peace support operations are one of the ways in which crisis response is provided with the support of an internationally recognised organisation such as the UN or the African Union, to prevent armed conflict, preserve or build peace, respect peace agreements and resolve emergencies in some countries. The aim of peace support activities is to contribute to creating a stable, safe and more prosperable environment in the long term. Coordinated external action is needed using diplomatic, security and development instruments.  The report welcomes the UN-AU Strategic Partnership on Peacekeeping and Crisis Management and its priorities for 2015-2018 and the importance of further efforts to prevent conflicts. Member States should not act in isolation in supporting peace support operations. One of the priorities of European action is to help manage borders whose throughput is one of the causes of the rise of terrorism.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is technically well done and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the European Union is a military dwarf and is destined to remain so. It does not have to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort (Serval and Sangaris are supported in terms of investments, equipment and men 90% by France and its African allies) and our soldiers wounded or fallen to the enemy. I voted against the text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to take stock of peace support operations, the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. In particular, the report calls for increased communication, planning and coordination between African and international actors on the ground.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur puts forward good approaches to more efficient coordination of simultaneous UN operations. However, the report repeatedly contains references to the common security and defence policy and to NATO operations. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as cooperation among the African Union, the EU and the UN is key to regional stability. It is time to reflect on how this trilateral cooperation works, and could work even better.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the European Parliament resolution on peacekeeping operations – EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union, I decided to abstain. I believe that it is, of course, true that peacekeeping operations are a form of crisis response and aim to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or build peace, promote peace agreements and address complex emergencies and problems caused by failing or weak states, and that peacekeeping operations aim to help create a stable, safe and prosperous environment for an extended period of time, but the resolution ignores reality that in the past "large" peacekeeping missions have not been successful at all in terms of long-term stability and peace. In principle, I agree with many of the demands made in the minority report that, for example, the mechanism of responsibility for protection should not be used as a pretext for military intervention, that multinational supranational companies and foreign powers immediately cease the plundering of natural resources and that damages be paid, that NATO leave the African continent, that the merging of civil and military capabilities is stopped and that EU cooperation with NATO is terminated, as well as their interventions, and that the EU is clearly committed to NATO. However, this does not change the fact that many countries on the African continent are on the brink of civil war, and the EU must not stand idly by or give up instruments to help resolve conflicts peacefully.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. It has changed dramatically over the past decade, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the AU, in which the EU must play an important role, must be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. Peacekeeping creates a positive feeling in everyone. It's a good ring. It adds a little nuance to the picture that in many of the countries where peacekeeping forces are now stationed, peace, order and stability have previously been found. Then came the export of "democracy", ending outdated state-of-the-art organization. As a side effect, chaos, misery, suffering. Finally, peacekeepers and their abuses. You could put together the building blocks that make up our world in a way that works for the great majority of people.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Nowadays the political situation and security landscape in Africa are very unstable and fragile. Sadly, Africa has the highest number of inter—state and intra—state conflicts in the world. In the last decade, the number of failed states and ungoverned spaces on the continent has increased, leaving many people affected by poverty, lawlessness, corruption and violence. Importantly, disappearing borders within the continent reduce security (statehood), provide opportunities for criminal activity particularly smuggling, fuel violence, help emergence of terrorist and insurgent groups such as al-Shabaab and Boko Haram. It could be argued that insecurity and instability in Africa directly affect Europe in terms of migrant crisis, smuggling and terrorism, etc. In order to prevent this negative trend, the EU should increase its contribution to peace support operations in Africa and expand its collaboration with the UN and the African Union in a more active manner. In particular, the EU should focus its efforts to enhance conflict prevention and to promote capacity building in support of security and development. Expressed in other words, to guarantee the protection of people and to stimulate the stabilisation process, the EU should rely on a holistic approach to peacekeeping operations. A stable and secure Africa means a stable and secure Europe.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU is conducting peace support operations (PSOs) that support the UN and the African Union to ensure international peace and security. These operations have a major humanitarian impact, but they have complex levels of management, given also the large number of actors involved in these operations. There is therefore a need to improve communication, planning, mission analysis and coordination between regional and international institutions, so that effective action can be taken. The ultimate aim is to ensure that the African Union is able to maintain a security situation in Africa, regardless of external aid. In this respect, the EU needs to focus its aid on developing Africa's skills and responsibilities. Taking into account the essential contribution of our Union, and with the hope that this will lead to the development of a fairer and safer society, I am voting in favour of the report on peacekeeping operations.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the European Union blames it on the success of support operations in Africa supported by states and in particular by France. The European Union does not have to play a military or international role, nor to phagocyte that of the States.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on peace support operations and the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. These are operational recommendations following the various feedbacks from mission experiences that have seen meagre "European" participations in Africa, such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic.  The European Union is a military larva, and is intended to remain so. It does not have to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort and our wounded or fallen soldiers. Serval and Sangaris are supported, in terms of investment, equipment and people, 90% by France and its African allies.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report is a technical evaluation of the various missions carried out by Member States in Africa and mainly by France, with the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic. Its author, British General Geoffrey Van Orden, makes operational recommendations based on these experiences. However, while the technical analysis is successful, the substance of the text tends to give importance to the European military force and to attribute to it the war effort led by the Member States. The European Union is not intended to become a military force. It must respect the sovereignty of States in this area and stop owing away from commitments to which it is foreign. I recall that 90% of the investments, men and equipment are made by France and its African allies and that it is these men who shed their blood and fall in the face of enemy fire. I am speaking out against this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on peace-support operations aims to increase the EU's contribution to peace operations, and collaboration with the UN and the African Union. The report calls for Member States to significantly increase their contributions from military and police to UN missions. I am opposed to this report as, inter alia, it calls on the EU to make greater efforts to strengthen international security, and maintains that European security must be the principle of EU interventions. Moreover, the report does not recognise the negative role and destabilization that the operations of the 'good of the West' have brought to different parts of the world, and does not take into account that many of the EU's missions in recent years have not been successful in terms of long-term peace and stability of countries. For all this, I voted against this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the call on the Member States contained in this report to assist in the training of African armies. If, for example, the France is interested in training or financing African armies, let it do so in its competence, but there is no reason to call on the Czech Republic to do so. I agree with the statement in the report 'that permeable borders are one of the main factors in the spread of terrorism in Africa'. It is a pity that government MEPs do not understand the same in the case of Europe. I do not agree with the call for 'the inclusion of women in mission staff as well as gender counsellors'. It is regrettable if some Africans do not treat women well, but I do not think that the inclusion of gender counsellors in military missions will improve the situation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ineffixed institutional structure has led to frequent unrest and crises, and lately the security situation in Africa has deteriorated significantly. The emergence of rebel groups, mercenaries and terrorism has shaken the entire African Union, alarming UN action as an internationally recognised peace ambassador. UN peacekeeping missions and actions to prevent terrorism are increasingly becoming a common practice in many areas.  The number of fragile states and areas without organised security is on the rise, reflecting not greater population poverty, violence and corruption in the African area. As a partner to the UN, which is making efforts to reduce crisis situations, the European Union, which carries out four military operations and five civilian missions, aligned with UN missions, stands out. The missions aim to ensure long-term peace, create a safe, prosperable and stable environment that will result in adequate protection of civilians, respect for basic human rights and economic development of African Union countries.  The main mechanism of European cooperation with the African Union is the African Peace Facility established in 2004, with a budget of €1.9 billion. I supported the Report on Peace Support Operations - the EU's cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union, as strengthening institutional capacity is essential for the African Union.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopted a resolution approving the increase in the EU's contribution to long-term peace-building operations in Africa and supporting better cooperation between the EU, the UN and the African Union. The security risks in Africa are immense. The soaring number of terrorist attacks creates circumstances for counterterrorism operations to become the rule rather than the exception. This inevitably increases the risk of new flows of refugees and terrorist threats to Europe. The EU must increase its financial and military contribution to UN peacekeeping missions. In order to carry out the tasks effectively, it is important to improve coordination and cooperation between the participating countries and organisations. It is in our interest to help these countries build their own capabilities to ensure the security of their citizens.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Peace support operations as well as civil missions have long become an integral part of the European Union's policy in its relations with African countries, especially over the last decade. I therefore agree that it is precisely the connection between diplomacy and security and development efforts that are the most effective option of the relevant EU policy. It is important to note that, in view of the limitations on the participation of EU military forces (e.g. campaigns against the same terrorists), it is in principle important to cooperate comprehensively and coordinate efforts with legitimate governments in the region and the African Union in order to be able to combat these hostile elements effectively. The real strength of the European Union is not, however, manifested in peace-support operations as such, but in other conflict prevention efforts, such as exchange of experience with experts, implementation of reforms, humanitarian aid, etc. Of course, the effectiveness of action by the EU and its partners in the waters of the Horn of Africa must not be forgotten at any cost – it is hoped that the same will happen as soon as possible in the waters of the Gulf of Guinea in cooperation with the participants in the region. It is also important to note that an absolute majority of our member states are also members of NATO. Consequently, the development of EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union should also take into account, in purely military terms (in terms of technical provision), the NATO factor, without which indirect support is not really possible, does not actually allow any EU peace-support operation abroad.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Instability, civil and war conflicts in Africa in connection with terrorism also threaten the safety, health and lives of the inhabitants of other continents and, given the geographical distribution, Europe in particular. The effects are now being made not only in the form of the refugee crisis, but also in the spread of terrorism. I agree with the need to support and assist the EU and the UN in tackling these problems, but at the same time it must be said that the African Union itself must be more active and involved in solving the problems of countries on its continent. The EU spends around €1.9 billion a year on solving Africa's problems through a peace facility created in 2004 and funded by Member States. I consider it important to control the use of these funds so that they do not become subject to corruption or other illegal activity, which will exacerbate Africa's problems.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. This report discusses security cooperation between the European Union and other international organizations in Africa (the African Union and the UN). The security climate of this continent has changed drastically in recent years, including the emergence of terrorist groups in Somalia, Nigeria and throughout the Sahel and Sahara. This report stresses improved communication procedures between the UN and the EU. It also highlights the strategic role played by PSDC missions in Africa, particularly in terms of training local forces. It also reiterates the need to rebalance the EU's action towards the Sahel. For now, most of its efforts have turned to the AMISON mission in Somalia, while at the same time new threats were emerging in the Sahel. The report also highlights the tenuous link between security and development, and stresses the need to respect human rights in the event of military intervention by European troops. In the end, it contains a number of proposals that would significantly improve the handling of security crises in Africa. So I'm voting in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on peace support operations - EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Technically flawless, this report is the result of the work of British General Geoffrey Van Orden. We do not appreciate his inclination to give the European Union the merit of military operations mainly organised and financed by one or more Member States, such as the Serval and Sangaris operations organised by France. Moreover, we cannot support the establishment of a European army outside the framework of the free association of sovereign states.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on peacekeeping operations – the European Union's engagement with the United Nations and the African Union. The aim of this report is to strengthen the European Union's contribution to peace support and cooperation operations with the United Nations and the African Union. The primary purpose of these operations is to create stable and secure frameworks, to guarantee justice, good governance and to strengthen the rule of law and respect for human rights where, as in Africa, operations to restore peace and the fight against terrorism are now continuous. A commitment by the Union, together with its Member States, to increase support for these States is essential, through a comprehensive approach, including not only the activation of military or diplomatic instruments but also other factors, such as the exchange of information, modern technologies, the provision of humanitarian aid and the restoration of political dialogue.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider peace support operations (ESEs) to be a key tool for dealing with serious crises, such as armed conflict in countries with high rates of such actions. Part of the business is rehabilitation as well as ensuring peace by addressing unforeseen situations and challenges. Given the current situation, where world peace is under serious threat and especially in African countries such as Somalia and Nigeria, where there is an increased flow of terrorist groups, we as the EU should invest in such initiatives, which will contribute in a wider time to restoring and maintaining security and stability. At the same time, peace support operations are also a means of disseminating the fundamental principles and values of the Union, such as the rule of law, respect for human rights and the rule of law in those States.  I know that the EU and the UN have the appropriate means and resources to achieve the EEEs. At the same time, the UN is the main guarantor of international peace and takes multilateral initiatives to achieve global security and peace. We therefore need a holistic and organised approach in this area and I believe that this initiative is a good step in this direction.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about coordinating simultaneous UN operations and stressing the need to focus more on a long-term solution in the future. Furthermore, the causes of conflicts must be combated more intensively. However, there are some criticisms, such as.B. the very vague and widely applicable formulations in the field of future support activities. That is why I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on peace support operations, the EU's relations with the UN and the African Union, as these operations aim to prevent armed conflicts, restore, maintain or strengthen peace, respond to complex emergencies. Stability in the countries of Africa and Europe's neighbourhood would have a positive impact on all countries.  I believe that the technical and financial support provided by the EU to african Union countries is of particular importance so that they can better prevent crises themselves, the strengthening of terrorist organisations, and the growth of unmanageable territories.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Defence is an exclusive competence of states and the Union cannot therefore properly finance a military operation, "but EU funding of military actions such as peacekeeping operations with development objectives is not explicitly excluded" from the treaties. The report calls for greater interference, with "ideally" a UN mandate. "Ideally", everything contributes to greater support for the European Union's common security and defence policy and NATO operations such as Darfur or Somalia, all while pushing the African Union further to counter regional legitimacy for intervention. As for the objectives of development and conflict prevention, this does not go beyond the evocation stage. However, this is the key issue for those who pride themselves on wanting to ensure regional security. On the contrary, these inept military operations will drain the Development Assistance Fund. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is technically well done and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the European Union is not intended to be a military force per se, nor to become one. As such, the war effort is supported mainly by France, as evidenced by Operations Serval and Sangaris. So I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on Peace Support Operations as it recognises the recurring issues that limit the effectiveness of European Union operations in peacekeeping missions.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Africa is the scene of multiple conflicts. The latter are largely responsible for its economic backwardness and poverty. While this resolution insists that Africa should become more involved in peace support operations on its territory, the AU wants it as well. Unlike the OAU, which pursued a policy of non-interference, the AU applies the principle of non-indifference to atrocities and massacres committed on the continent. It clearly states that it is "seeking African solutions to African problems". It went even further: it established an African mechanism to prevent unilateral foreign intervention in African affairs. For it to do so on the ground, it must be helped to develop its capabilities. This will be the only way for her to best assume her responsibilities. The EU understands this. The usefulness of the PSDC's missions, both civilian and military, to achieve the stabilization of Africa's regions in crisis is well demonstrated. I encourage the strengthening of European military cooperation for greater EU effectiveness in UN peace missions.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The objective of the peace support operation is to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or build peace, enforce peace agreements and address complex pressing challenges and challenges arising from a crumbling or poorly functioning state. More recently, the number of failing states has increased in relation to terrorist groups operating on the African continent. Permeable borders on the African continent allow violence to spread, reduce security and provide opportunities for crime. On the basis of the new agenda for sustainable development, peacekeeping is a key objective. The European Union itself contributes the most to the UN system, in particular in the form of financial assistance for UN programmes and projects. The Union has spent around EUR 1.5 billion in recent years on mine support procedures and assistance to mine victims, making it the largest donor in the area, as anti-personnel mines have been the biggest obstacle to post-conflict reconstruction. I very much appreciate the Union's efforts and commitment to helping to strengthen the African peace and security architecture.
