However, it should not be forgotten to examine the use of earmarked funds in the light of deep-rooted corruption in Africa, and I also believe that the African Peace Facility should be linked in order to encourage the African Union to increase its own contributions to peace support operations. I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In relation to the report on Peace Support Operations – EU engagement with the UN and the African Union, I am concerned with the security threats present in sub-Saharan Africa, including human trafficking, arms trafficking, terrorism and poverty. It is of concern to note that terrorist acts in this region are on the increase, with tragic outcomes. What is transpiring in Burkina Faso, Mali, Somalia and Côte d’Ivoire are a stark reminder of this. I believe that support for the creation of good governance structures, respect for the rule of law and human rights, the prevention and fight against radicalisation, attention to matters pertaining to education, climate and food security should be kept as a high priority when responding to the current situation in sub-Saharan Africa. Such aspects contribute to the socio-economic development of the country, as well as to sustainable development. That is why I have voted in favour of the report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Foreign Affairs report commends EU peace support operations and advocates deepening cooperation with the UN and the African Union, in particular as far as their military and police contribution to UN missions is concerned. It sees peace-support operations as a form of response to the crisis, aimed at preventing armed conflict, restoring and maintaining peace, implementing peace agreements and addressing challenges and emergencies caused by failing or weak states. It notes that the security situation in Africa has changed dramatically over the past decade with the rise of terrorist and rebel groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahel region. The number of unstable states and areas without governance is increasing, leading many to poverty and outlawing conditions, corruption and violence, and easy-to-cross borders within the continent contribute to increasing violence, reducing security and creating opportunities to commit crimes.  It therefore calls on the EU, in cooperation with the UN and the African Union, to step up its efforts to strengthen international security.  I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Peace support operations (OAP) are a crisis response tool and aim to prevent armed conflict, restore or consolidate peace, ensure respect for peace agreements and respond to emergencies and challenges associated with fragile states. It is important to stress that peace and security are indispensable preconditions for development and I advocate the need for coordinated external actions using instruments in the fields of diplomacy, security and development in order to restore confidence and respond to the challenges posed by wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition processes. The changing security situation in Africa cannot go unnoticed due to the emergence of terrorist and rebel groups in Somalia, Nigeria, the Sahel and the Sahara. I support the need for coordinated external actions using mechanisms in the fields of diplomacy, security and development, with the purpose of restoring confidence and addressing the challenges posed by wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition processes, bearing in view of the view that the stability of the African and European neighbourhood would be extremely beneficial for all.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is technically good and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the EU is not a military power and does not have to be. It is therefore unacceptable for it to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort (Serval and Sangaris are supported in terms of investments, equipment and men 90% by France and its African allies) and our soldiers wounded or fallen to the enemy. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Cooperation among the African Union, the EU and the UN is key to regional stability, and we have long-standing partnerships with both organisations. In the field of security and peace support operations, these partnerships increasingly overlap and it is time to reflect on how this trilateral cooperation works, and could work even better.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, on peace support operations and the European Union's commitments to the United Nations and the African Union. In particular, the report stresses that Africa must respond quickly to crises affecting it, particularly thanks to the African force, which is on hold today. In this context, the role of the European Union is to support these African forces.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report as it is a form of response to the crisis. Peace support operations aim to create stable, safe and prosperous environments in the long term; whereas good governance, justice, greater respect for the rule of law, protection of civilians, respect for human rights and security are fundamental conditions for this. Unfortunately, the security situation in Africa has changed dramatically in recent decades. Terrorist and rebel groups have appeared and appear in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahel regions. In these places, counterterrorism operations have become part of everyday life.  The EU should take a more active and unified anti-terror economic policy to prevent the import of 'bloody' raw materials, since the main financial source of terrorism, in addition to drug and people smuggling, is the exploitation of natural resources not only in Africa. The origin of raw materials from legal sources should be shown to importers by a traceable central system.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Peace Support Operations (PSO) encompass activities of all civil and military organisations that deploy peacekeeping missions. I support this report that aims to enforce peace agreements, prevent and stop armed conflicts and restore, maintain and build peace.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Acknowledging the importance of a long-term approach towards guaranteeing peace in Africa, and driven by the adequacy of the measures proposed with this aim in the report, I have resolved to support the resolution. The report notes the need to reinforce EU involvement with Peace Support Operations in Africa following strategies effectively coordinated with those of the UN and the African Union. Not only should overlaps be avoided, but particular focus should be placed on promoting capacity building rather than substitution, with the ultimate goal of ensuring the continent’s autonomy in conflict resolution. Furthermore, accountability mechanisms regarding funding utilisation ought to be further refined.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this draft because it contains good approaches, but it tends in part towards the EU army. Other criticisms would be the future financing as well as the very vague and widely applicable formulations in the field of future support activities.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Peace-building operations must continue, as the stability of african and EU neighbourhood countries is also of the utmost importance to the EU itself. To this end, the EU must make sure that the promised contributions are actually received from Member States, that the use of EU funds is appropriate, targeted and properly monitored. It is also important, among other things, to train peacekeepers and bring to justice those who commit crimes as peacekeepers.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – Falsified so-called 'Peace Support Operations', either under the cloak of relevant UN missions or independently within the framework of the CFSP, are over time the pretext and vehicle of raw imperialist interventions and EU wars, in liaison with NATO, throughout the world. The report expresses the sharpening of the aggression of the monopolies represented by the EU and its contradictions with other imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, particularly on the African continent. It calls for strengthening the military capabilities, funding and action of such EU imperialist operations with greater economic and military involvement of its Member States, wherever it is necessary to promote the positions of its business groups. It promotes the formation and strengthening of alliances with local urban classes and their associations in Africa, such as the African Union, to counter the geopolitical influence of its competitors.  The people of the region be vigilant. They have bitter experience of EU military interventions with various pretexts, such as in Libya, Mali, the Central African Republic, Somalia, the Sahel countries and Niger, which are a permanent military bridge and form the conditions for the profitable action of monopoly groups by the wild exploitation of its resources and peoples.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at the current level of EU contribution to peacekeeping and humanitarian operations, in particular in Africa, and the potential for further EU involvement. In particular it calls for greater EU facilitation of Member State financial contributions to the UN and AU. Further, it calls for increased use of Common Security and Defence Policy measures in these types of operations and more EU coordination of Member State policies. Participation in, and funding of, humanitarian and peacekeeping operations should solely be the responsibility of independent states and the relevant international institutions. We are against current and further EU participation in issues related to defence and security.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that peace support operations are being conducted to manage crisis situations affecting countries that are members of internationally recognised organisations, given that these organisations also include the African Union, given that, in the face of a changed international context, security is even more necessary today, given that peace is one of the objectives for sustainable development , as enshrined in the 2030 Agenda, considering, in addition, that the European Union provides economic aid to the African Union and that its support complements that of other international actors, given that coordinated actions with the United Nations, the African Union and other organisations could lead to more effective results, given, finally, that greater commitment by the European Union and its Member States to conflict prevention is essential , I think I should vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The United Nations are the foundations of an international peace and security. Counter-terrorism operations dispatch more than 120 000 people serving in Africa. If we are to bring ourselves closer to peace and security in the world and the EU, a better coordination, collaboration and communication is to be developed between all Members State, the UN and the African Union. I take the chance to vote in favour of EU engagement to the UN and AU in order to build a stronger European community, where we could exchange intelligence, information, technologies and training and continue the fight against terrorism and injustice.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, which reminds us that the African Peace Facility (with a 25 000 strong African Standby Force) is the EU’s primary mechanism for cooperation with Africa, currently placing emphasis on exit strategies and increased burden-sharing with African countries, targeted support and improved decision-making procedures. EU contributions to UN and AU operations may include exchange of intelligence, information, technologies, critical enablers, training or logistical support, and development of rules of engagement in peace preservation and crisis management. The report states that the EU and UN should significantly focus its support on capacity—building and strengthening African ownership in order for the AU to independently supervise the security situation in Africa.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The UN is currently conducting nine peacekeeping operations in Africa, and peace support operations are an important response to crisis and war situations and can contribute in the long term to the eventual end of years of wars and conflicts. Peace is a guarantor of security all over the world. The key to the success of peacekeeping operations in this deteriorating international environment that significantly affects the natural and operational needs of a particular operation is to approach each crisis separately and offer a comprehensive response.  EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union in peace support operations is crucial. This cooperation can be achieved through the exchange of resources, information, technologies, training programmes and logistical support. The EU also has its own instruments at its disposal through a common foreign and security policy that can intervene and contribute to peacekeeping in crisis countries. Africa is a crisis hotbed that has never been extinguished, conflicts on the African continent involve hundreds of different interest and extremist groups of people who are difficult to reconcile, and who tailor the fates of ordinary people whose lives are at stake.  Development and progress have been halted in Africa. The obstacle to Africa's future is crises and wars, peacemaking is a necessary precondition. I therefore supported this resolution, which will involve the EU more strongly in cooperation with the UN and the AU in establishing and preserving peace.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is technically good and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the EU is not a military power and does not have to be. It is therefore unacceptable for it to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort (Serval and Sangaris are supported in terms of investments, equipment and men 90% by France and its African allies) and our soldiers wounded or fallen to the enemy. I am voting against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report which provides recommendations to improve EU activity in the field of peacekeeping operations in Africa, as part of UN initiatives in cooperation with regional organisations. Bearing in mind the important changes in the area of security in Africa and its consequences for the EU, the report tries to give a number of guidance to the EU on how to help Africa ensure its security. There have been many contributions from our group to improving the report. In particular, the inclusion of the reference to the necessary transparency of the Peace Fund in Africa and the need to focus on structural reforms rather than the financing of African forces, which is one of the main limitations of the fund as it is managed today. We have stressed the importance of security in the Sahel-Sahara region and we have called for alternative sources of funding to be found to the European Development Fund, which should, in fact, concern development. Indeed, we have also included a strong reference to the link that exists between security and development, recalling the Bêkou Fund for Central Africa, which is a clear example of how the Union can promote a global approach to peace, security and development.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Peace support operations are one of the ways in which crisis response is provided with the support of an internationally recognised organisation such as the UN or the African Union, under a UN mandate, with a view to preventing armed conflict, reestablishing, preserving or building peace, respecting peace agreements and addressing complex emergencies and challenges that arise in failing or weak countries, as the stability of the African and European neighbourhoods would significantly contribute to all countries.    The aim of the peace support operation is to contribute to creating a long-term stable, safe and more prosperous environment, as good governance, justice, strengthening the rule of law, protecting civilians, respecting human rights and security are the basic preconditions for meeting this goal, with successful reconciliation, reconstruction and economic development programmes contributing to achieving self-sustaining peace and prosperity. I support the peace support operation in cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union as the security situation in Africa has changed drastically in the last decade, given the emergence of terrorist and rebel groups in Somalia, Nigeria and countries in the Sahel and Sahara regions, and peacekeeping and counterterrorism operations have become the norm, not the exception in many areas. There are more and more unstable states and areas without organised government, causing many to be exposed to poverty, lawless, corruption and violence.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report addresses the issue of peace-support operations in Africa and the EU's commitment to the UN and the African Union. It deals with these peace operations from a neo-colonialist and militaristic perspective and not with a view to contributing to the effective guarantee of peace on the continent over the auspices of the UN and respect for the sovereignty of African states. It advocates a greater military and policing contribution of Member States to the region. It advocates greater collaboration between the UN, the EU and NATO and faster forms of intervention in these African countries, proposing the leadership of the coordination of the intervening countries in a neo-colonialist vision. This report hides the role of EU Member States in destabilising the region, as well as the growing influence of NATO. Interventions that are almost always justified with the defence of human rights, but which always have as their main objective the geostrategic control and important natural resources and wealth of these countries.  We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has invested around €1.5 billion in Africa over the past two decades to support mine demining and assistance, making it the largest donor in this area. I supported Mp Van Orden's report with a view to increasing the focus on political, humanitarian and development-political efforts to support civilian peacekeeping operations and support military actors.  In particular, the report expresses concern about the high number of cases of sexual exploitation and forced prostitution of women, child prostitution and child trafficking. It calls for respect for human rights, the avoidance of all forms of violence, and reiterates that human rights must be the centre of any initiative implemented under peace support operations.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad to see that this motion reiterates the importance of cooperation between the European Union, African Union, and the United Nations  – an essential tri—partnership for tackling the many trends which have emerged in the past decade. One very concerning trend is the rise of terrorist and insurgent groups in Somalia, Nigeria, and the Sahel—Sahara region, which has come to threaten the stability and sovereignty of surrounding states. They have taken advantage of porous borders and ungoverned areas to expand their control, making the importance of investment in conflict prevention and Peace Support Operations (PSOs) vital to building African capabilities and accomplishing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Along these lines, I believe we must continue to stress the importance of efficient and coordinated responses between the three international organisations, utilising the full potential of all resources – rather than increased funding as a solution – to effectively carry out any and all operations. I support this motion and look forward to seeing more strides made in this direction.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the involvement of the European Union, and in particular its Member States, in peacekeeping operations in Africa. This continent is our neighbor and our fate is related to its development. If we support crisis management in Africa, the level of migration of victims of these crises to Europe will logically also decrease. Let us therefore work with the UN, the African Union, but also NATO to address these problems.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The United Nations (UN) remains one of the main guarantors of international peace and security, with 120,000 officers deployed worldwide, the vast majority of whom are stationed in Africa. I voted in favour of this report, which recalls the importance of the UN-European Union strategic partnership in the field of peacekeeping and crisis management, with the Union and its 28 Member States contributing 37% to the financing of these operations. But it is clear that continued support from international forces on the African continent is not desirable and that is why we support the establishment in 2016 of the 25,000 members of the African Forces on hold. In the international context of counter-terrorism or the management of the migration crisis, EU-Africa cooperation in information exchange, training or logistical support, or capacity building are priority issues.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at the current level of EU contribution to peacekeeping and humanitarian operations, in particular in Africa, and the potential for further EU involvement. In particular it calls for greater EU facilitation of Member State financial contributions to the UN and AU. Further, it calls for increased use of Common Security and Defence Policy measures in these types of operations and more EU coordination of Member State policies. Participation in, and funding of, humanitarian and peacekeeping operations should solely be the responsibility of independent states and the relevant international institutions. We are against current and further EU participation in issues related to defence and security.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, MEPs welcomed the European Union's special contribution to the African continent, which is plagued by multiple regional conflicts and diverse origins. Within the Mauritanian, Libya, South Sudan triangle, not one region is spared, not one population is truly safe. The European Union has a special mission in these conflicting regions, between a shared history, the will to intervene without interference and with respect for territorial sovereignty.  1.5 billion people around the world live in conflict-affected areas, i.e. the urgency of the situation and the need to act for peace and security, both of which are prerequisites for development in the world. In voting for this resolution, MEPs sent a strong signal in support of these countries that are suffering, where many scourges are concentrated: poverty, corruption, ethnic conflicts, human rights violations, the list goes on... Boko Haram, AQIM, MUJAO, terrorism weaves its web in Africa; it is our duty to fight it.  There is still time for the EU to find a concerted and common response. It's about our common destiny. This resolution is a guarantee of that.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which deals with the EU's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union in support of peace.  The Union and the Member States have a major role to play in their success, especially as it is essential to promote interventions in the multilateral framework offered by the United Nations, which should be the main guarantor of international peace and security and be likely to help to respond concretely to the new security challenges that have emerged in Africa. The European Union and the Member States are already making a substantial contribution to this. But these actions with the United Nations and the African Union need to be improved and the resolution stresses certain necessities in order to contribute to the same objective: the European Union must concentrate its action where it can bring real added value, ensure the legitimacy of its action and its effectiveness in supporting and coordinating with the actions of the Member States. This approach seems sensible to me and that is why I have supported it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is crucial to present coordinated strategies to respond to crises in Africa, especially in the fields of diplomacy, security and development. This obviously involves early-stage communication and enhanced consultation procedures in crisis situations of organisations such as the UN, the AU, NATO and the OSCE.  There is a need to improve the exchange of information, including on mission planning, implementation and analysis. In an increasingly complex security context, UN and AU missions need a comprehensive approach. We should invest more in conflict prevention rather than limiting ourselves to remediation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aid and efforts of the United Nations, the African Union, the United States, NATO, many European countries and the European Union to support peace in Africa are paramount. Nevertheless, I believe that it is also our duty to help Africa develop its own capabilities so that African countries can be more directly involved in peacekeeping on their continent.  Moreover, in the interests of efficiency, I consider it important to avoid the duplication of various missions approved by the United Nations. The European Union must strive to distribute tasks effectively and focus on areas where it can bring the greatest added value.   In keeping with what is said in this report, I have decided to support it.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question is a large and valuable document illustrating the eu's importance in the world. The Commission and the other institutions are working hard to reduce global poverty, while also ensuring our security. It is even more important to reconcile the efforts of the different EU institutions, especially with important structures such as the African Union.  As our recent document has shown, peaceful efforts are not always successful. This is also particularly visible in Africa. Here I see many opportunities for improvement, both for our institutions, the EU's external relations office and for the African Union, by mobilising the efforts of its members, as well as attracting activists from non-governmental organisations, strengthening cooperation between local authorities and promoting the decentralisation of governance. At the same time, I would like to stress that the mere increase in funds, which is very subtly requested in the report, will not solve the problems – we must first of all think about the quality of governance, the empowerment of citizens, local, situation-specific solutions that are of interest to specific people, communities, regions and the reallocation of available resources to support them.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The UN is the main actor in the difficult task of ensuring international peace and security, with the vast majority of its efforts concentrated in Africa. This report focuses on the EU-UN Strategic Partnership for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management and its priorities for 2015-2018.  The EU and its Member States contribute approximately 37% of the budget to UN peacekeeping programmes. In Africa, the EU contributes through the African Peace Support Programme (EPA), whose action plan pointed out the shortcomings felt and emphasized resolution strategies. The EPA is an important starting point with the potential to create a strengthened partnership between the EU and the African Union.  In addition to the military and police contribution to UN peacekeeping operations, I believe that the EU should continue to lead the operationalisation of forces in Africa and should also include the exchange of intelligence, information and technology services or training and logistical support. Because I think it is important for the EU and the UN to continue their efforts and support in african capacity building to become autonomous on their territory, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Union's commitment to peace support operations in support of internationally recognized organisations, such as the United Nations and the African Union. These peace support operations are a form of response to crisis situations.  Faced with a security climate in Africa that has worsened considerably due to the emergence of terrorist groups, coordinated external actions that implement diplomatic, security and development tools are needed.  It is crucial to remember that these operations are carried out within the framework of United Nations mandates. The success of such operations depends on perceived legitimacy and the ability to manage complex partnerships by avoiding duplication.  I therefore supported this text because it calls for an evaluation, a rationalisation of existing structures, better coordination, greater participation of Member States in UN operations, military assistance for African states and finally the strengthening of European capacity in Africa.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on in the Committee on Foreign Affairs aims to take stock of the situation regarding the European Union's peace support operations in Africa. It is worth remembering that the European Union is not only an economic reality, but also a leading player on the international stage. The EU is active on African territory under the CSDP, in support of UN and African Union operations. In line with the position of the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I recognise the importance of the development of certain EU-in-house peace and crisis management missions, which have managed to save hundreds of thousands of human lives, I oppose the systematic use of the military route for crisis and conflict management, and what this leads to in terms of diversion of European funds that should be focused on the development of African countries. I understand that peace on the continent cannot depend so much on the presence of foreign troops in these countries, and on conjunctural action plans and a structural and comprehensive response based on the revision of the terms of trade, the strengthening through enhanced cooperation of productive, technological capacities and the formulation of development plans tailored to the needs and capacities of the populations of these countries

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Van Orden report on peacekeeping operations and collaboration with the UN and the African Union. Although fervently criticised, EU peacekeeping operations in Africa are essential. But we need to learn from our mistakes and make these missions effective. I would like to stress that particular attention must be paid to the security situation in the Sahel-Sahara region, which can generate important migratory flows to the European continent. Only by providing peace on the African continent, complemented by development aid, can we talk about a chance for stability and democratisation of the African continent.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The EU's cooperation with the UN and the African Union is essential if we want to bring about and maintain peace in Africa. That is why it is necessary for the European Union to continue to help and cooperate with Africa, especially if we want Africa to do its own job in the future. Because of Denmark's defence opt-out, we refrain from supporting the concrete elements of the report that propose increased military coordination in the EU. However, we do not want to prevent the other EU countries from such a decision.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Report on Peace Support Missions - EU Cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union". In these missions, the United Nations works with local organizations and governments to ensure a more peaceful situation in Africa. Terrorism, in particular, is increasingly becoming the focus of these missions. The report therefore calls on the Member States to allocate more soldiers and resources to the peace support missions.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on peace-support operations aims to increase the EU's contribution to peace operations, and collaboration with the UN and the African Union. The report calls for Member States to significantly increase their contributions from military and police to UN missions. I am opposed to this report as, inter alia, it calls on the EU to make greater efforts to strengthen international security, and maintains that European security must be the principle of EU interventions. Moreover, the report does not recognise the negative role and destabilization that the operations of the 'good of the West' have brought to different parts of the world, and does not take into account that many of the EU's missions in recent years have not been successful in terms of long-term peace and stability of countries. For all this, I voted against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support geoffrey van Orden's report on the European Union's cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union in peace support operations. It is important that neither the Member States nor the European Union act in isolation. The deployment of numerous missions authorised by the United Nations in the same regions, sometimes with different organisations at local level, can make it difficult to achieve the objectives set. Coordinated action is therefore needed to meet the challenges posed by internal wars and conflicts. For the success of operations, it is essential to optimally manage these complex partnerships, rationalising existing structures and avoiding duplication of activities or missions. In this context, I believe that strengthening European military cooperation can increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the EU's contribution to UN peacekeeping missions.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on peace support operations (OAP) aims to prevent armed conflict, consolidate peace and address complex challenges linked to outcast states. Africa has been facing a wave of unprecedented instability over the past few years, imposed by terrorist and rebel groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahara. The emergence of fragile states and regions without a consistent form of government, which do not meet the necessary conditions to ensure the prevalence of fundamental rights and the prosperity of their population, eventually condemning it to extreme poverty, anarchy and violence, also endanger the security and stability of third states. In this context, it seems to be pressing to improve the performance of the African Union and African regional communities as a means for the success of THE And the rehabilitation of post-conflict countries. I voted positively because I believe that the EU has a relevant role to play in the PAOs, continuing to provide financial and technical support to the African Union and sub-regional organisations as a means of intensifying the fight against violence in Africa, thereby contributing to development, good governance and respect for human rights.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have always considered, along with my Socialist colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group, that Africa is a priority, including as well the aspects related to security. This report tackles the issue of the European cooperation in the framework of the UN initiatives for Peace Support Operations in Africa, including as well the EU CSDP missions and operations in the region. This initiative report comes with recommendations for the EU to improve its engagement in Africa in the field of peace support operations, which I cannot oppose. I believe that cooperation between the African Union, the European Union and the United Nations is absolutely key to regional stability, and we have longstanding partnerships with both of these organisations. I would like to see this cooperation work better and I believe this report goes some way in making that happen.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support my colleague Mr Van Orden as he examined the success of peacekeeping missions by forces from Member States in Africa. It is vital that developed nations with capacity to help stabilise African nations take a stand against terrorist organisations like Boko Haram, torturing and martyring at will – particularly persecuting Christians.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I abstained for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security situation in Africa has changed dramatically in the last decade, with terrorist and insurgent groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahel region. It can therefore be concluded that there are a number of interstate and national conflicts in Africa. Although we have recently seen increasing cooperation between the EU, the UN and the African Union (AU), particularly in peacekeeping operations, I do not consider the security situation to be sufficient in terms of a long-term stable and safe environment. I am particularly concerned that more and more people in the AU are affected by poverty, lawlessness, corruption and violence. I supported the resolution because I consider peace support operations and EU cooperation with the UN and the AU to be one possible form of response to the current crisis. I expect peace support operations to help solve the pressing problems arising from a crumbling or poorly functioning state. I am glad that the new APF action programme addresses shortcomings and places greater emphasis on exit strategies, increased engagement of African countries, more targeted support and better decision-making procedures.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The purpose of the report is to increase the European Union's contribution to peacekeeping operations and to cooperation with the UN and the African Union.  The report highlights the fact that European countries and the EU are the main source of UN contributions through the financing of programmes and projects. In total, EU Member States contribute the most to the UN peacekeeping budget - as much as 37% - as well as troops to as many as nine peacekeeping missions.  The EU Treaty prohibits expenditure from the EU budget for the purposes of military or defence operations, but does not explicitly exempt the financing of military tasks, such as peacekeeping operations with development objectives. The report also draws attention to the EU's participation in crisis management activities in Africa with a view to peacekeeping, conflict prevention and strengthening international security, in accordance with the UN Charter. This underlines the importance of greater investment in conflict prevention, with a view to political and religious radicalisation, election-related violence, climate change and population displacement. The role of the African Peace Facility is recognised as essential in the development of a trilateous partnership between the UN, the EU and the AU.  Although the report is quite good, I am sceptical about strengthening European military cooperation to increase the effectiveness and effectiveness of the European contribution to UN peacekeeping missions, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important for the European Union to act as a guarantor of stability and peace in its immediate neighbourhood. For this, in addition to diplomatic and military instruments, we should also use economic and economic cooperation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Since creating a more prosperous, secure and stable environment in the long term as well as respect for human rights, protecting civilians, strengthening the rule of law are one of the primary objectives of the peace support operation, I support this report. Unfortunately, peacekeeping and counterterrorism operations have become a rule, not an exception in many areas due to the emergence of terrorist and rebel groups in Africa over the last decade.  Four military operations and five EU civilian missions are currently under way in Africa, often operating simultaneously or in sequence with UN operations, which makes the EU's contribution to strengthening the African Peace and Security Structure evident. I also believe that one of the ways in which crisis response is provided is precisely to support peace support operations.  Furthermore, more than 120 000 active persons have been deployed in 16 UN peacekeeping operations and the UN is also the main guarantor of international peace and security. Finally, I think there is a clear need to support each other in security and development interventions.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Cooperation among the African Union, the EU and the UN is key to regional stability, and we have longstanding partnerships with both organisations. In the field of security and peace support operations, these partnerships increasingly overlap and it is time to reflect on how this trilateral cooperation works, and could work even better.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Peace support operations are one of the ways in which crisis response is provided with the support of internationally recognised Organisations under the mandate of the United Nations to prevent armed conflict. The aim of peace support operations is to contribute to creating a stable, safe and more prosperable environment, for which good governance, justice, protection of civilians, respect for human rights are basic preconditions. In the last decade, the security situation in Africa has changed drastically. Terrorist and rebel groups have emerged in Somalia, Nigeria and countries in the Sahel and Sahara regions, with peace-and-counterterrorism operations becoming the norm, not the exception. There are more and more areas without organized government, as well as unstable states. Such a situation causes poverty, lawlessness, corruption and violence. The development of a tripartum partnership between the UN, the EU and the African Union is a key factor in preventing further conflicts. I support the guidance outlined in the report, as I consider that further efforts are urgently needed to prevent conflicts in order to improve the security situation in Africa. In my view, other factors such as political or religious radicalisation, displacement and climate change should be taken into account.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on peace-support operations - EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union.  They face an unstable and dangerous environment in third countries. As far as the security situation in Africa is concerned, the rise of terrorist and rebel groups in recent years has really put security to the test. Peacekeeping operations, however, are primarily aimed at helping to create an environment for a more stable and secure life in third countries.  I support coordinated external action and better management of complex partnerships without duplication of work or missions. I therefore agree with the call for the assessment and rationalisation of existing structures.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's own-initiative report on peacekeeping missions – EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union (AU), as I believe that we also need to reflect at European level the quality of current cooperation between the EU, the UN and the AU. Cooperation with the AU, in particular, deserves a lot of attention nowadays, because without cooperation with African countries, the big problems of the present, such as migration or terrorism, cannot be satisfactorily solved. These complex problems need to be addressed comprehensively with the help of all instruments of international cooperation. The report clearly states that the focus should be on compliance with the funding rules or not duplication of activities of the participating institutions or bodies, but this does not mean that, for example, the EU representation in African countries or the offer of cooperation to individual states or the AU directly from the EU position cannot be used for common objectives.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 When the EU, in cooperation with other international organisations, intervenes in the internal affairs of third countries, it always creates problems greater than those that existed. In the name of democracy, he's committed crimes.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises that the UN is the supreme keeper of international peace and security. There are currently more than ever 16 UN peacekeeping operations involving 120,000 people. Over the past decade, the situation has changed dramatically, and in many regions peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become part of everyday life, which must be addressed. As crises in Africa require a coherent, global response that goes beyond mere security aspects, the role of the AU, in which the EU must play an important role, must be further strengthened. The report welcomes the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP for Peacekeeping and Crisis Management between the UN and the EU and its priorities for the period 2015-2018. It notes, however, that proper management of these complex partnerships is essential for the success of operations, avoiding the re-20th of missions. The report urges the EU to strive for an appropriate division of labour and to focus on the points where it is best able to provide added value. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report in the hope that it would help to raise awareness of the importance of closer coordination among many international organisations interested in or participating in international and African peace support operations outside the EU, including the UN and the African Union. Harmonising efforts and the effectiveness of governance are equally crucial for the sparing use of resources and the consistency of civilian and military objectives and instruments. Although the experience of cooperation is fundamentally good for the UN and for most African partners, the European Union, as the most important financial burdener, should not be indifferent to efficiency aspects in the future. The report can also help to promote the long-term desire for the EU to have an appropriate common military toolkit for the global achievement of common European objectives agreed within the CFSP.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Peacekeeping missions initiated by the EU, the UN and the African Union are under increasingly complex conditions and require a comprehensive approach. In addition to diplomatic and development cooperation, there is also a need for in-depth knowledge of security situations, intelligence and information exchange. Some Member States of the European Union have long been involved in peacekeeping operations on the African continent, not only through UN and AU missions, but also within the framework of the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy. These actions are intended to help stabilise countries facing crises. However, for the success of the mission, their legitimacy in the eyes of citizens is of paramount importance, and therefore, where possible, military forces should come primarily from African Union countries. It should also be emphasised that, very often, the main problem of the success of peacekeeping operations is not, as is commonly believed, a lack of funding, but its poor spending. Regular and meticulous reviews of the use of EU funds involved in peacekeeping activities in Africa are therefore needed, which will have a positive impact on reducing widespread corruption on the continent.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is an important international actor interested in maintaining world peace and combating negative phenomena that endanger international security. For this reason, Member States have frequently supported UN-led peacekeeping missions. Missions on the African continent in recent decades have aimed at strengthening state structures affected by infighting between various factions, combating the terrorist phenomenon or combating oppressive regimes. The missions were carried out in cooperation with NATO structures or through the capabilities of some member states. In recent years, the development of African Union structures has led to a partnership with this regional organisation, with a view to developing the capacity of those States to manage unfavourable situations against their security on their own.  In order to achieve these objectives, financial resources allocated under the European Development Fund (EDF) through the African Peace Fund have been used to support structural reforms in African states. Particular attention should be paid to the security situation in the Sahel-Sahara region, which can generate significant migratory flows to the European continent. Only by ensuring security on the African continent can those states develop in all respects, and the EU can support this complex process.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. 1.5 billion people worldwide live in unstable, conflict-affected regions and fragile states, and unsoverned spaces are expanding, leaving many people in poverty in lawless areas where corruption and violence proliferate.  Coordinated external actions using diplomatic, security and development tools are needed to restore confidence and address the challenges posed by wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transitions. Europe's attitude may not always be faultless, but I would like to welcome this report and I support mrs Mogherini's policy.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The security landscape in Africa has changed dramatically in the last decade, with the emergence of terrorist and insurgent groups in Somalia, Nigeria, and the Sahel—Sahara region, which is why it was essential to review our peace support operations strategies. I voted in favour of this report, which evaluates the EU’s engagement with the UN and the African Union in peace support operations, as useful step allowing us to focus this review. For one, I am convinced that we should support African countries to build their own capacities, instead of them relying on external ones. I also agree with the report’s suggestion to increase the coordination between all actors, in order to tackle the challenges more efficiently and avoid unnecessary duplication. More investment in conflict prevention is also necessary. Furthermore, while the lack of funds is not a problem, it is essential that we achieve better targeted funding. Finally, sexual abuse by UN personnel is highly unacceptable and must absolutely be halted if we want to restore confidence in our peace operations.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report by Van Orden, because the most important cooperation mechanism between the European Union and the African Union is to ensure peace on the African continent through ongoing peace operations under the auspices of the UN. The EU's role in this process is crucial, as many Member States are actively involved in peace missions. It is worth stressing that the rapporteur rightly demonstrates the need for compact and integrated access to peace in Africa, on the basis of which economic development support on this continent must be supported.  This requires a long-term political perspective that takes into account the causes of conflicts and their solutions without the need for the use of force.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Since peace support operations are one of the ways in which crisis response is provided with the support of an internationally recognised organisation such as the United Nations or the African Union, I supported a report seeking to increase the European Union's contribution to peace support operations and cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union.  I believe that the aim of peace support operations is to contribute to creating a long-term stable, safe and more prosperous environment, and the basic preconditions for meeting this goal are good governance, justice, the rule of law, the protection of civilians, respect for human rights and security.  I would point out that European countries contribute greatly to the United Nations system by providing financial support for UN programmes and projects, and call for further efforts to strengthen international security, stability and peace.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Operation on Peace Support - I supported the EU's cooperation with the UN and the African Union because the main mechanism for European cooperation with the African Union is the African Peace Facility, providing EUR 1.9 billion from the European Development Fund. The EU provides technical and financial support to the African Union and other sub-regional organisations, implements advisory and training measures within its CSDP missions, thus contributing to strengthening African crisis management capabilities. Peace is key to developing a new agenda for sustainable development by 2030, and the security situation in Africa has changed dramatically in recent decades with the rise of terrorist and insurgent groups in Somalia, Nigeria and the Sahel region. The African Union has different restrictions from the UN and can support one of the parties and intervene without a call, even if a peace agreement has not been signed, while still respecting the UN Charter. The latter still plays a major role in ensuring international peace and security, as it has the most comprehensive framework for multilateral cooperation in crisis management.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I recognise the importance of the development of certain EU-in-house peace and crisis management missions, which have managed to save hundreds of thousands of human lives, I oppose the systematic use of the military route for crisis and conflict management, and what this leads to in terms of diversion of European funds that should be focused on the development of African countries. I understand that peace on the continent cannot depend so much on the presence of foreign troops in these countries, and on conjunctural action plans and a structural and comprehensive response based on the revision of the terms of trade, the strengthening through enhanced cooperation of productive, technological capacities and the formulation of development plans tailored to the needs and capacities of the populations of these countries

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report in the final, although I do not identify with all the points. In general, however, I consider it very important that initiatives aimed at supporting the peace process in African countries be as loud as possible.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report and the EU engagement in peace operations in Africa under UN and international mandates. It is crucial that we support democratic forces and contribute to the rule of law and the establishment of democratic institutions in countries which have suffered wars. This effort should be encouraged.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These are operational recommendations following the various feedback from mission experiences that have seen "mild" "European" participations in Africa such as the Serval operations in Mali and Sangaris in the Central African Republic.  This report is technically well done and the mastery of its author, the British general Geoffrey Van Orden, is to be commended. However, the EU is a military larva and is intended to remain so. It does not have to claim a military role at the expense of the Member States to justify its incessant self-promotion campaigns on the back of our war effort (Serval and Sangaris are supported in terms of investments, equipment and men 90% by France and its African allies) and our soldiers wounded or fallen to the enemy.  I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the spread of terrorist groups in Africa, peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations have become a necessity in many regions. Today, peacekeeping operations are increasingly characterised by the deployment, in the same theatre of operations, of several UN missions, bringing together various regional actors and organisations, such as the African Union. For these actions to be successful, those partnerships must be effectively coordinated in order to avoid duplication. In this context, there is a need for an effective burden-sharing between states and organisations. Moreover, UN and African Union missions need a global approach. In addition to organising diplomatic, military and development missions, other elements, such as in-depth knowledge of the security environment and the exchange of information and technologies, are also essential. There are also EU security instruments, in particular common security and defence policy missions and operations, that could be used in these regions. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the Report on Peacekeeping Operations – the EU's collaboration with the UN and the African Union.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Peacekeeping operations are tasked with stabilising the conflict area. Based on its authority, the international community is committed to solving it. The EU, in order to be an active player in world policy, must not run away from responsibility for international security, which is particularly important in African countries. In view of the chance that these operations will achieve their objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Peace support operations are a form of response to the crisis, usually in support of an internationally recognised organisation such as the UN or the African Union, with a MANDATE from the UN, with a view to preventing armed conflict, restoring, maintaining or building peace, implementing peace agreements and addressing challenges and emergencies caused by failing or weak states. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I recognise the importance of the development of certain EU-in-house peace and crisis management missions, which have managed to save hundreds of thousands of human lives, I oppose the systematic use of the military route for crisis and conflict management, and what this leads to in terms of diversion of European funds that should be focused on the development of African countries. I understand that peace on the continent cannot depend so much on the presence of foreign troops in these countries, and on conjunctural action plans and a structural and comprehensive response based on the revision of the terms of trade, the strengthening through enhanced cooperation of productive, technological capacities and the formulation of development plans adapted to the needs and capacities of the populations of these countries.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Peace Support Operations – EU engagement with the UN and the African Union. I strongly believe that investing more in conflict prevention is crucial, taking account of factors such as political and religious radicalisation, election-related violence, population displacements and climate change. The report stresses the need for coordinated external actions that make use of diplomatic, security and development tools to restore confidence and tackle the challenges of wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition. The report equally underlines the importance of early communication and enhanced procedures for crisis consultation with the UN and the AU, as well as other organisations such as NATO and the OSCE.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report highlighting the strategic partnership in peace-support and crisis management operations and their priorities for the period 2015-2018, highlighting the contribution of the EU and its Member States to the United Nations peacekeeping budget (approximately 37%) and the need for Member States to increase their military and police contribution to United Nations peacekeeping operations. We are talking about a balanced report which comes at an important time, given the situation of instability in several African countries. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The Greens/EFA Group support many of the issues raised in the Van Orden report: the need to increase Member States’ contributions to UN peacekeeping and the clear language on the issue of sexual exploitation and abuses by personnel in peacekeeping.  However, the Greens/EFA Group opted for abstention at the final vote since because of the language we oppose paragraph 15, which states that ‘ODA needs to be redesigned under the OECD framework through peacebuilding lenses’ and that the EDF regulation ‘should be reviewed in order to allow programming design that includes peace, security and justice expenditures that have development-related motivation’. We believe that current development aid already allows good governance projects in the security sector and there are dedicated EU instruments for security sector reform and that such a change would limit the impact of development aid. The last sentence of paragraph 20 calls for a legal base for transferring military equipment to third countries financed by the EU budget. We believe that this is illegal as Article 41(2) clearly states that expenditure arising from military or defence operations (e.g. military training missions) cannot be charged to the EU budget. Paragraph 21 supports the Council position favouring EU budget financing of military equipment for third states.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: in writing. – The EU too often implies that it alone carries the responsibility for addressing global problems and that Africa is its special responsibility. This is far from the truth as the report makes clear. There must be a consistent drive towards a more coordinated response by all international actors; the UN must carry the main responsibility for external military intervention but the African Union must increasingly take the lead, supported by the most capable of our nations as well as by the United States, by NATO, and by the EU, as appropriate. Enhanced international cooperation; appropriate division of labour; and a continued emphasis on African capability and responsibility, must be our priorities. The needs of the African countries concerned and the security of our own countries should be the overall guiding principles for EU involvement. I do not support, by the way, the references to CSDP that have been made through amendments to my report in Committee. The EU should have no role in military matters.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for this report for a number of reasons. In particular, because it pays attention to the help needed in the management of borders. This is a priority for the EU's commitment to Africa. It refers to the porousness of borders, which is one of the main factors for the development of terrorism in Africa.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 On behalf of the Committee on Development, I made an opinion on the report on peace operations – EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union voted on today. The report underlines the EU's overall approach to peacekeeping operations and seeks to increase the African Union's responsibility for peacekeeping operations in Africa. As stated in the opinion of the Committee on Development, peace operations must be seen as a continuum of conflict prevention, conflict resolution, peacebuilding and post-conflict development. This is a holistic vision whose role needs to be increased. The EU's external action in stale and conflict-affected countries should focus on conflict prevention and capacity building to support security and development, thereby addressing the root causes of instability.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on "peace support operations" (PSOs) and the European Union's commitment to the United Nations and the African Union. PSOs "are a form of response to crisis situations, usually in support of internationally recognized organizations." They are theoretically aimed at conflict prevention, and of course, peace, the primary condition of development. However, there are at least some contradictions in increasing the EU's military and police contributions to strengthen the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) at the expense of financing development policies. Worse, the failure of previous "Western" interventions is not in question and other issues, however essential for security in Africa, are forgotten. Nothing, for example, about the dramatic consequences of land grabbing or the need to strengthen basic social services in Africa. The "responsibility to protect" should not be used as a pretext for military intervention in those countries where the former colonial powers have already done enough damage and continue to do so, including economically. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Contrary to the prophecies of the nineties that heralded an era of peace, security and prosperity, today we live in a more dangerous world, with more wars and more inequality and misery. These wars, often disguised with humanitarian intentions, reflect the need for rich countries to dominate large reserves of raw materials. To this do, they foment corruption. Africa is tired of interference. She is tired of corrupt governments supported by multinationals with the connivance of capitalist countries. She is tired of successive interference maneuvers in which weapons are dumped on the continent and fratrited wars are fomented to the satisfaction of the large multinationals of the industrial military complex. Africa calls for a new paradigm in international relations. A paradigm based on respect for national sovereignty, respect for self-determination, the right of each people to be able to dispose of their resources and choose their own model of development.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the draft has good approaches to coordinating simultaneous UN operations, it tends in sections towards the EU army. Criticisms are the future financing as well as the very vague and widely applicable formulations in the field of future support activities. That is why I preferred to abstain.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This report looks at the current level of the EU contribution to peacekeeping and humanitarian operations, in particular in Africa, and the potential for further EU involvement. In particular it calls for greater EU facilitation of Member State financial contributions to UN and AU contributions and calls for increased use of Common Security and Defence Policy measures. Participation in and funding of humanitarian and peacekeeping operations should solely be the responsibility of independent states and the relevant international institutions. We are against current and further EU participation in issues related to defence and security.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Peace Support Operations (PSOs) are a form of crisis response, normally in support of an internationally recognised organisation, such as the UN or the African Union (AU), with a UN mandate, and designed to prevent armed conflict, restore, maintain or build peace, enforce peace agreements and tackle the complex emergencies and challenges posed by failing or weak states. This report recognises the need to focus on capacity building rather than the short—term fix of capacity substitution. The report also calls for greater transparency and closer scrutiny of the use of funds from national governments to the UN and the EU and for improvements to be made on better coordination amongst all international contributors to avoid unnecessary duplication. I voted for the report as cooperation among the African Union, the EU and the UN is key to regional stability, and we have longstanding partnerships with both organisations. In the field of security and peace support operations, these partnerships increasingly overlap and it is time to reflect on how this trilateral cooperation works, and could work even better.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – Falsified so-called 'Peace Support Operations', either under the cloak of relevant UN missions or independently within the framework of the CFSP, are over time the pretext and vehicle of raw imperialist interventions and EU wars, in liaison with NATO, throughout the world. The report expresses the sharpening of the aggression of the monopolies represented by the EU and its contradictions with other imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, particularly on the African continent. It calls for strengthening the military capabilities, funding and action of such EU imperialist operations with greater economic and military involvement of its Member States, wherever it is necessary to promote the positions of its business groups. It promotes the formation and strengthening of alliances with local urban classes and their associations in Africa, such as the African Union, to counter the geopolitical influence of its competitors.  The people of the region be vigilant. They have bitter experience of EU military interventions with various pretexts, such as in Libya, Mali, the Central African Republic, Somalia, the Sahel countries and Niger, which are a permanent military bridge and form the conditions for the profitable action of monopoly groups by the wild exploitation of its resources and peoples.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Africa is one of the largest sources of instability in the modern world. The close proximity of this continent means that Europe must observe and actively participate in the fight against the threats that arise there. Cooperation with our African partners in training, logistical support and information exchange should be broader and the involvement of European military capabilities on the African continent greater. I fully agree with the conclusion made in this report that border management, especially efforts to ensure their tightness, should be of particular interest to us. This is the only effective way to stop the two biggest problems currently affecting the EU: international Islamic terrorism and an uncontrolled influx of migrants. However, we must not forget that the EU is only part of a global security system in which its role is not at the fore. This potential of the UN, NATO and the United States is the most important element of peacekeeping operations on the African continent. Eu Member States, with a very good political orientation in this extremely complex area, should provide important expertise, strengthen their commitment to the organisation of training for local security forces, be technical facilities and offer the highest quality military equipment and equipment. The CSDP's commitment to Africa so far shows that the EU can and should be part of an international coalition to build lasting peace on the continent.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on peace-support operations - EU cooperation with the UN and the African Union. As the report notes, the unstable security situation in Africa requires a coordinated global response that goes beyond purely security aspects. The report calls on the Member States to take coordinated external action in which diplomatic, security and development tools will be used to restore trust and address the challenges of wars, internal conflicts, insufficient security, instability and transition.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I can be very brief and say that on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development Agriculture we welcome the strong support for this report. We worked with our colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) on this and it highlights very clearly that 600 Members in this Chamber believe that we do need more action to tackle unfair trading practices in the food supply chain.  I think this sends a strong signal to the Commission and to all actors in the food supply chain about the political concerns around this issue. None of us has the ideal solution, but all of us have identified with the problems that exist, where there is an imbalance of power between those at one end of the food supply chain, and producers at the lower end. This report, as I say, gives a strong message that further action is needed, and I hope the Commission will listen and respond.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I abstained in the vote on the report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain because we have to strengthen farmers and farmers in the face of non-payment and price manipulation of large food distribution, and that is not achieved without binding measures. Price volatility and falling agricultural income pose a serious threat to the agri-food sector, but abuses of distribution chains occur within the framework of Europe's own agricultural policy, which has intensified competition between farmers through deregulation of European production and liberalisation of global trade. It is these deliberately created conditions that have permanently destabilized agricultural markets and created a structural imbalance between small agricultural producers and large distributors, which are doubly favoured by trade liberalization. Only a return to a production-focused, non-market PAC offers guarantees of a lasting solution to the price crisis in the field.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Unfair commercial practices are a stifling factor for producers and processors. In Europe, 99.1% of food and drink businesses are small and medium-sized. Unfair trading practices such as putting downward pressure on prices, late payment and imposing unconditional returns on unsold goods are destroying the sector, which is losing its attractiveness partly because of these practices. These practices create an imbalance and threaten not only people with fragile livelihoods, but also the functioning of the single internal market as a whole because they would create conditions for price lowering, which is a prerequisite for malformations and closures of local businesses. By pressuring producers, these practices also take away consumers' right to an informed choice as to whether producers receive a decent payment for their production. Measures must be proposed at national level to ensure a fair income for producers, because they are the essence and to maintain food security in the European Union. I therefore strongly believe that the European Union should put forward a proposal for binding measures protecting loyal traders and terminating or minimising unfair practices.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – I agree with the position expressed in the report and I also believe that we must take legislative action to eliminate unfair trade practices in the European Union's food supply chain. It is quite clear that wholesalers are vigorously abusing their dominant position on the market, thereby putting the capital-bordering undertakings which are at their service in an impossible position. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the engine of the European economy and small food manufacturers and retailers are the basis for European food. We cannot trust the market to self-regulate this situation, which requires national and EU regulators. The primary concern should be in the interest of European citizens, facilitating access to safe, healthy and nutritious food. Unfortunately, market self-regulation does not seem to be going in this direction, and it is our responsibility to contribute to rebalancing.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, unfair commercial practices are a serious problem and must be stopped. A Commission report of January 2016 confirms that these unfair practices can exist at all stages of the food supply chain. There is an imbalance of income and power in this chain. This imbalance disadvantages small and medium-sized enterprises, small producers. And small producers make up more than 90% of the economic structure of the European Union. They are the most vulnerable at the moment. They are being jeopardised by their ability to survive in the market precisely because there are unfair commercial practices. They are being jeopardised by the possibility of coming up with new initiatives, or of trading, or of expanding cross-border into the internal market of the European Union. Or that's not how a free market works. Therefore, European Union competition law must be aligned to combat unfair practices.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna trí vóta ar an tuarascáil seo agus is tuarascáil suimiúil é. because this deals with unfair trading practices. The word ‘unfair’ is more or less accepted as a reality and it has to be dealt with.
