It looks at the way to evaluate the situation around this practice and the most appropriate ways to give food producers and retailers adequate protection against these unfair trading practices. The report looked at issues such as the effectiveness of voluntary schemes, the supply chain initiative, private own-brand label products and the fear factor in commercial relations.  There was a big question about whether we should have a harmonised legislative approach at EU level or not. At the end of the day, the committee and the EPP decided that they would stick with a voluntary scheme, identifying unfair trading practices and addressing all challenges faced within the EU when tackling unfair trading practices. I hope the report will lead to the elimination of unfair trading practices but I’ll not hold my breath.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report harmonises national rules on unfair commercial practices in the food sector. The legislation does not type practices and is based on countermeasures put in place by the nation states. The provisions contained therefore do not harmonise downwards but look at best regulatory practices. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair trade practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 Although I am in favour of the general lines of this report, my final vote has been abstention, because I believe that it does not provide binding elements to limit the actions of large multinationals, in order to stop unfair practices in the food supply chain. It is therefore a report with good words but a difficult direct applicability.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain.  Indeed, this report attempts to defend SMEs and small producers against the unfair business practices of large food retailers that have effectively contributed to the destruction of the commercial and commercial fabric of villages and towns in France centralizing the supply of products in "de-off" superstructures or "commercial zones". The measures set out aim to arm them legally and to establish a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. Despite the fact that this report never mentions the fierce unfair competition faced by SMALL and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs, traders and craftsmen) through the reckless opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation, it remains in the interest of the economic actors and the economic model we defend.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was a very positive report which sought to address unfair trading practices (UTPs). UTPs are a particular issue in the food supply chain where there are serious imbalances between farmers and SMEs and larger actors in the food supply chain such as supermarkets and can include (but is not limited to): payment delays; exerting untoward pressure to cut prices; retroactive changes to a contract; and sudden and unjustified cancellations of contracts. Supermarkets especially abuse their power in the food supply chain by selling key products below the cost of production, and staples such as fruit and veg as well as dairy are sold as ‘loss leaders’. The report criticises the Supply Chain initiative, a voluntary stakeholder dialogue set up by the European Commission to work on the issue. Many farmers’ representatives have not joined this voluntary forum as it has been widely criticised and it lacks the mechanisms to seriously tackle the issues and have any real effect. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for a European framework to end the unfair business practices of hypermarkets that penalise farmers and small suppliers. There are rules in EU legislation to combat unfair business practices between businesses and consumers, but nothing between the different players in the agri-food chain. It is up to the policy and the law to rebalance these relations between large retailers and producers. In a context of agricultural crisis, linked to market concentration and price pressure, particularly from the retail sector, it is essential that the Commission takes responsibility and puts in place a European framework to effectively combat these unacceptable practices in order to better protect our farmers.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, with a view to putting an end to unfair commercial practices to the detriment of small and medium-sized producers and farmers, in particular when they engage in trade relations in a high-concentration market.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'I share concerns about unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, but this report puts too many powers in the hands of the Commission and the EU.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Unfair trading practices are practices that deviate greatly from good trading practice and in which business partners do not meet on an equal footing. In particular, late payments, unilateral or retroactive changes to contractual terms and conditions and the refusal of written contracts are extremely problematic for small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for more than 99% of food and beverage manufacturing companies. I therefore agree with Parliament's call on the Commission to come forward with legislative proposals against unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain in order to ensure adequate income for farmers and extensive choice for consumers.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to defend small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) against these unfair business practices by legally arming them and by establishing a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths.  Although this report is concerned with combating the destructive trade imbalances in the food supply chain (non-food) and abuses of a dominant position, this report never mentions the fierce unfair competition faced by SMEs, SMEs, traders, craftsmen and farmers (though at the centre of the rapporteur's attentions) by the reckless opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation to preserve the balance , employment, dynamism, quality, know-how and therefore the wealth and identity of our country. In the interest of the economic actors and the economic model we are defending, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This report calls for an EU regulator to tackle deemed unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. I believe that individual countries should implement their own legislation to tackle this problem.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to warn of income and power imbalances in the food supply chain, which must be dealt with urgently in order to improve the bargaining power of farmers. Faced with the concentration of purchasing power plants, a position of domination can be exerted on European producers. This text is a first warning for the EU to finally reconcile producers and consumers.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to draw attention to the problem of UTPs and, recognising the initiatives already taken at national and EU level, be it national regulatory measures or self-regulatory initiatives, to explore further options to address unfair trading practices in the internal market.  July 2014 The Commission published a communication to encourage Member States to look for ways to better protect small food producers and retailers from unfair trading practices, which are common in business relations when one of the two countries has a stronger position. Unfair trading practices are due to differences in the economic resources of trading countries and thus bargaining power in business relationships, and this practice in the food and non-food supply chain can have a negative impact on the EU economy as a whole, as companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, may lose their capacity to invest and innovate, and decide not to expand their businesses in the single market. I agree with the need for decisive and consistent action to completely eliminate unfair trading practices in the food supply chain in the European Union. The scale of this problem requires the adoption of rules at Union level to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all actors in the food supply chain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to defend small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) against the unfair business practices of retail retailers in the food supply sector. Indeed, they, being almost in a position of commercial monopoly, abuse their dominant position and use unfair business practices that distort the market, atrophy the investment capacities of the SME/SMEs and consequently affect the employment of the French. While the measures proposed by this text are likely to improve the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the food supply sector, it remains to be regretted that the reckless opening of trade borders, the main culprit for their catastrophic situation, is not in question.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this initiative report which stresses the need to eliminate unfair trade practices (limiting market access, unilateral contractual changes, etc.) in the food supply chain, in particular to improve the situation of farmers over whom these practices have serious repercussions.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair commercial practices develop when, within trade relations, one party finds itself in a strong position in relation to the other, generating imbalances in bargaining. This is extremely damaging to the EU economy because it primarily affects small and medium-sized enterprises, which are thus losing their ability to invest and innovate and not by expanding their activities in the single market. The Czesak report, which I supported today, considers it essential to define as a priority the concept of unfair commercial practices, while at the same time establishing appropriate sanctions for anyone who implements them. According to a survey launched in 2011, the food supply chain seems to be among the most affected by these behaviors and for this reason one of the first on which action should be taken. Among the measures proposed in the text is that which provides for the national authorities to be empowered to apply the rules, to initiate investigations and to deal with complaints anonymously. Only through the adoption of EU rules that ensure the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain will it really be possible to protect the European economy and SMEs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, because it introduces anti-abuse measures for producers and consumers to try to remedy a number of practices that act against small producers. This report also calls on the Commission for more cooperation and legislation at European level. PPE's amendments to the text delve into this direction, but I maintain discrepancies in form. This report reflects the need for greater cooperation between the weakest links in the food sector, and proposes lines of solution which I believe address the problem. The report was unanimously adopted in committee and our shadow rapporteur's amendments were included, so my vote is favourable.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain as well as the two amendments tabled by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development indicating that framework legislation at Union level is considered necessary to address unfair trade practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase , and that such legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair commercial practices between enterprises.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. Indeed, the ECR MP's report has the merit of wanting to defend small and medium-sized enterprises in the face of unfair competition from food and non-food distribution superstructures and their quasi-commercial monopoly. The aim is to provide SMEs with a legal arsenal that enables them to compel distribution behemoths to comply with standards of good conduct. I regret, however, that the rapporteur does not mention the unfair competition that our companies face because of the reckless opening of borders and the inability of Member States to put in place any protective regulation towards workers.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain clearly highlights some of the most important issues hindering the activity of our farmers, such as late payment and strong downward pressure on the cost of goods. I agree with this text on the concerns that are currently affecting the agri-food sector, for which I am constantly fighting, and I therefore wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. Unfair trading practices are a serious problem that is observed in many sectors of the economy. In 2016, The Commission's report on unfair business-to-business trade practices in the food supply chain confirms that such practices can occur at any stage of the food supply chain and that the problem is particularly evident in the food supply chain and has a negative impact on the weakest chains. The existence of this problem is confirmed by all actors in the food supply chain and by many national competition authorities. In its report, Parliament welcomed the Commission's actions to date to combat UTPs in order to ensure a better balanced market and overcome the current unequal situation caused by diverging national legislation and voluntary codes addressing unfair trading practices in the EU, but points out that these actions are not enough to combat UTPs.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies. In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported my colleague Czesak's report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain, which, after many months of coordination, was only ready for confirmation. We need to take the fight against unfair trading practices in the food chain to a higher level, because we see that voluntary collusion is not the way to go. Farmers and producers in the food chain are at a disadvantage vis-à-vis well-organised and concentrated trade, and the deterioration of the situation is now adding to the pressure on the purchase prices of agricultural products and the poor organisation of farmers. In such a situation, farmers are at the mercy of traders, who are also owners of the processing industry, so they often sell below the production price, only to be able to keep the business. This situation is not sustainable in the long term, so it is essential to approach the establishment of an EU-wide legislative framework as soon as possible that clearly lays down the rules of the game. The most attention should be paid to increasing competition in trade and encouraging farmers to be bringing together, so that they can more easily resist the pressures of large and concentrated trade. Only in this way will it be possible to establish appropriate conditions of competition in the markets and fair relations between farmers, suppliers and traders. Because everyone involved will benefit from this.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The food supply chain is a key sector for consumers' daily lives and for the economy as a whole. The sector employs more than 47 million people within the EU and accounts for 7% of GDP in the EU. So far, the EU has had measures that have been largely voluntary and have proved insufficient.  As many as 95 percent of stakeholders in the food supply chain have been victims of UTPs. Precisely because of the perishability of food products, the purchasers of goods very often manipulate the contracts they have with suppliers. Primary manufacturers are put before the choice of "either let your product rot or sell it for a trifle".

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report denounces the abusive practices of retail behemoths towards SMEs/TPEs. It plans to legally arm them and to build a binding code of conduct for these major retailers. While this report does not allude to the reckless opening of borders as a key cause of the difficulties faced by SMEs/TPEs that it intends to protect, it is nevertheless working in the right direction. Therefore, I voted for this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. –  I voted in favour of this report, which was a very positive report which sought to address unfair trading practices (UTPs). UTPs are a particular issue in the food supply chain where there are serious imbalances between farmers and SMEs and larger actors in the food supply chain such as supermarkets and can include (but is not limited to): payment delays; exerting untoward pressure to cut prices; retroactive changes to a contract; and sudden and unjustified cancellations of contracts. Supermarkets especially abuse their power in the food supply chain by selling key products below the cost of production, and staples such as fruit and veg as well as dairy are sold as ‘loss leaders’. The report criticises the Supply Chain initiative, a voluntary stakeholder dialogue set up by the European Commission to work on the issue. Many farmers’ representatives have not joined this voluntary forum as it has been widely criticised and it lacks the mechanisms to seriously tackle the issues and have any real effect. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small food producers and retailers are very often victims of unfair commercial practices due in particular to the asymmetry of financial resources between the parties in the bargaining process, which is an important brake on the ability of SMEs to invest, expand and innovate. While many Member States have developed measures to respond to this problem, their interventions have nevertheless developed in a disorderly and uneven manner, causing an intricate and partially ineffective regulatory framework. In order to combat this phenomenon, the EU needs to take responsibility for drawing up common rules that apply to all Member States, in particular by defining more precisely what conduct constitutes unfair commercial practices, and by identifying clear and strict penalties for those who implement them.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report attempts to defend SMEs and small producers against the unfair business practices of large food retailers that have effectively contributed to the destruction of artisanal and commercial fabric in our territories by centralizing the supply of products in outlying superstructures, called commercial zones. The measures set out aim to arm them legally and to establish a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. Although the rapporteur does not tackle head-on the fierce unfair competition faced by SMALL AndMs, SMEs, traders, craftsmen and farmers, generated by the lack of protective regulation, he has the merit of defending these economic actors, who provide sustainable jobs. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair Commercial Practices (NCP) are contrary to good faith and fairness and are unilaterally imposed by one trading partner on another, affecting good commercial conduct. NCp is a serious problem and occurs in several economic sectors, with negative effects on the entire EU economy. Today, at European level, there is no EU legislation targeting unfair business-to-business trade practices in the food supply chain. At national level, however, most Member States have approached the NCP using a variety of approaches based on the problems that have arisen. Although measures to combat unfair trade practices have evolved significantly in recent years, I consider it necessary to have framework legislation to combat the NCP at Union level, ensuring that European citizens are more transparent and have a level playing field in the common market. At the same time, I would point out that this new framework instrument must not affect the level of protection in countries with national legislation in the field of combating nCP between businesses.  I support this proposal for an EP resolution, because the aim of the report is not only to inform and analyse the problem of unfair practices, but also to identify new solutions applicable in this area for better functioning in the EU internal market.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The pressure that companies downstream of the supply chain exert on the weakest links, such as farmers and SMEs, must stop. They are not the only ones affected. The price war is causing considerable job losses in companies that are no longer able to get the fair benefit of their products. This is an unwelred prospect at a time when we are de-creating jobs. In the long term, this phenomenon will have a direct impact on the consumer who will be faced with a reduction in the diversity of products on the market. We need to ensure that every link in the supply chain has a fair income. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a European legislative framework to combat unfair trade practices.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it allows the Italian and European agri-food industry to keep the issue of unfair commercial practices on the Eu ropean Union's political agenda. The dossier takes an unequivocal and strong position against the abuses of large-scale organized distribution (Large-scale distribution). Some competition authorities have identified specific practices that transfer excessive risks to suppliers and could undermine their competitiveness.  The report also points out that the dispute settlement mechanism proposed as part of a so-called Supply Chain Initiative cannot go beyond certain limits as trade imbalances are unlikely to be adequately resolved through free bargaining between the parties.  I therefore agree with the adoption by the European Commission of a proposal for framework legislation allowing Member States to adopt, maintain or amend national legislation based on common principles, including a fair combination of voluntary and regulatory frameworks through the control of an independent public authority with investigative powers and with the power to impose dissuasive penalties.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to come forward with meaningful legislation to tackle imbalances in the food supply chain. Measures to combat Unfair Trading Practices have largely operated on a voluntary approach thus far and have been wholly ineffective. The current model of a voluntary stakeholder dialogue set up by the European Commission has done little to meaningfully address imbalances. I was therefore pleased that this week the European Parliament voted in favour of amendments which call on the Commission to bring forward legislative proposals, echoing the calls of Farming organisations for a mixed system combining regulatory and non-regulatory solutions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report highlights the urgent need to eliminate unfair trading practices which undermine many fields of our economy, especially in the food supply chain. I therefore voted in favour of the report because for the benefit of people involved in business affairs, a fair relationship between business partners should be guaranteed as soon as possible. However, I would like to remind of the market diversities among Member States so that it is challenging to draw up common legislation that fits for all. So, I prefer the more flexible model which tackles the issue via voluntary schemes together with national regulations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report calls for a clear framework in relation to the fight against unfair commercial practices. It should be considered that there is still no European list of recognised unfair commercial practices, which can only be deduced from the countermeasures put in place by the individual Member States. The report is certainly to be welcomed, as it proposes upward harmonisation, thus referring to those Member States that have achieved higher standards of protection. I fully agree with the approach as soon as it has been outlined and have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from the report submitted. The text includes a proposal that envisages solving the problem through a legislative means, i.e. new EU regulations, which I do not consider a happy decision at the moment. I am in favour of minimal or strictly necessary interventions in business in general. In this respect, I was satisfied with the text that was approved in committee. I do not want to underestimate the problems of smaller suppliers and primary products, they should certainly be addressed – their joint activities at European level, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, seem to me to be an appropriate way. They are better at setting up equivalent links between suppliers than EU directives or regulations.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that decisive and consistent measures must be taken to completely eliminate unfair commercial practices in the FOOD supply chain in the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain is a good opportunity to focus on issues concerning the private sector but affecting a large part of the European and global economy. As I believe that unfair practices followed by actors in the supply chain burden not only economic but also health-related citizens, I supported the report by voting in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the world I have in mind, farmers pull healthy and good products out of the land and traders place them on the market. This division of tasks includes fair compensation for all and a fair division of risks. At a time when, for external reasons, one of the two parts of the value chain acquires disproportionate bargaining power, the imbalances affect all other actors upstream and downstream. We are not talking about illegal behaviour, but it is appropriate to draw a line between what is right and what is wrong even in seemingly free contractual relationships that are in fact spoiled by particular dynamics. This report is a first step in this direction and I voted in favour firmly convinced that it is in the interests of producers, consumers and, through them, also of the traders themselves.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, the aim of which is to evaluate the situation and to look for the most appropriate ways of giving food producers and retailers an adequate protection against unfair trading practices (UTPs). The report also tackle such issues as an effectiveness of the voluntary scheme – Supply Chain Initiative, private own—brand labelled products and the fear factor in commercial relations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Unfair commercial practices can have negative consequences for entities involved in the food supply chain, especially between farmers and SMEs, which in turn can have an impact on the entire European economy and final consumers by limiting their choice of products and their access to new and innovative products. These practices occur most often when there are inequalities in trade relations between partners in the food supply chain resulting from disparities in bargaining power and are a real obstacle to the development and proper functioning of the internal market, disrupting its functioning. Despite the existence of voluntary self-regulatory regimes and national regulation, some problems tend to persist. I support the Czesak Report because it considers it important for the Commission to present a uniform European framework to combat PCDs throughout the food supply chain, to encourage Member States to create or recognise public services/bodies implementing control and sanctioning measures, and to focus on information to consumers on agricultural products, chain imbalances and certification systems that enable informed product choices to be made and to act accordingly.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. This report calls for the creation of a European Regulator to tackle UTPs. Many Member States currently have national regulators, and the United Kingdom is considered to have one of the best. UKIP believes that a harmonised approach would not be in the best interest of the UK, and therefore we have voted against this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Late payments, difficulties in market access, unilateral changes in contractual conditions, sales below production cost. These are some of the unfair practices that often characterise the commercial sector of the food supply chain, with increasing difficulties for farmers and less quality and information for consumers. That is why the European Parliament has asked the Commission to define as soon as possible actions aimed at ensuring greater transparency in a sector which is so strategic for the European economy and Society, especially towards the so-called large-scale distribution which often, in size and capacity of presence on the territory, ends up penalising small and medium-sized production and sales activities. , also limiting the possibilities and purchasing power of citizens. We therefore await an operational proposal from the Commission extending and strengthening the legislation already in force, in order to put quality, equal rights and support for work at the heart of European policy in this area too.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 Although I am in favour of the general lines of this report, my final vote has been abstention, because I believe that it does not provide binding elements to limit the actions of large multinationals, in order to stop unfair practices in the food supply chain. It is therefore a report with good words but a difficult direct applicability.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Delays in payments and refunds, unilateral changes to contractual conditions, transfer of costs to trading partners are practices that are causing many difficulties for operators in the food supply chain. Nor are voluntary initiatives taken at national and European level sufficient to encourage market participants to respect the principle of fair negotiations. The increasing fragmentation of internal market rules makes a coherent European framework, clearly defining common principles in the fight against unfair trade practices, urgent. I support this report, which is a first step in the construction of an environment of fair competition between Member States, which will allow fair and transparent relations between producers, suppliers and distributors. Rebalancing bargaining power across the chain will strengthen competitiveness, contributing to sustainable development and a choice of diversified quality of affordable food for all consumers.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair trade practices have negative effects on the entire EU economy. A 2011 survey shows that 96% of respondents in the food supply chain said they had already undergone at least one form of unfair trade practice. Self-regulatory systems are not enough to solve this problem. I voted for the introduction of clear sanctions for anyone who applies such practices and for the firm and consistent action to permanently eliminate this phenomenon.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of this report is to highlight the problem of UTPs and, highlighting initiatives that have already been taken at national or European level, to consider possible further opportunities or to strengthen existing initiatives to address UTPs in the European internal market. In July 2014, the European Commission issued a communication to encourage Member States to look for ways to increase the protection of small food producers and retailers against unfair trading practices, which often take place in business relationships where market forces vary. UTPs are generally defined as practices that are grossly different from good commercial conduct and are contrary to the principles of good faith and fair dealing. The report also draws attention to the so-called 'fear factor', which often causes the weaker party to take no legal action because it fears that the stronger party will terminate the commercial relationship. The report recalls that many countries have recognised the harmfulness of UTPs and have taken regulatory initiatives. However, the rules within the EU vary widely, also due to the different scale of the phenomenon. I believe that this report can bring about many positive developments in the Member States in terms of trade and market economy. With this in mind, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Putting an end to unfair commercial practices should be a priority. Particularly when we are speaking about unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers as this report those. This report, which I voted in favour of, deals with small and medium-sized producers and farmers who engage in commercial relations on a highly concentrated market. This report emphasises that all voluntary schemes in place aimed at tackling unfair trading practices such as payment delays, restricted access to market, abusive changes to contract terms, undue pressure to decrease prices and the like, are insufficient. All this means that EU proposals for an EU framework doubled by a strong enforcement mechanism, including penalties are urgently needed.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support a European framework to address unfair trading practices, which risks undermining the significant efforts being made in the UK through the Grocery Adjudicator and Grocery Code to address unfair trading practices in the UK market. This national self-regulatory scheme is much more effective than a European scheme ill-fitted to the UK market would prove to be, as the criticism of own brands in this report shows. Own brands deliver more choice and competitive pricing to consumers, and any attempt to undermine the UK’s consumer-focused market should be rejected. However I also recognise the hard work done by the rapporteur to try to make the report better and so I abstained.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this resolution is a signal that the European Parliament is giving in support of farmers. It is a positive signal for producers of food consumer goods and who are often not protected in relation to large commercial networks. It is important that the efforts of these people are properly rewarded, just as it is important for consumers to benefit from quality products at decent prices. I hope that the responsible officials of the European Commission will respond as quickly as possible to the requests made through this resolution. The resolution also serves Romanian farmers, who we already know often have difficulty selling and distributing their products on fair terms.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Czesak report sets out the European Parliament's overall position on the growing phenomenon of unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. It is calling on the European Commission to present a legislative proposal to stem the many misconduct that is increasingly harming consumers and businesses. I have given my support to this report precisely because its main objective is to safeguard farms and small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the agri-food sector, which are often forced to suffer unfair practices such as loss-making, late payments or sudden changes in contractual conditions, for the benefit of large-scale distribution alone. That is why it is necessary to establish a regulatory framework at European level as soon as possible, defining common rules and effective control mechanisms and ensuring transparent relations and fair contractual conditions between all those in the agri-food chain, in particular the weakest. Only in this way will our European consumers also be able to benefit from a wider choice of innovative and quality products, at fair and competitive prices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report discusses the thorny issue of unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. I believe that it is the duty of national and European public policy-makers to establish the most appropriate means of ensuring that food producers and distributors have adequate protection against these scourges. Moreover, in the context of a severe agricultural crisis, it is essential to combat these unacceptable practices that reduce the margins of processors and producers and reinforce the dynamics of crisis. This structural problem needs to be dealt with urgently, so I particularly supported the Commission's request to propose a European legislative framework. It is now clear that the Supply Chain initiative is not sufficient and national actions are uneven. Considering that it was appropriate to send a strong signal to the European Commission that it must act and to change European competition law, in order to take more account of the specifics of agri-food and the interests of producers, I voted for this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. These unfair business practices, contrary to the principles of good faith and loyalty, unbalance the market. Establishing an open list of these unfair trade practices and strengthening national legislation would ensure fair and transparent relations between the various players in the food supply chain.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. It is important to send a strong signal to the European Commission and the agricultural sector, which is why I voted in favour of this report. In the context of the crisis in the agricultural sector, it is essential to deepen the regulation of business practices. Producers and processors must be given genuine protection from unfair trade practices. Moreover, I would like to see trade relations take place in a context of mutual trust, not fear as is all too often the case today. Finally, I strongly supported the two amendments of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development because it is necessary to strengthen, in a coordinated way between Member States, transparency and contractualisation in trade relations in order to rebalance relations between producers and traders.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies. In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain.  I voted in favour of the proposal. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. Agriculture, the agri-food industry and the distribution sector, which account for more than 5% of Europe's value added and 7% of employment, have undergone significant structural changes that are detrimental not only to farmers and producers, but also to processors. The European Union must give itself the means to combat unfair trade practices (DPCs). In this case, my priority is to ensure that European farmers and consumers benefit from fair terms of sale and purchase and that CDPs translate into enforcement and sanction mechanisms (not on a voluntary basis). Transparency on costs throughout the chain is a good way to show where the profits are and where the abuses are.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Unfair business practices include delaying payments, restricting market access, implementing unilateral or retroactive changes under contracts, suddenly or unjustified cancellation of contracts, unfairly transferring business risk, and transferring transportation or storage costs to suppliers. Farmers and SMEs are particularly vulnerable to these practices. They are sometimes forced to sell at a loss, when price negotiations with a stronger player place them at a disadvantage.  With farmers' incomes in the EU down 13% from 2013 and the current crisis even more widespread in sectors such as dairy and pork farming, there is an urgent need to end unfair trade practices in the supply chain.  While some states, such as France, have introduced national laws to put farmers in a fairer position, there is currently no legislation at European level. This is why the situation requires an EU response beyond the voluntary actions taken by some retailers in the supply chain. We need a strong signal, it also requires European legislative initiatives.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies. In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. I voted in favour of the proposal. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of preventing unfair trading practices is extremely important and serious. The strategic importance of the food supply chain stems from the fact that it employs more than 47 million people in the EU and accounts for around 7% of gross value added. In my opinion, finding a common concept of an EU solution makes it impossible, in particular, for the broad current undershoot of the issue in national legislation to differ significantly in scope and in the way of legal processing. I therefore consider it necessary for coordination to allow freedom of choice in the means of resolution in view of the existing legislation of the Member States. I do not agree with the adoption of further EU legislation and consider it effective to address this issue at national level. That is why I abstained.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to defend small and medium-sized enterprises against unfair business practices, or abuse of a dominant position, by legally arming them and developing a relatively restrictive code of conduct for mass distribution, particularly from a food point of view. Although the text never mentions the unfair competition faced by SMALL AndPEs, SMEs, traders, craftsmen and farmers through the irresponsible opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation, it is in the interests of the economic actors concerned.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, as it pays particular attention to the range of unfair commercial practices ing within the European Union, while also highlighting good practices undertaken in the Member States to improve the fight against these practices in the form of laws or other initiatives.  A large number of countries have already taken measures that contribute to combating unfair practices. However, there is still a so-called "fear factor", for which many traders do not take legal action, afraid of harming their trading relations with partners.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report, as we agree that transparency and information in the supply chain should be increased. The existence of framework legislation at EU level is necessary to address UTPs (Tackling unfair trade practices) and to ensure that European farmers and consumers have the opportunity to benefit from a level playing field.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. The dairy industry in Wales is under constant stress from unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. For the industry to be sustainable, we need to ensure fair and transparent relations between producers and suppliers.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the Commission to submit one or more proposals to combat unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain in order to ensure transparent relations between producers, suppliers and distributors. I also express my concerns about food waste, the lower selling cost of production and the misuse of certain agricultural products - milk, fruit and vegetables - as "balance products" by large retailers. These practices can have negative consequences for entities involved in the food supply chain, especially between farmers and SMEs, which in turn can have an impact on the European economy and final consumers by limiting their choice and access to new and innovative products.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: it remains in the interest of the economic actors and the economic model that we defend to vote in favour of this text.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the European Commission published a communication asking Member States to look for ways to protect small producers and retailers in the food sector against unfair commercial practices (PCDs), which occur whenever in trade relations one party is in a stronger position than the other. It was of no use. There is a progressive loss of the bargaining power of agricultural producers and agro-industries in the face of the power of large retailers. The practice of dumping between Member States is common, influencing the setting of the price level along the value chain – from primary production to processing to the final consumer. Imbalances between Member States, with different production systems, are accentuated at different stages of development, leading to increasing deficits and increased food dependency in countries with weaker production systems. The option has been to avoid the issue of abuses by "big buyers" in the food supply chain. Do not disturb the current concentration of power in the hands of retailers and large industries, nor propose measures to sustain and reverse this situation. The European Commission merely launches communications through which it undertakes to introduce mechanisms to combat these CFDs by encouraging the adoption of voluntary codes of conduct. Nothing changes.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because late payments, limited market access and pressure to reduce prices are just some of the unfair practices, often carried out 'from farm to business', which must be brought to an end. To lose out is the weakest link in the chain, namely small agricultural producers and retailers in the food supply chain, a sector that represents the beating heart of the Italian economic fabric and which employs 47 million people in Europe. 'Unfair' actions must be clearly defined by the EU, providing for clear sanctions. It is also essential to combat the 'fear effect', which leads companies to unwillingly accept misconduct on the part of the strongest party, in fear that it will put an end to the business relationship. Since 2009, the European Parliament has adopted five resolutions and the Commission has adopted three reports on this subject. We have had enough of analysis, and now we need to take concrete action once and for all.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as action is needed to tackle UTPs in the food supply chain.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current protection of retailers and small food producers against unfair trading practices of large chains is not enough. The continued disproportionate fall in the prices of milk, pigmeat and related products is also deepening the difficulties. The unfair practices of large supermarket chains consist primarily of enforcing unfair contract terms, threatening or demanding undue discounts. Small producers can't defend themselves. They are concerned about the subsequent termination of the business relationship. The problem concerns many European countries, including Slovakia. Several Member States of the European Union have therefore taken concrete measures against unfair wholesale practices. Above all, however, their effectiveness is questionable. We still have a lot of catching up to do with that. We need to focus on what works. A greater reduction in unfair practices by large chains will give small producers opportunities to invest and maintain employment in this important sector.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report as I agree with pointing out some unfair practices in the commercial chain.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, as I agree that transparency and information in the supply chain should be increased. The existence of framework legislation at EU level is necessary to address UTPs (Tackling unfair trade practices) and to ensure that European farmers and consumers have the opportunity to benefit from a level playing field.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because significant efforts are already being made through the UK Grocery Adjudicator and Grocery Code to address unfair trading practices in the UK market and I feel that a European framework could undermine the hard work already being done under this national scheme. My colleagues and I also feel that the ‘own brands’ component is a particularly negative development because such brands offer alternative routes to market for producers, such as Marks & Spencer, whose products are popular with consumers and give them a wider variety of choice.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Czesak report states that all voluntary schemes in place (such as the Supply Chain Initiative) to tackle unfair trading practices (payment delays, restricted access to market, abusive changes to contract terms, pressure to cut prices, etc.) are insufficient and that EU proposals for an EU framework doubled by a strong enforcement mechanism, including penalties, are needed. I support legislative/regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and strong enforcement mechanism and penalties. I supported the report as I want the EU to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium—sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations on a highly concentrated market.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies. In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. I voted in favour of the proposal. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm will to end the abusive practices that occur in the food chain. Unfair practices are based on imbalance and economic dependence and mainly affect European farmers. The aim of the report is that there is a legal minimum of common protection — as already exists in some national or sub-state legislation such as Catalonia — for all European farmers and consumers to benefit from fair conditions of purchase and sale. From the European institutions we must seek measures to alleviate the devastating effects that such trade practices can have on small producers in particular.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  This report calls for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair trade practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level. Therefore, if we do not do so at EU level, we will create distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this report as we need to renew our efforts in tackling income and bargaining imbalances in the food supply chain. At the moment some farmers and small/medium businesses are operating in an unfair position compared to supermarket chains and larger enterprises and, so far, efforts to tackle these unfair practises have been ineffective. A more open and fair food supply chain would not only strengthen the position of our European farmers; it would also ensure a wide choice of products including new and innovative goods for the common European consumer.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, as it clearly identifies the problems and also specifically refers to the catastrophic situation on the dairy market, which has long since become a threat to the existence of many small and medium-sized family farms in agriculture. Measures are needed here – and I openly criticise the position of some colleagues from the PPE and S&D who, in the current debates, are pretending that they have never voted in favour of reforming the milk market. The problems today are the consequences of yesterday's reckless political action.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report aims to assess the situation and look for the most appropriate means of providing food producers and retailers with adequate protection against unfair trading practices. It is also necessary to provide an open list of unfair trade practices and to enforce national legislation, to increase the effectiveness of the voluntary scheme and, at the same time, to address clearly all the challenges associated with unfair trading practices.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as I want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle Unfair Trading Practices (UTPs) and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created – while workers and farmers suffer. Furthermore, a lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of SMEs and their strengthening within the Eu ropean market is one of my main areas of activity here in the European Parliament. That is why I support this report, because decisive and consistent action is needed to eliminate unfair commercial practices in the EU food chain once and for all. The scale of the problem requires the adoption of EU rules that ensure that markets function properly and that there is fair and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain. It is necessary to outline the precise way in which they are considered unfair practices and to define related sanctions. It is not enough for European SMEs, and in particular Italian and Sicilian SMEs, to produce in quality and to carry out consumer information actions when it is so easy to be deceived, especially in the food sector. The policy of promoting protection marks is in danger of being frustrated without an adequate system of sanctioning unfair practices.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The retail brands, in the absence of a government response, have gained a dominant position and have gradually marginalized small businesses. They have also imposed unfair trade practices on small producers.  The report presented aims to defend SMALL and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) against these unfair practices by establishing a relatively restrictive code of conduct for retail giants. That is why I voted for this report. However, it is regrettable that unfair competition for our companies as a result of open borders is not mentioned. Yet this competition, coupled with deregulation, has broken the balance and destroyed jobs.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Mr. Czesak's report on unfair trade practices in the supply chain aims to protect small producers and retailers from unfair retail practices. I fully agree with that. We see what these practices have given or still give in France: prices paid to farmers who do not cover the real costs, approaches to our towns and villages disfigured by shopping malls, closure of small shops in our city centres, lower quality of products, prices still high for consumers, and at least disproportionate to agricultural prices... On the other hand, I do not share the confidence that the report seems to have in the Commission to solve this problem, particularly through a European harmonisation of the rules. Is it not the same Commission that has been calling for years for an end to French restrictions on the installation of supermarkets, in the name of competition? Nevertheless, although this is not Parliament's first report calling for a rebalancing of the balance of power between the various players in the channel, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, because it introduces anti-abuse measures for producers and consumers to try to remedy a number of practices that act against small producers. This report also calls on the Commission for more cooperation and legislation at European level. PPE's amendments to the text delve into this direction, but I maintain discrepancies in form. This report reflects the need for greater cooperation between the weakest links in the food sector, and proposes lines of solution which I believe address the problem. The report was unanimously adopted in committee and our shadow rapporteur's amendments were included, so my vote is favourable.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the importance of this report, I voted for it in the light of the negative effects that unfair trade practices can have on the European economy. This may lead to the loss of sME investment and innovation capacity and could also affect their enlargement decision.  I also believe that strong and consistent action is needed to permanently eliminate unfair trade practices in the EU food supply chain. Given the scale of the problem, there is a need to adopt at EU level provisions to ensure the smooth functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain. Unfair commercial practices should be clearly defined and clear penalties should be provided for anyone who applies such practices. And national agencies should be responsible for implementing the rules and should be able to open own-initiative investigations and deal with anonymous complaints.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as alongside other Labour MEPS, I want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle Unfair Trading Practices (UTPs) and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created – while workers and farmers suffer. Furthermore, a lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the Commission to take legislative action against unfair supermarket trade practices that penalise farmers and small producers. There are already strict rules in EU legislation to avoid unfair business practices between businesses and consumers, but not between players in the food chain. This must change rapidly, in order to regulate the abusive practices of supermarket chains (sales below production prices, late payments, etc.), which reduce the margins of producers and farmers and no longer allow them to live decently from their work.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is essential to ensure that European competition law takes into account the specific features of agriculture and serves the welfare of producers as well as consumers, who play an important role in the supply chain. However, European competition law must create the conditions for a more efficient market that enables consumers to benefit from a wide range of quality products at competitive prices, while ensuring that primary producers have an incentive to invest and innovate without being forced out of the market by unfair trading practices.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report was taken in the right context, having clearly recognised the enormous negative impact that UTPs have on farmers, SMEs and micro-enterprises and consumers, it nevertheless approaches things strictly in the context of the creation of the single market. We have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support this report, along with the majority of my colleagues. It is obvious that many large retailers and processors abuse their position in the food supply chain with ordinary farmers. This has the unfortunate effect of making farmers price takers and it leaves them with a very weak bargaining position with retailers. It also has led to a situation whereby large retailers and processors can abuse their dominant position which, although not illegal, is very questionable. Considering the current weak agricultural markets, where farmers are receiving very low prices for their products, even below the cost of production, it is necessary that an adequate legal framework is in place so that farmers are protected and can achieve a fair price for their produce. That is why I supported the Commission bringing forward legislation on UTPs. However, I was disappointed that within the report it did not specify when the Commission should bring forward such legislation. On another note, I was happy that the report did acknowledge and support farmers joining producer organisations as one way to combat UTPs.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I had no objections to the final balanced consensus.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the text on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, which finally takes into account the concerns of Both European distribution players and producers. The European Union is often accused of being disconnected from the difficult realities that make the daily lives of European citizens. This is sometimes true, as evidenced by the agricultural crisis to which Europe is slow to respond. Our priority must be the protection of those who contribute to the economic growth of our countries and who are the foundation of this stability that is so necessary for us.   Competition law must be reformed and take into account the specificities of agri-food and the interests of producers. That is the signal we are sending to the European Commission. If we do not know how to be offensive on the international scene and defensive when our interests are at stake, such as the future of our agriculture, in the next twenty years we will become a Europe lagging behind that the rest of the world will know thanks to history textbooks but not for its ability to define and build the future.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, I support the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, as free and fair competition, balanced relations between all market participants, and enhanced and effective enforcement of sectoral legislation at European level are key to the proper functioning of the food supply chain.  Unfair commercial practices have a negative impact on small and medium-sized enterprises in particular, as they reduce their ability to invest in innovation and look for ways to expand their business. Following the Commission's recent evaluation report, a large number of countries took into account the damage caused by unfair commercial practices and took regulatory measures to address them. However, there is still room for improved.  The report makes clear recommendations to Member States to improve national laws so that laws can be implemented in practice in an adequate and effective manner. Given the national specificities and characteristics, I welcome the measures taken by the Commission to combat unfair commercial practices. These measures aim to ensure a more balanced market and address the current fragmentation within the EU.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We have to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations on a highly concentrated market.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the UTPs Report in the food supply chain (2015/2065(INI)) as this is a serious problem where this report does not address the problem, but certainly contributes to a better understanding of the difficulties encountered by small food producers and can contribute to possible solutions. First of all, these are delays in payments, limited market access, unilateral or retroactive changes to the terms of the contract, forced participation in discounts and other practices.  It is necessary to ensure that European competition law takes into account the specificities of agriculture and that this is for the benefit of producers and consumers. Conditions must be created for a more efficient market that will allow consumers to access products at competitive prices and protect primary producers. European legislation exists in terms of combating unfair practices towards consumers and in terms of competition, but there is no legislation dealing with UTPs between various operators in the food supply chain.  Small producers are the basis of production feed. It is a huge sector that employs a huge number of people, allows many families to live and enables development in rural areas. Food production is a strategic resource and cannot be fully left to market regulation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report is well-oriented as it aims to defend SMALL and medium-sized enterprises against these unfair business practices by legally arming them and by building a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. While anxious to combat destructive trade imbalances in the food supply chain (non-food) and abuses of dominance, this report never mentions the fierce unfair competition faced by SMALL and medium-sized enterprises (though at the heart of the rapporteur's attention) through the reckless opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation to preserve the balance, employment, dynamism, quality, know-how and therefore the wealth and identity of our country.  I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to put forward proposals against unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, in order to ensure a fair income for farmers and a wide choice for consumers. In the context of the current agricultural crisis, it is important that Parliament sends a strong signal to farmers. This text will help to regulate the abusive practices of supermarket chains that reduce the margins of producers and farmers.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In order to provide consumers with good quality food, support is needed for its producers. They are the ones who make the greatest contribution to working to keep products fresh and healthy. Especially the smallest manufacturers are most often suppliers of the best products, because small production allows them to take care of the smallest detail in the whole process. That is why we should support such entrepreneurship and do everything to ensure that no one exploits economic inequalities in the market to achieve their own benefits. Such unfair practices, which eliminate the smallest producers, can deprive the consumer of local, traditional products and condemn the use of 'food behemoths' products. Existing regulations have so far proved ineffective. Such practices should be precisely defined and clear tools developed to combat them effectively already at Member State level. It is necessary to enforce such regulations effectively by means of penalties or sanctions in order for the new law to take effect.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support an EP resolution calling on the European Commission to propose a framework at EU level against unfair trading practices in the food supply chain in order to ensure a fair income for farmers and a wide choice for consumers. The law must ensure a fair and transparent relationship between food producers, suppliers and distributors.
