More needs to be done to improve relations between suppliers and supermarkets, particularly with regard to reducing the so-called fear factor. Farmers and small/medium-sized enterprises are particularly vulnerable to unfair trading practices such as late payments, limited market access, sudden breach of contract, .c. To date, the performance of voluntary and self-regulatory systems has been 'limited' due to lack of adequate implementation, under-representation by farmers, conflicts of interest and conflict of dispute resolution mechanisms are not able to address the 'fear factor' of suppliers.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the problem of unfair trading practices in the food and non-food supply chains. As he is committed to SMEs, but also to small food producers and the dairy industry, I agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created, whilst workers and farmers suffer. Lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfair commercial practices between businesses in the food chain are often narrowed down to supply-customer relations of multinational retail chains. The fact remains that it is precisely these relationships that really rank the public among the unfair practices, but deceptive country of origin marking and other tricks are certainly among the unfair practices. In many EU countries, chain stores occupy an important market position, often over 50% of the food market, and it is therefore important to name unfair practices and take steps within the meaning of the proposed procedures to contribute to predictability and compliance with agreements, including risk responsibility and the elimination of unjustified requirements. It is known that some major companies only reluctantly provide written contracts to suppliers, they try to postpone the payment of invoices, respectively, they require long maturity. The aim is often to force the take-back of unsavory goods, payments for so-called listing, or other unfair practices. A typical phenomenon is the forced share of the vendor in the vendor's discount promotions. The aforementioned and other practices have been discussed for many years and it is good that the EP is addressing these issues. Only increased attention from the EU institutions and nation states can make progress in eliminating this negative phenomenon, which has brought with it the predatory emergence of large retail chains. The report suggests possible ways to improve the status quo and I therefore fully support it.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the report on unfair trading practices with the proposed amendments by Czesław Siekierski, I voted in favour of the proposal. I believe that unfair trading practices between large retail chains and small and medium-sized suppliers and farmers are generally a major problem in the EU. This conduct not only implies unfair conditions for suppliers, who are often forced to sell their products below the price and face further violations of their rights. But other consequences of these practices include poor working conditions for farmers, lower quality food supply for consumers and food waste. The proposal therefore aims to ensure fair and transparent trade relations between producers, suppliers and retail chains. This should ensure fair earnings for farmers, a wide choice of food for consumers, while reducing food waste. Currently, there is only legislation within the EU to protect consumers from unfair commercial practices. However, there is a lack of legislation at Union level ensuring protection for individual parts of the chain store. It is therefore essential that the EU adopts legislation uniformly and effectively to prevent unfair trade practices in all Member States.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies. In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. I voted in favour of the proposal. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to highlight the issue of unfair commercial practices that often apply to business relationships and are usually imposed by the party that holds the strongest position in the market. It is obvious that such practices, particularly in the food supply chain, affect not only small and medium-sized enterprises and their ability to invest and innovate, but also the entire EU economy. In view of the widespread spread of the phenomenon, particularly in the midst of an economic crisis and the different treatment enjoyed by the various Member States, it is necessary to adopt EU rules ensuring the proper functioning of trade relations and promoting alternative ways of resolving trade disputes, so as to address the 'fear factor' that leads the weakest parties not to take legal action. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – A balanced, eligible report showing a long list of manifestations of unfair commercial practices. Farmers are particularly vulnerable to multinational trade chains, as agricultural production that has already been started cannot be stopped and products are perishable. It rightly misses the absence of EU legislation aimed at combating unfair practices between different actors in the agri-food chain. It expects tough sanctions to be imposed for abuse of a dominant position within the food chain. It is essential to make up for the lack of legislation.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, as I find it important to ensure that European competition law takes into account the specificities of agriculture, ensures the well-being of producers and consumers, creates the conditions for a more efficient market that enables consumers to benefit from a wide selection of quality products at competitive prices , while ensuring that primary producers have an incentive to invest and innovate without being displaced from the market through unfair commercial practices.   A solution must be found to end the abuse of dominant traders, although it does not always meet the legal definition of this, namely unilateral modification of retrospective contracts, flat fees imposed by suppliers, "pay to stay", late payments over 60 days, arbitrary discounts that large chains charge themselves in the event of an earlier payment or payment on time , forcing suppliers to use explicitly designated third companies for the production of packaging, labels, etc. Independent national food regulators should ensure effective mechanisms to combat these unfair commercial practices.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it seeks to protect small producers and SMEs from unfair business practices in the retail sector.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. In this context of the agricultural crisis, we wanted to send a message of support to EU farmers by voting in favour of the Czesak Report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. The aim now is to put an end to anti-competitive practices between producers and processors. Indeed, I believe that it is necessary to change European competition law to combat economic imbalances and unequal negotiating positions in this sector. With this vote, I want to express my support for small producers and food retailers, who must be able to benefit from increased protection and regain a position of strength in the face of these unfair practices.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. The major retailers have practiced very aggressive trade policies and have contributed to the destruction of the commercial and commercial fabric of french villages and towns, centralizing the supply of products in "de-off" or "commercial" superstructures. These brands are all-powerful and are often the subject of complaints from small producers or retailers subjecting to unfair business practices (or abuse of dominant position) further distorting the market, atrophying the investment capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), ruining the attractiveness and dynamism of the sectors and affecting the employment of the French to finish. The report is well oriented because it intends to defend SMALL and medium-sized enterprises against these unfair business practices by legally arming them and by establishing a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. Unfortunately, this report does not mention fierce unfair competition through the reckless opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation to preserve the balance, employment, dynamism, quality, know-how and therefore the wealth and identity of France and the other Member States.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. Indeed, the report put to the vote proposes to establish a code of conduct and legal measures. It can thus protect small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), producers and traders who have been subject to unfair competition from large retailers for years. These have profoundly changed the French production method and have almost entirely granted themselves a monopoly on distribution. In the face of this, it is time to revalue the other food chains. I am in favour of this text, despite the lack of denunciation of free trade agreements that annihilate trade borders.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the Socialists demand that strong and consequential measures must be taken to eradicate once and for all these practices in the food supply chain in the EU, which stem from economic imbalances in trade relations and differences in bargaining power between the various actors in the chain.  With this report, the Eurochamber calls for the need for framework legislation at Union level to address unfair commercial practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers have the possibility of benefiting from fair conditions of sale and purchase, as voluntary systems are shown to be not sufficient. This legislation should not reduce the level of protection of countries that already have national legislation to combat unfair business trade practices.  There are Member States which are already regulating such practices at national level, so if we do not do so at EU level we will generate distortions in the internal market. As a Social Democrat I believe that the solution to this problem is regulation.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 If traders push suppliers towards lower prices, have long payment deadlines, withdraw from supply contracts without giving a reason, they usually have the right to do so, just as suppliers have the right to find other customers. If anyone thinks that traders are abusing their power, it is a matter of commercial law and its enforcement in individual Member States and the EU has no say in this.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The prevalence of UTPs is becoming a serious problem that is present in more and more economic sectors. The Commission's latest report confirmed that unfair practices can occur in all parts of the food chain. The importance of the food supply chain in the European Union is reflected in the number of employees exceeding 47 million and accounting for 7 % of gross value added.  Food supply chain operators most often use forms of UTPs, such as restricting market access, sudden and uneducated terminations of contracts, late payments, insufficiently detailed or ambiguous information on the terms of the contract, charging for fictitious services, forcible participation in action discounts and charging for better positioning of products in stores and other additional unfair fees. UTPs can be negatively reflected in individual players in the food supply chain, most often micro, small and medium-sized agricultural enterprises, which spills over into other sectors and the entire economy of the European Union.  Unfair practices can profoundly economically impact and cause investment reductions and business innovation, ultimately leading to the suspension of production, trade and processing. I supported the UTPs Report on the food supply chain. In my view, European competition law should allow consumers to access a wide range of quality products that will have competitive prices.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfair trading practices in themselves have a very negative impact on the relevant aspects of the Functioning of the European Union, including, of course, the interests of consumers and also the capacity of smaller market players to develop effectively and participate in the functioning of the market. Such practices in the area of food supply, on the other hand, pose a potential threat to the health of citizens, which is not acceptable in itself. Some 15 years ago in my country – Latvia – in almost any relatively large city it was possible to find a local or regional food sales company, most of which owned only a few or only one shop at all. While, of course, there is such a thing as free competition and different market conditions, nowadays an absolute majority of food is sold in supermarkets or in markets of different sizes. Without anyone being offended, I simply want to stress that the smallest players are always the weakest and most at risk, especially in the context of unfair trading practices. In some Member States, more or less effective rules are functioning to combat unfair trading practices, but there is no single system at Union level. I therefore join in calling on the Commission to initiate the development of such a system as soon as possible. In addition to other benefits, it could also contribute significantly to the development of the single market by actively involving smaller market players in the context in which this type of unfair practice would be combated to the best possible.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfair practices take various forms, in particular abuse of a stronger position. Due to the fear factor, they are difficult to prove and detect. They have an impact on the EU economy, harming the economy and entrepreneurship, especially small and medium-sized enterprises and, ultimately, consumers themselves. In food chains, 96% of respondents said they had been exposed to at least one form of these practices. Tackling this problem will in future require stricter regulation, which will establish transparent and fair relations between food producers, suppliers and distributors and which will contribute to strengthening the functioning of the internal market.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The food chain links three important sectors of the European economy: agriculture, the agri-food industry and the distribution sector. They alone account for a total of 7% of employment. The major structural changes in this food chain have contributed in recent decades to creating economic imbalances in individual trade relations between the various players. This is why unfair trade practices (CDPs) within this chain are the subject of particular attention from the EU.  While only about 20 Member States have measures to combat CDPs, the European Commission is still not proposing a solution. It merely encourages a flexible approach, giving pride of place to private initiatives that are solely voluntary. The report stresses that European farmers and consumers must benefit from fair terms of sale and purchase. To make the fight against CDPs more effective, the text calls for the adoption of a binding European legislative framework, which provides for an enforcement mechanism and sanctions. I support these measures and therefore vote in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This report aims to provide SMEs/SMEs with the tools to combat unfair business practices in retail. However, the problem of funds that constitutes the opening of trade borders without any economic protectionism is, as usual, completely evaded by this text.  Apart from this reservation, we support this text which is in the interest of the actors of the agricultural world.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. It is essential to ensure, through policies aimed at combating unfair practices in the food supply chain, greater protection for small producers and retailers so that all the numerous misconduct that is increasingly harming consumers and businesses is curbed. It is therefore necessary to adopt demanding EU legislation that guarantees fair and transparent rules and rules between all parties involved in the food supply chain in order to safeguard companies and SMEs in the sector.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report that regulates an issue that almost all of us have encountered in our daily lives, and these are unfair commercial practices within the food chain. These unfair practices cost suppliers €30-40 trillion a year. These undesirable practices are well known across the EU, which is why 20 Member States have adopted legislation aimed at combating these undesirable phenomena. I agree with the idea that combating these undesirable practices, which have a negative impact on the most important thing, namely consumer health, would certainly be appropriate to adapt at European level, provided that the standards of protection in the Member States are not in any way lowered. I therefore supported the report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade relations in modern globalised society are often surrounded by unfair commercial practices, where the powerful party exploits the weak and in our case small producers. This is also the case in the food market, where large companies are violating the good trading practices and good faith that must prevail in food trade, taking advantage of their dominant position. This report refers to this economic imbalance, which exists because of the greater bargaining power of stronger companies than small ones. Eu research in the field of food supply has shown that UTPs are a common occurrence, so I believe that legislative initiatives should be taken to set the right rules of law appropriate to deal with this delinquent behaviour. The negative effects on the internal economies of the Member States are also evident and decentralised and sporadic efforts at national level alone are not effective. With my vote in favour I would like to contribute to the introduction of rules at European level that ensure transparency and fairness in trade in food supply with clear penalties for offenders.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft deals with unfair trading practices in the supply chain of non-food and food. This has a major impact on our SMEs. The rapporteur wants consistent measures to be taken to completely prevent unfair trade practices in the food supply chain in the EU. I can therefore only take a positive view of this draft.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 UTPs are a serious problem that is observed in many sectors of the economy. In 2016, The Commission's report on unfair business-to-business trade practices in the food supply chain confirms that such practices can occur at any stage of the food supply chain and that the problem is particularly evident in the food supply chain and has a negative impact on the weakest chains. The existence of this problem is confirmed by all actors in the food supply chain and by many national competition authorities. In its report, Parliament welcomed the Commission's actions to date to combat UTPs in order to ensure a better balanced market and overcome the current unequal situation caused by diverging national legislation and voluntary codes addressing unfair trading practices in the EU, but points out that these actions are not enough to combat UTPs.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report denounces unfair trade practices in the food sector. He cites as an example "unfavourable negotiations with other players in the food supply chain, for example during demarcations and reductions in supermarkets" requiring producers to work at a loss. This phenomenon is also increasing because the "increasing concentration of market power on a limited number of multinational groups tends to harm small and medium-sized producers". But if the finding is correct, the proposed avenues of action are weak. The report timidly calls for "detail pricing to be as transparent as possible" so that prices in the food supply chain reflect the added value of primary producers. Finally, he welcomes the Commission's action in this area. I abstain so as not to prevent meagre progress, but I regret that maximum multipliers are not put in place to stop the looting carried out by the mass market.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report is well-oriented because it aims to defend SMEs/TPEs in the face of aggressive and even unfair commercial practices of the retail sector by legally arming them and by building a binding code of conduct for the behemoths of the sector. On the other hand, I must stress that there is never any reference to the reckless opening of trade borders. In the interest of the economic actors and the economic model we are defending, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. Combating unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain is essential to ensure transparent relations between producers, suppliers and distributors. Large retailers must respect farmers and producers. It is not fair for producers to see their agricultural products sold below the cost of production, such as milk, fruit and vegetables. In the long run, if nothing is done to combat unfair trade practices, we will put at risk the future of EU production in these products, with enormous damage to farmers and SMEs.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to this report which addresses harmful practices in the European food supply chain, so-called unfair trading practices. We need to protect both farmers and consumers against unnecessarily high prices and to protect small producers from unfair competition. The proposed measures and greater cooperation between Member States can help address this issue.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Unfair trade practices in the food and non-food supply chain have detrimental effects on the EU economy as a whole: companies are deprived of their capacity to invest and innovate. In this context, the weaker party often does not take legal action because it fears that the commercial relationship will end. While the European Commission has called on Member States to find ways to give small producers and retailers greater protection against unfair trade practices, the problem is far from being solved. This situation is explained by the stubbornness of the Member States to adopt different positions on the subject. This report has the merit of highlighting the risks associated with unfair practices: strong and coherent measures are needed at EU level to completely eliminate these unfair practices. The ultimate aim is to stimulate reflection and find problem audit solutions within the European internal market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union has a long-term interest in protecting small food producers and retailers from unfair trading practices, which often occur in trade relations when there is a diversity of market forces. UTEs can have a devastating effect on the Union economy as a whole, as they can cause businesses to lose their ability to invest and in insect and not seek to expand their business in the single market. In practice, it is often the case that the weaker party does not take any legal action and accepts unfair practices despite their harmful effect, because it fears that a stronger party will end cooperation. However, the rules in this area vary from one Member State to another. In parallel, market participants are also trying to address this problem by developing principles of good practice in vertical relationships and self-regulatory frameworks for their implementation, exemplary by the supply chain initiative. It is therefore essential to take decisive and consistent action aimed at completely eliminating unfair commercial practices emerging in the food supply chain. The scale of the problem requires the introduction of legislation that will guarantee the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. The proposal has my support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because it is essential to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations on a highly concentrated market.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission published a communication in July 2014 urging Member States to look at ways to better protect small food manufacturers and retailers from unfair commercial practices, which often occur in business relationships where one party is in a stronger position than the other. The report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection notes that unfair commercial practices in business-to-business relationships have come to the fore in recent years, with unfair commercial practices becoming relatively prevalent, especially in parts of the supply chain. In a Survey conducted in March 2011, 96% of food supply chain respondents said they had been exposed to at least one unfair commercial practice. It calls for strong, consistent measures to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain. Because of the scale of the problem, it demands EU rules ensuring the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain, and unfair trade practices are clearly defined and sanctions are imposed on those who use them. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Unfair commercial practices in the food supply chair seriously harm small producers, making the relationship between the latter with suppliers and distribution unclear. That is why I am in favour of a regulatory framework that protects producers and SMEs against these unfair practices, in particular selling below the cost of production, jeopardising the long-term sustainability of production.   On the other hand, these practices may also have an effect on the reduction of available products and on the increase in their prices.  For the reasons set out above I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is well-oriented because it aims to defend SMALL and medium-sized enterprises against unfair business practices by legally arming them and by building a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. I vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We support this report as we want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created, whilst workers and farmers suffer. Lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report highlights unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. At a time when the European Union is legislating to better protect weak parties in contracts, as demonstrated by the adoption of the Consumer Protection Directive in 2011, this text is part of this process. That is why I voted for it.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of unfair practices in the food supply chain is a constantly expanding phenomenon that mainly affects SMEs and has a deleterious effect on the European internal market. An interview in March 2011, carried out by the European Federation of Food Industries, shows that as many as 96 % of respondents said that they had been exposed to at least one form of unfair commercial practice. More and more cases of late payments, restrictions on access to the capital market, abusive changes to contractual clauses and pressure to cut prices are becoming increasingly apparent. As draftsman of the opinion of the report on access to credit for SMEs, I am well aware of these issues and have therefore chosen to vote in favour of European action to identify measures that go beyond the current voluntary mechanisms. We must not forget that unfair practices occur where there are imbalances in financial resources and bargaining power between the parties. The so-called 'fear factor' is increasingly pushing weaker trading partners not to take legal action to avoid retaliation. That is why our coordinated efforts at European level to combat these phenomena must not fail.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of europe's economic and social fabric, and its particular vulnerability to unfair commercial practices, we are voting in favour of the Czesak report. The imbalances and distortions result from the abuse of a dominant position are, in fact, a serious threat to SMEs and the functioning of the single market itself. The phenomenon, assisted by globalization and the integration of production chains, particularly affects operators in the agri-food sector. According to a 2011 study, in fact, around 96 % of respondents claimed to have been victims of unfair practices. Some Member States, recognising the extent and extent of the damage, have developed rules and policies at national level. It is clear, however, that the proper functioning of the single market requires a Community and holistic response from the European Union, a concrete solution that guarantees, on pain of sanction, fair and transparent trade relations. To this end, given the threat of repercussions, I share the wish for investigations to ensure the anonymity of the reporting companies.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report, as farmers in the food supply chain are particularly vulnerable to unfair commercial practices. Following negotiations with an unfavourable outcome for producers, producers sometimes make large losses or unfair practices have adverse effects on the entire supply chain. Small, medium and micro enterprises account for almost 90% of the economic fabric of the European Union and are the ones that feel the effects of unfair practices the most and should therefore be protected by appropriate regulations and mechanisms by the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission issued a communication in 2014 urging Member States to search for new ways of giving more protection against Unfair Trading Practices (UTPS) to small food producers and retailers. I support this report that aims to end this situation of unfair trading practices.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that unfair trade practices must be identified and combated throughout the European Union. The use of these practices in the food supply chain affects the entire market, including consumer interests. These practices also have a negative impact on the employment and quality and diversity of the products made available. I think it is very important that the authorities of the Member States, together with the European Commission, continue to promote good practices and continue to fight to identify and penalise unfair commercial practices.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on unfair trading practices because, in my opinion, it goes too far in regulating commercial contractual relations in the food supply chain. I am of the opinion that market relations should only be interfered with when those market relationships are demonstrably distorted and when this is really necessary. In my opinion, this is not the case. I do not want the creation of an EU legal framework that dictates to food market participants the conditions under which they can conclude contracts. As a result, this means favouring one party over another, and I conceptually consider this to be unhealthy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report has also received my support. This draft deals with unfair trade practices in the supply chain, which are major disadvantages and unfair conditions, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, including the dairy sector. In my opinion, the report contains very good approaches to counter this development.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Unfair commercial practices concern, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which may, as a result, lose the ability to invest and to abandon their desire to develop their activities in the single market. I therefore consider it important that both the Member States and the EU address this issue and try to harmonise ways of combating such manifestations of unfair trade.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report records some blatant practices of profiteering and speculation in the food supply chain, which it treats as an exception and a 'distortion' of competition. That is why, under the concept of enhancing the competitiveness of enterprises, it proposes spoof measures, such as the creation of a 'business platform' for the exchange of 'best practices', 'codes of conduct' or the invocation of 'corporate social responsibility of enterprises'. In other words, it instructs the business groups, which operate on the sole criterion of their profits, to "self-regulate" their activities. The creation of business partnerships to control producer and market prices, relentless competition vis-à-vis other groups and the destruction of the self-employed and small VEDs are the operating conditions of monopoly capitalism in the conditions of dominance of large business groups and not 'competition malfunctions', as the report disorientingly attempts to present. This is the capitalist mode of production at the monopoly stage. The pursuit of profit and exploitation will only be eliminated by overturning the power of monopolies and socialising them, with the people in power.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. This report calls for the creation of a European Regulator to tackle UTPs. Many Member States currently have national regulators and the United Kingdom is considered to have one of the best. UKIP believes that a harmonised approach would not be in the best interest for the UK and therefore we have voted against this report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I feel I must support Mr Czesak's proposal for the definitive elimination of commercial practices in the food supply chain, as there is no doubt that such behaviour causes serious damage to companies in the sector. We are well aware that 90% of European companies are SMEs and that they are particularly active in the food sector. Because of their characteristics, SMEs are seriously affected by unfair competition, which makes it increasingly difficult not only for them to survive in the market, but also for the development of innovative ideas. Despite the efforts of the European Union and the Member States to combat this phenomenon, through regulatory action, it must be noted that the problem still exists. Therefore, in sharing my colleague's view on the need for further action, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Unfair trade practices are practices that grossly deviate from good commercial conduct. UTPs in the food supply chain is a major problem, particularly for farmers, producers and SMEs. I firmly believe in the need for free and fair competition and, therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Data in Croatia show that in the last few years almost 100 000 family farms have disappeared from the Register and their fate is unknown, food imports are rising and purchase prices of agricultural products are falling. Milk purchasers terminate contracts with producers overnight without any consequences, and in a year in Croatia 2 000 milk producers have ceased to operate, while most still have loans and their livelihoods as well as the future of their children have been called into question.  There is no shortage of similar examples in other EU Member States. In order to put an end to UTPs in the food supply chain in western EU countries, a certain level of voluntary relations between the chain partners has been established, and at the initiative of both producer and purchaser organisations. However, regardless of the good intention and desire to regulate relations voluntarily, such a system does not produce results ither.  I therefore believe that it is necessary to adopt framework legislation at EU level in order to address UTPs and to ensure fair sales and purchasing conditions for European farmers and consumers. This is exactly what the amendments of the AGRI Committee adopted call for, which gave this report a clear message that we will no longer tolerate UTPs.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is well-oriented because it aims to defend SMALL and medium-sized enterprises against unfair business practices by legally arming them and by building a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths. I vote for this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support this report because it proposes the establishment of a European regulation that addresses the widespread and growing problem, in the field of food production, of the unfair commercial practices that small producers and retailers suffer from their trading partners with greater bargaining power. The report highlights how self-regulatory regimes have proved insufficient and, therefore, calls on the Commission to put in place mandatory legislation, including control systems and penalties for offenders. From a survey carried out in 2011, within the food supply chain, 96 % of respondents stated that they had been exposed to at least one form of unfair commercial practices. The most common types are late payments, restrictions on market access, abusive changes to contractual clauses and pressure to reduce prices. These practices differ widely from good commercial behaviour and are imposed by a stronger trading partner, which has more financial resources. All this has a detrimental effect on the European economy because SMEs lose their ability to invest, innovate and expand their business in the single market. The EU must therefore commit itself to eradicating these practices, with obligations and sanctions.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since manufacturers sometimes operate at a loss after negotiations with other food chain operators, e.g. in cases of impairments and price reductions in supermarkets and that UTPs constitute an obstacle to the development and well functioning of the internal market and seriously hinder the proper functioning of the market, the European Parliament welcomes the steps taken so far by the Commission to combat UTPs to ensure a more balanced market and to overcome the current fragmentation resulting from the different national approach to tackling UTPs in the EU.  But he points out that these steps are not enough to counter unfair trading practices. I welcome Parliament's decision to combat UTPs in the food supply chain and believe that the strengthening and establishment of producer organisations should be accompanied by an increase in the bargaining power of farmers in the food supply chain, in particular by enabling them to collectively negotiate contracts.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report only gives examples of unfair commercial practices that food supply chain participants have declared to be common in the sector. We believe that a clear, rigorous and objective definition of abusive and unfair practices is necessary. The issue of the value chain is a glaring in the food supply chain. The prices of products paid by consumers do not reflect the prices paid to producers, most often crushed by the imposition of the distribution sector, particularly by large retailers, ensuring absurd profit margins for them, when producers often impose prices below the cost of production.  The Commission has chosen not to address the issue of abuses by "large buyers" in the food supply chain. Instead of strongly opposed to the current concentration of power in the hands of retailers and large industries and propose measures to support and reverse this situation and promote active combat ing dumping, it merely launches communications through which it undertakes to introduce mechanisms to combat these unfair commercial practices by encouraging the adoption of voluntary codes of conduct and while creating eu-wide standards of "good practice" principles.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ UTPs are present in large numbers and in many economic sectors, and can occur in any part of the food supply chain in the business-to-business business. Of the total food and beverage production in the EU, cross-border trade between Member States is 20 percent and employment in the sector exceeds 47 million EU population. Some of the most common UTPs that need to be controlled and prevented are late payments, limited market access and ambiguous conditions present in contracts. I supported MeP Czesak's report to put in place coherent and stringent measures to prevent such problems in the EU food supply chain and to make markets more efficient with a level playing field for all partners.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfair commercial practices in the food or other supply chain can generally be regarded as dishonest conduct unilaterally exploited by one trading partner vis-à-vis another. Although it is not easy to assess this phenomenon in all contexts, statistics and market analyses show that these practices also occur quite often in the EU and take many forms, as companies in the Czech Republic have often felt. Among other things, these may be unilateral or retroactive changes to the terms and conditions, flat-rate fees that companies require from suppliers for pay-to-stay or late payments, even for months. This situation must finally be actively responded to. Given that the effectiveness of self-regulatory mechanisms can rightly be questioned in this case, the report supports regulation at Union level, which should lead to the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the supply chain.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair commercial practices consist of late payments, restriction of market access, unilateral changes in contractual conditions (including with retroactive effect), sudden and unjustified termination of the contract, unfair transfer of commercial risk and transfer of transport and storage costs to suppliers. The EU already has legislation to combat unfair commercial practices between businesses and consumers (Directive 2005/29/EC), but there are no EU rules to combat unfair practices between different operators in the agri-food chain. Farmers and SMEs are particularly vulnerable to unfair commercial practices. This report aims to put forward proposals against unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, so as to ensure a fair income for farmers and a wide choice for consumers. The aim should be to ensure transparent relations between food producers, suppliers and distributors. I voted in favour of this report in order to achieve the objective of fair trade which can, in turn, help to avoid overproduction and food waste.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. There is an urgent need to address imbalances and unequal power relations in the food supply chain. That is how I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to put forward concrete proposals to deal with unfair trade practices in the food supply chain. A fair income for farmers and a real choice for consumers are the two objectives that the European Commission must have in mind in proposing mechanisms for ensuring fair and transparent trade relations between producers, suppliers and distributors in the sector.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report under consideration now addresses the issue of unfair competitive practices (PCDs) recognising the merits of the Member States and the Union in the efforts already made in this area. The issue of PCDs in inter-business relations has gained ground in recent years and the subsequent debate has been supported by statistical data. PCD means all practices that deviate from the rules of good commercial conduct - in contrast to good faith and fair commercial practices. The above practices result in the loss of investment capacity and innovation of companies, thereby harming the EU economy. Today, the consequences of PCDs are already identified by a large number of Member States and their legal frameworks include a number of measures to regulate certain aspects inherent in these practices. Nevertheless, the report is of the opinion that the Community context lacks a specific regime, in particular a clear definition of THE PDPs and the provision for sanctions for those who use them. Because of the foregoing and, since I consider it essential to establish a trade regime of the Union itself, I voted in favour.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the adoption of this report, as I believe that concrete proposals must be made at European Commission level against unfair trade practices in the food sector, but also to ensure decent incomes for farmers.  The resolution, approved by 600 votes at 48 and 24 abstentions, demonstrates the urgency of improving farmers' bargaining power in the trade chain. It is inadmissible that fruit and vegetables, dairy and meat products, the main foods of a healthy diet, should be sold at undervalued prices by the major distributors.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. This report calls for the creation of a European Regulator to tackle UTPs. Many Member States currently have national regulators and the United Kingdom is considered to have one of the best. UKIP believes that a harmonised approach would not be in the best interest for the UK and therefore we have voted against this report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Even today, unfair trade practices are present in our economy, particularly in the agri-food sector. Delays in payment, limited market access, unjustified termination of contracts, pressure to bring down product prices, the list does not end! These practices must stop now. The European Parliament voted this week in favour of a resolution on unfair trade practices in the food supply chain.  It is not only a question of moral ethics, but also of common sense and collective pragmatism. The food supply chain is of strategic importance to the European Union; the agri-food sector employs more than 47 million people and generates 4.3% of our GDP. As a reminder, since 2009, the European Parliament has adopted five resolutions on problems in the EU distribution channel. Today's resolution is the culmination of that. This is to say that we will continue to protect our fellow citizens and above all that we will do everything in order to avoid the establishment of a climate of uncertainty within our European market. We want to preserve a spirit of mutual trust, mutual aid and fraternity characteristic of our Europe.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is time to put an end to unfair trade practices in the food supply chain and that is why I voted in favour of this report for which I was rapporteur for my political group. These unacceptable practices have very damaging consequences for the entire food supply chain, particularly for farmers and SMEs, as well as for the consumer.  Contractual freedom and the effective implementation of applicable tools or legislation to protect all players in the chain, regardless of their geographical location, must be guaranteed. In particular, we call on the voluntary initiative of the Supply Chain Initiative to address its shortcomings, such as the under-representation of SMEs and farmers, the absence of sanctions for non-compliance, governance weaknesses, or the inability to submit confidential complaints. In addition, we encourage Member States to set up public authorities or specific bodies at national level to combat these practices; these authorities should also cooperate effectively with each other. The time is no longer for doubt as to the existence of these practices; it must now be put to an end.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Unfair Business Practices (PCD) are those that are significantly devisefrom good business conduct and are unilaterally imposed by one trading partner on the other (contract changes, late payment, restricted market access, forced price drop). They can have detrimental effects on the EU economy, as they can result in the loss of investment and innovation capacity of enterprises, particularly SMEs. Many of these SMEs are also concerned about taking legal action against stronger companies for fear that the business relationship will be called into question. In a survey conducted in March 2011, 96% of respondents in the food supply chain said they had already been exposed to at least one form of PCD. The rules in this area differ considerably from Member State to Member State, as well as the scale of the problem. The fact that CFPs are a widespread and growing problem calls into question the effectiveness of self-regulatory schemes in restoring market balance. Rules are needed at EU level to ensure that markets function properly and that there are loyal and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the EU executive to put forward proposals to combat unfair trade practices (CDPs) in the food supply chain. In the context of the crisis - as we are experiencing - which is particularly shaking the milk and meat sectors, we have called for the EU to have legislation to combat these unfair practices (delays in payment, limiting market access, unilateral changes to contractual conditions, unjustified termination of contracts, unfair transfer of commercial risk and transfer of transport and storage costs to suppliers). EU-wide framework legislation is needed to combat CDPs and ensure that European farmers and consumers benefit from fair terms of sale and purchase (particularly with the aim of ensuring fairer and more transparent trade relations between producers, suppliers and distributors in the sector). It should be noted that the EU already had legislation to combat unfair business practices against consumers (Directive 2005/29/EC), but there were no EU rules to combat unfair practices between the various operators of the agri-food chain. Unfair business practices were only partially covered by competition law.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfair practices in the food supply chain, in particular the unjustifiably low share of value added from primary producers, are one of the main causes of the current crisis.  I welcome this report, and it contains a number of provisions that I have put forward in the AGRI Committee. I call on the Commission to take a close look at our proposals. I call on the Member States to do the same. We urgently need to take legal measures to protect farmers and, in the long term, to ensure the viability of the countryside.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. The food supply chain has undergone significant structural changes that have contributed to a situation characterized by highly variable levels of bargaining power and economic imbalances in individual trade relations between the chain's players. These imbalances are now reflected in recurrent unfair trade practices that weaken smaller players, such as producers. It is essential that the European Commission tackles this problem through a legislative proposal to combat these unfair trade practices. To be effective, the answer will have to be European, particularly in terms of adopting a common definition and standards. It will also have to take into account the particularly difficult situation of small players and in particular producers. The Supply Chain Initiative, while it may be a useful initiative, is still too marked by many imperfections. For example, it has never resolved a conflict between the different actors. Thus, it seems necessary to supplement it with binding measures, as requested in this report. It also indicates that such measures will have to include elements of enforcement and deterrent sanctions. So I supported that report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we are witnessing situations that can set up unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, fostering untransparent relations between producers and wholesalers/retailers. On the other hand, we have found enormous food waste, reports of sales below the cost of production and the misuse of certain agricultural products - such as milk, fruit and agricultural products, sold at very low prices in promotions. All this should make us think and act. I therefore favoured the adoption of this report, which calls on the Commission to put forward proposals to combat these practices in order to provide greater transparency, clarity and rigour in relations between the food production and marketing sectors. This will contribute to a general reduction in costs and an increase in revenues for companies with less bargaining capacity, as well as to facilitate the disposal of their production and, consequently, the reduction of food waste, therefore for a more responsible consumption. In the absence of effective voluntary and self-regulatory schemes, concerted action at European level is needed, which will join forces and enable European farmers and consumers a level playing and buying conditions in all Member States.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 In the food market, trade relations and negotiating position between small producers and large retail chains are often er proportionate, which easily leads to practices that are contrary to good commercial practice. These shortcomings need to be addressed in order to guarantee a reasonable income for primary producers and a wide range of products for consumers. The Union needs common ground rules, because voluntary self-regulation by traders has failed to solve these problems. It should be possible to report practices that are contrary to good commercial practice anonymously. If a small business is based on a single retail chain, he or she is clearly in a position from which it is difficult to point out grievances under his own name. Unfair negotiating stations are also commonplace in Finland, where grocery trade is highly concentrated. In Finland, for example, large retail chains can often collect so-called marketing money from suppliers. It is not always clear whether the money will provide marketing or whether it is simply a mandatory threshold money to guarantee the product's access to the shelf.  Such practices affect both food producers and consumers. The range decreases, the price of food rises and producers' earnings fall. The consumer price of food in Finland rose by as much as 18.7 per cent between 2010 and 2014, while the average rise in EU countries remained at 9.7 per cent. Over the past year, poverty has been discussed several times in the European Parliament in its various forms, such as energy poverty. Maybe next we should talk about food poverty? The problems raised in the Czesak report are not new. Since 2009, Parliament has adopted as many as five resolutions on retail problems. Now is the time to act.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the European Commission to take measures and tools to combat unfair business practices between companies at European level. The problem of unfair competition is particularly present in the food supply chain and has negative effects on the weakest link in the chain, particularly small producers and farmers. This report calls, without further delay, for a framework for the abusive practices of certain companies in order to restore a level playing field.  I supported this report because it also calls for the establishment of EU-wide framework legislation necessary to combat unfair trade practices and ensure that European farmers and consumers benefit from fair selling and buying conditions. This Eu framework legislation should not lower the level of protection already in place in some Member States.  Finally, the report calls for greater transparency and access to more information in the supply chain, including better consumer awareness through product labelling.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented aims to assess the most appropriate tools to be given to producers in the agri-food sector in order to ensure adequate protection against unfair commercial practices. The situation is worrying when we consider that a 2011 survey shows that 96 % of respondents in the food supply chain said that they had been the victim of unfair commercial practices. In order to combat these practices effectively and thus protect small and medium-sized enterprises as well as the interests of consumers, the rapporteur has proposed taking decisive action. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, because it introduces anti-abuse measures for producers and consumers to try to remedy a number of practices that act against small producers. This report also calls on the Commission for more cooperation and legislation at European level. PPE's amendments to the text delve into this direction, but I maintain discrepancies in form. This report reflects the need for greater cooperation between the weakest links in the food sector, and proposes lines of solution which I believe address the problem. The report was unanimously adopted in committee and our shadow rapporteur's amendments were included, so my vote is favourable.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Strong measures are needed to tackle unfair trading practices in the food supply chain and in particular to protect producers, small businesses and consumers. Not for the first time, the Commission is relying too heavily on a voluntary approach and self-regulation, despite the evidence that this is not appropriate in this case. Sometimes tougher measures are needed, such as an EU legal framework with proper enforcement procedures and genuinely dissuasive penalties.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on Unfair Trading Practices in the Food Supply Chain'. We must not allow manufacturers, who are often the weakest links in the so-called food supply chains, to be discriminated against. The report calls for EU regulation to compensate for the starch imbalance between producers and food chains, thereby preventing such unfair practices.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the Social Democrats, I supported this report because it comprehensively describes the situation in the food supply chain and at the same time asks the Commission for concrete measures to settle the current market situation. Unfair commercial practices have long been a serious problem faced by all elements of the supply chain. I also supported the amendments of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, because I agree with the provision that unfair commercial practices can only be reduced if there is framework legislation at EU level, which is in line with the wording of the report. The report also mentions the specific reasons for the need for a common European approach on this issue.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that we need legislation to restore balance and ensure fairness and transparency in the food chain. It is therefore important to increase the bargaining power of farmers by improving the producer organisation and cooperation throughout the food chain.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 Although I am in favour of the general lines of this report, my final vote has been abstention, because I believe that it does not provide binding elements to limit the actions of large multinationals, in order to stop unfair practices in the food supply chain. It is therefore a report with good words but a difficult direct applicability.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has called on the Commission to take action against unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, as the initiatives implemented so far have not been effective enough. Unfair commercial practices have negative consequences for farmers, such as lower profits, higher costs, overproduction or food waste and difficulties in financial planning. There are, for example, producers who are sometimes forced to sell downwards due, for example, to large discounts and discounts in supermarkets. It is therefore necessary to define clearly what unfair commercial practices are and then to establish clear sanctions for anyone who implements them. The sector most affected, both in the food supply chain and in the non-food sector, are SMEs which, where there are major financial imbalances, lose their ability to invest and innovate. Furthermore, we must not forget the 'fear factor' that occurs when small companies, for fear of having their business relationship concluded, find themselves forced to accept misconduct. I therefore felt it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Farmers are currently suffering from a price crush which, in some sectors such as milk, is at historically low levels. In addition to unfavourable market conditions, farmers' relationship with industry and distribution reveals differences in terms of trading capacity, resulting in lower prices they receive. Given the need to ensure the disposal of their products, farmers are often urged to accept conditions that force them to revise their income forecasts down. There is an urgent need for European legislation to rebalance this relationship and ensure a fair price for farmers. This issue acquires a particular importance in the case of regions whose production depends heavily on the distribution to drain their products, as is the case in the Azores.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Today we adopted a report on UTPs in the food supply chain, including amendments I tabled on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, calling on the European Commission to present an appropriate legal framework for a fairer distribution of income in the food chain.  There is no doubt that farmers are currently in the worst position in the 'field m.in-to-table' chain, as a result of their low bargaining power in negotiations with traders or processors, which is the result, on the one hand, of a small degree of organisation and, on the other, of unfair practices by other operators. There are examples of contracts in which farmers are placed under several dozen conditions to be met at a very low price offered for a product. Significant delays in payments to farmers are also widespread, causing serious problems for farms to maintain liquidity. Nor do these practices serve consumers who receive an increasingly diversified offer. The agricultural crisis and falling agricultural incomes make the need to tackle this problem even more urgent, and I hope that the Commission will propose appropriate solutions to improve the situation of our farmers in the near future.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report in plenary because I would like to see an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in an already greatly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle Unfair Trading Practices (UTPs) and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Any undue delay will mean that UTPs will continue to distort the market, which will affect the integrity of the European single market, it will adversely affect consumers and create unnecessary food waste. UTPs will needlessly cause workers and farmers to suffer and a lack of action to tackle this will not only have this continue, but also undermine the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that we streamline the fight against unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution, which aims to help ensure fair remuneration for their products for farmers, while ensuring a wider choice for consumers.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although individual EU Member States already have rules to combat unfair trading practices (TDIs), I find the behaviour of supermarket chains across the EU, especially in supply-customer relations, very difficult. This is also indicated by the result of a study in March 2011 which showed that up to 96 % of respondents in the food supply chain confirmed that they had been exposed to at least one form of TD. I consider this to be a serious problem, especially as TDAs affect SMEs and microenterprises, which make up more than 90% of businesses in the EU and are much more vulnerable to NPO than large enterprises. I think that unless a joint initiative and a common framework for the behaviour of supermarket chains across the EU is made, it will be very difficult to expect an improvement in the position of domestic farmers and food producers against the strong, dominant economic strength and position of the supermarket chains. I believe that only good EU legislation will guarantee the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all those in the food supply chain.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's resolution on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. I consider this problem to be very significant from the point of view of farmers and consumers. We meet it in individual countries, including the Czech Republic, but the problem is so connected with the EU internal market that it deserves a European approach and solutions at EU level. The European Parliament is calling for the most appropriate ways to protect food producers and suppliers against unfair commercial practices by retailers, most often retail chains. Two approaches clashed in the negotiations and votes on this text. The IMCO approach preferred self-regulation and non-interference with legislation. The AGRI Committee took a different stance, urging in its opinion to "present the proposal for EU framework legislation in a timely way", thus in favour of a legislative solution at EU level. In the end, the position of the AGRI Committee prevailed in our PPE faction, which I agree with. I am of the opinion that voluntary self-regulatory solutions may contribute to the cultivation of trade relations, but they cannot in themselves provide a solution to the problem of unfair commercial practices. My position is in line with that of the Czech Ministry of Agriculture. I therefore supported the resolution as such and the amendments of the AGRI Committee.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Unfair trade practices in the food supply chain between businesses and suppliers are a major problem in the EU, but unfortunately it is under-exposed. In general, they could be defined as deviating strongly from good business behaviour, contrary to good faith and fair conduct, and imposed unilaterally by one trading partner on another.  Small and medium-sized enterprises and farmers are placed in an unequal position and face difficulties. A number of Member States are taking action against such practices, while other Member States are still planning similar measures. Thus, the rules in this area vary greatly between Member States, as do the scale of this problem.  Member States which do not have a competent enforcement authority are invited to consider setting it up and to grant it the powers of supervision and enforcement of the measures necessary to put an end to unfair trading practices.  The report also calls for the creation of transparent retail selling prices, thus better denoting the added value generated by primary producers. The report also calls on all parties in the food supply chain to consider standard contracts, as well as new-generation contracts where risks and benefits are shared.  For this reason, I believe that the report is good and I have supported it.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'It has been known for some time that supermarkets have a lot of power and Europe has already taken several initiatives to combat this. It is therefore not the first time that these unfair commercial practices have been the subject of debate. The Commission is also aware of the problem, but would rather the food supply chain develop a self-regulatory initiative or the Member States to take the initiative here. It doesn't seem like a good idea to us. Big supermarkets are only getting bigger and more and more cross borders because of their power. They therefore have more and more consequences for pricing and contract negotiations, where conditions are often changed unilaterally. These commercial practices lead to an uneven playing field. Moreover, the self-regulating chain initiative does not appear to be working. Farmers' organisations in several Member States are already boycotting it because there is no enforceability and no anonymous complaints can be made. This excellent report therefore calls on the Commission to come up with a legislative initiative (a directive) to combat these unfair trade practices and to give a little more firmness to the self-regulating chain initiative. Not only through anonymous complaints or better enforceability, but also independent management of such an initiative and better follow-up, for example with unannounced checks.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fair trade can only work if mutual trust works between seller and buyer. Today, there are already a number of non-legislative self-regulation instruments, such as codes of ethics. We should follow the path of promoting such behaviour and not introducing new regulations. These lead to increased bureaucracy and will not solve the problem on their own.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The size and strategic importance of the food supply chain for the European Union should be taken into account as the sector employs more than 47 million people in the EU and the total value of the EU market for products related to the retail food trade is estimated at €1.05 billion. I support this report as unfair trading practices in the food supply chain are difficult to interpret as a breach of current competition law, as its existing tools are only effective in the case of some forms of uncompetitive behaviour.  In this regard, I consider UTPs to be a serious problem that is ethalous in many economic sectors. The same problem has negative effects on the weakest link of the food supply chain, and the Commission, the European Economic and Social Committee and Parliament have repeatedly highlighted this problem. Food trade has an increasingly important cross-border dimension and food supply chain operators benefit greatly from the single market.  Finally, the impacts of UTPs are particularly subject to small, medium and microenterprises accounting for more than 90 % of europe's economic structure, and competition law only partially covers the same unfairness in the food supply chain.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as my Labour colleagues and I want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created, whilst workers and farmers suffer. Lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. Unfair trading practices are a serious problem affecting many sectors of the economy. That is why Member States have long adopted national laws to punish unfair commercial practices in court or to put an end to out-of-court dispute resolution. The EU is now to take action. However, there is no concrete added value for an EU-wide action initiated by the Commission. That is why I am voting against.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Generally speaking, UTPs can be defined as a practice that grossly deviates from good business conduct, contrary to the conduct in good faith imposed by one trading partner in relation to another. This practice occurs where there are imbalances in financial resources and can have a detrimental impact on the Union economy as a whole, as it can lead to companies, in particular SMEs, losing their ability to invest and deciding that they do not want to expand their business in the single market. Weaker trading partners will not take legal action, in the case of such practices, but accept such a practice however harmful it may be, fearing that a stronger partner will end the business relationship. A large number of Member States recognised the harm that the application of such practices can do and introduced different ways to combat UTPs, leading to major deviations between countries in terms of the level and form of redress. I support the proposal for a resolution, as I believe that adopting common standards will enable a labour market where there are fair and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain.  Despite the Commission's numerous efforts to reduce unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, there is still room for improvement. We must not forget that dishonesty in the food supply chain is a serious problem that arises in many industries and which causes market failure.  I agree with the report, which considers that the principles of good practice and the list of examples of fair and unfair practices in vertical relations in the food supply chain should be extended and applied effectively.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, i.e. in accordance with the opinion of the Czech Republic. This is a complicated issue because unfair commercial practices cannot be addressed by existing legislative instruments. In this situation, there has been some improvement in the Czech Republic thanks to the amendment of the Act on Significant Market Power, but it does not solve the whole situation. Even given the international presence of some retail chains, solutions at international level would also need to be adopted, namely a ban on unfair trading practices that will protect SMEs, micro-enterprises and, of course, consumers, and set a level playing field for business chains across the EU.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We agree that transparency and information in the supply chain should be increased.
