The existence of framework legislation at EU level is necessary to address UTPs (Tackling unfair trade practices) and to ensure that European farmers and consumers have the opportunity to benefit from a level playing field.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as unfair commercial practices affect both producers and consumers. We need a more transparent trading system. We are talking here about practices such as late payments, restrictions on market access, unilateral or retroactive changes to terms and conditions, unexpected and unjustified termination of the contract, unfair pass-on of business risks, elimination of transport and warehousing costs for suppliers. Unfortunately, all these bad practices can be found in Hungary, and at the same time as the introduction of sunday shop closures, the government has put a network of shops close to the government in a monopoly position. But there are also a number of other instruments, such as special taxes, selective controls and intimidation, that would be unthinkable in the European single market. I believe that an important loophole in commercial practices is the range of different levels of food tax burden, which is also bad for producers and consumers, and even has a significant budgetary impact due to VAT fraud. Hungary, the most significant part of the food price is 27%, but with government help, some commercial operators can add various indirect charges, such as the 'shelf charge'. Existing EU legislation against unfair commercial practices in the relationship between businesses and consumers exists, so I agree that we should extend this to operators in the agricultural trade chain, as competition rules also only partially cover the area.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 UTPs have a negative impact not only on small and medium-sized enterprises – as they deprive them of the opportunity to invest in innovation and thus to develop their activities in the single market – but also on the EU economy as a whole. Disparities and inequalities are particularly evident in the food supply chain, and it is therefore necessary to look for ways to increase the protection of particularly small food producers and retailers against unfair trading practices, often used by the biggest players in the market. Already, many Member States have taken regulatory action to combat them. In addition, stakeholders themselves have developed a number of good principles and frameworks for self-regulation to implement them, and have successfully developed less formal and universal dispute resolution and redress mechanisms. The principles of good practice and the list of examples of fair and unfair practices in the food supply chain should therefore be extended and enforced more effectively.  I am afraid that the creation of regulation at EU level will be further evidence that the European Union is over-regulated, which will provide it with additional ammunition for its critics.  I have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report and the amendments tabled by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. I believe that the food chain needs regulation at European Union level, as food trade takes place across borders within the internal market. The food chain also needs fairer rules of the game because the disadvantages of the agricultural crisis have been unreasonably paid by producers in particular. Uniform regulation ensures predictability, which will level the market.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The access of small food producers and traders to the free market is currently affected by a number of unfair trade practices in their dealings with food supply chain participants. These practices arise in the presence of imbalances between the financial resources of the two parties and are manifested by setting disadvantageous prices, late payment, restricting market access, unfair contractual terms in relation to small producers, who are obliged to accept this way of working, not having the means to defend themselves. The situation is widespread, despite regulatory measures taken by Member States, which rely on voluntary and self-regulatory systems.  Strong and consistent measures are needed to remove these negative practices from the Union's food supply chain. They imply a clear definition of unfair commercial practices and clear penalties for their deterrence, applied by the competent national agencies. The current report envisages the introduction of the necessary mechanisms for the implementation of these measures, which can support small and medium-sized producers. That is why I express my support for the current form of the document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the text because its aim is to highlight the problem of unfair trade practices and, while emphasizing initiatives that have already been taken at national or European level, whether national regulatory measures or self-regulatory initiatives, to stimulate reflection on other possibilities to resolve the problem of unfair trade practices within the European internal market.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Unfair trading practices (UTPs), such as payment delays, restricted access to the market, or unplanned changes to contract terms are a serious problem for our economy. The problem is particularly evident in the food supply chain, where it can affect small food producers and retailers when their business partners are stronger than they are. In addition to leading to lower profits, food over—production and wastage, and ultimately reducing consumer choice, it hampers SMEs in their ability to invest and innovate.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported the Czesak mep's report because he unequivocally calls on the Member States to look for new ways of increasing the protection of small food producers and retailers against unfair commercial practices. The rapporteur rightly lists examples of unfair practices that deviate seriously from good trade behaviour and run counter to the principle of fair trade. It is therefore necessary to stop harmful practices on the agricultural market, which have a negative impact on the economy of the European Union as a whole, and especially on the economies of the small Member States, which is unacceptable.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. Unfair trading practices are those which deviate greatly from good business conduct, are contrary to good faith and fair conduct and are imposed unilaterally by one trading partner on another. Unfair trading practices need to be tackled, as they have a detrimental impact on the EU economy, SMEs are losing their ability to invest and innovate, and as a result they do not choose to expand their business in the single market. So far, 20 Member States have introduced legislation to combat unfair trading practices. Large corporations have become a country within the country and operate under their own productive conditions, which in certain cases overturn national laws. The issue concerns the whole of the European Union and demands its response. Unfair trade practices need to be clearly defined, decisively acted on and eliminated.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, because it introduces anti-abuse measures for producers and consumers to try to remedy a number of practices that act against small producers. This report also calls on the Commission for more cooperation and legislation at European level. PPE's amendments to the text delve into this direction, but I maintain discrepancies in form. This report reflects the need for greater cooperation between the weakest links in the food sector, and proposes lines of solution which I believe address the problem. The report was unanimously adopted in committee and our shadow rapporteur's amendments were included, so my vote is favourable.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report. I am glad that the emphasis is on the role of producer organisations. Further and more regulation in the final round may not be of any use to small suppliers at all, but in this case I support the creation of a common framework to reduce unfair commercial practices, provided that countries with higher levels of protection are respected and the choice of means remains with the Member States.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report. Unfair trading practices (UTPs) are a serious problem, occurring in many sectors of the economy. UTPs occur where there are inequalities in trading relations between partners in the food supply chain, resulting from bargaining power disparities in business relations, which are the result of the growing concentration of market power among a small number of multinational groups, and these disparities tend to harm small and medium-sized producers. UTPs can have harmful consequences for the individual entities in the food supply chain, particularly in the case of farmers and SMEs, which in turn can have an impact on the entire EU economy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The major food (and non-food) retailers have engaged in very aggressive trade policies and have effectively contributed to the destruction of the commercial and commercial fabric of French villages and towns, centralizing the supply of products in "de-off" or "commercial" superstructures.  Today, being almost in a commercial monopoly situation, these retail chains (both the food supply chain and also the non-food supply chain) are all powerful and are often the subject of complaints from small producers or retailers subjecting unfair business practices (or abuse of dominant position) further distorting the market, atrophying the investment capacities of SME SMEs , ruining the attractiveness and dynamism of the sectors and affecting the employment of the French to finish.   The report is well oriented because it intends to defend SME SMEs against these unfair business practices by legally arming them and by building a relatively restrictive code of conduct for distribution behemoths.  Unfortunately, this report never mentions the fierce unfair competition faced by SMALL and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs, traders, craftsmen, farmers (though at the centre of the rapporteur's attentions) by the reckless opening of trade borders and the absence of any protective regulation. I'm voting for.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report stresses that unfair commercial practices are a serious problem that can be encountered in many sectors of the economy. This threat concerns, in particular, food supply chains. Unfair practices may consist of: delays in payment, limitation of market access, unilateral modification of contractual conditions, modification of them with retroactive effect or pressures made to lower product prices. The rapporteur notes that these practices are the result of imbalances in income and strength in food supply chains and stresses that the most appropriate means must be found to ensure adequate protection against these practices for food producers and distributors. Furthermore, it is stressed that the supply chains initiative and other national and EU voluntary systems should be developed and promoted more intensively. It is also necessary to develop effective control mechanisms so that complaints can be lodged anonymously and dissuasive sanctions are established, with coordination at European Union level. In view of these circumstances, I voted in favour of the report on combating unfair trade practices in the food supply chain.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The key to developing healthy trade is to support small and local food producers. Their protection against unfair trading practices, which often occur when market forces diversification, should be enhanced. Market domination by large food producers can have a negative impact on the eu economy as a whole, hampering the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. The draft report can contribute to the fight against unfair trading practices.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, because it introduces anti-abuse measures for producers and consumers to try to remedy a number of practices that act against small producers. This report also calls on the Commission for more cooperation and legislation at European level. PPE's amendments to the text delve into this direction, but I maintain discrepancies in form. This report reflects the need for greater cooperation between the weakest links in the food sector, and proposes lines of solution which I believe address the problem. The report was unanimously adopted in committee and our shadow rapporteur's amendments were included, so my vote is favourable.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the report is good, with serious criticism of the status quo, and represents a significant step forward for this Parliament.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain in order to address existing imbalances and injustices in producer-supplier-largest retail chains where farmers are disadvantaged vis-à-vis much stronger commercial operators.  The resolution is in line with the AGRI Committee's efforts to protect the position of farmers most vulnerable to negotiating trade conditions with other actors in the food supply chain. Not only can they not rely on fair income, but are forced to sell at below-cost prices and in order not to lose the customer, very often they do not file complaints.  Clearly, existing competition and fair trade legislation is not enough to overcome vicious practices in food supply chains. I am therefore pleased with the proposal to establish framework pan-European legislation to tackle unfair commercial practices. Such legislation is becoming increasingly necessary against the background of the deepening crisis in various sectors of agriculture – milk and dairy products, pork, fruits and vegetables.  The common agricultural policy supports the establishment of producer organisations which can contribute to strengthening farmers' positions through the possibility of reaching collective supply contracts.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – A number of statistical data and market analyses show that unfair trading practices have intensified in recent years and are particularly widespread at some stages of the supply chain. At least 80% of producers and 96% of those in the food supply chain have found that they have experienced unfair trade. Unfair trading practices pose a particular threat to small food producers, including farmers, who are often forced into disproportionate and unsuserish contract terms by large companies. Moreover, attention must also be paid to the so-called fear factor, where the weaker party often does not take any legal action and agrees with unfair practices, despite the damage, because of fears that the stronger side will end trade relations. It is estimated that suppliers, usually farmers, lose between €30 billion and €40 billion a year as a result of unfair trading practices in the EU. A different ability to achieve more favourable conditions in trading relationships is a completely natural and widespread phenomenon, but the abuse of the strongest market position is already seen as an abnormal relationship between economic operators, which often leads to the development of unfair trading practices. Methods based on voluntary refusal to use unfair practices contribute to reducing this problem, but this is not sufficient to solve the problem in full, so consistent measures must be taken to completely eliminate unfair trading practices and guarantee the proper functioning of the market, as well as fair and transparent relations between all actors in the food supply chain.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. The report puts forward proposals against unfair trading practices in the food supply chain in order to ensure fair earnings for farmers and a wide choice for consumers. The aim of the report is to ensure fair and transparent trade relations among food producers, suppliers and distributors. Fair-trading should in turn help to prevent overproduction and food waste. Farmers and small and medium businesses are particularly vulnerable to unfair trading practices (UTPs). They are sometimes forced to sell at a loss when price negotiations with a stronger party put them at a disadvantage. I voted in favour because I am of the view that income and power imbalances in the food supply chain have to be tackled as a matter of urgency in order to improve farmers’ bargaining power.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a vitally important issue. Producers cannot be the main ones affected by price volatility. We cannot tolerate unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain that end up harming the weakest link in that chain: producers. It is necessary to clearly express our opposition to such practices through this report. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Labour Party colleagues, we supported this report as we want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers when they engage in commercial relations in a highly concentrated market. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front. It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created, whilst workers and farmers suffer. Lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted wholeheartedly in favour of this report because it, together with the report by my Liberal colleague Huitema, send a positive message and belief in the future of our agriculture in Europe. The report focuses on the position of the individual small producer in the chain consultation and the sometimes plight they find themselves in relation to multinationals.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The large distribution is now a central problem that generally affects the entire food production sector. The criticism comes from all branches and coincides in a reality that is tremendous. The large distribution, due to its weight, today absorbs the lion's share of added value throughout the production chain. That is, it lives at the expense of those who produce, crushing the prices paid to producers, and practicing improper margins that are an insult to the thousands of farmers who every day close their companies for lack of profitability. The proposed measures are merely a palliative. The EU so keen on attacking democratically elected national states and governments does not seem too motivated to intervene on this issue, which is pointed out by the general ity of economic actors as one of the main obstacles to the survival of broad economic sectors with emphasis on the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft deals with unfair trading practices in the supply chain of non-food and food. In this context, we see major disadvantages or unfair market conditions, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. Among others in Austria, the dairy sector suffers from this. I therefore believe that this report, which counteracts these developments, is worthy of support.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report together with my Labour colleagues, because we want to put an end to unfair commercial practices against small and medium-sized producers and farmers who face a highly concentrated market of relatively few large retailers who dominate. Voluntary schemes, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, fail to deliver on that front.  It is time for the EU to develop regulatory measures at European level to tackle UTPs and to ensure better enforcement mechanisms are in place at Member State level. Further delay means that UTPs continue to distort the single market, consumers are adversely affected, and competent suppliers close and unnecessary food waste is created, whilst workers and farmers suffer. Lack of action to stop UTPs also undermines the European Growth and Jobs agenda. On the whole, the food sector’s supply chains are full of exploitation of workers, violations human rights, and damage the environment around the world. The EU is one of the only international actors that can act to ensure that food supply chains are fairer and more sustainable, and this is one step towards that cause.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I strongly endorse this report because I believe that the EU is an environment in which all enterprises should be able to thrive. SMEs in particular are the backbone of our economy. Small producers and retailers of food products are a part of this group. Therefore, it is only normal that they receive sufficient protection against UTPs (Unfair Trading Practices). While I strongly support the free market and all the benefits that it brings us, we cannot allow it to be abused. I welcome the fact that in depth-studies into the problems with regard to UTPs have been concluded. Their results clearly show the need for this resolution. However, whatever the actions or legislation that is being called for, one should refrain from unnecessary intervention in the free market.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that small firms have less negotiating power in business relations than large enterprises is natural. However, if they abuse it to impose conditions which are manifestly unfavourable to their suppliers and often contrary to good morals, the result is a restriction of consumer choice and a risk of producer decline, especially in the agrosector. I am not entirely convinced that today we need new European legislation against unfair commercial practices. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of the own-initiative report that calls for precisely this, because I see it as a warning to large firms to start following fair play rules even against small ones.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report records some blatant practices of profiteering and speculation in the food supply chain, which it treats as an exception and a 'distortion' of competition. That is why, under the concept of enhancing the competitiveness of enterprises, it proposes spoof measures, such as the creation of a 'business platform' for the exchange of 'best practices', 'codes of conduct' or the invocation of 'corporate social responsibility of enterprises'. In other words, it instructs the business groups, which operate on the sole criterion of their profits, to "self-regulate" their activities. The creation of business partnerships to control producer and market prices, relentless competition vis-à-vis other groups and the destruction of the self-employed and small VEDs are the operating conditions of monopoly capitalism in the conditions of dominance of large business groups and not 'competition malfunctions', as the report disorientingly attempts to present. This is the capitalist mode of production at the monopoly stage. The pursuit of profit and exploitation will only be eliminated by overturning the power of monopolies and socialising them, with the people in power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report in order to draw attention to the problem of unfair commercial practices in the European Union's internal market. In my opinion, decisive and consistent action is needed to completely eradicate the unfair trade practices that are applied in the FOOD and supply chain in the EU. In view of the general occurrence of this problem and its deepening, the question of the effectiveness of self-regulatory market mechanisms is on the question. In my opinion, this problem requires the introduction of regulations at Union level in order to ensure the proper functioning of markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food and supply chain. Unfair practices must be precisely defined and prevented under the threat of severe sanctions.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Food producers face a number of problems in the common market, including, in particular, abuses by consumers of their products. This is particularly true of large retail chains using practices, because of their dominant position, which can be considered contrary to eu rules.  Unfortunately, not all of them are explicitly described in law, which is why it is so often difficult for injured parties to assert their claims. The most frequently reported abuses are: problems in timely payment of receivables, freedom to formulate and interpret contracts with suppliers, transfer to suppliers the costs of promoting products in stores, the cost of price reductions, as well as the costs of transport and storage of products. All these actions and many other similar unfair practices put producers at a very disadvantage and deprive them of a significant part of their already low income. Especially for farmers and food processing companies in the Polish this problem poses a major challenge and sometimes a threat to their activities.  I agree with the proposals and proposals for solutions set out in mr Czesak's report. There is no doubt that the European Union should pay more attention to protecting the rights of vulnerable operators who are discriminated against and exploited in the food supply chain. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Unfair trade practices in agriculture damage the two weak links in the chain: consumers and small producers. All too often, it has been the large-scale distribution that has abused its dominant position in order to impose its own conditions on others. The European Commission, in its report, acknowledges the spread of these abuses and notes that only a few Member States have implemented legislation to combat them. However, it confines itself to supporting voluntary resolution initiatives based on the exchange of good practice, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, solutions that have proven to be insufficient to adequately protect producers. With this resolution, we have therefore called on the European Commission to present concrete legislative proposals to establish a minimum and uniform regulatory framework at Community level against unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, so as to guarantee a fair income for farmers and a wider choice for consumers. At M5S, we want relations between food producers, suppliers and distributors to be more transparent. I have therefore insisted that we should have shared and harmonised rules that avoid a levelling down of standards and instead develop equal competition between companies from all sources, ensuring that the peculiarities of the culture and history of each territory are protected.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. Unfair trading practices are mainly due to income and power imbalances in the food supply chain and therefore urgently need to address and improve the situation of farmers in the food sector. I join the calls on the Commission to come forward with proposals against unfair trading practices in the food supply chain, so that farmers have fair incomes and consumers have a wide choice.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in this report can I in particular draw attention to paragraph 74 which talks about risk-based analysis and independent scientific evidence? In this House we need to look at and debate the difference between a hazard and the risk-based analysis which this report supports and calls for.  But I also want to remind colleagues of paragraph 33, where we call on the Commission to ensure that consumers and farmers are sufficiently educated in new and emerging breeding techniques, so as to have an open and informed public debate on these issues. I think that we should be working to make this happen, because in the past we have not had an informed public debate on various technologies, which has led to resistance and indeed sometimes total objection to them. I do not want this to continue happening.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I did not support this report because I believe that the legal vacuum in which we are in, pending a legislative proposal by the European Commission on genetically modified organisms and an improved regulation on their disposal and production in the European Union, create preconditions for ambiguities and sending incorrect signals to citizens. In my opinion, this report unfortunately achieves this.  I also do not condone the call on the Commission to use its new scientific advice mechanism, which places greater emphasis on risk-based hazards and the benefits of adopting or not adopting new technologies, products and practices. Agriculture is a sector that provides livelihoods for all of us. Innovation in it must be done in a spirit of measures that are friendly and improving human, animal and plant health, as well as the state of the environment. The risk-based approach model implied in this report is not applicable to the proven European legislative framework and I believe this is the Union's strong advantage in maintaining a sustainable model for the production of harney and maintaining standards that are beneficial to citizens and the environment.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, global food demand is increasing and is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. Healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world today and in the future. Challenges to an increasing global food demand include shrinking land availability, environmental loss and degradation, water shortages, increased energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases.  All of these challenges are putting huge pressure on the agricultural sector and so they must be properly addressed. New technologies have the potential to play an important role in making farming more productive and sustainable and allow the agricultural sector to overcome these many challenges. It is important to ensure there is a vibrant agricultural sector within the EU and a wide range of innovative technologies should be developed across all farming types.  Irish companies have been at the forefront of developing agricultural technology for many years now. A combination of Ireland’s large high-tech talent pool along with Ireland’s strong agricultural sector has meant that Ireland has the capacity to develop many innovative agricultural technologies that are badly needed.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report pushes for productivity and export-driven agriculture. We cannot help noticing that it is the exact opposite of so-called 'sustainable' agriculture. The argument 'we must produce more' is the usual of the pesticide industries pushing for mass production and the introduction of GMOs. I am opposed to an incomplete assessment of the risk of the introduction of new substances, as they are to speeding up the approval processes for chemical pesticides. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it presents many arguments with which I am totally against it. For example, it uses the promotion of new technologies to justify the intensification and increase of industrialization in agriculture, supports new breeding techniques that are nothing more than new GMOs being attempted through the back door, and uses the increase in the world's population as an argument to justify increasing productivity , putting in Europe the task of feeding the world, rather than opting for the food sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture. Despite some interesting findings and measures such as the defence of precision agriculture, crop rotation or the circular economy, this text aims to promote new selection techniques, especially post-GMO. It also includes the desire to let the Commission draw conclusions that are not always based on scientific evidence, and leave it solely to judge the consequences. Finally, the text undermines the precautionary principle of these new techniques and technologies, which opens the door to the acceptance of innovations without prior consideration of risks.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which was particularly regressive and sponsored a principally negative agenda. The report repeatedly called for increased production and the intensification of agricultural activities, using a growing population as the justification for this. Moreover, this report also called for more uptake by famers in the use of drones and ‘technology driven’ machinery, all with the aim of taking farmers off the land and causing considerable extra costs for small farmers. The report suggests that any farmers who lose their jobs as a result of these robotically—driven tractors can simply be retrained, which is a very myopic stance to take. The report further asks the Commission to take into account the use of this technology by farmers when assessing their eligibility for greening payments in CAP, but doesn’t draw attention to the fact that the vast majority of farmers won’t be able to afford this. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Innovation in agriculture and forestry is essential to address the food, environmental and climate challenges of the 21st century. The agricultural world is experiencing multiple crises; innovation - well thought out, well-supported, well-financed - can be a solution to encourage sustainable agronomic and ecological practices, in line with the major challenges we face. But innovation must respect the precautionary principle: that is why we have opposed 'new selection techniques'. Indeed, some of them could potentially be considered GMOs, which it is out of the question to reintroduce by a backdoor means, even as we win battles against GMOs displayed as such. Beyond this issue, innovation must also be thought of in conjunction with a redefinition of cap objectives and integrated into a more comprehensive strategy. If the emergence of new production models is to be taken into account, there is no question of harming or destroying existing quality models adapted to local realities.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture, because we must ensure that tomorrow agriculture is sustainable and able to feed an ever-growing population. However, intensive agriculture is not the only answer to these challenges. We have food waste to deal with first. Innovation and research must accompany the future of agriculture, but always with a view to safe and healthy food, improving the environment, and not only protecting it, but also reducing the consumption of chemicals such as fertilisers and pesticides. The precautionary principle should always be in focus before any approval of new plant protection products.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. It is estimated that by 2050 the world's population will increase by 2.4 billion people, for which more food needs to be produced. However, at least one third – in some areas, almost half – is wasted on food production. In addition, the unhealthy and nutrient-poor diet is also a problem, as more and more people suffer from obesity, cardiovascular diseases, among other things. In order to counteract these unfavourable developments, sustainable food production and healthy eating must be ensured. The former, in particular, is increasingly difficult for farmers to implement, as the declining availability of arable land, environmental losses and damage, water scarcity, rising demand for energy and the emergence of new pests and diseases are putting considerable pressure on our natural environment. For this reason, scientists and farmers should work together to find innovative technical solutions that can increase productivity and sustainability. The aim of this cooperation is to ensure that the solutions developed are realistic and applicable in practice. In order for this benefit to be beneficial to all farmers, solutions must also be found, just as small farms can use the mostly costly and administratively complex technologies. I am also in favour of making agriculture, which is suffering from a shortage of skilled workers, more attractive again and of counteracting the dismantling of training, training and innovation centres.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The heart of this report is the promotion of new breeding techniques, particularly post-GMO. It includes the desire to let the Commission draw conclusions that are not always based on scientific evidence, and leave it solely to judge the consequences. The precautionary principle of these new techniques and technologies is being undermined, which opens the door to the acceptance of innovations without prior consideration of risks. Moreover, this initiative report defends a model of forced productivity, and attempts to hold the European Union accountable - or even blamed. It exacerbates the EU's role in the world's food supply, and makes it almost responsible for feeding the entire planet, in the name of population growth. Therefore, the few good observations distilled on the drip do not weigh heavily in the face of the utopian and dangerous progressivism carried by this report which operates a fundamental challenge to the precautionary principle, which is our leitmotif in our approach to GMOs. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to confirm in the interest of transparency and democracy that I voted against this report. With an ever increasing global population it is important that innovative solutions for sustainable agriculture are found as we move into the future. Farmers have their part to play in becoming more sustainable and efficient as they feed more and more people. We need investment in agricultural technology and scientists should be aiming to work side by side with farmers to tackle to problems we face in the decades to come. Unfortunately the so called solutions in this report would not achieve much.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, the result of a long work by my colleague Jan Huitema, on strengthening innovation in the agricultural sector. Rather than subsidising a status quo that is proving outdated, European agriculture policy should focus more on innovation. Like my ALDE colleagues, I am firmly committed to unlocking the innovation potential of agriculture in order to produce more quality products, ensure food supply and combat climate change more effectively.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. By 2050, food demand is expected to increase by 70%. The declining availability of land, environmental damage and deterioration, water scarcity, increased energy demand and new harmful organisms and diseases put our natural environment under great pressure. This makes it increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way. Technological innovation is a vital part of the solution. The aim of this report is to ensure that Europe has a dynamic agricultural sector that develops a wide range of innovations and technologies in all areas of farming. I agree with the need for investment in research. Insufficient research is being put into practice and farmers cannot take advantage of the opportunities offered by new technologies and innovations. The EU and the Member States, academia and industry, including breeders, the chemical production sector for agriculture, farmers and food producers, must cooperate in improving the practical application of research results.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report that mixes good and bad ideas. While the search for innovation and the willingness to adapt agriculture to today's challenges are indeed necessary, this liberal-inspired report proposes bad solutions. Thus, the text promotes new selection techniques, particularly post-GMO and not based on scientific data. The precautionary principle is trampled on: the text opens the door to the acceptance of innovations without prior consideration of potential risks.  Moreover, this initiative report defends a model of forced productivity.  The few good observations distilled on the drip do not weigh heavily in the face of the exaggerated and dangerous progressivism carried by this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Indeed, while technological change is important to meet challenges such as rising food needs, the text is not acceptable as it highlights a pro-industrial, dehumanized, pro-pesticide and pro-GMO vision to increase food production, the report does not even mention the fight against waste.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The experience of EXPO 2015 Feeding the Planet has placed one of the main themes for the global future on the agenda. Today, population growth, and consequently the demand for healthy and nutritious food, is colliding with a steady decrease in land availability, environmental loss and degradation, water shortages, growing energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases, factors that are subjecting our natural environment to considerable stress. Technological innovation, if well used, can certainly make a valuable contribution to addressing these challenges. That is why I have today chosen to vote in favour of the McIntyre report. The Union must make it more cost-effective to invest in research, basic and applied, and in technology in the agricultural sector, with the primary objective of protecting the genetic diversity of animal and plant species. We must ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all European farmers, and that is why an overall approach must be strengthened that favours the development of specialist skills and knowledge. Only with a look at innovation and forward-looking scientific development will it be possible to hold together the fight against malnutrition and the protection of the environment and jobs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, because I do not share the philosophy or rhetoric of the report, according to which the EU must intensify its agricultural production through greater crop technology, to produce more and export to third countries without the capacity to feed its population. I reject the logic presented in the report that the increase in the world's population justifies an intensification of agriculture in the European Union. On the contrary, I believe that the EU should promote a transfer of knowledge to these third countries, which serves to stimulate production at source, allowing all peoples to move towards their own food sovereignty.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU, which states that it is considered essential to maintain and develop the yield of local species, given their ability to adapt to the characteristics of their native environment and that, in order to ensure the genetic diversity of European agriculture, the right of farmers to obtain plants autonomously and to store and exchange seeds of different species is respected varieties. In addition, I voted against it in relation to the paragraph on which it is essential not to impede the application of high-precision improvement techniques or the conduct of experiments with those techniques without valid justification and that the legislation should be in line with the objectives pursued so as not to be out of date or to be onerous.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this text on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture. Of course, the report has the merit of making some good observations; the need to defend precision agriculture, farmers' breeding rights and access to genetic resources, especially local ones, and their protection is recalled. However, this common-sense effort is negatively counterbalanced by the rapporteur's productivist perspective on the report. The main point of disagreement is in particular the abandonment by the rapporteur of the precautionary principle on the issue of GMOs, since the rapporteur leaves it to the Commission to sort the good grain of the tares in the scientific data and new production techniques. Moreover, the text suggests the almost maternal responsibility of the European Union, which is responsible for producing enough food for the rest of the world, due to an exponential demographics. This is neither Europe's role nor a sustainable solution for a future agriculture.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While presenting ideas that we can support, the text promotes the idea that innovation in agriculture passes for the acceptance of GMOs. As I have always been opposed to the production of gm foods, I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report that focuses on the challenges facing agriculture in the coming years and how solutions provided by technology can contribute to more sustainable agriculture in a growing production demand scenario and a growing shortage of natural resources. The report stresses the need to allocate funds to research, especially within the framework of the European Partnership for Innovation, Skills Development and Knowledge Transfer. It also defends genetic diversity as key to sustainable agriculture and warns against soil degradation as a serious problem for agriculture, so it calls for efforts to improve it and manage water use.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it advocates technological solutions for sustainable EU agriculture. Satisfying the world's growing population of healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. Food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. The declining availability of land, environmental damage and deterioration, water scarcity, increased energy demand and new harmful organisms and diseases put our natural environment under great pressure. This makes it increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way. Technological innovation is a vital part of the solution. Agricultural technologies can make a significant contribution to making farming more productive and sustainable. Parliament believes that the EU should become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. The aim of this report is to ensure that Europe has a dynamic agricultural sector that develops a wide range of innovations and technologies in all areas of farming, whether traditional, organic or other. We must ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all EU farmers. In addressing the problems faced by many large farmers, it is also important to find solutions that can be successfully applied to a lesser extent in rural communities.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, there is an urgent need for the EU and the world as a whole to be able to produce more safe, healthy and nutritious food in order to overcome problems such as malnutrition, obesity, cardiovascular disease, etc. Since, on average, at least a third of the food produced, and even half of it in some sectors, ends up as waste, one of the most effective ways of meeting this projected demand without exhausting limited resources is to use technological solutions to increase production, improve distribution tools and eliminate food waste.  I consider it important to make progress in applied research in recent years, but greater efforts need to be made to ensure knowledge transfer to end-users and to give farmers and other users of agricultural technologies and products, including small farmers, a role to play. I would like the Commission to ensure that, in addition to scientific and technological innovation, traditional techniques and economies can continue to flourish, as they are of immense value: they are safeguards for the diversity of culture, the countryside, history and tourism. At the same time, many regions of Europe provide livelihoods for a whole range of small-scale farmers. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture. The projections show that demand for food is expected to increase by as much as 70% by 2050. Strengthening technological innovation in agriculture is therefore key both to meet the demand for healthy food and to manage the environmental risks that may arise from unsustainable agricultural practices. I therefore support technological development in the field of agriculture, because without proper progress, agriculture will not be able to meet basic expectations: feed people with safe food, provide farmers with decent income and maintain consumer confidence. Research and targeted transfer of knowledge play the greatest role in this. Such research will have a future if we can motivate young people to work in agriculture or agricultural research, because they are the promoters of change. Research also needs to be more transparent, as this is important in order to maintain consumer confidence in the safety of European food. I also support research into new plant protection methods, research that will ensure food safety and research that will provide answers to the questions that climate change is asking us.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I voted with reservations about this report, due to certain ambiguities in the text regarding the introduction and regulation of new genetic technologies in EU agriculture.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The heart of this report deals with the promotion of new selection techniques, particularly post-GMO, as part of a model of forced productivity, leaving the Commission alone to judge conclusions to be drawn from these experiences.  It stresses the EU's role in the world's food supply and makes it almost responsible for feeding the planet in the name of population growth. It calls into question the precautionary principle to which I am firmly attached with regard to GMOs. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which sought to loosen the rules for approval of new breeding practices for plants and animals, and pesticides. The report effectively wanted to set aside certain ‘low-risk’ substances, that could side-step approval processes, without having subjected them to any risk analysis at all. Much of the report was an attempt to deregulate the approval process for pesticides, which in light of recent controversies, is not at all appropriate. I also did not find statements about the need for intensification of food production to justify weakening current approval processes. For these reasons I voted against.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 By 2050, the world's population will exceed nine billion people, a phenomenon that will put unprecedented pressure on the natural resources at our disposal. It is important for the European Union to be ready for this fundamental challenge, encouraging the technological development of agricultural practices capable of promoting the continent's food security through greater ecological sustainability.  With this in mind, it is necessary to promote the consolidation of the circular economy as a new model of reference development, to develop new mechanisms to raise citizens' awareness of sustainable consumption, to promote the transparency of production and supply chains, and to encourage the development of a regulatory framework, particularly within the CAP, which is simpler and more flexible, capable of adapting to an increasingly changing environment.  The European Union and the Member States must invest more in applied research and transnational research, as well as promote an open and constructive dialogue between scientists, farmers and industrialists. In this sense, the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, with around EUR 80 billion of mobilised appropriations, is an encouraging sign, as regards investments and funding priorities at European level, which must, however, be further deepened and encouraged.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to find technological solutions to meet the current challenges in the agricultural world in a sustainable way. While we share some findings, such as the defence of a circular economy or the defence of farmers' breeding rights, we are clearly opposed to the promotion of new selection techniques, particularly post-GMO, are being promoted. Dogmatically, the European Commission draws its conclusions without relying on scientific data. Indeed, the precautionary principle of these new techniques and technologies is being undermined, thus opening the door to the acceptance of innovations without prior consideration of risks. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Satisfying the demand for healthy eating and optimal food intake are some of the world's biggest challenges. Healthy food demand is expected to increase by up to 70% by 2050, and the ever-shrinking availability of land, environmental losses and environmental degradation, water scarcity, growing energy needs, as well as the emergence of new harmful organisms and diseases put considerable pressure on the natural environment, so it is increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way. An important part of the solution is technology innovation. Agricultural technologies have greater potential in agricultural productivity and sustainability, with farmers seeing technology as the only realistic way to respond to current challenges. I voted in favour of the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture because I believe that it is very beneficial for both farmers and sustainable agriculture and for the future to identify viable solutions for achieving organic and healthy agriculture.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By 2050, population growth is expected and food demand will increase directly in proportion to this by 70 percent. Today, there is a positive trend in healthy food on the European market, which unfortunately farmers cannot cover due to several factors such as: reduced land availability, environmental losses and environmental degradation, water scarcity, energy needs, and the emergence of new harmful organisms. Most farmers and landowners are small businesses and the additional costs threaten their survival on the agricultural market. Powerful farmers need state-of-the-art technology, high-performance funding solutions and lifelong education. Technological innovation is an essential part of the solution. The EU has prepared for the next period the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, which is the Union's largest research and innovation programme, with funding of around EUR 80 billion.  I support this report because I believe that the need to improve productivity, competitiveness and environmental performance is not just a matter of economy, but rather a moral obligation of the EP to optimise and increase agricultural production in the most sustainable way possible for the well-being of European citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I am convinced that innovation has the potential to help achieve sustainable agriculture in the EU. I believe that precision agriculture, which is based on data-driven technologies, including satellite navigation tools and the Internet, is capable of generating important benefits for the environment, increasing agricultural incomes, rationalising the use of agricultural machinery and greatly improving resource efficiency, including the use of irrigation water. The Commission should therefore encourage the development and dissemination of precision agriculture by solving the problem of high cost. I note that the collection and analysis of large integrated data sets have the potential to stimulate innovation in agriculture and are particularly useful for addressing and developing an efficient and sustainable food chain. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to remove the barriers to the development of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) in agriculture. We also need more research into innovative practices in the field of plant-soil interactions, which could reduce the environmental impact and use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides and other soil treatments. The Commission should allow the sharing of best practices between Member States in this area.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which sought to loosen the rules for approval of new breeding practices for plants and animals, and pesticides. The report effectively wanted to set aside certain ‘low-risk’ substances, that could side-step approval processes, without having subjected them to any risk analysis at all. Much of the report was an attempt to deregulate the approval process for pesticides, which in light of recent controversies, is not at all appropriate. I also did not find statements about the need for intensification of food production to justify weakening current approval processes. For these reasons I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it proposes very good and applicable suggestions to upgrade conventional farming. Under the pressure of a growing population, deteriorating environment conditions and numerous other problems that the agricultural sector is constantly facing, new solutions are needed in order to help the farmers deal with these. I agree that technology, innovation and research, constant improvements are the keys to tackling the challenges ahead of us. The rapporteur also rightly pointed out that a common approach is needed in order to come up with sustainable solutions to challenges that concern every single one of us.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The general idea of the text is completely opposed to our idea of agricultural production in the EU. For us, in fact, we do not need to produce more, we need to produce better, also considering better management and distribution of waste (just think that 30 % of what is produced within the EU is thrown away). The report also contains a number of problematic points such as the constant progress in innovative animal and plant selection (with implicit green light for new GMOs + clones), new GMO products through genetic editing techniques, classification of certain chemical pesticides as 'low-risk' carried out on the basis of an incomplete risk assessment. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the EU can become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. This report aims to ensure a dynamic agricultural sector in Europe by developing a wide range of innovations and technologies in all types of agriculture, conventional, organic or other. We must ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all our farmers. Finding solutions that work on a small scale in rural communities is just as important as addressing the challenges faced by many of our large-scale farmers.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU is a very important issue that will have a major impact on the lives of Europe's citizens in the long term. The need to find solutions to the problems afflicting the agricultural sector, particularly in the light of the environmental burden, is obvious. However, this does not mean that we can accept the imposition of strict or even complex obligations on farmers and livestock farmers, when their main problems have not been solved. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The future development of the agricultural sector cannot ignore the technological innovations that scientific research makes available. It is a question of increasing crop yields and reducing the environmental impact, both of which are very topical given the still too widespread malnutrition and the need to provide future generations with a healthier environment. This report, outlining the desirability of a regulatory framework that favours innovation in agriculture, looks to the future in the sense I have just described, showing responsibility and strategic vision. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Global food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050 and healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. Shrinking land availability, environmental loss and degradation, shortages of water, increased energy demand, and the emergence of new pests and diseases are placing considerable pressure on the agricultural sector. In this respect, new technologies can play a vital role in making farming more productive and sustainable. I supported this report which focuses on the EU becoming a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability, while ensuring that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all our farmers.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – All societies need good agricultural technology but this does little to deliver it so we opposed it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technological innovation is a necessary component for the progress of the agricultural sector. Agricultural technologies have the potential to make agriculture more productive and sustainable. The European Union and its Member States should strive to make the agricultural sector more attractive to new entrants to agriculture, research and the development of new technologies. I voted in favour of promoting new technological solutions for agriculture because the aim is to make economic instruments and facilities available to all European farmers, even on a small scale. In this respect, it is appropriate to create an environment conducive to innovation by removing any kind of unjustified obstacle.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that innovative technologies should not be limited to one type of agricultural practice and need to be applicable to all farming types being it conventional, livestock or arable, or small or large-scale. Having said that, traditional techniques and farms can continue to flourish, given that these are an immense asset, being a source of cultural, rural, historical and tourism diversity, and provide a livelihood for numerous European small-scale farmers in a whole variety of regions. I want to see more small-scale holdings who gain access to high technology which tailored to their needs. Unfortunately, not all of these technologies are meeting farmers’ needs, either because the technology has yet to be optimised or adapted to local farming conditions, or because it is capital intensive and lies out of reach for the small farmer. Most farmers and landowners are small businesses and minimising the administrative burden on these SMEs is vital. Margins in the agricultural sector are small and extra costs threaten the survival of some small farming operations. Finally, I support skill development and knowledge transfer in these areas, including by means of training and apprenticeships for young farmers and new entrants.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it presents many arguments with which I am totally against it. For example, it uses the promotion of new technologies to justify the intensification and increase of industrialization in agriculture, supports new breeding techniques that are nothing more than new GMOs being attempted through the back door, and uses the increase in the world's population as an argument to justify increasing productivity , putting in Europe the task of feeding the world, rather than opting for the food sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Innovation in the agricultural sector and, in particular, in farm management is crucial with a view to creating a strategic framework and the right tools for the future of agriculture. We are faced with changes which, if not guided, risk overwhelming us. Demographic challenges require adjustments both in food production and in the way we consume and dispose. Some technical solutions can contribute to the reduction of fertilizer use, better exploitation of soil and water, but also create varieties with higher yields, with better resistance to pests, diseases and reduction of environmental impact. This is important. However, their spread must go hand in hand with the need to combat food waste at all levels of the food chain, from production, to retailers, to consumers. I voted in favour because I believe it is important to make the best use of technologies, with a finalisation of sustainable agriculture, but I reiterate the importance of continuing the fight and awareness-raising against food and food waste.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Against the background of global population growth, food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. The increasingly low availability of land, as well as other factors, such as environmental losses, make agricultural technology innovation the only reliable solution. I voted to create an innovation-friendly regulatory environment and to ensure that EU regulations do not act as barriers to them.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Reduced land availability, environmental degradation, water scarcity, increased energy demand, unprecedented pests and diseases are putting considerable pressure on European raw material producers. To address these challenges, the EU should become a world leader in technology, innovation and sustainable development in agriculture. Attention should be paid to the need to develop agricultural technologies in all types of agriculture – conventional, organic and other types. The report stresses that the benefits of technological innovation must be accessible to all farmers, and that finding solutions to small-scale farming in rural communities is just as important as finding solutions to the problems faced by many large-scale farmers. The report draws attention to the importance of precision farming, which can rationalise the use of machinery and reduce the consumption of pesticides, fertilisers and water. It also mentions the importance of innovative plant and animal husbandry and calls on the Commission to publish the final report of the Working Party on New Techniques. I believe that creating a risk-based and innovation-friendly regulatory environment based on scientific evidence and ensuring that EU rules do not become an obstacle to innovation is crucial for sustainable and competitive EU agricultural production on the world market. Nevertheless, due to doubts about the content of the above-that document, I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ New technological solutions could make agriculture more sustainable while responding to the rise of global population, food security issues, increased demand for high protein products and healthier food. I believe that the focus on innovation and the use of new technologies such as ICT in agriculture are things that need to be promoted further. These positive steps can help attract new young farmers, they can help fund research, skill development and knowledge transfer. I agree with the report when it states that soil degradation is a major constraint in agriculture and I agree also with its call for efforts to improve soil and water management. New technologies and innovative agricultural practices could contribute significantly to reduce pesticides and herbicides whilst protecting water and combating soil erosion. However I do not agree that more farming is the only solution to the increase in world food demand. I believe that solutions such as combating food waste are a more sustainable solution. My vote reflected the above concerns.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome my colleague Anthea McIntyre’s report and its focus on supporting innovation through reduced regulation and on the importance of creating a risk-based regulatory environment, underpinned by scientific evidence. Innovation is vital for the future of agriculture, and this report – and all other efforts to support it – are to be welcomed.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture. The European Union must become a world leader in technology, innovation and sustainability in agriculture, while ensuring that the benefits of technical progress are available to all European farmers. In a context where global demand for food is expected to increase by 70% by 2050 and Europe has a moral duty to help feed the world, new technologies are one of the solutions to make crops and livestock more productive and sustainable.  The vote on this report revealed a clear opposition between the EPP, which defends innovation, and the left-wing and extreme groups which, on a precautionary principle built up in absolute dogma, refuse all technological progress, even those that could be beneficial.  I am convinced, like Rabelais, that "science without conscience is nothing but the ruin of the soul", but the absence of science and progress cannot be accepted either. As a defender of the principle of innovation in our agriculture, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture because technological innovation will play a key role in enabling more productivity and more sustainable crops. To do this, a joint approach by the Commission and the Member States is highly recommended.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. It is important to support the agricultural world, which is why I voted in favour of this report.  Today, agriculture faces multiple challenges, such as climate change or the scarcity of arable land. In a context of increasing global population, the rate of increase in food demand is estimated at 70% by 2050. This is why it is absolutely essential to propose concrete solutions for European agriculture that is both economically competitive and environmentally sustainable.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted overall for this text, which speaks at length about pesticides, indicating the need for farmers to become less dependent on these products and calling for a change in the regulatory framework. However, on behalf of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, I have called for a great deal of caution regarding everything that comes out of genetic selection.  Agronomic research today uses new techniques for modifying the living: gene activation or suppression, genome recombination, assisted mutagenesis... These new breeding techniques, called NBT, as the English acronym for "New Breeding Techniques", are closely related to seeds and raise legitimate concerns in that they reintroduce the GMO debate.  Technically, I wanted to distinguish between methods based on transgenesis (insertion of a foreign gene in the genome), which I reject in the name of the precautionary principle, and methods based on endogenous improvement within the same species, at the base of agriculture and practiced for centuries.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for innovation and adaptation to precision agriculture, crop rotation and a circular economy. It defends the access and protection of genetic resources, especially local ones, as well as the breeding rights of farmers. Nevertheless, the text aims to promote new selection techniques, especially post-GMO. It also includes the desire to strengthen the Commission's power to draw conclusions on these subjects, as well as the race for ever-increasing productivity, which is not the solution, but the problem. I also voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The global population is steadily increasing. By contrast, the areas used for agriculture are less and less, while there is a trend of ageing and a decrease in the number of people cultivating land.  That is why we need to make innovation in this sector easier for farmers, no matter how big or small they are. Conversely, farmers must have quick and secure access to research centres. At the same time, we need to be very careful with the so-called " GMO foods, because yes, they give a quick solution to the issue, but this solution comes at a cost to people's health. I supported this report and hope to help develop agriculture in Europe

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the world's population reaches nine billion people, the world's population will grow by 2020. by 2050, we need to find ways to radically change our approach to production. This report builds on Horizon 2020, combining research with innovation and focusing on three key areas: scientific excellence, industrial excellence and social challenges. The aim is to ensure that Europe produces world-class science and technology that boost economic growth. The challenges of sustainable agriculture over time must be addressed with a common approach and not with technological solutions that will have a major environmental impact on the natural wealth of the Member States, which is why we are voting against report A8-0174/2016.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the McIntyre report on technological solutions for sustainable EU agriculture.  Agriculture has always relied on new agricultural business models and practices, including new technologies and production methods to increase yields and adapt to a new and changing environment. I consider precision farming technologies to be of paramount importance for development and innovation. I believe that the principles underpinning precision farming can bring significant benefits to the environment, increase farmers' incomes, rationalise the use of agricultural machinery and significantly increase resource efficiency, including the efficiency of water use for irrigation purposes. I therefore encourage the European Commission to promote policies that encourage the uptake of precision farming technologies for all types of farms, regardless of their size or production profile. I could not support part of the report, I voted against the adoption of the paragraph on new genetic modification technologies. These new technologies have not yet been subject to studies demonstrating the safety of procedures and should therefore also be placed under the general GMO ban for the time being.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it fails to mention working with natural processes that could steer us away from potentially harmful fertilisers and pesticides. The report is not backed up by scientific or economic facts, and contains statements that could undermine rules on health and the environment. Farmers in Wales need support to produce food but also to protect our environment. The two can go hand in hand if sustainable methods are adopted.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Food demand is expected to grow by 70 % by 2050. The reduction of available land, environmental losses and degradation, the scarcity of water resources, the growing demand for energy and the emergence of new pests and diseases put considerable pressure on our environment. Technological innovation is a central part of the solution. The EU must take the world's leading role in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. The search for solutions that result on a small scale in rural communities is equally important in addressing the challenges facing many of our large farmers.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the few good observations distilled on the drip do not weigh heavily in the face of the exaggerated and dangerous progressivism carried by Mrs McIntyre. Above all, it makes a fundamental challenge to the precautionary principle, which is our leitmotif in our approach to GMOs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report assumes that technological innovation is a key part of the solution for the reduction of available land, environmental degradation, scarcity of water resources, increasing energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases. However, it tends to ignore the - economic, social, political - concrete framework for advancing technological innovation and implementing its products. The central concern in this report is to ensure that the EU has the world's leading technology and innovation (with more or less flourishes on "agricultural sustainability"). The whole report is clear from the increasing pressure to create a regulatory framework to facilitate the application of new technological solutions in agriculture, and it is considered that the European agricultural sector is relocating to "more dynamic markets", which is as it says, with the TTIP that is coming, the agriculture sector or further deregulates or else the major producers and large distributors will flee to the USA. It deplores the restrictions that European legislation "places on products and technologies without sound evidence of risk" (affecting GMS, herbicides, etc.), thus discarding any application of the precautionary principle.
