It is business that must prevail over safeguarding the health of populations and the environment.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agricultural and environmental sectors within the EU are experiencing a period of difficulty, also due to issues such as land availability, environmental damage and degradation, scarcity of water resources, increased demand for energy and the appearance of new pests and disease. To respond to all these problems, it is necessary to develop technologies applicable to all types of agriculture, from conventional to organic. The report has the merit of emphasising the fact that the introduction of a regulatory framework that favours and does not hinder innovation is essential if European agricultural production is to be sustainable and competitive on the world market.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because the report is a trumpet for GM.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must think about the future of the agricultural sector, to which the largest part of subsidies continues to flow, and therefore fully support innovation and new agricultural technologies, which, according to many experts and farmers themselves, are the only answer to the current challenges. The European Union must ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all farmers. The European Union and the Member States, academia and industry, farmers and food producers must work together to improve the implementation of research results. It is also important to create a more innovation-friendly regulatory environment and to ensure that EU legislation does not hinder innovation. Without a supportive regulatory regime, European industry will move to more dynamic markets. Too often, European Union legislation imposes restrictions on products and technologies without there being sufficient evidence of risk. If innovation is to be promoted, this legislation must be evidence-based.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because, despite some positive passages, there is a risk in this report of an excessive openness to the use of new technologies in agriculture, for example GMOs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 As the world's population reaches nine billion people, the world's population will grow by 2020. by 2050, we need to find ways to radically change our approach to production. This report builds on Horizon 2020, combining research with innovation and focusing on three key areas: scientific excellence, industrial excellence and social challenges. The aim is to ensure that Europe produces world-class science and technology that boost economic growth. The challenges of sustainable agriculture over time must be addressed with a common approach and not with technological solutions that will have a major environmental impact on the natural wealth of the Member States, which is why I am voting against report A8-0174/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at how new technological solutions could make future agriculture more sustainable while responding to the rise of the global population, food security, increase demand of high protein products in the new emerging powers and demand for healthier food. As such the report focus on innovation and the use of new technologies such as ICT in agriculture, that can for example: attract new young farmers; funding for research, especially under the European Innovation Partnership; skill development and knowledge transfer. I believe we have to make sure that tomorrow’s agriculture will be sustainable and will be able to feed an increasing world population. However intensive agriculture is not the only answer to those challenges. We have to tackle food waste first. Innovation and research should accompany the future of agriculture but with the aim of safe and healthy food, improving the environment by not only protecting it but also and diminishing our consumption of chemical products such as fertilisers and pesticides. The precautionary principle should always be at the core of any authorisation of new plant protection products. I supported its adoption in the Plenary.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the conviction that the nearest future of the EU is about technological development in the field of agriculture, so the EU must assume as its premise a principle of innovation in this field. With population growth, commodity production problems will soon arise, and therefore the need arises for the EU to make policies that support the development of plant varieties that contribute to competitive and resilient agricultural production by safeguarding, preserving and accessing all available genetic diversity in future improvement programmes. This will not only alleviate an agricultural problem, but at the same time create many jobs.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Agriculture remains one of the key industries for our societies and economies and it is very important that we constantly try to ensure and promote the best possibility for innovation and progress in our agriculture sector. The report highlights several important areas where progress can be made to enable this goal: to improve soil and water management; to ensure genetic diversity; to promote skill development and knowledge transfers; and to develop a long term investment and research plan. Moving into the future, it is essential that the European agricultural sector is in the forefront of sustainability as that this could both decrease the negative impacts of agricultural operations and increase the competitiveness and productivity of European farms.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU because I believe that the issue of the sustainability of our agricultural production and livestock farming is one of the central challenges of the near future, considering the increase in the world's population and the consequent increased demand for food. The technology, innovation and new techniques that science offers producers can therefore be useful in the face of these challenges. However, I remain firmly convinced that increased production and intensive agriculture are not the only solution: policies to combat food waste, consumer education policies and policies to protect our land and the environment must therefore increasingly acquire a central role. I also agree with the European Parliament's call for the problem of land use, which is also an important challenge for the security of our territories. Innovation and research can therefore be a key to sustainable agriculture, with fewer pesticides and the use of chemicals.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I was delighted to vote in favour of Mrs McIntyre's report on technologically innovative solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU, as it provides a very important impetus for progress in the agricultural sector. Modern agriculture and the entrepreneurial spirit of young farmers demand such support – Europe should give them.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. To ensure that the EU has a dynamic agricultural sector, the development of a wide range of innovative technologies in all areas of agriculture is crucial. The EU should take a leading role in the world in the field of agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Better management of natural resources is key for sustainable agriculture. The demographic challenges of tomorrow will make it necessary to adapt how we both produce and dispose of food – and in order to do this we must embrace technological innovation. By using technology we can help to reduce fertiliser use, better soil and water management, ICT-based management and real-time data monitoring. Along with S&D colleagues, I stress the importance of small and family farming to the agriculture sector, and that innovation must also be available to them through the European Innovation Partnership. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, because I do not share the philosophy or rhetoric of the report, according to which the EU must intensify its agricultural production through greater crop technology, to produce more and export to third countries without the capacity to feed its population. I reject the logic presented in the report that the increase in the world's population justifies an intensification of agriculture in the European Union. On the contrary, I believe that the EU should promote a transfer of knowledge to these third countries, which serves to stimulate production at source, allowing all peoples to move towards their own food sovereignty.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the European Union because it contains numerous inaccuracies and shortcomings. Promoting sustainable development and innovation in agriculture, as well as the development of agricultural technologies, is of course important and can have a significant impact on the further development of agriculture. However, for this particular report, many key issues have been left unanswered or explicitly omitted. The concept of 'new technologies' has not been properly analysed and it is therefore unclear what these technologies would be and what agricultural sectors they might be used for. These 'technologies' have not been studied in terms of the safety of agricultural production and the protection of the environment, and yet the use of any 'technology' without adequate research and analysis of their impact on agricultural production and the environment can be tragic and irreversible.  As a Member of the European Parliament, I could not therefore support an incomplete report in the vote, the legal, social and economic implications of which have not been fully analysed.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I support the need to improve productivity, competitiveness and environmental performance, and I believe that this is not just a matter of the economy. Technological innovation is an essential part of the solution, and agricultural technologies in particular have the potential to increase the productivity and sustainability of agriculture, and farmers recognise and appreciate this. I also encourage the creation of a more innovation-friendly environment and the ensure that EU regulations do not act as barriers to innovation. These are very important issues. One of these barriers for farmers and landowners is the multitude of administrative burdens in the management of these SMEs, and reducing burdens is essential. Margins in the agricultural sector are low and the additional costs threaten the survival of certain small holdings, and in the absence of a favourable regulatory framework, European industry will relocate to more dynamic markets.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. This is a very important report at a time of a deep farming crisis with low commodity prices. Strengthening innovation is key to improving the situation of farmers, agricultural input industries, traders and food companies alike.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report contained some positive elements, however its one-dimensional approach to the issue of technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU did not allow us to support it. Undoubtedly, the technological solutions introduced in recent decades have lowered production costs and have therefore also increased production. But they have not allyed up to farmers' enormous economic and social problems. Furthermore, the report does not refer to the burning issue of food waste, which is estimated at 30% of production. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. However, I did vote against a number of paragraphs which focused on plant breeding with non-conventional breeding techniques, which include new genetic engineering techniques and called on the European Commission to deregulate these and allow their use in agriculture. Likewise, I voted against calls for the possibility of provisional approval of so-called ‘low risk substances’. Criteria for such substances are not defined, and chemical substances should not in any case be put in the same category as naturally occurring substances. Thankfully, these paragraphs did not make it into the final report.  Overall, the report did make some very good recommendations for European agriculture and it clearly highlighted some of the major pressures it faces. For example, as the global population rises, satisfying the demand for healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. Shrinking land availability, environmental loss and degradation, water shortages, increased energy demand, and the emergence of new pests and diseases are placing considerable pressure on our natural environment. This means farmers are finding it harder to produce food in a sustainable way. To combat this, technological innovation is needed, as this report clearly acknowledges.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it is vital that new technologies play a role in providing nutritious and healthy food while food demand increases in the future.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on technical solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU, because while I support technological progress and a new approach to agriculture on the one hand, I think we should be very careful when it comes to individual agricultural innovations and a progressive approach. In this context, I do not support the current movement of the market that leads to us all eating the same.  Also, the European Union cannot be the only food producer, but it is necessary to ensure that every continent and country is able to ensure its own diversified food production. In addition, I believe that all necessary measures should be taken to avoid unceasing health and the environment and therefore cannot support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The few good drip-feeding findings do not weigh heavily in the face of Ms. McIntyre's exaggerated and dangerous progressivism. Above all, it makes a fundamental challenge to the precautionary principle, which is our leitmotif in our approach to GMOs. I objected to that.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the development of innovative technologies in the agricultural sector in a context of increasing global demand, the scarcity of available land, increased health risks and environmental degradation. The European Union must give itself the means to become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The coming decades are a huge challenge for agriculture. A growing global population, an ageing population, environmental degradation and limited drinking water resources are issues that will come soon. The answer to these difficulties is new production techniques, innovative solutions that will allow for intensive, modern and at the same time sustainable production. A good signal is positive feedback on genetic, mechanical or digital technologies, which now seem to be tools that can respond to the challenges ahead.  Thanks to innovative technologies, both small and large farms, whether organic or conventional, will achieve sustainable development and provide access to food also to needy consumers from outside Europe. For this to happen, adequate funding is required for research into new solutions, but also for equal access to research for all interested, small farmers or large farms.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although this report contains exploitable approaches, the rapporteur draws some incomprehensible conclusions. Similarly, this report does not clearly deny and demarcate genetically modified organisms. I therefore abstain from voting on this report.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The ÖVP delegation in the European Parliament voted against the comments on the new breeding techniques for the following reasons: the Commission is invited to provide a clarification of the legal status of the breeding methods currently under consideration, on the basis of sound legal analysis and scientific evidence. Qualification prior to the publication of this final report of the Working Group on New Techniques is therefore dubious and is not supported by the ÖVP delegation. However, the final report was approved, because agriculture thrives on innovation – it is important that legislation promotes and promotes it and regulates where the precautionary principle requires it.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. It is extremely important not only for meeting growing demand, but also for managing a number of negative factors that affect the agricultural sector.  Changes in the environment, loss of crop yields, soil quality and production are among the main challenges that would be addressed in integrating technologies. They need to be applied in every type of farming in order to become more productive and sustainable. In the meantime, the main priority should be the continuation of the practice of refinement of agricultural holdings, which proves how technological intervention reduces the resources used and increases yields.  Long-term planning and financing of this sector is mandatory in order to achieve a lasting improvement in the sustainability of agriculture, reducing production costs and improving competitiveness.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Agriculture is a key sector for the European economy. In recent years we have increasingly seen an improvement in technologies which, even for agriculture, guarantee innovation and development. The EU could certainly be a world leader in agricultural technology because of its characteristics, which would allow farmers to gain many benefits thanks to the productivity effects it brings. These instruments also allow progress to be made in the selection process both animal and plant by means of techniques that are found to be safe for protection against all pests and diseases affecting crops and to be able to benefit from a healthy and reliable system within the market. Innovation and progress also mean greater safety for consumers. Think, for example, of precision farming drones that allow an innovative management of agricultural activity, also for the benefit of the ecosystem. Agriculture continues to be at the heart of the European political agenda and the major issue of agricultural technologies must be addressed through cooperation between the Commission and the Member States in order to achieve full support.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it praises agricultural productivity. In addition, it gives the EU the unreasonable mission of feeding the whole world.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture. Despite some interesting points (notably the defence of precision agriculture, crop rotation and the circular economy), some paragraphs are unacceptable by the vagueness they cause on new selection techniques.  Moreover, this text praises productivity, gives the European Union food responsibility over the whole world, neglects the precautionary principle, and leaves it to the Commission to draw its own conclusions on selection techniques: it is therefore the sole judge of the consequences.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text focuses on innovation through the development of new technologies and techniques, with a view to establishing sustainable agriculture.  Of course, the adaptation of agriculture to the new needs of society is necessary. The report formulates some lines of thought and action in this regard, starting with the defence of the right to select farmers, the defence of access to genetic resources (especially local ones) and precision agriculture (crop rotation...).  Nevertheless, the text pushes for outrageous productivism and liberalism, which leads to mass production. Good proposals are drowned out by the urgent desire to introduce new techniques such as post-GMO selection. In doing so, the text goes beyond the precautionary principle, which assesses the risks posed by GMOs, is essential for assessing risks. All of these reasons are my vote against the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it presents many arguments with which I am totally against it. For example, it uses the promotion of new technologies to justify the intensification and increase of industrialization in agriculture, supports new breeding techniques that are nothing more than new GMOs being attempted through the back door, and uses the increase in the world's population as an argument to justify increasing productivity , putting in Europe the task of feeding the world, rather than opting for the food sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that it is good to use good technologies in agriculture, but this is to be the role of farmers themselves. I do not agree with the Commission's call 'to support policies that will encourage the development and deployment of precision farming technologies on farms of all types'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The world's population is increasing and it is estimated that by 2050 this number will rise to 9.6 billion, resulting in a 70% increase in food demand. This report aims to bring closer opportunities to secure an active European agricultural sector, which will develop innovative solutions and technologies in all types of agriculture.  The EU should become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. The EU and Member States, including academia, growers, farmers and food producers, must work together to improve the transition from research to practice. It is also important to establish a more innovation-friendly regulatory environment that ensures that EU rules are not an obstacle. Due to reduced arable land, environmental degradation, lack of water, increasing energy demand and the emergence of new pests, the natural environment is under pressure, and farmers find it increasingly difficult to produce food sustainably. I supported this report because an amendment was not adopted aimed at enabling other uses of land, including urbanisation, industry, tourism and recreation, which are competition for agricultural land use.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sustainable agricultural development is actually a necessity for the success of any country (perhaps except the Vatican. The development of new technologies, investment in innovation, mutual cooperation, exchange of experience, the promotion of organic farming and much more constitute a set of things that should clearly be promoted within the EU. Particular attention must, of course, be given to the policy of the use of genetically modified organisms, so as not to distort markets in any way and to endanger the interests and health of consumers. The same applies to the use of chemicals. I agree with the need to promote more active development of genetic banks in agriculture, the protection and distribution of native species, and the promotion of crop impacts with a view to making agriculture more profitable. In terms of governance, it is essential to create a more innovation-friendly regulatory environment and to ensure that Union rules are not an obstacle to innovation. In parallel, more active support should be given to small farmers and businesses at different levels. The same applies to reducing administrative burdens. It is worth noting that, under Horizon 2020, around €80 billion is available for research and innovation purposes. It is necessary that not a small part of these resources contribute directly to the development of the agricultural sector. An important objective is also to provide the necessary skills and to attract knowledge and people to the industry who would like to work there.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the decision taken today. Not only is agriculture and the situation of farmers in the spotlight throughout Europe, but the industry will continue to play a central role in the world in the future. With the growing demand for food, whether conventional or organic, ever-increasing global demand, new technical innovations are constantly needed as an integral part of a solution strategy towards sustainable and even more productive agriculture. As part of a global market, the competitiveness of the sector in Europe must be promoted, as it is currently in danger of losing touch. Targeted investment, conducive regulation and the symbiosis of science, technology and agriculture on the ground will support the European agricultural sector.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The growth of the world's population and the need to ensure its livelihood, together with climate change, require the search for innovation and new technological solutions also in the field of agriculture. In 2050, the world's population is estimated to grow by 2.4 billion to reach 9.6 billion inhabitants. Demand for food will increase by 70%. This situation requires close cooperation between farmers and scientists in research and development of new solutions to ensure healthy, quality and sufficient nutrition, always taking into account the safety of food production, with an emphasis on health and environmental protection. Together, the Commission and the Member States must find a way for a long-term sustainable economy and create the preconditions for constructive cooperation between agricultural and scientific sectors.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Agriculture today faces many challenges: food, environmental, climate and energy. It needs to produce more, improve the quality of its products and ensure better management of natural resources. Faced with this demand for more sustainability, the rapporteur considers it important to use technological solutions: precision agriculture, digital agriculture, but above all those that emerge from the fields of genetic selection and crop protection through the use of pesticides.  A whole chapter of this report is devoted to precision selection techniques, better known as "New Selection Techniques" (NBT), and goes so far as to describe several in detail, some of which can potentially be considered GMOs. Although some passages in the text indicate that particular emphasis should be placed on the development of sustainable agricultural practices (conservation agriculture, agro-ecology, agroforestry) and on the circular economy, the many grey areas surrounding the NBTs encourage me to apply the precautionary principle. As a result, I abstain on this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the European Union sees my vote in favour. We are at an intense moment given the many challenges we face. It is important to be able to take care of the soil, a production of products that do not harm the health of consumers, protecting the richness of diversity. There are many production models to which the agricultural sector has referred and great potential for improvement and also for sustainable development. By investing in agricultural machinery, reliable precision techniques and quality, a remarkable result can be achieved.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about improving the compatibility of technical progress and agricultural production methods. This is intended to increase efficiency in production. However, I do not see any need for faster authorisation procedures for plant protection products and provisional authorisations of low-risk active substances. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the world's population grows, meeting the need for healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. Food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. The declining availability of land, environmental damage and deterioration, water scarcity, increased energy demand and new harmful organisms and diseases put our natural environment under great pressure. This makes it increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way. Technological innovation is a vital part of the solution. Agricultural technologies can make a significant contribution to making farming more productive and sustainable. Parliament believes that the EU should become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. The aim of this report is to ensure that Europe has a dynamic agricultural sector that develops a wide range of innovations and technologies in all areas of farming, whether traditional, organic or other. We must ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all EU farmers. In addressing the problems faced by many large farmers, it is also important to find solutions that can be successfully applied to a lesser extent in rural communities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report makes the situation of agriculture clear: competition for land, scarcity of resources (water, air, etc.) and climate change. And to promote "sustainable" agriculture in this context, the report encourages the development and adoption of 'precision' agricultural technologies, i.e. 'taking into account the variability of environments and conditions between different plots in order to optimise yields and investments'. In fact, under the guise of reducing inputs (because they are better used), it is a new race for equipment requiring expensive technologies and therefore a significant debt of farmers.  To guarantee genetic diversity, rather than to oppose the patenting of life, the text hypocritically proposes "a better dialogue between gene banks, private and public plant research, breeders, end-users".  Some passages are still conceded to the model of organic agriculture: thus, the text admits that "biocontrols (methods of protecting crops based on the use of living organisms or natural substances) could limit the use of traditional pesticides and contribute to better plant resilience". But the account is not there. And, in essence, this report reflects the absolute lack of vision for Europe's agricultural future. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The questioning of Ms McIntyre's fundamental precautionary principle with regard to GMOs is dangerous and contrary to our vision in this area. Despite a timely search for innovations and adaptations of agriculture in the face of current challenges, the overly progressive and ultraliberal ideas put forward by this report lead me to vote against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. It is estimated that by 2050 the world population reaches 9.6 billion people and that food demand will grow by 70%. We must know how to respond to this reality. This means that more and better investment is needed in agricultural technology, as well as in reducing the environmental impact of agriculture.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which provides new technological solutions for more sustainable forms of agricultural production. By implementing the proposals laid out in this report, we can unlock a new phase of agricultural innovation and begin to alleviate the economic concerns of EU farmers.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The agricultural challenges are significant given the strong global population growth. By 2050, the world's population will reach 9.6 billion, 2.4 billion more than today. In the face of this ever-increasing demand, food production will have to increase proportionately, in proportions to between 60% and 110%. The demand for safe and healthy food products for EU citizens is growing. In addition to this demand, there are many yield losses caused by climate change that require adaptation of existing production models.  It is therefore important to support the development of sustainable operating models by emphasizing the urgent need for technology innovation. Technological advances are needed to enable better use and preservation of genetic resources. In addition, it is essential to ensure that the excellence of local breeds is preserved and that farmers have the right to select and exchange plants independently in order to preserve the genetic diversity of European agriculture. The development of emerging technologies within the EU must therefore be encouraged to ensure the sustainability and competitiveness of European agricultural production on a global scale.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Agricultural technologies are needed to achieve productive and sustainable agriculture. European agriculture continues to lag behind many international competitors. Only sustainable and preferential investment in research will reverse this trend. The European Union should become a world leader in agricultural technologies, innovation and sustainability. For this to happen, it is essential to ensure that the benefits of technological innovation are available to all our farmers. Finding solutions that work on a small scale in rural communities is just as important as solving the problems faced by many of our large farmers. In particular, targeted investments in applied and translational research should be the solution. I believe that the cooperation of the European Union and its Member States, academia and industry, including breeders, agrochemicals, farmers and food producers, would also help. Creating a more innovation-friendly regulatory environment is also very important. Without a supportive regulatory regime, European industry will move to more dynamic markets. In view of the above, I fully support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on innovations and use of new technological solutions, such as ICT in agriculture, which might attract new young farmers, help to fund research, skill developments and knowledge transfer. However, intensive agriculture is not the only answer to those challenges. We have to tackle food waste first. Innovation and research should accompany the future of agriculture but with the aim of safe and healthy food, improving the environment by not only protecting it but also and diminishing our consumption of chemical products such as fertilisers and pesticides. Moreover, I am very concerned about the report’s promotion of use of new breeding technologies in farm animals. Such technologies include cloning, genetic modification and gene editing. I am concerned that such breeding technologies will mainly be used to further intensify the EU’s livestock sector. I believe that new technologies such as GM and gene editing other than in exceptional cases where there is a strong evidence that they will be beneficial to animal welfare and will not entrench the use of intensive systems with inherently poor welfare. Therefore, my vote reflected the above concerns.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. The shrinking of available land, environmental losses and environmental damage, water scarcity, increasing energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases put our natural environment under considerable pressure. The report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development states that technological innovation is an essential element of the solution. It advocates the EU's global leadership in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. It calls for Europe to have a dynamic greyhound sector that develops a wide range of innovation and technologies in all types of farming. It states that the benefits of technological innovation must be at the disposal of all farmers. It also notes that European agriculture remains behind many of its international competitors and can only be helped by sustained and prioritised investments in the Research Fund.  I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The increase in the world's population, the satisfaction of demand for healthy food and optimal nutrition, as well as the reduction of available land, environmental losses and degradation, the scarcity of water resources, the growing demand for energy and the emergence of pests and diseases put considerable pressure on our environment. These are the big challenges ahead. Technological innovation is a key part of the solution and agricultural technologies have the potential to make agriculture more productive and sustainable. This report aims to ensure that Europe has an agricultural sector capable of developing a wide range of technologies and innovations for all types of agriculture. It is important to point out that rural areas, in particular the outermost and mountainous regions, are more vulnerable to climate change, with the risk of depopulation and an ageing population, and consequently abandonment of any agricultural activity.  I believe that the challenges of sustainable agriculture must be tackled with a common strategy of the Commission and the Member States to ensure support for technological innovation, a risk-based and evidence-based regulatory framework, the continuity of fundamental research and the development of agricultural skills.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The few good drip-feeding findings in this report do not weigh heavily in the face of Ms McIntyre's exaggerated and dangerous progressivism. Above all, it makes a fundamental challenge to the precautionary principle, which is essential in the approach to GMOs. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report represents an unacceptable endorsement of industrial factory farming, despite its disrespect for the environment and animal welfare standards. Behind the smokescreen of high-tech solutions and ‘precision agriculture’, Conservative MEPs are trying to push forward even more environmental and climate damage. It is unacceptable for Parliament to endorse further increases of food production in the EU at a time of massive food wastage and immense climate impacts of unsustainable meat and dairy consumption. EU agriculture policy needs more balance between food production, environment and climate and cannot keep serving exclusively the interest of big agri-industries.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I support this text on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the European Union. As global demand for agricultural products increases along with the population, while the world's urbanization is reducing the area available for crops, while global warming is disrupting agriculture, it is essential to look now for ways to make agriculture more sustainable and productive.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growth of the world's population and the need to guarantee quality food for all, together with the decrease in arable land, environmental loss and degradation and growing energy demand, are posing major challenges for the agricultural sector. The need to respond to an ever-increasing demand for food, together with the reduction in available resources, oblige us to think about new solutions. Among these, undoubtedly, investing in new technologies is a path that must be pursued with determination, but also with responsibility. I believe that agriculture which is both productive and sustainable must, first and the first thing, ask itself both about the quantity and the quality of its products. In this respect, investing in new cultivation techniques and plant protection products is undoubtedly important, but it must be done in accordance with the health standards that must be guaranteed to our citizens. Finally, I would like to point out that, in the face of 805 million people in the world suffering from chronic malnutrition, optimising agricultural production is not just a task for the EU, but for everyone. We have a moral obligation to rethink our way of life, reducing waste.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We must also stress the importance of technology, innovation and sustainability in the greyhound sector, as this is the only way european agriculture can face the challenges of globalisation. In particular, we must make sure that research and development in the field of agriculture proves useful to the actual final user, as well as to make them accessible to all, including small and medium-sized enterprises and disadvantaged regions. In addition, we must not forget the long-term predictability and sustainability of each sector, because investments are futile if operations are dependent on aid and the aid system is constantly changing.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ By 2050, food demand is expected to increase by 70%, thus satisfying the growing demand for optimal nutrition, and healthy food represents one of the biggest challenges facing the world. I support this report, which aims to ensure support for technological innovation in order to tackle long-term challenges of sustainable agriculture.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Union must strengthen an increasingly clear position in supporting sustainable agriculture. As the world's population and implicitly the European community is constantly growing, with estimates showing that we expect 10 billion to have 10 billion global inhabitants in 2050, the EU urgently needs to identify sustainable ways to improve agricultural production. I am convinced that this improvement depends directly on the creation and use of new technological solutions. That is why I consider it absolutely necessary to propose the report to step up cooperation between the European Commission, the Member States and industry in order to improve the performance of technological systems, systems that would consume fewer natural resources, give a better yield, maintain the same quality of food and, last but not least, reduce pollution.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which sought to loosen the rules for approval of new breeding practices for plants and animals, and pesticides. The report effectively wanted to set aside certain ‘low-risk’ substances, that could side-step approval processes, without having subjected them to any risk analysis at all. Much of the report was an attempt to deregulate the approval process for pesticides which, in the light of recent controversies, is not at all appropriate. I also did not find statements about the need for intensification of food production to justify weakening current approval processes. For these reasons I voted against.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it calls for faster authorisation procedures for plant protection products or provisional authorisations. However, the draft also contains very good approaches that would speak for smaller breeders, but for me the faster approval procedures are a point of criticism.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The growth of the world's population leads to increased demand for food, while agricultural land is less and less and the natural environment is also influenced by other factors. In order for farmers to continue to produce food in a sustainable way, it is necessary to promote technology, innovation and make their benefits more accessible to all farmers.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report highlights the EU's aims to boost innovation and technology on farms through 'intelligent agriculture' or 'precision farming'. It lays down the conditions to ensure the competitiveness of capitalist farms in the EU. It is moving in the direction of the CFP to accelerate and strengthen entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. It paves the way for the development and cultivation of GENETICALLY Modified Organisms, stating directly that "the potential of genetically modified EU crops is not systematically exploited on Farms in Europe, where yields have stagnated in recent years", or elsewhere with associated formalities. The promotion of innovation and research in agricultural production, as proposed in the report, is linked to the struggle of business groups to acquire new, increasingly modern means of production, seeking cheaper production costs that increase their profitability. In capitalism, the direction and orientation of innovation and research serves the interests of capitalist enterprises, not the satisfaction of popular needs, while at the same time poor farmers are being uprooted and food products are becoming expensive and increasingly dangerous and unfit for consumption by workers. The only way out is the alliance of workers, poor farmers, self-employed against monopolies and capitalism.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ All societies need good agricultural technology but this does little to deliver it, so we opposed it.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a context where population growth poses the problem of ensuring food needs and ensuring healthy eating for all people, technology can certainly be an element to focus on. Technological innovation in the food sector could, in fact, be the answer to problems such as the shortage of arable land, water shortages and environmental degradation. Therefore, in my opinion, creating conditions in which farmers can benefit from technological development in order to meet the food needs of a constantly growing world population is of great importance. It must be said, however, that this requires greater cooperation between industry and research, through financial investment and more precise European regulatory standards. In the belief that these measures can be of great use, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is becoming a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. In order for the EU to meet the rising food demand various initiatives would have to be accomplished by 2050. Healthy food and optimal nutrition in the production still remain among the biggest challenges for the EU as well as for the rest of the world. Actions need to be undertaken within a short period to ensure that needs of land availability, water shortage and the increasing energy demand will be met by 2050. In my work and activities as a member of the European Parliament, among other initiatives, I fully support that technological solutions and innovation, which are our best chance to meet the upcoming demands.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against controversial parts of this report that were subsequently dropped, primarily the promotion of a new genetic engineering technique and an attempt to amend the EU legislative framework for GMO with the aim of facilitating the authorization of such techniques and technologies.  The biotechnology industry has been continuously and irresponsibly trying for a long time to convince the Commission of the need to deregulate new GMO techniques, which would ultimately mean that products generated by their application should not be checked and labelled which is unacceptable. Another controversial issue in this report concerned the use of "low-risk chemical substances" - new pesticides for which approval and application were also sought to ease administrative burdens in the approval process.  Both controversial topics negate the precautionary principle and aimed at supporting industrial food production, and agricultural production based on industrial principles results in harmful effects on environmental components: water, air and soil, but also biodiversity, but also on those who consume such food. I am glad that we rejected such proposals because they are contrary to what the EU boasts – the production of quality food on small and medium-sized family farms.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The few good drip-feeding findings in this report do not weigh heavily in the face of Ms McIntyre's exaggerated and dangerous progressivism. Above all, it makes a fundamental challenge to the precautionary principle, which is essential in the approach to GMOs. I am voting against this dangerous text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As our societies face a number of challenges in agriculture and have to play their part, and since it is estimated that by 2050, the world's population will grow to 9.6 billion, which means that around 2.4 billion people will live in the world more than today and that the estimated increase in the world's population to meet and supply food production needs will have to increase by between 60 % and 110 %; first of all, I would like to stress that, fortunately, it is a self-initiated report that has no legislative value or implications for member states' legislation.  However, in the context of the current free trade negotiations and the amendment of legislation authorising GM species at EU level, it should be given particular attention. Together with our Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, we decided to be against certain parts of my colleague McIntyre's report.  I believe that the precautionary principle should continue to be a fundamental principle under which European legislation will be guided, and so far I have stressed in all appearances that we must say no to the pressures of the GMO industry and strongly advocate for the preservation of food production in a natural, safe and clean environment. If any of the contested parts win the support of a majority of my colleagues in the European Parliament, I will vote against the report as a whole.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The world's population is steadily increasing and demand for healthy food is one of the biggest challenges we face. Farmers believe that it is increasingly difficult to produce food in a sustainable way, due to the various pressures to which our environment is exposed, including the reduction of arable land, environmental losses and environmental degradation. A crucial part of the solution is technological innovation, especially agricultural technologies that would make agriculture more productive and sustainable.  To ensure that Europe has an active agricultural sector, we must ensure that all our farmers benefit from technological innovation. I supported MEP McIntyre's report, which aims to develop the European agricultural sector through research into new technologies to drive the progress of sustainable agriculture, making the sector more attractive to invest in.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I have been booked for this report for a long time, I have decided to support it. Finally, our Group of Social Democrats managed to achieve, through amendments, that the report is finally dealing with food waste. This is one of the key issues that has received little attention in the long term. At present, it is already necessary to have a solution in order to have sustainable agriculture that can feed the world's population. Innovation and research should be part of the future of agriculture, targeting safe and healthy food. Moreover, I believe that this report will contribute to improving the environment by reducing the consumption of chemical products, fertilisers and pesticides. We have also succeeded in pushing for the precautionary principle to be at the heart of any authorisation of new plant protection products.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decrease in land availability, environmental loss and degradation, water shortages, growing energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases are putting considerable strain on our natural environment. The result is that it is increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way. Technological innovation is a vital part of the solution. Agricultural technologies, in particular, have the potential to make agriculture more productive and sustainable. Recent investment and new funding priorities at Member State level are encouraging. The Horizon 2020 Framework Programme is the EU's largest research and innovation programme, with around €80 billion of funding available over 7 years. I voted in favour of adopting this report and I hope that the long-term challenges of sustainable agriculture can be addressed with a joint approach by the Commission and the Member States to ensure adequate support for technological innovation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Reduced land availability, environmental losses and environmental degradation, water scarcity, increased energy demand, unprecedented pests and diseases put considerable pressure on European raw material producers and the environment. To address these challenges, the EU should become a world leader in technology, innovation and sustainable development in agriculture, but European agriculture is still lagging behind many of the Union's international competitors.  The rapporteur draws attention to the need to develop agricultural technologies in all types of agriculture – conventional, organic and other types – and calls for greater access to and commercialisation of research, which would allow farmers to take advantage of the opportunities offered by new technologies and innovation. The report stresses that the benefits of technological innovation must be available to all farmers, and that finding solutions to small-scale farming in rural communities is as important as finding solutions to the problems faced by many farmers running large farms. The rapporteur draws attention to the importance of precision farming, which can benefit the environment, rationalise the use of machinery and reduce the consumption of pesticides, fertilisers and water. It also mentions the importance of innovative plant and animal husbandry using proven techniques and calls on the Commission to publish the final report of the working group on new techniques. I abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union and its Member States need to be aware of the importance of new technologies in the search for more productive and sustainable agriculture, especially at a time when global demand for food is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. It is with these issues in mind that I voted for this text, which insists on innovation in agriculture, for the European Union to become a leader in the sustainability of the sector, while ensuring that the benefits of progress are shared equally among our farmers.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The report under consideration highlights the challenges in the fields of agricultural production in the context of increasing the world's population and in line with the requirements for optimal nutrition and demand for healthy foods. The rapporteur argues that Europe must optimise its production, also in the agricultural sector, in order to ensure the sustainability of resources and make the most of technological innovation. To this extent, taking the world's leading in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability, while ensuring access to the benefits of technological developments for all European farmers, is of decisive importance. On the other hand, Europe lacks human capital and technical know-how in the fields of agronomy and phytopathology and it is therefore clear that the sustainability of agriculture in Europe involves bringing farmers and scientists together in order to improve the practical translation of research and foster a new phase of agricultural innovation. Because of the foregoing, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ All societies need good agricultural technology but this does little to deliver it, so we opposed it.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. By this lunchtime vote, Parliament has asked a very large majority for the Union to put innovation back at the heart of the European agricultural project. The EU must use the full potential of 21st century technologies, both mechanical and digital, to become a world leader in this field.  It is an economic issue, but also an imperative of environmental performance in a world increasingly vulnerable to the symptoms of global warming: unusual heat, water shortages, the appearance of new pests.  We also need to implement the agricultural model that will respond to malnutrition, at a time when nearly 850 million people worldwide suffer from it, and global demand for food is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. Any solution will require bringing Member States, academia and industry (from seed companies to producers and processors) closer together to revitalise the sector and create a more dynamic agricultural market. In view of the new techniques for selecting plants, Parliament insisted on not deciding whether they fall under the GMO directive until it had received the Commission's legal analysis, expected in 2016.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. With the vote of this report, the European Parliament considered that innovation could contribute to sustainable agriculture in the EU and that precision farming technologies are particularly important.  Parliament stressed the importance of opening up the conservation of genetic resources to a greater diversity of plant and animal species and ensuring that research funding translates into technological improvements in agriculture and horticulture.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I want to draw my colleagues' attention to this post. Although well written, the bigger side is attempts to legitimise dubious agricultural practices, such as genetically modified products. Anyone who advocates healthy food, those who want to know what they eat, should vote 'against' it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted favourably on this resolution on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU, which aims to warn of the increasing difficulty in producing food in a balanced and sustainable way, given the scarcity of land (fertile) and available water resources, as well as the increasing degradation of our environment. The recommended solution proposes to make use of the technological innovations we have in the agricultural sector, making it more innovative, competitive and sustainable in the long term. It is also relevant that the use of these new technologies in agricultural production may also be at the service of the vast majority of inhabitants of developing countries, who are hostages to chronic malnutrition and maltrunição. The new Horizon 2020 framework programme could provide a window of opportunity in financing agricultural research and innovation. A new, more simplified and innovation-friendly regulatory framework will also be key to achieving a more modern and competitive European agricultural sector on a global scale. Only concerted work between the EU institutions, member states, academia and the agricultural sector will enable us to develop cutting-edge technological solutions for truly sustainable and competitive agriculture that will enable Europe to move into a new phase of agricultural innovation.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report adopted in the AGRI Committee aims to ensure the development of technological innovations at the service of the agricultural sector, whether conventional, organic or otherwise. In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this text. I believe that technological innovation applied to agriculture can deliver important results in the challenges to which many of our farmers are exposed both on a small and a large scale.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, because I do not share the philosophy or rhetoric of the report, according to which the EU must intensify its agricultural production through greater crop technology, to produce more and export to third countries without the capacity to feed its population. I reject the logic presented in the report that the increase in the world's population justifies an intensification of agriculture in the European Union. On the contrary, I believe that the EU should promote a transfer of knowledge to these third countries, which serves to stimulate production at source, allowing all peoples to move towards their own food sovereignty

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Report on Technologically Innovative Solutions for Sustainable Agriculture in the EU". Global food demand is constantly increasing and will continue to do so in the future. That is why we need innovative technological solutions, including in the field, in order to be able to feed our population adequately. Innovative technology in all areas of agriculture will be promoted much more in the future in order to facilitate and revolutionise sustainable agriculture.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I share the view highlighted in this report that we need to increase agricultural productivity in a sustainable way. That is why we need more extensive cooperation between researchers and farmers, as well as stronger and more successful transfer of knowledge to end-users. This also obviously requires a more innovation-friendly EU regulatory framework.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it presents many arguments with which I am totally against it. For example, it uses the promotion of new technologies to justify the intensification and increase of industrialization in agriculture, supports new breeding techniques that are nothing more than new GMOs being attempted through the back door, and uses the increase in the world's population as an argument to justify increasing productivity , putting in Europe the task of feeding the world, rather than opting for the food sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decline in the availability of agricultural land, environmental damage and degradation, scarcity of water resources, increased energy consumption and the emergence of new diseases are putting a lot of pressure on agricultural producers and the environment in the European Union. The EU is pursuing technological solutions to address these major challenges, especially to create more sustainable agriculture, as population growth and related demand for healthy food are putting a strain on the entire ecosystem. This report therefore stresses the importance and the necessary cooperation between the EU, the Member States, universities, industries and, above all, farmers, so that research carried out in laboratories can be directly and quickly applied in the agricultural sector. In this way, new technological solutions can be found and existing ones implemented to promote sustainable agriculture in the EU. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Innovation must be at the service of all types of farm, including those of a more modest or family size, for which the outermost regions can be a good laboratory. Innovative solutions can contribute to more effective agriculture in the use of resources that improve farmers' competitiveness. The text we discussed includes references to new breeding techniques. With regard to these, I believe that we cannot adopt an obscurantist position, because we must and have an obligation to create an environment conducive to the development of science, but always, and I repeat, always, with powerful and very precautionary precautionary measures with regard to the impact on the environment and the health of animals and people. More debate and more information are required so that we do not take too aprioristic positions. We must not prevent the development and work of research centres in these matters, but, in reinforcement, we must be very cautious in moving to production and consumption.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome parliament's adoption of the report by our colleague Anthea McIntyre from the Committee on Agriculture. The world's population is steadily growing – forecasts say that we will be close to 10 billion in 2050, and at the same time the opportunities for increasing the area of cultivated land on Earth are exhausted, and recently it is clear that it will even be depleted due to increasing pollution, yufishing, desertification or intensive urbanization. The growing water deficit, the threat of epidemics of plant and animal diseases and the unpredictable effects of climate change are also a challenge.  Action is therefore needed to develop more sustainable agriculture, based on respect for the environment and local communities. One solution is, for example, precision farming, which gives m.in the possibility of significantly reducing the use of pesticides.  There is no doubt that, in order to meet the challenges of the near future in agriculture, big changes must take place, not to say revolution, and efforts must be made to keep Europe at the fore of these changes. That is why this report is so important. At the same time, we must take into account that innovative technological solutions are intended to be costly, which can be a problem for most family farms that dominate Europe. They must therefore be accompanied by appropriate measures and financial support for the universal availability of innovation for all farmers.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was not able to support my other Socialist colleagues on this report as I believe that it represents an unacceptable endorsement of industrial factory farming and its utter disrespect for the environment and animal welfare standards. Behind the smokescreen of high-tech solutions and ‘precision agriculture’, conservative (both small ‘c’ and large ‘C’) MEPs are trying to push forward even more environmentally damaging policies. It is completely unacceptable for Parliament to endorse any further increases of food production at a time of massive food waste and the immense climate impacts that unsustainable meat and dairy consumption produces. The agricultural policy of the EU needs to be made more balanced, taking into account food production, the environment and climate change. It cannot keep serving the interests of big agri-industries as it has been doing almost exclusively.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The world is currently facing very worrying challenges, which also have a significant impact on agriculture (declining land availability, environmental damage and degradation, water scarcity, increased energy demand, the arrival of new pests and diseases). Sadly, today more than 1 billion people are suffering from malnutrition and it is becoming increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food sustainably. I supported the resolution because I consider technological innovation to be an essential part of solving this serious problem. I also believe that it is only through agricultural technologies that agriculture can be more productive and sustainable. However, I also consider it a worrying signal that the world's population will reach 9.6 billion by 2050, which will mean an increase of 2.4 billion compared to today, and the world will have to produce 70% more food, feeding, fibres and biomass on smaller agricultural lands and under climate stress. I expect the EU and its Member States to take measures that will help farmers produce more food for eu and world citizens that is safe, healthy, nutritious and with less impact on the environment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Given the growth of the world's population, one of the biggest challenges facing the world is how to meet the demand for healthy food and optimal nutrition. Demand for food is expected to increase by 70% by 2050.  The de-scarcity of available land, environmental damage and environmental degradation, water scarcity, increased energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases put significant pressure on the natural environment. As a result, the report highlights that it is increasingly difficult for farmers to produce food in a sustainable way.  Although I understand the above facts about the growth of the world population, I am opposed to some of the technologies supported in the report, as they promote the strengthening of the industrialisation of agriculture, such as new technologies for the cultivation of GENETICALLY MODIFIED mechanisms. I also think it is anything but positive that the report undermines the Nagoan Protocol on access to genetic resources and fair and fair sharing of benefits. What is more, I am opposed to the fact that the abovementioned growth of the world population is used in the report to justify the intensity of food production contrary to the principles of food sovereignty.  In summary, I believe that the technological solutions mentioned in the report are quite poor, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. This is a very bad report, clearly written by the agri-industry. It's at odds with what me and the greens stand for. It seems that it wants to pave the way for two dossiers that are pending before the Commission. It wants to keep the so-called new gene techniques out of current GMO legislation. And it sets criteria to approve so-called 'low-risk pesticides'. Not only could 15 to 30 new pesticides be introduced to the market, but the report also eliminates the need for the REFIT check (for better regulation) to review existing EU legislation on plant protection products. It also undermines the precautionary principle by driving an (American) agro-chemical approach in the pesticide approval procedure. For example, the focus is on possible damage afterwards, while Europe is driving a pre-risk assessment. In the context of the TTIP negotiations, this report is very convenient for them. The report undermines the entire international Nagoya protocol on combating biopiracy. The fact that the text touches on so many environmental issues and has not even been before the Committee on the Environment shows bad will and is actually unacceptable. On top of that, the one-sided choice for intensification of agriculture and precision agriculture is the only future.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Technological progress does not even miss agricultural production, and the European Union should encourage any innovation that makes it possible to produce more safe and cheaper food.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although we wish to encourage farm innovation and productivity, this is not the right way to do it.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Meeting the demand for healthy food and the need for optimal nutrition is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. Food demand is expected to grow by 70% by 2050. Technological innovation is a crucial part of the solution. Agricultural technologies have the potential to make agriculture more productive and sustainable.  To ensure that Europe has an active agricultural sector, we must ensure that all our farmers benefit from technological innovation. Finding solutions that are successful in small rural communities is as important as solving the problems many of our large farms face. The EU and member states, academia and industry, including growers, the agrochemical sector, farmers and food producers must work together to improve the conversion of research into practice, from laboratories to farms to consumers. This will allow Europe to start a new phase in the field of agricultural innovation. I support the proposal for this Resolution, as I believe that the European Union should become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. I also believe that the European Union must introduce new technologies in the agricultural sector to make farming more sustainable and productive.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU.  Due to the growth of the world's population, malnutrition, obesity and various cardiovascular diseases, there is a growing need to produce more safe, healthy and nutritious food.  As in other sectors, innovation can contribute to achieving sustainable agriculture in the European Union. In addition, we can also ensure the protection of the environment through various innovative approaches, in addition to increasing farmers' incomes and making more efficient use of resources.  I join the call for industry, the Commission and the Member States to work together to improve the efficiency and adaptability of robotic and other techniques in the context of over-agricultural farming, in order to increase farmers' demand and investment and to make effective use of agricultural and horticulture research resources.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 As the world's population reaches nine billion people, the world's population will grow by 2020. by 2050, we need to find ways to radically change our approach to production. This report builds on Horizon 2020, combining research with innovation and focusing on three key areas: scientific excellence, industrial excellence and social challenges. The aim is to ensure that Europe produces world-class science and technology that boost economic growth. The challenges of sustainable agriculture over time must be addressed by a common approach and not by technological solutions that will have a major environmental impact on the natural wealth of the Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that intensive food production due to population growth must be developed in a sustainable manner, as the world's population is expected to reach 9.6 billion by 2050, an increase of about 2.4 billion people compared to the world's total population today. I therefore voted in favour of this report. I believe that an important element of this process is the reduction of food waste, which has reached critical proportions in each Member State. To address this, I propose the development of socially minded instruments at EU level. Another important element is innovation, which I believe will be successful if actual farmers are given the opportunity. I consider the European Innovation Partnership to be good, but it would also be good to see concrete results. In some Member States, such as Hungary, the lack of a balance between livestock production and crop production, as well as responsible land use and precision tools such as efficient irrigation systems, is still a problem. The issue of energy is another major challenge, as global energy demand is projected to increase by 40% by 2030, and I agree that this need needs to be met by increasing energy efficiency and building a secure energy mix including renewable energies. Unfortunately, the Hungarian government is also lagging behind in this too. Of course, this requires resources, but in the absence of this, we can only talk about a theoretical debate. The Commission should therefore propose concrete solutions.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. By 2050, the world's population is expected to reach 9.7 billion, which means farmers will have to produce food for an additional 2.4 billion people. It is estimated that global food production will have to increase by 60-110 %. It is extremely difficult to meet the challenge of ensuring food security by increasing production without compounding existing environmental problems. Innovation in agricultural technology is key to addressing some of the biggest challenges facing agriculture today, given climate change, the increase in food demand resulting from the growth of the global population, and the threat to the environment. The European Parliament's report rightly points out the need to encourage innovative research and support, for example, precision farming, genetic diversity, soil management, water management and plant protection products. The document also encourages cooperation between scientists and farmers, and stresses the need to ensure an adequate transfer of knowledge towards end-users. I believe that the solutions proposed in the European Parliament's report are appropriate, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this document.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because innovation in the agricultural sector, which can offer new opportunities to farmers affected by the agricultural crisis, must be supported. I supported the report's idea that economic and sustainable development can go hand in hand and are not mutually exclusive. Supporting innovation is a strong step from the point of view of promoting competitiveness, and more effort needs to be made in this in the EU.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growth of the world's population and food needs will, in the coming years, put more and more pressure on the field of agriculture and on ensuring the food security of citizens. At the same time, environmental losses, environmental degradation, water scarcity and the emergence of new types of pests will create additional difficulties for farmers.
