One of the solutions to these phenomena could be technological innovation, manifested by the application of new agricultural technologies, of a genetic, mechanical or digital type. The European Union can become a world leader in agricultural innovation and sustainability through conventional, organic or other improvements that would be available to farmers. However, competitors outside Europe are currently making more progress than EU states, which highlights the need for investment in agronomic research at European level in order to be competitive at global level.  At the same time, however, this report does not address other solutions to this problem, such as combating food waste, preserving biodiversity and diversifying crops. Widespread use of pesticides, chemical fertilisers and new hybridisation techniques may jeopardise the quality of the food obtained.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The report focuses on innovation in agriculture, including agricultural management. The report highlights the need to combat food waste: in Europe, 100 million tonnes of food are consumed each year in Europe. The report highlights a range of techniques aimed at reducing fertilizer use, better soil and water management such as precision agriculture.  Thanks to the work of the socialists, the report has been improved: we find concepts such as reference to small family farms, animal welfare, the fight against food waste, the role of agro-forest systems, all of which were non-existent in the draft report. However, it is a report that looks at agriculture from a productive perspective: to produce more and more, now with the "innovative" tools of varietal creation, without these being specifically named: "genome editing" techniques that the industry does not want to see qualified as "genetic modifications" but for which it still wishes to obtain patent protection. So I rejected that proposal.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am convinced that investing in innovative practices in the agriculture sector is crucial for the EU to develop a model of sustainable agriculture and to remain competitive in this domain. I voted in favour of this report, which contains several concrete measures on how to boost innovation in this sector. Our main task will be to develop more resource-efficient agricultural practices, encourage crop variety to ensure biodiversity, increase food safety and tackle food waste. This can be achieved through big data, a greater dialogue between genetic banks, skill development, research, crop rotation, but also through the removal of unnecessary and burdensome regulations. Prioritising investment in the circular economy and climate-smart farming practices will be of particular relevance to achieve our goal.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Our agricultural model faces new challenges. The prospect of having to feed nearly 9 billion people by 2050, curbing global warming and better managing resources is pushing us to rethink our models and innovate. Technology can be used to make our agricultural production methods more efficient and sustainable. As far as agricultural innovations are concerned, the scope of possibilities is wide and we must be determined to encourage and develop scientific initiatives in terms of technology, agricultural practices or the social organisation of agriculture. But innovation cannot be exempt from the precautionary principle. A majority of which I am a member thus opposed the 'New Selection Techniques', for lack of sufficient scientific evidence to allow them to be considered non-GMO.  The report calls for more involved farmers in research and innovation processes. This is a remarkable consideration because it ensures that farmers are involved in the agricultural transition. Farmers must be involved in technological and environmental progress. It is with this in mind that the European Parliament adopted the McIntyre report.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, the biggest challenge the world will face in the future is to meet food demand. This is about systematic population growth. I voted in favour of the report because it talks about, first of all, the need for healthy food production. By 2050, the need for healthy food will increase by 70 percent. This fact may be an opportunity for agriculture in countries such as Lithuania, where there is a great potential to develop organic farming. But let us not forget that this development cannot in any way be based on GMOs, that is, genetically modified foods, because it is a threat to ecosystem and biodiversity. Healthy food is free from GMOs.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Rural areas, especially agricultural ones, are most exposed to real and potential climate change and it is necessary to adapt agriculture to changing circumstances using all available technical solutions. I believe that precision farming is essential for achieving sustainable agriculture of the European Union and requires the reliability of technology, but also the need for innovation to address high development costs. Agriculture is a sector that enjoys European support, and this also shows its importance and key role in the use of natural resources and the economic development of rural areas. But since I disagree with promoting genetic technology as the only realistic way to face the current challenges, I voted abstaining.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. One of the biggest challenges of today is how to ensure demand for a healthy diet, with the latter expected to increase by 70% by 2050. Technological innovation is a key part of the solution, because agricultural technologies have the potential to increase the productivity and sustainability of agriculture. The European Union should become a world leader in agricultural technology, innovation and sustainability. European agriculture lags behind its international competitors, but this can only change in the case of sustained and prioritised investments in the research base. The starting point should be targeted investments in applied and translational research. Although farmers and scientists play different roles in the innovation process, better outcomes can only be achieved if both sides cooperate more closely. It will be crucial to provide the necessary knowledge and skills and to attract the right expertise to the industry. It is also important to create a regulatory environment that favours innovation while ensuring that EU rules do not hinder them.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, because I do not share the philosophy or rhetoric of the report, according to which the EU must intensify its agricultural production through greater crop technology, to produce more and export to third countries without the capacity to feed its population. I reject the logic presented in the report that the increase in the world's population justifies an intensification of agriculture in the European Union. On the contrary, I believe that the EU should promote a transfer of knowledge to these third countries, which serves to stimulate production at source, allowing all peoples to move towards their own food sovereignty.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The innovation, new business models and precision agricultural technologies are particularly important to increase performance and adaptation to new and changing production methods and circumstances. Economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive and can be achieved through innovation, especially in rural and mountain areas with fewer opportunities for its citizens and most at risk of depopulation. I am in favour of these measures to improve agricultural and rural development opportunities.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report mixes good and bad ideas.  While the search for innovation and adaptation of agriculture to today's challenges is not bad in itself, this report takes the opportunity to open doors to many ideas that are too progressive and liberal. Among the good findings and measures are: - the defence of precision agriculture, crop rotation, the circular economy... - the defence of access to genetic resources, especially local ones, and their protection, - the defence of farmers' breeding rights... Nevertheless, the heart of the text is not there, but in the promotion of new selection techniques, especially post-GMO. The precautionary principle of these new techniques and technologies is being undermined, which opens the door to the acceptance of innovations without prior consideration of risks. Moreover, this initiative report defends a model of forced productivity and indeed exacerbates the EU's role in the world's food supply, and makes it almost responsible for feeding the entire planet, in the name of population growth. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Estimates show that food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. Therefore, optimal and healthy eating will become one of the most important challenges the world will face. The reduction of available land, environmental degradation, water scarcity, increased energy demand and the emergence of new diseases put considerable pressure on the agricultural sector. From this point of view, the present report supports the introduction of new technologies, which can play a key role in crop productivity and sustainability. In order to ensure a strong agricultural sector, it is essential to develop a wide range of innovative technologies for all types of operators. The report stresses that the European Union should become a world leader in technology, innovation and sustainability in agriculture, while ensuring that the benefits of technological progress are available to all farmers.  In this respect, the report – which I voted for – calls on the European Commission and the Member States to develop a long-term investment plan containing cost-effective solutions applicable to small producers, rural areas, outermost regions and mountain regions.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the global population grows, meeting the demand for healthy food and optimal nutrition has become one of the greatest challenges in the world today. Food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. The shrinkage of available land, environmental losses and environmental damage, water scarcity, increasing energy demand and the emergence of new pests and diseases put our natural environment under considerable pressure. For this reason, the sustainable production of food for farmers is an increasing test. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, because I do not share the philosophy or rhetoric of the report, according to which the EU must intensify its agricultural production through greater crop technology, to produce more and export to third countries without the capacity to feed its population. I reject the logic presented in the report that the increase in the world's population justifies an intensification of agriculture in the European Union. On the contrary, I believe that the EU should promote a transfer of knowledge to these third countries, which serves to stimulate production at source, allowing all peoples to move towards their own food sovereignty.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this included many negative proposals – weakening the Nagoya international protocol against bio-piracy and promoting new breeding technics and new GMOs amongst others.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. The report emphasises that the agriculture sector has always relied on new farm business models and practices that include new techniques and production methods to increase outputs and adapt to new and changing circumstances. The report equally underlines that ecosystem services, such as nutrient cycling, are of central importance to agriculture, and that some functions, such as carbon sequestration, go beyond food production. I voted in favour because I am convinced that innovation has the potential to contribute to achieving sustainable agriculture in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report rightly addresses the need to incorporate innovative technologies into agriculture in order to respond to a growing global demand for food and to do so in a healthy and nutritious way. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The McIntyre report, together with the Huitema report, send a positive message to our producers. I voted with conviction in favour of this report because it contains very detailed proposals that can help our farmers and bring about innovation. Nor does the responsibility of the government in this report be mitted.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report contains positive and relevant aspects. Yet it passes alongside reality. And reality tells us that today, in the Western world, too much food is produced, you pay to eliminate food products. Today's technology applied to agriculture has become a problem that will only end with a new economic model of production and distribution. Technology is now at the origin of intensive production that endangers biodiversity and the balance of our planet. GMOs and glyphosate, which the Commission has considered to extend for another seven years, are illustrious children of this technology. We do not deny the need for further research in agricultural practices. But first we have to understand each other. Agriculture subject to the laws of capitalism and the maximum accumulation of profit can only give rise to increasingly intensive and productiontechnologies.  Before talking about technology, it is therefore important to reverse our cap today completely liberalised.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting here, although, for example, the appreciation for the smaller breeders and local varieties, as well as a scientifically independent regulatory framework, deserve my approval. However, I cannot agree with the need for faster authorisation procedures for plant protection products and provisional authorisations of 'low-risk' active substances. Similarly, the demarcation with genetically modified agriculture does not go far enough for me.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this parliamentary resolution. A stable food supply is indispensable to the health of the EU citizen, but also for the rest of the world. However, we are currently facing strong challenges in this regard. As demand will only increase towards the future, we need to address these challenges. It is my belief that technology plays a pivotal role in providing these solutions. It will enable us to obtain our environmental goals, while at the same time maintaining our productivity and competitiveness. Thus, this resolution’s main message is to support the use of technology in agriculture. One way of doing this is to support R&D. But we also need farmers and scientists to be working closer together. With regard to the latter, we need to ensure that we attract the necessary expertise. In addition, they need to be provided with the necessary resources. Finally, I also recognise the high potential of Horizon 2020 in the development of Agri-Tech.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. The proposals included by the rapporteur in this initiative aim to support the creation of a sustainable and competitive European agri-food chain. The rapporteur calls on the European Commission to include the principle of innovation as a global policy orientation in all individual work programmes and legislative measures.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am very much in favour of this report, as I think it is very positive for the EU economy and for general well-being. To be sure, the agricultural sector must be boosted, in economic terms, to continue to create jobs and to try to consume the largest number of products produced in the EU. In terms of social welfare, it is necessary to try to ensure sustainable agriculture, which does not harm the environment, nor consequently, health. For all this, innovation applied to technology is a key tool. In Spain, for example, innovation has been regarded for years as an indispensable tool in ensuring the viability of the agri-food sector. I therefore very much agree with the initiative to enhance the development of technological and innovative solutions that enhance sustainable agriculture in the EU.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report highlights the EU's aims to boost innovation and technology on farms through 'intelligent agriculture' or 'precision farming'. It lays down the conditions to ensure the competitiveness of capitalist farms in the EU. It is moving in the direction of the CFP to accelerate and strengthen entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. It paves the way for the development and cultivation of GENETICALLY Modified Organisms, stating directly that "the potential of genetically modified EU crops is not systematically exploited on Farms in Europe, where yields have stagnated in recent years", or elsewhere with associated formalities. The promotion of innovation and research in agricultural production, as proposed in the report, is linked to the struggle of business groups to acquire new, increasingly modern means of production, seeking cheaper production costs that increase their profitability. In capitalism, the direction and orientation of innovation and research serves the interests of capitalist enterprises, not the satisfaction of popular needs, while at the same time poor farmers are being uprooted and food products are becoming expensive and increasingly dangerous and unfit for consumption by workers. The only way out is the alliance of workers, poor farmers, self-employed against monopolies and capitalism.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the McIntyre report for agreeing to technology-based solutions at the service of modern and sustainable agriculture in the EU. I would point out that the compilation and analysis of large integrated data sets have the potential to promote innovation in the agriculture sector and are particularly useful for addressing and developing an efficient and sustainable food chain, with benefits for farmers, the economy, consumers and the environment. I support the call on the Commission and the Member States to remove barriers to the integration of complex and fragmented ICT systems by fostering investment and bearing training costs and making the necessary infrastructure more accessible to agriculture. I would stress that I voted against paragraphs 30 and 31 which refer to new methods of animal or plant breeding because I consider that the text does not include the precautions due to the development and use of these techniques. I declare, however, that the negative vote in these paragraphs was based on the defence of the precautionary principle and does not contravene the promotion of research in agriculture, since I am convinced that innovation contributes constructively to the achievement of sustainable agriculture in the EU.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. In view of the increase in the world's population, meeting the demand for healthy food and optimal nutrition is one of the greatest future challenges to be met. Food requirements are expected to increase significantly over the next decade. In this report, however, the solution is found in pushing for intensive agriculture whose sole purpose is productivity at all costs. All the opposite of what sustainable agriculture should mean for the EU. At present, the European Union already has agricultural overproduction. In fact, 30% of what is produced in the European Union is wasted and therefore thrown away. The idea for us of the M5S is not and cannot therefore be to produce more at any cost, but to aim for sustainable and quality agriculture, an agriculture that takes into account the environment and biodiversity. We must start by improving the management and distribution of that large proportion of production that is wasted and not open the door to GMOs and pesticides, as is called for in this document. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have fought and will continue to fight for quality agriculture. I could only vote against a report which suggests that the future of European agriculture must be based on practices such as GMOs, cloning and the use of pesticides.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on technological solutions for sustainable agriculture in the EU. Global food demand is expected to increase by 70% by 2050. Enabling an optimal and healthy diet is one of the major challenges facing the world. The shrinking of available land, environmental loss, water scarcity, increased energy demand, the emergence of new pests and diseases puts a heavy strain on the agricultural sector. In order to ensure a sustainable agricultural sector in the EU, it is essential to develop a wide range of innovative technologies in all types of farming.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, European agriculture is not threatened by a lack of innovation. It is threatened by free trade agreements that are negotiated behind the backs of the public, behind the backs of the people. Spanish milk farms are one of the most technological in Europe and do you know what's going on? That our ranchers are ruining the most.  Innovation in the field, of course, is fundamental to generating wealth. Yes, and from Europe of course conditions have to be favoured so that people in the rural world can innovate. But the faith that technology will come to save us when we're done is a myth. Nothing is going to give us as much wealth as the planet, like earth and the people who care for and work for it. We have to get to the root of the problem. The crisis in agriculture has to do with our model of economic growth, with our productive model, it has to do with our way of life. Only by guaranteeing investment in projects linked to the territory that bet on food sovereignty and agriculture with farmers will that alone will make us achieve a decent future for our people and for our field.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I supported this report because I believe that the sustainable use of available resources in agriculture is key in the right direction. In this regard, I would like to emphasise the role of marine and oceanic natural resources, such as sapropella, which has huge potential for improving soil health and composition and hence agriculture. The Black Sea basin is rich in this sediment, which can be used to create biological soil improvers and fertilizers. They, in turn, create a prerequisite for the expansion of certain agricultural sectors, such as organic farming, and play an extremely beneficial role in maintaining soil health and quality. I appeal to the Bulgarian administration in this regard to establish a public-private partnership to support the extraction of this sediment from bulgaria's economic zone in the Black Sea. Sapropel is a response to the growing need for innovative soil improvers and its extraction is an investment in better agriculture, in industry development and inclusion of scientific institutes in real economic processes.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I support the Parliament’s call for modernising European agriculture. It is the best way to gain competitiveness on global markets. I also welcome that we have put food waste back on Parliament’s agenda.  Efficient farming is important to feed an ever—growing population in the world, but it is also important to use what we produce. 100 million tons of food is lost in the EU every year and food waste is economically, sustainably and ethically unacceptable. My campaign ‘Basta to Food Waste’ has highlighted that it is high time to step up our action over decades. We need to take the lead as opinion builders and work with all parts of the food chain: producers, retailers and consumers. Each of us must take our shared responsibility and change our lifestyles and attitude to food. At EU level, we need common definition, better data collection and targets, and to raise awareness, exchange best practices and clarify expiry dates and best before labels and rules for charity. I will finish by saying that food waste is our common challenge and we need not only to consider it an option, but a necessity.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís ní raibh aon deacracht vótáil ar son na tuarascála seo agus i ndáiríre tá sé an-chosúil leis an tuarascáil dheireanach maidir le cúrsaí talmhaíochta. The report highlights the importance of innovation when developing sustainable agriculture and how innovation can improve the economic prospects of producers. It emphasises that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive. Innovation and research have an important role to play in fulfilling both objectives of better economic prospects and sustainable production. Small and medium-sized farms are a hugely important part of European agriculture: it is essential that the benefits of innovation and research in agriculture reach small and medium-sized farms. It is not just high-production farms that benefit. The same applies to disadvantaged regions such as mountainous and peripheral regions. Agriculture producers in these disadvantaged areas have to be able to benefit from innovation and research. Agriculture is very important to my country, accounting for EUR 9 billion exported, or 10% of our total exports, and employing over 150 000 people.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on innovation and the development of European agriculture calls for the need for more agricultural production at all costs. In fact, according to the data we have received, the Eu ropean Union already produces a sufficient quantity of agricultural products, but wastes about 30 % of its products. Furthermore, the text basically paves the way for GMOs and so-called 'low-risk' substances, without making a full assessment of the latter and, in fact, neglecting the preservation of biodiversity. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I totally disagree with it. I believe that the new techniques, new varieties and new machinery proposed in this report will further increase dependence on agrochemical multinationals, industry and banks, increasing the gap between large producers of industrialized food and small-scale agriculture, with the increase in the disappearance of small farms, local varieties, cultural heritage related to traditional forms of agriculture Etc.  The solution would come through a system change, which is not based on technology and machinery, but on an agro-ecological production system, the defence of small-scale farmers, local varieties and, in most cases, the recovery of traditional forms of cultivation, short production-consumption circuits, and food sovereignty. Also social participation, and environmental education programs for responsible production and consumption.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on 'promoting innovation and economic development in relation to future agricultural management for the European Union'. Indeed, the only positive points mentioned in this text (promoting the consumption of local food products, promoting agriculture in trade and wealth creation in the EU, etc.) are neither quantified nor accompanied by concrete measures. On the other hand, there are many completely unacceptable elements (excessive productivism, exhilaration of the CAP, the Europe 2020 strategy, the digital single market, dogmatic defence of ICTs, when they are not always effective), which are very precise.  I have therefore objected to this text, which presents some interesting observations which are nevertheless drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which had as its overall aim the increased use of robotics and GPS driven machinery in agriculture, having the overall effect of taking farmers off the land. As an MEP from a vastly rural constituency, I oppose this move to take farmers off the land, it having an overall effect of decreasing jobs and removing the beating pulse of rural communities. The report further called for the European Commission to take into account the use of this technology when assessing farmers’ eligibility for greening payments in CAP – however, it did not take into account the fact that the vast majority of small, family-run farms would not be able to afford this. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in order to encourage the Commission to facilitate access to funding for innovation. Our societies face multiple challenges (food, environmental, climate) to which agriculture can provide solutions. This means producing more food, better quality, especially for health, and accessible to all, while combating food waste.  To meet these challenges, cap objectives need to be redefined. And as such, as has been the case in the past, innovation is a considerable asset for the progress of agriculture, including forestry. It must be taken into account in future revisions of the CAP in order to combine economic development and sustainable production.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on strengthening innovation and economic development in the context of future European farm management, because the demographic challenges of tomorrow will require adjustments both in food production and in the way they are consumed and discarded. Better management of natural resources is the key to sustainable agriculture. Some of the techniques that can help reduce the use of fertilizers are better soil and water management, such as precision agriculture and real-time monitoring of data. But at the same time we also have to deal with food waste. The problem of food waste must be combated at all levels of the food chain by production, processing and retailers to consumers, as 33% of food waste is produced by consumers.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'I support the case for efficient and innovative agriculture, the reduction of food waste and the efficient use of resources, but this report is too much of an inevitability of ever more productive and industrial agriculture, with a doubling of agricultural productivity by 2030, which I think is unrealistic.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. It is estimated that by 2050 the world's population will increase by 2.4 billion people, for which more food needs to be produced. However, at least one third – in some areas, almost half – is wasted on food production. In addition, the unhealthy and nutrient-poor diet is also a problem, as more and more people suffer from obesity, cardiovascular diseases, among other things. In order to counteract these unfavourable developments, sustainable food production and healthy eating must be ensured. The former, in particular, is increasingly difficult for farmers to implement, as the declining availability of arable land, environmental losses and damage, water scarcity, rising demand for energy and the emergence of new pests and diseases are putting considerable pressure on our natural environment. Innovative and technical solutions can be used to counteract these negative developments. To this end, outdated legislation should be updated and the exchange of knowledge between the fields of chemistry, health and technology should be improved. Given the unfavourable circumstances, I strongly support the proposal to counteract it by means of innovation. Promoting the deployment of new management systems, real-time data monitoring, sensor technology and the use of detection systems to optimise production systems must be sought in order to enable sustainable agriculture.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The very title of this report speaks volumes about the ideological mess it constitutes. Led by the Dutch ultraliberal Jan Huitema, it delivers a large number of ideas, measures, tracks of new regulations, which we regularly fight: - excessive productivity; - exaltation of the CAP, the Europe 2020 strategy, the digital single market; - dogmatic defence of ICTs, when they are not always effective (particularly in the establishment of registers by GPS, often approximate); - promoting global harmonisation of the European market through, among other things, the use and exchange of personal data; - the desire to create jobs, but the Commission's incentive to force ever more automation of tasks; - will to put in place, via the Commission, a single European legislation for drones and RPAS. The report distills the promotion of GMOs into a watermark and strongly challenges existing legislation in Europe on this subject. "Biostimulants," "biocontrol," "biological control mechanisms" are therefore sold as indispensable tools for 21st century agriculture. I voted against this report, which opens the door to changes that we do not want.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I deplore the regulatory burden that British farmers face as a result of the bureaucracy imposed on them by the European Union. Although I wish to encourage farm innovation and productivity the author of this report Jan Huitema, a dairy farmer, should know better.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, the result of a long work by my colleague Jan Huitema, on strengthening innovation in the agricultural sector. Rather than subsidising a status quo that is proving outdated, European agriculture policy should focus more on innovation. Like my ALDE colleagues, I am firmly committed to unlocking the innovation potential of agriculture in order to produce more quality products, ensure food supply and combat climate change more effectively.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. By 2050, the world's population will exceed 9 billion. At the same time, dietary priorities are changing rapidly, with more consumers demanding animal protein, such as dairy products and meat. At the same time, it is necessary to reduce the ecological footprint of agricultural production and to mitigate the impact on the environment and arable land. The opportunities offered by agricultural innovation are not fully understood and the European regulatory framework is not able to go hand in hand with rapid progress. Crucial challenges must be overcome in order to accelerate and promote agricultural innovation and entrepreneurship in the sector.  I agree that the common agricultural policy should be more focused on the needs of farmers, and that sufficient room for manoeuvre to strengthen innovation and competitiveness should be left. Innovation in technology can help to eliminate generic measures and achieve targeted interventions. Better alignment with other industrial sectors, such as the chemicals, health and technology industries, is needed.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report constitutes a veritable ideological mess, mixing with positive points that do not come with any serious commitment or concrete and quantified measures of much more numerous and above all more precise negative points: thus, this report is the vector for promoting a global harmonisation of the European market through the use and exchange of personal data and distills a real promotion of GMOs. , presented as indispensable for 21st century agriculture.  I therefore voted against this report, which drowns out some interesting findings under a flood of deadly recommendations for our agriculture.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because I believe that the innovation and development of the farms proposed by the rapporteur is contrary to the model of agro-ecological agriculture that we are defending. The report opens the door to the introduction of robotics on farms, such as the use of sensors to control livestock and drones. Although I am not against the use of these technologies, it seems to me to be a report designed for the benefit of large farms that have a high borrowing capacity to introduce new systems. On the other hand, the report proposes the introduction of more sophisticated risk management systems, which deepens my suspicions that it is a report designed for agri-food corporations, and not so that farmers and peasants can improve their working conditions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported mr Huitema's report on improving innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms. The dissemination of precision agriculture, which offers new comprehensive farm management approaches, should be encouraged. Greater efforts are also needed to fully develop and implement integrated phytosanitary protection management systems by supporting the research of non-chemical alternatives and low-risk measures.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I vehemently opposed this report, which is a true ultra-liberal mortal ideology for our agriculture and our farmers. The rapporteur defends everything we oppose: destructive productivity, the apology of the CAP and the single market, and the plea for a global harmonisation of the European market through the use and exchange of personal data. Worse, the few positive ideas (such as the promotion of local consumption or the place given to small and medium-sized farms or family farms) are only vaguely exposed to be abandoned very quickly in favour of a promotion of GMOs (with the use of polite terms such as "biostimulants" and a questioning of national protective laws on the subject. Finally, the rapporteur's optimism on the use of ICTs (which are not always effective, especially in the case of the establishment of registers by GPS) borders on naivety.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem raised by the report on promoting innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms is a concrete one and brings attention to the contribution that innovation can make in the agricultural sector. However, the issue is being dealt with in an unclear way, which could leave room for future manipulation and critical issues, and that is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In line with the McIntyre report, the Huitema report, on which I voted in favour, is also part of the challenges facing agriculture: how new practices, techniques and production methods have increased yields and improved agriculture's ability to adapt to changing new circumstances, and how technology and innovation open new avenues for optimizing resources or providing livestock solutions that contribute to greater level of animal welfare and health. The report also calls on the Commission to encourage more effective research that will more closely address market needs and the development of sustainable agronomic and agro-ecological practices and to report periodically on the impact of agricultural innovation on developments in the cost and sale prices of agricultural products and on the business viability of farms.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it advocates the promotion of innovation and economic development in the future management of European economies. Since the existence of agriculture, his methods have always changed. The introduction of the most up-to-date technologies ensures a thriving rural economy and keeps pace with wider economic development. Better use of innovation skills ensures that agriculture can contribute to many solutions. By 2050, the world's population will exceed 9 billion. At the same time, dietary priorities are changing rapidly, with more consumers demanding animal protein, such as dairy products and meat. This means that we need to reduce the ecological footprint of agricultural production in order to mitigate the impact on the environment and on ploughed land. The opportunities offered by agricultural innovation are not fully understood and the European regulatory framework is not able to go hand in hand with rapid progress. Crucial challenges must be overcome in order to accelerate and promote agricultural innovation and entrepreneurship in the sector. Parliament believes that the common agricultural policy should be more focused on the needs of farmers and should not hinder the achievement of policy objectives. Innovation in technology can help to eliminate generic measures and achieve targeted interventions. The introduction of precision agriculture and the use of large amounts of data will make it substantial for agriculture to change, to produce more kilograms of product with a smaller amount of resources, and interventions to combat diseases or harmful organisms will be more targeted.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that population growth, higher average incomes and changing consumer habits will change dietary habits, resulting in an increase in demand for processed foods and animal proteins, such as meat and dairy products, in particular in the world. At the same time, small and medium-sized family farms are an integral part of the European agricultural sector and are the basis for creating socially and economically vibrant rural areas that contribute to the preservation of cultural and natural heritage. These farms may find it difficult to reap the benefits of modern farming methods and practices, which could provide them with a decent income and improve the living and working conditions of farmers and help create quality jobs.  Innovation needs to address the issue of food waste and, in particular, regular food waste, as more than 100 million tonnes of food are thrown away every year in Europe, which is around 30-50% of the food produced in the EU. I believe that greater cooperation is needed to reduce the current level of waste. Outdated regulatory frameworks should not limit innovative ways of processing food waste and the exchange of best practices should be encouraged in order to combat food waste and loss. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported my colleague Huitema's report. The European agricultural sector is crucial for the EU. In addition to its core mission of providing healthy and quality food, it is an extremely important economic pillar that employs 25 million people. They are either directly engaged in agriculture or are employed in the food and retail sectors. EU agriculture still sets standards for agricultural practice around the world, which produced high-value-added products, providing knowledge-based solutions to feed an ever-growing and increasingly demanding population. Technological innovation can therefore make a huge contribution to improving land use and resource savings. So-called precision farming will transform agriculture and help us to invest less resources for more kilograms of produce. It will also contribute to a more targeted intervention against diseases or pests. Agriculture therefore needs to be better adapted to other industrial sectors (chemicals, health and technology) and cross-sectoral knowledge integration and youth motivation for farming will play an important role in this.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report adopted today, which emphasises the need for innovative and sustainable agriculture to meet the present and future challenges facing us. To date, the innovation potential of agriculture is not yet fully exploited and it would be a mistake to miss the opportunity to make this key sector our ally in providing adequate responses to today's problems.  The rapid increase in the world's population, accompanied by the challenges posed by climate change and the progressive loss of biodiversity, can only lead us to review and adapt our production models, including agricultural and natural resource management techniques, but also our models of reuse and disposal of waste, both agricultural and food.  One thing is certain: we can no longer afford waste and innovation, in this sector as in other sectors, can make a fundamental contribution. It can, in fact, encourage the incisive change throughout the production chain necessary to move to the model of valorization and recovery of resources which is then the circular economy and, at the same time, to put the role of farmers and the potential of this sector in terms of employment and quality production back at the centre.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on strengthening innovation and economic development in farm management in the future. I see the key to sustainable agriculture in better managing natural resources, reducing the use of artificial fertilisers, using soil and water better, managing the information system, etc. Likewise, we need to focus on food waste, as every year 100 million tonnes of food in Europe are wasted, which I consider to be huge harm and irresponsibility.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report highlights some interesting principles, including the consumption of local products, the place given to small family farms, the use of biofuels and support for young farmers. However, it is part of a liberal, productive, highly automated, and pro-GMO framework, which is unacceptable to me. I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which had as its overall aim the increased use of robotics and GPS driven machinery in agriculture, having the overall effect of taking farmers off the land. As an MEP from a vastly rural constituency, I oppose this move to take farmers off the land, it having an overall effect of decreasing jobs and removing the beating pulse of rural communities. The report further called for the European Commission to take into account the use of this technology when assessing farmers’ eligibility for greening payments in CAP – however, it did not take into account the fact that the vast majority of small, family-run farms would not be able to afford this. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 By 2050, the world's population will exceed nine billion people, a phenomenon that will put unprecedented pressure on the natural resources at our disposal. It is important for the European Union to be ready for this fundamental challenge, encouraging the technological development of agricultural practices capable of promoting the continent's food security through greater ecological sustainability.  With this in mind, it is necessary to promote the consolidation of the circular economy as a new model of reference development, to develop new mechanisms to raise citizens' awareness of sustainable consumption, to promote the transparency of production and supply chains and to encourage the development of a simpler and more flexible regulatory framework, particularly within the CAP, capable of adapting to an increasingly changing environment. The European Union and the Member States must invest more in applied research and transnational research, as well as promote an open and constructive dialogue between scientists, farmers and industrialists. In this sense, the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, with around EUR 80 billion of mobilised appropriations, is an encouraging sign, as regards investments and funding priorities at European level, which must, however, be further deepened and encouraged.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on promoting innovation and economic development in relation to future agricultural management for the European Union. Indeed, the only positive aspects of the text, such as support for young farmers as well as small farms or the promotion of local agricultural and food products, do not come with any serious commitment or concrete measures.  There are, however, many questionable elements. This dogmatic report promotes the Common Agricultural Policy, the Europe 2020 strategy and the Digital Single Market. The rapporteur also recommends a single law for drones. For all these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the UN, agricultural productivity should double by 2030 in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, while the agri-food sector should adapt to climate change and changing weather conditions.  Today, consumers demand food production that meets higher standards and values, so I consider it necessary to have new regulations that ensure a level playing field and fair competition in order to encourage economic development in the agri-food sector in all Member States.  Research and technological innovation are constantly needed to achieve greater production using as few resources as possible. By using sensors, drones and state-of-the-art remote communication solutions, we will create an efficient agricultural market by reducing costs as well as pesticide consumption.  I support the EP resolution motion because I believe that, for a New Europe, access to food and an adequate supply of good quality and safe food to all EU citizens, while reducing pressure on natural resources and thus preserving the environment and valuable resources for future generations, are important steps to be taken.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I consider it essential, in the future management of European farms, the adoption of management systems based on information and communication technologies, real-time data monitoring, sensor technology and the use of detection systems for the optimization of production systems or precision agriculture. I firmly believe, in fact, that these actions can lead to better control of production phases, greater crop yields and a reduction in energy consumption and greenhouse gases. The European Union, as you know, is the world's largest exporter of agricultural products. This makes the agri-food sector an important economic pillar of the Union. The agricultural sector has experienced and will see rounds of changes aimed at improving agricultural productivity. It is precisely this capacity for adaptation that has made a substantial contribution to the exceptional economic development of agriculture. The path taken by the agricultural enterprise with a modern face is therefore no longer linked only to the production of goods, but to the concept of multifunctionality, from the transformation of products to direct sales, from educational farms to agritourism.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which had as its overall aim the increased use of robotics and GPS driven machinery in agriculture, having the overall effect of taking farmers off the land. As an MEP from a vastly rural constituency, I oppose this move to take farmers off the land, it having an overall effect of decreasing jobs and removing the beating pulse of rural communities. The report further called for the European Commission to take into account the use of this technology when assessing farmers’ eligibility for greening payments in CAP – however, it did not take into account the fact that the vast majority of small, family-run farms would not be able to afford this. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Agriculture is the pillar of European economy and is related to our lives closely. I therefore voted in favour of the report, which intends to build a modern farming through technology reform. The report underlines the close relationship between economic development and sustainable agriculture and the potential of high technology accomplishing the two goals. Furthermore, it carefully examines measures the scientific measures to use our limited resources wisely in order to satisfy the demands of growing population. I am especially satisfied with the proposal that suggests introducing advanced techniques to farmers, in particular, to small and medium-sized family farms and farms in disadvantaged regions.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the own-initiative report aimed at encouraging innovation and economic development in the management of European farms. The report contains redundant references to the fact that the assumed considerable growth of the world's population by 2050 justifies the need to accelerate and stimulate agricultural production. It should be noted that, contrary to what is observed in the text of the resolution, the European Union is already in agricultural overproduction at the present time. The message from the resolution is then totally at odds with my position.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress the importance of new innovative and affordable solutions for the agricultural sector in order to increase the use of more environmentally friendly methods, goods and resources, including not only new farming and field management methods but also instruments to increase the use of renewable energy sources and means to gradually eliminate the need for fossil fuels.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on strengthening innovation and economic development in the context of future European farm management aims to improve agricultural production conditions by supporting new technologies. Although this appears to be positive at first sight, I believe that the agricultural sector in Europe is threatened mainly by the uneven allocation of resources and the dependence on companies specialising in the production of chemicals and pharmaceuticals. As I therefore believe that we should support producers where they really need it, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agricultural sector has always been a priority for the European Union as it guarantees quality food supply. The time has come to facilitate greater integration of this sector with industrial sectors, such as chemicals and health. I am convinced that proper cooperation will significantly strengthen synergies, pushing farmers to more efficient production. In addition, such progress will make it possible, on the one hand, to produce more using fewer resources and, on the other, to implement more targeted interventions in the fight against diseases and parasites. I voted in favour of this report because it pushes in this direction, with which I agree.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which highlights the importance of innovation to sustainable agricultural production and to improving the economic prospects of producers. It emphasises that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive and that innovation and research and development have a major role to play in fulfilling both objectives. The report points out that small and medium-sized family farms are an integral part of European agriculture and that it is essential that the benefits of advanced production techniques reach them too. The same applies for producers in disadvantaged regions such as mountainous and outermost regions. The report points to examples of where innovation can be applied to agriculture including ICT-based management systems and sensor technology. The need to facilitate the access of farmers to investment financing is also highlighted.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – All societies need good farm management and agricultural innovation but this will not deliver them so we opposed it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Innovation in agriculture has great potential that has not yet been fully recognised. It is crucial to address the main challenges in order to stimulate innovation and promote entrepreneurship in agriculture. The common agricultural policy should focus more on farmers' needs, in a flexible perspective in view of strategic objectives, which will increase innovation and competitiveness. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to encourage innovation and the economic development of farms, harmonising the agricultural sector with chemical, health and technological sectors, through the exchange of knowledge and the use of resources. The ultimate goal is to optimize interaction and improve the integration of agriculture into the circular economy.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented aims to highlight the expected growth of the world's population by 2050 and aims to push for an acceleration and over-stimulation of agricultural production. It says in the text that, given that soils are everywhere exposed to a decline in fertility, it is necessary to intensify and improve the productivity of land through innovative ways of ecosystem functions. In fact, the report conceals, not too veiledly, the intentions to strengthen and increase the production and innovation of agricultural entrepreneurship. I totally disagree with the proposal for a report before us, because it is heading in a completely opposite direction to what I think is appropriate, namely to produce less but better, with a reduction in waste and better management. I am therefore voting against.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I totally disagree with it. I believe that the new techniques, new varieties and new machinery proposed in this report will further increase dependence on agrochemical multinationals, industry and banks, increasing the gap between large producers of industrialized food and small-scale agriculture, with the increase in the disappearance of small farms, local varieties, cultural heritage related to traditional forms of agriculture Etc.  The solution would come through a system change, which is not based on technology and machinery, but on an agro-ecological production system, the defence of small-scale farmers, local varieties and, in most cases, the recovery of traditional forms of cultivation, short production-consumption circuits, and food sovereignty. Also social participation, and environmental education programs for responsible production and consumption.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 New technological solutions potentially can make the agriculture of the future more sustainable, addressing the growth of the world's population and giving security to food supply, the growth in demand for protein-rich products and the demand for healthier food. Genetic diversity is a possible solution for sustainable agriculture, encouraging the best possible use of resources to safeguard biodiversity and improve plant varieties. However, this is a controversial report, because it encourages the intensification of agriculture as the only solution to the increase in world demand for food products and does not include other solutions such as the fight against food waste or other more sustainable solutions. I voted for the resolution, but I believe that only through a balanced use of technological instruments and different policies can appreciable and sustainable results be achieved.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 By 2050, the world's population will exceed the 9 billion threshold. Thus, the demand for food will increase exponentially. The changes in the agricultural sector, one of the most dynamic economic sectors, have been either structural or linked to the production process, making this industry a state-of-the-art innovation and development industry. Better use of innovative power guarantees the success of the rural economy, as well as maintaining the pace of large-scale economic development. I voted for a common agricultural policy focused more on the needs of farmers and for harmonisation with other industrial sectors.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The agricultural sector today has to face the demand resulting from the rapid growth of the population. It is under pressure due to various challenges, including climate change and evolving socio-economic dynamics. European agriculture must therefore produce sufficient food while ensuring the environment, consumer safety and support for farmers. The potential for innovation in agriculture is not fully recognised and the European regulatory framework is not adapted to keep pace with the dynamics of progress. I believe that key challenges need to be addressed in order to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in agriculture. The EU could make better use of the innovative power of agriculture while ensuring that no legislative act stittles competition. Farmers should be given more freedom in terms of entrepreneurship and innovation. For example, in precision farming, you can limit the amount of plant protection products needed, or the amount of fertilizers required, or even the amount of water. Agricultural technology will predict where crop pests can be expected or whether they will attack in a specific place in farmland. I fully agree with the report's view that agriculture is part of the solution – not part of the problem – to address important challenges such as climate change, air and water pollution and animal welfare. I strongly support the report by signing up to all the compromise amendments.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Creating the right tools and the right framework will help us reach a more sustainable agriculture and farm management. The way our populations will change, coupled with demographic challenges, will necessitate changes in both the production of food and the way we consume and dispose of it. I agree that better management of natural resources is key to sustainable agriculture. I agree with the report where it stresses the need to tackle food waste, since each year 100 million tonnes of food in Europe goes to waste. Food waste is to be fought at all levels of the food chain from production, processing and retailers to consumers. Hence I voted in favour of this report

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the emphasis in this report on supporting innovation in technology and farm governance through coherent legislation. I also welcome the advocacy in this report of using big data and sensor technology to adopt a new whole-farm management approach to mapping, soil-quality, fertiliser use, etc. These techniques could significantly reduce the use of fertiliser and water, and combat soil erosion, making farming much more sustainable in the future.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the integration of policies to promote training of farmers on new technologies and support for innovation and entrepreneurship among young farmers are essential elements for making agriculture more environmentally sustainable and this sector more competitive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on promoting innovation and economic development in future agricultural management for the European Union, and on the link between innovation and sustainable agricultural production.  Innovation is very important for agricultural producers because it allows for better production efficiency. However, advanced production techniques must benefit all European producers, not just large producers, but also SMEs and producers in disadvantaged regions such as mountainous regions.  Considering that this is an important issue for the development of economically and environmentally sustainable agricultural production in Europe, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I have supported this text on promoting innovation and economic development in relation to future agricultural management for the European Union. Adopting innovative solutions will ensure that Europe's agricultural sector retains its primacy and ensures the prosperity of the rural economy and the jobs associated with agricultural work.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the importance of innovation for the future of agriculture and for its sustainability, both economic and environmental. All farmers, regardless of the size of their farm, and whatever geographical handicaps they face, must be able to benefit from technological and technical advances in order to be more competitive and environmentally friendly.  In addition, I want to emphasize that innovation must contribute to the well-being of farmers, which is a cause to which I am very attached but which is too often overlooked. In supporting this report, I would like to reiterate that economic competitiveness and environmental sustainability are not opposed, but complementary!

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. Innovation in agriculture and forestry is a good way to respond to the many challenges facing our societies: food, environmental, climate. But this innovation must not take place at any price, as I have defended as shadow rapporteur: - Innovation must be thought of in line with a redefinition of the cap's objectives, it must be integrated into a more comprehensive strategy. - It must take into account the emergence of new models of production and governance based on knowledge and new technologies, respectful of quality standards and adapted to the realities of european societies largely rural. - It must be at the service of employment. This means that the agricultural potential for the supply of food and non-food and service goods is enhanced. This requires vocational training, which is crucial in mastering new technologies and innovative practices. The agricultural profession is experiencing multiple crises. Innovation - well thought out, well-supported, well-financed - can be a solution to encourage sustainable agronomic and ecological practices, in line with the major challenges ahead.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The report's few positive points do not include any serious commitment or concrete and quantified measures. These include the promotion of local products, small and medium-sized farms, support for young farmers and the promotion of the use of biofuels via animal faeces.  On the other hand, the negatives are numerous and much more precise. GMOs and productivity are promoted, as are the CAP in general, the Europe 2020 strategy and the digital single market. Information and communication technologies are highlighted, albeit questionablely effective. The use and exchange of personal data is promoted, as well as the automation of tasks. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on promoting innovation and economic development in the framework of the future management of European farms. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) estimates that an expected increase in the global population of 9.1 billion people by 2050 will make it imperative to increase food production by 60% by that date, as well as crop yields in developed countries by 24%. This means that we need to make farms more modern and innovative so that we increase production, but also make it more environmentally friendly.   The report also floats the idea that farmers need to be freer in choosing innovations as well as implementing them. I think this is right because the manufacturer can best assess the benefits of using a technology.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are significant challenges that need to be addressed to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. The report promotes a common agricultural policy that focuses more on the needs of farmers without compromising policy objectives. We are voting in favour of the report, as we agree that the adoption of new technologies by the agricultural sector will ensure the flourishing of the rural economy. Young farmers, the natural environment and health take precedence and through these innovations they can benefit.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Huitema report on agricultural innovation.  Agriculture has always developed new practices, techniques and production methods that have increased yields, improved the adaptability of agricultural practices to new and changing conditions and reduced production costs. It must be seen that agriculture and forestry are a key part of our world, providing goods and services beyond food production and which can be strengthened by promoting new developments. I see innovation as a prerequisite for maintaining this development.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The European agricultural sector is of central importance to the Union in general, ensuring food, while being a key economic pillar providing employment to 25 million people who are directly involved in agricultural work, in addition to those working in the food, retail and other complementary sectors. The common agricultural policy should focus more on farmers and encourage innovation and competitiveness. Better alignment with other industrial sectors, such as chemicals, health and technology, is needed by improving the intersection of knowledge, integrating resource use and better understanding of reciprocal effects in order to optimise their interaction and better integrate agriculture into the circular economy.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this initiative report contains far too many unacceptable elements. It opens the door to changes that we do not want. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report "gives one in the harpsichord another in the horseshoe". It advocates reducing the environmental footprint of agriculture and supports extensive animal husbandry. Further ahead, advocate encouraging the recovery of animal proteins by valuing waste from livestock production, so as to produce rations with such animal protein. The report calls for the continued development of innovative plant cultivation techniques, the development of new varieties, with higher production, higher nutritional value, better pest resistance - i.e. a defence of GMOs, - while calls for the preservation of European seed banks and warns of the danger of chemical dependence on these new growing species. In the midst of some green rhetoric of concern about the loss of biodiversity and environmental protection, there is an apology for increased competitiveness - which has enabled current agricultural practices. While innovation and new technologies can help farmers, agriculture and the environment, the economic and social model in which they are included is what essentially determines the nature - positive or negative - of its effects and whether or not they serve a primary purpose - that of profit - which overlaps with others.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the challenges facing the European agricultural sector today, but especially in the future, can only be overcome through entrepreneurial and innovation policies. The EU must provide a regulatory framework that favours these policies and not obstacles. In particular, I welcome the reference to precision agriculture, which will make it possible to achieve important results, especially in terms of reducing the use of plant protection products, fertilizers, but also in saving water resources.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because I disagree with this approach. I believe that the current agricultural crisis is very closely related with an environmental, social and economic crisis, with a globalised production-consumption system and unequal distribution of resources in the EU and around the world

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Meeting the growing demand for quality food and nutrition is one of the important challenges facing Europe today. This will also require much greater support for technological innovation in agriculture. The European Union and its Member States have the capacity and resources to become global leaders in this area. However, real cooperation and the use of the benefits of the common agricultural policy are needed. Unfortunately, the reality today is, in particular, the rivalry and the mutual irritation of the legs between countries. Greater interdependence between the scientific community and the agricultural sector must also be a necessity. Solutions need to be sought, both on small rural farms and on large farmers. Timely practical implementation of research results on individual farms, farms or cooperatives is important.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because, despite some interesting elements, the report may pose a potential danger to the deregulated openness to genetic manipulation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are significant challenges that need to be addressed to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. The report promotes a common agricultural policy that focuses more on the needs of farmers without compromising policy objectives. I am voting in favour of the report, as I agree that the adoption of new technologies by the agricultural sector will ensure the flourishing of the rural economy. Young farmers, the natural environment and health take precedence and through these innovations they can benefit.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The demographic challenges of tomorrow will necessitate adaptations in both the production of food and the way we consume and dispose of it. Better management of natural resources is key for sustainable agriculture. Some of the techniques can help the reduction of fertiliser use, better soil and water management such as precision agriculture, ICT-based management and real-time data monitoring. But at the same time we need to tackle food waste since each year 100 million tonnes of food in Europe is wasted, food waste is to be fought at all levels of the food chain from production, processing and retailers to consumers, as 33% of food waste is produced by consumers. Agro-forestry and conservation agriculture have been recognised as sustainable innovative techniques that should be further promoted at European level. I therefore supported the report in the plenary.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the conviction that technological improvement on farms will be extremely beneficial for both farmers and our society. By 2050 the world's population will have increased to 9 billion people and improved technology will be a key element.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this report as it highlights several important aspects for the future of the agricultural sector. I support the overall view of the report that improving innovation and competitiveness is essential for the agricultural sector moving into the future and that future legislation should take this into account. I also agree with the report on the need to promote a more prudent use of natural resources, to ensure the biodiversity of our farms, to tackle food waste and to tackle soil degradation. I also echo the report in calling for the Commission to provide a more ambitious strategy to align and focus research and innovation on these issues so that the European agricultural sector can retail and even improve its competitiveness in the future.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on promoting innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms, especially for the intelligent approach to the prospect of world population growth by 2050. According to FAO estimates, in a few decades the global demographic scenario will change radically and require the development and sustainable improvement of food supply technologies. In recent decades, we have seen a sudden decline in farmland productivity due to drought, land use and adverse weather events, with very serious economic consequences for farmers who have also had to deal with the crisis.  Agricultural SMEs, especially family-run ones, are one of the most vibrant realities in the Food Scene of the European Union, contributing to the social and economic dynamism of rural areas, and for this reason they need more attention and in terms of better living conditions and employability. It is therefore necessary to develop new agricultural policies that take into account not only innovation and research, but also a modern approach to corporate governance based on clear and coherent regulation of agricultural entrepreneurship.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on improving innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms, which is very much in the way of my colleague Mrs McIntyre's report. Europe must promote innovation and best practices that make it easier for farmers to lead their (family-run) farms into a good future.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Improving innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms is essential to improve the economic prospects of producers. It is important that the benefits of improved techniques also reach smaller family farms. Access to investment finance should also be facilitated.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because I believe that the innovation and development of the farms proposed by the rapporteur is contrary to the model of agro-ecological agriculture that we are defending. The report opens the door to the introduction of robotics on farms, such as the use of sensors to control livestock and drones. Although I am not against the use of these technologies, it seems to me to be a report designed for the benefit of large farms that have a high borrowing capacity to introduce new systems. On the other hand, the report proposes the introduction of more sophisticated risk management systems, which deepens my suspicions that it is a report designed for agri-food corporations, and not so that farmers and peasants can improve their working conditions.
