name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that the common agricultural policy should focus more on the needs of farmers, without compromising their objectives, namely to give sufficient flexibility to strengthening innovation and competitiveness. Technology innovations can promote the abandonment of generic measures and contribute to specific interventions. The use of precision agriculture and large volumes of data can transform agriculture and contribute to greater production, using fewer resources and more specific disease or pest control interventions.  The European agricultural sector is of fundamental importance as it provides food supply and is an essential economic pillar, employing 25 million people directly involved in agricultural work and complementary sectors such as food and trade.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The common agricultural policy should focus more on farmers’ needs leaving enough flexibility to enhance innovation and competitiveness. Innovations in technology can help us move away from generic measures and contribute to targeted interventions. Employing precision farming and big data will transform agriculture and contributes to produce more kg of product with less input of resources and more targeted interventions to combat diseases or pests.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report because we fundamentally disagree with the Commission's approach. We believe that the current agricultural crisis is very closely linked to the environmental, social and economic crisis, to a globalised production-consumption system and the unequal distribution of resources in the EU and around the world. New techniques and varieties, together with new technologies, further increase dependence on multinationals and banks, thereby increasing the gap between large industrialised food producers and small scale farmers. And so along with their marginalization are lost along with local varieties as well as the cultural heritage associated with traditional ways of harvesting.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report for a number of reasons. Firstly, the report aims to emphasise the pivotal importance of innovation for sustainable food production in the context of increasing environmental concerns. At the same time, innovation should be an integral part of the efforts to ensure a sustainable economic prosperity in a thriving European rural community. Making better use of innovative power ensures agriculture can be part of the solution to a number of economic and environmental challenges, especially considering the depopulation of rural areas in more recent times. By singling out the most topical issues such as precision farming, climate smart farming and making better use of the power of nature by combating plant diseases with insects, the report shows how we can produce more products in a better, more sustainable way while lowering our impact on the environment. A main concern of the report is that the potential of innovation in agriculture has not been fully recognised nor is the European regulatory framework fit to keep pace with rapid advancements. Key challenges have to be addressed in order to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in agriculture, something that is needed considering the current market volatility and global competition.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it recognises the importance of small and medium-sized family farms within the EU and emphasises the importance of sustainable agricultural production.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution to strengthen innovation and economic development in the management of European farms in the future, as I believe that new technologies are an essential factor for sustainable and competitive 21st century European agriculture. Innovation enables agriculture to be part of the solution to a number of economic and environmental challenges, and in this context it is essential to ensure agricultural production that reduces the impact on the environment.  However, the regulatory framework lags behind in terms of adapting to new technologies and further prevents the development of entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to revise outdated legislation, and encourage investments in the production process.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report contains far too many unacceptable elements. It opens the door to changes that all members of our group do not want. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow.  I naturally voted against this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to highlight the role of innovation in economic and environmental sustainability in agricultural production. Its aim is also to promote farmers' access to the benefits of advanced production techniques, whether they are conventional farms, small farms or producers in areas with geographical and natural handicaps.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 New social structure, demographic changes mean that food producers are constantly being forced to look for new solutions to meet the expectations of the food market. Consumers are not only getting older, their food tastes are also changing. All these challenges must be answered by farmers and processors.  It is therefore not enough to increase current production. New solutions should be sought that not only respond to the increased demand for food in the future, but will also be sustainable enough not to cause progressive environmental degradation. Greater integration of agriculture with other sectors of the economy, such as chemicals, health and technology, is very necessary in order to make more effective use of knowledge, innovative innovation and interaction. This will create new jobs in the agri-food sector and will inspire the production of more diverse products or services.  Meeting the growing and growing needs of European and global consumers will ensure that European agriculture maintains its importance and continues to set standards for the highest quality production.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the promotion of innovation and the economic development of farms. The rapporteur has put forward interesting technical solutions, such as.B. the increased use of drones, which could increase the productivity of European agriculture. In addition to these technical solutions, the report also takes up the fight against food waste. The rapporteur opposes the patenting of animal and plant species naturally. All these aspects can have a positive impact on the productivity of our domestic agriculture. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it offers the Commission a range of innovative ideas and solutions for future European farm management.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In the midst of demographical, dietary, environmental and economic changes, the agricultural sector will have to deal with an increased food demand and to ensure new methods of production. Some stakeholders continue to emphasise the potential of technology and innovation in order for the common agricultural policy to cope with these issues. The report, for instance, aligns agricultural innovative technology with job creation and improved operations management. However, this technologically centralised approach could generate a new challenge for local varieties and small scale-farmers, mostly due to the competition with industrialised food production. Therefore, I voted against.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The main virtue of the report is its balance, in so far as it supports the preservation of traditional farming structures where possible, while encouraging innovation where appropriate. Indeed, the grazing livestock farming of grey cattle and the large-scale field farming with GPS-controlled tractors can be accommodated side by side. It is important to state that, although the EU agricultural and food market is one of the most integrated markets in Europe, it is necessary to establish legislation that ensures a more level playing field and fair competition in the agricultural and food sectors of all Member States in order to stimulate economic development. All this should be supported.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This report focuses on encouraging innovation and economic development in the management of European farms, while also providing opportunities for job growth for farmers. European agriculture enjoys great peculiarities which could have an important impact on employment in many territories. It is clear that we must do a great deal to make technologies usable so that the competitiveness of our farms can grow more and more. The adoption of new technologies would make it possible to ensure a vigorous rural economy and, at the same time, improve production performance. Furthermore, innovation in agriculture would make the implementation of targeted interventions and provide for an update of outdated rules and ensure greater and correct harmonisation with other industrial sectors, in order to optimise the interaction of agriculture in the European economic system. I therefore believe that the agricultural sector is of fundamental importance to our country and that it is the global reference point for high-quality products, which is why innovation in agricultural management must be supported and encouraged.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it promotes GMOs in an overtly ultraliberal spirit.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on 'promoting innovation and economic development in relation to future agricultural management for the European Union'. The rapporteur, Mr Huitema, distills his promotion of GMOs in the watermark of his report and strongly questions existing legislation in Europe on this subject. "Biostimulants," "biocontrol," "biological control mechanisms" are therefore sold as indispensable tools for 19th century agriculture.  There are far too many unacceptable elements to this initiative report. It opens the door to changes that I don't want. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The whole report defends an ultra-liberal vision of European agriculture, which I strongly oppose. The proposals it presents that have a positive aspect remain vague and unpecable, while those that are negative are very precise.  Thus, the rapporteur proclaims his defence of local food products, support for young farmers and employment... without providing practical solutions. On the other hand, it insists on excessive productivity, the exaltation of the CAP (common agricultural policy), the promotion of a global harmonisation of the European market, in particular through the use and exchange of personal data... The proposals put forward are therefore destructive to the agricultural model we are advocating. I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I totally disagree with it. I believe that the new techniques, new varieties and new machinery proposed in this report will further increase dependence on agrochemical multinationals, industry and banks, increasing the gap between large producers of industrialized food and small-scale agriculture, with the increase in the disappearance of small farms, local varieties, cultural heritage related to traditional forms of agriculture Etc.  The solution would come through a system change, which is not based on technology and machinery, but on an agro-ecological production system, the defence of small-scale farmers, local varieties and, in most cases, the recovery of traditional forms of cultivation, short production-consumption circuits, and food sovereignty. Also social participation, and environmental education programs for responsible production and consumption.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I agree that it is good to use various beneficial innovations in agriculture, but this is to be the role of farmers themselves. I do not agree with the Commission's call 'to propose a more ambitious overarching strategy with measurable outputs aimed at harmonising research and innovation with political priorities and orienting them towards these priorities'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) estimates that the expected growth of the world's population to 9.1 billion people by 2050 will require a 60% increase in the production of safe and high-quality food and crop yields in developed countries by 24% by that year.  FAO estimates also suggest that the area of arable land will increase by only 4.3%, which will require better management of natural resources to prevent soil degradation. This report refers to the necessity of strengthening innovation and economic development in sustainable farm management, which can be a solid cornerstone of economic performance and help ensure that all EU citizens have sufficient supplies of quality and safe food.  The EU is the world's largest exporter of agricultural products, making the agri-food sector a key economic pillar of the Union employing 47 million people. In order to achieve the SDGs, agricultural productivity needs to be doubled by 2030, while the agri-food sector will have to adapt to climate change, improve the quality of ecosystems and soil.   Innovation can increase work productivity and revenues by reducing production costs and increasing business efficiency. Economic development and sustainable production can be achieved simultaneously using innovation, R&D, new governance and business models, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the global population's demand for food is growing much faster than arable land (only 4.3% by 2050), fostering innovation in agriculture is not a matter of simple necessity, but a matter of survival. In addition to innovation, the competitiveness of EU farmers should also be developed compared to other world-class actors. Labour productivity, the development of information and communication technologies, the dissemination of the necessary information and data, the promotion of precision farming (with the same drones with the aim of using each arable land centimeter), innovation in livestock are those aspects of the future management of European agriculture that need to be promoted most activism. In parallel, maximum attention should be paid to issues such as biodiversity, the reduction of food waste, the levelling of soil degradation, climate change, and efforts to promote cross-sector synergies. Within the EU, agriculture provides jobs for 25 million people, and these people are the only ones who work directly on land. There are even more employees in the sectors associated with them. In other words, the effective development of agriculture in the Member States of the Union is not only an economic matter of fundamental importance, but also a social question, an answer to which, at least in part, can be found precisely in a rational policy of promoting innovation.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the decision taken today. Agriculture, as a fundamental sector with a high potential for innovation, always needs new solutions, impulses and technological progress. Only in this way can the agricultural sector fully develop its potential. Our contribution in the EU should be to incentivise innovation and not to hinder it through flexible and conducive legislation. This not only guarantees food security, but also allows economic potential to be exploited, for example through jobs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the one hand, we are looking for innovative solutions and new technological processes in the economic development of farms in order to ensure the livelihood of an ever-increasing population. On the other hand, we are not taking almost any action against wasteful food management. At the same time, 1.3 billion tonnes of food are affected by this waste every year. This also has an impact on the environment. Strengthening innovation in agriculture is, of course, very important. But we also need to address the other side of the problem, and it needs to be dealt with without delay in the circular economy process.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on strengthening innovation and economic development in the context of future European farm management for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report contains some positive points, including the promotion of local consumption, the place given to small and medium-sized farms and support for young farmers. However, this report, which emanates from the ultraliberal Jan Huitema, sings the such punctuations, notably the promotion of the CAP and the Europe 2020 strategy, which are the causes of the current ills of the French campaigns.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft provides comprehensible approaches to increasing the productivity of the agricultural economy. However, some points in the field of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) have been left open. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of the most up-to-date technologies ensures a thriving rural economy and keeps pace with wider economic development. Better use of innovation skills ensures that agriculture can contribute to many solutions. By 2050, the world's population will exceed 9 billion. At the same time, dietary priorities are changing rapidly, with more consumers demanding animal protein, such as dairy products and meat. This means that we need to reduce the ecological footprint of agricultural production in order to mitigate the impact on the environment and on ploughed land. The opportunities offered by agricultural innovation are not fully understood and the European regulatory framework is not able to go hand in hand with rapid progress. Crucial challenges must be overcome in order to accelerate and promote agricultural innovation and entrepreneurship in the sector. Parliament believes that the common agricultural policy should be more focused on the needs of farmers and should not hinder the achievement of policy objectives. Innovation in technology can help to eliminate generic measures and achieve targeted interventions. The introduction of precision agriculture and the use of large amounts of data will make it substantial for agriculture to change, to produce more kilograms of product with a smaller amount of resources, and interventions to combat diseases or harmful organisms will be more targeted.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), food supplies will need to be increased by 60% by 2050. To achieve this, the report proposes to encourage "innovation" in agriculture.   The report is critical of the current agricultural model. It criticizes the use of pesticides and inputs, promotes organic farming and even agroforestry. It also takes into account food sovereignty issues by calling for EU protein independence. But it is also committed to ensuring "the continued development of innovative plant breeding techniques." Behind this barbaric terminology looms the possibility for pharmaceutical companies to manipulate the genetic material of plants to claim their intellectual property. In other words, it allows GMOs. However, the new techniques, new varieties or new machines touted by this report will have the first consequence of increasing farmers' dependence on multinational phytopharmaceuticals and banks. This will increase the gap between large agro-industrial producers and small farmers.  I vote against this text which clearly does not grasp the stakes of the new agriculture that has become necessary (environment, employment, culture, landscape...).

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite lucid findings, the conclusions are ideological and worrying in areas as varied as the CAP, Strategy 2020, the Digital Single Market, GMOs, ICTs, RPAS. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on strengthening innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms. It is estimated that by 2050 the world population reaches 9.6 billion people and that food demand will grow by 70%. We must know how to respond to this reality. This means that we need to invest more and better in agricultural technology and innovation. Farmers have the capacity and knowledge to innovate, but are limited by European legislation. I would like to point out that, for example, the fight against pests with insects already exists, but European legislation sometimes still hinders this innovation. There is still much to be done in this area, but the EU is taking action to that end. The Memorandum of Understanding between the European Commission and the European Investment Bank is extremely important for supporting agricultural projects and young farmers by providing new funding opportunities. This will be possible to modernise farms and further support research.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my support to this report on enhancing innovation and economic development in our agricultural sector. Being at the forefront of new technology uptake ensures a thriving rural economy. This report helps bring EU policies in line with the needs of both Europe’s food producers and society.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The expected increase in the world's population to 9.1 billion people by 2050 will require a 60% increase in food supply. Land everywhere is experiencing a decline in their intrinsic fertility due to their degradation, and in particular soil erosion as a result of climate change. It is therefore essential to modify and modernise agricultural techniques in an innovative and sustainable way in order to meet an increased demand for food products.  To address these problems, we encourage the adoption of innovative agriculture that offers new technological approaches to land use and helps to limit erosion while optimizing production. To do this, more investment is needed to implement plant protection management systems, using sustainable solutions and more environmentally friendly pesticides. Indeed, the goal of a sustainable agricultural system can only be achieved if natural resources are used responsibly with innovative new technological means to maximize land production.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Agriculture is one of the most dynamic economic sectors. Leading the way in introducing new technologies is a guarantee of a flourishing rural economy and keeping up with wider economic development. The potential for innovation in agriculture has not yet been fully recognised, nor is the European regulatory framework ready to keep up with rapid developments. The common agricultural policy should focus more on the real needs of farmers. More knowledge and information on ecosystems linked to the production process on the farm will strengthen development, exemplary by integrated pest management, which makes smarter use of the interaction of chemical and biological measures. Targeted incentives in the production process and investment are essential. On the other hand, outdated legislation should be updated to adapt to new solutions. Better harmonisation with other industries, such as the chemical industry, health and technology, is needed by increasing knowledge combination, integrating resource use and better understanding of the mutual effects. Moreover, thanks to innovations in technology and practices, new jobs can be created throughout the agri-food value chain and new income streams can be secured. It should be borne in mind that agriculture is a key economic pillar of the Union, which is why I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report since I believe that sustainability of the environment and agriculture production is necessary in order to ensure a sustainable economic development of our primary production, and a transition to a bio-economy is required in order to attain sustainable development and be able to implement the COP21 agreement effectively. In this regard, it is important that incentives and other tools are available to invest in new and greener farming practices.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development states that the world's population will exceed 9 billion by 2050. At the same time, eating habits are changing rapidly: more consumers require animal protein, such as dairy products and meat. This makes it essential to reduce the ecological footprint of agricultural production in order to alleviate the pressure on our environment and arable land. It states that the common agricultural policy should place greater emphasis on the needs of farmers without jeopardising the political objectives, i.e. sufficient flexibility should be allowed to increase innovation and competitiveness. Precision agriculture and the use of big data will transform agriculture and contribute to producing more products using fewer resources and more targeted interventions to combat diseases and pests. It considers targeted incentives for production processes and investments to be vital. Finally, it advocates updating outdated legislation to adapt it to new solutions, such as replacing fertilisers with manure produced from animal manure. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Agricultural practices have evolved over time, transforming either structurally or in relation to the production process, making the agricultural sector one of the most dynamic economic sectors, contemporary agricultural practices being of great modernity. Technological innovation and agricultural technologies have the potential to make agriculture more productive and sustainable.  I am voting in favour of this report because I believe that the challenges of sustainable agriculture must be tackled with a common strategy by the Commission and the Member States to ensure support for technological innovation, a risk-based and evidence-based regulatory framework, the continuity of fundamental research and the development of agricultural skills.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report contains far too many unacceptable elements. It opens the door to changes that we do not want, for example on GMOs. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it offers the Commission a range of innovative ideas and solutions for future European farm management.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. As in all sectors, agricultural innovation is essential in order to be able to cope with the new challenges that arise: an increase in the world's population, a decrease in the area of arable land... This report highlights the role of innovation in economic and environmental sustainability in agricultural production. That is why I voted for it.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European agricultural sector plays a very important role in our daily lives. It primarily provides food, which, in addition to constantly changing eating habits, is a real challenge and, on the other hand, represents the jobs of millions of people. The growth of the world's population and the associated difficulties, hunger on one side and waste and excessive waste production on the other, highlight clear support for innovation. I welcome the fact that the report has concrete proposals.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Dietary preferences rapidly change with more consumers requesting animal protein like dairy and meat. By 2050 food demand is expected to increase by 70%, thus satisfying the growing demand for optimal nutrition, and healthy food represents one of the biggest challenges facing the world. I support this report that aims to enhance innovation and competitiveness in the agricultural sector in order to tackle these new challenges.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it encourages the improvement of agricultural practices within the Union by supporting actors in this sector. It is commendable that the European Parliament has found resources at institutional level to improve the balance between the means and modes of production in modern agriculture and the long-term policy. The report voted on today contains a package of measures favourable to intense but sustainable agricultural development in the context of demographic growth. This sustainable development is necessary to reduce the need for vegetable protein products imported into the European Union and to respond to the diversification of the needs of consumers of agri-food products.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which had as its overall aim the increased use of robotics and GPS driven machinery in agriculture, having the overall effect of taking farmers off the land. As an MEP from a vastly rural constituency, I oppose this move to take farmers off the land, it having an overall effect of decreasing jobs and removing the beating pulse of rural communities. The report further called for the Commission to take into account the use of this technology when assessing farmers’ eligibility for greening payments in CAP – however, it did not take into account the fact that the vast majority of small, family-run farms would not be able to afford this. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because, although the draft has good approaches, I am unfortunately unable to agree with some of the points. For example, the report does not sufficiently reject genetically modified organisms, but on the contrary, leaves a margin of interpretation open.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The world's population is growing and increasing consumption of meat and dairy products. It is therefore necessary to accelerate and encourage innovation and entrepreneurship in agriculture in order to keep pace with such consumption while increasing the ecological footprint of agricultural production.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report, based on the fact that agriculture lags behind other sectors of the capitalist economy in integrating innovation and technology, calls for increased investment and the conditions for profitability for monopolistic groups in the sector. In Greece already banking groups and food monopolies are active in this direction. Any existing problems highlighted in the report, such as pollution and productivity of soils, water, product quality, etc., are addressed on the basis of the EU's competitiveness strategy, taking advantage of its comparative advantages vis-à-vis other imperialist countries in the 'green economy', in the quality of agricultural products, in innovation, in the exploitation of new technologies. It calls for the replacement of public from private systems of disaster production insurance. It seeks adjustments aimed at maximising efficiency and profits, expanding markets and business activity, further boosting capitalist growth, concentration and concentration in agriculture. The only way to exploit scientific and technological achievements for the benefit of the people is the socialization of concentrated means of production by popular power, the organization of the economy with central planning, which will develop research and innovation based on popular needs.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ All societies need good farm management and agricultural innovation but this will not deliver them so we oppose it.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that agriculture is one of the most dynamic and potentially innovative economic sectors, given that the CAP should be more focused on farmers' needs and promote the use of technology and innovation in agriculture, given, finally, that the creation of high-quality products requires innovative elements, also in order to enhance the role of the European Union in the coming years, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is of paramount importance to sustain agricultural production in order to improve the economic prospects of producers. I am convinced that economic development and sustainable production go hand in hand. The new innovations and research play an essential role in fulfilling both the objectives. Hence, I vote in favour of the better economic development of disadvantaged regions such as mountainous and outermost regions as well as small and medium-sized farms, as this is crucial for the better implementation of a stable, sustainable future.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution to strengthen innovation and economic development in the management of European farms in the future. Looking back, in history, agricultural practices have always changed and improved with the development of new tools and tools, the development of new varieties and breeds. The only constants of this development were the environment to which both man and his family who worked in the field and created a safe meal for themselves and society.  Looking ahead, we see the new and countless opportunities that modern technology and technology brings with it. From developing ways of production, soil treatment, breeding, breeding of plants and animals, to monitoring production by drones or from space, etc. However, in all this we must not forget those same historical constants - an environment in which in the future we will produce food and a man and his family, who will still produce food for himself and society in the future. It is in this that I see the fullness of this report, because it looks to the future without forgetting man, family and the environment.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report contains far too many unacceptable elements. It opens the door to changes that we do not want, for example on GMOs. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow. I am voting against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenges posed by population growth over the next few years put us in the face of the need to adapt both our way of producing food and our consumption patterns. This report, which I supported, focuses on agricultural innovation and farm management, with the aim of preparing the right regulatory framework and instruments for agriculture of the future. Not forgetting the importance of defending biodiversity and the high quality of European agricultural products. The key to sustainable agriculture is improving the management of natural resources. There are techniques, such as precision agriculture, computerised management systems and real-time data control, that can help achieve important results such as reduction in fertiliser use, water and lower soil consumption. The reuse of agricultural waste and the recovery of minerals as biological fertilizers are also to be encouraged.  In addition, the report emphasises the need to tackle the problem of food waste. Every year, in Europe, 100 tonnes of food end up in the trash. This waste must be combated at all levels of the food chain, from production to processing and sales to consumption, since 33 % of this waste depends on consumers.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Consumers demand that stricter and higher quality environmental, nutritional and health standards and values be introduced into food production, while at the same time the agricultural sector must become diverse and innovative in order to provide quality, safe and affordable food for all citizens while ensuring decent and sustainable profits for their producers.  On the other hand, the quality of life of agricultural workers and rural communities must be improved. I would like to recall that simpler measures and clearer guidelines for the implementation of CAP measures could encourage farmers to apply more sustainable farming practices. I welcome the European Parliament's decision, while I am concerned about the low level of awareness of the potential of big data and the internet, and the fragmentation of connected technology systems, which increases barriers to greater application and slows startup.  However, I underline the importance of new innovative and affordable solutions for the agricultural sector in terms of making greater use of environmentally friendly methods, goods and resources, including new methods of cultivation and field management, but also ways to increase the use of renewable energy and phasing out the need for fossil fuels.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MeP Engström's report on strengthening innovation and farm development to implement the external dimension of developing innovative plant farming techniques. I welcome the further development of European seed banks, which is essential for the development of new and diverse plant varieties to ensure higher yields, higher nutritional value and better resistance to pests. I emphasise the importance of developing strategic investment in the organic farming sector in order to improve techniques conducive to increasing soil microbiological activity and biodiversity.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am aware that agricultural practices have been undergoing changes since the very birth of agriculture. As a result of these changes, agriculture has become one of the most dynamic economic sectors, the current practices of which are highly modern. However, we are currently facing the problem of the world's population growing to more than 9 billion people by 2050. Therefore, the common agricultural policy needs to be more focused on the needs of farmers without abandoning the pursuement of its policy objectives, i.e. ensuring sufficient flexibility to boost innovation and competitiveness. I believe that promoting production with targeted incentives and investments is key. On the other hand, outdated legislation also needs to be updated in order to provide a framework for new solutions, such as the use of animal manure fertilisers instead of artificial fertilisers. EU agriculture will now and perhaps in the future produce high-quality, value-added products, while providing knowledge-based solutions that will help feed the world's growing population with increasing demands.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European agricultural sector is of fundamental importance to the European Union. It guarantees food supply and is at the same time an essential economic pillar that employs 25 million people directly involved in agricultural work or employed in the food or retail sector. To date, the EU's agricultural sector continues to be the world's benchmark in terms of agricultural practices that enable high-quality, high-value-added products to be produced while providing knowledge-based solutions to feed a constantly growing and needy world population. Therefore, I believe that, if new technological solutions based on innovation and competitiveness in the area of food supply are integrated, EU agriculture will continue to be important in the years to come. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Today, the agricultural sector is facing demand from rapid population growth and is under pressure due to various challenges, including climate change and evolving socio-economic dynamics. European agriculture must therefore produce sufficient food while ensuring the environment, consumer safety and support for farmers. The potential for innovation in agriculture is not fully recognised and the European regulatory framework is not adapted to keep pace with the dynamics of progress. Key challenges need to be addressed in order to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in agriculture.  The EU could make better use of the innovative power of agriculture while ensuring that no legislative act stittles competition. Farmers should be given more freedom in terms of entrepreneurship and innovation. For example, in precision farming, you can limit the amount of plant protection products needed, or the amount of fertilizers required, or even the amount of water.  Agricultural technology will predict where crop pests can be expected, or whether they will attack in a specific place in farmland. I agree with the report's view that agriculture is part of the solution – not part of the problem – in addressing major challenges such as climate change, air and water pollution and animal welfare. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses innovation as a factor of economic and environmental sustainability in agricultural production. This text outlines various proposals that will allow our farmers to access different production techniques on traditional, small farms or in areas that face geographical or natural handicaps, such as mountain areas or overseas.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ All societies need good farm management and agricultural innovation but this will not deliver them so we oppose it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The world's population will increase to more than 9 billion people by 2050. Food preferences change rapidly, with more consumers requiring animal protein, such as dairy products or meat. This requires reducing the ecological footprint of agricultural production in order to relieve pressure on our environment and arable land. Better alignment with other industrial sectors, such as chemicals, health and technology, is needed by improving the intersection of knowledge, integrating the use of resources and better understanding of reciprocal effects in order to optimise their interaction and better integrate agriculture into the circular economy. This will also create more jobs throughout the agri-food value chain and ensure new income streams. The European agricultural sector is of central importance to the Union, ensuring food, being an economic pillar that provides employment to 25 million people who are directly involved in agricultural work, in addition to those working in the food, retail and other complementary sectors.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of this report on strengthening innovation in the agricultural sector. This precision agriculture offers new approaches to managing the entire operation, such as GPS/GNSS-guided machines, which allow arable land to be worked to the nearest centimetre. The text of the voted report estimates that these techniques could lead to a significant reduction in the use of plant protection products and the consumption of water and fertilizer, while combating soil erosion.  The text of the adopted report also calls for the continued development of innovative plant selection techniques, "with the maintenance, however, of euseed banks, as it is crucial to ensure the effective development of new varieties offering better yield, higher nutritional value and better resilience to pests, diseases and adverse weather conditions, and to ensure greater biodiversity".

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European agriculture currently needs help. We must also ensure its viability and help survive the crisis, but at the same time we must also lay the long-term foundations for its growth. Without support for innovation, of course, not entering genetic modifications of plants and animals, we will not do so. I think this report is drawing up quite good guidelines for the future, which are worth supporting.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Agricultural practices have changed both structurally and in the production process, making the sector one of the most economically dynamic.  The common agricultural policy, as the cornerstone of European agriculture, must focus both on farmers and consumers, without compromising policy objectives, making innovation and competitiveness more flexible and improved. As innovations in the field of technology contribute to specific interventions, the application of precision agriculture and large volumes of data will transform agriculture and contribute to higher production using fewer resources.  In addition, alignment with other industrial and technological sectors, such as chemicals, health and technology, is essential to better optimize and integrate agriculture into the circular economy. Thus, technological and/or technical innovations will create more jobs by ensuring new income streams. The potential for innovation in agriculture has not yet been fully achieved, and some important difficulties must be overcome in order to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector, as we are talking about a sector that provides employment for 25 million people and functions as a food reserve for our continent - so I voted for it.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The UN estimates that the earth's population will grow from seven billion to more than nine billion by 2050. For this reason, food production needs to be significantly increased. Over the next 15 years, agricultural production will have to be doubled. It is also very important to reduce food wastage. According to some estimates, 1.3 billion tonnes of food are wasted every year. In Europe alone, 100 million tonnes of food are thrown away every year. We cannot afford this. In future, systems must be developed to distribute edible and unsold foods to charity and to return contaminated food back to the food cycle by composting. Food habits should also be changed. Appropriate nutritional information should be shared in homes and schools in order to learn how to follow a healthy and ecological diet already in childhood. Despite all the enlightenment, we must be prepared for the fact that population growth and rising average incomes will lead to an increase in demand for meat and dairy products. The production volumes of these should not be increased by short-sighted solutions. In meat production, for example, excessive medical care can lead to antibiotic resistance when drugs lose their effectiveness. Agriculture should not be developed either from the point of view of nature or the consumer. It must also be ensured that farmers receive a reasonable income from their work. The EU agricultural sector is a key pillar of the Union's economy, safeguarding security of supply and employing tens of millions on farms and in food and retail sales. The Huitema report is important and contains a lot of proposals to support, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technology at the service of agriculture makes it possible to increase its innovation and competitiveness. I voted in favour of the report discussed in the AGRI Committee, which is about encouraging innovation and economic development in the management of European farms, because I support the idea of increasingly technological agriculture. Some Italian areas, such as the Po Valley, are concrete proof of the positive results that technology can bring in the agricultural sector. Much more can be done to improve productivity. The implementation of new technologies will in fact allow to achieve this goal by using fewer resources and with a greater attention to respect for the environment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because I believe that the innovation and development of the farms proposed by the rapporteur is contrary to the model of agro-ecological agriculture that we are defending. The report opens the door to the introduction of robotics on farms, such as the use of sensors to control livestock and drones. Although I am not against the use of these technologies, it seems to me to be a report designed for the benefit of large farms that have a high borrowing capacity to introduce new systems. On the other hand, the report proposes the introduction of more sophisticated risk management systems, which deepens my suspicions that it is a report designed for agri-food corporations, and not so that farmers and peasants can improve their working conditions.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Neuitema report on promoting innovation and economic development in future European agricultural management. By 2050, the UN estimates that the global population will exceed 9 billion, and food demand will increase exponentially in parallel with changing diets in different regions of the globe. With resources limited and climate change are making its effects increasingly acute, European agriculture must produce more but more sustainably. Innovation is essential when we talk about intelligent water use and better environmental protection, but I want to stress that food safety and health must never be compromised. I believe that better coordination with the EIB and increased investment in the agricultural sector must be one of the priorities of European governments as well as of the European Commission.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Due to demographic challenges, adapting both food production and the way we consume and dispose of food will be necessary. By strengthening innovation and promoting techniques such as ICT-based management and data monitoring in real time, we can reduce fertiliser use, improve soil quality and water management.  However, it is important that we tackle the major problem of food waste at the same time. Every year, 100 million tonnes of food are thrown into Europe. The report ensures a balanced approach that focuses on both innovation and food waste. That is why I support the report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on improving innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms'. The report emphasises the importance of doing more for sustainable agriculture and promoting innovation in this direction. Family farms, in particular, are an important part of European agriculture and should be given more support in the future. It also calls for support to be given to farmers in less-favoured areas and for all farms to be given easier access to financial support.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we need to support innovation in the agricultural sector in order to increase productivity and sustainability. In view of the rising demand for food as a result of global population growth and some negative effects that agriculture may have on the climate, constructive measures need to be taken to enable farmers to produce more food, with less resources and more climate-friendly.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I totally disagree with it. I believe that the new techniques, new varieties and new machinery proposed in this report will further increase dependence on agrochemical multinationals, industry and banks, increasing the gap between large producers of industrialized food and small-scale agriculture, with the increase in the disappearance of small farms, local varieties, cultural heritage related to traditional forms of agriculture Etc.  The solution would come through a system change, which is not based on technology and machinery, but on an agro-ecological production system, the defence of small-scale farmers, local varieties and, in most cases, the recovery of traditional forms of cultivation, short production-consumption circuits, and food sovereignty. Also social participation, and environmental education programs for responsible production and consumption.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agricultural sector in the EU has always sought new practices, techniques and production methods with which to increase production and improve the ability of agricultural practices to adapt to changing new circumstances, as well as reduce production costs and consumption of the raw materials used. In order to ensure adequate profitability for the agricultural sector, it is appropriate to invest in innovation, research and development of new governance and business models. In this regard, this report stresses the importance of adopting new solutions aimed at increasing the use of innovative methods, goods and resources, capable of reviving the economic development of the entire sector. Considering innovation and sustainability to be two key aspects for the future of agriculture in the EU, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Innovation in agriculture requires sufficient investment in research and development and the involvement of farmers in the search for solutions and dissemination of results. Innovative solutions such as those that comprise precision agriculture must be at the service of all types of exploitation. They shall present a cost/opportunity ratio proportionate to the financial capacities of smaller holdings, such as those in more remote or outermost areas, such as Acores, where agriculture is an essential activity for local employment. Agriculture, to feed the world, must adapt to the challenge of climate change and make rational use of available resources. To this end, we need innovative solutions, based on technology or a different view of traditional practices, in a process where farmers must be in the spotlight, as key actors of change and the subject of proper training.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Unlike the McIntyre Report on ‘Technological solutions for sustainable agriculture’, this report from Jan Huitema is much more balanced and includes some key policy points which Labour MEPs have been advocating. We need to see a range of innovative ideas and solution if we’re going to have a dynamic and fit-for-purpose European agriculture sector, particularly in terms of farm management.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European agricultural sector is generally of fundamental importance to the Union, as it provides food and, at the same time, is a key economic pillar providing work for the 25 million people directly involved in farm work. Although agriculture is one of the most dynamic economic sectors, in recent years we have seen problems everywhere in the world with a decline in natural productivity and soil fertility caused by soil degradation, in particular soil erosion, as a result of the loss of ecosystem functions such as topsoil formation, hummus, pollination, water retention and nutrient circulation. I supported the resolution because I believe that the proposals and measures on the table in the current report can contribute to strengthening innovation and economic development in the area of farm management, especially for small and medium-sized farmers. However, helping farmers and their groupings to introduce innovative products will require stronger financial support from the EU and the removal of any barriers to access to credit to help them expand their business.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Changes in agricultural practice are structural or related to production processes. They make the agricultural sector one of the most dynamic sectors. As this sector is among the first to introduce new technology, the rural economy can be thriving and follows overall economic development.  The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations estimates that the expected increase in the world's population will lead to an increase in food supply. This requires increasing and improving agricultural production with fewer resources, in particular because of the pressure on natural resources and the associated effects on biodiversity, environmental vulnerability, climate change and land scarcity.  However, I think that the report is somewhat ambiguous and could be understood as supporting innovations that are contrary to my principles. While I understand that these are necessary for progress, it is necessary to ensure that they are health-friendly, environmentally friendly and do not have negative consequences in other areas.  I am opposed to the mention of drones and certain sections of the report that give the possibility of supporting GENETICALLY MODIFIED mechanisms. Although the report advocates the idea that greater transparency in the supply chain and production can help consumers make more informed decisions when purchasing products, which I agree with, I believe that the report should be improved.  For this very reasons, I voted against it.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Like Mrs McIntyre's report, this initiative report goes against our logic. It focuses on "high tech, high investment, high cost" solutions. It is based on the idea that Europe must feed the world and it extrapolates the figures of population growth on a global scale. And it drives increased productivity, precision agriculture, exports and a business approach that will lead to less employment and more factory farming for meat production. It also 'repackages' the classic approach to fertilizers and pesticides that the farmer only makes dependent on this input. Despite the fact that we have been able to make considerable adjustments to this report, there are still some difficult points. For example, the rapporteur would like to promote Climate Smart Agriculture. This in itself is an interesting way of thinking, but agro-ecology is also Climate Smart and does not use new gene techniques.  Many aspects of this report are environmental issues that would not have made it to the Environment Committee because they go against mainstream power. Perhaps that is why the report was not discussed by the Committee on the Environment? I finally voted against it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European small farms as well as small and medium-sized enterprises could become leaders in innovation in agriculture. To this end, we should in future allocate part of the funds that are now disappearing purposelessly in the common agricultural policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Due to soil erosion, and especially due to degradation, internal fertility and productivity of arable soils have declined, and the loss of ecosystem functions such as humification and pollination are the causes of soil erosion. The effectiveness of ecosystem functions needs to be increased in an innovative way in order to establish climate resilience.  Also, according to estimates by UN food and agriculture organisations, the expected growth of the world's population to 9.1 billion people by 2050 requires a 60% increase in the production of quality and safe food. Consumers are already demanding the production of better and safer food as well as better nutritional and health values of the same, which means that it is necessary for agricultural production to increase and improve, while on the other hand being environmentally sensitive and making more use of natural processes and ecosystem services.  An important fact is that the EU employs 47 million people in the retail and food processing sectors and in food services that contribute positively to the trade balance. Finally, there is a large part of the area of abandoned agricultural land that has been untreated in some Member States, which needs to be exploited and adapted with the help of technologies and agri-ecological approaches, as they can significantly help farms. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. Improving innovation and economic development in the future management of European farms is an undeniable necessity. However, the resolution of an EU Parliament cannot prejudge the necessary agricultural and economic decisions of individual farmers in 28 Member States. That is why I voted against this text. It has no added value.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) estimates that increasing the world's population by 2050 will also require a 60% increase in the production of safe and high-quality food while preserving resources for future generations and preventing food waste and loss. By 2030, agricultural productivity needs to be doubled to achieve the SDGs, while the agri-food sector will need to adapt to climate change and improve the quality of ecosystems.  The European Union is the world's largest exporter of agricultural products. The agri-food sector is a key economic pillar of the Union, employing 47 million people and contributing 7.2% of the total value of EU exports. The European Union food and agriculture market is one of the most integrated markets in Europe and regulations are needed to ensure more uniform conditions and fair competitiveness to boost economic development in all Member States. I support the guidance set out in this report, as I believe it will lead to a more productive and resource-efficient agricultural model that makes better use of products essential to address sustainability. I also believe that this is a step forward towards increasing farmland processed.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on strengthening innovation and economic development in European farm management in the future.  As in other sectors, the agricultural sector is facing significant progress and the development of new ways, techniques and production methods. This increased farmers' yields and reduced production costs.  The report rightly notes that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive and can be achieved through innovation, research and development, new governance and improved agronomy.  We must therefore promote innovation in technology and governance.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 There are significant challenges that need to be addressed to accelerate and stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. The report promotes a common agricultural policy, focusing more on the needs of farmers without compromising policy objectives. We agree that the adoption of new technologies by the agricultural sector will ensure the growth of the rural economy. Young farmers, the natural environment and health take precedence and through these innovations they can benefit.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I agree with the need to promote innovation and economic development in agriculture, which is why I voted in favour of this report. I agree that for as long as agriculture has existed, agricultural practices have changed: whether they are structural or related to your production process. I share the view that these changes have made agriculture one of the most dynamic economic sectors. However, I believe that the promotion of innovation will not go in one fell swo down, or merely with central incentives. This needs to be understood at Member State level and innovation and economic promotion at local level is needed. For example, in order to reduce food waste, social channels can be found, food should be used on time rather than thrown away. With regard to the new innovative breeding process, I think it is important to get a resolution from the Commission as soon as possible in order to prevent an unfounded social rejection. Breeding should not be mixed with GMO techniques. But in order to create an environment that encourages innovation, we need to create harmony in the areas of energy, taxation and production, all of which have an impact on innovation. Similarly, I consider it important to increase knowledge of ecosystems and raise awareness, which will allow for a more rational use of the interaction between chemical and biological measures. Targeted incentives for production processes and investments are therefore vital.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 European agricultural policy must stop supporting the outdated status quo and focus on innovation. We must take all measures to increase the quantity of high-quality agricultural products, ensuring the supply of food for all, while effectively combating climate change. Agriculture now, like other sectors of the economy, must unleash its innovation potential, and the Member States and the Union should be involved in this process. The European Parliament's report properly outlined the current obstacles and the relatively small scale of innovation in agriculture. This is due to a variety of obstacles, including insufficient transfer of knowledge to farmers by researchers, high initial costs of purchasing the necessary machinery, in particular for small farmers, and the fact that the rules are not always adapted to the specific needs of the agricultural sector. In addition, it is also worth considering creating new financing opportunities for farmers in cooperation with the European Investment Bank and further developing existing risk management tools.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because improving innovation and economic development in farm management is one of the themes to which the EU's agricultural policy must pay attention. Through innovation, we can also combine other industries more effectively with agriculture. By combining different industries and thinking innovatively, we can make agriculture more competitive and support farmers during the agricultural crisis by offering new solutions.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of new technologies and innovation in agriculture has led this area to unprecedented development, ensuring the success of the rural economy and wider economic development. At the same time, demographic pressure on agriculture will lead to increased pressure on the environment and arable land, leading to the need to strengthen the innovation process and the EU's Common Agricultural Policy.  New legislative measures could promote the abandonment of generic practices, more efficient use of resources, integrated pest management through the use of biological methods and less chemical methods, the replacement of artificial fertilisers with those from garbage produced by domestic animals. At the same time, there would be a need for better harmonisation between agriculture and other industrial sectors, on chemicals, health and technology, in order to better integrate into the circular economy.  Given the importance of the agricultural sector for the Union, in the context that 25 million people are directly involved in this activity and the result of their work ensures the food supply of European citizens, I believe that this report is very important for the proper management of the agricultural sector in the future.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The expected rise in the world’s population to 9.1 billion by 2050 will require a 60% increase in food supply and a 24% increase in crop yields, according to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). This is why I voted in favour of this report, which makes a series of observations and recommendations as how to meet the challenges of climate change, rising food demand, population growth and threats to the environment. I firmly believe that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive and are achievable mainly through innovation, research and development, new governance, business models and improved agronomy. Concretely, I am particularly supportive of the ideas of improving the regulation to make it more coherent and clear with room for entrepreneurship, encouraging transfer of knowledge from researchers to farmers, creating new financing opportunities for farmers, as well as encouraging the use of innovative agriculture techniques.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. We face three challenges that agricultural innovation can address: a food challenge, with the prospect of having to feed 9.1 billion people by 2050, an environmental challenge, due to the degradation and depletion of natural resources, and finally a climate challenge, linked to climate change at work and the risks they entail. Meeting these challenges requires redefining the objectives of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and facilitating financing for agricultural innovation. The scope of possible innovations is wide, whether technological innovations (digital, robotics), innovations in agricultural practices (better protection and value of resources), or in terms of social organisation (e.g. developing the circular economy). The stakes here are twofold. The redefinition of the CAP's objectives must certainly provide solutions to the challenges of agriculture, but it must also ensure that it does not leave farmers alone in the face of crises in their sector, such as in milk or pig farming. Innovation must be at the service of enhancing agricultural potential, sustainability and food security.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I supported the report on the future management of innovation and the future of economic development in the field of European farms. The importance of the European agricultural sector is fundamental in terms of the European Union's economy. This sector not only provides food, but is at the same time a pillar of development, as it provides jobs for 25 million people. people who work directly in agriculture. People from the manufacturing, food and trade sector should also be included here. Union agriculture must therefore concentrate on innovation, which will ensure, as far as possible, the nutritional autonomy of Europe. The common agricultural policy should therefore pay more attention to the needs of farmers, in particular as regards aid for the production of different products and services in this sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on strengthening innovation and economic development in the management of European farms in the future, as it underlines the importance of innovation in the agricultural sector and their contribution to further strengthening the sector and its competitiveness in the future.  According to UN data, agricultural productivity needs to be doubled by 2030 in order to achieve the SDGs, while at the same time the agricultural sector will have to adapt to climate change and improve the quality of ecosystems and soil.  I believe that innovation is an essential tool and a horizontal priority in cap development and implementation policy for the period 2014-2020, so the Commission needs to provide a more ambitious comprehensive strategy with measurable results to bring research and innovation in line with policy priorities.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I have supported the strengthening of innovation and economic development in European farm management in the future. The agricultural sector is one of the most dynamic economic sectors and is one of the first to introduce new technologies. The ecological footprint of agricultural production should be reduced in order to alleviate pressure on the environment. Greater attention should be paid to the needs of farmers, without jeopardising the achievement of policy objectives, which means that we should allow sufficient flexibility to strengthen innovation and competitiveness. Targeted incentives in the production process and investments are of paramount importance. Agriculture needs to be better adapted to other industrial sectors, knowledge integration needs to be strengthened, resource use integrated and mutual effects better understood in order to optimise their interaction and better integrate agriculture into the market economy. The European agricultural sector is of crucial importance to the entire European Union in terms of providing food and employment to 25 million people. It also sets standards for agricultural practice around the world and enables the production of products with high added value.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Family or small and medium sized farms are an integral part of the European agricultural sector and provide social and economic dynamism to rural areas, thereby contributing to the conservation of cultural and natural heritage. It is positive that the CAP could be more flexible and could be adapted to local needs without further administrative burdens. Innovation, new business models and precision agricultural technologies are particularly important to increase performance and adapt to new and changing production methods and circumstances. I support these measures to improve opportunities for development of rural and mountain areas.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The very title of this report speaks volumes about the ideological mess it constitutes. He delivers a large number of ideas, measures, tracks of new regulations, which I regularly fight: - excessive productivity; - exaltation of the CAP, the Europe 2020 strategy, the digital single market; - dogmatic defence of ICTs, when they are not always effective (particularly in the establishment of registers by GPS, often approximate); - promoting global harmonisation of the European market through, among other things, the use and exchange of personal data; - the desire to create jobs, but the Commission's incentive to force ever more automation of tasks; - will to put in place, via the Commission, a single European legislation for drones and RPAS. Above all, Mr Huitema distills, throughout his report, his promotion of GMOs and strongly calls into question the existing legislation in Europe on this subject. "Biostimulants," "biocontrol," "biological control mechanisms" are therefore sold as indispensable tools for 21st century agriculture. There are far too many unacceptable elements to this initiative report. It opens the door to changes that I don't want. The few interesting findings are drowned in a disturbing ultraliberal flow. I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Estimates show that by 2050, the world's population will exceed the threshold of 9 billion people. In the context of current demographic and commercial dynamics, food preferences are changing rapidly, but the potential for innovation in agriculture is not adequately recognised. The European regulatory framework is also not adapted to keep up with developments. In this respect, this report stresses that, within the framework of the common agricultural policy, emphasis must be placed on the need to strengthen innovation and competitiveness. The aim is to transform agriculture to achieve greater production, using fewer resources and through effective disease or pest control interventions. New solutions adapted to human needs are therefore needed to maintain productivity and standards for global agricultural practices in order to obtain high-quality and high-value-added products. Last but not least, the European agricultural sector is extremely important in social terms, as it provides jobs for more than 25 million people. I therefore voted in favour of the Report on the promotion of innovation and economic development in the context of future European agricultural management.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 For as long as agriculture has existed, agricultural practices have changed, whether structural or related to the production process. These changes have made agriculture one of the most dynamic economic sectors: today's agricultural practices are modern. The development of the rural economy and the need to keep up with wider economic development are ensured by the sector being at the forefront of the takeover of new technologies. Making better use of the innovation capacity ensures that agriculture can be part of a number of solutions. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because I believe that the innovation and development of the farms proposed by the rapporteur is contrary to the model of agro-ecological agriculture that we are defending. The report opens the door to the introduction of robotics on farms, such as the use of sensors to control livestock and drones. Although we are not against the use of these technologies, it seems to me to be a report designed for the benefit of large farms that have a high borrowing capacity to introduce new systems. On the other hand, the report proposes the introduction of more sophisticated risk management systems, which deepens my suspicions that it is a report designed for agri-food corporations, and not so that farmers and peasants can improve their working conditions.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on enhancing innovation and economic development in future European farm management. I am strongly committed to unleashing agriculture’s innovative potential in order to produce more quality products, ensure food supplies and fight climate change more effectively. I believe that agriculture is one of the most innovative economic sectors. However, although farmers have the capacity and the knowledge to innovate, they find themselves limited by obsolete legislation or rules. It is of crucial importance to trust farmers and to use the power of innovation and the power of nature in order to reach our common goals.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing.
