The report highlights the importance of innovation in improving European agricultural production and the economic prospects of producers, stressing that economic development and sustainable production are not exclusive. It also bets on the need to enhance access to investment for farmers and stresses the importance of benefits also reaching both small- and medium-scale family farms as well as mountainous and remote regions. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'My Dutch liberal colleague Jan Huitema has convinced me very much of his vision for the future of agriculture in Europe. The report is positive and emphasises the innovation and economic viability of our primary producers. I voted with conviction for this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, the world's population will reach 9.1 billion by 2050; as a result, the food supply will need to be increased by 60%. This is an opportunity that the European agri-food industry will no doubt seize. To encourage this, this report supports a widespread use of information and communications technologies (ICTs) to improve 'competitiveness and innovation'. The usual European leitmotifs with the expected result: rising productivity and incomes, and even job creation. However, it is worth recalling the consequences of the "Green Revolution" of the 1930s and 1960s. During this period, other new technologies were generalized with the known negative effects on small farmers, the environment, and food sovereignty. We are paying the consequences today. Moreover, this report risks opening the door to GMOs, and the solutions advocated, based mainly on technology and machinery, cannot be the right ones. Rather, it is a change in the system that needs to be moved towards an agro-ecological way of producing that defends small farmers. So I voted against it without hesitation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report contains positive and relevant aspects. Yet it passes alongside reality. And reality tells us that today, in the Western world, too much food is produced, you pay to eliminate food products. Today's technology applied to agriculture has become a problem that will only end with a new economic model of production and distribution. Technology is now at the origin of intensive production that endangers biodiversity and the balance of our planet. GMOs and glyphosate, which the Commission has considered to extend for another seven years, are illustrious children of this technology. We do not deny the need for further research in agricultural practices. But first we have to understand each other. Agriculture subject to the laws of capitalism and the maximum accumulation of profit can only give rise to increasingly intensive and productiontechnologies.  Before we talk about technology, it is therefore important to reverse our cap today completely liberalised.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft provides some very traceable approaches to increasing the productivity of the agricultural economy. However, since it does not disclose sufficient rejection of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on the crucial points, but on the contrary leaves open inappropriate scope for interpretation, I cannot agree with this amendment in this form.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I endorse this parliamentary resolution. The agricultural sector is an important part of our economy. As is the case in all sectors, continuous technological innovation is needed if supply wants to meet demand. At the same time it will help to achieve this goal in a sustainable manner. With this in mind, this resolution calls for increasing flexibility in this sector and more space to be left for innovation. Therefore, any legislation needs to be targeted and have a clear purpose. Legislation that is out-of-date or obsolete should either be updated or removed. In addition, we need to enhance better cooperation with other sectors. This will eventually lead to more innovation, an improved agri-food chain and new jobs. To conclude, by embracing technology and innovation, the EU’s agricultural sector will remain one of the most modern, efficient and competitive in the world.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on the promotion of innovation and economic development in the context of future European agricultural management. This initiative underlines the importance of innovation in order to have sustainable agriculture. The report also points out that small family farms are an integral part of European agriculture and therefore they also need to benefit from the latest production techniques.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am very much in favour of this report as I believe it is key for the EU to be able to ensure a prosperous rural economy. To this end, the use and empowerment of innovation in various areas of the sector is certainly imperative. In Spain, for example, innovation has been considered indispensable for years to achieve a more sustainable and competitive agricultural sector, because this makes it easier to address issues such as both economic, social and environmental sustainability. I therefore support this initiative which will undoubtedly bring great progress to current and future productivity, sustainability and efficiency challenges.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report, based on the fact that agriculture lags behind other sectors of the capitalist economy in integrating innovation and technology, calls for increased investment and the conditions for profitability for monopolistic groups in the sector. In Greece already banking groups and food monopolies are active in this direction. Any existing problems highlighted in the report, such as pollution and productivity of soils, water, product quality, etc., are addressed on the basis of the EU's competitiveness strategy, taking advantage of its comparative advantages vis-à-vis other imperialist countries in the 'green economy', in the quality of agricultural products, in innovation, in the exploitation of new technologies. It calls for the replacement of public from private systems of disaster production insurance. It seeks adjustments aimed at maximising efficiency and profits, expanding markets and business activity, further boosting capitalist growth, concentration and concentration in agriculture. The only way to exploit scientific and technological achievements for the benefit of the people is the socialization of concentrated means of production by popular power, the organization of the economy with central planning, which will develop research and innovation based on popular needs.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much welcome today's vote on this report, which saw me as draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. This own-initiative report addresses important issues for the agriculture of the future, such as, in particular, the need to focus on sustainable agriculture that can ensure an adequate and quality food supply while preserving the environment and resources for future generations also in the light of the new economic model for the development of the circular economy. At the same time, the report stresses that it is essential to combat food waste in the light of the fact that 1.3 billion tonnes of food are wasted or lost every year and at the same time 800 million people suffer from chronic hunger and more than two billion people are malnourished, generating a situation that is no longer tolerable. In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleagues with whom I have worked over the last few months and call on the European Commission to take on our recommendations.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Huitema report because I believe that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive and that it is possible to modernise European farms through innovation, research and development. Tomorrow's demographic challenges require adaptations in both food production and the way we consume and dispose of it (every year 100 million tonnes of food is wasted in the EU, with 33% of this waste being produced by consumers).  I underline the need to create synergies between new forms of economic development in agriculture and our consumption patterns in line with the principles of the circular economy. The role of agriculture is paramount in this regard through the prudent use of natural resources. I would also like to point out the potential for job creation not only in the food production sector, but also in the tourism and green bioeconomy sectors, especially in an area where the EU is already the world's largest exporter of agricultural products, making the agri-food sector an essential economic pillar of the Union.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. It is estimated that the world's population will exceed nine billion people by 2050. In order to feed this population, food production will have to increase, according to this report. The answer to this challenge is to promote technological innovations in the agricultural sector in order to focus on intensive production. The report believes that technological innovations can help us to implement targeted interventions in agriculture. The idea is to produce more by also using precision agriculture in the fight against diseases and pests and therefore, once again by allowing and promoting the use of pesticides and fertilizers. The aim of the document is to promote the harmonisation of the agricultural sector with other industrial sectors, such as the chemical, health and technological sectors. All things that can only see me against. At M5S we strive for quality production, we are to produce better and in a sustainable way. The European Union is already in agricultural overproduction. We must concentrate our efforts on combating food waste; 30 % of agricultural product in the EU is thrown away. We want agriculture that is increasingly attentive and respectful of the environment and biodiversity. We want quality food on our plate. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on strengthening innovation and economic development in European farm management in the future. The report stresses the importance of innovation for sustainable agricultural production and stresses that it is essential that small and medium-sized family farms, which are an integral part of European agriculture, introduce advanced production techniques. I agree that economic development and sustainable production are not mutually exclusive, and it is therefore necessary to promote innovation, research and the development of production techniques.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, Federica Mogherini and I are very happy to be with you here today. As you know, in the last couple of months we have been working very closely with your Parliament on the issue of the smugglers working between Turkey and Greece, the terrible loss of life in the Aegean Sea. Because of what we have done, the business model of the smugglers on that road has been broken, people are no longer dying in the Aegean, and the numbers coming across from Turkey are very low indeed. But, look at the southern Mediterranean. People are dying, drowning in the sea. Smugglers have found a new business model, so our work is far from over. We must do the same we have done on the route through the Aegean also in the southern Mediterranean to find solutions, sustainable solutions.  We cannot tolerate this, the loss of human life on this scale, and we must do everything we can to stop it. That means we must engage more effectively with third countries of origin and transit to address the migration challenge in the long term, but also right now, immediately, and by we, I mean both the EU and the Member States. Learning from last year’s most important lessons, including the Valletta summit, today we propose a new partnership framework for across-the-board cooperation on migration with third countries. And we are asking you, the European Parliament, the European Council, Member States and the European Investment Bank, to give it their full backing. This framework rethinks how all actors – Member States, EU institutions and third countries – work together to bring order to migration flows and strive for well-managed migration. It establishes a result-oriented approach to mobilise and focus all EU and Member States’ tools and resources for that purpose.  We propose to use a mix of positive and negative incentives to reward those third countries willing to cooperate effectively with us and to ensure that there are consequences for those who do not. This includes using our development and trade policies to create leverage. Member States would need to play their part and be ready to mirror this approach through their actions and resources. We will set up a coordination mechanism to make sure we fully tap the EU’s collective influence. Together, we can achieve much more.  Operationally, our short-term objective is to save lives in the Mediterranean, increase returns of those who do not have the right to stay, and enable migrants and refugees to stay closer to home rather than embark on dangerous journeys. As we stem irregular migration flows, we must open up legal ways to Europe for those in need, in particular with more resettlement for refugees.  We will develop compacts tailored to each partner country’s specific circumstances, whether country of origin or transit or hosting a large refugee population. This approach will help bring tangible benefits for the refugees, for third countries, and obviously for the European Union and our own citizens.  We propose to first launch contacts with a limited number of priority countries: Jordan, Lebanon, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Mali and Ethiopia. We will also increase our engagement with Tunisia and Libya. To start with, the focus will be on improving border and migration management on the ground. This will require appropriate financing. The Africa Trust Fund will immediately be strengthened with EUR 500 million from the reserve of the European Development Fund. We are calling on Member States to match this to reach one billion. This could be done now, not waiting for the next boat to capsize. But this is not only about additional funds. This is as much, maybe even more, about better mobilising the funds we – the EU and Member States – have at our disposal. Combining our forces, a total of EUR eight billion could be made available to support the compacts for the next five years.  Looking at longer-term challenges, we also need to do more to improve opportunities in countries of origin so people are not compelled to leave. For that, we need to reconsider our traditional models of development cooperation and give a much greater role to private investors. While bottlenecks to investment differ across regions, we think we can replicate outside Europe the success, if not the exact design, of our internal European Fund for Strategic Investments, so we will shortly propose a new external investment fund aiming to crowd in private investment in developing countries starting with Africa and the EU’s neighbourhood. For this we will mobilize EUR 3.1 billion which should trigger total investment of up to 31 billion, and we could even reach 62 billion if Member States and other partners match the EU’s contribution.  I am convinced that by doing this, we can reach concrete results together with our partners. For this, we need the full commitment of all EU institutions, Member States and partner countries.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vicepresidente della Commissione e Alto Rappresentante dell'Unione per gli affari esteri e la politica di sicurezza – Signora Presidente, mi permetta di usare un momento per associarmi al sentimento di dolore che quest'Aula ha espresso ieri per la perdita di Gianluca Buonanno. Siamo sempre stati, io e Gianluca, su posizioni opposte, anche in modo vivace, come era sempre con lui, sia in quest'Aula sia quando eravamo insieme al Parlamento italiano. Sicuramente oggi saremmo stati su posizioni opposte. Ma siamo innanzitutto esseri umani. Davanti a questo immenso dolore, vorrei esprimere le mie più sincere condoglianze alla famiglia, innanzitutto alla moglie e ai bambini, ai suoi cari e anche al suo gruppo politico sia qui che in Italia. Switching to English and turning to the issue we are presenting today, together with Frans, together with the rest of our colleagues in the Commission. We have today a couple of very strong messages on one side – political messages – and also a couple of very strong, concrete commitments that we are presenting today. We hope we will get the full support of the Parliament, and also of the Council and the rest of the institutions.  The first message is in the method; we are sitting here together again and last month we were also sitting here together on another issue: I think it was on the SDGs. This is the way in which this Commission has chosen to work; joining the different strengths of our policies, works and tools – external and internal – and trying to give a strategic vision to our actions. I would like to thank not only Frans, but also our services, for the excellent teamwork we have developed over these years. The second strong message is a shift in paradigm and attitude. We need to move from the narrative we have had so far – that the refugee and migration crisis is a European crisis, to the recognition that this is not only an issue for Europe. The majority of the movements of people in the world are happening inside Africa, inside Asia and not only towards Europe, and that it is a global phenomenon that we need to face with a global approach. I was in New York yesterday addressing the UN Security Council, meeting the Secretary-General and working with them on the preparation of the summit on migration that the UN will hold in the margins of the General Assembly in September. This is the right approach that we are trying to encourage. It is a global responsibility: every single partner, every single country, every single region in the world, every single regional organisation and every international institution has to do its part. Europe is trying to do its part, saving lives and saving lives at sea. With our operation Sophia, we have saved already tens of thousands of lives. All others have to do the same. Also, because it is not only the people that are dying at sea that we have to save, it is also the thousands of people dying in the desert before they reach the shores of the Mediterranean – they are not on our TV screens, but they are also human lives. This is a shift in mentality, a shift in approach, that would bring us to build partnerships; global partnerships are what we need to face a global phenomenon like this. The third strong message is that we need to focus on our partnership approach, firstly with the countries of our immediate region around the Mediterranean – compacts with Jordan and Lebanon were already decided in February. In this package, we have a strong message for their implementation, but the other message we have is a strong focus on Africa. Africa, for demographic reasons, for economic reasons, for inequalities, for climate change reasons, is going to continue to be a major continent when it comes to movement of people. This is not going to disappear anytime soon unless we take a strategic approach in the long term – as well as in the immediate term – to face the inequalities and the policy issues that are at the core of the reason why people are leaving their own countries. With this communication, we put our relations with Africa in terms of strategic partnership, strongly and also with some resources on it. So coming to the facts and the commitments. Frans already mentioned the numbers of the economic commitment we put in. Firstly, there is the increased contribution to the trust fund for Africa – the extra EUR 500 million – bringing it to EUR 2.3 billion for EU funds for migration-related actions in Africa. Let me here raise a plea to the Member States to match this commitment, because we will need to be consistent on that side too. The second concrete commitment: the renewed partnerships under the migration compacts tailored to the priority countries we have identified, Jordan and Lebanon. As I have said, we already developed compacts during the London conference earlier this year, so now it is about delivering on this. We have identified Nigeria, Niger, Senegal, Mali and Ethiopia as further priority countries. I have launched already processes to debate with all of them in the last seven or eight months to discuss with their governments and presidents, as well as civil society and local authorities, what is needed in these countries. Sometimes it is specific areas of the countries or specific villages or regions in the countries where the majority of the flows originate, because of difficult economic, climatic, social or sometimes human rights situations. Our actions must be targeted where they are needed, and we have to have a win-win approach, moving from the delivery of aid to investment in Africa, especially starting with the aforementioned countries.  The win-win approach is what we need because, if this is a global phenomenon, we need to manage it together. This means that these countries, which are at the same time countries of origin, of transit and of destination, all need our support to manage better their internal challenges when it comes to hosting refugees and migrants. This also means providing support to the local authorities, infrastructures and possibility to sustain the effort from all different points of view.  Third, the long-term approach. Frans mentioned that we have launched an external investment plan which is a Copernican revolution in our approach to development cooperation. We discussed this with the EU development ministers and the foreign ministers in the last two Foreign Affairs Councils. Investing in Africa and trying to mix, in a smart way, European funds, public funds, private investors – we don't have to be scared of bringing the private sector in – and international financial institutions, starting with the EIB as guarantors. Following the good example of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, we need to learn the lessons that can be learned there, and develop a long—term investment plan for our partners who need infrastructure, social improvements, creation of jobs and support for growth in those countries. This, I believe, is finally an approach that is at the same time immediate and strategic. This can complement, in a coherent way, the proposals that we adopted last year with the agenda on migration, which already had one external part of measures. This builds on that, on the excellent achievement we had in the Valetta summit, building on partnership with our African friends and developing in a coherent way the work we have done in the last year, broadening and deepening our work, both in the immediate and in the short term.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-Presidents, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Migration is the mega-issue of our time, and we will probably have many more discussions about it. The principle is clear to my group: they are two sides of the same coin. One is: yes to help, yes to partnership – we must stop dying in our neighbourhood. On the other hand, however, it is also very clear that we must protect Europe from new waves of immigration, from new waves of migration, which Europeans are also afraid of. These are the two sides of the coin to be answered. First of all, it is important for me to do what both the Commission representatives have made clear, first of all to communicate to our citizens: if Europe is united, if we have good Commission proposals, then we can also deliver. The months-long exceptional situation in the Balkans has been stopped, and the wave-through has ended. We have now restored law and order in the Aegean. The smuggling gangs are being put to work. And the most important thing that has been said is that at least death has been curbed, fewer people are dying in the Aegean. In other words, if we act together, we will deliver. Aid is also arriving more on the ground, the first few hundred million of the new funds have now been invested, for example, in Turkey, and we are helping on the ground. It works, and we all know that it is only the beginning of a long-term development to get to grips with migration issues. That is why we need to work on legislation. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to express my thanks for the fact that we have found such good cooperation in the LIBE Committee on the Coast Guard and that we are showing there that we want to deliver together, including on safe third countries, on all the issues that we are putting forward in terms of legislation. It is disappointing, I would also like to say, that, according to the latest figures, the Member States are failing in the African Trust Fund. We have 1.8 billion from the EU budget on the table and so far only 81 million have been provided by the Member States. The Council, which is not here, should write this down. The commitments made in Valletta should also be implemented, please! That is the first step. The second step, however, is now the question of how we deal strategically with our neighbour, Africa. We must all be aware that the fate of our continent, the fate of Europe, is closely linked to the development of the African continent. I would therefore like to thank the Commission for its proposals today, from Federica Mogherini, from Frans Timmermans, and I would also like to mention Commissioners Hahn and Mr Stylianides, who have worked on them. Thank you for that. These are good basic proposals for the work we have to do. If we realise that Africa's population can double by 2050, it is one of the mega-themes of our time, to which Europe must provide answers. We have to describe the truths. The truth is that we must turn, we must take the problems seriously, not only out of pity for Africa, but out of self-interest. Out of self-interest, we must turn to this continent. We will also have to invest more money, we will have to give up more prosperity. We will have to make better use of the funds that have already been made available, but we will also have to break new ground. That is why I would also like to emphasise, on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, that the idea of rebuilding the EFSI for Africa, using the leverage approach, will be constructive in our approach, and that we are open to it. Trade policy has been mentioned: an important tool of the European Union. We need to build partnership through trade policy, not so much from a European perspective, but also more from the African perspective. But we also need to be clear. For if a partner in Africa does not cooperate, for example, on the repatriation of illegal immigrants, on the repatriation of rejected refugees and asylum seekers, then this must also have consequences in terms of trade policy. Then you can't continue to do business as usual and continue to do business as before. We need to talk plainly with our African partners. I would like to add one more thought to the debate, because today we have also discussed the Blue Card and the legal routes to Europe: my group is prepared to participate constructively in the issue. We need further development in the Blue Card. But I would also like to encourage reflection: we have millions of people are still out of work in the European Union, we have millions of young people in the south of the continent out of work. That is why I would like to make it clear to my group that Blue Card cannot mean that we are now opening up new ways of bringing even more migrant workers to Europe. We must first ensure that European youth have a future before we think about the African on this European continent. I would like to thank you for the proposals that have come today. Europe can do this together, and Europe will do it together!

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-Presidents of the Commission, let us tell the truth: we have been in a state of disreach in recent years. We did not see that we were faced with a young continent, which had so many problems and so many potentials, and above all we did not understand that, with this continent, we could share these challenges. If you think about it, all the great challenges that affect us also concern Africa. The fight against terrorism: are we fighting terrorism without Africa? The government of migration flows: do we do it without Africa? Interreligious dialogue? Economic, civil and cultural development? Africa is a partner for us. Now finally there is the turning point. And there is the turning point – let us be honest here too – thanks to the Italian Government and thanks to the European Commission. I say thank you to both of you, Federica Mogherini and Frans Timmermans, and to the entire European Commission for these proposals. There are two knots, I'm going straight to the concrete. The first node is the financial resource. You have done your best: EUR 500 million from the reserve fund is what the European Commission could realistically do. There is now work to be done by the Member States. We cannot put it into words and then not make the money available, including from the Member States. And then there is the multiplication and leverage mechanism on which we must check the EIB first. Governance must be done, but it must also change its mission, which cannot be to finance only triple-A projects, otherwise triple-A projects in Africa are not being financed, and we are hanging around. And we can do anything but make fun of ourselves. Projects in Africa are risky and therefore are not triple-A. The second issue is political and cultural. The Compact, this program, is not just a seuritarian program. Of course, it serves to manage migratory flows well. Let us pay attention to the theme of 'young Africans come to take away young Europeans' jobs'. This is a story that doesn't even hold up scientifically. Let me tell you who's studying these problems. The Compact, this programme serves to securize, of course, but it serves above all to establish a political, economic, civil and cultural partnership with Africa. If it's just a ruse to curb flows, it's very little. If, on the other hand, it is, as I am convinced it is, a means of finally achieving a great alliance, it is a great thing and deserves to be called a revolutionary turning point.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The Commission is coming up with a new master plan today. The intention seems to be to provide financial support to the main African transit countries in exchange for two achievements. First, they must stop migrants by fighting people smugglers. Secondly, they must take back illegal migrants from Europe.  NVA previously called for the conclusion of 'anti-drowning agreements' with all countries around the Mediterranean. We note today that this is being followed up. It proposes to send migrants back from the EU to Tunisia, Egypt, Mali, etc., while making efforts to resettle genuine refugees. Push-backs, combined with resettlement, our familiar mantra.  The EU's border and coastguard, in the creation of which I am actively contributing as shadow rapporteur, can carry out these return operations. In order to achieve a comprehensive approach, we now have the introduction of a maximum ceiling for asylum seekers to be accommodated.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me say to the Commission that I am very pleased with the global approach that you have finalised this morning – alongside the European Border and Coast Guard, the new asylum system and the new proposals on economic migration. Let us hope that we achieve a result by the end of the year.  I have to tell you that this is also a bit of a personal matter, because my first European Council was in 1999 in the north of Finland in Tampere, where we decided: from now on there is going to be a European asylum and migration policy. That was decided in principle in 1999 and now, 17 years later – I should say, finally – maybe we are nearly there.  So I am positive about the global approach, but I am more critical about the idea of now making migration compacts with third countries. If the Commission intends to simply duplicate the deal with Turkey, then I have a number of key problems with this, because  I have here Amnesty International’s report of one week ago about this Turkey deal.  For Europe it is a way forward. There are fewer people coming to Europe – at any rate in that part of the Mediterranean, because, in the meanwhile, there is an increase in the number of people flowing to Europe in other parts of the Mediterranean and I think the one is connected to the other.  But in addition to that – and independently from that – what the report is saying is that for the refugees this is certainly not the solution to their problems. They live in awful conditions. There are more than 100 000 of these migrants who are stuck between IS and a wall that Turkey is building up, kilometre by kilometre, on the border with Syria. At the same time there is no possibility for these people to have asylum, because Turkey has not ratified all the protocols of the Geneva Convention and so asylum is not possible for Syrian refugees. The conclusion, then, is that for refugees this deal is tragic. It is a drama. It is a problem.  So to say today that we have the solution to our problems, that we are simply going to duplicate the deal with Turkey and we are going to roll it out to all the other countries: sorry, I do not think that is the way forward in the future. It is simply saying: OK, we will give you money and you keep the refugees. Well, that cannot be the deal. That cannot be a compact. So my proposal is that, instead of having this migration compact, we need a real partnership with these countries. This real partnership has, I think, some tricky elements. It first of all means us, together – not them – us Europeans together, opening reception centres in these countries to pick up these migrants and refugees, in reception centres – in Libya, in Egypt, in Tunisia, in Lebanon, in Jordan, in the North African countries. Secondly, in these reception centres we can manage this together and make a distinction between those who are real refugees who can be resettled inside the European Union –  which is one possibility – and those who are migrants.  For our part we need to establish projects in the transit countries or in the countries of origin to give them a life, an expectation and a future in these countries of origin. There the situation is better than ever because, let us not forgot, Africa today has growth of between 4% and 5%. There is a basis for good projects in these transit countries and countries of origin. That seems to me to be the way forward, not to say: we are giving you money, we have already been promising you money for two decades but we never gave it to you, now you can have it if you keep the refugees. For me that is not a compact. If that is the compact, I am against it. I hope it will not be by accident if we can make real partnerships with them, managing the borders together, making projects in the transit countries and so on. Then it is a way forward. So you have to adapt your proposal in that way. Finally, on the last element, the question of the Blue Card, I have to tell you one thing. The Blue Card – which does not in fact exist for the moment, there are 10 000 Blue Cards – is a good attempt. I do not think that a directive is the right way forward, Mr Timmermans. I think there is a better way forward, which is to make one Blue Card, like there is one green card in the US: one Blue Card instead of a directive which will lead to 28 blue cards in the European Union. I think we, as the European Parliament, have the task, with you, to push the Council to accept one system instead of the 28 systems that could result from this directive.  (Applause)

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-Presidents of the Commission, in the Migration Compact you mention rights six times, but your whole proposal contradicts them, mixes them with counter-ness, is poorly disguised expulsion.  You say that the agreement with Turkey has saved lives, but the dead simply move. There are a thousand in May in the Mediterranean. Say that we must help the fugitives in their countries, announce aid to sixteen African countries, but make all economic cooperation conditional on repatriation and border control. The promised aid is a diktat: either relegate the refugees to your prison camps or no aid. Those who are war-affected do not leave Syria, Yemen, Libya and Afghanistan, do not dare to flee dictatorships to Sudan, Eritrea, states to which the Eu ropean Union envisages munificiating agreements such as the one with Turkey.  You say that fugitives must become more resilient, self-sufficient, remaining in the countries of origin or transit. I wonder if you know what you're talking about when you brazenly psychologistize resilience. Those who invented all this and accuse the Italian Government in the first place think that they have clean hands and a white heart, like Lady Macbeth before they know what she has done, but he has dirty them with systematic violations of international law and a shameful agreement with Turkey. You are already making, Mr Timmermans, Mrs Mogherini, the policies that are being demanded in Europe by the most extreme right.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – We are still furious with the Turkey deal and today we are already talking about a new deal, a deal with countries in Africa. A new deal where the European Commission is trying to work with member states to prevent deaths at sea and manage migration.  The great weaving out we have made with Turkey is repeating itself. The weeffout is that we don't say, "Africa, African countries, we see your problems. How can we help you?" But we say, 'We, we in Europe, we have screaming populists and that's why we want to stop migration'. Everything seems to be aimed at holding back refugees rather than helping them. And if we look at the figures, I wonder if your proposals are achieving their goal. This year, more people have died in the same period than they did a year ago. How is that possible? And why would your proposals solve this? There have not been more migrants who made the crossing, but more who have had to pay for it with death. Isn't there simply something wrong with how we offer a helping hand at sea?  An important observation you make is that poverty is the reason for many Africans to come to Europe. And you are starting – and to my delight – again the discussion about legal migration. We like to think about this, but at the same time you are breaking a foundation under development cooperation. The goal of development money is to combat poverty. That is also in our Treaty of Lisbon. But what does our surprise tell us? The Commission wants to use these funds to keep people there, to keep the borders closed.  Mr Timmermans, if I may speak to the great Social Democrat Schaeffer, no one can eat from borders. I wonder how your colleague Mimica actually looks at this? Or the Ministers for Development Cooperation in Europe? Or the members of the OECD's Development Assistance Committee? You take money away from the poorest to pay customs officers with it.  Dear Vice-President, two quotes from you: "The MDG showed us that lack of development of some countries is a threat to all, but so is unsustainable development on a global scale. This is the challenge that today we commit to overcome together". Those were your words when introducing the sustainable development goals. You also said: "In countries like ours there is no excuse for meeting the 0.7 GDP" for development aid. That is true, but you are forgetting that now and you are using the money to strengthen fortress Europe instead of fighting inequality in the world.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – As we know, loyalty is not purchased. Even if you manage to bribe someone, it's short-lived. Is the Commission proposing to bribe east African countries with one billion euros to stop the influx of migrants into Europe? Has the same already tried six billion euros and promises of visa-free travel to buy Turkey? "Oh holy naïve!" - if he could, a Czech Jan Hus burned on the bonfire would shout, because the money would be spent and the problem would continue. "And the times, and the customs!" – Ciceron would be seen again today. Why don't we start paying a peace tax to terrorists to be calm in Paris, London, Brussels and all the capitals of European countries? After half a year or a year, could we really start discussing this proposal with serious faces? Once again, what I said at the beginning of this migrant crisis: the main condition of the European Union's bilateral or multilateral agreements with African countries must be security and border security in the region. All aid projects submitted to the states of the region can and must also be linked to ensuring peace and security in these countries. Another essential and ongoing condition is the strict and professional external control of the European Union itself, in particular its southern borders. And yet, it is necessary to abandon the quota policy. It has been, is, and will be, an obvious incentive for migration to Europe, because this sends a signal 'you are welcome here, you will be taken care of'. It's obvious. And do not assume that the migrants themselves and their smugglers do not understand this. Dear ones, when a huge fire is extinguished, forests are cut off if necessary, roads are bought, sand and land barriers are built, no one is pervinly selling matches or lighters in supermarkets.

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Listening to what the European Union nomenklatura, the Commissioners and the majority groups, have said here, you get the impression that these waves of migration are more politically desirable than they are actually a phenomenon. Recall how the whole Arabian Peninsula has descended into chaos, as was the case with Egypt and Mubarak, with Tunisia and Ben Ali, as was the case in Libya with Gaddafi, and how they then tried to fight Assad in Syria, and how the waves of applause erupted everywhere, that an Arab Spring brought a much better time here. When it was not the Arab Spring, but all the problems, and the first major migratory flows heading towards Europe, do you know who was the first to loudly applaud it – with the exception of the political left? The first to applaud this was the bosses of the German automotive industry: it was Mercedes, it was AUDI, and it was BMW who was pleased that it might be a host of low-cost workers coming into the country, making the profits of the big corporations even more and more. Please, do what you are doing here and what fatal policies you are actually pursuing here, do with your conscience. As far as Austria is concerned, I can only say that we have always had an open heart for people who have sought protection and help. That was the case in 1956 with the Hungarians, in 1968 with the Czechs, in 1990 and the following with the Bosnians. But now that an intercontinental migration wave is also heading towards Austria, where people are crossing four or five safe third countries, including Union countries, all of which are not safe enough for them, where European ones are, we come to a point where we have to say: stop, it is enough!  This right has even been considered once within the European Union by creating first reception centres in the region by looking for safe zones in the region, but certainly not by continuing to look for strategies to bring more and more to Europe otherwise this ship will go under Europe.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, anyone who has not visited hotspots, refugee detention centres on the Greek islands or open camps in the rest of Greece can be misled by the racist poison of nazi Golden Dawn and its European allies. Let everyone think about what it would be like if they left their country to escape war, misery and were imprisoned at risk of deportation, because the European Union illegally does not consider him a refugee. Trapped in a detention center with your children in a tent, in the cold, rain and unbearable sun. Be hungry and throw away food, because it's not even good for dogs, and millions are being cut off by private food companies or non-governmental organisations that the European Union funds without them offering anything. The refugees say, "We don't live! We are just breathing; we have no future." You put together with the Greek government and the parties the NATO wolf guarding its victims and insotening tensions in the Balkans. Only the Communist Party of Greece calls on the Greek people, together with the refugees, to fight for their immediate transfer under the responsibility of the state and the UN to their countries of destination, by ensuring open, decent human accommodation, as long as they stay in Greece, with all the necessary infrastructure and services.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this debate. As politicians, we need to move away from just fire-fighting and start to tackle the causes of migration, otherwise we risk our actions always being too little, too late. Our focus must be on preventing these situations from occurring in the first place.  Migration is a global phenomenon but one that requires measured, compassionate and effective European leadership. Europe needs thinking that goes beyond tomorrow’s headline and focuses on tomorrow’s generation, and this means that the Commission – and, crucially, as we have heard, the Member States – must put up the money to help build capacity in third countries. We need to pump investment into developing countries, a form of Marshall Plan that will give people a chance of a future there without fear.  Of course we need better readmission and return tools for those not eligible for protection. Safe third countries must do more to accept their nationals back. This must be part and parcel of our negotiations, and then we can work to build capacity in their law enforcement, judicial and, crucially, asylum systems, so that people in need of protection can also find safe haven in states outside of the European Union.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which As Gianni Pittella has already said: of course we welcome this initiative. This morning, German media spoke of the need to build pressure on African states. I do not think that is the first point. First and foremost, it is really about a partnership. It is a question of fighting the causes of flight together, of investing in democracy, in the environment, in jobs, so that people no longer have to set off. It is a question of putting a stop to people smugglers, including through cooperation in the coastguard and the like. It is a question of enabling legal migration, because we need it partly in Europe. It is a question of creating a situation in the partner countries that allows for return and withdrawal. This is not only true, it is long overdue. This plan goes beyond short-term crisis management. Only long-term sustainable cooperation can help us to make up for what we have failed to do for decades. It won't be easy. Two concerns accompany us in this discussion: the first concern is the concern for financing. You have already pointed this out, Mr Weber. If of 11.8 billion 81 million have been paid into one pot, then I do not believe the Member States really want to do anything, and then I am not so optimistic that I believe their forecasts. That is why it can only be the case that the Member States pay into such a pot quickly and immediately, otherwise our money would also be leaked. The second concern concerns the question of who we actually want to cooperate with in the individual states: investment in peace, progress, democracy, yes, is urgently needed, but pragmatic approaches and realism are also needed. We must therefore not only treat everyone equally according to the motto of one size fits, but must negotiate individual contracts that are also based on our European values. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mr Etheridge under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I think we need a fundamentally different approach, with absolute priority on reducing the number of migrants entering the EU from outside. The current human-rights-driven agenda merely encourages migration. The pull factors of an open door, the near certainty of remaining once arrived on European soil, poor enforcement and repatriation, excessively generous welfare payments, and a legal straitjacket of international human rights conventions, are of far greater significance than the lack of physical barriers to migration – and Mr Verhofstadt’s ticket offices are not the answer, by the way. I am also concerned about the effects of visa liberalisation. There are indications that many people from third countries enter the Schengen area legally and then overstay. These people are not effectively recorded, net departure is not enforced. What is the Commission going to do about this? By the way, we should not expect Member States to provide additional EU budget funding to cover migration policies. Funds must be found from elsewhere within the budget. There must be former priorities which can be dropped and now there are new priorities. That is where you find the money from. There is no excuse for trying to call for more money from Member States.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that we must cooperate better with third countries in our neighbourhood in order to manage the root causes of migration, to ensure safe and legal routes to Europe as well as a dignified returns policy for those that are not entitled to international protection.  I agree with the Commissioner on this, but we must get our act together and manage migration flows. Just deporting everybody to so-called third countries is a dead end. It is a no-go, and the Commission must realise that the EU-Turkey statement, or deal, or whatever status it has, is a dead end. It is a no-go created to circumvent the democratic scrutiny of this House.  Let us instead now focus on the creation of a dignified European asylum system assisting our neighbourhood but never, never, outsource European responsibility to third countries, otherwise this continent, this Union, will be held hostage indefinitely.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, you have made a very nice speech to us, but it does not correspond to the reality of your policies. Mr. Timmermans, in a way, is more forthright. The world is facing a humanitarian crisis. Here is the reality of this humanitarian crisis, according to UNHCR: 28 million new IDPs in 2015 have fled conflicts and natural disasters; one million of them arrived in Europe and European solidarity, the richest economic zone in the world, is equal to zero or almost zero. Of the 160,000 promised relocations, only 1,500 are effective.  The Union has given in to Turkey's blackmail and now wants to model this agreement for Africa. All the Union's external policies should be mobilised to compel recalcitrant states to re-admit migrants, as if Africa were not already experiencing a terrible humanitarian crisis. 25% of the world's refugees are there and 87% of African migration is intra-African. Far from drying up migration, you will make it even more dangerous. Already 2,500 dead since the beginning of the year, probably more than 7,000 at the end of the year. The 10,000 mark has been reached since 2014, according to UNHCR announcements. Today, how dare you tell us that the smuggler model has lived? They adapt. I don't see change, I see the cynicism, including the drains on the EDF for the benefit of countries like Eritrea and Sudan, and we see the damage today.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, some colleagues have mentioned partnership and addressing poverty, human rights violations and that sounds very nice.  The problem is just it is not in the paper. What the Commission is actually proposing here colleagues is to use all foreign policy instruments that the EU has as its disposal for one sole purpose, namely to stop refugees and migrants on their way to Europe. Development aid, trade policies, we do not even have sanctions to sanction the human rights violations in trade agreements. But now we will use trade sanctions when a country is not taking back the refugees, the people that fled from that specific country. The Commission even wants to give money to a country like Eritrea, where people are fleeing for good reasons: because of torture; because of forced labour; because of human rights violations. and the money is not going to Eritrea on the condition that those human rights violations would be stopped, no. The condition is to stop people from fleeing from these conditions. I really wonder what after all of this is left from our value-driven EU foreign policy. And you have mentioned the global responsibility, and indeed that is very important, but where is the responsibility of the European Union itself, of our Member States? We cannot go around telling everyone, all the transit countries, to house more refugees if we ourselves – as one of the richest continents of the world – are not doing our job. How can we tell Jordan, Turkey, other countries to house more refugees if we ourselves are not able to house a mere million? Money, even if well spent, is not enough. And on resettlement, how are you Commissioners going to force Member States to accept a sizeable amount of refugees, sizeable meaning at least hundreds of thousands each year, and up to 20 000 that we were promised a year ago, of which only 4 000 have actually been resettled? Where is that responsibility? I think the problem we need to address is inside the European Union. It does not help to externalise the problems and look for solutions elsewhere. We have to find the solution inside the European Union.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal presented by the Commission is in fact a reworking of italian Prime Minister Renzi's Migration Compact, in which a logic of cooperation that is not disinterested, ambiguous, with few new elements, based on exchange rather than on the needs and rights of those fleeing and those who welcome it prevails. On the model of the EU-Turkey agreement, which is implemented at the cost of european dignity and the system of values, the European Union will seek to achieve cooperation in the management of migratory flows through yet another disbursement of billions and billions of euros.  Little is said about the nature of oppressive and dictatorial governments and regimes that would affect aid, about the rates of corruption in those countries and about the instability of governments such as Libya, with which it is difficult to think about possible operations. We are therefore in favour, in general terms, of development cooperation and the saving of human lives, but without hypocrisy. For decades there has been talk of aid to a continent which has been mainly exploited and destabilised by the major Western and European powers.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Mrs Mogherini wants to solve a global problem. Mrs Mogherini, do not make yourself look ridiculous, you are not even solving the problems here in Europe! Today, the CSU has excelled with the green slogan "Give up prosperity". We Europeans must deliver prosperity to Africa and Asia. Half a billion, one billion, and even up to 62 billion, if private investors also want to invest in Africa and Asia. This is the same sleight of hand as we have already heard in the Juncker plan here. Again, it won't work. I would almost like to say that it will certainly not work, because investment opportunities in Africa are still worse than in the European Union, even if we are adapting there. Even if it is 62 billion that will be invested there, it will not be enough. The German government alone has promised up to 93 billion euros to refugees already resident in Germany in order to receive support in Germany. You do not believe that you can bait millions of people in Africa and Asia with 62 billion if the German Federal Government alone promises 93 billion! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – And thank you, sir, for having the courage of your convictions to answer a question. I wish everyone had the same courage. Do you think that the EU public will be joyfully celebrating the calls we have heard in this Chamber for global wealth redistribution on a scale that would have had Karl Marx’s eyes watering, or do you think the taxpayers of the EU might think that perhaps they would like to keep some of that money for themselves and have it spent in their own countries? Do you think they share the zeal of some of our colleagues for throwing money elsewhere rather than in their home countries?

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Well, sir, fortunately you have the opportunity to vote on membership of the European Union in your country. In fact, Franz Josef Strauss would probably have turned around in the grave if he had heard the words of his party colleague, Mr Weber, today. We know this slogan 'give up prosperity' from the Greens and Communists, but that is not something that would actually be good for a so-called conservative force, even in Bavaria. So good luck with your company on June 23.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Whenever we no longer know in Europe, a new plan is obviously drawn up. In October last year, we heard from Mr Timmermans about the new plan to resettle 160 000 refugees. Only 1 400 are said to have been relocated, exact figures are not known. Mr Timmermans himself spoke of what we have achieved in the Aegean Sea, and we must also achieve in the southern Mediterranean. What have we achieved in the Aegean Sea? How many of the 72,000 Syrian refugees have been resettled so far? I have heard that only five of the 28 Member States have taken part in the relocation of refugees, and a few hundred have been relocated. How has the polluter, the United States of America, been involved so far in taking refugees? And Mrs Mogherini, one last word: it is right to save lives at sea. But then you should get those who have been saved back to where they came from after the Australian model.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I welcome the European Commission's proposal for a new migration deal presented today. Until now, we have only put out a fire in Europe with various actions, short-term ones, which were otherwise necessary to temporarily stem the migrant influx. With the new Dublin Regulation and the new migration agreement, we are moving towards a comprehensive solution and also a long-term solution. The €8 billion financial assistance will be first used by partner countries in Africa and the Middle East to improve migration, and especially border control, to tackle asylum, fight corruption and so on. An important part of this proposal is the establishment of entry points in the countries of origin. Above all, I welcome the idea of a European External Investment Fund, which must be designed with private capital and also be development-oriented. But investment in the real economy and in the social environment can have an impact on detering many people from taking a risky path to Europe and elsewhere. We are in favour of ensuring that the development aid paid by European taxpayers (by the way, much more than the American and the Chinese) will be more selective in the future. It is necessary to reward those countries which fulfil their international obligations, who are willing to accept their citizens again and who are involved in managing the flows of illegal migrants and even offer international protection to third-country nationals. Irresponsible governments, which do not cooperate, need to be able to eliminate aid, as well as trade and visa benefits. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 149(8)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You mentioned the need for investment in countries that are the emitters of the current wave of migration. I have two questions. One is whether you see fit to extend the Juncker Plan to such a programme? My second question is whether you see a task for strengthening bilateral relations for the External Action Service, so that we do not just talk about finances.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – The fact is that this concept is meant as the Juncker Plan 2 for countries outside the European Union. And it is normal that without investment, foreign investment, and especially European (Europe also contributes the most to development aid, more so than other countries, more than America and so on), without it there will be no economic momentum and also of the well-being in these countries from which refugees come. So that, in the long term, this fund seems to me to be the most important idea and the most important action by the European Union in preventing migration.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the success of European action depends on a number of conditions. Firstly, an effective migration policy, both internal and external, based on legality, solidarity and respect for human rights. Secondly, an investment in reliable partners, certainly with a realistic policy, but aware – and I say this also to Mr Verhofstadt – that to have real partnerships we need a new, less liberal approach to trade policies: cooperation and not exploitation. Thirdly and finally, we need sufficient and real financial bases. Here we must overcome the shadows that still exist in the debate between the Member States, and the absence of the Council today on a document that is said to be a turning point gives a lot to think about. As far as I am concerned, the Eurobond route was preferable. But if we take your proposals as good as possible, then it is useful that a safeguard clause should be inserted which would identify a time limit for verifying its operation and, if not, put in place the most appropriate financial instruments to solve and deal with the problem.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, it is a given that in the first half of this century we will experience unprecedented population movements not only due to war. Tackling refugee and migration flows must therefore be the main joint effort of the UN and the European Union states for years to come. The trafficking rings must therefore be hit and there must be pressure to implement both the agreement with Turkey, which continues to blackmail, and the Valletta agreement. This means speeding up refoulement processes and creating hotspots in Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan and African countries for direct resettlement of refugees in the European Union. In the long term, a distribution clause should be imposed at European Union level, as is the case with refugees. Refugee and migration require a comprehensive approach, and this means resources to tackle poverty in developing countries as well as support for development and investment in the countries of the Middle East and Africa subject to respect for human rights there.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Madam President, many of us, of course, share the momentum and ambition of the project of cooperation, aid and partnership with the targeted third countries, a partnership that we have long hoped for since Tampere, as Guy Verhofstadt pointed out earlier. I would like to take you at your word today on the priority that you have placed first and foremost, at the head of the text, that of saving lives in the Mediterranean, especially since just five or six days ago, a terrible shipwreck of 700 people illustrated this urgency. Take you at your word about the strategic vision, the paradigm shift you were talking about, proposing to implement it in action, not just words or intentions.  That is why I do not understand that, at a time when we are working the regulation of the creation of a European border and coastguard corps, the Council and the European Commission refuse to allow rescue and search at sea to be an all-in-mind part of the integrated management of external borders. This is one of Frontex's missions, let us take advantage of this strong political will to bring our words and words in line with our actions through this text on the creation of a coastguard at the external borders.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This proposal is not about cooperation. Nor is it about migration. It is about stopping refugees, about mobilising all possible means for this single purpose – economic, trade policy, visa policy and even military means. Do you not see for yourselves what a dangerous, anti-human and anti-future development this is? The EU-Turkey agreement is a treaty of shame that violates international law and people's rights, and now you want to continue on the same track. To further externalise and close the EU's borders through similar agreements between countries as .m. Eritrea and Sudan. It's a dead end. Europe's citizens do not expect a cynically closed Europe where we can barely breathe anymore. We expect a serious discussion based on how we can organise a more solidarity-based and dignified reception and take greater responsibility for accepting refugees in Europe. Back to the drawing board!

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I fully agree that our response to the present humanitarian crisis in Europe should be a comprehensive. I agree that Africa should receive our increasing political consideration. Nevertheless, the first ideas proposed on the migration compact do not mention two extremely important points: firstly, there is no mention of the defence of human rights. We seem only interested in getting rid of present and future refugees. Of course, we are ready to pay to get rid of them.  The second point is closely related to the first. Apparently, we totally trust all African leaders – morally and economically. My question is: are we going, for instance, to trust the countries which were mentioned here as we have trusted Turkey? Without defence of human rights, without a strong democratic control on our own procedures and on our agreements with third countries, we are about to repeat all the mistakes made in the recent past. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card question. – So you talk about human rights, but do you not agree with me that the human rights industry actively works against us? On a radio programme recently on the BBC, I actually challenged the Red Cross and said you turn economic migrants into refugees, and he openly admitted that. It is there to hear on tape. I was in the Greek migrant camps three weeks ago and the same thing is going on. Do you actually believe that taxpayers’ money should be wasted on such initiatives?

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I just believe that we should not confuse things. Human rights should be accomplished everywhere. If someone does not, well that is not my fault. I am sorry, we should do that.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, having been to the camps along the northern coast of the Schengen area, I can tell you it is a bonanza for criminal gangs and terrorists. In Dieppe I even saw port security letting Albanian people traffickers climb fences into the port, and it was I who was threatened when I asked him to stop this happening. Not one penny of British taxpayers’ money should go into this disastrous EU migration policy, and if you want to control migration, if you want to stop deaths in the Mediterranean, then we need be turning boats back.  Britain has a new problem this summer. We have our own invasion of migrants to the south coast and the EU has tried to hide its plans for a common EU coastguard and border force by holding the debate at the first plenary session after the UK referendum. Now I ask myself, why would they want to do that? Is it because they know the British people would recoil at EU control in territorial waters without having to even ask permission from the government? I hope people who are undecided about how to vote in the UK referendum listen to what the EU are planning, that immigration policy is decided at EU level and they are asking for EUR 50 billion to fund it. It is yet another reason for the people of Great Britain to vote to leave. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: question raised by raising the blue card. – After 23 June, the pressure of the migrant flow from Africa and other countries is surely expected for many years. Do you think that Britain will not be the country that will work partly to solve this humanitarian problem after 23 June, if it leaves the European Union? And do you think that if you don't cooperate, the problems will go away on their own, without the British making any big business about it and doing anything to help solve this problem?

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, can I correct you? It is 23 June. You will have missed it on the 25th.  I hope that, when we leave the European Union, the European Union will sort this problem. We, as an island nation, will sort out our own problem and sort out our own borders.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to thank, also on behalf of my group, High Representative Mogherini for her words of condolence and also for all my colleagues in this House who have been close to us at the moment. Beyond that, going back to the subject, I have to say that I find that there are two things that should be emphasized. The first is that it is true that there are flows of migrants. It is also true that these flows are often encouraged and criminal organisations in particular often gain, which are sometimes also terrorist organisations which perhaps then carry out attacks in our countries and sometimes ally themselves with those European criminal organisations. So we have a moral duty to stop these flows. On the other hand, there is an inalienable right, which is that right that must allow a person to live and grow in the country in which he was born. So aid to African countries is certainly fine, but let us be careful, because we have to see that these African countries then apply all those policies so that these people can remain in their territories and that we may not go, unfortunately as we did in part with Turkey, to make alliances with countries that unfortunately do not respect human rights and create great difficulties even in our policies.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, we are discussing a plan to tackle the root causes of migration. But I wonder what happened to the old days. Did they succeed or fail? Do they need updating or have they become old papers? The only thing that is certain is that there is no one to take responsibility and say with courage and more truth that he failed, to chant a "mea culpa". So far, you've failed miserably. The fences at the borders of the Balkan countries and the use of Article 25 of the Schengen Treaty by the Member States demonstrate this. A new readmission plan with third countries is now being promoted and the famous readmission plan with Turkey has never been implemented. A review of the blue card is being launched for highly skilled illegal immigrants, when unemployment among young scientists is constantly rising. You are talking about the integration and absorption of illegal immigrants, when we know very well that they come from countries with a mentality and religious beliefs outside of any notion of the rule of law and peaceful coexistence. Finally, let someone take responsibility for failure! Now your failed policies are stained with the blood of innocent people in Paris, Brussels, Copenhagen and the Aegean Sea. They are now measured by suicide statistics, uprooting young people from their home countries, with increased rates of depression and propensity for psychotropic substances. Finally, I would like to return to the bloodthirsty Communist Party and its MEP the Stalinist-style comments on Golden Dawn.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, many of us have long called for a genuine integration of migration into the Union's external policies and genuine migration diplomacy in this House. It is now done at the conceptual level. So we still have the challenge of realizing this fundamental change in our approach.  In this regard, I would like to focus on three elements. First, in-depth thinking is needed on funding. On the one hand, the good practices that already exist in the selected and so-called priority countries deserve to be better valued; on the other hand, the question of the effectiveness of our financial instruments and, in particular, the EDF must be asked. We need to reduce the number of priorities to have a better impact.  Second, yes, Africa is a key continent. In terms of migration management, support for border controls between African countries and the management of intra-African migration needs to be strengthened. As far as the causes of migration are concerned, it is imperative to achieve results in development cooperation. This requires a real effort and we are doing it: finding a working approach and incentives and not neglecting other economic and trade tools as levers for reforms related to the rule of law and human rights.  A general point: attention to the message that will be sent to all other countries that are not priorities at the moment. And a special question: what role for African regional organizations? Finally, two questions about the implementation of the action plan adopted in Valletta: what measures have been proposed to enhance the human and financial potential of the African diaspora in Europe? What about cooperation between sub-Saharan countries, southern Mediterranean countries and European countries?

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in adopting the migration package, the Commission has, in my view, taken the right approach, the approach which is based on a strategic and comprehensive vision, taking into account the different aspects of migration reality; which is based on the agreement and partnership with the issuing and transit countries of migration and which looks at a medium- and long-term project. Because when sixty million people are displaced in the world as a result of war, it is clear that being a global player in conflict prevention and resolution is an essential element in combating emigration. Because when there are also sixty million other people in the world displaced as a result of hunger for humanitarian crises, it is clear that we need investment to end poverty in those territories. I simply stress, as rapporteur of the European Parliament for humanitarian aid, that this whole process must be based on respect for human rights, international humanitarian law and the principles of humanitarian action.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to say on the eCR and, in particular, on the Alpha Party: we consider the measures we are discussing today to be absolutely right. However, it must also be said explicitly that, as much as it is right to provide aid as close as possible to the hotspots, it is of course just as important that we do not forget the accompanying measures. The accompanying measures are clearly to be found here in Europe in the EU. The EU has still failed in this respect. We still do not have a uniform approach to securing our external borders, we do not have a uniform application of the law, the MEMBER states of the EU act in completely different ways. We are seeing that there are still states that say that we can take in refugees in unlimited numbers, we do. There are those who have introduced quotas, and there are those who are pursuing foreclosure policies. How to secure the EU's external borders sensibly on such a basis is logically a mystery. This cannot be done, so, in addition to the aid that we have to provide in Africa, we must also put our house in order in the EU.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: I welcome the fact that the Commission intends to use financial incentives to support a solution to the refugee crisis. However, the agreement with Turkey cannot be a model. Just as I do not hope that we will listen to Austrian proposals that want to convince us of an 'Australian model', namely the pushing of boats into the open sea, internment camps for refugees on remote islands and the free-buying of responsibility through payments to countries with poor or no human rights standards. Apart from the illegality of the EU and the contradiction with the Refugee Convention, this is also practically unworkable: after all, which European naval soldier should use which ship in which territorial waters to ensure that the inflatable boats do not reach a European island? I expect European foreign ministers to take initiatives at European level aimed at finding a solution for all Member States.
