But, in the absence of such European initiatives, Austria, like all other Member States, should at least implement the decisions of the Commission and the European Parliament. That would help us all.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the European Commission is talking about a pact on migration with central ideas for controlling the Union's external borders and combating the slave trade in cooperation with African and Asian states along the line of the recent agreement with Turkey. But these are simply ways of temporary management and do not address the substance of the issue. The strong migration flows are due, on the one hand, to inhuman economic austerity policies and the absence of demographic policy within the Union, with the result that Europe suffers from dramatic under-birth, and on the other hand to poverty and wars in our wider geographical environment. We need another policy mix; at home, in order to give more support to raising children and creating jobs for young people, and abroad, so that peace can prevail in the Middle East and North Africa and improve the living conditions of people there. If this policy change does not occur, the problem will get further exacerbated.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, while I acknowledge the concerns that some people have about the impact of migration, the standard of debate on this issue during our referendum campaign in the UK has become highly distasteful. Those who argue we should leave the Union are deliberately confusing three issues: first, control of our borders. Leave campaigners know we still control our borders, which is why Vote Leave wrote to the Home Secretary asking her to refuse permission for Marine Le Pen to enter the UK to help them campaign. Secondly, asylum for those who need it, the central theme of this debate. Here the UK has rejected our responsibility of acting in solidarity with the countries under most pressure. We should be working with them to protect those fleeing conflicts for which we are more responsible than most as a result of our disastrous policy interventions in the Middle East.  Thirdly, free movement. This is a crucial part of the single market on which our economy depends. Leaving it would damage businesses and households and limit opportunities for thousands of British people who live, work and retire across the EU.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, an African trust fund? You want billions from the UK taxpayers' pockets for Africa? The UK is already the second largest contributor of foreign aid. Only last year we contributed GBP 2.5 billion worth of money in foreign aid; but you want more. Taxpayers actually fund the NGOs who are actively working against the wishes of the UK citizens and the citizens across Europe. I was in Greece with the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) last week. The message from the Socialist MEPs is that we will re-open our borders; our borders will be open. Even the NGOs were actually shocked at that, saying this would lead to riots in the camps. Unless we set the political messages right, billions will not make any difference, as the human rights industry is actively working against us. The only way we can stop and help genuine asylum-seekers is to reject your proposals, rejects the EU and vote Brexit on 23 June. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Honourable Mrs Atkinson, do you agree with the view of some people who are in support of The United Kingdom remaining in the Union that those who want to leave the European Union often do not know the facts and say nonsense. For example, you said here that in the LIBE Committee we are in support of opening the borders of the European Union. When was the last time you went to a LIBE committee meeting? And when did you hear us ever say anything like that?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card answer. – I was in a meeting of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) a couple of weeks ago, where I represented my group ahead of a discussion post going to the Conference of Presidents. I specifically asked for something that should not go onto the agenda, which was the EU—Turkey deal. So I was there representing my group, but we were actually ignored by the LIBE Committee. Timothy Kirkhope, a British MEP, refused to have our group’s proposal put forward. When I was in the migrant camps three weeks ago, the Socialist, Péter Niedermüller, actually said that we have open borders here. We are working with the Commission to open our borders. Now, there are three groups in here that were represented in that meeting who said that you could not give that message, it is dangerous. The NGOs told me that. So should ask your socialist colleagues what they are saying about having open borders. That is sending the wrong message to Africa and the rest of the millions that want to come as migrants to our countries and that we cannot afford.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: "The problem is not that we are flooded with immigrants, but that the wrong immigrants. They don't want to work at Bayerische Motorwerke or Aldi at all. They have been promised large benefits and they want big benefits. I once identified them, which cost me 3,000 euros, but a Congolese diplomat said that Europe was flooded with African cesspools. Well, we can be proud that we have freed part of Africa from this cesspool, but it is our duty to train these people of reason. Well, nothing teaches reason like hunger. You have to stop paying them benefits and just get them to work. And because the best teacher is an example, we have to set an example and stop paying benefits to ourselves too, because we demoralize our own people too. As you know, socialism is a system in which difficulties unknown in any other system are hero hero heroly overcome. And I just hear that all the time in this House everyone is trying to do that. Thank you for your attention. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr  Korwin-Mikke, I just want to know what facts you are using when you are talking like you did just one minute ago. Are there any facts? Do you know how much other parts of the world have got in values from exploiting the African continent during hundreds and hundreds of years? I want facts.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "I don't really understand what it is and what the connection is with africa being exploited. America has also been exploited and thriving. On the other hand, I am simply referring to the opinions of a diplomat from congo – from a country that knows a lot about emigration from Africa.  But one thing I know: when you pay people not to do it, it demoralizes people. All allowances must be abolished. People have to live with work, not benefits.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is not always a pleasure to notice to what degrees of surrealism debates in this House can turn. I had in principle the intention of starting with the statement that, judging by the number of references to the poor British taxpayers that have been made by right-wing British Members of this House – who so far have not refused any single European subsidy for themselves – out of pure humanitarian concerns we should wish for them to vote to leave on 23 June, because after that maybe the British taxpayers will be reassured. More to the point, I would want to say the following. I would want to believe, High Representative/Vice-President, what you have expounded to us but I doubt that it is going to be enough. I doubt it is going to be anywhere near enough; maybe for a migration compact of some sort with a number of select African countries, that could work. But for the development of Africa, for turning African fortunes around or for orienting African dynamism and growth into a different direction? I doubt it. The EUR 500 million alone that we are supposed to take from the European Development Fund reserve is much less than the Chinese are going to be investing in a single railway line from Mombasa to Central Africa in the coming years. That shows the discrepancy between our intentions and what we are ready and willing to put on the table when the worst comes to the worst, or when action is called for in order to replace words. I would really wish for us to be able to finally contribute to an African renaissance, but with those means I am afraid it is not going to be good enough.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent tragedies of migrants off the libyan coast and the island of Crete remind us that this phenomenon is still in a state of emergency. After the closure of the Balkan route, the only viable choice for asylum seekers to reach Europe remains the Mediterranean. The proposals presented here today aim to tackle the migration crisis with a new approach, focusing on new cooperation between the European Union and the countries of origin and transit of migratory flows. Investing in the economies of these countries, through particular infrastructure projects and with resources that come not only from the Community budget, is certainly a good starting point for improving European action in this area. Italy has long called for policies along these lines. The phenomenon of migratory flows to Europe will certainly not be exhausted in a short time, but the success of the actions announced today will require everyone's contribution, because it is worth remembering that this is a European issue and not a few individual States.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: – The European Commission is returning to proven methods, as has happened in previous migration crises from Morocco to the Spanish coast, from Libya to the Italian coast, ten years ago. In other words, pay migrants to remain outside the European Union. Mrs Mogherini also mentioned that the narrative has changed, that the migration crisis is not only a global issue for the European Union. Correctly! I think it is also right that north Africa is being given investment instead of aid. However, the European Union's own narrative on migration has also changed significantly. From what we have heard until very recently, all migrants must be given a place in the European Union. That they will all work in the European Union's economy and even put unemployed young people in the European Union at work, and that the main thing is to divide all asylum seekers into Member States. This would infuriate many of these countries themselves. Looking to the future, the most important risk remains. Criminal crime will not abandon this lucrative and secure migrant business. And perhaps it will move to these camps and projects in North Africa or the Middle East.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Of course, a systemic approach to the migration crisis is extremely important, so this initiative is also welcome. It is clear that, to date, neither the European Union nor the whole world has done enough to ensure that refugees can obtain safe havens as close as possible to their home country. Syrian refugees, for example, in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, need work, school places for children and medical care to wait for the war to end in Syria and then return to their home countries. Many, even most war refugees, do not want to come to Europe, but have been forced to do so. The European Union must provide significantly greater support to refugees as much as possible in the convergence of their homeland, for example through the UN Refugee Organisation. Only this will reduce the pressure on Europe and the tragedy in the Aegean Sea and the Mediterranean. If refugees do not have basic conditions in these countries, agreements with Turkey or other countries will not help either. Desperate people will, in any case, find a new and more dangerous path.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we talk about a new immigration agreement, the situation is getting worse rather than worse. Every day innocent people, including many children and infants, are sentenced to death. In the last week of May alone, 900 refugees were frozen in the Mediterranean. The situation is embarrassing and unacceptable. It is not possible for the Union's official policy to continue to circumvent its declared principles of solidarity, to close borders, to promote expulsions, to sign shameful agreements with Turkey on refugees. The situation is tragic. Even the people rescued from the long-dead naya are faced with miserable living conditions, while hotspots are now being turned into concentration camps. In order to stop crime, hollow promises must be stopped and immediate action taken. To create immediately a common and fair asylum system, based on practical solidarity and equal burden-sharing. To create legal and safe roads as well as a permanent binding and fair system for the situation of refugees. It is equally important to make human and decent places for refugees to be accommodated both in the Union and in third countries.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Ladies and gentlemen, in what you call a migration pact to those in power of this unholy European Union, you say that there is a need for a more European approach to migration. However, I can assure the citizens of the Union that this pact is anything but compact. The door is being opened to what you call legal forms of migration, for a further extension of blackmail treaties à la the 'dirty deal' with Erdogan, for new taxes through migration obligations and for all sorts of other variations on your recurring theme more resources, more taxpayers' money forever but more immigration. The citizens of the Union have been warned. It should not be inferred from the failure of Schengen and the failure of the European Union's open borders policy that there is more, but logically, that there is less need than ever for a European approach to migration.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – The unprecedented migration crisis of the last few years has clearly shown that no country can cope alone and therefore both coordinated pan-European action and close cooperation with third countries are needed. I am therefore of the opinion that the European Union must take three concrete measures to reduce migratory pressure on Europe. First of all, a distinction must be made between economic migrants and refugees. Those seeking a better way of life can take advantage of legal ways of entering European territory, but under no legislation do they have the right to enter the European Union illegally, trying to cross unregulated borders. Hope must be dissipated that Europe will provide them with the same support as refugees fleeing war. Furthermore, the European Union must step up the return of illegal immigrants to their countries of origin. I therefore welcome the reinforced role of the European Border and Coast Guard in this regard. But for the work of the new office to be effective, the European Union must swiftly sign readmission agreements with the countries of origin.  Finally, I am of the opinion that the possibility of setting up hotspots outside European territory should be considered again. I believe that this measure will reduce migratory pressure on Europe, because only those entitled to international protection will be able to reach the Member States as a result of their application being approved under European law. Overcoming the migration crisis requires new measures and an approach from the European Union, and strengthening international cooperation is an important component of the Union's package of action in this regard.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this communication. It was understandable that priority was accorded to negotiations with Turkey, but other more vulnerable countries also need our attention, something which was acknowledged today. But when Member States have contributed just 80 million to the 1.8 billion Trust Fund for Africa, the European Parliament must insist that genuine new money be provided and that development aid in particular should not be diverted, as otherwise more for more risks becoming more for less. It is one reason why the Italian proposal for eurobonds as part of the compact should be considered. These bonds would be not just financial bonds, but bonds of solidarity between Europe and the wider world.  Following the UN Conference on Financing for Development, the pledge is made for climate finance at COP21 and Europe’s own support for a financial transactions tax. We have to be open to creating new innovative forms of international finance to meet new international challenges.  I admit that the idea of a grand bargain with third countries to halt refugee flows is distasteful to many. You do not bargain over people’s lives. But let us face it, the EU has done precisely that, linking visa and trade concessions to readmission agreements over many years. So if the money is genuinely additional, if we recognise that 86% of refugees are in the global South and not making their way to Europe, if this new money first and foremost improves the lives and livelihoods of those refugees and of all peoples in the countries to which they have fled, if Europe honours its promise of safe routes for legal migration, then we should give it our support.  Finally, this communication on first reading does appear to fall into the trap of assuming that Europe in its external policy is much more effective as a funder than as a political actor. I praise the commitments in the communication to global diplomacy on migration, but would have liked to see more emphasis on the EU’s diplomatic role in conflict resolution, as well as on active efforts to ensure that human rights and international humanitarian law are upheld, not just saying it, but doing it. Nevertheless, I know that to be the personal commitment of the High Representative/Vice-President and on this and other issues she and First Vice-President Timmermans have our support.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, in my speech the English word ‘shit’ was used. It was not my word. In Polish it was ‘szambo’, which in English is ‘cesspool’ or something like that, and the word in German was ‘Abschaum’ which in English means ‘scum’, not ‘shit’. So please, I am not responsible for the translation.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Even. We heard the smelly interpretation of what you said. We move on to the next speakers.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the President-in-The The Political Elites of the European Union are far too weak to really protect Europe. They prefer to pay other countries to keep the migrants off our necks. This is not only hypocritical, it is also dangerous, because we are dependent on these countries. It was the closure of the Macedonian border that significantly reduced the number of refugees, and not this dubious pact with Turkey. In the same way, Italy must understand that it must close and guard its borders, otherwise it will make Austria, right on the Brenner. It is an illusion to think that any distribution mechanisms or penalties or Africa bonds are the solution to the problem. Yes, let us help the people who need help, but let us help them there! The majority of the population of European countries is against mass immigration. If today's political elites do not understand this and fail to protect Europe, people will choose extremists, not because they themselves are extremists, but because the political elites have failed miserably. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Silvia Costa (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. I would like to know, when you say that Italy must close its borders, whether this means that it must reject at sea people who come from the sea and who often come, precisely, from places where there are wars, persecutions or otherwise, are children, women, vulnerable people. What do you mean by Italy closing its borders on the sea? Reject them?

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. You don't have to throw them back into the sea, you don't have to shoot them. You can take them back to where they came from. There, of course, Europe must set up central camps there, such as those in Lebanon and Turkey. There can also be such in Libya. They also exist in Lebanon. That is the solution. Not all in Europe and then sent back like a package from Zalando. That's not how it works.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the deal with Turkey basically broke up the business models of the smugglers between Greece and Turkey. And of course what we are seeing is reorganisation on a route which is much more risky and is a deadly one. In this respect, I must say that your package is an essential one. We can discuss the details – we might have nuances and some disagreements – but it is the right approach. I do not see anything problematic in linking, basically, development aid, cooperation investment with control of migration flows, and I see no problem in linking it with the root of the problems which, of course, exist. I obviously leave aside the fact that we have got human rights problems in Turkey and elsewhere and we will have to tackle them. I would like to say that this is the right approach, but it will not work out well – or sufficiently well – if we do not have a strict, vigorous, serious return policy. This is something that we need to work on. If we have that and we have a balance, I am sure that we will finally create a unity in the European Union, a unity that we need for a European solution. I think that, at that moment, the polarisation that we have on some other aspects of that issue will go away.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the immigration emergency, we are tired of hearing the usual bales of the Renzi government and the Commission, dear Mogherini. For years we have been the only ones denouncing the danger of illegal immigration, which is invading Italy and Europe, and that is why you have called us racists, populists and xenophobes. You, the Commission and the Italian Government, have so far had so many chatter and zero facts. Worse still, you have hidden your head in the sand, you have declared that immigrants are resources and everyone must be helped. Shame on you! Shame on you because you're making fun of poor people. Shame on you because you are complicit in this mass invasion. Renzi's Migration Compact will be yet another hoax, just as the Juncker Plan for the relocation of immigrants was a hoax. The tragic truth is that the European plans and those of the Italian Government are hot air and thousands of illegal immigrants invade Italy every day. So no more lies. The invasion of illegal immigrants must be stopped immediately and the only solution is to close our borders and defend our borders.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Listening to many speakers here, I have to say that those who do not want refugees also want to prevent any measures from coming from refugees. That, I believe, is hypocrisy, Mr Sulik, for which you stand in particular.  I believe that the agreement with Turkey means: A: to put a stop to the traffickers and, secondly, to have the opportunity to help the people, the refugees in Turkey, through the six billion made available. This is starting to work, it must be said clearly. You can't take the people in the boats by the hook and bring them back. Why should the countries resume them if agreements have not been reached with these countries? Stop your stuss!  We must also note that the proposal has now come to try to focus on Africa. This is much more complicated, because it is a long-term development problem there. Helping people there, that there is a capacity for development, that there are reasonable human conditions in the refugee camps, that they can stay there close to their homeland, that they can try to take action against the traffickers on the North African coast, to destroy the business model, these are in themselves sensible starting points, the proposals that you have.  When people are at sea, they must be rescued and taken in with us. As a Christian, I cannot be responsible for anything else. That is why we must see that the matter on the Greek coast is dealt with sensibly and humanely. That is the only way, and I therefore ask you to continue with your proposal and put it into practice. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you referred, in your intervention, to those states that do not want to take in migrants. I would like to ask you how you comment on the uncompromising position of the President of Romania, Mr Iohannis, on this issue.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, I did not say that countries are being talked about, but about some colleagues who are against refugees and at the same time are against measures to prevent refugees from coming. Secondly, I believe that if we succeed in this way, that we have fewer refugees, it may also be easier to talk about relocation. Thirdly, I would have liked to have answered Mr Sulik's question: I think we should say that the crucial starting point is to address the causes, to end the war in the countries, to solve development problems and, in between, to help, not to let people come to sea and drown – because that is the bitter consequence – or to divide Europe through barbed wire fences on the Brenner or in Macedonia. Greece and Italy are great European cultural countries, and I do not want to turn them into refugee camps for Europe by once again drawing border fences through Europe, which are worse than the border fences that existed during the Cold War.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D). Mr President, the success of the new relocation pact lies not in the adoption of new measures to deal with the refugee crisis but in its faithful implementation without derogations, otherwise we will again be exposed as Europeans, as with the implementation of the relocation programme, where national egos have prevailed. Solidarity, equal burden-sharing, adherence to the principles and values of the European Union, respect for human rights, emphasis on legal migration routes, cooperation between the European Union and third countries of origin and transit, an adequate and sustainable financial basis. These are the key elements that should govern the new pact. There must be joint management of external borders, guaranteeing security, while combating criminal activities. However, border management does not involve closing borders.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Vice-Presidents of the Commission for this proposal that they have presented to us today, which I believe is heading in the right direction. We must initiate a virtuous process of investment in the countries of origin of the refugees, so that they remain there and that there are conditions of development there which will also slow down the process. We are well aware that the African numbers, the increase in the African population, will mean that between now and thirty years the flows would be in great danger of increasing. So we have a time frame in which to intervene and in which we have to build stable relations with these countries. I do not know whether the EUR 500 million will be enough, but it is a first step in the right direction. But surely we will have to do more. Vice-President Timmermans spoke of mixes of positive and negative incentives. Well, I would also like to start to feel something in terms that are negative for those countries, including in Europe, which are not fully involved in the processes and which obviously do not want to play their part. Because we are all European countries and there are no countries that, being closer to the border, must do more, but we must all work together with a common effort. Therefore, negative incentives are also welcome for those who oppose the processes and do not cooperate effectively in successfully in this operation, which is truly European.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Because of the economic situation, because of the social situation, because of the civil wars taking place nowadays in some countries in Africa, Europe is going to see more and more people trying to come to Europe in the years ahead – especially from Africa. Do you not think that in the end the European Union has to come up with a long-term strategy and policy to meet this important challenge? It is not only practical measures or effective solutions that need to take place now: we need a long-term strategy for this.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. The strategy we are talking about is not a short-term strategy, because making investments in African countries will certainly not give a short-term return. We have talked about a programme that must cover several years already, and therefore a package of billions, and we will probably have to do even more to make this strategy more efficient and effective. I therefore agree that it must be a long-term strategy, because in the short term we will have to buffer, and there are other means of buffering.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the choice is very clear. Either Europe remains an old continent on the defensive or it sets a partnership for the future with the neighbouring countries to support their development, to better manage migration and also to support refugees. The choice is so clear. Of course this means a big undertaking, a big undertaking based on investments, but let me underline that investment is also jobs. Many new jobs could be created for both young people in Europe and in the neighbouring countries. I believe that you should use this argument of jobs – new jobs which can come from this initiative – to convince Member States to put more resources into the initiative because we need more contribution from the Member States. Let me tell you that, so far, young people in Europe understand this very well. They share this vision, they have many initiatives in this direction, and it is my pleasure to announce that very soon young people’s organisations will come forward with concrete proposals in exactly this direction.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the first point which I would like to stress here, and which I think is most important to welcome in this Commission initiative, is in fact the understanding of structural factors. We have two fronts here, one which is an immediate front, which is life-saving, and I don't think we can hesitate to put all the resources we have at our disposal to save the lives that are being lost every day in the Mediterranean. This is an undebutible obligation of an organisation with the European Union and the countries of the European Union. But then you have to face the structural factor. And here I think that in addition to the Middle East, where there is, finally, clearly, in the case of Jordan of Lebanon, already the idea of the pacts to move forward, the African question is fundamental. And in particular, as Portuguese who knows the African situation well and what will certainly be the flow of people in the coming years, this will be something to keep for a long time and not just a conjuncture crisis. I think it is essential that we are able to intervene in particular in sub-Saharan Africa and so I think that here the Commission is indeed on the right track and that the different countries of the European Union really want to open up to refugees, but on the other hand, they must also control this crisis, they must just adhere to this Commission plan.  And so I would say that this is very good news at this stage and I congratulate the two Vice-Presidents on the effort they have made. It is not easy to defend this position at this time.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – The fact that we are now ining partnerships with African countries is, in fact, worrying. Poverty in Africa has not been a problem since yesterday. We should have done this a long time ago. But it's not a criticism of the proposal. I just want it to be too late. Aware that solidarity between the Member States of the Union is no longer a reality, that countries in the African Fund are not already contributing to what they have promised today.  I agree that the refugee or migration crisis is not just a European problem, and I support you in this global approach. But I wonder what those awards and the consequences you mention when presenting the compact are for members who will not participate. I agree that greater investment and also a reversal in the approach are necessary. But firstly, not in a way that simply postpones the burden on the African continent and closes Europe's borders. And secondly, not in the way that European money gets into the wrong hands. We have to be strict about who and how we allocate funds. It is essential to ensure that we have honest and honest partners in African countries. At the same time, it is also essential to strengthen the legal and safe routes of immigration to Europe, as you say. We have heard that the Balkan route is closed, that there is less dying in the Mediterranean Sea, but there is a growing human trafficking and new migration routes are opening up. I cannot pass the unimaginable fact that newcomers to Greece can only apply for asylum via Skype. These are things that can be improved immediately and give hope to people. Finally, I agree that European migration management requires a long-term, strategic approach. However, this must not only focus on the containment of flows with Africa, but, in particular, the establishment of sincere cooperation with Africa, which will strengthen the African continent in political and economic terms, in cooperation with Europe and in contacts between people.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Mr President, Africa's explosive population growth combined with the enormous poverty of certain regions and the wars raises a hot question: Can mass, by millions, migration of african citizens be part of the solution? On the occasion of the influx of tens of thousands of economic migrants from Africa and beyond, the Commission is trying to give a double answer and is saying 'no', proposing a new ambitious framework for cooperation with incentives and disincentives for the countries of Africa and our neighbourhood. In other words, it is trying to give a double answer to both underdevelopment and the reduction of migration flows. If you convince us that this project will hit the huge waste of resources and corruption in the implementation of actions through a mechanism of transparency and a genuine investigation of complaints by civil society, I believe that your proposal will be a valuable contribution. Otherwise we risk talking about a conciliation mechanism with officials from African countries, which will increase their privileges, while Europe will pay them to take their citizens back.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt about the importance of an investment plan for Africa, which can benefit greatly from an extensive cooperation programme. However, this proposal seems to focus above all on strengthening the cooperation and capabilities of third countries, so that they prevent people fleeing war and poverty from reaching our shores. The basis of the document is conditionality which betrays the meaning of cooperation and aims to subject the whole relationship with third countries, which should be based on mutual respect and fairness. I find it worrying to divert the funds allocated to cooperation for border management purposes; it does not create opportunities for young Africans, it does not combat inequalities, but it increases inequalities, and it does not attack the root causes of migratory flows. Here the Member States must move from words to deeds, because so far even the aid promised has not been seen. Outsourcing our borders and responsibilities is not the solution, all the more so as European governments still refuse to implement those common solutions that alone could tackle the phenomenon.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have listened to this debate from the outset. Naturally it is a very controversial topic and, as a result, the debate was somewhat controversial too. But, at the same time, I think that credit must be given to the Commission for coming to terms with this very, very difficult and challenging issue and also for giving leadership when leadership is actually minimal in many instances. The idea of a new partnership agreement with Africa make sense, using trade and development policies as leverage and, of course, ensuring that aid goes to those who need it most, and also bringing order to chaos and having legal rather than illegal immigrants. All that is necessary. People might not like it, but I think it is necessary, as is, in particular, the emphasis that this is a global problem which, like COP 21, Europe cannot solve on its own. It can give leadership and hopefully, as was the case with COP 21, we can get a global agreement that will deal with the situation in the long term and, hopefully, end the migratory flows, especially for those who have to flee.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: Sur President, nirringrazzjak. Or tliet snin, chemm or fil-Parliament, nitkellem fuq il-migrazzjoni in fuq il-problems you din tista' toħloq. L-enfasi tiegħi kienet: ejja nagħtuhom futur ġo pajjiżhom. Hekk biss nistgħu nibdew intaffu l-problems economics ta' dawn in-nies, insalvawhom minn difna difna żgura fil-Mediterran in nevitaw il-problems li l-migrazzjoni mhux kontrallata tista' toħloq għall-pajjiżi Ewropej. Għalhekk smug b'sodisfazzjon lill-Kummissarji Timmermans in Mogherini li llum tkellmu u ffukaw fuq il-proposti ta' għajnuna lill-pajjiżi Afrikani, ġo pajjiżhom. Permezz ta' investiment, ukoll mal-privat, in ta' għajnuna finanzjarja konsiderevoli. Inkunu attenti biss li l-biljuni ta' fondi proposti u l-investiment verament ikun ta' benefièju għaċ-èittadini u mhux jispièèaw fil-bwiet tal-ftit għax inkella l-problema hemm tibqa'.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – The European Commission's proposals and policies on the migrant crisis can be described unambiguously as an impressive failure. A failure was the thesis that all illegal immigrants could be invited and accepted to the European continent because they claimed to be refugees, and in fact many of them were illegal migrants. Failure was the idea that these people could be distributed temporarily, first temporarily, then permanently, because you did not allocate anyone with these distributions. The agreement with dictator Erdogan, in addition to failure, was also severe hypocrisy because you agree with a dictator in the name of human rights who violates human rights on a daily basis and who daily crushes the principles of liberal democracy.  Also a failure is the promise to pay billions of euros out of the pocket of the European taxpayer as a ransom for this man. This proposal will also be a failure, and now I have another proposal to colleagues who defend the thesis that they can accept all illegal migrants. Set an example, take a family home and show us how it's done.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, it was an interesting debate, but at the same time I am still hungry. I think that Europe really needs to have a clear strategy, to have a vision, and that is not quite the case today: we give more the feeling of "suffering" than of acting.  And yet we must act, we must act in two directions. First, we must have a real development policy: there is no point in telling us, morning, noon and evening, that we are the ones who give the most money to Africa, we need to rethink our development policy so that it is useful and effective, which is not the case today. Second, legal pathways for economic immigration must be built. This is the only way to combat illegal immigration; you have to give, for example, multiple-entry visas that allow a migrant to come to work for a few months, go home and eventually return when he has work. We must fight against all employers - I am thinking of agriculture, construction - who illegally employ illegal immigrants, and at the same time allow readmissions to be effective. And it is by walking on these two legs that Europe will perhaps finally be able to provide an answer to this question.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Mr Timmermans, I have no doubt of your goodwill, there would be more to come, but even rhetoric is late in all this. Mr Pittella has been very elegant, but I do not think it is just myopia on the part of the Member States. They have long known that refugees also die on the African crossing and know, of course, that comprehensive and sustainable development in Africa is just and necessary for Africa. They've known for a long time and they haven't done anything—well, unfortunately, they've done a lot, too much. So I would like to ask you: what guarantees does the European Commission have, how are they going to get Member States to change their foreign, trade, economic, military and cultural policy towards Africa? Because it's really about this. Without that change, there will be no plan, no strategic alliance, nothing.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, sometimes listening to some of the comments, let me be very frank, we had doubts and thought that maybe a careful reading of the proposal itself could be useful, to start from the facts.  In the debates this afternoon you mixed many different things. Mr Verhofstadt was asking at the beginning – it is a pity he is not here – whether this is a duplication of the deal with Turkey. The two situations are completely different. As Frans mentioned at the beginning, from Turkey we have mainly Syrian refugees. It is temporary – hopefully temporary, we are working also on that, this is another story – a flow of refugees, asylum seekers. That falls into one specific international legal framework. We are trying to deal with that in a sort of immediate and also – let me use this word that I do not like at all, but that is the reality of our policies today – emergency mode.  What we are putting on the table here is something completely different. It is something that starts from the fact that with Africa we have a common interest in working on the development of the continent with a sense of partnership.  Some of you asked how are the African interlocutors reacting to this? Very well. Yesterday I was in New York at the Security Council. African countries, but not only African countries, Latin American countries, were saying: This is the right way to go because finally you are not only investing  in development – which is the right thing to do, by the way, in itself. And incidentally, I am proud to say that the European Union is the first donor worldwide, it is the first – and if you want, I can give you the figures for it also being the first donor to Africa – the first donor internationally with more than half of the official development assistance worldwide: EUR 68 billion in 2015, over EUR 20 billion ODA to Africa every year, and this is going to stay. I am proud of that.  This is the right thing to do anyway but there is another issue. Please go to Ethiopia and talk to the women that came back voluntarily, not from Europe but from the Gulf because they were becoming slaves, while we support projects from the ILO to reintegrate them into their communities, offering training and job opportunities. Listen to their stories and then come back to me and say that we are doing deals on their shoulders. No. We are protecting their lives and their rights. Go and talk with the young girls from Nigeria who turn into sex slaves in Europe and tell me that the deal we want to strike with Nigeria is not to protect their rights and their lives.  I am sorry, but you do not protect the lives of people only by saving them at sea. You also save their lives at the beginning of the journey. Go to Lampedusa and listen to the stories that the survivors tell you, or if you cannot fly there, watch the movie ‘Fuocoammare’ (Fire at Sea). There was a showing of it a couple of months ago in the European Parliament in Brussels. Listen to those words that tell you that these people are turned into slaves from the very beginning of their journeys. They are in chains crossing the deserts, locked in jails in Libya, locked in the boats that then sink.  We have a human responsibility – and our African partners as well have a human responsibility – to protect their lives. This is what we are talking about, and doing this together with international agencies starting from the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the UNHCR.  So what we are talking about is job creation, perfectly rightly, for African women, for African youth – go to Agadez, that was living from tourism before security made it impossible – about offering those young people job opportunities that are not linked to the smuggling networks or the criminal organisations, working on education, working on social development, working also on human rights and protection of the people. This is what we are talking about.  So, is it enough? No. But sorry, if we never start to do the right thing, in 10 years’ time the people who come after us will be facing exactly the same thing and I wish the people that were here 10 years ago had made the same choices as we are proposing to you today, because maybe today we would have better situations in Africa and also in Europe. We have to start somewhere.  So we know very well this this proposal is not going to turn the situation upside down in 24 hours, but there is no policy that could do that, and we should stop selling illusions to our people. But there are good things we can start doing consistently in partnership to change things, and we have to start.  So this is what we are proposing today. This goes together with opening regular channels for migration, for sure, this also is not my direct responsibility. This is also linked to the need for Member States to be coherent and do their part. This is also about other actors in the world doing their part and being coherent, from Asia to Latin America, to North America and the international organisations, to the UN system and to our African partners, because the only thing that would change Africa is not only our compacts, it is African leadership.  And here, believe me, we are very straightforward, very much so, because there is no other way of changing African societies other than yes, investing, but also creating, together with investments, the conditions for investments to flourish which are: the rule of law, interconnection within the continent – if you want to fly or to travel from one African capital to another you have to fly to Europe; does that make sense? – developing infrastructures, developing security conditions that are good for European investments, that are good for African investors as well, and people. So yes, it can be win-win-win.  Last, but not least, some of you mentioned the fact that, as the flows diminish or go down to zero on the eastern route, we see an increase on the central Mediterranean route. Let me tell you, please have a look at the numbers but most of all at the nationalities. They are two completely different routes and there is no link, as of today. Last year, through Libya to Sicily, we were facing a major inflow of Syrians. It is not the case today. At the moment we are not seeing a shift. It is simply that Africa is young, it is poor, it is facing the dramatic effect of climate change, and it is only natural that this happens, if we do not work with a long-term strategic perspective to change this. That is what we are suggesting to you to do.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will make just a few remarks in addition to what High Representative Mogherini said. It is my deep conviction that the only way we can maintain a humane refugee policy, based on our most fundamental values, is if we make a clear distinction between people who deserve international protection and people who come to Europe because they see economic opportunity in Europe. All too often – and we have heard it again here today – people pretend that everyone arriving on Europe’s shores is an economic migrant. I have heard some of your Members saying it today. This is a cheap way of getting rid of your moral and legal responsibility vis—à—vis people who deserve international protection, but it is made possible because, until now, we have not been good enough at making a clear distinction between people who deserve international protection and people who do not. Why? Because for too many years Greece and Italy were left alone with a problem. They asked time and time and time again for a European solution and the only answer they got from the rest of Europe was that ‘it’s not our problem, but your problem, so take care of it’.  So now we need to solve it and the only sustainable way of solving it is by  doing it in a European way. We can solve it, and get pan—European support for a humane refugee policy, if, and only if, we sort out the issue of economic migration in a sustainable way, and the compact with African countries is one element for doing that. That is why I passionately believe in this way forward. I have heard no one who criticises it giving us a better idea. If you have a better idea, share it with us. But to simply say, ‘let everyone into Europe’ is the shortest way to ending our humanitarian policy, the shortest way to ending the reception of refugees in Europe and the shortest way to giving populists the opportunity to say that everyone who comes here is an opportunist looking for a better future at our expense.  Tell that to a family fleeing from Raqqah, fleeing from Aleppo, from barrel bombs. Tell them that they are economic migrants. It is a scandal. So that is why we believe that, as part of a comprehensive long-term migration and refugee policy, we also need to be able to show that we can return people to their places of origin if they do not have the right to international protection and, more importantly, that we create opportunity in African countries so that economic growth does not disappear into the pockets of the elite but goes to everyone with talent and every young person has an opportunity to build a life for themselves in their country of origin. That is what we need to do and this is surely not going to be done on its own. We need the Member States to contribute. The biggest problem here is not just a lack of finance. It is the lack of clear direction, of coordinated efforts, of doing the same thing from all 28 with the European Union and its institutions and all doing it in the same vein, instead of having individual, very often post—colonial, ideas of how to have a relationship with individual African countries. Let us bring some order into this.  Finally, let us never forget that we are talking about human beings. We are not talking about numbers or objects. We are talking about people who have dreams – like you and me – who want a better life for their children and who do not want to be abandoned by the rich part of the world. I had a very wonderful experience last week in Sweden, a country that has taken in per capita more refugees than any other European country – more than 160 000. Now that they have the impression that we are slowly getting this under control, you see the mood in the Swedish society shifting towards, ‘OK, let us make a success of this’, companies offering thousands of intern places for refugees, schools accommodating many new pupils and communities welcoming new citizens. I hope that next week at the European Championships we will see Zlatan Ibrahimović being one of the stars – the son of people who fled the Balkan wars 20 years ago and who is now a very proud Swede, and Sweden is very proud of him. Let us see how many Zlatans we will have 20 years down the road in Sweden.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. – If we see that, as all studies and estimates point out, the current wave of refugees is exponential and will tend to increase, we realize that this is the greatest civilizational challenge for Europe since the end of World War II. It is clear that there will always be migration for economic reasons. All human beings have the right to seek to emerge from poverty and aspire to a better life. Two million Portuguese have done so throughout the 20th century. We have to get used to thinking a little more than the first mate. There is a whole work of information and pedagogy to do, starting with policy makers and ending up in schools. At a time when accounting is over, we run the risk of dehumanising refugees: the risk of no longer seeing human beings in them and seeing only numbers. It is the duty of each of us to counter the discourse of prejudice and fear and to remember that our human dignity depends on recognizing the dignity of the other first.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – First of all, I would like to congratulate the Commission for having managed, by working closely with Parliament, to put an end to the trafficking of refugees operating between Turkey and Greece. We can already see the positive results: zeroing the loss of life in the Aegean Sea and reducing the flow of Syrian refugees from Turkey. This is not the case in the southern Mediterranean. Naturally, this is a completely different context, taking into account the ethnic origin of migrants. It is not war refugees, but people who, for demographic, economic and inequality reasons, continue to come from Africa to Europe. This European agenda on migration must be addressed both from an economic support perspective and from a law enforcement perspective in African states. I recommend mobilising the European institutions and the Member States to find tools and resources that, in collaboration with third countries, lead to control of the migration phenomenon. African and neighbouring countries must be helped through investment funds by the EU, but control of these funds should not be neglected; how third countries spend this money. A long-term strategy is needed in which we Europeans work with African states.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – For the Socialists, Community immigration policy, both internally and externally, must be based on solidarity and the equitable sharing of responsibility, respect for legality and human rights. The success of the so-called migration compact will depend on adequate funding and sufficient budgetary resources. Robust external investment action is needed, with reliable partners and acting at source, in so-called issuing countries, with innovative development initiatives, also from the point of view of their financing. The EU must continue to insist on improved migration flow management and effective external border control. The EU should assist issuing countries with "training" initiatives and through the provision of equipment and technology, while these third countries must also actively participate in search and rescue activities. The European Border and Coast Guard should, within its new mandate, intensify cooperation with third countries and play a role in coordinating migration flows from full respect for fundamental rights and European values.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. Today, I warmly welcome the presentation of the new Migration Compact by our High Representative Federica Mogherini. I believe that, after excellent work, we have finally reached a European turning point, thanks also to the contribution of Italy, which has accompanied the request for the preparation of this innovative document. Finally, Europe has developed a clear defence of its borders. Helping the countries of origin and transit of migration, with an investment plan aimed at their economic development, makes it possible to prevent and, perhaps, avoid new flows and therefore new tragedies. Above all, we must help these countries – Jordan, Lebanon, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Mali, Ethiopia, Tunisia and Libya – from which an unstoppable exodus would otherwise start. This reversal of the trend is the only way to prevent desperate people from dying in the Mediterranean. Every euro spent on Africa and the Mediterranean is one euro spent on Europe. Another investment we must make is the creation of a border police force, prepared and equipped with the means to quickly identify infiltrators in the thousands of refugees seeking shelter in Europe.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The ALDE political faction and I have been calling for a long time for legal migration to be made possible in the context of migration movements, for example through the revision of the European Blue Card Directive for new labour, especially skilled ones. These people should be able to legally enter the EU if objective criteria are met. I am glad that the European Commission is presenting us with a proposal that codifies such a reform. Certain sectors in Europe are suffering from labour shortages and this may be one way of addressing this shortfall. In the Czech Republic, for example, an estimated 50,000 skilled workers are now missing in the automotive sector only. I have long said that having migration under control means, among other things, that there are legal options for those who fulfil the conditions for applying within the European Union. Legal migration is also, without a doubt, one way to increase our competitiveness and innovative potential. The "brain drain" to the US, including from EU countries, is a very good example of this.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – If we rewind the clock back to the past few years it becomes pretty evident that every year, every June and July this Parliament meets in Strasbourg to yet again debate the issue of migration, emphasising the fact that more hundreds of people have once again perished in the central Mediterranean trying to make it to European shores. This Parliament calls for all EU Member States to act and address this issue, but once again very little happens. The time for speeches has long been gone. The time for action was years ago, but the EU as a whole failed to act in a way which really matters and which can change things. Long-term solutions to challenges are needed more than ever before. Southern Mediterranean arrivals’ journeys are spearheaded by a need for development, a necessity for employment and a thirst for globalisation. These challenges cannot be solved with quick-fix policies, but a with long term strategy that generates growth, encourages development, ensures education for all and grants opportunities for the many and not for the few in a way which is fully transparent, democratic and accountable.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – For the Socialists, Community immigration policy, both internally and externally, must be based on solidarity and the equitable sharing of responsibility, respect for legality and human rights. The success of the so-called migration compact will depend on adequate funding and sufficient budgetary resources. Robust external investment action is needed, with reliable partners and acting at source, in so-called issuing countries, with innovative development initiatives, also from the point of view of their financing. The EU must continue to insist on improved migration flow management and effective external border control. The EU should assist issuing countries with "training" initiatives and through the provision of equipment and technology, while third countries must also actively participate in search and rescue activities. The European Border and Coast Guard should, within the framework of its new mandate, intensify cooperation with third countries and exercise a role in coordinating migration flows from full respect for fundamental rights and European values.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. We are debating here today, on the same day that the UN tells us that in just two years the deaths in the Mediterranean have exceeded 10 000 and while in recent years we have proceeded in order scattered between urgent appeals from Parliament and resounding failures by the Council to take decisions. Today we are in the umpteenth debate on a proposal on which Italy has strongly pushed, which has seen more than 48 000 people arrive on its coasts, and in particular in my region, Sicily. The Italian approach, that Migration Compact which we consider to be no longer deferrable, indeed very urgent, is now largely the Commission's. Immigration is not a problem of the Member State or just a European problem, it is global and cannot be tackled without the involvement of a continent such as Africa, to whose pacification we must all contribute with resources, concrete projects and effective cooperation. Now, however, we need the sharing of each of the Member States, without ifs and buts, we need a new approach and the intervention of each one for solutions that are no longer emergency but structural, true, without giving in to electoral interests and easy populism and demagoguery such as those I still hear in this House today.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – 1,000 deaths in the Mediterranean last week alone: it is perceived that the Council and the Commission have no ideas on how to deal with the causes of the humanitarian crisis or to face consequences, betting on replicating the immoral outsourcing deal with Turkey. And they continue to give business to traffickers by not opening up legal and safe access routes, as they say they are explaining to Europeans that the flows of migrants and refugees can help stem Europe's ageing. And they are not even moving towards creating instruments to finance the integration of refugees and migrants.  Treating Africa "one-size-fits-all" is a gross mistake. A Marshall Plan for Africa must begin by stopping the austerity of job-destroying in the Union itself. We need European governments to stop taking in illicit flows of capital that elite kleptocrats steal from their peoples and states. Stop supporting oppressive regimes such as those in Egypt, The Sudons, Ethiopia, Eritrea, among others, which gathered at the La Valetta Conference. And stop wasting the Union to act in coordination in the CFSP and CSDP frameworks to resolve conflicts, combat terrorism and organised crime, strengthen the rule of the law, promote sustainable development in Africa, the neighbourhood and beyond.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - The Commission's proposals are welcome and a step forward, but they are not enough. We need a short-term policy with concrete decisions to save people's lives, but more, much more than that. We don't need a long-term policy towards Africa. Indeed, we need a permanent policy towards Africa, towards all those African countries that are countries of origin for migrants and towards countries that are transition countries.  Only a permanent policy with a completely new concept can solve problems in countries that need to become our partners, not new neocolonial areas and economies. The overall Migration Pact is a step in the right direction, but doubling the population in Africa in the next few decades expects a lasting solution!

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Commission described migratory pressure as the 'new normal' and presented a new partnership plan with third countries. I am satisfied with the efforts to build a long-term strategy to tackle the problem, because the data are adamant that there is no prospect of migratory pressure to Europe stopping or diminishing in the coming years. This plan recognises that this will be the main problem of the EU and the next generation of European citizens. This problem is also probably the only one we cannot solve by achieving a better standard of living and economic growth in Europe. The better conditions we have here, the more willing they will come to us.  More than half of immigrants in Europe do not come from regions of military conflict. In the coming years, the EU will be a haven for climate refugees, which we still don't talk about much about. We must therefore promote better living conditions in the African countries and support their economic and social development. This investment is necessary to protect our European standards, rights and freedoms. I welcome the package of special agreements, arrangements and measures and hope that the start of this long-term strategy will be adopted and supported by all European governments.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal for a new European pact on migration is undoubtedly a step forward in relation to the current situation, not least in so far as it incorporates the Italian Government's proposal of the same name. To stem the human tragedy that saw, according to Caritas data, 2 814 lives die out in an attempt to reach our continent only in 2016, it is necessary to act directly in the countries of origin of migrants and refugees. However, it is not only with money concessions that we will find a solution to the increase in migratory flows. It is good to invest 8 billion in Ethiopia, Eritrea, Niger, Nigeria, Mali, Lebanon and Jordan, but we will need control over the management of funds, the conditions of migrants and refugees, or we risk an ineffective response. Let us not, however, hide the umpteenth failure of the Member States to achieve shared responsibility for relocations with an investment plan. Only when we recover a spirit of solidarity between Europeans will we also be able to find a humane and just solution to help those in need.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's presentation of the Migration Pact, as it is a step towards real aid and a perception of the fundamental, if still less stressed, fact that migration problems need to be addressed, particularly in those countries where they arise – whether they are countries that have had to leave refugees or the countries they are going through. It will now be important to focus on the details of the implementation of the proposed measures, including, for example, how these proposals will be financed or to which projects they will be directed, so that the aid is truly effective and long-term, based on partnerships with those countries.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βοζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνιδη (
text: PPE), in writing. – The effort in recent years for a holistic European approach to migration must undoubtedly also be a priority for the EU's foreign policy. Europe's responsible attitude towards third countries of origin/transit of economic migrants is crucial. Let us not forget that about two thirds of the world's migrants come from less developed countries, with half of them migrating to developed countries. The Malta Summit, attended by african countries, reaffirmed the guidelines for EU-Africa cooperation and confirmed the service of these actions through the newly established Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and Migration in Africa. However, the procedures have since progressed very slowly, because, among other things, these countries do not cooperate effectively with the EU on issues relating to tackling irregular migration and, above all, on the implementation of a more effective return policy. Recently, I pointed out in a question to the Commission the urgent need to promote readmission agreements with African countries of origin for economic migrants, with which there is currently no such agreement. At the same time, more incentives should be offered as a reward to the cooperating third countries, such as targeted financing and education opportunities to limit migration flows from them.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the Commission statement on a legal migration package (2016/2758(RSP)), and - the Commission statement on an action plan for the integration of third-country nationals (2016/2759(RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I do not hide that you inspire me to speak in Greek tonight but since it will be all Greek to everybody, I come back our working language. Honourable Members of the Parliament, Mr President, I am really pleased to present before you today a revised EU Blue Card proposal and an EU action plan on integration. From the very beginning, this House has valued the importance of having sound and forward-looking legal migration policies, which are the other important side of the coin of managing migration comprehensively and in an effective way. But legal migration goes beyond migration and mobility as such. It plays an important role in strengthening the EU’s competitiveness and it can address demographic challenges and labour shortages. While, on the one hand, we will need to continue investing in the skills of our existing workforce and addressing unemployment, the rapid ageing of the population in the European Union will require us to attract skills from abroad to address shortages in specific sectors. I will give you two examples. In the ICT sector we need more than 100 000 highly skilled professionals per year. In the health sector there will be around one million unfilled highly skilled vacancies by 2020. Even if we upskill our labour force, this takes time. Besides that, we will still need more people to fill the shortages. Let me also state another fact, which I know is difficult to hear in the current context: European societies are and will continue to become increasingly diverse. Today there are 20 million non-EU nationals residing in the European Union – around 4% of its total population. The key element here is not to fight this reality but to embrace it and turn it into an advantage by ensuring the successful integration of migrants – including, of course, refugees – into the host societies as soon as possible, therefore maximising the benefits of immigration. Today’s proposals address all these issues. On the Blue Card, the European Union is increasingly competing with the growing number of other destinations for the same global pool of talent. We want to become more attractive than countries such as Australia, Canada and the United States of America. Therefore, the EU needs to establish a more efficient, transparent and simpler scheme for attracting highly skilled workers. This will bring substantial benefits to the European Union in terms of innovation, transfer of technology and increased investment flows. This will enhance the European Union’s competitiveness and help create new jobs. In fact, the new Blue Card scheme would bring an estimated post-dip annual economic impact of between EUR 1.4 billion to EUR 6.2 billion from additional highly skilled workers coming to the European Union to take up jobs. Right now, the existing Blue Card is unattractive, unknown and fragmented. So, how can we change? How can we remedy these shortcomings? Today’s proposal aims at establishing an ambitious Europe-wide scheme. It will be easier to qualify for the EU Blue Card. The scheme is also made more accessible if you have graduated recently or work in a shortage occupation. The EU Blue Card is also made accessible to highly skilled beneficiaries of international protection. This will allow them to make full use of their potential and skills and support their integration. The Blue Card can be obtained faster because the maximum processing time is shorter. The new proposal also provides for enhanced rights in terms of intra-EU mobility, access to employment and long-term residence, and for family members. On the action plan on integration, we are not starting from scratch on integration but we should learn from the past when looking at the future. If we look at integration outcomes across the European Union, third country nationals continue to face barriers in the education systems or the labour market. They are more at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The recent inflow of third country nationals to Europe, and in particular of refugees, represents an additional challenge but is also an opportunity and we have to seize this window of opportunity. It is therefore high time to investment more on integration if we want to ensure that all third country nationals can fully contribute to our economies and societies. I want to be very clear: the cost of non-integration in the longer-term will be higher than the cost of investing today in effective integration policies. On the other hand, if we succeed in making integration a success story, this will be highly beneficial, both for the host countries and for the migrants themselves. Effective integration also entails an understanding and subscribing to EU fundamental rights and values. This is an essential element of living and participating in the European Union, and we should not shy away from addressing this question when we define what it means to live in and belong to Europe. Now, while we fully recognise that integration policies are made and done at national, and particularly at regional and local levels, it is also true that those levels across the European Union are experiencing the same challenges. So the European Union has a role to play in supporting all stakeholders in this process in coordinating and in helping structurally and financially.  The action plan adopted today offers a comprehensive framework to support Member States’ efforts in developing and strengthening their integration policies. It targets all third country nationals in the European Union while including several actions that address the specific challenges faced by refugees. The key areas of action that we have identified are: Firstly, support to third country nationals, but also the communities that welcome them at the earliest possible moment in the migration process through pre-departure and pre-arrival measures. Secondly, education and training. Thirdly, integration of third country nationals into the labour market and into vocational training. Fourthly, facilitating access to basic services such as adequate and affordable housing and health. Fifthly, and finally, the action plan also proposes to strengthen the coordination between the various actors working on integration at national, regional and local level and proposes a more strategic approach towards the use of EU funds for integration, not only asylum, migration and integration funds but also the European Social Fund and other relevant EU funds. Honourable Members of the Parliament, I look forward to hearing your comments on our proposals today but most importantly, I count on you to help us turn them into reality as soon as possible. It was one and a half years ago that I was committed to bring this proposal here today and I am more than happy to do so.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Dear President, Allow me to comment on this point of discussion on the migration issue as a whole, as these are very closely related issues. The Commission's proposals, all that we have just heard and before, must aim at reducing the total burden on Europe. It is now clear that the protection of the Union's external borders, and thus the protection of its maritime borders, is a priority for European interests. And that is not only our interest, but also our humanitarian responsibility, because uncertain steps can be interpreted as an invitation to the hundreds of thousands waiting for a better life. And if we keep it consistently, we will do everything we can to keep it from coming to the Union illegally, maybe we can stop the Mediterranean from becoming a mass grave.  To do this, what we heard at the previous point of discussion is that we need to separate genuine refugees from migrants and return illegal economic migrants. We need to spend money on everything and do our part in addressing the causes of the migration wave. Our development and visa policy must be dependent on cooperation from third countries. But it is a clear and important realisation – and I am pleased that it is being said today – that urgent responses to illegal migration cannot be combined with medium and long-term responses to demographic and labour market challenges. In order to solve the latter problems, account should be taken of the specific situation of the Member States and member states should take sovereign decisions in this area. No mandatory or automatic mechanisms may be introduced.  The blockade proposal should take into account the high rate of skilled young unemployment in Europe and this initiative will have to look like this. The integration of migrants who have come to the EU has not been very successful so far, and it is becoming increasingly clear that there are new complex problems in which education will play a major role. We must say that Europe's ability to integrate is finite and that we adhere to our traditional European values. We expect those who want to live in Europe to respect them, so that integration can be easier.

name: Claude Moraes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his statement and the proposals. They are very important proposals and indeed very brave coming at the time of the global migration crisis. As we heard in the previous debate, it is a global migration crisis. But if I start with the first proposal on integration, I was reminded of a Swiss German poet – I cannot remember the name – who, when asked about guest workers in Germany, said ‘we invited guest workers to Germany, unfortunately we got human beings’. The problem is that if we do not manage migration, and if we do not manage the integration of those whom we invite or of those refugees who are deserving of international protection, we will pay the cost. I think the Commissioner has made that point. But the Commission, the European Parliament and of course the Member States above all have to understand that integration is not an option. We will pay the cost if we do not employ those integration measures that we can have at our disposal.  Ultimately, most integration measures are done at local level, but we know from our discussions with the Commission that there are key integration measures that we can advance with the Commission in the labour market that are at our disposal.
