We know that some countries, like the United Kingdom, will opt out of those and I want to make that clear to those who are listening very carefully to that point. On the question of the Blue Card, many people throw around issues like the Australian-style points system. Well let us be very clear on the question of the Blue Card: at the moment it is completely unsatisfactory. The issue of managing migration, which everyone wants to talk about across the political spectrum, has to be worthy of the name. If we are going to manage migration for the benefit of migrants in a proper respectful mutual partnership with those countries who are sending migrants, then we have to have a proper well-studied proposal, like the seasonal workers proposal or the student proposal that my colleague Ms Wikström has finished. Legal migration must not be done on the cheap and on the quick. With the Commission we must do it properly, so that we have a proper mutual understanding with the sending countries: no cherry picking, a proper legal migration proposal that is worthy of its name. I thank the Commission for its proposal today.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: I would remind you that, according to the Rules of Procedure, visitors who watch the debate from the gallery are not allowed to applaud. I note this because some may not have had it in mind.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – No one will deny that Europe faces major demographic challenges, today but certainly in the future. It is therefore a very good thing that the EU is thinking about its policies and is now having a debate. There is a lot of fodder for discussion on the table today. I will confine myself to a few key comments.  Let me first stress and reiterate that asylum and migration are two different things that need to be dealt with separately. For example, asylum cannot solve structural internal economic shortcomings and legal migration cannot solve the asylum crisis either.  That's how I get to my second point. The revision of the Blue Card Directive. It is essential for our economy that Europe can attract highly qualified people. But, I repeat, the blue card must not be a shortcut for asylum. I therefore stress the importance of an effective free vacancy that can only be filled via the blue card. A revision of the Blue Card Directive should recognise that Member States are best placed to assess the needs of their national labour market.  And finally, once in Europe, it is important that newcomers integrate well. I therefore support the proposal to free up European funds for the integration of new comers. It is important that these funds go to the competent institutions and the Member States so that they can spend them themselves in accordance with their own local needs.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, it has been several years since we have been calling for an ambitious reform of this text in the face of the shortcomings of the 2009 Blue Card Directive and we are saying, in particular my parliamentary group, that there is an urgent need for Europe to have a genuine and effective policy on legal immigration, successful integration, while at the same time combating both irregular immigration and illegal work. Four points quickly: in order to do this, we need to really re-examine this legislative instrument, as you have pointed out, Commissioner, to avoid us carrying out a half-hearted reform, as we often, unfortunately, we do and which results in us putting the work back on the job, a few years later, to adapt it to the situation. In short, let us come together with a reform that is meaningful and courageous, let us legislate with ambition, as we are used to saying here. Second point: we need to adapt the scheme by setting legal immigration quotas for the Union and do it country by country, sector by sector, according to the needs of the European economy, this, for example, thirdly, with a European portal containing information on needs, on job offers that the Union needs for the system to function smoothly , correctly and efficiently. And finally, as Guy Verhofstadt pointed out in the previous debate, let us not create 28 devices, but a device that is readable, effective and usable. In conclusion, this new blue card, it must perhaps be a "realistic" equivalent of the Americans' Green Card to attract innovation and stimulate our much-needed European economic development.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are not going to discuss whether people without papers, whom many of you like to call 'illegal', deserve to be expelled or not. We will not discuss whether they deserve access to health care or social benefits or not. Because that would be getting into his racist and xenophobic logic. We refuse that a person's administrative situation conditions his rights and his freedom. More importantly, we deny this division between legal and illegal people, because no human being is illegal. Illegal is a condition imposed on them by their laws. They want legal, a few—very few—for highly skilled jobs, in a very utilitarian view of migration, and they want illegals for cheap labor, 21st-century slaves. And they want illegals for the sexual exploitation of women. In the Spanish state, more than 85% of trafficking victims are women who do not have roles. We will not support any measure that is not a guarantor of a life in dignity for all migrants. For all of us.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would agree with what the Commissioner has said about the need to develop our own skills base within the European Union. That is the topic of the next debate this afternoon. Of course, we need to actually do more to retain the highly-qualified people that we have, but this is never going to be a perfect match. As the Commission figures show, there are major shortages. I would add engineers to his list, and if we want to move further in terms of a just transition towards a low-carbon economy, engineers are people that we need. They do not all have to be men.  But the group that we are talking about very much this afternoon are people who actually do have choices about where they go, and some of the proposed changes to the Blue Card sound very positive. Indeed, a number of them were argued for by some of us in this Chamber the first time round – I am sure Mr Moraes will remember that. But when this Blue Card was coming into place, again at the beginning, one of the things that we were told was that people who have choices were often put off coming to the European Union because they actually perceived it as a place where they would experience racism, where they would experience xenophobia and where they would not be made welcome. Would the Commission like to comment on whether he feels that the European Union has moved on to become a more welcoming environment, or indeed whether the integration proposals that he has are going to work as part of a two-way street? That needs to cover attitudes here as well. We do need to look at the issues around social inclusion and at how the different funding mechanisms we have work together to actually make sure that no group is excluded.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Mr Obermayr has asked for a blue card. From what I can see, however, it is in the order of the registered speakers to speak after 10 minutes. So let him wait to speak then and raise the issues he wants. We're too late. Let me be a little strict with your input.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that I find myself listening with great interest to what he says in his speech. If we took the words ‘European’ and ‘Union’ out of this for a moment, Commissioner, you say that immigration should be skills-based: I agree. You say that sometimes there are times when it would take too long to train particular skills that we need in our economy for ourselves, and again, I agree. Also, you accept that there is a need for control rather than for uncontrolled immigration, and again I agree.  Of course, in terms of training up skills, there is an awful lot more that we need to do. I agree with all of that. But the debate that we have in the United Kingdom when we come up to the referendum on 23 June is not just about non-EU immigration, it is also about EU immigration. It is the same issue to us whether people come from Poland or Pakistan, whether they come from Austria or Australia, whether they come from Spain or Senegal.  We believe that people should be treated the same. Nobody would have argued, 40 years ago – certainly not in the UK – that we should have a system of uncontrolled immigration from the other 27 countries of the European Union, but highly controlled migration from the other 167. So Commissioner, your arguments against uncontrolled immigration from non-EU countries I say apply just as well to immigration from EU countries. We need appropriate control from everywhere.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – On top of bins of development money, billions of euros will soon disappear into Africa, in the hands of corrupt leaders and organisations such as Boko Haram, Al Qaeda and the Islamic State. After Erdogan's Turkey, Brussels is now proposing to put the fate of our country in the hands of corrupt countries such as Nigeria, Libya, Ethiopia, Niger and Senegal.  Combating the asylum tsunami with a wave of money can only be concocted here in Brussels. The aim is not to stop the flow of immigration, on the contrary.  While the borders remain wide open, you propose to create even more legal avenues to allow fortune-seekers to come this way. That blue card of yours is rather a golden ticket, with even more and even more unlimited possibilities to get in here. So we're going to pay handsomely for more immigration, but you're calling it legal instead of illegal. Completely bizarre! There is only one package of measures that works. A package that can only be proposed and introduced by courageous sovereign nation states. A package to freedom. A package of the people. A package of borders closing, de-Islamising and leaving the European Union. Better today than tomorrow.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we must be clear in the essential way: we cannot confuse economic migration with refugees. And we must combat illegal migration and trafficking in human beings and regulate legal migration. And in the context of economic migration, as the Commissioner said, it is clear that Europe must be able to attract the best in the world and promote internal mobility.  A different issue is the legal and safe access of people fleeing war and seeking protection on our territory. We will prevent thousands of deaths in the Mediterranean while we fight human traffickers. We will better manage the influx of people. But we have to be serious: resettlement mechanisms only meet their objective with numbers that go against reality. And they do not replace other access instruments, such as humanitarian visas. It is clear that the success of resettlement mechanisms depends on collaboration with third countries. But also here, a warning to navigation: more funding can not be more frontloading, that is, face the present with what was destined for the future. We cannot reach 2017 and be faced with a new emergency, because we have not been able to guard upfront spending. A final note on integration policy. My country, Portugal, was considered the 2nd best country in the world in the integration of migrants in 2015. Despite this, we know there's still a lot of work ahead. At European level, what remains to be done is, unfortunately, much more.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – I have no doubt that the successful integration of migrants into european Union countries, in European society, is our common goal. To this end, we need common, balanced, uniform and comprehensive European rules, which will be unconditionally complied with by all European countries. The Blue Card as a legal instrument of migration is a tool that has so far been used far too little, like humanitarian visas, although it could solve many problems.  The Blue Card reduces work on the black market, from which profiteers only profit, contributes positively to integration and reduces discrimination against migrants. Equal treatment and equal pay is not only a way of ensuring the social integration of migrants, but generally contributes to the fight against social dumping. However, we need a single Blue Card that covers the entire European market, not the 28 countries. Working and living conditions and access to education for migrant workers and their children, regardless of their status, are an essential factor in their integration into the social and economic sphere of the host country, and measures to do so must be implemented at national, regional and local level. However, adopting rules or measures is pointless and doomed to failure in advance if we know that they are fragmented and left to be assigned to individual countries, and if we know that certain countries do not adhere to them and even predict it openly. To mention the resettlements: Hungary and Slovakia have still not expressed their willingness to resettle people. Some countries, such as the Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Estonia, reject resettlement requests without good reason. Poland is enforcing a freeze that has never been granted to it.  This is simply unacceptable and we will not bring Europe back to life in this way.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – It is crucial, I have the conviction, to set up the entry integration process correctly in this migration crisis, for those who are granted asylum and residence in the European Union. Adepts must undergo a edible social programme with language teaching, understanding of our culture, history, moral principles and the foundations of christian spiritual tradition, which will prepare them for their asylum stay. They need to understand that there are our rules under our roof. There cannot be foreign ghettos with a closed structure, they cannot dictate to us how we will live, especially they cannot bring religious intolerance to Christian symbols and traditions. They must also be warned that perverse behaviour such as assaulting defenceless women, as was the case in Cologne at the beginning of the year, will be severely condemned and punished. Respect for women, children and the weak is a fundamental European and Christian value. Many refugees come from countries where conversion is punished. But we in Europe preach freedom and therefore we will not hide the Christian message. Our principles of tolerance, aid and respect are based on the gospel of Jesus Christ, which was once brought from Greece by Cyril and methodius, which is why christian groups in Europe today help those in need and hardship. But they can't abuse it.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We must remember that every human being is, has been or can, if life so does, be forced to become a migrant. And thanks to the technological advances that we see and thanks to the era of globalisation in which we live, it is easier for people to move around the globe. This, of course, places great demands on our societies, to manage the flow of migrants. Whether it is asylum migration or legal migration – we need to be better at integrating those who have arrived.  Everything else is wasting people. With their skills, with their knowledge, experience, ambitions and willingness to contribute. Unfortunately, we have done this in many countries, including Sweden, where it has taken almost seven years for a person to become self-sufficient and live off the income of his own work. That's not acceptable anymore. Integration, on the other hand, must, I mean, be built from scratch, built locally. It cannot succeed because there is a decree coming from above. On the other hand, member states can build successful integration on sharing experiences, both good and less good, with each other. Learn from each other, for an integration that can lead to increased growth, to innovation and creativity. We need that across europe. Migration plus successful integration. It can be a new life, new opportunities and new successes. And we need that, so we really need to do this with integration in depth.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a double standard cannot be established when it comes to accepting the integration of people who come to Europe fleeing terror or fleeing misery. Taking opposing measures based on the professional qualifications these people possess does not mean being supportive, it means giving legal coverage to brain drain, which only manages to shear a source of intellectual wealth in the countries of origin.  We need integration plans, of course, and resources to do so. However, that means not cutting in the welfare state. On the contrary, it happens to invest in welfare state. For investing in social rights and public services. The opposite not only makes citizens already living in Europe increasingly poor, but it makes it increasingly difficult to integrate those who come.  On the other hand, it is of little use to talk about integration plans if what we do is to expel through the European Union-Turkey agreement, or through a new migration pact, in this case a bad copy for the Middle East and Africa, which places responsibility for the control and management of migration flows over third countries, the vast majority of them dictatorships.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for While the previous debate was going on, the Commission's proposal came. I could read this on my phone. With so little time to prepare, it is clear that it is difficult for all of us, but at the same time it is quite easy to guess what the Commission would propose. I am as disappointed as I thought I would be when I then read the proposal, the blue card directive, i am thinking in particular. After all, it is still only about those who are highly educated and those who we believe will be able to contribute to the competitiveness of Europe. It's something better than before, and that's good, but it's not enough. We had hoped that the Commission would also take the right to include those with lower education, those who are currently also risking their lives in the Mediterranean instead of being able to get a job, or looking for a job, getting a job and being able to get here by ferry, boat, train, plane or something. The only thing the Commission gives that group is the answer that we should send them home as soon as possible, or to the country they last passed. We must also have a solution for those who risk their lives on the way here, the so-called economic migrants or job seekers. They are not irregular migrants.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, 7 June 2016 will remain as an interesting date in the history of immigration to Europe. On that day, the Brussels Commission announced its plan to increase legal immigration. It proposes to improve the European Blue Card, created in 2009 to attract a skilled workforce. The aim unveiled by Commissioner Avramopoulos at his press conference is to bring in 20 million legal immigrants, in addition to illegal immigrants. From my point of view, this is progress, because just a year ago, the same Commissioner put forward the figure of 50 million. The successes of the National Front in France and the FP in Austria have already earned us 30 million fewer immigrants. Some more successes of the patriots and we will come to a much lower figure. We will do this, Mr Avramopoulos, because the real solution to overcome our demographic deficit is to encourage states to develop birth control policies and not to bring in immigrants.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: – One more word about the investment plan for Africa. This plan is vital to prevent people from embarking on a hopeless and dangerous journey to Europe. Together, we believe that this Marshall Plan should create a strategic partnership for Europe and for Africa, and that it must succeed.  Secondly, legal migration to Europe with the easing of the blue card is one of the essential tools for managing this migration, contrary to what the previous speaker said. It is extremely important that we finally work on a single model for that blue card so that you, Commissioner, can indeed, with our help, put an end to the fragmented situations with 28 different cards. That would be a huge step forward.  The fact that it becomes more attractive for migrants with specific training to come to Europe is, of course, not only very important for the migrants themselves, but that is also vital for our economy. The previous speaker does not seem to have fully noticed this. The battle for talent at the global level is not being decided to the european Union's advantage today. We really need to change that.  Finally, let us not lose sight of the fact that, at the same time, we must do everything in our way to ensure that young people who are looking for work in the European Union are as much as possible accompanied in their search for a job.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Some of what is being said here is intolerable. Force Europeans to have children and let people drown in the Mediterranean. I do not know whether these are really human proposals. Indeed, we must consider the integration of refugees into the European labour market as one of the major challenges in Europe. Europe must not fail in this task. Work is the key to successful integration and gives refugees the opportunity to become self-employed and gain economic independence. It gives them human dignity and self-esteem. By dealing with colleagues in the workplace, friendships are made and social integration is made possible. The Blue Card is not a bad idea in principle, but it is not the solution to the refugee crisis in Europe. We have to say that again. In an own-initiative report, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has called for the European Social Fund to be increased to 25% within the framework of cohesion policy in order to enable integration measures, for applications to be processed more quickly, because the longer refugees wait for their residence status, the more difficult it is to integrate into the labour market, both for the refugee and for the employers. And we need rapid recognition and recognition of qualifications. We call for good, equal access to education, training, housing, health care and the labour market and social protection.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, we have a new miracle cure: the migration agenda is here and, as a new ingenious concept and recipe, is to cope with the uncontrolled flood of migration to Europe. Frontex will once again play a major role – Frontex, a poor paper tiger that was previously allowed to act as a water rescue, was allowed to register 900,000 border crossings last year, of which 3 665 carried out a ridiculous 3,665 repatriations. Ladies and gentlemen, that is a rate of 0.4%. So the conclusion is clear: big sayings - not a solution. Europe – and I predict this – will also be overrun by refugees this year, but obviously that is also the wish of Mr Timmerman, who is so enthusiastic about an EU mixed culture. Ladies and gentlemen, I do not want that, I see it as a real danger, a real threat to social peace in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to the communications that the Commission has made here today on the subject of immigration, from the Migration Compact to the legal migration package, and I welcome them with moderate satisfaction, in the knowledge that we need to act upstream and certainly not downstream. That is why the special investment plan for Africa is welcome, in the knowledge that it will enable the economic and social conditions of those States to be improved and, at the same time, that it will allow these states to cooperate fully on the subject of border control and repatriation, in the same way as what happened with Turkey and what happened a few years earlier with Libya. , when the Italian Government concluded that agreement which produced exceptional results. Allow me to express some misgivings on the subject of legal migration. I believe that we must show complete solidarity with the refugees, with the migrants fleeing war and persecution, but we cannot afford to encourage economic migration in a context of the very serious economic, social crisis that our continent is going through – just think of the youth unemployment rate which is 22 % in Europe, and in my country, Italy. , has reached 35.9 %, and in my own country, Sicily, it has reached 55.9 % – unless we have some highly specialised figures who cannot be found within the internal labour market, but leaving it solely up to the Member States to identify the maximum number of economic migrants to be able to take in.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card, sir. I understand from your speech that we may have room for some agreement, so I just wish to get some clarification from you. Would you agree with me that the only real benefit that comes to anyone from getting so many new people into the labour market so quickly goes to large employers, who manage to drive down the cost of labour and stop people being able to earn the kind of money they once did, and that is the real reason why there is such a drive to try and get more people into the labour market in Europe? Would you agree with that?

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that we can only afford to accommodate highly skilled workers. If the employer is a large industrialist or the owner of a small and medium-sized enterprise, it does not matter. I believe that we cannot afford to welcome everyone, but we must limit the possibility of welcoming them within our continent to only a few highly specialised figures.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, leave allow me to take in Romanian.  Madam President, Commissioner, we are talking today about a common European framework that will be able to secure the Union's borders through the European Border and Coast Guard, set the acceptance criteria on the basis of common standards and make it possible to manage the flows of legal migrants. In this respect, in my group's position paper, I have included a number of proposals inspired on the basis of good practice from several European countries, including Germany, and which have also obtained the open support of my country's Foreign Ministry. I therefore propose the introduction of an individual declaration of a legal nature which applicants must sign to access to the filtering areas, hotspots, or the external border of the European Union. The declaration would require recognition and ownership of the European Convention on Human Rights, recognition of European social values and, as specified in the Constitutions of the Member States in which they are directed or resettled, both in terms of respect for the rules of the rule of law and public order, in countries where the migrant-general is located or relocated, the imperative recognition of the secular character of European states and the secular framework of our societies , the prohibition of carrying out any form of proselytism or militancy with the exception of legally recognised political activities, and the non-involvement in any radical or religious activities leading to radicalisation and recruitment. I also consider it necessary to integrate into the legal framework of European criminal law the right to expel criminally convicted legal migrants, inspired by the solution within the German state. Last but not least, I stress the support of the Romanian state and my group for the development of integration projects with moderate Muslim states.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Thank you to Commissioner Avramopoulos for his presentation today. We have recently spent a lot of time in overdue maintenance and solving problems of the past in the area of migration policy. I am pleased that we can also talk about some more forward-looking plans today. We have already discussed the first point this afternoon, namely making agreements with African countries, linking trade conditions, linking investment to cooperation in areas such as the readmission of illegal migrants and border control. Mr Avromoupoulos rightly pointed out that integration and legal labour migration are two crucial elements of a holistic approach to migration.  I have two short questions on the second aspect. First of all, we know that the blue card system is not popular. In 2014, this system was used 13000 times, of which 12000 was used by Germany. What I am missing in this proposal is: what is concretely in it to make it more attractive to the other 27 countries? On the one hand, according to your proposal, we are going to oblige these countries to participate in this system, when perhaps the basic problems of the blue card have not yet been fully resolved.  My second question is linked to the need for social and economic development in Africa. It is highly skilled migrant workers who are important to rebuild society on the ground. How do you take this into account in this proposal?

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, no policy, no instrument, no agreement, if taken individually, ensures a response to migration on their own. We reiterated this only a few weeks ago, adopting the resolution on the holistic approach to migration. Managing this phenomenon also means, above all, opening up legal immigration channels and subsequently ensuring the adoption of ambitious measures and policies aimed at integrating migrants into the social, economic and political fabric of the host countries. The Commission is taking a step towards our demands, noting that Europe can only prosper if it facilitates the mobility of knowledge and people. The legislative proposal on the amendment of the Blue Card is a good one. However, demographic challenges and multiple labour shortages require Europe to go beyond the concept of a highly qualified worker. We must respond to the needs and new needs of the labour market and the different Member States by investing in human capital. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Do you not think that education is an indispensable means of integration to allow full participation in the society of refugees – both those fleeing war and those from economic emigration?

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Yes, education is a key instrument for integration. As I said at the beginning of my speech, no policy, no instrument and no agreement, if taken individually, ensures a response to the phenomenon of migration on their own, so that when responding to a policy of integration, we must take into account a number of factors which must include social, economic, political but also cultural.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: A brief note. I had overlooked the fact that you are from the same group as Mrs Kyenge. Normally, I do not accept blue cards from the same group, and i do so for the other Members for information. I think that if you have questions with each other, you can do it within the group, but here in plenary there are blue cards to ask questions to colleagues from the other groups. That for clarification.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the action plan to improve Member States’ integration of migrants and the revision of the Blue Card Directive. The time has come to change our rhetoric and recognise that Europe needs workers to sustain our economy and our welfare. We have to move from crisis response to managing flows according to our needs. For this, the EU—Turkey action plan is a crucial way to have an effective migration policy. We need to save and protect people fleeing conflict, but not all migrants are refugees. Those who do not need international protection must be returned safely. Developing tools for legal migration to Europe is also a way to combat irregular migration. It is a way to prevent people from risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals who exploit them. I call on Member States to fully implement the labour migration tools that exist: the Seasonal Workers, the Intra-Corporate Transferees and the Students and Researchers Directives.  Skill development and access to the labour market are the highway to integration, and early integration is key to effective integration. The sooner children go to school and migrants work and contribute to our society, the sooner they will feel part of our society and respect our system and values. This is why it is also important that refugees – in particular women – have access to work to ensure empowerment and social inclusion.  In the global fight for talents, Europe needs common, clear and simple rules to attract skilled workers and match the needs of our economies. It is not about migrants taking our jobs, but it is about migrants contributing to new...  (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to raise a sore matter for you, as a question of whether it is acceptable for you, for example, to have the government of a Member State, specifically the Hungarian Government, declare that it does not want to take in a single person. No refugees, no legal immigrants, no one. What do you think you can do with that attitude?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I have said many times in this House that solidarity must include all 28 Member States, and that we must go from a voluntary system of redistribution of those who have the right of international protection in Europe to a more binding system for all the Member States, because this is the basis of our common European solidarity.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the challenge of migratory flows to Europe requires a holistic and global European approach. The Commission's proposals today are therefore welcome, also in the wake of the Italian proposal of the Migration Compact. We will deepen them and work on them as the European Parliament with the utmost attention. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we adopted by a large majority an own-initiative report on the integration of refugees into the European labour market, for which I was rapporteur and which will be voted on in this House next month. We can start here. The report, among other things, clearly states the need to extend the Blue Card to beneficiaries of international protection, in line with what the Commission is proposing to us today. Allow me, in a spirit of full cooperation between the various parts of society, including refugees and migrants, to be able to say a key message, including here in plenary. No to the harmful integration of the social cohesion of our communities, no social dumping among vulnerable groups, yes to adequate economic resources, including through the strengthened European Social Fund within the framework of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework that we are going to face, which must be invested in what must in all respects be considered an opportunity. It is an essential test, let us not forget, for our values of humanity and solidarity as Europeans.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In the Socialist Group, we see the importance of immigration into Europe in more forms than just asylum immigration. In order to combat people smuggling, we must ensure that there are other ways of legally and organising to enter Europe legally and organisedly. For example, the Blue Card Directive should be extended beyond the category of skilled labour. Labour migration can not only be the case for people with higher education, but of course such a card must always take place in such a way, given in such forms, that workers cannot exploit people, so that we do not end up in more social dumping. I, like many other Members, are therefore disappointed that this proposal is not included in the proposal that the Commission has just presented. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we always stress that work is by far the best way to get into society, consequently ...

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support In recent weeks, a series of reports have been prepared and are being prepared, which form some pillars of the Common European Asylum Policy. Integrated European border protection, the transformation of the European Asylum Office and the reform of the Dublin Convention all serve the purpose of assessing refugee applications and immigration within a controlled, regulated framework, respecting fundamental rights and human dignity.  It is essential that the Commission has now taken a further step and started to develop a strategy for European integration. If we cannot create this, if we cannot offer a meaningful future, hope and chance to the refugees arriving here, then the whole European asylum policy makes no sense. We need provisions to strengthen an inclusive society, social cohesion and to counter xenophobia, populist politics, which unfortunately also gets a voice in this Parliament.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, an hour ago we discussed the migration package in this House, and we are now discussing initiatives aimed at promoting, at once, a positive look at regular migration. It is the right path, but at the same time it is an amendment to the whole situation described here, which is not the absence of Europe but the European Union's denial by the Member States, in breach of its own agreements, ununited in the face of adversity and in a state of panic, in particular in the face of the so-called 'refugee crisis'. Of course. Of course, regular immigration routes must be encouraged. Of course, we must promote a coordinated and coherent policy that makes sense at European level. Of course, it must be accompanied by the European Border and Coast Guard and integrated management of the Union's external borders. Above all, it must be equipped with the necessary resources to ensure that the blue card and regular immigration promotion tools also make sense in the budgets of the European Union. With European bonds, as proposed here this afternoon, at this headquarters. With European bonds that encourage regular immigration and adequately finance this new policy, which is an amendment to the whole of the one currently in force.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Mr Avramopoule, I strongly disagree with the policy of granting work permit to third-country citizens, while Europe, and in particular the countries of the European South, are plagued by poverty and unemployment. The launch of legal migration flows will lead to even higher unemployment, lower wages and the dissolution of the social state. Legal immigrants settling in the Union must be integrated. This means accepting and respecting the constitutional framework and laws of the host State, not gingification, and abandoning various antiquated social practices and perceptions. That is why I welcome the opinion of the Advocate General of the Court of Justice of the European Union, who considers it legitimate to ban the Islamic headscarf in the workplace. Finally, clauses for the distribution of legal immigrants at Union level should be established on the basis of population, area, GDP, growth rate and unemployment rate in each Member State.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the previous debate has made it clear that we need a clear short-term, long-term, but I would say permanent, literally permanent policy for Africa. That is why, on the other hand, we also need legal channels of migration, because only if we introduce the right legal channels of migration can we expect the integration of migrants into our society. Everything else will be one too dangerous, too serious improvisation, and that is why I welcome this proposal that the Commission is putting forward because it is going in this direction, because it is going in the direction of making legal channels of migration, but I call for the mandatory maximum, except of course the Member States, to include both local and regional authorities, as they too must be involved in this legal process of involving migrants.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, immigrants fleeing their home countries are usually brilliant minds and gifted people. I wonder whether the new proposal presented today by the Commissioner responsible, Mr Avramopoulos, on behalf of the Commission, to attract to the European Union people with a high level of skills through the blue card procedure will not reinforce the phenomenon of the so-called 'brain drain', that is to say the leakage of brains from their home countries. And I would particularly like to point out that the issue also has an intra-European dimension, because there are countries which are affected by the economic crisis and where this phenomenon is particularly acute, as is the case in Greece. I would like an answer to that.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, we do not need to look very carefully at the proposal brought to us by Mr Avramopoulos, in order to find that it does not satisfy and does not address a problem but serves purpose. You know that there are 23 million unemployed people in Europe. Are they not suitable or are there not the right ones to fill the gaps that are supposed to be filled by those coming from third countries? They say that Europe's population is ageing and, instead of confronting, we are calling on others to fill the gap. In Greece, Mr. Avramopoule, are young people, the talented, the educated and generally those who meet high standards not suitable to fill these positions? Will those who come from third countries illegally cover them? Do they give you the impression that they are the ones you want to choose? And one last: How is it possible that they can ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider one thing to be very important. Education and the legal avenues for access to training, education and work are revealed as a win-win strategy, that is, one that allows many of these people, immigrants or even in emergency refugee conditions, to have access to a life opportunity, but also to our ageing societies to have skills in internationalisation and the ability to accept the skills we need. I would also like to point out that it was important, for example, to adopt the directive, the other day here in plenary, on the possibility, which is certainly not permanent, but at least at last the doors are opened for researchers, students, volunteers and trainees. But now it is a question of making this more structural as a fundamental element of integration and innovation. From this point of view, I think it was very important to have provided for the educational corridors of refugee students in our universities in the forms of legal access.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Avramopoulos, the European Union insists on pushing with its belly the serious humanitarian crisis it is facing. It externalises its borders in the hope of containing the exodus of refugees, in which it has direct responsibilities, the strength of its policy of interference and aggression in North Africa and the Middle East. Your criminal migration policy and the agreement with Turkey have militarised the response to a humanitarian drama, with NATO's presence in the Aegean Sea. They have created concentration and deportation camps, where human dignity is attentive and human rights are trampled on. They diverted the migratory route to the Central Mediterranean, with tragic consequences expected.  Two thousand eight hundred and fourteen dead recorded this year alone, 10,000 in the last three years, among men, women and children. A real tragedy that will worsen and transform the Mediterranean into an authentic mass grave. The terrible images of bodies that give rise to the coast today are a clear expression of the class character of this European Union and of those who legitimize it. May it weigh on your conscience!

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to start by expressing my thanks to all the Honourable Members for their valuable contributions and the interesting debate. I am really pleased to see that many of you recognise the importance of these issues in the context of a migration crisis where we continue to deal with the immediate challenges, as Mr Coelho rightly pointed out. One does not compete with the other. We must continue to find immediate solutions while making our policies future-proof. Let me address some of your comments and concerns. On the Blue Card, the scope remains only for highly skilled employees. This is the purpose of the Blue Card. For other skill types we have existing instruments, such as the Single Permit and the Seasonal Workers Directive. In the coming months, we will focus on making sure they are implemented properly, but we will also make a comprehensive evaluation of all existing legal migration instruments to see if there are any shortcomings.  On refugees, Mrs Valero, actually this is the only element that challenges the scope because we do allow those who have received international protection in an EU Member State to apply for the Blue Card, if, of course, they fulfil all the conditions. As you know, the rights of asylum seekers are laid down in the EU asylum legislation and they have access to the labour market no later than nine months after they submit their application. For highly skilled potential asylum seekers outside the European Union, they can simply apply for the Blue Card if they secure a job offer.  On the single scheme, how can we ever have a truly internationally competitive scheme like the United States’ Green Card if we continue to have more than 20 different systems? Let us be very clear on what we are putting on the table. Member States still decide on the volumes, and they have safeguards to protect their labour markets when there are sudden moments of high unemployment through the labour market test, as well as safeguards against abuse. An EU scheme will help to increase our competitiveness and create opportunities for more investment and jobs in the European Union. Some words about the brain drain that concerns many of you, justifiably: our proposal includes a mechanism to limit brain drain. Firstly by promoting ethical recruitment: Member States may refuse a Blue Card if an applicant comes from a sensitive sector – for example, health care in a developing country. Secondly, by promoting circular migration: a Blue Card makes it easier to go back and forth for periods of time. A well-managed policy leads to a win—win situation. It has benefits for receiving countries but also for the countries of origin, such as remittance payments and the return of migrants with new skills and networks. This will turn the brain drain into a brain gain. I hope you will agree with me that the status quo on the Blue Card was not sustainable. It had to be improved and we have been as ambitious as possible. We count on you to take this work forward now with the Council. On the integration action plan: as Claude Moraes stressed, integration is not an option. I think we all agree that it is in the ultimate economic – but also social – interest of everyone in the European Union to integrate third country nationals fully and as soon as possible. Of course, this is – and remains – a national competence, but our action plan aims to support Member States towards building more cohesive and, ultimately, stronger societies.  This is not about creating pull factors or spending money disproportionately. This is precisely about making that investment in the beginning so that the returns are bigger in the end for everyone. Building on the action plan, we will continue to mainstream the priority of integration, non—discrimination and inclusion into all relevant policy actions and areas. Finally, we will regularly review the implementation of the actions presented in this action plan and the progress achieved in Member States, identify additional actions needed for the future, and report to the Parliament and the Council.  Now allow me to say some words in Greek, answering the question put by my compatriot, Mr Chrysogonos. Mr Chrysogen, first of all I would like to thank you for your question. I said a few things earlier about the brain drain, about the brain drain. My assessment, and I mean it, is that attracting people with a high level of skills to the European Union will ultimately have beneficial effects for all of us: the European Union, the Member States, the blue card holders themselves and of course their home countries. I spoke earlier about the benefits of the European Union and of course of the Member States. I would like to take this opportunity to stress that these people – you have no doubt – will acquire new skills, improve what they already have. Have no doubt also that, as the time comes to return home, they will return better ready to contribute to the reconstruction of their countries. Many of them come from countries that have literally collapsed and disintegrated. So when that day comes, it will be an indirect contribution from Europe and it will be an investment to be present with us. I really mean this because I do believe that this whole proposal makes a positive contribution for everyone, both for Europe and for the Member States and for third countries. It will be the Member States that determine the number of skilled migrants they need and which countries are able to absorb. What we have presented today is a dynamic move forward, given the experience we have gained all this time from the migration and refugee crisis. But it was also time for Europe to open legal channels. Until a few years ago, Europe had no immigration policy, only a few nuggets scattered across various Commission Directorates. Now it is both holistic and coherent and comes to answer the current big problem under the stifling pressure of refugee and migration flows. But it has also come to create a legal framework, because in the future – I said this before – Europe will need a workforce. And no one should worry about what will happen within Europe, because a short time from now – I would like to tell you this from today – we will present a comprehensive plan to finally combat the phenomenon of unemployment. Europe is here, present, and the Member States expect a lot from us and the answer and help will have it very soon.  But the fact that Europe will need a workforce in the future everyone knows, and we are talking about too many millions, which will de facto emerge as a necessity in the future. Europe is getting old. We know that and we repeat it often in our discussions here. I wish she was able to respond on her own. But we will need a workforce and that is why today we are creating the legal environment, the legal conditions, so that we can move forward in response to the demands of the times and especially of future needs. If there were two years ago what we are presenting today, it would have been different and more effective to deal with even the migration crisis, as manifested through the flows of migrants mainly, in the first instance, and refugees later on.  I would like to think that what we are doing really meets our own debt but also your expectations, to remind us of our earlier discussions in this Chamber where you have always urged us to get to this point. And today we are pleased to be here in front of you, saying that not only have we done so, but also that we owe a great deal to the European Parliament, which has given us the impetus, the encouragement, to move forward with this result. Thank you very much for coming.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, the Humanism on which Europe is built requires us to lend a hand to those fleeing the horrors of war. However, asylum alone is not enough. I welcome the Commission's intention to step up its integration efforts. I hope that this important aspect of migration policy will be given due attention and adequate funding. Because educating in understanding cultural differences, understanding, but above all respecting our values, as well as providing equal chances and opportunities are long-term measures that can guarantee our tolerance, justice and peaceful coexistence. Only successful integration will guarantee the freedom to be different in the name of our colorful togetherness, as a counterbalance to the language of hatred, social isolation and radicalisation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Uncoordinated action on migration has led to a major loss of confidence among the citizens of Europe. Member States such as Austria, Germany and Sweden have had to take in the most refugees per capita, while failing to find a solution to the refugee and migration crisis. This was followed by the controversial Turkey agreement, which so far has proved to be unhelpful in its implementation and can push the EU into a dangerous dependence on the Turkish government. The EU's sustained fight against the causes of flight should have started years ago, whether materially or diplomatically. Similarly, an expanded Frontex mandate could have stopped people smuggling and counteracted the huge migratory flows. The Commission is only now trying to open negotiations with governments in Africa and the Middle East to conclude migration agreements. Billions of dollars in funding will be pledged to the main countries concerned. A new fund will be endowed with EUR 62 billion and will serve as a motivation for rapid and sustainable implementation. Countries that do not cooperate, on the other hand, are to be sanctioned with massive cuts in development cooperation. Whether the desired cooperation will, however, lead to the desired repatriations or the reintegration of migrants from Europe can be observed with scepticism.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposals to reform the blue card will have only a limited impact in strengthening Europe's economic dynamism. This will remain insufficient as long as only highly qualified third-country nationals are targeted. On the contrary, this reform should be an opportunity to move beyond the overly restrictive approach of European policies on legal migration. We also need to align the EU's economic immigration policy with the gaps in the European labour market. Instead of the premise that we need to attract workers with high skills, it is important to target any type of skill in sectors where there is a shortage of labour and where European nationals would not respond to the call. In addition, the blue card could become a single work permit allowing free movement throughout the EU. Closing the door to this possibility would dampen our growth potential, which would be all the more damaging given the demographic challenges we face. Thus, the Commission should have proposed a comprehensive framework for the stay of third-country nationals in the EU, in order to be able to fully meet the needs of the European labour market.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the adopted decision on the European Agenda for New Skills (2016/2504(RSP)).

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I just wanted to ask you for your benevolence while the Commissioners changed. The possibility of addressing from this House a greeting to a group of drums who have come from Calanda , the village of Buñuel – who have come precisely to see if we wake Europe from its lethargy.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear Members of Parliament, I am very pleased to be here with you in Strasbourg to present the New Skills Agenda, which will be formally adopted and announced to the press on Friday. But I am happy to be with you already here today to share and discuss with you the key elements of our Agenda. The Skills Agenda is one of the most important initiatives on the Commission’s Work Programme this year. It will directly contribute to our promise to deliver on Jobs, Growth and Fairness. I would like to address my thanks to Parliament for your active contribution to the debate on skills: from last year’s report on ‘Creating a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century’, by Martina Dlabajová to the adoption this year of the resolution on ‘Skills policies and youth unemployment’ by Marek Plura, or the report on ‘Mobility in vocational education and training’ , by Ernest Maragall, to mention only a few of your initiatives, as well as the very useful joint hearing of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) and the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) in April, where I participated together with my colleague Tibor Navracsics. Skills are a pathway to prosperity. With the right skills, people are equipped for good-quality jobs and can fulfil their potential as confident, active citizens. Also, in a fast-changing global economy, skills determine Europe’s competitiveness and the capacity to drive innovation. Yet the situation in Europe calls for action. More than 70 million Europeans have poor reading, writing, numeracy and digital skills. One in four adults has not achieved an upper secondary qualification. Too many people work in jobs that do not match their talents. Women represent 60% of new graduates, but their employment rate remains below that of men. At the same time, 40% of European employers have difficulty finding people with the right skills. And too few people have the entrepreneurial skills and mindsets needed to establish their own business. Furthermore, the digital transformation is re-shaping the way we live, work, and do business and the types of skills needed. Europe faces shortages in high-level skills – you just had a discussion on that with my colleague Mr Avramopoulos – and despite good employment outcomes, vocational education and training is still regarded as a second choice by many. While national and regional labour markets and education and training systems encounter specific challenges, all Member States face similar problems. The New Skills Agenda for Europe focuses on three priority areas: improving skills levels and their labour market relevance across Europe; making skills and qualifications easier to understand and compare across borders and economic sectors; and improving forecasting and understanding of skills needs now and in the future. To step up action and not to leave anyone behind, we propose a basic skills guarantee. This is a recommendation to Member States to bring together their resources to offer low-skilled people opportunities to catch up and acquire the skills that will help them to find employment, stay in work, and improve their working situation. A revision of the European Qualifications Framework will make it easier to understand and compare skills and qualifications, and facilitate work and study mobility. We are also putting forward a ‘Blueprint’ for cooperation on skills in specific economic sectors to stimulate stakeholders to work together, to identify skills needs and identify practical solutions. Refugees and migrants come to Europe with a diversity of skill-sets that can contribute to our economies. In order to facilitate integration into the labour markets, we propose a Skills Profile Tool for Third Country Nationals to help identify and document their skills, their qualifications, and their professional experience. A red thread across our Agenda is the need to stimulate strong business-education partnerships, such as those under the European Pact for Youth. These partnerships also have a crucial role in promoting entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial mindsets. Other actions will follow over the next two years. Later this year, we will propose a revision of the Europass Framework to support the documentation of skills and qualifications and better skills intelligence. We count on your support for swift adoption when the time comes. We will also launch a ‘Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition’ to develop a large digital talent pool and ensure that individuals at all levels are equipped with adequate digital skills. For 2017, work in the pipeline includes a revision of the 2006 Key Competences Framework, proposals supporting the modernisation of vocational education and training, and an initiative on graduate tracking to improve information on how graduates progress in the labour market. European funds are there to help with the implementation of these proposals. For the period 2014-2020, there is more than EUR 27 billion of the European Social Fund available to support skills. Europe’s prosperity depends upon our most valuable asset – our people. In a fast-changing global economy, it is people’s skills which will be a motor for our competitiveness and growth. The Skills Agenda sets out how Europe will add value to Member States’ action and to mobilise actors. Together, I am sure together we can unlock Europe’s full potential.

name: David Casa
text: f'isem group PPE. – Mr Sinjura President u nilqa' b'sodisfazzjon il-ħolqien tan-New Skills Guarantee li tkellmet dwaru l-Kummissarju, li ser jgħin mhux ftit sabiex jimtela l-vojt li l-Youth Guarantee i setgħetx tindirizza, u li ser jgħin biex dawk l-adulti f'livell baxx ta' snajja', sabiex jitgħallmu l-essenzjal bħall-qari, is-somom u ħiliet diġliita. Ma' dawn, minn kemm jista' jkun kmieni, għandna ndaħħlu wkoll l-element ta' ħiliet intraprenditorjali.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Education is our future and must therefore be at the top of our agenda, and the austerity programmes of recent years have also made investment in education and training suffer. If we only look at the schools in Europe, they certainly do not meet the requirements of a digital future. As a result, we are not playing in the top league in digital competence in the world. In order to be added, we need a successful education strategy, which, in my view, consists of three core areas. This is free access to education, including the teaching of digital skills. All young people need cross-cutting skills that enable them to make informed decisions, develop initiative and build self-confidence. Apprenticeship plans must also ensure that young people have access to, use, and are not just consumers. Secondly, we need a review of education and training. More complex job and competence profiles lead to new requirements for employees. Training must also be more closely interlinked with the world of work, where social partners must be closely involved in curricula and competence strategies.  The third point is the institutionalisation of lifelong learning. In order to be able to keep up with technological development, which is getting faster and faster, and thus also to ensure the competitiveness of the European Union, we need a qualification strategy that counteracts the future shortage of skilled workers. Lifelong learning must be institutionalised, for example through a guaranteed minimum right to paid educational leave. This is what small and medium-sized enterprises need, which cannot do this qualification alone.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your Indeed, I agree with you and my colleagues that skills and qualifications are extremely important. That is why this Commission initiative is so important to all of us. I just wanted to point out that we cannot focus solely on the problem of lack of qualifications, on their supply, leaving aside the issues of how to increase the demand for skills, qualifications, their proper use. Indeed, we know that there is a discrepancy between qualifications and market needs, and I understand that the Commission's initiative aims to reduce this divergence. But according to a 2015 report by the European Centre for Vocational Training,  25% of workers are over-skilled for their work and 27% of workers are over-skilled and whose current work does not offer opportunities for further development. This is also a problem that the Commission should tackle in its initiative.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: on the alde group. – Madam President, Commissioner, we are very much expecting the presentation of an agenda for new skills. I look forward to it all the more because it is one of the key issues that my colleagues in the ALDE faction have been advocating for a long time.  When we talk about new skills, we should always look at them with a link to the real needs of the labour market. You yourself, Commissioner, mentioned that almost 40% of companies in Europe said in the survey that they were having trouble finding employees with the required skills, including digital ones. National skills and demand mismatches could be overcome by higher labour mobility. We should therefore support it more, for example through a system of mutual recognition of qualifications or even indirectly by increasing emphasis on digital literacy and language learning. Member States should also take advantage of opportunities offered by the European Social Fund, for example, and increase the adaptability of the workforce.  It is our duty to show young people how the labour market really works and to provide them with adequate practical training during their studies. We should work together to make apprenticeships and technical education more attractive to young people. Let us pay more attention to dual "work-based" training, working to raise standards of education and training. New recommendations for the development of practical skills are key to the effective integration of people into the labour market. We should therefore focus in particular on better anticipating future skills and skills needs. To do this, we need to link the world of education with the labour market. And if our European economy is to continue to grow and remain competitive, the adoption of the above measures is the necessary step. Commissioner, thank you for your proactive approach and your openness to debate, and I very much wish that launching an agenda for new skills would be the right direction.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. –Madam President, under the pretext of high levels of unemployment in the European Union, it is stated that the intention is to meet a Europe 2020 target which assumes that a quarter of the working-age population remains, asso much, unemployed or in training.  Under the pretext of continuing lifelong learning, the Commission pursues a logic of subordination of education and training not to the interests of the country's structural needs, but to the benefit of the so-called "labour market" and the interests of large economic groups promoting the elitisation of education, fuelling inequalities and social discrimination.  Under the pretext of the need to adapt capabilities to the challenges of technological developments, the European Union promotes flexicurity, synonymous with labour deregulation, attack on workers' rights and collective procurement, pursuing its neoliberal agenda. This European Union no longer has to offer the poor and workers but the path of impoverishment and exploitation!

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I too would really have appreciated having the full documents in front of us to have a more in-depth discussion, but I think it is clear. We are well aware that we have key shortages in our skills area – we have just discussed that, not least in terms of the Blue Card proposals. We are well aware that it is not just in the digital sector; it is also in the engineering sector where we have an enormous shortfall. I really hope that the new proposals are going to be looking again, for example, at STEM skills, and where we are actually going to develop those, particularly in relation to gender. In one of the earlier reports, we looked at the focus on the shift in our economy to a more sustainable, low-carbon economy. It had a whole range of recommendations on skills within that, which I also really hope are going to be taken up in the proposals coming from the Commission. Otherwise, I think we are just doomed to repeat our reports without actually moving forward.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it was 2011 and the Commission was proposing the Agenda for New Competences in the field of employment. What have we achieved? Nothing. We have razed workers' rights with the new labour reforms. Italy, Greece and France are proof of what we have achieved. We had asked for and were calling for the mobility of workers. Today, the only thing that is mobile in the labour market is brains fleeing from southern European countries to Northern Europe, as well as strong legislation at European level. In fact, even today we are still unable to get to work on the Posting of Workers Directive, which has come out, has been revised and has not yet been implemented, and we are already talking about reviewing it again. Unfortunately, there is no basic political choice that really protects the interests of workers and that deals with them and with the social emergencies that are currently gripped by Europe.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome the Commission's initiative on skills.  Skills are now the key to responding to the profound changes in Europe, which are resulting in a polarisation of jobs with, on the one hand, highly skilled and creative jobs and, on the other, low-skilled jobs. I believe that the challenge is really to enable all Europeans to have a level of competence that translates into knowledge, know-how, but also know-how in line with the needs of companies. In this sense, I believe that we must do everything possible to promote learning training, which must be developed but also revalued, regardless of the level of education and whether in initial training or continuing education.  We also need to do forward-looking work and work on the skills of the future. In this sense, a skills information platform could be a first step, but it would also require personalised support for job seekers and, in particular, the most vulnerable, who do not necessarily have the skills to get by with a digital platform. Commissioner, I would like to welcome your commitment, but above all stress the need for Member States to commit to this. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. This programme actually started in 2010 and has a horizon until 2020, we are about halfway there. When this timetable was first put up, in 2010, the same year, Viktor Orban's government , sitting in your group, lowered the age of compulsory education from 18 to 16. Did you agree with that at the time, or did you tell Orban that this was not good?

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, I think we really need to remind our Member States of the need to work on skills and, in particular, on learning. In my country, France, the government has placed learning as one of its priorities. In any case, he announced it, but at the same time he took measures that really discouraged businesses, and in particular craftsmen who, precisely, call on apprentices and promote learning. Therefore, where I agree with you is that there is really work to be done in the Member States and in my country, France in particular.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I very much welcome the fact that commissioner Thyssen has brought forward to Parliament today the new Agenda on Competences for Europe, in order to strengthen human capital, employability and competitiveness. I also see that the request I made as chairman of the Committee on Culture in the joint meeting with the EMPL Committee to work towards this objective, in agreement with Commissioner Navracsics and with an integrated and holistic approach in the context of lifelong learning, has been followed, and I hope that it will also go ahead.  We know that there is a persistent mismatch between the skills required and those offered, that we need to strengthen digital skills, but also citizenship skills, key competences, and high education, that we need to promote knowledge alliances, partnerships between training institutions, education, universities, businesses and research, to promote the education, labour and innovation chain and also apprenticeship in high education. I share the three focus on the quality of training, the comparability of skills and qualifications and the promotion of career conscious choices. It is also interesting, and I would like to have some further study, the proposal on skills guarantee to offer and validate personal skills, as well as the revision of the EQF framework to better include informal and non-formal competences. I am pleased to see that in the actions planned for June there is the launch of a competence recognition tool for those from third countries, a measure that we had also called for to promote educational corridors for refugee students in European universities and schools. I would like to understand better how it is intended to help Member States strengthen national systems, their comparability and the mobility of both university students and vocational training students. In conclusion, I believe that it is also important to pay more attention to the issue of strengthening training tools for teachers and trainers, including through European e-Teaching Platforms.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I think we are in agreement that there is always a need for upskilling and adjustment of workers skills in line with the advancement and emergence of new technologies. But we cannot use the Skills Agenda to simply do the bidding of private interests. Dressing up insecure, precarious working conditions as flexibility cannot be tolerated; equally, internships and apprenticeships must offer quality training and remuneration, not exploitation. Simply bending education systems to the will of private industry interests is not to the benefit of society. The best way to help people adapt to changing circumstances is to educate them in a holistic manner. Learning should be a lifelong process, but one of self-improvement that leads to development of critical thinkers. This not only benefits the economy, but society as a whole.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, skills, that is the new magic word for European politicians. Everybody loves it – skills – especially new skills. I can already see a poster in bright colours with a lot of glitter and smiley faces saying ‘new skills’. But what does that actually mean? What does it sound like in the ears of young unemployed people? What will it mean for them? Will it actually bring them new opportunities or is it just a strategy to scapegoat them for not having a job? ‘Sorry, you might have three Bachelor degrees and a Master’s on top of that, but you just did not have the right skills to get a job’.  If we want to make the new Skills Agenda a real success it will have to be in support of existing educational systems, taking into account the needs and wishes of the students, and it will have to be accompanied by an investment programme that can actually create the jobs that people will need these skills for. New skills will have to develop from being a magic word to having a real tangible outcome for the lives of people in Europe, otherwise we have not done our job well. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Reintke, I would like to thank Mrs Reintke for her work Unfortunately, I only have a degree as an engineer. However, it was not too difficult to find a job immediately after graduation. You spoke of young people who have three degrees and a master's degree and find nothing. To be honest, I think that is a little exaggerated. This applies to every country in Europe. I understood your speech as saying that it is best not to do anything, that we can leave new competences. Is that the opinion of the Greens?

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – If you go to some parts of Spain, then there are such fates. There are young people who have three degrees and still can't find a job. What is the reason for this? Because we need not only a new skills agenda, but also investment to create the jobs for which these young people should then be trained. That is the whole point! That's why we need the skills. At the same time, however, we need other activities from European level in order to really give young people new prospects in the European Union.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, what is the point of our talking about the new Skills Agenda for Europe when the President of Turkey, a candidate country, says that women who do not have children are half human? Women must be able to choose their own paths in life, whether it is having children, having a job or both. Turkey is clearly a country whose leadership does not respect women and is only interested in their ability to reproduce or, presumably, clean up after their husbands. Perhaps Mr Erdogan and the men who think like him should look at the huge contributions that women have made in the past, from Jane Austen to Marie Curie, the Suffragettes, the women who kept the country running during two world wars and the women who now serve in our armed forces. How anyone can call themselves feminist and support this chauvinistic country’s attempt to join the EU is unbelievable. I hope that British women realise this and vote to leave.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
