text: – Commissioner, I would like to thank you for the introductory speech. Unfortunately, we do not yet have the basis for this agenda, so what I am going to talk about will be partly questions and partly expressions of some expectation, because of course the European skills agenda is good to have. You yourself mentioned what the starting point might be. We are still failing to reduce the number of failed pupils in primary education sufficiently, we are failing to improve the quality of education, we are still not, on average, 20% of primary school pupils are below the basic level of education. I would like to ask you whether these international researches – we will have new international PISA research this year – are the starting point for the new skills agenda, or whether it is just the results of the labour market. I would assume that the new skills agenda will, on the one hand, monitor the improvement in the quality of precisely those basic literacy, basic competences, skills, but will, of course, also reflect the demands of the labour market. It is not only possible to monitor the labour market and not to see the importance of basic literacy for lifelong learning.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we hope that the concrete proposals relating to the Agenda for New Competences, starting with the two already presented on the ambitious skills guarantee and the revision of the European qualifications framework, will match the objective of improving access to the European labour market, making it more inclusive towards the most vulnerable groups. I would like to highlight a number of priority aspects: the development of digital basic skills, the harmonisation of competence assessment frameworks, the review of vocational training systems, the study of systems for the early assessment of the skills of refugees and immigrants. These results will only be achievable if the measures we are debating today are seen as complementary to reforms and investments aimed at protecting the social rights of European citizens and creating jobs. Without new jobs, new skills will not be enough.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, if securing work for 75% of the European workforce by 2020 is a central objective of Europe 2020, then already failed policies and training programmes do not solve the problem of unemployment. Yes, to upgrade skills, but with what goal? Certainly not the exclusive service of the interests of the market but for all citizens to have better supplies for life through equal access to high-quality public education. The blind adaptation of education to the labour market, its commercialisation and the degradation of classical studies have nothing to do with its role and its purpose to build free personalities. That is why the new skills agenda must aim to meet people's knowledge and qualification needs and not just to meet the needs of businesses.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the obsession with skills to be developed is an indication of a process of reification of the human person that has been going on for some time. Young people are seen as a resource of human capital to exploit. The European Commission's approach is wrong in that it aims to achieve job insecurity, as demonstrated by the recent labour market reforms demanded of Italy and France by the European Union. This insecurity, in turn, is reflected in the social and cultural life of European citizens. Young people are transformed into objects to be filled with skills, which have little or nothing to do with the development of civic virtues and critical spirit, identified exclusively as a function of an exasperated search for infinite economic growth. What is more, it was decided to use an instrument such as The Youth Guarantee, allocating more than one billion euros, which produced no positive results. Youth unemployment, especially in southern Europe, continues to remain at unacceptable levels. Let us change course radically: let us abandon these programmes that have fallen from above and implement policies that put the territories at the centre with their peculiarities and the real needs of European citizens!

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: – I do not need to remind you here of the army of Young Europeans without a decent job. In Flanders, the figures are certainly not so bad compared to some southern European regions. However, there are also pain points for us: concentration of youth unemployment in cities, an over-representation of low-skilled and boys and girls of immigrant origin, but also a percentage of lifelong adult adults well below the European average. Therefore, this agenda for new skills does not come a day early because it offers an answer to these specific pain points.  People are always more than the diploma they hold. Everyone has his or her own backpack, his own talents. These ten initiatives must not only make it clear to themselves and to the potential employer what exactly is in that backpack, but also that backpack itself must be filled. And that has to happen throughout the career, a career that will take quite a long time for someone who starts working there today. Careers of 45 years will be no exception for my generation. The shift from the focus from diplomas to skills offers opportunities. Young talents don't stay under the radar. The slightly more mature talents can be encouraged to go in a different direction. Europass, for example, could become a better tool for this. With custom jobs and the right person in the right place, no job is too hard. With what is at the forefront of the new skills agenda, Europeans will be much better prepared to keep that long career challenging, humane and varied.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking the Commission for this skills agenda. It has been a long-term effort to make qualifications more comparable between Member States, and that is, of course, extremely important. It is also an important new complement for reaching all the adults who cannot be covered by the Youth Guarantee but who are without education. This is a group that is very weak in the labour market and it is precisely they who need our support. However, I would like to raise a small warning finger for the preoccupation with entrepreneurship that permeates communication. Entrepreneurship is described as the way in which people should manage a labour market and society that is changing very quickly and in order to deal with complexity and uncertainty. I think we can all agree that entrepreneurship is important, but i think that it should be the solution to all the problems described, i think, going far too far. In the worst case, entrepreneurship may be called "self-employment".

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Commissioner, the new skills agenda that you have presented to us in the neoliberal dominant labour framework does not guarantee full labour rights but further deregulates industrial relations, leads to a reduction in expenditure on education, involves businesses more and more in the educational process and ultimately claims that the phenomenon of migration of scientists from Greece and Europe is to blame for the fact that there is no scientifically trained and trained staff. This package, Commissioner, is doomed as is your overall policy. You're not interested in the employee. You are interested in business profits. So the French workers and the youth who have taken to the streets, the Belgian unions that are on strike, 25% of the unemployed in Greece, 40% of the young unemployed in Greece cannot expect anything from these proposals. They are fighting to overturn neoliberal policies.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I support the new skills agenda presented today, because it focuses on the skills that are in demand in the labour market. Prosperity and safeguarding of our social achievements are based on the skills and know-how of all of us. Europe-wide recognition of skills and a uniform understanding of qualifications are of paramount importance for an open Europe with a cross-border labour market. We must ensure that there is a better permeability of academic and vocational education and training. Thanks to my own professional experience at a medium-sized company, the training occupations with the concept of dual training are particularly close to my heart. I think it is right that the Commission wants to strengthen dual training. In order to achieve this, I believe that it is appropriate to exchange best practice models, in which the social partners must be involved. But I also warn that no one can guarantee successful education, and better education does not automatically lead to a secure job. The educational mission for primary education lies with the state. I believe that businesses and society can expect good basic training to be provided by the state, which leaves enough room for second chance and takes people on their way to education and does not let them down. Companies and secondary education providers should then be able to build on sound primary education. Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her I am very much looking forward to the publication of the texts on Friday – you have my full support!

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we support you in the objectives. We're skeptical of instruments. And we're radically against it and we disagree with funding.  We support their objectives because, of course, something rare must happen in the European Union when, at the same time as we accumulate the highest rates of youth unemployment, 40% of employers say they do not find workers qualified enough to meet their demand. Of course, we support their goals when today 50% of long-term staff are under-trained, according to statistics.  But, for all that, we are skeptical of instruments; because it does not serve us just a programme designed in the European Union to be implemented whatever the Member States want — whether we call it collateral or do not call it collateral. We need a real programme of action, not just coordination. And that is why we disagree on its funding: because how it is explained that, if we need more training today so as not to increase the gaps that are accumulating — digital and also generational ones — at the same time we will continue to have a fully under-subsidised European Social Fund and continue to accumulate cuts in training programmes for employment in the Member States. We need, in the mid-term review, to increase the European Social Fund by 25% for training programmes. Without funding there is no possible design.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for her announcement today. We look forward to the details of it when they are published. As has been said by the previous speaker – and I want to make the same point – 20% of our young people in Europe are unemployed, 40% of our employers have difficulty in finding those with relevant skills, and we also have long-term unemployed who do not have relevant skills.  It was the same story 20 years ago in the mid-1990s, when 15% of our young people were unemployed and they did not have the relevant skills. It is the same story, but it is something that we really need to address. Now we have an agenda focused on it, looking at our education and training sector, which is so important.  We need to involve industry and employers in our education schemes. It is not enough for them to give their opinions and to complain that they do not have the relevant skills. They need to be involved directly in apprenticeship models and in funding apprenticeship models as well, because it is in their own interest to ensure that they work to develop employees who have the relevant skills. I think that is very important.  I welcome and am delighted to hear that you underlined the EUR 27 billion funding that is available under the European Social Fund to support such skills development. I hope all the Member States will work and will take up that offer and develop the relevant training programmes for the necessary skills.  Of course, quality and measurement of that quality of education is very important. You mentioned that 70 million Europeans do not have the necessary reading, writing and numeracy skills – the three Rs. This is a matter of primary education skills, which is a matter for Member States, but it is something that needs to be taken seriously if we are to advance at all in the new type of economy that is demanded, particularly as we face the global challenges and the need to equip our workforce.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, thank you for presenting the new Skills Agenda for Europe. And indeed, at the moment, in the digital, rapidly changing labour market, it is no longer enough to acquire skills for life, they need to be constantly updated, constantly improved, as new sectors, new jobs are emerging, new working methods to which workers really need to adapt. Unfortunately, look at the situation: in the case of unemployment still high in the European Union, it is sometimes difficult for employers to find workers who have the right skills to fill those vacancies, so, honourable Commissioner, we really need to invest more in training and, in particular, in those incentives, so that workers can learn in the workplace. And here, employers should work particularly closely with education and training institutions to prepare exactly the professionals needed for the labour market. Commissioner, I draw attention to the problem of brain drain in European countries, we are losing good professionals. Proposals must be submitted to the Commission. And I draw attention to three categories of people: people with disabilities, the elderly and women, especially those who return after parental leave. These people are in particular need to acquire new skills.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I fully support the launch of a new programme, a new skills programme and I want to thank the Commissioner for this job, as it is really necessary for European citizens and European workers to adapt to the changes taking place in the labour market. We understand that the aim is to enable European citizens to adapt to the world of work through the tools you offer here, and it is constantly changing.  Therefore, of course we should take care of young people, first of all, but also workers who should be able to be employed throughout their lives, and therefore I thank you for these innovations that you offer here to maintain our competitiveness. It's a real shame for young people to work in jobs that don't match their educations, their talents and their aspirations.  I also commend and welcome the target by 2020, which is 75% of the working population that should be employed from the age of 20-64, promoting certainly smart, sustainable and inclusive growth over the next ten years, and beyond, is also to be welcomed. Lifelong education is essential, also adapting to new jobs, first of all I mean digital skills and in any case I want to welcome the conditions for creating new jobs.  The biggest problem is the lack of education and training and this is what leads most to youth unemployment. I believe we will take care of this through this programme and to ensure sustainability, more people need to be employed across the Union.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I join in congratulating the Commissioner. Speaking of skills, however, we cannot escape the question of what is the place and what is the role of the education system in societies. Firstly, the quality of the education system should be measured not by the level of preparation for the exams, but by the level of preparation for life. Secondly, in addition to cognitive skills, cross-cutting skills are necessary, but also socio-mental skills. Thirdly, we must not only involve entrepreneurs and others in education processes, but also require them to be very involved in the absorption of prepared young people and job creation. Fourthly, there is a need to change the methods and methods of education, also much greater recognition of non-formal education than before. Finally, fifth and lastly, we need to make greater use of existing EU instruments, such as Erasmus+, in order to step up the acquisition of new skills, but also to gain confidence in the qualifications acquired in the Member States of the Union and in countries outside the European Union.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in twenty to thirty years’ time, most of the jobs will be in categories of qualifications which do not exist today, as also is the case today in comparison to twenty or thirty years ago. The technological change will be even faster in the upcoming decade. So the way in which people will work, be hired and put into practice their entrepreneurial skills will be fundamentally different in the future. As I said, the speed will only accelerate.  What we have to do is firstly the following: we have to equip the young people of Europe with the right skills they will need to have access to the jobs of the future. We are discussing a lot about online and about the digital single market, but digital skills are the point where our whole digital agenda becomes personal. It is the point where the citizens of Europe feel that Europe does something for them. What do we have to do in concrete terms? Firstly, I believe that we have to involve youth organisations more and more strongly when we draft new policy proposals. Secondly, I think that digital literacy has to become one of the core skills acquired from an early age and also later perfected throughout one's life. The education systems at national level have to be adapted to this. The Member States have to make sure that their education systems respond to the needs of the market and that we do not lose out in terms of global competitiveness. Furthermore, we also have to make sure that the EU budget is responsive to youth policies and that the EU can set up a coherent framework and provide technical and financial assistance to our budget to help this shift from traditional education to a modern one.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the recognition in the Commission’s proposal of the need to adopt a global and lifelong approach when it comes to skills, combining work skills and life skills. In an uncertain world we need to prepare a generation of young people with the motivation, commitment and transferrable skills, such as creative thinking, entrepreneurship, leadership and capacity building, so that they can become audacious problem solvers and responsible citizens. We are asked to help prepare these young people to live in a fast-changing world which we cannot yet even imagine. One thing we know, though, is that this future world will be more and more digitised and connected. That is why media literacy is the key. But here again, it should not limit itself to learning about the tools and the technologies, it should aim at equipping individuals with the critical thinking and digital curiosity necessary for them to become not only users of technologies but active citizens in connected societies. For me the backbone of this Skills Agenda must be education for citizenship, including e-citizenship through formal, non-formal and informal learning.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Mr President, skills, the necessary skills for success are at the heart of our competitive, innovative, economically progressing Union, so I very much look forward to the concrete proposal. In Europe currently almost 40% of the population holds a university degree, though at the same time one in four employers struggle to find people with the right skills.  To address this, I believe we need a more uniform approach and a very convinced political leadership in Europe. We need to foster complex problems solving e-skills, entrepreneurial management skills – 90% of future jobs will require ICT skills yet at the same time only one third of Europeans have used the internet; not to mention that we are not entirely aware what the jobs of the future will look like and be.  In order to ensure the added value we must step up practical skills recognition such as through the Entrepreneurial Skill Pass and other existing programmes, as well as the recognition of competences acquired online. Skills are not only to be fostered but also, most importantly, made portable, applicable and fit to the needs of employers and businesses. We have a single market for our goods and services and now it is time to match that with a single market for our human capital.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, two pillars must support this agenda of new powers for Europe. A concrete response to the high unemployment rates, a condition that particularly affects, and as has already been repeated here, young people from some of our regions, on the other hand, a real stimulus to the economy of the various European countries facing huge gaps in relation to the absence of qualified and specialised professionals in crucial development sectors. I would therefore like to refer to a tourism sector which, representing 10% of GDP, employs around 25 million people across the Union. There is an urgent need to support the digitisation of companies, create tools for industry professionals to acquire new skills, digital skills.  We believe in tourism as a career of choice: because we then create this option. We want labour mobility, we have implemented traineeships and work tools among European SMEs. We need to bet on a common curriculum, create online platforms of demand between demand and job supply, professionalize services provided with qualification strategies in human resources.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Parliament has long called for a Community strategy on new powers. Welcome, therefore, to today's agenda. If Europe does not want to create new barriers or new forms of exclusion in this digital society, and if we are to seize new opportunities, we must urgently push forward a new formative agenda capable of bridged the growing gap between supply and demand for skills in the digital economy. Initiatives to promote media and internet literacy for all citizens of the Union should also be put on the table. And resources must be devoted, more resources to lifelong learning to ensure that workers, especially the least skilled, have adequate skills in a hugely changing environment.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, as I said this morning, today's members of the Union in 1980 accounted for 30% of the world's GDP, and today this share has been reduced to 17%. Global economic and technological trends are changing and Europe needs to adapt to this. I see no other way than to invest in new knowledge and skills and better connect the education system with the labour market that we need to further liberalise. If it is to keep pace, Europe must be open to technological innovation and new business models that are changing existing labour market circumstances. Attempts to preserve existing jobs through regulatory hits on Uber and Netflix will not stop these companies, but they could stop the necessary transformation of the European economy and its adaptation to global trends, which will have a much more negative impact on the number of jobs in the European Union in the long run.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: –  Mr President, it would seem that the EU wishes to control every part of its citizens’ lives. You now want EU standards for skills and education. Does that mean that the same educational standards are required in every single EU country, and the same form of education? You want to control what skills people learn, and of course where and how they use them, all of that at the cost of tens of billions of euros of taxpayers’ money.  Education and training, like most other things, work better with less state, or less superstate, involvement, less politicians, more educationalists. The EU’s desire to control everything and every facet of life, unfortunately – and unintentionally – is negative and destructive at every level.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear colleagues, honourable Members, let me be short in my concluding remarks. Time is running, as the President reminds us, and I spoke already for longer in my introduction. But let me add this: I am very happy that we agree on the necessity and the importance of a Skills Agenda. Of course improving skills must go hand in hand with macroeconomic politics to stimulate job creation. The two are mutually reinforcing. The European fund for Strategic Investments is one flagship action which is helping us to do just that, injecting investment into the real economy to create more and good quality jobs.  And let me repeat what I said already in the joint committee meeting last April: employability is not a dirty word. Education and training must prepare young people to participate fully in society and to be an active citizen, and help them to acquire transversal skills, but people rightly expect that their education and training will also help them to get a good job. Good basic skills, having a good basis to build upon for lifelong learning, is therefore in the interest of both the economy and the individual fulfilment of every person.  Our Skills Agenda is an agenda for all. It is for young and old, for people in education, in unemployment, inactive people and people in work. The success of the Skills Agenda will depend on the commitment and the active engagement of many players, Member States first and foremost, as well as businesses and trade unions, education and training institutions, workers, learners and many others.  The European Parliament has a key role to play in raising the political profile of this debate, both in Europe and in your home countries and in supporting the implementation of the Skills Agenda. I want to thank you for your support and for your inspiration. I look forward to cooperating with you and, as I mentioned in my introduction, the documents will be available as soon as possible, that is when they are formally adopted next Friday.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – The New Skills Agenda is a key initiative to bring Europe back on the path to prosperity. With the right knowledge, people are better equipped to access the job market for the first time, reorient their professional lives or return to employment after a long period of time. However, the situation is dramatic: more than 70 million Europeans have poor reading, writing, arithmetic and digital skills. Too many people work in jobs who do not match their talents, while 40% of European entrepreneurs struggle to find people with the right knowledge. That is why we Socialists welcome this initiative, but we will be very attentive to its development and implementation, since it does not serve us only a programme designed in the EU to be implemented as the Member States wish. What we need is a real European action programme, equipped with adequate funding with a specific focus on the countries and regions with the greatest needs. Europe needs a skills agenda for all: young people, the elderly, people in employment and the unemployed. Only in this way can we ensure a just, sustainable and prosperous future for all.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The New Skills Agenda aims at improving the teaching and recognition of skills across the EU. It will boost employability and competitiveness and it will better respond to industry needs. The goal is to achieve a shared vision and a commitment to work together on improving the quality and relevance of skills formation, in order to keep step with the rapidly changing skills requirements of the labour market, equip everyone with a minimum set of basic skills and make qualifications easier to understand – thus helping workers and learners to move more easily within the EU. In this context, I welcome the comprehensive approach put forward by the Commission to address the basic deficit of skills and the skills mismatch at all levels, including transversal, entrepreneurial and digital skills. We need to continue investing in Europe’s human capital in order to maintain our competitiveness. I welcome very much the revised European Qualifications Framework, which will improve understanding of qualifications acquired abroad. I am convinced that it is important to promote the comparability of qualifications between the countries covered by the EQF and other countries, in particular neighbourhood countries such as Ukraine. This will help to ease the transition to the labour market and to create jobs and growth.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The EU Agenda for New Skills and New Jobs is part of the EU-2020 Strategy, responding to the target of giving work to 75% of the working-age population. In other words, it is assumed that 25% of the working-age population will not be active. The EU-2020, behind the social and environmental rhetoric, is the implementation of policies that have materialised the degradation of the socio-economic conditions of the population, promoting labour flexibility and deregulation, the primacy of deepening the internal market, with the liberalisation and privatisation of even more economic sectors, the liberalisation and deregulation of international trade. The Agenda for New Competencies has no other purpose and is part of this agenda. It advocates labour flexibility, the commodification of education and the tendency towards early professionalisation (through the link between school and the labour market or dual education), the promotion of "international competitiveness", through deregulation and the loss of rights and wages. Education, vocational training and diversification of technical skills are fundamental factors to ensure the adaptation of workers to the constant change that characterizes contemporaneity - at the technological level, in the methods of communication or management and organization of work. But there are several objectives of this Agenda: deregulation of work and bottlenecking the role of education systems.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The new European Agenda on Skills aims to support the discovery and development of skills from an age. This will create social capital that increases employability and competitiveness in Europe, thereby reducing poverty and social exclusion. As an existing example in this area, I would like to mention the Hungarian Talent Support Network set up by Professor Péter Chermely. Last year, the Hungarian initiative was put into practice at European level and a talent support network was established at EU level. The first 14 European Talent Centres were accredited last September, and this year 200 European Talent Points from 24 countries applied to be part of this network. And discovering and properly caring for talent plays a key role in the better well-being of the individual, ensuring a more secure future for the generations that grow up. The new European agenda on skills plays a major role in this.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – The New Skills Agenda is a key initiative to bring Europe back on the path to prosperity. With the right knowledge, people are better equipped to access the job market for the first time, reorient their professional lives or return to employment after a long period of time. However, the situation is dramatic: more than 70 million Europeans have poor reading, writing, arithmetic and digital skills. Too many people work in jobs who do not match their talents, while 40% of European entrepreneurs struggle to find people with the right knowledge. That is why we Socialists welcome this initiative but we will be very attentive to its development and implementation, since it does not serve us only a programme designed in the EU to be implemented as the Member States wish. What we need is a real European action programme, equipped with adequate funding with a specific focus on the countries and regions with the greatest needs. Europe needs a skills agenda for all: young people, the elderly, people in employment and the unemployed. Only in this way can we ensure a just, sustainable and prosperous future for all.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Agenda for New Skills is a necessary and long-awaited document. The problem on the labour market in the European Union is not only high unemployment due to too little labour supply. We also have many vacancies and employees' skills are often mismatched with employers' expectations and dynamically changing working conditions. I therefore welcome today's Commission statement. I am pleased that the problem has been taken into account as a whole and that support will be directed both to the education of basic skills among less educated workers and to more advanced technologies. I am of the opinion that the training of relevant skills, especially digital and entrepreneurial ones, should be an integral part of the education process from an early age and at all stages of education. It is also important to create an appropriate climate and framework for lifelong learning, as its potential is still not fully exploited in many Member States.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – Did you know that a staggering 23 million people are currently unemployed across the EU – 10% of the active population? For our European economy to grow and remain competitive, we need more jobs. From 2012 onwards our working age population has started to shrink. To ensure the sustainability of our welfare systems, more people need to work. But the problem goes beyond mere job numbers. We need a new approach to education and skills development also to ensure that fewer Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. We have seen what devastating effects a lack of true integration – social and economic – can have on our societies. For example, radicalisation succeeds in those communities that feel they have been left out. We have to reverse this negative trend. This is why inclusion of part-time and temporary workers, also for the refugees and migrants currently Europe, is so important. I am supporting the Commission in today’s launch of the New Skills Agenda. Its task is not just to create more jobs, but to improve and strengthen our European social fabric. After all, our future success is ensured only if all aspects of our society feel they are working together, towards the same goal.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – First of all, I am pleased that the Commission has taken up the subject of the European Agenda for New Skills and that it has focused on basic and cross-cutting skills and strengthening cooperation between educational institutions and the labour market, and on vocational training. Basic literacy, numeracy and reasoning skills examined for years m.in. pisa test for 15-year-olds show that more than 20% of young Europeans do not achieve a basic level of skills. What is most worrying is that this proportion is more than twice as high in low socio-economic families and immigrant families, where it exceeds 37% on average, but up to 70% in some EU countries. This creates a vicious circle of poverty and exclusion, social ghettos, limited access to the labour market and further education for entire social groups, when half or even most of the population is trapped in low skills throughout their lives. I agree with the Commission that cross-cutting skills, such as foreign language skills, digital skills, at all levels and educational specialties, are also needed. We also need constantly updated sets of skills needed in the labour market, defined and developed in students in close cooperation with the business environment. Therefore, the announced review of the qualification framework and the building of partnerships with employers and other labour market partners will be crucial to the success of this initiative.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the decision adopted by the Commission on a new Skills Agenda for Europe. We need clear action plans on better encouraging interaction between the education institutions and social partners. Their involvement in designing curricula and work-based learning is essential in order to ensure that all citizens acquire general knowledge and overcome the lack of relevant skills for available jobs so we can reach a better functioning labour market. Courses for reskilling and upskilling adults are also needed.  We should urgently incorporate new technologies in the learning process and further foster partnerships to fill high-tech skills gaps and promote digital entrepreneurship in order to align the European economy to the new digital reality. We should prepare and encourage individuals to start their own business and run it successfully. In this regard, special attention should be paid to the development of entrepreneurship and networking skills, language competences and other transversal skills and competences. The lack of comparability of qualifications awarded in the EU with third country qualifications is an obstacle to attracting talent to Europe and in particular to integrating the refugees and asylum seekers the EU hosts. Recognition of degrees and qualifications is essential for social integration and a functioning labour market.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – According to the Skills Agenda for Europe, one of the EU's main employment targets by 2020 is for 75% of the population to work from the age of 20 to 64. However, given the unemployment rates currently recorded in Europe, this objective seems unattainable for some EU Member States. In particular, in countries affected by violent fiscal policy, unemployment rates exceed 20%. But unemployment in Europe, which is deep and affects millions of citizens, is due to the productive model and not to a supposed lack of qualifications. It is due to the structure of the EU and the Eurozone. It is due to the merch austerity and poverty that lead to underconsumption. It is due to the unequal distribution of wealth generated in the Union, with the countries of the South leading the way in unemployment, while Germany with huge trade surpluses has an unemployment rate of 4.5%. In order to reduce unemployment, the policy of austerity must be abandoned, the productive model in the Union and the structure of the EU and the Eurozone itself must be changed. At the same time, investment must be made in education, training and digital skills in order to achieve the objectives of the Skills Agenda for Europe.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The skills guarantee presented as part of the New Skills Strategy is essential. At a time when mobility is being encouraged, making skills and qualifications comparable at European level is essential. Barriers to access to the labour market must be removed, particularly for low-skilled adults. This requires strengthening the basic skills, not only necessary to work, but also and above all, to integrate socially into society. I am in favour of the recognition of both formal and informal learning, because experience is knowledge in itself. Bridges must be built between education, vocational training and the world of employment. Professional sectors as learners are applicants. With its supporting competence, the European Union has an essential role as a bridge, to create the link between the different actors and to allow the good practices identified in the Member States to be spread. There are 22 million unemployed people in Europe, including 5.2 million young people, while shortages are being seen in many sectors. Let us bring these two worlds together by creating favourable conditions for employment and taking into account the specificities of labour markets in the various Member States.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – According to an ILO study, between 25 and 45 percent of the European workforce are either under— or over—qualified for the jobs they do – a situation that is largely due to the fast paced change in the structure of our economies. Because recently an increased number of people underwent digital education or training, the number of unfilled vacancies demanding IT skills became smaller than what was expected a few years ago. But there is still much to be done to align the European economy to the new digital economy and close the gap between the number of job seekers and the number of unfilled jobs. This is why I welcome the issuing by the Commission of an agenda to equip, skill and reskill students and people in employment or looking for employment with the competencies needed in a modern labour market. With a well designed and implemented strategy we can go beyond addressing labour market needs: we can also help the ‘skills—poor’ have a better start – or a new start – in life and to reduce poverty and social exclusion in our countries.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the European Commission estimates that around 70 million Europeans do not have sufficient reading, writing and calculus skills, and almost half (45%) the EU population does not have sufficient digital skills. This is more than an alarm state for the early 21st century. Despite the huge unemployment in Europe, more than 40% of employers say they cannot find workers with the necessary knowledge and skills to grow their business. Let's add that a huge number of young people with higher education cannot find work or work in places far from their education. Therefore, something is wrong in the education system and needs immediate and serious changes. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal for the new Skills Agenda for Europe. A comprehensive approach and activation of all effective tools are needed to address today's underlying skills deficits against labour market requirements. Young people should be the focus of the programme for understandable reasons, but only this will not solve the problem of the mismatch between the requirements and the real skills of the workers who are now in the army of the unemployed. Let us invest in all europe's human resources, in training the skills needed today and tomorrow.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Bangladesh (2016/2729(RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the European Union and Bangladesh are long-term partners. Our relationship has led to results that are mutually beneficial for both sides, particularly in trade, investment and development. The European Union is the first destination for Bangladesh exports. A combination of substantial EU investments in Bangladesh with EU development assistance has certainly contributed to Bangladesh economic growth and to its achievements in terms of poverty reduction and reaching the Millennium Development Goals.  The relationship is still growing. The EU and Bangladesh continue addressing together new challenges, such as contributing to the sustainability of the Bangladesh ready-made garment industry, a very important topic I think, through the Sustainability Compact and, more recently, addressing comprehensively migration and mobility.  In this context, the first European Union-Bangladesh dialogue on migration management was held in Dhaka on 5 April 2016. The most important policy objectives in Bangladesh are possibly to become a middle-income country by 2021 and therefore to continue lifting Bangladeshi people out of poverty, which I think has to be the first priority. Achieving this very ambitious target will need the involvement and determination of all Bangladeshi citizens and institutions, as well as the support of Bangladesh international partners. The worrying political evolution in Bangladesh could be very detrimental in this respect and since the controversial January 2014 elections, boycotted by the opposition and criticised by the international community, the political, human rights and security situation in the country has unfortunately steadily deteriorated. The resolutions on Bangladesh adopted by the European Parliament in the last two years cover these 2014 elections, human rights violations and freedom of expression. High Representative Federica Mogherini, her spokespersons and the European Union Heads of Mission have also issued statements on these and other issues such as the death penalty and the recent brutal killings, even yesterday, of independent thinkers and activists. This is a very worrying situation. These resolutions and statements over the last couple of years track and summarise very well a growing collective concern in the European Union about the political evolution in Bangladesh.  We think it is important that an overall new social and political consensus will need to be built in Bangladesh for democracy, human rights, freedom of expression and political liberties to be fully restored, promoted and protected in the country. It is time to put an end to the arbitrary arrest and harassment of opposition leaders, to restore tolerance and to open spaces for public political debate. It is also time to ensure freedom of expression as a fundamental human right and to promote respect. It is also essential to ensure the protection and safety of all citizens. Especially the brutal murders and horrifying attacks on citizens must cease, and of course investigations into these killings need to take place, and those responsible have to be brought to justice. It is now time for the Government of Bangladesh and democratic political parties together to engage in real dialogue for the country’s stability, democracy and economic development.  The European Union needs a Bangladesh where core universal human rights values are upheld. I have spoken already about social-economic rights: they have to be effectively protected; but of course where institutions respect the rule of law and fully ensure protection and safety of all citizens, priority must be placed on the promotion of tolerance and freedom of expression. Of course the Government of Bangladesh has a primary role in this perspective. We will continue to follow closely the situation and address our concerns at our regular dialogue with the Government of Bangladesh. We count in this on the support of you, the Members of the European Parliament.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as a member of the Delegation for Relations with South Asian countries, I am concerned about the climate of violence and the crimes committed in Bangladesh in recent months. They were, as it is known, assassinated representatives of several religious minorities - Hindus, Christians, Sufists, Buddhist monks, but also voices who expressed themselves in favor of secularism and religious pluralism. Those who defend freedom of expression have been murdered, attacked or threatened.  At the root of these crimes are extremists and radicals. I reiterate, therefore, the call that our Parliament already made in November 2015 to the Bangladeshi authorities to investigate these crimes independently and transparently, so that the culprits are identified and punished. The Dhaka authorities have already said that they will have zero tolerance for such atrocities, that they will improve security and that they have begun investigating some of the crimes committed. All these crimes need to be investigated and we need to see results. It is true, on the other hand, as the Minister said earlier, that in Bangalesh we have a special situation from a political point of view, given that, in the last elections, the opposition did not participate. That inflames the spirits. I remind you that the election mission we should have sent there was cancelled. I repeat, the boycott of this election is the source of much tension. Otherwise, we are all aware of the importance bangladesh has as a partner, including as a trading partner. We must consider this and ask our Dhaka partners for a significant improvement in the political and public climate in general.

name: Neena Gill
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, at least ten secular liberal activists have been murdered in cold blood since the start of 2016 alone. Daesh and al—Qaeda claimed many of these attacks, yet Bangladeshi authorities systematically refuse to acknowledge their presence, opting to use these atrocious killings for electoral purposes instead of protecting activists and vulnerable groups like LGBTI. The blatant failure of the Bangladesh international crimes tribunal to meet fair trial standards is fuelling more violence and extremism. We cannot afford to let Bangladesh descend into full—blown violence. We need to do the following: set up projects to counter violent extremism, with India as a bridgehead, which will help us gain a foothold and stop the country from becoming a regional stronghold for terrorism.  Second, the focus of all sides in Bangladesh – government and opposition – should be on genuine accountability for the crimes today and for those committed in 1972. Extrajudicial killings and arbitrary arrests have to stop.  I call upon the High Representative to take a lead in the UN on further steps implementing sanctions against those responsible for abusive policies on all sides and supporting an internationally—supervised judicial mechanism to ensure justice is served.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Bangladesh is a secular South Asian democracy and it is a political model that I strongly support. Its championing of religious tolerance, freedom of expression, women’s rights and education, are values that we would recognise and celebrate here in Europe. Such values are, however, threatened in Bangladesh right now – but not by the government, as some in this Chamber will seek to argue this evening, but by Islamist extremists. In 1971 Jamaat-e-Islami was rightly banned in Bangladesh, not only for the atrocities committed during the civil war, but also for its continued ideological campaign and terrorist activities against the secular state. Since the lifting of this ban in 1979, Jamaat continues along this path, with reported links to extremist jihadist groups.  I urge tonight the opposition party, the BMP, to end and denounce its links with them so that it can fulfil its proper secular democratic role in opposition. Only today was the body of a Hindu priest found near to his temple, the killing clearly motivated by his religion. He joins the many others that have been murdered in similar attacks: academics, gay rights activists, secular bloggers and journalists, as well as other individuals from religious minorities such as Christian, Buddhist or Ahmadi. Bangladesh, as one of the poorest countries in the world, does not enjoy the luxuries of established and properly trained and sophisticated security services as we do here in the West. As we in the European Union battle against our own extremist insurgencies, we must offer more support and sympathy to Bangladesh’s Government and less words of criticism and condemnation.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I want to focus today on the extreme violence against human rights defenders, LGBT activists, journalists, bloggers and religious minorities. Too many innocent victims have been killed and the debate today is long overdue. The pace of outrageous incidents still increases, and as recently as today, a Hindu priest was hacked to death. Our thoughts go out to the victims and their families and loved ones. It is widely believed that violent Islamist terror militia are behind these despicable acts, and clearly liberal voices and religious minorities are the targets. It is important that the government does all it can to prevent more horrendous bloodshed and, while we see that the authorities have launched new actions against terrorist groups, concerns remain that more could have been done to protect people and also that point blank killings of suspects are not a proportionate and adequate response – and not as just or as impactful as a fair trial to bring people to justice.  Given the long list of many people killed by Islamist militia since 2013, it is surprising, and actually quite disappointing, that EU leadership has not been stronger and that we have not been more vocal. You rightfully pointed out the important ties and the relations we have in the form of trade and development. We leveraged it before when factories collapsed and we should leverage it again, with stronger words offering assistance to tackle terrorism, but in an appropriate manner. So I wanted to ask you, Minister, why we have not seen more statements, or could you share more about the actual steps that EU leaders and the External Action Service and High Representative Mogherini have taken in reaching out to the Bangladeshi authorities? What will be the real consequences if there is a lack of adequate response to these outrageous murders? What is happening on the part of the EU Member States delegations on the ground in Bangladesh?

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President. Mr Minister, following the tragedy of Rana Plaza, which was High Representative, Mrs Ashton, and Commissioner De Gucht, they called on European companies to promote better standards of health and safety in factories in Bangladesh. They relied on the corporate social responsibility guidelines. More than a thousand people had died in a factory that is part of the value chain of European companies and you continued to call for the fulfilment of recommendations that depend on the will of companies: that is like putting the fox to take care of the hens.  Gentlemen of the Commission, can we continue to talk about corporate social responsibility when companies such as Benetton or Inditex refuse to compensate victims? We have to change the regulations. We urgently need a binding mechanism to ensure that this liability is formal and punishable by civil means and by criminal means. Such a mechanism is already under way at the UN, even though the European Union , its representative there – wanted to block the process. In October, this working group meets again and the European Union should be part of the change and not an obstacle, because we have a lot of responsibility for the fulfilment of human rights in Bangladesh.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I should say at this point that I speak in my capacity as chair of the Delegation for relations with countries with South Asia, which includes Bangladesh. As others have said, an overwhelming majority of Bangladeshis are extremely proud of the fact that they are able to live as a whole range of different faiths and communities, but we are seeing this gradual escalation from those claiming to be from Islamic State or from spin-offs of al—Qaeda attacking a range of people, as we have heard: from a shopkeeper to gay rights activists, and indeed the murder recently of Mahmuda Akter, the wife of an anti-terrorist police officer. It is certainly time for very strong signals from the government that society is not going to be divided. I think we should be pleased to see the statement from 100 000 clerics and their fatwa for peace, which will be fully published on 18 June 2016. But a strong civil society is absolutely essential, and to provide grassroots resilience and a sense of community rather than seeing – as we sometimes feel at the moment – that the government sees those grassroots as a problem. We really should be upholding the work of human rights defenders, such as the organisation ‘Odhikar’, and indeed press freedom. We are seeing far too many journalists going to jail. We also need to see effective policing and a judicial system where people really do feel that there is equality before the law. As others have said, we are seeing an extremely worrying situation there. We really need to be supporting the government in its efforts, but making sure but that it also acts in the best interests of all Bangladeshis.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are witnessing an extremely worrying escalation in Bangladesh. The question arises as to why, because a country that has always distinguished itself by syncretism, by the tolerance of the Muslim majority, at the moment sees this resurgence. The reason is also, and above all, in poverty. We are well aware of the way in which European multinationals exploit workers in Bangladesh, especially as regards rice in agriculture, and textiles even more. This somehow prepares and facilitates the work of Daesh, Al Qaeda, those extremist groups that are increasingly penetrating this civil society in Bangladesh, which was once stronger and more immune to this risk, and are leading it to radicalisation. As Europe, we must push for reforms in the judicial field, on the functioning of the police, and even more so we must demand progress on democracy and freedom of the press. But first we have to deal with our own actions. The economic and social stability of the country is the fundamental pillar for preventing radicalisation and terrorism. Let us not forget this and demand consistent action on the part of our multinationals.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as Rana Plaza is known, it collapsed, killing 1100 people and injuring more than 2500. Bangladesh is the second largest exporter of clothing in the world, with 60% of its production being exported here to the European Union.  This disaster was a terrible draw to pay attention to the need for concrete action with regard to improving the safety of buildings, also to the general working conditions not only of this country, but also of other suppliers of the Union. Three years after the signing of the Sustainability Pact we consider some commitments made by the Government of Bangladesh to be positive. However, much more needs to be done in our opinion.  For example, the government must comply with ILO Convention 87, it must extend the application of the entire Labour Law to industrial free zones for export and must also, of course, continue with the fight against corruption and enforcement of compliance with labour standards.  And I end up, Mr President, hoping that this Pact, resulting from the commitment and goodwill of many international, European, independent countries and bangladeshi companies, will be an example for improving working conditions in other countries and for more effective and also coordinated international community action.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The situation in Bangladesh is very worrying and the risk of civil war can no longer be ruled out. Two camps have been irreconcilable for years, and this has led to the paralysis of democratic institutions, violence is constantly on the increase, and the IS terrorists are taking advantage of this situation. In such circumstances, the work of human rights defenders is essential, and it is unfortunately systematically restricted. Organisations such as ODHIKAR are intimidated, their livelihoods threatened, and often cruel violence is used, as on Sunday, when a Christian was hacked to death. The same thing happened in April with an LGBT activist from the Boys of Bangladesh. It is still possible to stop this diabolical cycle. Europe can play an important role in this. Europe's voice is also being heard in Bangladesh, so we are trying to avert that.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Madam High Representative, there is reason to be concerned about Bangladesh: a government that is so repressive towards the media, civil society, human rights protectors and opposition, and on the other hand, the outbreak of religiously inspired violence that shows that a fundamentalist movement within Islam is trying to gain a foothold. Many feel that the government is not doing enough to punish violence and stop extremism. If Bangladesh slips further and seeks an answer in religious rhetoric, it could have dramatic consequences.  I agree with the emphasis and priorities you are setting. The EU has levers. We are the largest trading partner and the main customer of textiles thanks to intensive cooperation. Bangladesh can use the EU's 'Everything But Arms' initiative, which allows it to export to the EU without a tariff on imports. This must not be taken for granted and unconditional. In the aftermath of the Rana Plaza textile factory disaster, we have proven that we can do business. Use the levers consistently to support a healthy democratic culture and political stability.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As a member of the South Asia delegation, I share the concerns about the humanitarian situation in Bangladesh. Political life is marked by the permanent conflict between the Awami League and the BNP. The rift, such as the rivalry between Sheikh Hasina and Khaleda Zia, seems unbridgeable. In addition, many murders appear to be the result of radical fanatics. The brutal struggle against religious minorities, against secular bloggers, against foreigners is constantly taking on new dimensions. The justice system, which was supposed to deal with the atrocities of recent years, is so politicized that serious wrong decisions keep coming. A situation of the rule of law, public debate and freedom of the press must finally arise again. Let us use our influence to ensure that the parties finally come to the table again. For the sake of the people, we must not give up this hope.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, the human rights situation in Bangladesh is indeed a worrying situation and NGO reports show us how alarming it is. While the authorities have a responsibility to uphold fundamental and human rights, we also have a responsibility to ensure that our European companies respect decent work and respect for human rights, when they are order-in-command in these countries.  We were all outraged after the Rana Plaza, yes, but what have we done to make a difference? Not much: no legislative initiatives either by the Commission or on the part of the Council that would guarantee the respect of human rights by these companies.  There are also no regulatory initiatives in relation to the repair that should be done by companies. No parliamentary initiatives on the obligation of responsibility of these companies. We talk a lot about political crimes, and that is important; I think we need to put economic crimes on the agenda and now we have the opportunity to decide.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – Suppose you were currently a Christian in Bangladesh or part of another minority religious group in the country, you would increasingly fear for your life, as attacks by extremist Muslims on Christians and other religious minority groups have been increasing in Bangladesh in recent months. The constitutionally guaranteed religious freedom thus leads to religious persecution. A Christian spokesman in Bangladesh whom I spoke to today spoke clearly. I quote: "Officially, there is room for Christians to profess their faith. But in practice there is increasing persecution and discrimination and minority rights are not respected. The media also play a role and christians regularly put themselves in a bad light." End quote. And passant denies the government's obvious presence and activities of Salafist terrorist organizations such as Al Qaeda and IS on its own territory. Last year, the EU spent €800,000 on human rights projects in Bangladesh. My question is: did some of the money also benefit the precarious position of religious minorities? Perhaps the Council, in the person of Minister Koenders, can clarify this.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am seriously concerned by the unprecedented violence against members of religious and ethnic minorities, civil society activists, journalists and bloggers that has swept Bangladesh recently. There seems to be no clear end to the tragic news. These brutal attacks have not only targeted anyone opposing mainstream views, but have seriously infringed freedom of expression in the country. We have to press on the Bangladeshi Government to properly investigate these crimes. Citizens need to be assured that their freedoms are respected, impunity is ended and the rule of law is re-established, otherwise a carte blanche for radical behaviour and unpunished violence will endanger the stability of Bangladesh, with potential implications for the entire region of South-East Asia.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Taslima Nasreen, Sakharov Prize 1994, still days here in the European Parliament, with other Sakharov laureates, denounced the spiral of radicalisation and violence that plagues his country, which cannot return by death threats.  Brutal murders are repeated without anyone being safe. Members of religious, sexual, religious and ethnic minorities, bloggers, academics, journalists, opposition members and foreign citizens are eliminated without investigations being conducted to identify the perpetrators of such heinous crimes.  On the other hand, kidnappings, arbitrary arrests and assassinations by security forces are multiplying. We have established dialogue with Bangladesh through a cooperation agreement. After the Rana Plaza tragedy, it is unacceptable for human rights to be relegated to the background.  European authorities must make it clear to the Bangladeshi government that it has no true support for its persistent denial that terrorist groups such as Daesh and al-Qaeda are not active in the country, while blaming the opposition and local activist groups for the violence.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Mr President, tragically for the people of Bangladesh, recent barbaric murders remind us of the country’s lengthy history of political instability and wanton violence.  While we must do our utmost not to meddle in the affairs of sovereign nations, we have a responsibility to condemn violence while encouraging and fostering political dialogue. To this end, the only viable way for Bangladesh to get itself back on track is for the country’s leading political parties to show real leadership to get the country out of this impasse. One cannot ignore the toxic effect of the ruling coalition’s blatant electoral manoeuvring in the run up to the previous elections. It created a climate of great institutional mistrust and has only added fuel to the fire of violence that we are witnessing now.  On the other hand, the opposition would do well to distance itself from extremist groups, developing real policies for their countries instead. Ultimately, the only way to guarantee a fresh start for Bangladesh and its people is for new elections to be called under a caretaker government as soon as possible.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Bangladesh describes all the symptoms of the poor state of health of freedoms and points to the risks of the country's disintegration. The repression and killing of many activists testifies to the seriousness of the moment, and I believe that we absolutely cannot turn our heads anywhere else. The government does too little, and this risks – and we must stress this – objectively risking being a cover for the criminal actions of extremist groups. It would be appropriate for the European Union, over and above words, to exert all the necessary pressure for the Bangladeshi authorities to act more decisively. We must use all the instruments at our disposal. I would like to draw attention here to the position expressed by the European Parliament last November and call for everything to be done to put an end to violence and intimidation of human rights defenders and for the issue of rights to be put at the centre, including in Bangladesh.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: It is true that socio-economic rights are also part of human rights. That's what I wanted to focus on. It is now three years after the Rana Plaza disaster and we really have to say that not much has changed, when there would be so much profit to be made if we allowed trade unions to make improvements themselves. But the government is not cooperating. Bangladesh's labour laws have high legal thresholds which make it easy for employers to intimidate, fire and even abuse – we know about cases.  In addition, export production zones are not covered by existing labour law. That should change, because guaranteeing a decent life for men and women who make our clothes should be worth something to us. Trade unions are an important key to this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, as the debate has shown, the situation in Bangladesh is indeed explosive. There is a constant violation of human rights. Christian populations and other religious minorities are being persecuted. At the same time, a dangerous Islamist movement is developing, attacking journalists and bloggers. On a social level – we have said this before – there is a constant violation of labour rights, especially in factories, and from then on the safety rules are not respected either. It is a given that Bangladesh is an important partner of the European Union, as it exports mainly textile products to Europe. It is therefore possible for the European Union to exert influence, pressure, in order to respect human rights, the rule of law, respect for transparency and democracy as a whole.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in my speech, I would like to address the dangerous situation in which a significant number of Bangladeshi garment workers are located. Almost 20 million people depend on clothing production. The country operates more than 5,400 supply factories, employing nearly 3.6 million workers. But Bangladeshi workers are among the lowest paid in the world, and the minimum wage will not even cover their basic needs. The low cost of human labour, together with the almost unexerciable law, offers multinational supranational companies substantial impunity and the ideal opportunity to shift all imaginable risks to the workers themselves. Add to this a dangerous work environment that often either catches fire or completely down to a defenseless employee. I hope that the High Representative does not ignore this issue in her negotiations with the Bangladeshi side and is in support of a stronger role for trade unions in this area and an end to the exploitation of workers.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Bangladesh seems to be on a course departing from democracy and leaning towards insecurity. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina seems to be determined to destroy the position of the Bangladesh National Party before the next election in 2018. This continues an already authoritarian course of eliminating any opposition, via banning political parties and changing laws that normally guarantee the integrity of elections. Also five different Islamist extremist attacks in the past year have been targeting minorities, activists and intellectuals. No one has been punished for any of these crimes; instead Hasina blames the BNP for the attacks, giving justification for further persecuting and discrediting them in the name of national security.  On an issue where all other powers, China, India and the United States, have failed to raise any alarm, the EU needs to put pressure on the Bangladeshi Government to respect the fundamental principles of democracy, those of free and fair elections, the right to political opposition and the responsibility of a government to protect its citizens from violence.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start also by joining with the Members who have expressed their outrage at the killing of the Hindu priest, who was hacked to death. On behalf of the Council, I would like to offer my condolences to the families and to the next of kin. Obviously for us it is also extremely important that those who are responsible for this are brought to justice. Let me say a few words about the input that you have brought to the debate tonight. I think we are all quite conscious of the fact that Bangladesh is an enormously complex and extremely vulnerable country; in terms of environmental issues it is the most vulnerable country in the world. It is the most densely populated country in the world, and it is a country that has different aspects.  On the one hand, it has made some progress in reaching the sustainable development goals, which is actually amazing. If you look at the rise of civil society in Bangladesh we have seen that, through very important progress made through civil society in cooperation with the government, enrolment in primary education is now close to 100%. At the same time, we see a reduction in poverty, and maternal mortality has declined by 40% in nine years. That is the positive news. But at the same time, the Council joins you today in looking at some of the very negative developments that we have seen.  First of all, I think the shrinking space for the democratic and secular opposition comes at a par with all the issues that you have mentioned – the multiplication of terrorist attacks, targeting bloggers, religious minorities – including Christians, I would say – foreigners and law enforcement officers. The most brutal murders included a student, a professor, two LGTBI activists, a policeman and a security guard, a Hindu tailor, the wife of a police officer, a Christian grocer and a Buddhist monk.  We are talking about a rise in these kinds of very violent human rights violations, and we see at the same time a limiting of political space for political opposition, as well as for civil society. It obviously worries the Council, as it does you, and I want to say that beyond all kinds of declarations we give out regularly – and I can give you most of the statements that we have given out in the last couple of months – it is not enough to make statements. All these statements refer to the facts that you have been putting forward, including the violence and the need for justice. It is also important that we work on countering, first of all, the issues that are behind this, including projects to counter violent extremism and to assist in deradicalisation. We will continue, and I will come back to that in a second, this important element in our human rights instruments. We are very worried about the rise of that. It is also very important for the Government of Bangladesh to acknowledge the risks of this radicalism, including possibly the risks posed by ISIS. Therefore, and this was also in answer to some of the questions, the dialogue in the context of the United Nations that some of you have mentioned is extremely important. It is also important that our delegations reach out not only through projects in these areas, but also in the bilateral meeting at the ASEM Summit, to the Government of Bangladesh on these very disturbing developments.  When we talk about human rights, we should talk about the fact that the human rights situation is steadily deteriorating, mainly at the expense of the most vulnerable segments of the population of Bangladesh. Your appeal should be communicated; the response by law enforcement agencies seems at best too slow and inadequate, for example in the most important and iconic cases, the horrible rape and assassination of a 19-year-old female student in the military cantonment of Comilla, which still remains unexplained.  I wanted to mention, in the context of this complex situation in Bangladesh, the Sustainability Compact, especially in Bangladesh, but also in other countries. We have to talk about human rights in the broader sense of the word, including the social-economic rights and the role of unions and so on and so forth. Following the Rana Plaza collapse where everybody was extremely horrified – and this was already more than three years ago – over 1 100 people were killed and thousands injured. The Sustainability Compact was agreed between the government and the European Union, the United States and the ILO, with commitments on three interlinked pillars in the ready-made garment industry. I would like to support all of you who have said that this is not only a compact that should remain on paper, but needs operationalisation and implementation, as well as the responsiblisation of the business sector in order to ensure that it actually works.  It requires some elements. First, respect for labour rights, in particular freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining; I think that includes the important role of the unions. Second, the structural integrity of factory buildings and occupational safety and health; I think we should also support where we can – bilaterally but also in the context of the European Union – the Government of Bangladesh and others in ensuring this. Then, of course, responsible business conduct is absolutely important. The donors fund the ready-made garment industry programme in the context of remediation measures. That goes up to USD 200 million, so it is not small fry, so to speak. Canada has recently also joined as a partner. We recognise the progress made by Bangladesh, but of course, and I think that was correctly mentioned, the need is there for the government to facilitate trade unions’ registration, to upgrade the directorate of labour with additional staff and resources, and to ensure that the legal framework is also applicable in the export processing zones, protecting freedom of association and collective bargaining.  I think these are important points. What do we have as instruments? First of all, we have the dialogue with the Government of Bangladesh, and I think it should focus especially on these areas. Continuing progress in the SDGs, at the same time making it apparent that we are worried about a deterioration in the political space and the degradation of the security situation. We must also see where we can assist, because this is a major issue. It is the responsibility of all actors, including the government first and foremost, but also other actors – terrorist groups, responsible and irresponsible political parties – to play their role in ensuring that this political degradation does not continue.
