Issa wasal iż-żmien li nitgħallmu mil-lezzjonijiet u l-iżbalji tal-passat u li nirrikonoxxu li huma l-qrati li huma l-istituzzjonijiet l-aktar adattati biex iwettqu investigazzjonijiet dwar pro大eduri kriminali. It-tortura m'għandhiex tkun l-arma tagħna, i tirrappreżentax il-valuri u l-prin大ipji tagħna, i tirrappreżentax flower-Ewropa li nemmen fiha jien.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. A US Senate report revealed that the CIA used methods of brutally interrogating and torturing people on European soil after the September 11 attacks. European governments must realise that this is not just a disgrace, but a serious violation of fundamental rights and European values. New evidence is still coming to the day. We visited Romania with the LIBE Committee delegation last autumn, but the authorities refused to allow us to enter the building of the alleged detention.  It was different before in Lithuania. It is precisely the European Parliament's report on this mission that has made a strong contribution to the disclosure of certain secrets. Crucially, as mentioned above, the publication of the US Senate report was crucial. It not only revealed the scale of the crimes, but also that torture is ineffective in the fight against terrorism.  Under international law, there can be no excuse for such acts. And we need to show that we are serious in order to judge those responsible. It was the most systematic violation of human rights and humanitarian law since The Second World War on European soil. Individual European governments have not completed detailed investigations into alleged involvement, let alone taking action against those responsible or at least taking moral responsibility.  It's disappointing that only the Hollywood film industry has managed to get to the classified information from the Senate torture report. While civil society, NGOs and even supporters of detainees have not achieved this. Dozens of people remain in Guantanamo, with no charges or legal proceedings.  Investigations in individual Member States must continue in order to determine the degree of involvement. These violations will never go away, and no carpet is big enough to sweep them under it.  It is our shared responsibility to close this extremely shameful chapter in our European history and to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again.  I call on my colleagues to strongly support the resolution in tomorrow's vote.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A civilised man cannot behave differently, he must condemn torture, he must condemn the imprisonment of people without judgment, the use of extraordinary measures. However, I would like to say frankly that I have some doubts about how this matter is to be present in the European Parliament. Firstly, as the Minister representing the Presidency said, the United States has closed a programme that could be harshly criticised and which is likely to be the subject of further research. Commissioner Jurova says that at that time there was no European Union instrumentation, there were no legal agreements, there were no obligations. The Presidency reminds me, and I also want to remind you, that the issue of national security is in the area of accountability of the Member States, and that is where the procedures for establishing these facts should take place. This is a question of sovereign decisions by these countries.  The European Parliament has every right to appeal to the public, to mobilise public opinion, but does it have the right to conduct investigations? I think that, on the basis of the Treaties, this can be the case for the European institutions themselves, not the Member States. So there is a need for some rationality in action.  No one can pass indifferently to the facts of the use of uncivilized methods, against torture. However, there are no terrorists in this discussion. That is what I would like to ask: why are there no terrorists in this discussion? They are the ones who want to destroy our civilization. It is clear that terrorism cannot be fought by abusing human rights by striking human rights, but human rights cannot be interpreted in such a way that the free world is paralyzed in the fight against terrorism.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I was a member of the committee of inquiry into the CIA renditions programme and the Flight Stats about 10 years ago now. You might ask why we are still discussing this after 10 years. Why are we still repeating the same statements? But I can tell you that I will never tire of this until justice is done.  We can all talk about whether the legal framework was in place at the time or whether it is a matter of national sovereignty, but actually I get the feeling that the Council and the Member States are hiding behind legalistic arguments. If it is true, as Minister Koenders says, that national security is a purely national matter then I would like to understand why it was that the Member State governments back in, I believe, October 2001 collectively decided to allow CIA flights in European airspace.  They collectively decided that, but now they are hiding behind the argument that it is a national matter. When it is about accountability and about responsibility, all of a sudden it is a national matter. No, I think that if the governments at the time had the courage to take that decision collectively, then they should now be accountable and responsible collectively as well, and not hide behind these arguments.  Then you say, Minister Koenders, but we have the judiciary and we have a solid judicial framework. Well, I actually observed that Member State governments of different colours (irrespective of the colour, I might say) have gone out of their way to frustrate judicial investigations and prosecutions. They have tried everything in their power to stop those processes.  You mentioned the word ‘shame’. I very much agree with you. It is an absolute shame that 10 years after the first report in the European Parliament we are still talking about this and, as Dick Marty said at the time, it is like talking to a rubber wall. It is as if we are not heard. But we will keep discussing this until justice is done. No impunity in the European Union, because that, Minister Koenders, that is shameful.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Parliament has indeed been working on allegations of detention, torture, imprisonment and therefore illegal cia activities in the European Union for ten years. At every meeting in this Chamber, certain groups, under pressure from the governments concerned, seek to prevent the continuation of our work, and they continue. In this case, the violations of these fundamental rights are serious and on behalf of a foreign power. They are proven and denounced, including by the U.S. Senate. Member States and the Council cannot hide behind the treaties. Shame is not enough, Minister. Member States must carry out investigations. We want the truth, because it is the only way to prevent such events from happening again, so that victims can finally have the right to justice. There's no justification for torture, nothing! Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to regret that, contrary to president Obama's promises, the Guantanamo prison is still not closed and that men are languishing there, outside of all legality.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, in December 2014, the US Senate published a report on the CIA's use of torture. This report confirms suspicions about the involvement of several Member States in illegal detention programmes and the fact that the use of torture was tolerated on European soil from 2001 to 2006.  Those responsible for these acts must be tried. The inaction of the Member States and the European institutions in this regard is unacceptable. We cannot tolerate impunity in the face of such human rights violations. Investigations must continue.  That political groups in this House call for a halt to the work of the European Parliament on these multiple and terrible violations of human rights and to oppose the fact that all the light is shed on these illegal practices and the complicity of some Member States is a disgrace. The European institutions must ensure that the opacity and difficulties that States face in these investigations are removed. Until the whole truth is established, it is our responsibility to ensure that investigations continue. The credibility of our institutions, particularly that of the European Parliament, has so far saved the honour of the European Union. I hope, ladies and gentlemen, that you will be able to keep him on track.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear about this, someone has already said it: it is a real shame, it is a shame to admit that, fifteen years after a resolution was adopted in this Parliament a year and a half ago, a leaf has not yet been moved. No investigation has been opened. Member States continue to hide behind the regulatory framework or even behind state secrecy. Such an attitude is in no way acceptable, because at a time when we accept that within our Member States – it has happened in Romania, it has happened in Poland, it has happened in Lithuania, and it has been established in the US Senate report – acts of torture, inhuman and degrading treatment, we are accepting that it can happen to each of us. So I think it's really time to raise your voice and demand that the culprits pay, because if you go on like this, you're really not going anywhere.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, it is easy to draw the conclusion from the revelations about the horrific torture of the CIA in Member States of the European Union, in Guantánamo and in the United States. The United States, the European Union and its governments, which are responsible, have been left and left undisturbed. The committees set up were literally to wash away the imperialists' responsibilities.  It goes a long way to projecting the European Union as a defender of human rights, at the same time as calling for strengthening so-called counter-terrorism cooperation with the United States, in the name of which you are carrying out imperialist wars and torture. Repressive mechanisms of the United States, the European Union, NATO and agencies such as the C.I.A., the Euro army, the CFSP, Europol, the new border guard-coast guard are working closely together to hit the popular movement to suppress refugees and migrants. They compete in state and industrial espionage for the profits of their monopolies. They themselves financed the repulsive action of mechanisms such as the Islamic State. Peoples can disable the reactionary mechanisms that defend capitalist barbarism by taking power and ownership of the wealth they produce themselves.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, torture cannot be justified – under no conditions at all. Therefore, I also condemn the practices of interrogation techniques as they were reported by the US Senate.  The United States play a crucial role in fighting terrorism around the world, including here in Europe. Our cooperation on counter-terrorism needs to be preserved for the shared benefits of citizens on both sides of the Atlantic, and in full respect of all fundamental freedoms. I believe we need a continued political dialogue between the Transatlantic partners on security and counterterrorism issues, including on the protection of civil and human rights, in order to combat terrorism effectively. In times of global instability, the Transatlantic relationship is of unique importance and of strategic nature. Having the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA in mind, I would like to underline what I consider being one of the key messages of the US—EU joint statement of 15 June 2009 on the closure of Guantanamo Bay and future counter—terrorism cooperation: joint efforts to combat terrorism must comply with international law, in particular with human rights like the rights to human treatment free trial and the freedom from torture. There can be no exception at all.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, European Court of Human Rights judgments passed in the cases of Al-Nashiri and Abu Zubaydah versus Poland, pending respectively versus Romania and Lithuania, and Nasr and Ghali versus Italy plus El-Masri versus fYROM, and judicial decisions in the UK in favour of victims of torture all prove that European governments lied to this Parliament to callously cover up active complicity with the CIA extraordinary renditions torture programme. Worse, that cooperation was paid for with large sums of money, as the US Senate Intelligence Committee of December 2015 reveals. Even worse, impunity has been granted by EU states to those responsible for these crimes. In Italy, for instance, state secrecy was used to block the judiciary and, as a result, innocent, low—level officers were convicted, while top culprits are protected. Italy now wants to put in jail the Portuguese American, Sabrina de Sousa, a former CIA officer who was tried in absentia and never given the chance to prove her denial of any involvement. Even the victim of torture and kidnapping in that case, Mr Abu Omar, the imam of Milan, has stated that she is only a scapegoat. In my country, Portugal, all cover up efforts were made to protect Mr Durão Barroso who, as Prime Minister, abetted the CIA renditions programme, as I reported in detail to the General Public Prosecutor. The case was closed to spare him, and in the meantime he was made President of the European Commission. How can our governments be credible in the eyes of citizens to effectively fight terrorism if they are complicit in covering up these awful crimes? I will never give up looking for accountability in this case.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Amnesty International confirmed that Shannon Airport in Ireland had been used by the CIA and the US military for extraordinary rendition flights. Torture techniques used by the CIA and the Bush administration were due to the European Court ruling which concluded that the 14 Irishmen, known as the Hooded Men, suffered inhumane and degrading treatment, but not torture. So that gave the Bush administration ‘cover’ to use the five torture techniques. But the British Government told lies to the European Court and the British Secretary of State has now been compelled to give further evidence.  The 14 Irishmen underwent horrific interrogations from which they never recovered. Hundreds more like them have been tortured by the CIA. The rapporteur is right. It was torture. It breached international law and such criminal behaviour must be exposed and challenged, at the very least to prevent other Member States from torturing and – as was the case in Ireland – governments being involved in the murder of people.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European It has been almost 10 years since the European Parliament dealt with the CIA's operation to illegally and secretly transport and imprison prisoners in EU countries. The evidence is known, but the confession is yet to come. All documents contain the adjective "alleged." The Member States concerned do not cooperate in order to clarify the matter. The name of the person responsible under each document is CIA. But the CIA is not a country. Don't we dare say the responsibility of the supreme leaders of the United States? Are we afraid of the "big brother"'s disdenation? It is high time that the facts, the truth, were clearly and unequivocally recorded, and then we expect that there will be consequences.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: This is not the first time that we have had this item on the agenda. On several occasions we have expressed our disgust at the cia's torture practices. Horrendous degrading practices such as waterboarding, sleep denial or the rectal insertion of food have no place in a rule of law in the 21st century. Terrorism must be combated without reducing ourselves to terror.  I agree with colleagues who say that we still do not have all the information on what happened. I also agree with those colleagues that this is regrettable and I would very much like to wave a magic wand here from the European Parliament and get all the information out of the table. Unfortunately, that's not how it works in practice. We must therefore also be realistic and dare to look at our own competences, and this is also confirmed by the actually disappointing results we have seen over the last two years from the committee we have set up here in Parliament. This story must be followed up further in national parliaments, national courtrooms and European courtrooms.  I have one more question for colleagues in the Liberal Group. There have just been big words about the laxity of institutions and the laxity of Member States. We have a resolution here tomorrow which regrets that only one mission has been organised from the European Parliament during the last mandate. Then I ask myself: how can it be that of all 70 Members of the Liberal Group, no one was prepared to bother to actually participate in that mission?

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have been discussing this for several years. The secrecy that surrounded this program at first led to the only very slowly it was possible to make clear what really happened. Only very slowly responsibilities have been cleared and, let us be clear, everything is not yet cleared. It is therefore up to us to continue to give the necessary impulses, respecting the principle of subsidiarity where it must be respected and the separation between the judiciary and political power. On the other hand, this theme cannot serve a moral crusade, a mere instrument for ideological propaganda. You can't ignore our interlocutor across the Atlantic either.  And it is not only the clearance of truth and responsibilities that moves us. We are also willing to prevent such ostentatious violations of fundamental rights from being repeated in the future. We believe that the fundamental rights of citizens are at the heart of the values of the European Union and that their protection is a requirement, even in the face of abuses by states.  This is therefore a mission that we must pursue in respect for the past which is not yet fully informed and in the name of a future that we want better and more respectful of the rights and dignity of the human person.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, human rights, fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity are common values of democracy, of the rule of law, which must be reflected in all areas of the European Union's internal and foreign policy. The fight against terrorism also requires respect for human dignity, privacy and all that fundamental human rights mean. The European Union must be the guarantor of respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, but at the same time also of the security of citizens. Strengthening transatlantic relations in the fight against terrorism must gain new valences for the benefit of all, based on common interests and values. However, we consider that the excessive politicisation of the subject of the existence of secret prisons, as well as the possible involvement by the CIA of some countries in the illegal transport and detention of prisoners, is likely to affect precisely the process started in some Member States of finding out the truth and holding the culprits accountable. It is our duty to allow Member States to complete their own judicial investigations and not to interfere in the judicial processes that have begun, thus respecting the principle of impartiality and independence of justice, convinced that, if there have been violations of the law, light will be made clear. It is important that, from the height of the European Parliament, we give expression to a strong and firm belief that it is absolutely necessary to have clear evidence before making nominations and engaging in sterile debates, which do not end with concrete results.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, we condemn the practices of torture by the CIA at Guantánamo and other hells. The CIA's secret detention system has led to massive human rights violations and horrific torture. The CIA's secret detentions included inhuman and degrading treatment, torture, kidnapping and detention without trial. The use of torture is not permitted and of course cannot be justified and legitimised for any reason, nor of course for the alleged disclosure of information in order to combat terrorism. Of course, impunity for the tactics followed by the C.I.A. allows the violation of human rights to continue. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to condemn any form of human rights violations carried out by the CIA and to ensure that it carries out further investigations into its Member States which, according to the report, were complicit in the CIA's programme of secret services and extraordinary surrenders.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, let us remember that the USA is officially our ally, despite the fact that its President’s recent interventions in the UK made me question his personal goodwill. Its security services are not under EU control; nor, thankfully, are the UK intelligence services – undoubtedly the best in the world, and we are very grateful for what they do.  Yes, intelligence services should interrogate as humanely as possible; absolutely they should. But their work must not be hampered by politicians and their political principles to the degree where we are put in danger. The human rights of terrorists must never be allowed to trump the right to freedom and safety of innocent citizens. Unfortunately you cannot break a terrorist down by putting them on the naughty step.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, torture and other forms of inhuman treatment must not be acceptable as a method in the fight against terrorism. I believe that from this place we would have to send a clear message that we condemn all intelligence activities and domestic and partner services where people are tortured on European soil. I am aware that certain intelligence circles consider this practice very effective in gathering information that could help prevent more attacks, as well as that some citizens will find it ok to retaliate in the same or similar measure due to the increasingly frequent attacks and under the impression of horrific images from the scene. There will be more and more pressure to, at least until the danger passes, to renounce humanity and our Christian values. If we agree to that, we won't be any different from the ones we're fighting.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, even though, as I said before, the matter falls under national competence, the Commission has been following this issue closely and encouraged Member States to ensure, within the remit of their competences, that such a situation does not arise again.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this interesting exchange of views. I think first of all we have all agreed, without any exception, that human rights and the rule of law and the fight against terror is something that can never be put in a relationship at the cost of one giving up the rights of people for the other. I think that is important. It is important to note that because we are still today fighting terror and terrorism and therefore I think all the research, the investigations, the reports that have been made were extremely important to enlighten us about what happened at the time. I have said also in the first part of my declaration what the view of the Council is, ranging from the way we look at the policies of President Obama to correcting what has happened before, including the so-called enhanced interrogation techniques, secret detention and the like. Secondly, I have mentioned also the fact that we have a certain competence. While I do respect, certainly, the sharp oppositions being put against the Council tonight, I think by Ms in ‘t Veld, I do not understand that now all at once the Council collectively is responsible for this.  I have told you why I think it is a shame what happened. I think it has to be investigated. I think we have a legal framework. I think there has never been any Council decision being made, as you said, that we would cooperate with the United States on CIA rendition flights, that is simply not true and I would like to see where that has been decided. The only declaration that has been made was after 9/11 to cooperate, as all of us did, with the United States in the fight against terror. If you can show me where you see that the Council collectively is responsible for agreeing on rendition flights, I would be very interested to hear that because that sheds a new light on these events. I would like to be informed on this because you mentioned this in this debate.  I fail to see that point and I am disappointed by it as well, since I have said here, on behalf of the Council, how important I think it is that we learn from what has happened. I understand the quest for accountability. I think that accountability has to be done. I tell you here that we cannot change the competences of the European Union and its institutions; maybe some of the political parties would like to have that, but I cannot change that. It is very easy to blame here the Council in its entirety, you know that it is unjust, it is unfair and I would have liked that this debate would have led to another conclusion, namely that accountability goes where it is supposed to be not simply because there is somebody in front of you. Secondly, that accountability goes through a strong legal system we have in Europe. Thirdly, that we clearly make as a Council together, in its commonality, any discussion we have as the Council that these kinds of human rights violations cannot be accepted, and we will continue to fight for human rights in the context of the necessary fight against terrorism and that we applaud the decisions taken by President Obama.  I hope maybe that can enlighten, nevertheless at the late evening, a little bit this debate, that it does not go on moral high ground or finger pointing but in something that really brings us further in the fight for accountability on these events that have taken place.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Wednesday 8 June 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. The fight against terrorism cannot become a source of impunity and mask the crimes of those who do not respect the rule of law, human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms. Despite the unanimous condemnation of the CIA's secret interrogation and detention programme, in which abductions, torture, inhuman and degrading treatment, arbitrary and illegal detentions took place, many shadows remain over the involvement and complicity of the authorities of certain Member States. In some countries investigations are continuing, in others they are stopping, elsewhere they are not even being launched. We have seen, in fact, that the study by the ad hoc committee of the American Senate has not led to any kind of assumption of responsibility on the part of the UNITED States, while in Europe, despite the recognition of violations of fundamental rights and cases of torture, much remains to be done with the investigations and the handing over of those responsible to justice. Invoking the concept of 'national security' to hide abuses and responsibilities is an intolerable squeeze on transparency, democratic control and fundamental rights.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I believe that the text of the resolution on the actions taken following the European Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate's report on the use of torture by the CIA brings serious allegations against some Member States, without providing the necessary evidence but relying solely on a patchwork of newspaper headlines, allegations from the NGO area and misinterpretations. The report of the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee and the report of the Romanian Senate Committee on the presence of CIA detention centers do not indicate any evidence demonstrating the use of torture on CIA prisoners in secret locations on Romanian territory.  Moreover, the text of the resolution intervenes in ongoing national judicial investigations, which have been launched precisely to shed light on this endless story and undermines the problems of national security and sovereignty by asking the European Commission to present a 'White Book' which 'defines what does not fall within the scope of the concept of national security'. This request violates national competences and has the potential to turn into a huge security breach in the future. Thus, the text of this resolution does not reflect the needs and interests of Europeans, but those of Russia.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Bogdan Zdrojewski, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the capacity of european security and defence policy to operate in space (2015/2276(INI) (A8-0151/201 (6) and the Commission statement on the placing on the market of comic industry products (2016/2731(RSP)) and the Commission statement on a European industrial policy on space (2016/2730(RSP)).

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let me start by explaining that I took the initiative to work on this report for five main reasons. Firstly, in order to draw attention to the importance of the development of the space industry for the whole of Europe. Secondly, with a call for long-term financial guarantees. Thirdly, with an attempt to promote what has already been done, what has already been done, and I would remind you that this is the only civilian system in the world, not a military system, as in the case of Russia, China or the United States. Fourthly, it is also an initiative to build a number of different mechanisms to support tasks for Galileo and Copernicus in the area of security in general. I would like to emphasise – security in general, not military tasks. Fifthly, I was very keen to emphasise the importance of systems for virtually all economic areas. There is agriculture, and infrastructure, and connectivity, and energy, but of course also educational tasks or science tasks.  What is important, of course, is the recommendations themselves. I will not present the report because it has been sent to you. On the other hand, my recommendations stem primarily from the conviction that the development and financing of space industry and technologies is one of the most important guarantors of Europe's economic success, as well as the improvement of the quality of services and the building of effective security systems – as I mentioned earlier – as well as the strengthening of this element, which President Juncker often speaks of– a creative, initiativeal, strong Europe.  What is important in these systems is also to ensure that the most important, most significant threats that exist at present are controlled. They are very different – they are both climate threats, that is, those that are associated with natural disasters, and terrorist ones, that is, man-made with complete premeditation, as well as special events and failures, for example in energy areas. It is also important that space systems and technology provide an opportunity to react quickly to completely new phenomena, such as the current difficulty of dealing with drones, which are commonly used by individuals, by individuals, and which pose serious risks, for example in air traffic, as well as terrorist threats. At the end of this preliminary speech, I would like to thank Mr Marinescu, who prepared, on behalf of the ITRE Committee, an assistive opinion in which he drew attention to elements relating primarily to the economy. I would also like to thank those colleagues who have tabled a total of more than two hundred different amendments, which in fact improve the report itself and draw attention to a number of other elements which, because of its limited scope, could not be included in the original version. Finally, I would like to say that the debate on this report was a great barometer of our condition, of thinking about the future today, that is, at a time when, in short, it is not too late.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur for opinion Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that 2016 is a very important year for European space policy. There are two extremely important documents and events: the Council on 'common security and defence policy and the involvement of space technology in this policy', as well as the strategy that you will present in the autumn for space policy. I hope that these two documents will solve the future of space policy, the future of the current Galileo and Copernicus programmes, which need modernisation. I would just like to refer to governance. I hope that you will be able to shape the governance of these programmes and bring the European agencies together with the Commission and industry, and at the same time I would like to make you a proposal. We need research and development, and I believe that a joint venture – a joint undertaking – in this direction would be beneficial for Europe.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to thank you for the opportunity to discuss the future of the European Space Policy and space sector here in the European Parliament. I want to thank, in particular, the Foreign Affairs Committee for its work on space capabilities for European security and defence that was coordinated by Mr Zdrojewski, with input from Mr Marinescu who represented the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.  I have to say that this debate is timely as we are now preparing the space strategy for Europe that will be presented and adopted in the autumn of this year. This is also timely because these are challenging – but really exciting – times for space in the world and in Europe. Europe is today the second biggest player in space. Space is crucial for security and defence, but it also generates an important spill-over effect in many other sectors, enabling business development, jobs creation and growth. Of course, things are changing as the global context is evolving fast, competition is building up and the market is increasingly driven by the private sector. European companies need a market large enough to sell their products, yet this is not always the case, of course, today. Our strategic assets such as critical technologies components and systems are really crucially important here. Despite its increase, the budget available for space remains small compared to our competitors. We have to face these challenges together. Europe cannot afford to treat it as ‘business as usual’ because competitors and partners are really moving fast. This is why the Commission announced its intention to work towards the new space strategy for Europe, and we intend to be inclusive – involving, of course, the Member States, the European Space Agency, EUMETSAT, the industry and, of course, Parliament. I therefore welcome our debate today and wish to engage more with you over the next month on space issues.  But before I come to the space strategy, let me say just a few words on our European flagship space programmes, Copernicus and Galileo, because they are moving forward. As I commented several months ago, four out of six Copernicus services are fully operational and the community of users is growing. We launched successfully another satellite in April. EGNOS is operational and two weeks ago we had another successful launch for Galileo, which brings the number of satellites in orbit to 14. We really can, and should, be proud of that. Of course, I have to mention the initial services which will start later this year. We hope to launch four more satellites in November. The main challenge now is to work to exploit these achievements for new or better services, products and applications. Space solutions and technologies can have a decisive impact on high political priorities such as climate change, air quality, border management, transport, environment issues and security. Actually, the largest impact may be outside of the space domain, per se. Most of the growth and economic value will come from the commercial downstream uses of space. Market uptake of our programmes is therefore at the heart of this strategy. We will propose measures in that sense. The role of the Commission in the public sector should be as an enabler. We should promote favourable conditions and encourage businesses to develop innovative products and services. Innovation clusters and business incubators will be supported. This will benefit SMEs and, of course, start—ups. We are also looking at how we can use smart financing and synergies among different EU programmes to increase the uptake of space. Our top priority for Copernicus is ensuring fast and easy access to data and services anywhere in Europe, so we envisaged supporting the development of several industry—led platforms, making the most of the available data—processing technologies. We will identify any legislative, administrative and technical barriers that need to be addressed.  On Galileo, together with the GSA, we will continue to make chipsets and receivers Galileo— and EGNOS—compatible and develop the relevant applications. Our intention is to promote the use of EGNOS and Galileo in various sectors, focusing of course on those with the highest potential. But we also need to take a strategic view. Our main objective should be to bring the benefits of space to European society and to the European economy. We need a strategy to address the current and emerging challenges. We need a strategy that covers all the relevant public and private actors in Europe. We want to mainstream the use of space to support public policies, providing effective solutions to the big societal challenges such as – as I said before – climate change, security, migration, and the digital agenda. We want to promote a globally—competitive European space sector that is innovative, agile and entrepreneurial, and create more jobs and, of course, more growth in Europe. We want a space environment that is sustainable and remains accessible, safe and secure.  This is the vision of the strategy that we are working on. We expect it to cover five main areas. First, as already said, we want to maximise the benefits of Galileo and Copernicus. Second, we want to respond to emerging needs – for example, we may consider how space could better contribute to security policy, border surveillance and maritime security. We are also looking into the international developments taking place and how space technology could help our climate change agenda, notably with regard to CO2 emissions. Third, we want to boost the competitiveness of the European space industry throughout research, innovation and the modernisation of the industrial base. That means using opportunities from new business models to encourage greater involvement and risk—sharing by the private sector and a smart financing approach. Fourth, we want to address the strategic aspects and dualist dimension of space. This means supporting the resilience and protection of critical space and ground infrastructure, including in the context of the current space surveillance and tracking framework. We are assessing how we can support Europe’s independent access to space. When talking about security and strategic aspects of space, and similarly to what is said in the report of Mr Zdrojewski, I consider that space based capabilities and services can, and should, play a key role in the context of European security and defence. I particularly note the references in your report to GovSatCom capacities, SST, precise navigation and earth observation. This is also an element discussed in the context of the announced European Defence Action Plan which I am preparing together with Vice—President Katainen.  Finally, we want to strengthen the role and impact of the EU as a global actor. In April, we launch a broad public consultation process open until 12 July, to help us shape the strategy.  To sum up and conclude, I see space as an enabler for solutions to key political priorities and societal challenges, as a vector for growth, enabling new services, new business opportunities in space, as an industrial sector in its own right, which is facing increasing challenges and needs to be supported, and as a strategic asset supporting Europe’s autonomy of action on the global stage. The opportunities offered by space programmes will only be felt if they are used widely by both public and private users. That means stronger and more coordinated efforts at all levels – European, national and local. So we have to work together to bring the benefits of space closer to our citizens.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union has so far been ahead of the curve in space, and it is particularly important that it stays ahead of the curve, given that today the space sector is facing major changes at the international level and this requires a European response to the height of the stakes, which are immense. Indeed, the United States is investing, Russia adopted a new space strategy in 2014, China has started launching communications satellites and India has also understood that it must play today in the court of space powers. The European Union must therefore do everything it can to ensure that it does not get left behind. Access to space is a strategic issue for our political and economic independence. The multitude of space data is not sufficiently exploited and we would benefit from using it more widely by developing a real space market in Europe. To do this, of course, we must provide unwavering support to Galileo and Copernicus, because we need these technical tools to fulfil all our ambitions in this area. We also need, as you said very well, to be prepared for applications in a number of sectors, including the automotive sector, the airline industry and many others. I could also take an example, because the impact of space, the space sector is important in the field of agriculture, I conclude, the environment, but for example we also need a real global strategy because, in the area of COP 21 for example, Mr President, well with space, we will have a real vision of what is happening in our oceans. , also in terms of greenhouse gas emission limits.  That is why, and I conclude, that Europe must be the launching pad for a real global strategy and must remain a great space power, provided it supports its industrial base.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we all see that the security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both within and outside the European Union. It is characterised by terrorists attacks, hybrid wars, mass murder and other challenges to our common security and defence affecting all Member States and to which all Member States of the European Union must respond by adopting a joint strategy and a coordinated response. These security challenges call for the strengthening of the European Union’s security through the continued development and support of the European Union Common Security and Defence Policy, in order to make it a more effective policy instrument and a real guarantee of the safety of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of European norms, interests and values, as enshrined in the Treaty on European Union. Space capabilities in Europe – the satellites – could be used to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants and their roots. In the case of those coming from North Africa, they could be used to identify the ship-boarding areas in order to engage with them faster and save more lives, to improve naval security and to support European Union missions abroad. The European Council of June 2015, which focused on defence, called for the fostering of greater and more systematic European defence cooperation, with a view to delivering key capabilities, including through the coherent and efficient use of EU funds and existing EU capabilities.  Space policy is an essential component of the strategic autonomy which the European Union must develop in order to safeguard sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and independent capabilities needed to carry out assessments. The references to financial implications for further development of the space capabilities in connection with the Common Security and Defence Policy should be maintained, as they are mainly about creating perspectives and not going against the provisions of the Treaty. The European Union/United States cooperation on future space-based capabilities and services for security and defence purposes is, in my opinion, mutually beneficial. Finally, I believe that in the long term the European Union must build its own instruments establishing a defence union in full complementarity with NATO.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by More and more areas of our lives depend on space capabilities – telecommunications, navigation, meteo observation. That is why the union's new space strategy is so important if we are to keep up with the world. In this respect, the development of the space market is also very important.  However, defence capabilities are also linked to space technologies, as the Zdrojewski report mainly refers to. The proliferation of space technologies leads to competition for space resources. Many countries are actively developing anti-satellite technologies, including in the field of orbital weapons, which demonstrates the militarisation of space and the need for European countries to develop space infrastructure defence capabilities.  Mr Zdrojewski's report rightly emphasises the need to develop the European space industry, including in terms of enhancing the defence capabilities of EU countries. This should be done in close cooperation with our allies, because it is right to say a document on the need to coordinate the activities and compatibility of European space capabilities with NATO and the US.  (The President interrupted the speech due to a lack of simultaneous translation into Italian)  However, the Commission's planned measures to support the space industry should reduce the high concentration of space industry. The two companies employ more than half of the staff of the European space industry. The main production capacity is located in six countries – France, Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Spain and Belgium. The Union's space strategy, which was presented in January 2016 by Commissioner Pieńkowska, aims to strengthen the competitiveness of industry. This ambitious objective should take into account the innovation potential of other Member States as well and should support the participation of smaller companies in the Union's space policy.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group – Many people do not realize how our entire daily lives are full of all kinds of applications from space. When I go to Strasbourg and I pack my suitcase, I first look at my weather app to see what kind of clothes I have to bring. We're all sitting here all day watching our mobile devices, on our phones, on the Internet. You can't miss it all anymore.  Did you fly here? Then you've needed it for safe air travel. If you're in the car, you're used to your navigation system. In short, space applications are all around us in our daily lives. We are increasingly dependent on large amounts of data that satellites provide us, whether for collectivity or for navigation or for earth observation. These are all things that can make our daily lives more and more easier and which more and more companies are benefiting from.  I would like to make one appeal to Commissioner Bieńkowska on the space strategy: we need to raise awareness of the flagship programmes we have, both to Galileo and certainly to Copernicus. We need to involve more private companies, because these private entrepreneurs can create the jobs and growth we so desperately need. The government can't do that. But then they have to know that these data are freely accessible and that they can make very nice products with it.  Commissioner Bieńkowska is on the right track, as I have heard now and also last week at the space conference in the context of the Dutch Presidency. I would like to contribute to the fact that we will soon be able to discuss a progressive space strategy, with a lot of influence from the private sector.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Continue with the militarisation of the EU now in space. The report states that EU space capabilities are crucial to all aspects, including genuine warfare. It calls for civil space programmes, research projects and training courses to be designed with a view to security and defence. Then we will again pretend that the two key EU space projects, Galileo and Copernicus, are purely civil in nature. We could also conclude that Galileo was co-financed from the agricultural budget, but not if you read this report. As a reminder, ARTICLE 41(2) of the EU Treaty prohibits the financing of military-related projects. I believe that the EU would do well to comply with the 1967 Space Treaty, which states that activities should only be undertaken – and I quote – for the peaceful exploration and use of space.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I follow the discussion with a laughing eye and a crying eye. The negotiations on the report were very good and very positive and very constructive. We can certainly achieve a great deal in the civil, economic sphere with the EU's space strategy. In my view, it is a sector where it is almost perfectly possible to show how the public sector, how the European Union can support the private sector. On my mobile phone I have 10 or 15 applications where space technology is used, from the software for running to navigation software and so on. This is not just about companies operating in space technology itself, but about small European startups that can use Galileo and Copernicus, which can use data provided by the public sector, which private individuals could not do in this form. We have to do that, we have to invest massively in this, because European industry needs the support of the Commission and of all of us. This is a right move, and what I have heard, what is planned in the next few months, is also worthy of support and is moving in the right direction. However, I was very concerned by the speech by my colleague from the Social Democrats: if satellites and surveillance are only about repelling refugees and controlling refugees, then I believe that something has been fundamentally misunderstood. This technology has good and bad sides; we could use them to save lives – I would have expected a lot more speeches on this now – and we should.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the UK Government is increasing its focus on the UK space sector, and that is a good idea. The UK should use our excellent technological base to develop our space policy and to do it properly, so that the people of the UK can benefit from the innovations that undoubtedly come from this kind of research and development and also – let us be straight, if you do it right – the profits.  However, I am concerned, and I share some of the sentiments some of the other speakers have had about the EU developing its space policy in this manner, particularly when it falls under a defence remit in a certain degree. Maybe the ambitions of this place are so grand that not even this continent will suffice. Maybe the world is not enough. Maybe it needs to go into space. But this is not what the EU should be for. It was supposed to be about trade. Now your ambitions take you into space and you have defence ideas about Star Wars. Well on that theme, fortunately for us in the UK, on 23 June we have the opportunity for Darth Juncker’s Death Star to be finished off by Nigel Skywalker and the Rebel Alliance. I will be doing my very best to make sure that the correct side wins through on that and that UK space technology is dealt with in the UK.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am outraged by this first-class burial which you reserve for the ambitions of space independence that France has carried in Europe, including within the Space Agency. I find in this propaganda report a concentration of propaganda and submission, which are often the debates of this Parliament. Submission, when you want to grant our space ambition to NATO and the United States. Even if you also talk about European independence, you are not misleading anyone. The ambition for independence is an all-out independence, outside of NATO, therefore. Propaganda, when you talk about hybrid warfare to increase the pressure for the Warsaw Summit, where a whiff of war against Russia will float on the corpse of a great independent Europe for a multipolar world of peace. So, I say solemnly, France will carry its space ambitions with the States that will want to remain free in the future, far from a subservient Europe.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I appreciated your speech, especially for the commitments you have made for the future. Industrial and space policy is fundamental to the growth of our Union. This is a sector that is and will be instrumental in achieving the target of 20% of gross domestic product from manufacturing by 2020. We need only think of satellite navigation, the saving of the Earth, areas with enormous potential for growth and new jobs, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, which are then the real backbone of our economy. I would like to highlight three issues. Firstly, we need an extension of the financial instruments available, perhaps using Horizon 2020 and COSME more, it would be a mistake to reduce investment in space. Secondly, cooperation between the European Commission, the European Space Agency, the national authorities and the Galileo agency must be strengthened and the institutional apparatus must also be simplified. Thirdly, we need to speed up the process of making Galileo operational. I hope that we can really start at the end of 2016 for partial services and in 2020 for full operational capacity. We are all convinced that space services will be able to provide fundamental services. Galileo, EGNOS and Copernicus also demonstrate the Union's ability to manage major financial projects. Commissioner, I believe that, if you go down the road you have indicated, you will find the support of the vast majority of this Parliament. So you will be able to count on us if you go ahead and keep the commitments you have made to MEMBERS of the European Parliament this evening.

name: Constanze Krehl (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The texts we are discussing today once again confirm the ever-increasing relevance of the issue of space in the European Union. Security plays an important role in this. I particularly welcome the fact that the report by the AFET Committee does not only refer to security and defence in the classical sense, but also emphasises the dangers posed by space debris or collisions of objects in space. Preventing accidents will be a major challenge in the medium term, especially as traffic in space continues to grow. And on Earth, too, security has many aspects. For example, Earth observation from space can help us observe climate change and respond faster and better to natural disasters. However, while the issues of security and defence must be taken into account in the EU's space programmes, there is no doubt that the programmes are civil and must remain civil. Our goal is to explore space and use it for existing and yet to be developed technologies. This is also a great opportunity for our businesses in the European Union. In this area, we should work in particular to ensure that more small and medium-sized enterprises with innovative ideas take action in this area. Technological advances have also made it easier for us to better evaluate and use the data we receive from Copernicus, among others. Here, however, we are not yet fully exploiting our potential. In our resolution, we make it clear that platforms must be created that allow the optimal use of big data and are easily and freely accessible to the widest possible range of users, particularly from academia.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, if there is a clear need for cooperation at EU level, it is precisely in the area of space projects. I had the honour of coordinating the resolution on market penetration in space. I would like to thank my colleagues from the other political groups who have been involved in its preparation.  The European Union is investing a great deal of effort and funding in the infrastructure of the Galileo and Copernicus projects. I believe both systems will be completed quickly. But it seems to be neglecting a little of the huge potential that the space data market holds for innovation, growth, jobs, and many other areas.  Our resolution identifies technical and market barriers. For example, the Commission must better ensure the use of Galileo and Copernicus projects in the European Union's programmes and policies. We need platforms for clear access to data. We need to help our start-ups and SMEs break through the market with their applications and services. It is also important to speed up the production of chipsets for Galileo. Personally, I would underline the synergies between the two programs – whether they are integrated applications or marketing activities. The already functioning Galileo security system is also essential. I trust that our recommendations will be reflected in the commission's forthcoming space strategy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European space sector may or may not be of great use to society. It all depends on how we guide it. Whether we want you to serve us or if this is just a war movie. The Galileo and Copernicus systems oriented towards civilian use are useful for air safety, GPS navigation or more effective action in the face of possible disasters. But the objectives of this report have a two-sided view: military security and defence policy, border control against refugees, etc.  The use of these programmes to locate refugee entry zones can be found; but people are saved on earth, with safe access roads for refugees. I am alarmed that anyone who has referred to migration from the Socialist Group has ignored this. Let us do things right and do not resort to fear and the militarization of space, which is the opposite of science and knowledge.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I congratulate the rapporteur and the opinion-makers of the ITRE Committee. I would also like to congratulate the Commissioner for his words on this future space strategy and defence action plan. We are talking in the European Parliament before the Commission creates this strategy, because we wanted to have a positive impact on the Commission's actions.  Most of us speak in the same spirit, in the same tone. This is important, Commissioner. We are urging a very ambitious programme. Such an ambitious programme the European Parliament is, of course, not everyone, as usual in a democracy, able to support it. We are talking about many things, most about the use of space technologies. This is important, but even more important is the technological advantage that has always been gained by countries that have been at the fore front in space technologies. This technological advantage lasts differently, even three or four decades. This is the perspective we think about if we invest in good, state-of-the-art space technologies. We believe in the European Parliament, at least in the ITRE Committee, that spending on an ambitious space policy is not just expenditure. These are investments for decades. Once again, ambitions cost money, but lack thereof would cost us much more. It will increase our dependence on others, reduce safety, expose us to wasting the potential of our industry, contribute to the brain drain. So we encourage an ambitious programme.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there is no doubt that we are at a crucial moment in defining a forward-looking European space strategy, which will maximise the social, employment, economic, scientific and technological benefits of space investment in the European Union. A strategy that must be able to guarantee Europe, in the short and long term, independent access to space and a dominant position in global markets in the field of space technologies and services. A great many of these cases have been mentioned. This will only be possible with consistent and massive support for galileo and copernicus space research and programmes. It should be remembered that the technologies developed in the context of space research have added value in many other areas. Reference has already been made to transport, agriculture, humanitarian aid, climate and energy, but we could talk about all the science on materials, electronics and astronomy. The space industry is undergoing profound changes, mainly due to technological innovations that create opportunities for citizens and renewed interest in space by the public and private sectors. That is why it is essential to identify possible technical and legislative obstacles and to focus on establishing a coherent and stable regulatory framework to facilitate the commercialisation of space data-based services. It is also necessary to give adequate support to the European space industry – I agree here with my colleague Mr Tajani – to support entrepreneurship and to promote internationalisation. I am thinking of the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Zdrojewski's report is a good crescendo for the already existing interest in the European Parliament, in particular in the SEDE and ITRE, and for the activities of the European Commission. I hope that the visit recently made by the SEDE delegation to Noordwijk at the Headquarters of the European Space Agency has also contributed to the quality of this report. For Polish, European space policy is very important. I wanted to highlight projects such as the Satellite Earth Observation Satellite Programme and the PRS signal programme for Galileo. I just hope that in the future the satellites will be launched into earth orbit autonomously. I compliment this part of the report, which also applies to transatlantic cooperation.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – The European Space Policy directly affects people in Europe. We are talking about a high-tech sector that creates many jobs, billions in annual turnover and numerous business opportunities for applications applied in everyday life, both in telecommunications, navigation, media, transport, meteorology and others. We need to identify how the uptake of space data can support the economic growth of our Union by focusing on the benefits of space related to the digital single market and capital markets, synergies with the European Structural and Investment Funds. On the other hand, European space policy must be an integral part of our security policy. The exchange of information and space data forms part of the response to global security challenges, including the fight against terrorism. A common space policy will help to achieve Europe's leadership by developing independent technologies and missions, services and applications in other areas beyond economic and security.  Little is known about the fact that, for example, Bulgaria occupies a worthy place among the countries with a space program. It is the third country after the United States and Russia, which produces ready meals for space crews, has its own cosmonaut and is the eighteenth country with its own satellite. In this regard, the efforts of each Member State, regardless of the size of the country, are important to ensure the improvement of geopolitical stability through international cooperation, awareness and transparency, as well as to increase the contribution of space to European defence and security policy.

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: – The European Union's space policy is crucial for economic growth and the development of societies. It has a direct impact on citizens' daily lives, for example weather forecasts are based on data generated by the space industry. Such activities are a driver of innovation and competitiveness, especially in the area of the so-called sharing economy. The data generated by the space industry is crucial for its development. Take, for example, self-driving cars. For this project, it is necessary to improve land mapping and satellite navigation techniques, which are respectively the objectives of the EU's Copernicus and Galileo programmes.  In the context of the challenges ahead, closer coordination of the European Union's space policy is needed. Number of stakeholders: Member States, the European Space Agency and the EU itself make it difficult to optimise decision-making and reduces the effectiveness of implementation of decisions taken. The main objective of the Union should be to ensure better coordination between the different actors and a more effective management of public resources. In this context, we should mention the funding structure of the Union's space policy, which focuses on the development of existing programmes.  Apart from completely new initiatives, the Union excludes the possibility of active participation by the new Member States, which are just taking their first steps in space policy. I would therefore like to ask how the European Commission intends to encourage the new Member States to participate more actively in the Union's space programmes?

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I say to you as Vice-President of the Sky and Space Intergroup, we must fight above all for our independence of access to space. It is essential for us to maintain full control of our own growth, but it is under threat. To succeed, we must be firm, pragmatic and innovative. Firm in our intentions: the industry needs public orders for it. Are we ready to schedule the sequel to Galileo and Copernicus? The national preference for institutional orders and fire is the global norm, except in Europe. Why not impose the European preference? Are we so afraid of it? Citizens need a public power that invests in its existing infrastructure, such as Kourou.  Will Europe finally fulfil its role in financing the firing range and the connection to the new transatlantic cable? To require a strategic and visionary Commission is to be realistic, because our customers today will be our competitors of tomorrow: India, very soon, and perhaps after Indonesia, or even Saudi Arabia. So we absolutely have to innovate to stand out. Ariane 6: Are the Commission and the States ready to ensure the three to five annual institutional fires necessary for the programme to be profitable? The issue is still pending. Regarding reusable launchers, CNES has just announced a research partnership with Japan. This is good news, but Europe is lagging far behind these major innovations. Does the Commission have a strategy? Here's the set... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker.)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Union must stop treating space with the same ideas as the other areas of joint action. First of all, space policy involves research, i.e. the development of human resources. Funds should be given to support scientists in this field in all countries. It is unfair for Greek astrophysicists to migrate to Western Europe because they do not have the infrastructure to proceed with their research in Greece.  Space cannot today be treated simply as another market for private investors. That would be irresponsible. Space decisions directly affect the security of countries but may also have long-term effects on the natural environment. It is therefore not possible to make space a market like any other. Space technologies have added value for many sectors such as telecommunications and transport. The European Union must work in the field of space not only with the US and Japan but also with other space powers, such as Russia, India and China, in order to have even greater results in cutting-edge space technology, which must finally be put at the service of humanity.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we have always advocated a space policy based on deepening cooperation between European countries and not only.  With complete clarity, we have always said that this space policy should focus solely on peaceful purposes and permanently exclude any use of space for military purposes.  Criticism of the militarisation of space and the renunciation of any arms race in space was a position that the majority of this Parliament has never taken. On the contrary, this militarization is explicitly assumed and defended, as it happens here today, while we are being told about the development of the space market.  It is revealing of the way the European Union looks into space and is also dangerous. The endless adventure of mankind for the discovery of this great book continually open, of which Galileo spoke to us, cannot serve to prolong on earth the wicked, aggressive and oppressive order that some have been imposing.  On the contrary, it should help us solve problems, not create problems. An adventure to free not to oppress.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly I really want to thank the House for all your interventions, for all your remarks. This is valuable for us because, as was said, we are just in the process of preparing the space strategy, the first such European strategy. I want also to say at the very beginning that it is extremely important also for those Member States that are just starting space activities. I am really trying to engage with those Member States, with all of them.  Last week, we had an informal EU ESA Council meeting in Den Haag because all the European Member States, both those who are ESA members and those who are not, have to be included in our work – all the stakeholders. Of course I do not want to make governance the first major topic of the strategy, but we do have to design the governance and the whole work of the strategy in a very smart way because space is really a strategic asset for Europe. It is a strategic industrial sector.  Many here were discussing the link between space and defence policy. I can commit here because I am in charge of both strategies, so this is a space strategy but also for the defence action plan. I can commit that I will be very attentive to this dimension, even more so because 2016 is a very central year for European defence. We will have a global strategy, and then a defence action plan. They will be the two key milestones to increase cooperation and defence at European level and between the Member States also. We will be focusing very much on cooperation in research, in defence, cooperation on industrial projects, which is very important, and stronger coherence of capability needs. I agree also with those who call for action in order to ensure autonomous access to space. I think that without such an access there is no space strategy in Europe.  I want very much also to underline the ambition of the strategy. We want and will be ambitious. This will be an ambitious strategy but I can only echo Jerzy Buzek who said that the lack of ambition will cost us more. I also want to turn your attention to the fact that the ambition of the strategy means also ambition on the means we can allocate to space. We have started to discuss this but I really count on your support in this regard because especially now and in the next few years, it will be extremely important. If all of us call for an ambitious strategy then we will have ambitious means for it.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! During the debates, I have collected a lot of compliments for this report, for which I would like to thank you very warmly. It's enjoying. However, I will say right away – not quite, because on this occasion there is still a need to both promote and inform about what space technologies are. So we have a lot of work ahead of us. Thank you for the speeches by Mr Tajani, Mrs Grossetête, Mr Jerzy Buzek, Mrs Anna Fotygi, because they show concern for this common, strong, modern, creative Europe. I would like to thank Anna Fotydze in particular, because it was she in the SEDE committee who launched the procedure for this report, which was also very important to me.  I would also like to respond to Mr Schaffhauser, but he is not there, so I will congratulate Mrs Grossetête, because what France is doing when it comes to space technology deserves special recognition and, I must say, it is a great, gigantic effort. And the fact that France is now also spreading this effort to other countries, much less advanced, deserves respect and can be a source of pride, not attack, as has just happened.  Lastly, mrs Lösing, who is not there either, there is no war, no military, no militarisation. The concept of safety, on the other hand, concerns many elements – the movement of an ambulance on the road, the search for a missing tourist, the search for a ship, the response to various threats that are related to industrial disasters. And we must remember that when we talk about safety, we are sensitive to the fate of every individual. We will also stress in all our space capabilities that the system being built – not by a single country, but by the whole of Europe – is to lay the foundations, the foundation of a strong, modern, future-strong Europe that will also be economically strong. Once again, I would like to thank everyone sincerely.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 8 June 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In their civilian use, programs that develop space technologies have become of great economic importance. This report further shows that such technologies can become fundamental in ensuring safety. Preventing attacks and attacks on European citizens must be a priority, both for the European Union and for each of the countries that make up it. For this reason, all countries of the Union must work together to ensure that such programmes which seek to ensure security and defence are successfully developed. As an initiative that will benefit, in the end, all citizens, I hope that it will have the necessary support for its approval.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – Space politics developed in the context of the Cold War, when the United States and the Soviet Union began the conquest of outer space, engaging in a space race. Of course, over the past 70 years the global, political and technological landscape has undergone fundamental changes. Today, space policy means strategic opportunities in key areas such as telecommunications, transport and energy, surveillance of weather and climate events and, last but not least, security.  But European space policy must be understood in a much broader geopolitical context. The EU does not yet have the profile of an important player in the field, although sustained efforts have been made in this regard since the early 2000s. On the other hand, it is not desirable for the EU through its space policy to cause unexpected developments or global risks. In this context, the boundary between risk and opportunity is very fine and it must be rigorously analysed.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – While it is important to future-proof our security and defence strategies in the field of space capabilities, we must not forget to secure ourselves in terms of more basic necessities such as energy. Before relocating into space we must first make sure everything is in order at home. Energy security has to be a core priority for the EU. A reliable supply of energy will ensure not only our survival but also our ability to conduct research and innovate in the field of security and defence. We should not increase our dependency on Russian gas by doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline. Doing so would be extremely detrimental to our energy security since Russia has demonstrated on countless occasions that it is not a reliable partner for the European Union and that it does not hesitate to use energy as a political weapon. The solution to our current predicament lies in creating more effective energy interconnections within the EU, as well as diversifying our sources of supply.
